site_title: Apple supplier Foxlink unlikely to resume full India operations for two months: source
summary: Foxlink, an Apple supplier, is unlikely to resume full operations for two months after a massive fire engulfed its factory in India's Andhra Pradesh state. The fire led to part of the building collapsing and damaged four of the facility's 10 assembly lines. Six assembly lines will resume operations later this week due to damage to IT servers. The incident raises concerns of supply chain disruptions for Apple, particularly for iPhones made or shipped from India. The root cause of the incident is still being investigated.

site_title: German prosecutors raid homes of HSBC employees over tax fraud scam
summary: German prosecutors raided the homes of 16 HSBC employees as part of a probe into the Cum-Ex tax dividend scandal, a trading strategy that siphoned off billions of euros in government revenue. The searches, which started on Tuesday, are part of an investigation into over 1,500 people and target institutions including BNP Paribas and Bank of America's Merrill Lynch. The scandal, which began in 2012, is expected to continue to roil the financial industry as prosecutors step up pressure on international banks.

site_title: Land betterment charge rates for non-landed residential use raised by 0.3% on average
summary: The Singapore government has announced moderate increases in land betterment charge (LBC) rates for non-landed and landed residential uses, as well as for hotel use, reflecting current flat land values and cautious property investment sentiment. Non-landed residential LBC rates rose by an average of 0.3% for the next half year, while landed residential rates increased by 0.4% and hotel/hospital rates by 1%. LBC rates for commercial and industrial use groups remain unchanged.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
piximage

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on sticky inflation fears, but still end Feb higher
summary: European shares slipped 0.3% on Tuesday, despite ending their second straight month higher, due to sticky inflation fears. Data from France and Spain showed 12-month inflation rates of 7.2% and 6.1%, respectively, pushing investors to expect higher interest rates from the European Central Bank. Banking stocks rose 1.4%, supporting the Stoxx 600 index, which still logged a 1.7% gain for February, its fourth positive month in five.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.7 per cent lower at 32,656.70 on Tuesday.

site_title: Venture Corp CFO resigns, company looking for replacement
summary: Venture Corporation's CFO, William Ng, has resigned for "personal reasons" and will leave on April 30. The company is seeking a replacement and has appointed Anthea Ng, current group finance director, to manage the CFO's duties in the interim. An announcement on the new CFO will be made when a suitable candidate is appointed. Ng's last day of service is April 30, and shares of Venture Corporation fell 0.6% on the news.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Venture Corporation has made investment in advanced manufacturing systems and automation to drive efficiency, productivity and value creation.##########jltech18##########

site_title: How the titans of tech investing are staying warm over the VC winter
summary: Key VC investors, known as "whales," are rethinking their strategies amid a VC winter caused by the tech crash in 2022. The world's biggest investors in innovation have been striking a more humble tone, shifting focus and reducing investments. The VC giants' newfound contrition comes on the back of a gigantic tech crash, with the Nasdaq index falling by a third in 2022. The downturn has spooked the VC funds' main sources of capital, their limited partners, leading to a chilling effect on the business of investing in startups.

images.alt_text: Venture capital funding has flowed away from Series C startups to earlier stages in 2022, as total investment amount in South-east Asia declined compared to 2021.
Founded in 2019, the fund raised US$400 million for deals that year.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q4 net profit falls 58% despite higher revenue
summary: IHH Healthcare reported a 58% decline in Q4 net profit to RM191.3 million due to an impairment loss of RM305.9 million in China and higher net financing costs. Despite this, revenue rose 9% to RM4.9 billion, driven by a recovery in foreign patient volume in Malaysia and Singapore. The company expects inpatient revenue to grow in a post-Covid world and remains confident of its long-term growth trajectory. A first and final dividend of RM0.07 per share was declared, a 17% increase from FY21.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Kevin Loh, managing director and chief executive of IHH Healthcare, notes that the group is taking steps to ensure its operations can cater for demand in its core business.
The sudden resignation of Dr Loh as managing director of IHH Healthcare has surprised the market

site_title: Hong Kong’s HKBN to get US$1 billion buyout offer from HGC, sources say
summary: Hong Kong telecommunications provider HKBN has received a takeover offer from HGC Global Communications valued at over $1 billion. The offer comes after a sale was put on hold last year due to concerns over valuation amid market volatility. HKBN's major shareholders include buyout firms TPG and MBK Partners. Deliberations are ongoing and might not lead to a transaction, with potential interest from Chinese companies or funds backed by the government also being considered.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as consumer confidence data disappoints
summary: US stocks declined on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.7% to 32,656.70. Consumer confidence data disappointed, with a drop in February, despite expectations of a rebound. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury note also edged lower, providing a favorable development for stocks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index followed suit, dipping 0.3% and 0.1% respectively. Individual stocks, such as Target, which topped earnings estimates, were a rare bright spot.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 17, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: EIB urges members to boost green finance to compete with US
summary: The European Investment Bank (EIB) has urged EU member states to boost green finance to compete with the US, particularly with the US$500 billion in spending and tax credits under the Inflation Reduction Act. The EIB, which has already financed a record 19.4 billion euros in green energy last year, is calling for a 50% increase in its RePowerEU initiative to 45 billion euros, aiming to mobilize 150 billion euros over five years. This move aims to strengthen Europe's competitiveness and climate change action, while also addressing inflation concerns in member states.

images.alt_text: In December, EIB announced that a 120 million euros loan will go towards the construction and operation of Repsol’s first advanced biofuels plant that will use food waste, such as cooking oils, to produce fuels for transport.
The green transition presents both a challenge and an opportunity.

site_title: Wee Cho Yaw to step down from UOI board, Wee Ee Cheong to succeed as chairman
summary: Wee Cho Yaw, co-founder of United Overseas Insurance (UOI), will step down as chairman on April 14, with his son Wee Ee Cheong taking over as chairman. Hwang Soo Jin will also step down, and new directors Winston Ngan and Leong Yung Chee will join the board on March 1. UOI managing director and CEO David Chan will retire on March 31, with Andrew Lim succeeding him as CEO on April 1. Wee Cho Yaw and Hwang will be designated chairman emeritus and director emeritus, respectively.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Credit Suisse ‘seriously breached’ obligations in Greensill case
summary: Credit Suisse has been found to have "seriously breached" its risk-management obligations in the Greensill Capital supply-chain financing affair, according to Switzerland's banking regulator Finma. The bank must take remedial measures, including a periodic review of key business relationships and a "responsibility document" for its 600 highest-ranking employees. The investigation also targets four former Credit Suisse managers. The bank's CEO welcomed the conclusion, citing strengthened risk and compliance culture. Credit Suisse froze and wound down a US$10 billion group of funds linked to Greensill Capital.

site_title: Microsoft adds new Bing to Windows computers in effort to roll out AI
summary: Microsoft is adding its new Bing search engine to its Windows operating system, aiming to integrate artificial intelligence (AI) into its desktop computers' search box. The new Bing, which is still in preview mode, will be accessible to over 1 million users in 169 countries. The update also includes software that can connect to iPhone messages and calls. Microsoft is moving to gain market share from Google with its AI-powered chatbot. The company has gathered feedback on the new Bing and is refining its AI chatbot to prevent provocative responses.

site_title: Germany in talks to merge power grids through buyouts
summary: Germany's government is accelerating efforts to merge four high-voltage grid operators to modernize power lines and secure affordable power amid the worst energy crisis in decades. Chancellor Olaf Scholz's cabinet is in talks with the Dutch government to pay over 20 billion euros for TenneT Holding, and negotiations with rival operators 50Hertz Transmission, TransnetBW, and Amprion are underway. The goal is to form a single unit, with the potential to create a private network investment company and reduce dependence on fossil fuels by 2045.

images.alt_text: The chemical company will close a number of factories, including two ammonia plants and related fertiliser facilities.
German consumer prices, harmonised to compare with other European Union countries, rose by 9.2 per cent on the year in January.
Germany’s solar industry has waned from its peak about a decade ago, when a wave of insolvencies purged many companies that had been set up with state subsidies.

Labour union Verdi called on workers from Germany's major airports to strike on Friday (Feb 17). The union is demanding a pay increase of 500 euros (S$713) a month for some workers, and higher holiday-shift compensation for others.

U.S. President Joe Biden and Polish President Andrzej Duda and Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki walk during a bilateral meeting to discuss collective efforts to support Ukraine and bolster NATO's deterrence at the Presidential Palace in Warsaw, Poland, February 21, 2023.
