site_title: Chevron boosts annual share buyback rate to US$17.5 billion
summary: Chevron boosts its annual share buyback rate to $17.5 billion, up from $15 billion, to show confidence in its cash-generation goals despite declining crude prices. The company aims to increase annual production by 3% by 2027, with a focus on the Permian Basin, to sustain shareholder payouts. Chevron's stock climbed 1.3% in premarket trading after the announcement, which comes amid criticism from US President Joe Biden for excessive spending on buybacks.

images.alt_text: Adjusted 2022 earnings more than doubled to US$36.5 billion from a year earlier, while oil and natural gas output from the company’s US fields climbed almost 4 per cent to the equivalent of 1.181 million barrels a day.

site_title: Hot stock: Samudera Shipping Line falls 8.2% to S$1.23 despite H2 profit gains
summary: Samudera Shipping Line's shares fell 8.2% to S$1.23 despite posting a 60% increase in net profit for the second half year to US$150.3 million. The company's full-year net profit rose 150.5% to US$322 million. A special dividend per share of S$0.2425 was proposed, higher than the previous year's S$0.1275.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Apple faces EU charge over App Store rules as regulators narrow case
summary: The European Union's antitrust regulators have narrowed their case against Apple, dropping a charge that Apple's App Store rules, which require developers to use its own in-app payment system, violate EU rules against unfair trading conditions. The EU found that Apple's "anti-steering obligations" for developers are not necessary or proportionate and are detrimental to users of music streaming services on Apple devices. Apple stated it was pleased the case had been narrowed and would respond to the regulator's concerns.

images.alt_text: The facility in India’s Andhra Pradesh state, where Foxlink makes charging cables for iPhones, was engulfed in a massive fire on Monday that led part of the building to collapse to the ground.

The FAS determined in August 2020 that Apple had abused its dominant position, then issued a directive requiring Apple to remove provisions giving it the right to reject third-party apps from its App Store.

site_title: US dollar heading for first monthly gain since September
summary: The US dollar is on track for its first monthly gain since September, driven by rising interest rate expectations and a strong rally against the Japanese yen. The US dollar index was flat at 104.7, but still set for a 2.5% gain in February, marking its first monthly increase since September. This uptrend is attributed to upbeat economic data and mounting expectations for the US Federal Reserve to raise interest rates more than initially expected.

site_title: Xi preps China for ‘intensified’ overhaul of government agencies
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to unveil a "relatively intensified" overhaul of government agencies, with reforms focusing on key industries and sectors, during his new term at the National People's Congress. The changes, designed to address high-stakes difficulties and challenges, aim to strengthen Xi's grip on the economy and bring policymaking power under his control. The restructuring plan is expected to have significant implications for China's economic and social development, with potential changes including reviving the Central Financial Work Commission and appointing Li Qiang as premier.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese President Xi Jinping waves after his speech as the new Politburo Standing Committee members meet the media following the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China October 23, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: US consumer confidence drops on more pessimistic outlook
summary: US consumer confidence unexpectedly dropped in February, falling to 102.9 from 106 in January, according to the Conference Board. The decline was driven by rising prices and concerns about the outlook, outweighing near-term labor market strength. Expectations for the next six months decreased to 69.7, the lowest since July, while current conditions rose to 152.8. This marks a reversal from the median forecast of 108.5.

images.alt_text: Exports of goods shot up 4.2 per cent to US$173.8 billion, boosted by a 14.8 per cent jump in consumer goods.

site_title: US housing cools further, with prices down 2.7% from June peak
summary: US housing prices declined 2.7% from their June peak, marking a sixth consecutive month of decrease. This drop was largely attributed to easing competition in the market, giving home shoppers more leverage in negotiations with sellers. The national home prices fell 0.3% in December from the previous month, according to S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller data. The decline in home prices was partly due to the pullback of buyers in 2022, following mortgage rate increases and record-high prices during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Home sales dropped last year amid rising interest rates and prices cooled from pandemic-fuelled highs.

site_title: Indian banks unprepared for central bank’s ESG push: survey
summary: Indian banks are unprepared to adopt environmental, social and governance (ESG) norms, citing lack of clarity on how such rules apply to lenders. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) may use a recent survey's findings to issue guidelines to boost green finance later this year. Globally, ESG-based lending has surged to $322 billion in 2021, accounting for 12% of total lending. The RBI's acknowledgment of climate change as a financial risk is driving the push for green finance guidelines.

images.alt_text: Governor Ron Desantis, seen here at his midterms election victory celebration in Tampa on Nov 8, 2022, is the unofficial leader of the conservative war against ESG.

site_title: UK food inflation hits ‘record’: survey
summary: UK food-price inflation has reached a record peak of 17.1% in the four weeks to Feb 19, according to a survey by Kantar. This is the highest increase recorded by the data provider since it began tracking costs in 2008. Grocery prices are the second biggest financial issue for Britons, after rising energy costs, highlighting the ongoing cost-of-living crisis.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England said this month that Britain’s weak productivity growth means the economy can probably only grow by about 0.7 per cent a year in 2024 and 2025 without generating inflationary heat.
House prices have soared by more than a quarter during the Covid-19 pandemic, but the boom has now gone into reverse.

site_title: China charges ex-Merchants Bank president over ‘huge’ bribes
summary: China's Supreme People's Procuratorate charged former Merchants Bank president Tian Huiyu over suspected bribery, insider trading, and abuse of power. Tian, 57, will be prosecuted after an investigation found he took "huge" bribes in exchange for loan approvals and project undertakings. The charges come as Beijing steps up efforts to clean up the $60 trillion financial system and prevent systemic risks. Tian's arrest and expulsion from the Communist Party in October led to a 30% decline in Merchants Bank shares in Hong Kong and Shanghai.

site_title: Tesla’s China sales slow as price-cut boost wanes
summary: Tesla's electric vehicle sales in China rose last week but fell short of the fourth quarter pace, indicating the price-cut boost is waning. The company's weekly retail sales increased to 10,703 vehicles, but year-to-date average daily sales were 1,016, down from 1,317 in October and November. Analysts attribute the slowdown to an ageing product line and consumers delaying purchases to see if other EV makers cut prices. Despite this, Tesla aims to grow exports and expand into new markets to maintain its lead.

images.alt_text: In a proposed class action filed in San Francisco federal court, shareholders said Tesla defrauded them over four years with false and misleading statements that concealed how its technologies, suspected as a possible cause of multiple fatal crashes, “created a serious risk of accident and injury.”

site_title: Heartland enterprises get space to test innovative ideas under new programme
summary: Singapore has launched the Heartland Innovation and Transformation (HIT) Programme, providing modular temporary spaces in mature heartland precincts for enterprises to test new business ideas. The 12-month programme, starting in the second half of 2023, aims to boost revenue and attract footfall to heartland shops. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling said the innovation will enhance the heartland economy.

images.alt_text: New S$70m scheme for eateries, retailers; S$50m campaign for heartland shops
Shoppers participating in a hawker-themed gameshow organised as part of this year's Heartlands Festival.

The Committee Against Profiteering is prepared to publicly highlight “egregious businesses” that use the goods and services tax (GST) increase as an excuse to raise prices unjustifiably, said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling on Monday (Jan 9).

site_title: At the home of Zara, fast and slow fashion collide
summary: In Spain's A Coruna, two contrasting fashion business models collide, with Inditex, the world's largest fast-fashion retailer, facing pressure to become more sustainable. The EU has pledged to make all clothes sold in the bloc "long-lived and recyclable" by 2030. Inditex is changing its processes to reduce environmental impact, using recycled materials and cutting water, energy, and raw material usage. Meanwhile, smaller boutiques in A Coruna are adopting more sustainable practices, such as producing limited collections and encouraging conscientious shopping. The EU aims to recycle 10% of annual textile production by 2030.

images.alt_text: None of the 11 pairs of footwear donated by Reuters were turned into exercise paths or kids’ parks in Singapore.

site_title: Medtecs posts FY22 loss of US$28.5 million amid lower PPE, face masks sales
summary: Medtecs International posted a net loss of US$28.5 million for FY22, down from a net profit of US$17.3 million in FY21, due to lower demand for its PPE and face masks. Revenue fell 60.5% to US$56.9 million, with segmental declines in original product manufacturing (69.5%) and hospital services (4.4%). The company attributed the decline to global trends and easing of Covid-19 prevention measures. Medtecs plans to enhance supply chain management, improve forecasting, and work closely with suppliers to respond to changes in demand.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Catalist-listed Medtecs gains as much as 19.4 per cent, while Top Glove rises 5.9 per cent.
Medtecs International last announced the opening of its US$20m glove manufacturing facility in Cambodia on Sept 30.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as Treasury yields rise
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 15.62 points (0.05%) to 32,873.47, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The decline was attributed to rising Treasury yields, which signaled more interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: Singapore hotels’ average room rate slips to five-month low in January; still higher on the year
summary: Singapore hotels experienced a 5-month low in average room rates in January, reaching S$248.91, down 4.3% from December's 14-year high of S$286.21. Despite this, the average room rate (ARR) still increased by 53% from the same period last year to S$273.94. This marks the lowest ARR since August 2022.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
While on the month, ARR was up in December, overall room revenues, RevPAR and average occupancy rate were lower.
January’s arrival numbers nudges up slightly from the 931,337 visitors recorded in the previous month.

site_title: Vietnam factory output up in February despite drop in smartphone production
summary: Vietnam's industrial output and exports rose in February, driven by higher footwear sales, indicating recovering global demand. However, smartphone production fell 9.8% and cellphone parts production dropped 14.7% despite a 14.7% increase in smartphone exports. The country's exports rose 11% in February to $25.88 billion, while industrial output increased 3.6% and trade surplus reached $2.3 billion.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's property crisis started last year, after officials issued a crackdown on corporate bond issuance following allegations of illegal activities.
Vietnam posted a US$116 billion trade surplus with the United States last year, led by shipments of goods such as electronics, clothing and footwear.

site_title: India’s Adani to repay up to US$790 million share-backed loans by March: sources
summary: The Adani Group plans to repay or prepay share-backed loans worth $690 million to $790 million by March-end, aiming to burnish its credit profile after a short-seller attack. The conglomerate is also seeking to refinance its 2024 bonds via an $800 million, three-year credit line. This move comes amid a regulatory probe and share price falls, as the group holds a fixed-income roadshow in Singapore and Hong Kong to shore up investor confidence. The plans were presented to bondholders in Hong Kong on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on one of its buildings in Ahmedabad, India, January  27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave

site_title: Thailand hosts war games with biggest US attendance in decade
summary: Thailand has hosted the largest Cobra Gold military exercise in a decade, with over 7,000 military personnel from countries including the US, Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, Japan, and South Korea participating. The exercise, which runs from Feb 28 to March 10, marks a significant development in US-Thai security ties, with the US sending its largest delegation in a decade. The move is seen as a response to China's growing influence in the region and Washington's efforts to balance its values and interests.

images.alt_text: Soldiers attend the opening ceremony of Cobra Gold, Asia's largest annual multilateral military exercise, at U-Tapao International airport, Rayong province, Thailand, February 27, 2023. REUTERS/Jiraporn Kuhakan

site_title: Keppel O&M chief Chris Ong appointed CEO of combined O&M entity
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) CEO Chris Ong will become the CEO of the combined Sembcorp Marine entity, following the successful merger between the two companies. The merger closed on February 28, with Keppel O&M becoming a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sembmarine. The new entity will have a board consisting of Mark Gainsborough as chairman and Yap Chee Keong as deputy chairman. The total issued share capital of Sembmarine has increased to 68.2 billion shares, with Keppel O&M consideration shares representing 54% of the total.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: Weight-loss drug trend on TikTok worries doctors
summary: A weight-loss drug trend on TikTok, fueled by the hashtag #Ozempic, has raised concerns among doctors due to its soaring popularity and global shortages. The diabetes medication has been touted for its weight-loss properties, with users claiming to have lost significant amounts of weight in a short period. However, doctors warn of potential side effects and global shortages, highlighting the need for caution and responsible use of the medication.

images.alt_text: With more than one billion active users, TikTok is the sixth most used social platform in the world, according to the We Are Social marketing agency.

site_title: China Aviation Oil H2 net profit falls 13.6% to US$13.9 million
summary: China Aviation Oil reported a 13.6% fall in H2 net profit to US$13.9 million due to a 7.6% decrease in gross profit and increased expenses. The company proposed a final dividend of 1.60 Singapore cents per share, down from 1.90 cents in FY2021.

images.alt_text: China Aviation Oil's (CAO) into-plane refuelling operations at Hong Kong International Airport.

site_title: Is shipping setting the right course for net zero?
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has submitted a revised proposal to the International Maritime Organization (IMO) for a "Fund and Reward" (F&R) system to achieve 2050 net-zero carbon goals for shipping. The F&R mechanism would require ships to pay a mandatory contribution per tonne of CO2 emitted into an IMO fund, rewarding the use of alternative fuels and sustainable practices. The fund would also support the production of alternative marine fuels in developing countries. However, critics argue that the system could lead to a global taxation bureaucracy and logistical challenges, raising concerns about its feasibility and fairness.

images.alt_text: A year's worth of washed-up plastic from one small beach, ready to be taken away for disposal.
Carbon Market Watch and the NewClimate Institute looked at 24 of the biggest global companies that have pledged to achieve carbon neutrality and positioned themselves as climate leaders.

site_title: The rally in China’s tech stocks is fading fast
summary: China's technology stocks are experiencing a fading rally, with the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index falling 16% from its January high due to growing concerns over growth, regulatory risks, and global economic uncertainty. Despite solid corporate earnings, investors are pricing in more risk amid geopolitical tensions, US rate hikes, and industry competition. The disappearance of dealmaker Fan Bao has raised doubts about President Xi Jinping's crackdown on the private sector, and investors are becoming increasingly cautious, with some considering reducing their exposure to big Chinese tech firms.

images.alt_text: The product, to be called “HunyuanAide”, will incorporate Tencent’s AI training model named “Hunyuan”.

site_title: Indonesia central bank has been intervening to defend rupiah: governor
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the bank has intervened to defend the rupiah exchange rate, which has been under pressure due to predicted US interest rate hikes. Warjiyo expressed confidence that the rupiah will strengthen once uncertainty around rate hikes subsides.

site_title: Sustainability projects get more Enterprise Development Grant support for 3 years; low-carbon tourism on Lazarus Island
summary: Singapore's government has announced enhanced funding support for sustainability projects, with the Enterprise Development Grant (EDG) providing up to 70% funding for three years. Low-carbon tourism initiatives, including eco-tourism accommodation units on Lazarus Island, will also be launched. Businesses will receive support for sustainability knowledge through new courses and playbooks. The government aims to transform its economy, achieve net-zero emissions by 2050, and promote green industries in its green economy strategy.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

As part of the strategy, Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong launched the Professional Services Industry Transformation Map (ITM) 2025, which he said will play an important role in strengthening Singapore’s role as a leading business hub.
Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives; raises quantum for Global Investor Programme
Higher cap of S$100,000 for the Market Readiness Assistance scheme will be extended by another two years until Mar 31, 2025.
Singapore government to build power generation capacity if tenders draw insufficient interest

site_title: Singapore boosts grants, tax schemes for companies going abroad; new Scale-Up X for promising local enterprises
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 aims to support businesses venturing abroad with enhanced grants and schemes. The Market Readiness Assistance grant will be extended to Mar 31, 2025, with a higher cap of S$100,000. Companies will also gain access to more export financing options, including foreign-based financial institutions and multilateral development banks. A new Scale-Up X programme will offer tailored support to promising local enterprises, focusing on leadership, internationalisation, and investment readiness.

images.alt_text: The enhancements to the EFS include trade loans, working capital loans and support for domestic construction projects via project loans, which saw extensions from Mar 31 this year to Mar 31, 2024.
Kurt Wee, president of the Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME), was hoping for the Energy Efficiency Grant to be extended to more sectors.
Budget 2023: Funding boosts for enterprises will help Singapore develop globally competitive firms

site_title: Irish breakthrough, but ‘Brex-eternity’ continues
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has struck a deal with the European Union over the Northern Ireland protocol, a key issue in Brexit negotiations. The proposed Windsor framework aims to resolve challenges related to trade and EU law. The deal includes removing customs checks on goods destined for Northern Ireland, limiting the role of the European Court of Justice, and giving the UK's devolved legislature in Northern Ireland a say on EU laws. Despite this agreement, Brexit is far from over, with ongoing negotiations and potential resistance from hardline Brexit groups. The UK-EU relationship is likely to continue evolving, potentially leading to a series of bilateral deals, similar to Switzerland's approach.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is expected to announce the deal on Monday after a meeting with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

site_title: Pockets of opportunity in Apac real estate from higher borrowing costs
summary: Higher financing costs in the Asian-Pacific (Apac) region are expected to force more willing sellers to adjust prices to meet buyers' expectations of discounts. With borrowing costs outpacing asset income yields, "negative carry" risks are increasing, particularly for highly leveraged investments. This could lead to a rise in distressed sales, although a large number is unlikely. Despite global headwinds, pockets of cyclical resiliency remain, with some markets, such as Japan and Singapore, expected to hold their values relatively well.

images.alt_text: A general view shows office buildings in the Raffles Place financial business district in Singapore on January 12, 2023. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
While premier Singapore office buildings are still relevant, yields on such buildings may need to expand to reflect higher interest rates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives until Dec 31, 2028, amid global tax rule changes. The country also aims to develop tech talent and grow its digital economy. Hotel room rates slipped to a five-month low in January, but remained higher on the year. The government is launching a blueprint and advisory panel for digital infrastructure and a new Heartland Innovation and Transformation Programme. Condo and HDB rental prices continued to rise in January, while corporate earnings showed mixed performances.

site_title: China says its economic recovery is still not solid
summary: China's economic recovery remains fragile, with the country facing triple pressures of demand contraction, supply shock, and weakened expectations. The Communist Party's central committee stated that the foundation of China's economic recovery is not yet solid, citing various unexpected factors that could occur at any time. This assessment comes ahead of the 14th National People's Congress, where reforms and leadership candidates will be discussed.

site_title: Samudera proposes S$0.2425 special dividend as H2 profit surges 63.6%
summary: Samudera Shipping Line reported a 63.6% surge in second-half net profit to US$150.3 million, driven by improved utilisations and rates across all business segments. Revenue rose 61.8% to US$514.4 million, with the container shipping segment contributing 61.1% of total revenue. The company expects prevailing geopolitical and economic headwinds to weigh on cargo demand and freight rates. A special dividend of S$0.2425 per share is proposed, bringing the full-year payout to S$0.32 per share.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The acquisition of the vessels is not expected to have any material impact on the net tangible assets and earnings per share of the Samudera group for the financial year 2022.
Samudera said that it wants to up its stake in LNG EW to better realise value from the company.
Inodonesian carrier Samudera Shipping is listed in Singapore.
Samudera Shipping reported a 367.6 per cent surge in earnings for 1H 2022 to US$171.7 million
In its query issued at 4.52pm, SGX RegCo asked if the company was aware of any possible explanation for the trading.

site_title: Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives; raises quantum for Global Investor Programme
summary: Singapore extends tax incentives for five more years, including the Pioneer Certificate, Development and Expansion Incentive, and Investment Allowance, until Dec 31, 2028. This move aims to support companies that are not subject to the global minimum effective tax rate under Pillar Two of the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS 2.0) initiative. Meanwhile, individual investors seeking permanent residency via the Global Investor Programme will need to invest more, with the investment quantum being raised to "ensure greater contributions from these investors."

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

Addressing concerns that the government has shifted from a “pro-growth” approach, DPM Lawrence Wong reiterated its commitment to “growing the economic pie”, as only then would Singapore have the resources to “redistribute, strengthen its social compact and progress as one people”.

“We want to help Singaporeans tackle cost of living pressures, but we must be careful not to inadvertently generate more demand and worsen inflation,” said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong in Parliament.
Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.

site_title: China fund panic spurs risky backtrack on mark-to-market pricing
summary: China's banks and asset managers are using amortised-cost accounting to value assets in investment funds, a method that can mask day-to-day volatility and price swings. This approach is being used to attract buyers and stem client redemptions, following a sharp bond decline last year. Regulators are showing more tolerance for the method, which was previously restricted, to prevent massive redemptions and protect the bond market. However, the use of amortised-cost accounting can also cover up risks and undermine China's push for transparent fund returns.

images.alt_text: The proposal comes at a time of heightened tensions between Washington and Beijing over issues from the Russia-Ukraine war and suspected Chinese spy balloons to tit-for-tat trade friction and technology rivalry.
Policymakers need to get consumption levels up, stabilise a struggling property market and lift economic growth before they can consider any monetary tightening, the analysts say.

site_title: Singapore’s market cap down 4.3% in February amid earnings hit, persistent inflation worries
summary: Singapore's total market capitalization declined 4.3% to S$815.3 billion in February, driven by cautious investor sentiment amid inflation concerns and the corporate earnings season. Key losers included Keppel Corporation, Sats, and DBS, while Genting Singapore was a notable gainer. Analysts expect volatility to persist, with weakening global macro conditions posing downside pressure, while China's reopening could drive some upside.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Analysts will be paying close attention to the earnings of banks, companies in the tourism sector as well as hospitality and retail Reits in the coming weeks.

site_title: Modern services get boost to create 100,000 jobs, as Singapore strengthens its business hub status
summary: Singapore has unveiled its Services 2030 strategy, aiming to create over 100,000 jobs and boost the modern services cluster's value-add by at least 50% by the end of the decade. The strategy, part of the Singapore Economy 2030 vision, includes initiatives to strengthen the country's position as a leading hub for professional services, infocomm technology, and media. The government will also introduce new tax incentives and programs to support local companies, including an enhanced Market Readiness Assistance scheme and a new Scale-Up X program.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

As part of the strategy, Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong launched the Professional Services Industry Transformation Map (ITM) 2025, which he said will play an important role in strengthening Singapore’s role as a leading business hub.
Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives; raises quantum for Global Investor Programme
Higher cap of S$100,000 for the Market Readiness Assistance scheme will be extended by another two years until Mar 31, 2025.
Singapore government to build power generation capacity if tenders draw insufficient interest

Under the Heartland Innovation and Transformation (HIT) Programme, more modular temporary spaces in mature heartland precincts will be constructed and made available for enterprises to use these spots to test out new business ideas.

At the same time, the government will help businesses strengthen their knowledge on sustainability through new courses and playbooks, said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan. This would help businesses to learn more about sustainability topics and the steps needed to become more sustainable.

site_title: HSBC riles Hong Kong bankers with plan to end private offices
summary: HSBC is planning to cut office space by 40% globally, including potentially ending private offices for senior investment bankers in Hong Kong. The move follows similar changes at HSBC's London headquarters, where the executive floor was scrapped two years ago. The plan aims to optimize space, increase flexibility, and address confidentiality risks. This move comes amid a difficult year for deal-making and a need for cost cuts, following a drop in the overall bonus pool and a major shareholder's call for deeper cost cuts.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings in the Canary Wharf business, financial and shopping district in London. HSBC is reviewing its workplace needs once its current lease ends in 2027, as it looks to cut office space by 40 per cent globally compared with pre-pandemic levels.
HSBC said greenwashing is “an important emerging risk that is likely to increase over time as we look to develop capabilities and products to achieve our net-zero commitments.”
HSBC’s operations in Russia consisted of a corporate banking business which offered a range of lending and investment banking services to domestic and multinational customers.

site_title: Singapore government to build power generation capacity if tenders draw insufficient interest
summary: Singapore's government plans to build new power generation capacity if private companies don't bid enough for tenders. The country relies on imported natural gas for 95% of its energy mix. To strengthen the energy market, the government will also enhance regulatory requirements for electricity retailers and explore more secure gas procurement contracts. Additionally, Singapore is developing new energy supply sources and diversifying its energy mix, including a renewable hydropower project with Laos and Thailand.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Aerial photo of Senoko Power Station as viewed from a helicopter. Photographed on Dec 1, 2021.

site_title: Sydney’s property prices up for the first time in 13 months
summary: Sydney's property prices rose 0.3% in February, the first increase in 13 months, driven by higher-end properties. This signal a possible turnaround in the city's market, but its impact on other cities is uncertain. The national home value index fell 0.1%, the smallest decline since May, as the Reserve Bank continues to tighten monetary policy to combat inflation. Experts warn that the rebound could be short-lived due to further interest rate hikes and a weakening economy.

images.alt_text: The ballooning prices will add to cost of living pressures in Australia, with data released Wednesday showing wages are growing at less than half the pace of inflation.

site_title: Japan's lower house approves record budget
summary: Japan's lower house has approved a record 114.4 trillion yen budget, the country's largest to date, with a 6.8 trillion yen increase in spending. The budget includes record military spending and welfare spending for Japan's aging population. The move is expected to further increase Japan's debt burden, now 263% of its economy. Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's administration aims to double childcare outlays to address declining birthrates. The budget's passage in the lower house makes approval by the upper house by March almost certain.

images.alt_text: Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes volatile fresh food but includes energy costs, rose 4.2 per cent in January from a year earlier, matching a median market forecast.

site_title: Cryptoverse: Bitcoin moves towards Satoshi’s payment dream
summary: Bitcoin is moving closer to its creator Satoshi Nakamoto's vision of a peer-to-peer electronic cash system, with growing adoption in payments. The amount of Bitcoin stored on the Lightning Network has jumped 66% to an all-time high, and transaction volumes have increased 18% and 32% for BitPay and CoinsPaid, respectively. Proponents argue that Bitcoin offers lower transaction costs and quicker speeds than traditional cash, particularly for cross-border transfers. However, challenges such as regulatory uncertainty and the readiness of blockchains to handle high transaction volumes remain.

images.alt_text: Tether now commands 52.6 per cent of the stablecoin market.
The cryptocurrency is staging one of its strongest efforts yet to break away from the stock markets.

site_title: Nanyang Polytechnic appointed Jobs-Skills Integrator for precision engineering
summary: Nanyang Polytechnic has been appointed as the Jobs-Skills Integrator for precision engineering, a pilot sector under the Jobs-Skills Integrator scheme announced in Budget 2023. As integrator, NYP will work with companies and training providers to enhance placement support for jobseekers, and provide advisory and training services to SMEs and workers. The initiative aims to help SMEs build workplace learning capabilities, with a Workplace Skills Recognition Programme being piloted in retail and wholesale trade sectors.

images.alt_text: Tertiary students at Nanyang Polytechnic located along Ang Mo Kio Ave 8, 4 February 2021.
The government will pilot the scheme in the precision engineering, retail and wholesale trade industries.
Jobs-Skills Integrators: execution must go beyond coordination

site_title: Rivian slumps with full-year output forecast 25% below estimates
summary: Rivian Automotive forecasted 50,000 electric vehicles for 2023, below Wall Street's expectations, with revenue falling short of estimates at $663 million. The company's adjusted loss was $1.87 per share, in line with forecasts. Supply chain issues and supplier shortages hindered production, with multiple days of lost production during the quarter. Rivian's shares fell 6.9% in late trading, and the company expects a loss of $4.3 billion for 2023, with a backlog of preorders extending into 2024.

images.alt_text: Rivian, which has been losing money on every vehicle it builds, narrowly missed its full-year production target of 25,000 units last year as it dealt with supply-chain disruptions.
The company has patents for electric bicycle components and designs.

site_title: European Investment Bank proposes new fund to counter US green subsidies
summary: The European Investment Bank is considering a new fund to counter US green subsidies under the Inflation Reduction Act, which incentivizes companies to invest in the US. The fund, modeled after a pandemic-era support package, would promote European industries with a competitive advantage. Volkswagen-owned Audi has already announced plans to build a factory in the US, citing the subsidies. A capital increase is not required, but financial guarantees from the EU or member states would be necessary. The move aims to level the playing field and safeguard European industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the German car manufacturer Audi is pictured at the training center during a media tour in San Jose Chiapa, Mexico April 19, 2018. REUTERS/Henry Romero/File Photo

site_title: AirAsia parent posts Q4 profit; expects China reopening boost
summary: Capital A, the parent company of AirAsia, reported a profit of RM256.2 million (S$77 million) in the fourth quarter, reversing a loss of RM756.6 million from the same period last year. The company expects 150 aircraft to be operational by March, aiming to return to pre-Covid capacity by the end of the year. China's reopening is expected to further boost the airline's business, with CEO Tony Fernandes stating that the company is on track to complete its restructuring efforts and resolve its 'Practice Note 17' status.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of AirAsia under Capital A is seen displayed in this illustration picture taken March 7, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Australia retail sales rebound by 1.9% in January
summary: Australia's retail sales rebounded 1.9% in January from December, exceeding median forecasts of a 1.5% rise. The sales of A$35.1 billion were 7.5% higher than a year earlier, indicating that consumption is holding up despite changing spending habits and online sale events. The strong rebound suggests that the economy is resilient, but analyst uncertainty about the outcome was high, with estimates ranging from -3.7% to +5.0%.

site_title: Mega projects, tourism to propel Thailand’s growth, finance chief says
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3.8% this year, driven by a slew of billion-dollar infrastructure projects and an upswing in tourism. Despite a below-par performance last quarter, the finance ministry is sticking to its forecast, citing firm domestic demand and an improving services sector. The government's approvals for high-speed railway projects and private sector investments will ensure capital spending remains on track. Tourism is also expected to support the economy, particularly with China's reopening, which has seen foreign tourists return in droves, with arrivals topping 2 million for the second straight month in January.

images.alt_text: Tourism is a key source of jobs and driver of Thailand’s economy and was typically worth about 12 per cent of its annual gross domestic product before the pandemic struck and decimated its travel sector.
Domestic spending has increased and the government will accelerate large project investment to help growth, the minister told a Radio Thailand programme.
Thai move to lure affluent foreigners with tax breaks and other financial incentives, which mirrors steps by countries including Singapore and the United Arab Emirates.

site_title: Sembmarine: Out with the old, in with the new
summary: Sembmarine, a Singaporean offshore & marine heavyweight, is set to emerge from a merger with Keppel Corp's O&M arm, creating a new entity with a sizeable order book of S$18 billion and a greater focus on offshore renewables and sustainable solutions. The company's latest FY2022 results showed narrowed losses and a positive Ebitda in the second-half period, attributed to strong execution and project delivery. The merged entity's market capitalization is expected to rise to S$8.67 billion from S$3.99 billion, but volatility may persist due to integration challenges and competition in the sector.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Public might be allowed to block international calls, SMSes in fight against scams
summary: Singapore is stepping up its fight against scams, with plans to give the public the option to block international calls and SMSes, and to verify calls from government officials. The country has seen over 31,700 cases of scams in 2022, resulting in S$660 million lost. The government is also exploring a money-lock solution for bank customers and tightening laws to clamp down on money mules. Minister of State for Home Affairs Sun Xueling emphasized the need for a vigilant and discerning public to take action against scams, with a new national anti-scam campaign launched in January.

images.alt_text: Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan says amid global political fragmentation, Singapore must continue to support and uphold the rule of international law.

Addressing concerns that the government has shifted from a “pro-growth” approach, DPM Lawrence Wong reiterated its commitment to “growing the economic pie”, as only then would Singapore have the resources to “redistribute, strengthen its social compact and progress as one people”.
Minister Indranee Rajah said Singapore’s total fertility rate has been declining for many years, like other advanced societies.

site_title: Tesla to go ahead with major Mexico plant, Mexican president says
summary: Tesla will build a major new plant in Monterrey, Mexico, after President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador and Tesla CEO Elon Musk reached an agreement. The plant is expected to bring a significant investment and job opportunities to the region. The deal was reached despite concerns over water scarcity in the area, with Lopez Obrador stating Musk understood the challenge and made commitments as part of the deal. This move is seen as a boost to Mexico's efforts to attract investment and erode Asia's dominance in manufacturing industries.

images.alt_text: Tesla has lagged competitors in China in introducing new models, improving navigation systems and adding luxury interior touches or white-glove customer service to meet a developing range of consumer tastes, analysts and fans said.

site_title: HP maintains cash-flow outlook even as PC demand craters
summary: HP maintained its annual cash flow guidance of $3.25 billion despite a 19% drop in first-quarter revenue to $13.8 billion due to plummeting PC demand. The company expects PC demand and profitability to improve throughout the fiscal year, with adjusted profit between $3.20 and $3.60 per share. Despite a weaker consumer market, commercial PC sales initially shielded HP, and the company plans to invest in growth segments such as subscription services. HP's shares rose 2% in extended trading following the report.

images.alt_text: HP, which makes most of its money by selling computers, has been navigating a sustained downturn in PC demand.

site_title: UK home prices to fall, but unlikely to come crashing down
summary: UK home prices are expected to fall by 2.4% in 2023, less than previously predicted, due to a resilient job market and easing recession fears. Higher borrowing costs have pushed the Bank of England to increase interest rates, leading to a further increase in mortgage rates. Home prices are expected to rise 1% next year and 3.5% in 2025, with London experiencing a steeper drop of 5% this year before recovering in the medium term.

images.alt_text: UK unitied kingdom house housing rent Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: More US homebuyers are paying in cash, sweeping a majority of sales in some markets
summary: US homebuyers are increasingly paying in cash, with the share of all-cash deals rising to its highest level since 2013, according to real estate data analytics firm Attom. This trend is particularly true in the Southeast, where cities like Augusta, Georgia, and Atlanta saw cash sales above 50%. Regular buyers, who would have been priced out by institutional investors, are now stepping in to purchase homes, often using their own funds to avoid high mortgage rates.

images.alt_text: The second straight monthly increase in contracts could see existing home sales rebounding or posting another small decline after logging their 12th straight monthly decrease in January.

site_title: Centurion Corporation H2 earnings down 12% to S$38.5 million
summary: Centurion Corporation reported a 12% decrease in net profit to S$38.5 million for the second half of 2022, due to a reduction in Covid-related grants and higher administrative costs. Revenue rose 15% to S$89.9 million, driven by stronger demand for workers and student accommodation. The company's portfolio saw a "healthy recovery" in financial occupancy, with purpose-built student accommodation assets in Australia and purpose-built workers' accommodation assets in Singapore and Malaysia experiencing significant growth.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Centurion Corporation also  operates other student accommodation properties in Australia under Dwell Adelaide Student Living.

The lease and development of the land is in line with Centurion’s strategy to grow its workers accommodation business in Singapore, and represents an opportunity to enlarge its portfolio to 35,550 beds here.

site_title: Fair value losses drag Straits Trading into the red in H2
summary: Straits Trading posted a net loss of S$121.8 million for the second half of 2022, reversing a net profit of S$111.6 million in the same period last year. The loss was driven by a net fair value loss of S$79.7 million on investment properties. Total revenue for the period rose 45% to S$257.5 million, with tin mining and smelting revenue up 48.5%. The company's full-year net profit was S$551.3 million, up 133% from the prior year.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Chew Gek Khim, executive chairman of Straits Trading said that part of the proceeds would be used carry the company’s growth strategy.

site_title: China Everbright posts 16% lower FY2022 earnings of HK$1 billion
summary: China Everbright Water reported a net profit of HK$1 billion (S$171.9 million) for FY2022, down 16% from FY2021. Earnings per share declined 16% to HK$0.3532. The company proposed a final dividend of HK$0.0514 per share, lower than FY2021's HK$0.0683. Revenue fell 3% to HK$6.7 billion, while gross profit margin dropped 3 percentage points to 38%. Despite a decline in earnings, the company remains in a healthy financial position.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The project (not shown above) will be constructed in two phases, and has a combined daily waste water treatment capacity of 60,000 cubic metres.
China Everbright Water's wastewater treatment project in Qingdao. The company has secured its first municipal-level sludge disposal project

The project will be based on a build-operate-transfer model and comprises a waste water treatment plant with a designed daily waste water treatment capacity of 20,000 cubic metres as well as an ancillary pipeline network of about 37.1 km.

site_title: Japan’s birth rate plunges to a record low
summary: Japan recorded a record-low birth rate in 2022, with 799,728 newborns, a 5.1% decline from the previous year. This marks the lowest number of births since 1899, exacerbating Japan's rapidly ageing society. The declining birth rate threatens the country's workforce and economy, while the rising cost of caring for elderly citizens strains the nation's finances. The government plans to increase the labour force by encouraging women to work and accepting immigrants, with a focus on child and family support policies.

images.alt_text: In Japan, the decling birth rate is particularly acute because it has the world’s second-highest proportion of people aged 65 and over.

site_title: Jardine Cycle & Carriage H2 earnings down 42% to US$252.3 million
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) reported a net profit of US$252.3 million for the second half of 2022, down 42% from the same period in 2021. Revenue rose 18% to US$11.1 billion, driven by higher sales in Astra's automotive segment and other operations. The company recommended a final dividend of US$0.83 per share, up from US$0.62 in 2021. Full-year profit rose 12% to US$739.8 million, with underlying profit reaching a record high of US$1.1 billion.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
All three banks returned negatively in the month. DBS’ market cap loss of S$3.3b made it the top loser, but it was still the most valuable stock in Singapore with a market value of S$87.6b.
Rising costs and a challenging operating environment are oft-cited reasons for delisting.

site_title: Singapore to launch blueprint, advisory panel for digital infrastructure
summary: Singapore is developing a Digital Connectivity Blueprint to outline its long-term ambitions for connectivity infrastructure, including broadband, mobile, and WiFi networks, as well as subsea cables. The blueprint, set to be launched later this year, will be guided by an advisory panel co-chaired by Senior Minister Janil Puthucheary and Irving Tan. The plan aims to support the industry in tapping 5G capabilities and create economic opportunities for all Singaporeans, building on Singapore's successful infrastructure planning, which has led to 98% broadband coverage nationwide.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

At the same time, the government will help businesses strengthen their knowledge on sustainability through new courses and playbooks, said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan. This would help businesses to learn more about sustainability topics and the steps needed to become more sustainable.
Singapore government to build power generation capacity if tenders draw insufficient interest

site_title: US goods trade deficit widens in January; wholesale inventories decline
summary: The US goods trade deficit widened 2.0% to $91.5 billion in January, driven by a 3.4% increase in imports to $265.3 billion and a 4.2% jump in exports to $173.8 billion. Despite the trade deficit, it is expected to have a neutral impact on GDP growth in the first quarter. Wholesale inventories declined 0.4% in January, reflecting drops in durable and nondurable goods, and may be a drag on GDP growth.

site_title: New Delhi city warns Uber, Ola on use of bike taxis
summary: New Delhi city authorities have warned Uber and Ola, two ride-hailing companies, for allegedly violating local transport rules by providing two-wheeler bike taxis. Despite a February 19 transport department order to "immediately stop" allowing personal bike taxis, the services remain available for booking on the companies' apps in the city. The move comes after Uber reported over 1.9 million trips to and from metro rail stations in Delhi on its bike taxi service, Uber Moto, in 2022.

images.alt_text: Uber has set a 2040 target for 100 per cent of its rides to be in zero-emission vehicles, public transport or with micro-mobility, including in India.

site_title: US and Europe still dominant forces driving Asean growth: economists
summary: The US and European economies remain the dominant drivers of growth for most Asean countries, including Singapore, Vietnam, the Philippines, and Thailand, despite China's growing influence. China serves as the final node of global supply chains, but the final demand lies in Western economies. Economists expect the US and Europe to slow down in 2023, with China's growth expected to be slightly higher, but still not enough to offset the impact. The region's economies are heavily reliant on Western demand, with Singapore, Vietnam, and Thailand having over 40% of their economies exposed to the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Labour, led by Keir Starmer, has promised to ensure Britain has the fastest growing economy among the G7 on a sustained basis if it wins power.
The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing.Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Billionaire donates US$1.9 billion to art museum where he lives
summary: Billionaire Mitchell Rales donated $1.9 billion to his Glenstone Foundation, one of the largest gifts to the arts. The donation, valued at nearly the same as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, supports a Maryland sculpture park and museum where Rales and his wife reside. The funds will support operating costs, capital building projects, and acquisitions. The gift dwarfs a $200 million donation by Amazon founder Jeff Bezos to the Smithsonian Institute. Glenstone's collection features modern art by notable artists, and the donation has raised questions about the public benefit of private museums.

site_title: US to require companies winning chipmaking subsidies to share excess profits
summary: The US will require companies winning subsidies from its $52 billion semiconductor manufacturing program to share excess profits and explain how they plan to provide affordable childcare. The Commerce Department plans to start accepting applications for a $39 billion manufacturing subsidy program in late June. The CHIPS Act aims to bring semiconductor manufacturing back to the US, competing with China's growing dominance in global markets.

site_title: Australia has not received advice to ban TikTok from govt devices: Treasurer
summary: Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers stated the country has not received advice to ban Chinese video-sharing app TikTok from government devices, contrary to actions taken by the US, European Parliament, and Canada. The decision will be based on advice from national security agencies, and the government is currently assessing the risks associated with the app.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: China's flags are seen near a TikTok logo in this illustration picture taken July 16, 2020. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Condo, HDB rents continue to climb in January; HDB volumes rebound: SRX, 99.co
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rental prices continued to rise in January, with condo rents increasing 1.4% from December 2022 and HDB rents rising 0.6%. Condo rental volumes fell 0.9% year-over-year, while HDB volumes rebounded 12.2%. Experts predict moderate rental growth in 2023, with estimates ranging from 10-15% for both condo and HDB markets. The slower rate of rental growth may signal that rental rates are reaching their peak this year.

images.alt_text: Among the three private non-landed property segments, the mass market segment is consistently the largest sector in the past 19 years in terms of the number of housing units transacted.
Two projects - Farrer Park Fields and Ulu Pandan Glades - are offered under the Prime Location Housing (PLH) model, which applies to flats in prime and central locations.
Flash estimates from SRX and 99.co published on Monday (Feb 27) show that overall prices have gone up 8.6 per cent as compared to a year ago.

site_title: UMS Q4 net profit hits S$16.1 million; final dividend of S$0.02 proposed
summary: UMS Holdings reported a net profit of S$16.1 million for its fourth fiscal quarter, up from S$5.7 million in the same period last year, driven by 16% revenue growth to S$101 million. The company attributed the stronger performance to higher sales and a reversal of a tax provision made by its Malaysian subsidiary. However, the group suffered from lower gross material margin, higher expenses, and foreign exchange losses. UMS proposed a final dividend of S$0.02 per share, unchanged from 2021, and expects to remain profitable in 2023 despite a softer outlook for the next six months.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
While the Biden administration push, described by economists as an industrial policy, has opened opportunities for some companies, significant hurdles remain.
FILE PHOTO: A security guard stands outside the headquarters building of China Securities Regulatory Commission in Beijing, September 7, 2015. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo
Reducing its payments to shareholders undermines Intel’s standing in a growing competition among chipmakers to offer higher returns.

site_title: Tumultuous times ahead for Thailand as a heated election looms
summary: Thailand is poised for a tumultuous election in May, with Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha's support dwindling amidst a tight contest between him and Pheu Thai party leader Paetongtarn Shinawatra. A recent survey shows Prayut trailing Paetongtarn by 2.8 percentage points, while a separate poll indicates 20% of eligible voters prefer the incumbent. Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3-4% this year, providing a backdrop for the election, which is crucial for the country's political stability and long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: Foreign tourists are returning to Thailand in droves, with arrivals topping 2 million for a second straight month in January.

Tourism is a key source of jobs and driver of Thailand’s economy and was typically worth about 12 per cent of its annual gross domestic product before the pandemic struck and decimated its travel sector.
Thailand is the world’s third-largest rice exporter after India and Vietnam.

site_title: Evergrande fails to win creditors’ support as key dates loom
summary: Evergrande Group, a Chinese real estate developer, has failed to reach an agreement with major creditors on a debt restructuring framework, which is crucial for avoiding potential court-ordered asset liquidation. The company faces a March 20 court hearing in Hong Kong on a winding-up petition and has yet to meet the March deadline set by creditors. Disagreements remain over the equity value of Evergrande and its two Hong Kong-listed units, as well as the structural seniority of its debt.

images.alt_text: This aerial photo taken on December 3, 2022 shows a housing complex by Chinese property developer Evergrande in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
Builders using grace periods to push out debt payments is allowed under bond covenants.
Hui Ka Yan had been part of the political advisory body since 2008 and of its elite 300-member standing committee since 2013.

site_title: Digital pound could protect consumers in bank runs, BOE says
summary: The Bank of England's deputy governor, Jon Cunliffe, suggests that a digital pound, dubbed "Britcoin," could protect consumers in bank runs by providing an additional payment system. The digital currency, backed by the central bank and government, could help resolve failed banks by giving consumers a "safe place" to store value. Cunliffe argues that the benefits of a digital currency outweigh the risks, and the BOE would need to partner with private firms to create the product. The digital pound could be launched by 2030, with the goal of preparing the UK's payments system for a future without cash.

site_title: How 5G disappointed ‘pretty much everybody’
summary: 5G network has failed to deliver on its promises, disappointing telecom companies, consumers, and businesses. Despite the hype surrounding its potential to enable driverless cars, immersive reality, and mind-blowing gaming experiences, 5G has largely been a consumer proposition for businesses rather than a consumer proposition. Profits have slumped, and companies such as Ericsson have laid off 8,500 people. Many consumers remain unclear about the benefits of 5G, and marketing efforts have been criticized for exaggerating its capabilities.

images.alt_text: HKBN offers broadband Internet services to residential and corporate customers in the city. It also provides other enterprise telecom solutions, runs data centres and offers Wi-Fi connectivity.

site_title: High airfares are here to stay, AirAsia’s Fernandes says
summary: Airlines are expected to maintain high airfares due to the post-pandemic travel boom, according to AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes. Demand outstrips supply, leading airlines to lock in higher charges. Fernandes notes that fares are "real prices" and not just a result of high prices, but rather the industry's underpricing of its product. AirAsia plans to return its entire fleet of over 200 planes to service a year earlier than initially planned, citing the main obstacle as getting planes back in service.

images.alt_text: The International Civil Aviation Organization expects passenger demand to recover to pre-Covid levels on most routes this quarter and then to about 3 per cent higher than 2019 levels by year-end.

site_title: Adani continues investor roadshow in Hong Kong to win back trust
summary: Gautam Adani's crisis-ridden conglomerate is hosting an investor roadshow in Hong Kong, continuing efforts to ease concerns about financial health and corporate governance following allegations of accounting fraud and stock manipulation by US-based Hindenburg Research. The two-day roadshow follows meetings in Singapore, where executives claimed the group has enough money to repay debt over the next three years. Despite rescue moves, Adani bonds remain below pre-allegations levels, amounting to a combined loss of about $800 million.

images.alt_text: Aside from allegations of fraud and market manipulation committed by the Adani Group, ESG fund managers must now also digest documentation indicating their green dollars were indirectly financing coal, the dirtiest fossil fuel.

North Queensland Export Terminal, which is controlled by Adani family trust, is being considered to raise funds for the group, according to the report on Monday, citing sources aware of the fund-raising.
The Adani Group is seeking to stem the negative fallout from the Hindenburg claims as it faces debt maturities from a number of its companies by the end of next year.

site_title: What Europe’s economy needs now
summary: Europe's economy needs targeted support, not broad-based stimulus packages, due to growing investment gaps and high inflation. Instead of increasing interest rates, policymakers should invest in green sectors and sectors that promote resilience and competitiveness. The US Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) is a step in the right direction, providing massive support for green sectors. However, its limitations, such as excluding European manufacturers, raise concerns. Europe can neutralize the IRA's problematic provisions by engaging in dialogue with the US and targeting its investments. The European Investment Bank proposes creating a pan-EU equity fund to support large ventures in the net-zero economy.

images.alt_text: The European Union and the United States are raising the stakes with massive green subsidies and a pro-green business push, but the UK has yet to follow suit.
Germany’s solar industry has waned from its peak about a decade ago, when a wave of insolvencies purged many companies that had been set up with state subsidies.
Audi would most likely build a joint plant with Volkswagen, which is planning on building more cars for the US market locally in future.

site_title: Meta to form AI product team to keep up with chatbot competition
summary: Meta is forming a new AI product team to develop generative AI tools, including chatbots, to compete with other companies like Snap and Microsoft. CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced the move in a post on Instagram, stating the company aims to turbocharge its work in AI to improve messaging, advertising, and content recommendations. The new team will be led by Ahmad Al-Dahle and will include dozens of employees from scattered teams. Meta plans to use AI to develop chatbots and visual filters for its messaging apps and social media platforms.

images.alt_text: Meta’s LLaMA, short for Large Language Model Meta AI, will be available under non-commercial license to researchers and entities affiliated with government, civil society, and academia, it said in a blog.
Asked to comment on the Singapore Budget 2023, ChatGPT didn't fail completely but produced no epiphany either.
Meta plans to push some leaders into lower-level roles without direct reports, flattening the layers of management between top boss Mark Zuckerberg and the company’s interns.

site_title: Asia: Markets pick up but traders worry over looming rate hikes
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, driven by bargain-buying after a series of losses due to fears of higher-than-expected interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The gains followed Wall Street advances, but traders remain cautious ahead of US data releases. Recent robust jobs market and inflation data have spooked traders, who now expect more Fed rate hikes. Some commentators see a potential period of gains as Fed hikes are priced into valuations, while crude prices remain heavy due to recession and demand worries.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Manila, Jakarta and Wellington markets were all in the red on Monday.

site_title: Zoom gains after profit outlook beats analysts’ estimates
summary: Zoom Video Communications reported a profit forecast that beat analysts' estimates, with earnings of 96-98 US cents per share for the first quarter. The company attributed the beat to cost-cutting measures and a sales slowdown. Shares rose 8% on the news, despite a prediction of less revenue for the current quarter than expected. Zoom is finding its footing after a dramatic boom-and-bust cycle during the pandemic, and the company is working to hold on to larger corporate clients through new products and services.

images.alt_text: Zoom is fighting to reverse a slowdown in growth for its video communications service by expanding its tools for business.
Zoom is fighting to reverse a slowdown in growth for its video communications service by expanding its tools for business.

site_title: Murdoch testified Fox News hosts endorsed idea that Biden stole election
summary: Fox Corp Chairman Rupert Murdoch acknowledged under oath that some Fox hosts "endorsed" the notion that the 2020 US presidential election was stolen, contrary to the network's claims of fair coverage. Documents show Murdoch and other Fox executives believed Joe Biden fairly beat Donald Trump and that the results were not in doubt. Murdoch's testimony contradicts Fox's argument that its coverage of Trump's claims was inherently newsworthy and protected by the First Amendment. A five-week trial is scheduled to begin on April 17, with Dominion Voting Systems seeking to recover from irreparable harm caused by Fox's alleged spread of falsehoods about the election.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Rupert Murdoch, Executive Chairman of News Corp and 21st Century Fox, takes part as a judge during a global start up showcase at the Wall Street Journal Digital Live (WSJDLive) conference at the Montage hotel in Laguna Beach, California, October 20, 2015. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Hot stock: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering rises 5.9% to S$0.036
summary: Koh Brothers Eco Engineering reported a 20.6% improvement in net profit to S$1 million in H2 2022, with revenue rising 51.2% to S$107.5 million. The company's shares rose 5.9% to S$0.036, driven by higher construction revenue. However, it expects challenging operating conditions in the construction sector due to rising material and energy costs, as well as inflationary pressure.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Sotheby’s expands in Shanghai, lured by wealth in mainland China
summary: Sotheby's is expanding its presence in mainland China, growing its office in Shanghai and conducting transactions directly in the country. The move follows China's growing share of billionaire wealth and its potential to capture a significant market share in the global art trade. The auction house plans to display more items and hire staff in China, with Sotheby's Asia managing director Nathan Drahi citing "tremendous potential" in the market. This expansion comes as other luxury companies, such as Christie's, also enter the Chinese market.

images.alt_text: At a soiree of some 90 people on a recent Friday evening in the centre of Hong Kong’s financial district, women in white gloves hobnobbed with Sotheby’s executives as they admired Hermes collectibles.
Located at Landmark Chater in Hong Kong's Central district, the 2,230 sqm space will open in 2024, Sotheby’s said in a statement.

site_title: India’s economy seen losing speed as rising rates hurt demand
summary: India's economy is expected to slow down in the October-December period due to rising borrowing costs, which are hurting consumption accounting for 60% of GDP. The Reserve Bank of India has increased interest rates by 250 basis points since May to tame inflation, but economists warn that this may lead to a contraction in household budgets and consumption. GDP growth is projected to be 4.7% last quarter, the slowest quarterly performance since last year, and 6.9% for the fiscal year, slightly below the government's estimate of 7%.

images.alt_text: Core inflation has stayed above 6% for 16 months in a row last month.
India’s headline inflation remained above the central bank’s target ceiling of 6 per cent for most part of last year due to high food prices, which comprise about half of the inflation basket.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker Ng says Malaysian jail was ‘absolute hell’
summary: Roger Ng, a former Goldman Sachs banker, has written a court filing describing his six-month imprisonment in a Malaysian prison as "absolute hell". Ng, convicted of conspiring to violate US anti-bribery laws and laundering money, spent time in Sungai Buloh prison where he was chained to 20 other inmates and contracted malaria and leptospirosis. Ng is now seeking leniency in his US sentencing, arguing that the punishment he received in Malaysia is sufficient. He will be sentenced in US federal court on March 9.

images.alt_text: The firms had agreed to pay the settlement figure in three phases: US$800 million within seven days from the end of the London proceedings, and the remainder within two years of the termination.

A Goldman Sachs Group Inc. logo hangs on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange in New York, U.S., on Wednesday, May 19, 2010. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. racked up trading profits for itself every day last quarter. Clients who followed the firmÕs investment advice fared far worse. Photographer: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg
The Malaysian government in 2018 turned its attention to Goldman Sachs for its work raising US$6.5 billion in 2012 and 2013 for 1MDB.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng reverses H2 loss, posts S$1.2 million profit
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng, a food and beverage company, reported a net profit of S$1.2 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, reversing a S$1.7 million net loss in the same period last year. Revenue rose 4.9% to S$176.8 million, driven by higher growth in its Malaysia operations, and gross profit grew 11% to S$51.5 million. The company proposes a final dividend of two Singapore cents per share.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Yeo Hiap Seng's CEO Samuel Koh has resigned and will take on the role of consultant for the company from Jan 1 to Jun 3, 2023.

site_title: Services 2030 strategy to help Singapore grow modern services, create 100,000 new jobs
summary: Singapore aims to grow the value-added from "modern services" by at least 50% and create over 100,000 new jobs by 2030 under the Services 2030 strategy. The Professional Services Industry Transformation Map 2025 has been launched as part of the strategy, covering consulting, legal, and accounting services. This is one of the pillars of the Singapore Economy 2030 vision, alongside Manufacturing 2030 and Trade 2030 strategies.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore extends investment promotion tax incentives; raises quantum for Global Investor Programme

site_title: Sembmarine calls for trading halt after H2 results release
summary: Sembmarine halted trading of its shares on Feb 28, 2023, after reporting a net loss of S$118.3 million for H2 FY2022, significantly narrower than its S$523.3 million loss in the same period a year prior. The loss was a major improvement from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: BTO flats in Farrer Park, Ulu Pandan among nearly 4,500 on offer in February
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched five public housing projects, offering 4,428 flats for sale under its February Build-To-Order exercise. Two projects, Farrer Park Fields and Ulu Pandan Glades, are being sold under the Prime Location Public Housing model, which applies to flats in prime and central locations. Flat prices start from S$185,000 for a two-room flexi flat, increasing to S$484,000 for a four-room flat. The projects' sales will be closely watched for buyer responses, particularly in Farrer Park Fields and Ulu Pandan Glades.

images.alt_text:
ST20230207-202313441712-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
Generic photograph of HDB flats being built around Darul Ghufran Mosque as viewed from Blk 413 Tampines Street 41 on Feb 7, 2023.

site_title: GK Goh owners launch offer to privatise company at S$1.26 per share
summary: GK Goh's founder and chairman, Goh Geok Khim, has launched a voluntary conditional offer to privatize the mainboard-listed investment company at S$1.26 per share in cash. The offer represents a premium of 38.5% over the last traded price and is below the company's net asset value per share. The offeror, a special purpose vehicle (SPV) owned by Khim and managing director Goh Yew Lin, plans to acquire 116.6 million shares, with the remaining shares to be compulsorily acquired if at least 90% of the shares are accepted. The delisting and privatization are expected to enable the company to focus on its businesses and operations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The reception area at the Singapore Exchange Ltd. (SGX) headquarters in Singapore, on Tuesday, Feb. 7, 2023. SGX is scheduled to release earnings results on Feb. 9. Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg
GK Goh's shareholders approve disposal of Boardroom stake
GK Goh joins US$25m Series B round of IoT startup UnaBiz
GK Goh unit to divest stake in Definitiv Group

site_title: ‘Rest your best!’: Pokemon Sleep game coming this year
summary: The Pokémon Company has announced the release of Pokémon Sleep, a new game set to launch in summer 2023, combining a smartphone sleep tracker with gaming. Players will research Pokémon sleep styles on a small island, with longer sleep sessions increasing their score and Pokémon sightings. The game will feature a "Pokémon GO Plus +" device, a Pokeball-shaped gadget that offers prompts to wake up or go to sleep. This marks the company's return to the gaming world after four years, following the success of Pokémon Go, which was released in 2016.

images.alt_text: Stuffed toys featuring Pokemon characters are seen at the 72th toy fair (Spielwarenmesse) in Nuremberg, southern Germany, on February 2, 2023. (Photo by Christof STACHE / AFP)

site_title: China uses TikTok to expand its influence globally, US lawmaker says
summary: A US Republican lawmaker, Representative Mike Gallagher, claims China is using TikTok to expand its global influence, arguing for the app's ban in the US or sale to a non-Chinese company. Gallagher's new committee aims to counter China's economic influence, amid concerns over alleged Chinese spy activity, including a balloon that transited across the US and China's potential support for Russia's invasion of Ukraine. China has pushed back on these claims, stating it does not offer weapons to conflict zones and advocates for peace in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: With more than one billion active users, TikTok is the sixth most used social platform in the world, according to the We Are Social marketing agency.

Content creators Kaity Dennis, Riri Bichri and Celeste Polanco at Central Park in New York on Jan. 21, 2023. These TikTok creators trusted their managers and now they just want their money. (Casey Steffens/The New York Times)

site_title: Hong Kong scraps mask mandate after almost 1,000 days
summary: Hong Kong is scrapping its mask mandate, which had been in place for nearly 1,000 days, starting March 1. The mandate, imposed three years ago, required everyone over 2 to wear a mask in public or face a fine of up to HK$10,000. The decision comes after neighboring Macau relaxed its mask rules. Hospitals and elderly homes can still impose their own restrictions. The move marks Hong Kong's emergence from the pandemic and its efforts to return to normalcy.

images.alt_text: People wear face masks in the MTR station, a day before government scraps the mask rule in Hong Kong, China February 28, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Canada joins US and EU in banning TikTok from government phones
summary: Canada has banned the use of TikTok on government-issued mobile devices due to security concerns over data collection. The ban, effective February 28, follows similar decisions by the European Commission and US Congress. The move aims to protect the privacy and security of Canadian civil servants. Although Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has not committed to a full ban on public access, he considers the civil-service curbs a "first step" in keeping Canadians safe.

images.alt_text: China has pushed back on what it called “hysteria” over the balloon and said it doesn’t offer weapons to conflict zones.

site_title: Gold prices set for monthly loss as US rate-hike bets dent appeal
summary: Gold prices are expected to decline by about 6% for the month due to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, weighing on the asset's appeal. Spot gold fell 0.1% to $1,816.33 per ounce, while money markets predict the US Fed's target rate to peak at 5.405% in September. This rise in interest rates increases the opportunity cost of holding gold as a hedge against inflation, making it less attractive to investors.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,268.88 points. The gains followed similar movements in US and European markets. Shen Yao, Golden Agri-Resources, and International Cement Group were among the top actively traded counters. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also saw gains, with DBS and UOB increasing 0.1% and OCBC rising 0.2%. The rally marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore Exchange, losers outnumbered gainers 353 to 228, after 1.8 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changed hands.

site_title: Hong Kong reopening tested by busiest month for events in years
summary: Hong Kong is set to host its busiest month for events in years, including the Clockenflap music festival, Art Basel, and the Rugby Sevens tournament, despite its slow pace of reopening. The city's efforts to lure travelers back with a 500,000 airline ticket giveaway coincide with the launch of the Hello Hong Kong campaign. However, tourism numbers remain low, with passenger volumes at the airport only 33% of pre-pandemic levels. Hong Kong faces challenges, including a labor shortage and a shrinking population, which may impact its status as Asia's premier arts and exhibition center.

images.alt_text: Containers sit stacked at the Kwai Tsing Container Terminal in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2020. Hong Kong's container throughput fell 20.4% in January from a year ago according to preliminary figures posted on the Port Development Council's web site. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg
Indoor and outdoor mask requirements may be removed at the same time, though face coverings will still need to be worn at high-risk places including hospitals, Ming Pao reported on Monday.
Since August 2018, Hong Kong’s workforce has dropped about 5 per cent to 3.8 million people, according to the latest official figures.

site_title: China’s growing local debt means less money to support economy
summary: China's growing local debt poses a significant economic risk, with at least 17 out of 31 provincial governments facing high debt levels exceeding 120% of income in 2022.
