The debt is expected to limit fiscal stimulus and force some governments to scale back spending. The People's Bank of China is likely to keep interest rates low to control repayment burdens. China's top leaders will discuss key economic targets, including a new local bond quota, budget, and monetary policy, at the upcoming Parliament.

images.alt_text: Domestic orders and consumption drove output higher and saw economic activity in China swing back to growth in January
This aerial photo taken on December 3, 2022 shows a housing complex by Chinese property developer Evergrande in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Japan’s factory output posts biggest fall in 8 months on weak autos, chips sectors
summary: Japan's factory output declined 4.6% in January, the largest drop in 8 months, due to weak demand in the automotive and semiconductor sectors. Output of auto products fell 10.1%, while manufacturing of production machinery and electronic parts dropped 13.5% and 4.2%, respectively. Despite this, retail sales rose 6.3% in January, beating forecasts. Manufacturers expect output to rise 8.0% in February and 0.7% in March.

images.alt_text: epa10487106 Kazuo Ueda, government-nominee for next Governor of the Bank of Japan, speaks during a parliamentary hearing, in Tokyo, Japan, 24 February 2023. Ueda will succeed incumbent governor Haruhiko Kuroda in April 2023.  EPA-EFE/KIMIMASA MAYAMA
Japan’s G7 focus will be geopolitics, not economics

site_title: Sri Lanka’s key inflation rate eases to 50.6% in Feb
summary: Sri Lanka's key inflation rate eased to 50.6% in February from 51.7% in January, with food prices decreasing to 54.4% and non-food inflation rising to 58.8%. The country's central bank is expected to hold policy rates for a fourth time as it secures a US$2.9 billion bailout plan with the IMF. Experts predict inflation will continue to ease, but only reach single digits by the end of the year.

site_title: UK homebuyers are getting the best discounts in over five years
summary: UK homebuyers are securing the best discounts in over five years, with the average discount to asking price reaching 4.5% according to a report from property portal Zoopla. This marks a significant increase from 0.4% in 2022 and 0.6% the year before. Sellers are cutting their asking prices by an average of £14,100 to attract buyers, with many homeowners having room to be flexible accepting offers below the asking price, according to Zoopla's executive director Richard Donnell.

site_title: PropNex Q4 profit up 24.5% to S$17.8 million; proposes 1-for-1 share issuance
summary: PropNex posted a net profit of S$17.8 million for Q4 2022, a 24.5% year-on-year gain, driven by increased commission income from agency services and project marketing services. Revenue grew 23.3% to S$298.4 million. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.08 per share and a one-for-one share issuance, aiming to broaden accessibility and encourage trading liquidity. Q4 earnings per share reached 4.8 Singapore cents, higher than the 3.86 cents in Q4 2021.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Resale prices rose 2.3 per cent quarter on quarter, making for the slowest growth in 2022.
Flash estimates from SRX and 99.co published on Monday (Feb 27) show that overall prices have gone up 8.6 per cent as compared to a year ago.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOL, Sembmarine, Golden Agri-Resources, Sheng Siong, Golden Energy and Resources
summary: Several Singapore companies reported financial updates on Tuesday. UOL Group posted a 44% fall in net profit to S$120.8 million for the second half of 2022, while Sembcorp Marine narrowed its net loss to S$118.3 million. Golden Agri-Resources reported earnings of US$392.4 million for the half-year, with its full-year Ebitda reaching a record high. Sheng Siong Group saw a 1.4% fall in net profit, while Golden Energy and Resources increased its net profit to US$432.6 million.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore Exchange, losers outnumbered gainers 353 to 228, after 1.8 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changed hands.

site_title: Nestle to close factory, head office in Myanmar
summary: Nestle is closing its factory and head office in Myanmar due to the "current economic situation." The move follows other foreign companies exiting the country, including TotalEnergies, Chevron, and Telenor, amid widespread unrest and economic turmoil since the military coup in 2021. Nestle will instead market and distribute its products from Thailand, Malaysia, and the Philippines. The company has 138 employees in Myanmar and plans to support those affected by the decision.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on August 10, 2011 shows Nestle's logo on a road sign near the company's headquarters in Vevey. - Swiss food giant Nestle will halt production in Myanmar, a spokesperson told AFP on February 27, 2023, the latest company to head for the exit following a military coup two years ago. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)
A seat for Myanmar's delegate is left empty during the opening session of the 32nd Asean Coordinating Council meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, Feb 3, 2023.
The former leader, 77-year-old Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi, is expected to spend the rest of her life in jail.

site_title: OUE Lippo Healthcare’s losses widen to S$4 million in H2 despite higher revenue
summary: OUE Lippo Healthcare reported a net loss of S$4 million for the second half of 2022, despite a topline increase to S$77.2 million. The loss widened from S$2.5 million in the comparable period in 2021. The company attributed the rise to consolidation and higher revenue from its China businesses. It also reported a negative working capital position with S$21.5 million in net current liabilities. The board stated it can meet debt obligations and remains agile to respond to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Dasin Retail Trust is the only China-focused S-Reit to register a gain in unit price after China on Dec 7 announced the nationwide loosening of Covid restrictions.
First REIT now has 14 out of its 32 Asian healthcare assets in Japan nursing homes.
OUE's net profit of S$113.8 million from the same period the year before was boosted by a one-off S$110 million gain from a shareholder loan conversion.

site_title: Golden Agri’s H2 profit rises 21.5% to US$392.4 million
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 21.5% increase in half-year earnings to US$392.4 million, driven by higher contributions from its downstream segment. Revenue rose 3.8% to US$5.9 billion, with downstream revenue growing 12% due to lifted Indonesia's temporary export ban on palm oil products. The company's upstream segment saw a 10.7-tonne per hectare fruit yield improvement, but was impacted by crude palm oil price normalization. A proposed final dividend of 0.991 Singapore cents per share is expected to be distributed on May 18.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Uma Devi

The Golden Agri-Resources Ltd. logo is displayed in the reception area of the company's offices in Singapore, on Thursday, May 30, 2013. Golden Agri, the second-biggest palm plantations operator, expects to maintain profitability at its China unit as a drop in soybeans and higher selling prices improve earnings in oilseed processing.  BLOOMBERG
The fair value loss was a result of changes in the fair value of Golden Agri's investments in the fourth quarter.
RHB says that Golden Agri benefited from strong growth in fresh fruit bunches, which are the raw materials from which palm oil is extracted.
The company attributed the improved performance to higher palm oil prices, with market prices for crude palm oil (CPO) rising 23 per cent in the 9-month period.
CPO futures contracts on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives market are up 6.6 per cent since the beginning of the year. But since late April, the commodity is down about 33.3 per cent.

site_title: India rate-setter says core inflation must ease towards 4%
summary: India's Monetary Policy Committee is targeting a core inflation rate of 4% to achieve its inflation target. Core inflation has stayed above 6% for 16 months, prompting policymakers to raise interest rates by 250 basis points since May last year. External member Shashanka Bhide said high core inflation indicates a cost-price nexus in the economy, and stabilizing core prices is necessary for manufacturing firms to expand capacities. Bhide expects a short-term adverse impact on growth but believes a sustained rate increase will improve growth.

images.alt_text: india Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg
India’s self-nomination as the leader of the Global South is the culmination of messaging on the global stage that it will not simply play by the rules and norms of more powerful nations.
India’s headline inflation remained above the central bank’s target ceiling of 6 per cent for most part of last year due to high food prices, which comprise about half of the inflation basket.

site_title: Food Empire more than doubles final dividend as H2 profit rises to US$33m
summary: Food Empire Holdings reported a net profit of US$33 million for the second half of 2022, more than doubling its earnings from the same period last year. The company's revenue rose 29.7% to US$221 million, driven by growth in its Russian, Kazakhstan, and CIS markets. A final dividend of S$0.044 per share, more than double the previous year's, is proposed for shareholders. However, the company faces potential margin pressure due to foreign exchange rate volatility and economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Maybank analysts express confidence that Food Empire will pay its shareholders a special dividend that will bring the group’s total payout for FY2022 to S$0.04.

site_title: Tesla, Musk sued by shareholders over self-driving safety claims
summary: A proposed class action lawsuit was filed in San Francisco federal court against Tesla and CEO Elon Musk, alleging they defrauded shareholders over four years with false and misleading statements about the safety of Autopilot and Full Self-Driving technologies. The lawsuit claims Tesla concealed the risks of accidents and injuries associated with these technologies, which were suspected in multiple fatal crashes. The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages for Tesla shareholders from February 2019 to February 2023, following a decline in the company's share price after the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration began investigating the technologies.

images.alt_text: ELon Musk’s wealth has been buoyed by a nearly 70 per cent surge in Tesla’s stock price this year.
The layoffs hit employees on team across the company, including engineering and product, according to people familiar with the situation.

site_title: Oil futures slip 1% on worries about more US interest rate hikes
summary: Oil prices fell about 1% on Monday due to concerns about US interest rate hikes, which could slow economic growth and oil demand. Strong US economic data, including a rebound in shipments and new orders for capital goods, limited losses. Oil supply concerns were alleviated by Russia halting exports to Poland via the Druzhba pipeline. Despite this, US crude stockpiles are at their highest since May 2021, and analysts expect further supply cuts from Russia.

images.alt_text: West Texas Intermediate US crude futures (WTI) traded at US$76.09 a barrel, 23 cents, or 0.3 per cent lower, while Brent crude futures were down 30 cents, or 0.36 per cent, at US$82.86 a barrel at 0411 GMT.

site_title: Stellantis to cut up to 2,000 workers in Italy this year
summary: Stellantis plans to cut up to 2,000 jobs in Italy this year, representing about 4.3% of its workforce, as it transitions to electric vehicles. The cuts will mainly affect non-production workers, who will receive early retirement and salary benefits. The move is part of the company's cost-cutting drive to adapt to the shift to battery-powered cars. Stellantis aims to boost production at its Melfi plant and invest in a battery factory in Termoli to focus on EVs and plug-in hybrid vehicles.

images.alt_text: Stellantis’ Europe chief has blamed Opel’s loss of market share largely due to inadequate transport capacity to deliver the cars to sellers.
Musy (above) says Stellantis would have grabbed more of the passenger car market if it could have gotten its hands on more EVs.

site_title: Florida takes over Disney district to punish ‘woke’ politics
summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis signed a bill allowing him to appoint a board to oversee Walt Disney World's services, effectively ending the theme park's self-governing status. The move was seen as a punishment for Disney's opposition to a law banning school lessons on sexual orientation. DeSantis hailed the end of the "corporate kingdom," stating that accountability would be the order of the day, while critics feared the arrangement would make Disney beholden to the governor.

images.alt_text: Earlier Wednesday, Disney announced upbeat financial results, led by big gains at its theme parks.

site_title: Oil rebounds almost 2% on China growth hopes
summary: Oil prices rebounded nearly 2% on Tuesday, driven by hopes for a strong economic rebound in China and offsetting concerns about US interest rate hikes. Brent crude futures rose 1.8% to $83.89 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 1.8% to $77.05 a barrel. Analysts expect Chinese demand to drive commodity prices higher, with oil positioned to benefit the most, and forecast prices to rise above $90 a barrel by the second half of 2023.

images.alt_text: An oil pumping unit, also known as a "nodding donkey" or pumping jack, operates at sunset at a drilling site operated by Tatneft OAO near Almetyevsk, Russia, on Friday, July 31, 2015. Eleven months of surviving with oil below $100 have left Russia hardened enough to endure a monthlong drop to $40 a barrel, a survey of economists showed. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Bank of England says easing rules for small lenders shows ‘competitiveness’
summary: The Bank of England has announced reforms to bolster the UK's financial sector post-Brexit, aiming to boost competitiveness. The central bank will ease rules for smaller lenders, including easing liquidity, disclosure, reporting, and remuneration rules. This move aims to make the UK a more attractive destination for financial businesses, while maintaining international standards. The Bank of England will host a conference in September to explore the links between regulation and international competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England said this month that Britain’s weak productivity growth means the economy can probably only grow by about 0.7 per cent a year in 2024 and 2025 without generating inflationary heat.
The stubborn rise in mortgage costs, which is sharply slowing demand in the property market, is one of the headaches Rishi Sunak will inherit upon replacing Liz Truss as UK prime minister.
December’s reading is the highest since July and the third consecutive monthly improvement in the index.
A slump in inflation that sharp would be a major boost to Rishi Sunak’s government, which has made easing the cost-of-living crisis a key pledge.

The sharp uptick in February was driven by rising customer demand and increasing confidence among business executives after a subsidence in the market turmoil triggered by then-Prime Minister Liz Truss’s budget plan.

site_title: US business equipment orders increase by the most in five months
summary: US business equipment orders increased by 0.8% in January, the largest gain in five months, driven by companies seeking to boost productivity in a tight labor market. This rise follows a downwardly revised 0.3% decline in December. The data suggests businesses continue to invest in equipment despite high borrowing costs and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: Shares kick off week on solid footing, UK’s Sunak strikes new deal with EU
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 1.1% on Monday, rebounding from its biggest weekly drop of 2023, driven by gains across all major sectors and a new trade deal between the UK and EU. British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's announcement eased concerns of a trade war, while a firmer sterling weighed on the UK's FTSE 100. Major euro area sector indexes ended higher, with retail stocks leading gains, despite concerns over inflation and interest rate hikes. The Stoxx 600 has outperformed the S&P 500 this year, boosted by an improving economic outlook and China's reopening.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 finished 0.3 per cent higher at 3,982.35, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2 per cent to 32,889.29 on Monday.

site_title: Is it higher for longer rate hikes for Asean too?
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) region's central banks are expected to diverge in their policy paths amid mixed inflation data. The Philippines raised interest rates higher than expected, while Indonesia and Malaysia kept rates unchanged, and Singapore's inflation edged up slightly. The Bank of Thailand is expected to further increase its policy rate. However, with supply shocks easing and declines in commodity prices, expectations are growing that the region may be nearing the end of its tightening cycle or will pivot before the US Fed's rate hikes peak.

images.alt_text: Inflation in the Philippines is running at 14-year highs, with January's rate coming in at a faster-than-expected 8.7 per cent.
Bank Indonesia has held rates for the benchmark seven-day reverse repurchase at 5.75 per cent.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB downgrades IReit Global to ‘neutral’ as leasing risks persist
summary: RHB Research downgraded IReit Global's rating to "neutral" from "buy" due to declining occupancy and lower distribution per unit (DPU) in the near term. The downgrade comes after the real estate investment trust (Reit) missed estimates due to higher costs and a vacant Darmstadt Campus after its sole tenant moved out in November 2022. Analysts attribute the lack of leasing progress to a weak economic outlook and higher supply in the locality, with backfilling efforts being "rather slow". The target price was lowered to S$0.55 from S$0.63.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Gross revenue rose 10.7 per cent to 31.6 million euros in the second half (H2), while net property income (NPI) grew 5.2 per cent to 24.3 million euros.
Analysts anticipate that the interest rate hikes and leasing slowdowns will put “some downward pressure” on IReit’s portfolio revaluation in December.
The brokerage has initiated coverage on Europe-focused real-estate trust IReit Global with an “accumulate on weakness” rating at a target price of S$0.69
Cromwell European Reit has signalled its pivot to light industrial and logistics, with its acquisition of assets woth 57.8 million euro in the UK and the Netherlands

site_title: US may need new trade agreements so EV makers can meet anti-China rules
summary: The US may need to establish a new trade consortium to meet the anti-China demands of the Inflation Reduction Act's electric vehicle (EV) tax credits. The head of the Alliance for Automotive Innovation, John Bozzella, suggests that "friend-shoring" partnerships with allied nations will be required to create new supply chains due to China's significant share of critical minerals. Currently, 37 EVs are eligible for tax credits, but this number is expected to shrink to around 10 when the rules are finalized, prompting automakers to bring battery production in line with the IRA's rules.

images.alt_text: John Bozzella, president of Washington-based trade group Alliance for Automotive Innovation. Photographer: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg

site_title: Elon Musk regains his spot as the world’s richest person
summary: Elon Musk regained his spot as the world's richest person after Tesla's stock price surged nearly 70% this year, boosting his net worth to $187.1 billion. Musk's wealth surpassed that of France's Bernard Arnault, who held the title for over two months. Tesla's stock price increase was driven by demand for electric vehicles and price cuts on several models. Musk's wealth had fallen to $137 billion at the start of 2023, but he regained his position after the company's stock price rebounded.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk last year completed a US$44 billion deal for Twitter that gave him control of the company for US$54.20 a share.

site_title: US cyber official urges Microsoft, Twitter to boost security
summary: US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) Director Jen Easterly is set to criticize Microsoft and Twitter for their security protocols, calling them "disappointing" due to inadequate multifactor authentication and default settings. Easterly urges technology manufacturers to take ownership of customer security and proposes legislation to hold companies liable for products with significant defects. She also recommends tech companies stop charging extra for basic security protections and fix widespread coding problems, citing Go, Java, Python, and Rust as examples.

site_title: Messi beats Mbappe to Fifa Best prize, Putellas claims women’s award
summary: Lionel Messi won the Best Fifa Men's Player Award for 2022, beating Kylian Mbappe and Karim Benzema, after leading Argentina to a World Cup triumph. Messi, a seven-time Ballon d'Or winner, received the award at a ceremony in Paris, France. Meanwhile, Alexia Putellas retained the women's award, despite spending half of last year recovering from a serious knee injury. Messi succeeds Robert Lewandowski on the Fifa honours list, while Putellas adds the Fifa crown to her Ballon d'Or wins.

images.alt_text: Manchester United, which has won a record 13 Premier League titles, has consistently been able to attract the game’s biggest stars, including the likes of Cristiano Ronaldo, Paul Pogba and Zlatan Ibrahimovic.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher as traders await retailer earnings
summary: US stocks ended higher on Monday, with the S&P 500 rising 0.3% to 3,982.35, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2% to 32,889.29. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index picked up 0.6%. Investors await retailer earnings, including Target and Costco, amid a mixed data week and unchanged interest rate decision from the Federal Reserve. Despite a "decent relief rally," concerns over inflation and interest rates persist, with analysts predicting a "higher-for-longer" interest rate environment.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's overnight losses following US Fed's remark that inflation was still high and more rate hikes are afoot dented sentiments in the Singapore bourse

site_title: World Bank estimates Feb 6 earthquakes in Turkey caused US$34.2 billion in damage
summary: A 7.8 magnitude and 7.5 magnitude earthquake on February 6 caused approximately US$34.2 billion in direct damage in Turkey, killing over 44,300 people. The World Bank estimates total reconstruction and recovery costs could be twice as high, shaving off 0.5 percentage points from Turkey's forecast GDP growth. Over 1.25 million people were left homeless, with the heaviest damage in 11 southern provinces. The World Bank has provided US$1.78 billion in immediate assistance.

images.alt_text: Economists and officials estimate that the quake will cut economic growth by up to two percentage points this year.

site_title: Fair-value losses drag Ho Bee Land’s H2 earnings down 93% to S$16 million
summary: Singapore property developer Ho Bee Land's second-half earnings fell 93% to S$16 million, driven by a significant fair-value loss on its London portfolio. Revenue rose 35% to S$257.4 million, boosted by sales in Australia and rental income from London's The Scalpel. The company recommended a S$0.08 per-share dividend, down from S$0.10 in 2021, and expects its Elementum project to contribute strongly to revenue in FY2024.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Artist's impression of Elementum project in Singapore
Nicholas Chua, CEO, Ho Bee Land
According to a profit guidance, the group’s year-on-year revenue and operating profit have gone up but these have been offset by several factors.

site_title: Automation and AI will shape the finance and HR industries
summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) are expected to revolutionize the finance and HR industries, enabling organizations to automate repetitive tasks, improve decision-making, and create a more agile workforce. AI can reduce the burden on finance executives, allowing them to focus on strategic tasks, while HR can leverage AI to capture and analyze employee feedback, drive productivity, and improve employee happiness. To build trust in AI, organizations must prioritize transparency, explainability, and ethics, and ensure that AI models are integrated directly into core platforms and data sources.

images.alt_text: Do-it-yourself education has been on the rise in recent years, with the prevalence of platforms such as Udemy, LinkedIn Learning, and Coursera that support self-paced learning.

site_title: Foreign ownership of new entities up in 2022, with rebound in owners from China
summary: Singapore saw a resurgence in foreign ownership of new companies in 2022, with 29% of new corporate entities formed being foreign-owned, a rise from 23.7% in 2021 and 25.1% in 2020. China led the way, with a rebound in new firms with owners from the country after a slump in 2021. Observers expect this trend to continue into 2023, driven by China's reopening and Singapore's business-friendly taxation system, although market conditions may slow momentum this year.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Renald Yeo
Slowdowns are a great time to identify the next Amazon, Grab or Alibaba, as the dotcom bust and global financial crisis decades ago proved.
China has the world’s second-largest number of ultra rich, after the US, with more than 32,000 people holding wealth exceeding US$50 million.
Relocating to Singapore puts the wealth of China’s richest beyond the reach of Beijing, whose recent high-profile crackdowns have rattled billionaires.

site_title: Delfi H2 earnings up 44% to US$24.5 million; proposes special dividend
summary: Delfi Ltd reported earnings of US$24.5 million for the second half of 2022, a 44.4% increase from the same period in 2021. Revenue rose 21.6% to US$236.7 million, driven by growth in the Indonesia market and its premium format segment. The company proposes a final dividend of US$0.02 per share and a special dividend of US$0.0072 per share, with earnings for FY2022 up 49.9% to US$43.9 million. Delfi attributes its performance to growth in its premium segment and tight cost control, but faces uncertainty due to global economic factors.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Given Delfi’s premiumisation strategy that focuses on product differentiation and increasingly places emphasis on the modern trade sector, UOBKH believes the stock is “well-positioned” to capitalise on premiumisation trends.
“Positive trends such as a young population and growing disposable income will continue to propel revenue growth for Delfi’s range of chocolate products,” says Lim & Tan.

site_title: US pending home sales post the largest gain in 2½ years in January
summary: US pending home sales surged 8.1% in January, the largest gain in 2½ years, according to the National Association of Realtors. This increase, however, was largely due to a decrease of 24.1% in year-over-year sales. Economists had forecast a 1.0% rise. Despite this, NAR chief economist Lawrence Yun expects home sales activity to be bottoming out in the first quarter before incremental improvements occur. The housing market has been impacted by the Federal Reserve's monetary policy stance, with mortgage rates rising to a three-month high of 6.50% last week.

images.alt_text: Residential investment has contracted for seven straight quarters, the longest such stretch since 2009.

site_title: Co-working startups face fresh challenge of winning over landlords
summary: Co-working startups face a new challenge in winning over landlords as the industry evolves towards asset-light management contracts. After the pandemic, operators shifted from renting spaces to managing them for a fee, with landlords having a stake in the game. This model has gained popularity, with companies like WeWork and JustCo adopting it to shed lease liabilities. However, operators must convince landlords that they can add value by increasing yields, as the industry faces rising interest rates and economic headwinds. The success of this model will determine the future of co-working.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

ST20221029-202253130955-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/

Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) along the Singapore River on Oct 29, 2022. 

Can be used for stories on money, job, manpower, tourist, tourism, property, land, commercial, office, finance, financial, and CBD.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: UK PM Sunak strikes deal with EU over Northern Ireland
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced a deal with the European Union to resolve tensions over the Northern Ireland protocol, a post-Brexit trading agreement. The new deal separates goods going to Northern Ireland from those continuing into the EU, reducing paperwork for companies. The UK government will have a veto over changes to EU rules, while the European Court of Justice will have final say on single market issues. The deal aims to end a row that has overshadowed UK-EU ties since Brexit, allowing the UK to set its own VAT rules in Northern Ireland.

images.alt_text: One UK official says they have told Prime Minister Rishi Sunak that strong trading relations with Europe will be essential for the economic challenges of the future in areas such as emerging technologies, and to deal with threats like global supply shocks and China.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after worst weekly selloff of 2023
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday after a worst weekly selloff of 2023, driven by investors buying beaten-down shares amid concerns of aggressive interest-rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 89.24 points, or 0.27%, to 32,906.16. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 22.32 points, or 0.56%, and 122.25 points, or 1.07%, respectively.

site_title: GK Goh’s largest holder said to be considering delisting
summary: GK Goh Holdings, a Singapore-listed investment firm, is considering taking the company private after its largest shareholder, GKG Investment Holdings, which owns about 63% of the firm, is working with financial advisers on the deal. The process is private, and discussions are ongoing, with an announcement possible as soon as Monday. Trading of GK Goh's shares was halted pending the release of an announcement, which has a market value of S$286 million.

site_title: UK government calls in supermarket bosses for salad crisis talks
summary: The UK government has called in supermarket bosses to discuss the ongoing salad shortage, which has entered its third week. Disrupted harvests in Southern Europe and North Africa due to unseasonable weather have led to supply chain issues. Major supermarket groups such as Tesco, Asda, and Aldi have imposed customer purchase limits on affected items. Food and farming minister Mark Spencer will meet with the bosses to discuss restocking efforts.

images.alt_text: Eggs have already become scarcer and more expensive as a result of additional costs, coupled with a local outbreak of bird flu.

site_title: Apple pays 906 million rouble fine for alleged app market abuse in Russia
summary: Apple has paid a 906 million rouble (S$16.4 million) fine to Russia's Federal Antimonopoly Service (FAS) for alleged abuse of its dominance in the mobile apps market. The FAS determined in 2020 that Apple had abused its position and ordered the company to remove provisions giving it the right to reject third-party apps from its App Store. This follows a complaint from cybersecurity company Kaspersky Lab, which had its Safe Kids application declined by Apple's operating system. Apple had appealed the decision but ultimately complied with the order.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's IPIC and Aabar to pay Malaysia US$1.8 billion to settle 1MDB dispute
summary: Abu Dhabi's IPIC and Aabar have agreed to pay US$1.8 billion to settle a 1MDB dispute in Malaysia. The firms will pay US$800 million within seven days and the remainder within two years. The settlement resolves a challenge filed by Malaysia in a London court against a 2017 agreement between 1MDB and IPIC. This follows Najib Razak's 12-year jail sentence for corruption related to 1MDB. The agreement allows Malaysia and Abu Dhabi to continue working together for economic benefit.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s highest court Tuesday(Aug 23) upheld former prime minister Najib Razak’s 12-year jail sentence for corruption in the 1MDB financial scandal.

site_title: Grab’s profitability push enthralls analysts, but befuddled investors aren’t biting
summary: Grab's FY2022 results show narrowed losses and a forward-looking adjusted Ebitda breakeven target, but the stock price fell 11.5% after the announcement. Analysts overwhelmingly recommend a "buy" despite the market's skepticism. The disconnect may be due to the market's differing views on breakeven and profitability, as well as the complexity of Grab's financial metrics. Investors are seeking more concrete numbers, while analysts see potential for growth. The company's listed market in the US, where rising costs are affecting consumer behavior, may also be a factor.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Grab saw delivery segment adjusted Ebitda turn positive in Q4 2022 on contributions.
Tech platforms have different approaches to the way they report similar metrics, making an apple-to-apple comparison challenging.
Platform workers are often more vulnerable than other workers because they cannot find other jobs, or require flexible hours due to caregiving or medical needs.

site_title: Barclays, NatWest expect Fed to raise rate hike pace in March
summary: US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by 50 basis points in March due to persistent inflationary pressures and economic resilience, according to Barclays and NatWest. Barclays forecasts a 5.75% terminal interest rate, while NatWest expects a 5.75% rate by June, with 25-basis-point hikes at the May and June meetings. This would take the interest rate to its highest level since 2007.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve delivered a string of 75-basis-point and 50-basis point rate hikes in 2022 in its battle to curb inflation that had climbed to 40-year highs.
The US Federal Reserve has signalled that more rate hikes are in the offing to quell inflation, raising the risk of a hard economic landing.

site_title: UK says BOE losses on quantitative easing may cost taxpayers £200 billion
summary: The UK government plans to cover potential losses of up to £200 billion from the Bank of England's quantitative easing programme, which could cost taxpayers £200 billion. The losses stem from the BOE buying government and corporate bonds to lower interest rates, now being unwound, triggering losses on invested funds. The Treasury has requested an additional £180 billion to cover the shortfall, with £11 billion already cleared by parliament. The BOE made £120 billion in profits during the low-rate period, but now faces larger losses as interest rates rise.

images.alt_text: The BOE is coordinating with the government on which bonds to sell and when. A gilt maturing in 2029 is excluded from Tuesday’s sale because it was recently auctioned by the DMO.

site_title: Sinarmas Land H2 profit more than trebles to S$216.1 million amid property boom
summary: Sinarmas Land reported record-high earnings of S$343.6 million for FY2022, a 135% increase from FY2021, driven by higher sales of commercial and industrial land parcels and revenue from residential units. The group's hospitality business saw an improvement in revenue and occupancy following the reopening of international borders. Revenue for the full year rose 48.8% to S$1.3 billion, with gross profit increasing 88.2% to S$577.9 million. A first and final cash dividend of S$0.00138 per share is proposed.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Sinarmas Land and K2 Data Centres' first development, K2 Data Centre Jakarta 1 Campus will see the first phase come online in early 2024.
The development is the first in BSD City by Sinar Mitbana Mas, and will be constructed in phases starting from 2023.
Revenue rose on higher sales of commercial and industrial land parcels in BSD City and Kota Deltamas in Indonesia, as well as higher revenue recognised from residential and apartment units.

site_title: Broadcom faces EU antitrust warning on US$61 billion VMware deal: sources
summary: Broadcom is set to receive an EU antitrust warning regarding its proposed US$61 billion bid for VMware, citing potential anti-competitive effects on the market for certain hardware components. The European Commission opened an investigation in December, and a decision is expected by June 7. Broadcom stated it will continue "constructive work" with the commission. The deal, announced last year, would allow Broadcom to restrict competition in the market for certain hardware components which interoperate with VMware's software.

site_title: US offers US$375 million loan to Li-Cycle for battery-recycling project
summary: The US has offered a $375 million loan to Li-Cycle for its lithium-ion battery-recycling project in New York, with a 12-year term and matching interest rate to the 10-year US Treasury rate. The loan supports the expansion of the facility, which aims to recycle old batteries into chemicals for over 200,000 electric vehicles annually. The project aligns with the Biden administration's goal of having half of all vehicles sold by 2030 be zero-emission and creating a domestic battery supply chain.

images.alt_text: More than half of last year’s orders came from automakers and their suppliers – a group that has long led the way in automation of US factories.
European Commission proposed loosening state aid rules for investments in renewable energy or decarbonising industry, on a temporary basis, until end 2025.

site_title: Malaysia's FGV optimistic US import ban will be lifted this year
summary: Malaysia's palm oil giant FGV Holdings is optimistic that a US import ban on its products will be lifted by the end of the year. The company has taken steps to address allegations of forced labor, including upgrading housing facilities, compensating foreign workers who paid recruitment fees, and adhering to laws on working hours. FGV has set aside RM111.64 million to compensate affected workers and expects to submit a final report to the US Customs and Border Protection by the end of the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Indonesia and Malaysia have accused the EU of implementing discriminatory policies targetting palm oil.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources H2 net profit rises to US$432.6m, warns of weaker coal demand
summary: Golden Energy and Resources reported a net profit of US$432.6 million for the second half of 2022, a significant increase from US$85.2 million in the same period in 2021. Revenue rose to US$3.2 billion, driven by higher average selling prices for energy and metallurgical coal segments. However, the company warned that coal demand is weakening due to factors such as lower-than-expected demand in many regions and adequate inventory levels, potentially impacting prices.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Gear said a key rationale for the deal is to cut its exposure to the thermal coal business conducted by Gems, which faces ESG pressures
Gear said the distribution-in-specie is meant to reduce its exposure to energy coal, which is facing scrutiny as a fuel source.
Golden Energy and Resources had on Nov 1 announced that it is looking to restructure or exit all or substantially all of its energy coal business.
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources

site_title: China considers ways to curb youths’ ‘excessive’ video use
summary: China's National Radio and Television Administration is studying measures to curb young people's addiction to short videos, popularized by tech giants like ByteDance and Tencent. The agency aims to prevent minors from spending too much time on short videos, improving content quality, and promoting "healthy development." This move comes after Beijing has previously limited gaming time for children and clamped down on other industries with widespread followings. The government's objective is to curb the power of China's internet titans while reviving the country's economy. Concrete measures are unclear.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of TikTok's parent company ByteDance is seen at its booth during an organised media tour to the Zhongguancun National Innovation Demonstration Zone Exhibition Center in Beijing, China February 10, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Central Asian aviation sees opportunities in Ukraine crisis
summary: Central Asian airlines are capitalizing on Russia's closed airspace, with flights in and out of the region booming since the invasion of Ukraine. Airlines like Kazakhstan's Air Astana have seen significant growth, with passengers up 16.5% year-over-year and after-tax profit reaching $78.4 million in 2022. New airlines, such as Silk Avia and Air Samarkand, have also launched to capitalize on the increased traffic. As Russian tourists look for alternative destinations, the region is expected to continue growing, with tourism in Central Asia potentially becoming a major alternative to Europe.

images.alt_text: Passenger planes owned by Russia's airlines, including Aeroflot and Rossiya, are parked at Sheremetyevo International Airport in Moscow, Russia March 1, 2022. REUTERS/Marina Lystseva NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES.

site_title: US dollar slips but remains near seven-week high
summary: The US dollar index slipped 0.1% to 105.05, after reaching a seven-week high of 105.36, due to investors reassessing the US economic data and global interest rate outlook. The dollar had risen almost 3% in February, snapping a four-month losing streak. The euro fell to its lowest against the US dollar since January 6, but rebounded, while the pound rose 0.31% against the US dollar due to a potential post-Brexit deal with the EU.

site_title: HDB to launch more BTOs in mature estates in 2023; measures to help first-timers to kick in from August
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) plans to launch more Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in mature estates in 2023, including Kallang/Whampoa and Queenstown. To help first-time applicants, an additional BTO flat ballot chance will be offered for families with children and married couples aged 40 and below. The first BTO sales exercise will be launched in February, with around 4,500 units available, and 23,000 units to be launched throughout the year to meet strong demand. Measures to reduce waiting times and non-selection rates will also be introduced.

images.alt_text:
Generic photo of Toa Payoh HDB estate covered in mist on a rainy day on January 25, 2023. 
Can be used for property, low visibility, rain, weather, climate stories.

site_title: VinFast slashes lease prices for first US buyers, to deliver first EVs Mar 1
summary: Vietnamese electric vehicle maker VinFast has cut lease prices for its first US buyers by over 50% for California customers, starting deliveries on March 1. The monthly lease price for the VF 8 City Edition has dropped from $599 to $274, representing a discount of 33-54% from the initial price. The move comes as the Biden administration's EV credits take effect, increasing competition among EV makers. VinFast expects to deliver vehicles in Canada, France, Germany, and the Netherlands following its US deliveries.

images.alt_text: VinFast was awarded an “Air Permit”, the company said, adding it was still seeking other permits for the Chatham Country factory, but would start a tender for construction.

site_title: Some highly rated US companies take unusual funding route as rates rise
summary: Highly rated US companies are issuing convertible bonds, a shift in the market dominated by companies with few other options. Investment-grade-rated companies like PPL and Southern Co have raised $2.4 billion through these bonds, converting to shares at lower interest rates than traditional bonds. This trend is driven by the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and an accounting rule change that reduced the cost of issuance. The market is on pace to reach $65 billion to $70 billion in convertible bond issuance this year, more than double 2022 levels.

site_title: Geo Energy H2 earnings down 56% to US$56.6m on expected credit loss allowance
summary: Geo Energy Resources reported a net profit of US$56.6 million for the second half of 2022, down 56% from US$129.8 million in the same period in 2021, due to allowances for expected credit losses and a higher effective tax rate. Revenue fell 13% to US$365.1 million, while coal sales volume declined slightly to 10.2 million tonnes. The company attributed the decline to lower sales volume and higher average selling price.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

One of the world’s biggest greenhouse gas emitters, Indonesia last year set a more ambitious target for reducing carbon emission by 31.89 per cent on its own, or 43.2 per cent with international support, by 2030.

North Queensland Export Terminal, which is controlled by Adani family trust, is being considered to raise funds for the group, according to the report on Monday, citing sources aware of the fund-raising.
Gear said the distribution-in-specie is meant to reduce its exposure to energy coal, which is facing scrutiny as a fuel source.

site_title: CSE Global H2 earnings fall to S$0.2m on restructuring costs, project overruns
summary: CSE Global, a technology solutions provider, reported a second-half profit of S$0.2 million, down from S$4.9 million in 2021, due to restructuring costs and project overruns. The company attributed the decline to a one-off restructuring cost of S$1.3 million and cost overruns of S$5.9 million in two projects. Despite revenue growth of 26.2% to S$295.5 million, the company's margins were impacted by supply chain disruptions. The board recommended a final dividend of S$0.015 per share, unchanged from 2021, and shares closed flat at S$0.35.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Lim Boon Kheng, group managing director of CSE Global, said: "The continued supply chain disruptions are expected to prolong project execution timeframes and have an impact on our gross margins."
CSE Global expects the acquisition will be earnings accretive and be a strategic fit to complement its current business.

site_title: Air India to fund US$70 billion plane order with cash, equity amid overseas push
summary: Air India plans to fund its record $70 billion aircraft order with internal cash, equity, and sale-and-leasebacks. The airline will buy 220 planes from Boeing and 250 from Airbus, aiming to expand its presence in international markets. CEO Campbell Wilson says the order will significantly increase Air India's wide-body long-haul fleet and capacity, particularly in long-haul international routes to North America and Europe. The airline is also refurbishing and upgrading its planes, hiring over 4,200 cabin crew and 900 pilots, as it seeks to compete with bigger rivals.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 2, 2020, an Air India plane is seen parked at the Indira Gandhi International airport in New Delhi. - Hackers have stolen data on about 4.5 million Air India passengers around the world in the latest breach reported by a major airline. (Photo by Money SHARMA / AFP)

site_title: JPMorgan investment arm purges its ESG funds of Adani stocks
summary: JPMorgan's investment arm has purged its environmental, social, and governance (ESG) funds of Adani stocks after a short-seller report alleged the conglomerate committed fraud and market manipulation. The move comes as other major firms, including BlackRock, have reduced their exposure to Adani due to concerns over the company's ties to coal. The Adani Group has rejected the claims and continues to bleed money, losing roughly $150 billion in combined market capital since the report was released. Regulators are under pressure to stay on top of systemic risks, including the lack of clarity and regulatory definition around index funds.

images.alt_text: Gautam Adani, who chairs Indian conglomerate Adani Group. Adani Enterprises last week set the floor price for India’s largest follow-on public offer (FPO) at 3,112 rupees per share, with a price cap of 3,276 rupees apiece.

North Queensland Export Terminal, which is controlled by Adani family trust, is being considered to raise funds for the group, according to the report on Monday, citing sources aware of the fund-raising.
The Adani Group is seeking to stem the negative fallout from the Hindenburg claims as it faces debt maturities from a number of its companies by the end of next year.

Signage of Adani Group in Mumbai, India, on Friday, Jan. 27, 2023. Shares of Adani Group’s companies have lost more than $30 billion in market value in less than two sessions, as a selloff sparked by US short seller Hindenburg Research’s scathing report deepened on Friday. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the wall of its realty office building on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
More than 500 funds registered in the European Union as “promoting” ESG goals hold Adani stocks, either directly or indirectly, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

Signage of Adani Group in Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, on Feb. 15, 2023. Adani Group said it has adequate cash reserves and its listed companies are able to refinance their debts, in a credit report aimed at reassuring investors after a critical investigation by US short-seller Hindenburg Research last month.. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg
The attack on the Adani Group by short-seller Hindenburg Research has rocked India's financial markets.

site_title: Toyota production up 9% in January, chip pain still lingers
summary: Toyota boosted global vehicle production by 9% in January, its first increase in two months, despite ongoing chip shortages. The company produced 689,090 vehicles globally, a 8.8% increase from the same month last year. However, global sales slipped 5.6% to 709,870 vehicles, reflecting the continued impact of the chip shortage. Smaller rivals Honda and Nissan also reported declines in production, with Honda output falling 21.7% and Nissan production falling by a quarter.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor (left) agreed to give the largest wage hikes in two decades according to its union and Honda Motor said it will raise wages by 5 per cent, including the biggest increase in base pay in about 30 years.

steering17



Source/copyright/credit: Big Fish Publishing Pte Ltd

Toyota Motor this week unveiled its new game plan under incoming chief executive officer Koji Sato, laying out several changes across the enormous business as it pushes harder towards electrification.

Koji Sato (centre), incoming president and chief executive officer of Toyota Motor, (from left) Kazuaki Shingo, incoming chief production officer, Yoichi Miyazaki, incoming chief financial officer, Hiroki Nakajima, incoming chief technology officer, and Simon Humphries, incoming chief branding officer.

site_title: Indonesia to boost oil palm replanting efforts, says senior official
summary: Indonesia aims to boost its oil palm replanting efforts, targeting 180,000 hectares this year, despite a five-year failure to meet the initial target. The government has simplified requirements and called for improved coordination and private sector involvement to meet the new goal. The move comes amid increased pressure from the European Union's new deforestation law, which requires companies to provide due-diligence statements on commodity production.

images.alt_text: Oiltek cheif executive Henry Yong says that the current order book is one of the highest the group has seen.
Indonesia and Malaysia have accused the EU of implementing discriminatory policies targetting palm oil.

Indonesia, the world’s top palm oil exporter, issues export quotas for palm oil companies which have sold a proportion of their products to the domestic market, under a policy known as “Domestic Market Obligation” (DMO).

site_title: Indonesia’s miner Amman Mineral Internasional seeks IPO
summary: Indonesian copper and gold miner Amman Mineral Internasional has submitted documents for an initial public offering (IPO), according to a financial regulator official. The miner operates the Batu Hijau copper and gold mine in Indonesia's West Nusa Tenggara province, with 25,000 hectares of concession areas and reserves of 17.54 billion pounds of copper and 23.9 million ounces of gold. The IPO's details, including the amount to be raised and timeline, remain undisclosed as the regulator reviews the documents.

site_title: Thai January rice export volume up 75.2% y-o-y
summary: Thailand's rice exports for January rose 75.2% year-over-year to 805,519 tonnes, valued at 14.28 billion baht. The growth was driven by year-end orders, higher demand from the Middle East, and a weak baht currency. The Middle East was the only growing market for Thai rice, taking 2.02 million tonnes. Despite the surge, the Commerce Ministry maintains its overall rice export target of 7.5 million tonnes for 2023.

site_title: March will bring bear-market risks for US stocks, says Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley strategists predict a high-risk month for US stocks in March due to faltering earnings and high valuations. The S&P 500 has dropped for three straight weeks amid concerns over sticky US inflation and potential rate hikes. Analysts expect stocks to trade lower, with a possible 24% decline to 3,000 points in the first half of the year, citing a "valuation is broadly expensive" outlook.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore Exchange, losers outnumber gainers 83 to 35 after 63.8 million securities worth S$49.8 million changed hands.
The yield of the 10-year US Treasury note climbed closer to four per cent in a sign of rising expectations for more Fed interest rate hikes.

site_title: China’s Tencent sets up team to develop ChatGPT-like product: sources
summary: China's Tencent has established a team to develop a ChatGPT-like chatbot called "HunyuanAide", incorporating its AI training model "Hunyuan". This move comes as Tencent, Alibaba Group, and Baidu also work on similar products. The company initially stated on February 9 that it was researching ChatGPT-tool technology. Local media outlet 36kr first reported the "HunyuanAide" project on February 27.

site_title: China banking tycoon Bao Fan ‘cooperating with investigation’
summary: Chinese banking tycoon Bao Fan, 52, is cooperating with an investigation by authorities, his company announced. Bao, chairman of China Renaissance, disappeared on February 16, sparking concerns of a crackdown on the financial services industry. The company did not provide details about the investigation, but said it would cooperate with authorities. Bao's disappearance follows a series of high-profile cases of Chinese financiers falling foul of the authorities, including Alibaba's Jack Ma and Chinese-Canadian businessman Xiao Jianhua.

images.alt_text: Fan Bao, chairman and chief executive officer of China Renaissance Group, pauses during a Bloomberg West television interview in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Wednesday, June 15, 2016. China Renaissance Partners provides financial solutions na advisory services operating as an investment bank providing services to entrepreneurs, multi-nationals and institutional investors. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Incoming BOJ head says shift to tighter policy only if inflation heightens significantly
summary: Bank of Japan Governor-elect Kazuo Ueda stated that the central bank will exit its massive stimulus only when Japan's trend inflation reaches the 2% target significantly. Ueda emphasized that trend inflation must improve before the BOJ shifts to tighter policy, and the current ultra-easy policy is necessary to maintain growth benefits. He also expressed openness to reviewing the BOJ's monetary easing framework and suggested that any overhaul of Yield Curve Control may not come immediately. Ueda's nomination is expected to be approved by parliament, following which he will succeed incumbent Haruhiko Kuroda in April.

images.alt_text: With inflation in Japan exceeding the central bank's 2 per cent target, the outlook for the economy and wages will be key to how soon the Bank of Japan could phase out its massive stimulus programme.

site_title: UOL H2 earnings down 44% to S$120.8 million; special dividend recommended
summary: UOL Group reported a net profit of S$120.8 million for the second half of FY2022, down 44% from the same period in FY2021. Revenue from property development rose 11% to S$977.4 million, driven by higher progressive recognition of revenue from Clavon and The Watergardens at Canberra. The company attributed the improved performance to a strong showing from property development and hotel operations. A special cash dividend of S$0.03 per share was recommended, with a record date to be announced later.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Generic photo of condos and private properties
Meyer Park overlooks a two-storey landed housing estate with a sweeping sea view and is well-connected to several expressways, including the Marina Coastal Expressway.

site_title: Skinny yields on prime office buildings may not be sustainable
summary: Singapore's office property market experienced a strong run in 2022, with the Urban Redevelopment Authority's central region office rental index rising 11.7%. However, high interest rates may put pressure on capital values, with yields on prime office buildings potentially needing to expand to reflect borrowing costs. Despite this, demand for Grade A office space remains strong, driven by sectors such as technology, finance, and life sciences. The yield for office space may need to expand substantially to make sense in a high interest rate environment, potentially impacting transactions and valuations.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
pixgenerics / ST20221207_202295518537 / Alphonsus Chern // Generic photograph of the Marina Bay Financial Centre (L) and other tall buildings in the city centre. 07 December 2022.

site_title: Oil lower on firm dollar, market shrugs off Russian supply cuts
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, down 0.3% for WTI and 0.36% for Brent, as a stronger dollar offset gains from Russia's planned 25% oil supply cuts in March. The dollar's strength makes US-commodity priced oil more expensive for holders of other currencies, leading to decreased demand. US crude inventories surged to a seven-month high, adding to market volatility. The market is also awaiting China's manufacturing surveys for direction on oil demand, which could influence prices further.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$83.16 a barrel, up 95 cents, or 1.2 per cent.

site_title: Sembmarine narrows H2 loss to S$118.3 million on execution, completion of projects
summary: Sembmarine narrowed its second-half net loss to S$118.3 million, down from S$523.3 million in 2021, due to higher contributions from floater and offshore platforms projects, as well as repairs and upgrades business. The company reported Ebitda positivity and trimmed its full-year loss to S$261.1 million. Turnover fell 16.3% in the second half, but revenue rose 4.6% for the full year. Sembmarine's new contract wins totaled S$7 billion in 2022, and its net order book rose to S$6.75 billion.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger.
The plunge in Sembmarine's stock on Monday came on the back of record short-selling volume which accounted for 24 per cent of the day's total trades

site_title: Impact-first investing: A different type of philanthropy
summary: Impact-first investing prioritizes social and environmental impact alongside financial returns, empowering social enterprises to scale and create lasting change. This approach, championed by investors, offers a strategic means to give back to society, providing patient capital, community, and collaboration to help businesses thrive. By challenging traditional philanthropy, impact-first investing aims to create a better and more sustainable world, where businesses prioritize both profit and positive impact, and stakeholders expect companies to adhere to ethical and sustainable practices.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Condo resale prices in Singapore dropped 0.6% month-on-month in January, marking the first decline in 28 months. The city fringe and suburban areas saw the steepest price drops. Services sector growth slowed to 10.9% in Q4 2022, down from 15.9% in Q3. Tightening access to lower-skilled foreign workers may improve job outcomes for locals, according to Manpower Minister Tan See Leng. Singapore shares closed lower on Monday, tracking Wall Street losses, with the STI down 0.6%.

site_title: South Korean corporate K-pop battle likely to drag on as SM resists takeover
summary: South Korean entertainment company SM Entertainment is resisting a takeover by HYBE, which manages K-pop group BTS, after HYBE acquired a 14.8% stake in the company. SM announced a new shareholder return policy to keep small investors happy, but HYBE accused SM of trying to obstruct its efforts. The two companies are engaging in a lengthy battle, with SM's shares trading at 120,300 won, just shy of HYBE's tender offer price. The outcome is uncertain, with individual shareholders' votes set to be decided at a shareholders' meeting.

site_title: Dow and Sport Singapore said they would recycle our shoes. We found them for sale in Batam
summary: Reuters tracked 11 donated shoes from Singapore to Indonesia, where they were sold by a company called Yok Impex, rather than being recycled into exercise paths or kids' parks as promised by the Singapore Government and US petrochemicals giant Dow. The shoes were donated to a recycling program in July 2022, but were instead exported to Indonesia, where they were sold to second-hand goods exporters. Dow has opened an investigation into the matter and has removed Yok Impex from the project. The findings raise concerns about the effectiveness of the recycling program and the environmental impact of the exported shoes, which have added to Indonesia's already bulging landfills.

images.alt_text: The lay-offs come after PouYuen put 20,000 of its workers on paid leave in rotation at the end of last year.

site_title: Quantum computing revolution approaches
summary: The era of quantum computing is approaching, driven by the need for agility and accelerated digital maturity to address global challenges like climate change and population growth. Quantum computing uses quantum physics to solve problems beyond classical computers, leveraging principles of interference and entanglement. IBM is pioneering quantum computing systems on the cloud, compilers and algorithms are advancing, and communities of quantum-proficient talent are growing. Quantum computing will not replace classical computing but extend and complement it, offering new tools for data analysis and revolutionizing portfolio management and risk analysis.

images.alt_text: IBM's 433-qubits Osprey quantum processor, with more than three times the qubits of the IBM Eagle processor.
Quantum computers and related technologies – such as quantum sensing and cryptography – could revolutionise everyday life.
Google scientists said on Wednesday they have passed a major milestone in their quest to develop effective quantum computing, with a new study showing they reduced the rate of errors.

site_title: HSBC to halve London head office space: report
summary: HSBC is reviewing its London head office space, aiming to halve its current 500,000 sq ft space by 2027. The bank is considering a new headquarters of 400,000-500,000 sq ft, as it cuts global office space by 40% compared to pre-pandemic levels. This move follows a trend of firms adapting to remote and hybrid working patterns, with 25% of London businesses downsizing office holdings and 18% opting for co-working spaces.

site_title: Everything Everywhere dominates SAG awards, setting stage for Oscars
summary: Everything Everywhere All at Once dominated the Screen Actors Guild Awards, winning top honors for best film ensemble, lead female actor Michelle Yeoh, and supporting actors Ke Huy Quan and Jamie Lee Curtis. The film's victory cements its status as the front-runner for the best picture prize at the upcoming Oscars. With wins at the Directors Guild and Producers Guild awards, and a commercial success selling over $107 million worth of tickets, Everything Everywhere All at Once is poised to sweep the major awards ceremonies.

images.alt_text: Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh poses with the award for Best Actress - Motion Picture - Musical/Comedy for "Everything Everywhere All at Once" in the press room during the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards at The Beverly Hilton hotel in Beverly Hills, California, on January 10, 2023.

site_title: Indian retailer Fabindia scraps US$482 million IPO amid uncertain market conditions
summary: Indian apparel retailer Fabindia has withdrawn its US$482 million initial public offering (IPO) amid uncertain market conditions due to interest-rate worries. The company, known for sustainable and traditional Indian wear, may consider going public in the future despite global funds expressing interest in investing. This move follows e-commerce company Snapdeal and wearable electronics business boAt withdrawing their IPOs, and jewellery retailer Joyalukkas also scrapping plans. Market sentiment is weak, with India's benchmark Nifty 50 stock index down 4% this year due to inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: Office workers  walk past  a BYD showroom in Shanghai,  China, on Wednesday, August 31 2022.
Chinese electric vehicle start-up Nio was amongst those who led large IPOs issuance last year.
Next year’s optimism for India is driven by strong corporate earnings, a post-pandemic retail boom and an economy set to grow by 6 per cent in the next fiscal year.
Europe is becoming a more appealing listing venue for Chinese firms than the US.

site_title: Will the Fed manage a ‘soft’ or ‘hard’ or ‘no’ landing?
summary: The US Federal Reserve is signaling more rate hikes to combat inflation, raising concerns of a hard economic landing. A soft landing, where inflation is curbed without triggering a recession, is the Fed's ideal outcome, but economists and investors are uncertain about its feasibility. The Fed has previously achieved soft landings in 1994-1995 and 2001, but the current economic environment is uncertain, with inflation still above the 2% target and the pandemic's impact still felt. The outcome could be a "growth recession," a protracted period of slow growth and rising unemployment, or no landing at all, with the economy potentially reverting to its pre-pandemic trajectory.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly
A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 17, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Hong Kong exports plunge by most in 70 years
summary: Hong Kong's exports plummeted 36.7% in January, the largest decline in 70 years, due to waning global demand and the Lunar New Year break. Exports to Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, and Vietnam dropped 50%, 45.2%, more than 40%, and nearly 44% respectively. This was worse than expected, with imports declining 30.2% from a year ago. The trade deficit was HK$25.4 billion, marking a significant decline in trade activity.

images.alt_text: The city is looking to kickstart its economy as it sees rising competition from Singapore to be Asia’s top destination for business, talent and capital.

site_title: Maybank Q4 earnings inch up 5.4% to RM2.2b on higher interest income
summary: Maybank reported a net profit of RM2.2 billion for the fourth fiscal quarter, up 5.4% from the same period in 2021. Interest income increased 52.4% to RM6.5 billion, while interest expense more than doubled to RM3 billion. The bank declared a second interim cash dividend of RM0.30 per ordinary share and targets a return on equity of 10.5-11% for FY2023. Maybank will continue to focus on growth opportunities across its consumer and business segments within its Asean franchise, maintaining its liquidity position to support asset growth.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Governor of Bank Indonesia Perry Warjiyo, 63, is a career central banker who has played a key role in reforming Bank Indonesia’s (BI) monetary policy mix and its pandemic response.

site_title: SportSG, Dow apologise for shoe-recycling lapse, say process chain ‘vulnerabilities’ caused it
summary: SportSG and Dow have apologized for a shoe-recycling program lapse, where donated shoes ended up in Indonesian shops due to "vulnerabilities in the process chain" involving a subcontractor, Yok Impex. The shoes, which were meant for recycling into building materials, were instead extracted and exported to other countries. The partners have taken steps to address the issue, including stopping collection bins from being sent to Yok Impex and tightening up the process chain. Despite the mistake, 10,000 kg of used shoes have been successfully recycled into infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
None of the 11 pairs of footwear donated by Reuters were turned into exercise paths or kids’ parks in Singapore.

site_title: Plastic consumption on course to nearly double by 2050: research
summary: Research by Back to Blue predicts plastic consumption in G20 countries will nearly double by 2050 unless a comprehensive global treaty is drawn up to curb consumption. Existing programs only "scratched the surface," requiring a more comprehensive plan. The United Nations is negotiating a legally binding treaty, with 175 countries signed up, but failure to reach an agreement could lead to a 451 million-tonne increase in annual plastic production by 2050. A more aggressive ban on single-use plastics, higher production taxes, and mandatory recycling schemes could limit annual consumption to 325 million tonnes.

images.alt_text: A garbage collector gathering recyclable plastic at the Ban Tarn landfill site in Chiang Mai, Thailand.

site_title: Pfizer in talks to buy Seagen for likely for more than US$30 billion: WSJ
summary: Pfizer is in early talks to acquire Seagen, a US$30 billion drugmaker, according to the Wall Street Journal. The deal is in preliminary stages, with Seagen's market value expected to command a premium. This comes after the company was in advanced talks last year with Merck, which ultimately failed to reach an agreement. Pfizer declined to comment on the report, while Seagen did not immediately respond.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street losses; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to close at 3,263.24 on Monday, following losses on Wall Street. The decline was attributed to higher-than-expected US core pricing figures driving up rate-hike expectations. The STI's biggest loser was Venture Corporation, while DFI Retail Group was the top gainer. Local banks OCBC and UOB traded mixed, with DBS losing 0.2%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Boustead Singapore is offering to buy Boustead Projects at S$0.95 per share
On the Singapore Exchange, losers outnumber gainers 83 to 35 after 63.8 million securities worth S$49.8 million changed hands.

site_title: Germany’s Commerzbank makes stock index comeback
summary: Commerzbank, Germany's second-largest lender, rejoined the country's primary stock index, the DAX, after being removed in 2018. The bank's CEO, Manfred Knof, stated, "We have come to stay," as the lender marked a comeback following a major overhaul two years ago, which included closing branches and cutting thousands of jobs to restore profitability. The return is seen as a positive signal for the German banking market, indicating the bank's commitment to staying.

images.alt_text: Net profit of 472 million euros (S$674.1 million) in the quarter was higher than 421 million euros a year earlier.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on November 19, 2020 Markus Braun, the former chief executive of disgraced payments giant Wirecard, waits to face a public grilling by German lawmakers over the massive accounting fraud that brought down his firm, in Berlin. - More than two years after the collapse of German digital payments firm Wirecard stunned the financial world, ex-CEO Markus Braun and two former managers will go on trial for fraud on December 8, 2022. (Photo by FABRIZIO BENSCH / POOL / AFP)

site_title: World Bank’s IFC to provide Sri Lanka with US$400 million financing
summary: The International Finance Corporation (IFC) has agreed to provide Sri Lanka with a $400 million cross-currency swap facility to fund essential imports, including medicine, food, and fertiliser. This move aims to provide a foreign exchange cushion for the country, which is struggling with its worst financial crisis in over seven decades. The funds will be provided to three private banks, which handle over 30% of Sri Lanka's remittances and exports. The move is expected to boost confidence in the investor community and attract fresh capital inflows to support the Sri Lankan economy.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe refused to fund local polls saying that holding one during an economic crisis could be disastrous.
Opposition activists attacking police during a protest to get the government to hold local council elections on March 9. The election commission says it does not have funds to hold the polls.

site_title: Japan’s G7 focus will be geopolitics, not economics
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida chaired a virtual summit of Western presidents and prime ministers, highlighting the G7's growing focus on geopolitics amidst the Ukraine war. The group has pledged tens of billions of dollars in military and humanitarian assistance, and is planning to rebuild Ukraine in a post-war Marshall Plan-style initiative. This marks a shift in the G7's priorities, with geopolitical and security issues assuming paramount importance, showcasing Japan's leadership in this new direction.

images.alt_text: Attendees at the second meeting of the G20 Finance and Central Bank Deputies on Feb 22, in Bengaluru, India
Japan’s Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said the G7 needs to assess the effectiveness of current sanctions on Russia before deciding on further action.

Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman says: “Although there was not what we would call a communique, but only an outcome statement, we still think we’ve made some progress in having all the ministers on board.”

site_title: Indonesia’s rupiah charges to the top of Asia’s best-performing currencies
summary: The Indonesian rupiah has surged to the top of Asia's best-performing currencies, but its rally may be short-lived due to rising US interest rates and a potential shift in Indonesia's current-account balance. The rupiah has gained over 2% against the US dollar this year, but bond outflows and a weakening currency have eroded its momentum. Risks to the outlook are building, and analysts predict the rupiah may lose its top spot to the Thai baht and South Korea's won if Indonesia's currency falters.

images.alt_text: Almost two-thirds of the 21 companies that listed in Jakarta over the past decade finished their debut session higher than the listing price.

Joko Widodo, Indonesia's president, speaks during the Mandiri Investment Forum in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Wednesday, Feb. 1, 2023. The annual investment forum co-hosted by Bank Mandiri and Mandiri Sekuritas will continue through Feb. 2. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: The crusade to ban ESG makes no sense
summary: US Governor Ron DeSantis is leading the conservative war against Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) investment guidelines, which he claims threaten the American economy and economic freedom. Republican lawmakers have proposed over 49 laws to restrict ESG, targeting private investors and banks. The effort is seen as misguided, as ESG has been shown to have potential financial rewards, particularly in corporate governance reforms. Critics argue that ESG is not a substitute for government regulation, and that private investors should be allowed to pursue ESG goals without interference.

images.alt_text: Gov. Ron Desantis is joined onstage by his wife Casey as he speaks to supporters at a victory celebration in Tampa on Tuesday night, Nov. 8, 2022. DeSantis coasted to re-election, defeating his Democratic challenger, Charlie Crist. (Scott McIntyre/The New York Times)

site_title: China’s factory activity likely continued to grow in February: Reuters poll
summary: China's factory activity is expected to continue growing in February, according to a Reuters poll, driven by domestic orders and consumption. This follows the country's economic activity swinging back to growth in January. Economists expect the official manufacturing PMI to improve to 50.5, indicating expansion. Despite Covid passing through the population faster than expected, factory gate prices fell in January, but optimism is building, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a strong PMI reading of 51 in February. China's central bank expects the domestic economy to generally rebound in 2023.

site_title: China new home sales rise sharply in February: private survey
summary: China's new home sales rose sharply in February, with a 31.9% month-on-month increase, according to a private survey. This rebound follows a 34.3% fall in January, driven by a rise in demand in small and medium-sized cities after Covid curbs were lifted and supportive property policies were implemented. The sector has seen a near-term recovery amid slow economic growth, with home sales rising 63.8% in tier-three cities and 43.9% in tier-two cities.

site_title: Adani in talks for US$400 million debt against Australian coal port assets: report
summary: India's Adani Group is in talks to raise up to $400 million in debt against its Australian coal port assets, controlled by the North Queensland Export Terminal. The conglomerate has discussed with global credit funds, receiving two indicative term sheets from hedge fund Farallon Capital. This move comes after Australia's corporate regulator announced it would review a short-seller report criticizing Adani Group. The group operates the Carmichael coal mine and related rail line in Australia, as well as a solar farm.

site_title: JPMorgan proposes new Asia credit index with lower China weighting: sources
summary: JPMorgan proposes a new Asia credit index, Jaci Asia-Pacific, with a lower China weighting of around 30%, down from 43% in its existing index.
