The move comes amid heightened tensions between Washington and Beijing, and growing concerns over China's economic performance. The new index will include exposure to more Asia-Pacific markets, such as Japan, Australia, and New Zealand, and aims to reduce "single-country risk" and provide better risk-adjusted returns. The proposal is seen as a response to investor concerns over China's debt and geopolitical risks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A JPMorgan logo is seen in New York City, U.S., January 10, 2017. REUTERS/Stephanie Keith/File Photo

site_title: Four appear in Hong Kong court charged with gruesome murder of model Abby Choi
summary: Four people, including Abby Choi's ex-husband Alex Kwong and his family members, have been charged with murder in connection with the gruesome killing of 28-year-old model Abby Choi. Choi's body was found in a village house in Hong Kong, and police discovered a meat slicer and electric saw at the scene. All four defendants were denied bail and the court adjourned the hearing until May 8. The charges include murder and obstructing the case.

site_title: China accuses US of endangering peace in Taiwan Strait with military fly-through
summary: China has accused the US of endangering peace in the Taiwan Strait after a US P-8A Poseidon military plane flew through the sensitive waterway. China claims sovereignty, sovereign rights, and jurisdiction over the narrow strait, while the US and Taiwan consider it an international waterway. This incident is the latest in a series of military missions by the US in the area, which China has deemed provocative. China's Eastern Theatre Command stated that its forces monitored the US aircraft, escalating tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Achieving ‘peak plastics’ by 2050 requires bold moves on bans, taxes, recycling all at once
summary: A study by ocean science organization Back to Blue found that governments must agree on taxing single-use plastics, mandating producers to share recycling costs, and taxing virgin resin to prevent the world from reaching "peak plastics" by 2050. Without these policies, plastic consumption among G20 countries is expected to nearly double, with a ban on single-use plastics being the most effective approach, followed by extended producer responsibility and a tax on virgin resin. However, even with all three policies, plastic use will still fail to peak by 2050, and the UN treaty may need to be strengthened to reverse the plastic tide.

images.alt_text: The tax measure, which needs to be approved by the Senate before a reconciled Bill is sent to President Marcos for signature, is expected to raise to raise 9.3 billion pesos in revenues annually.
Toh Shuhui, partner, Tax Services, at Ernst & Young Solutions LLP.

The study by the Ellen MacArthur Foundation and the UN Environment Programme revealed that some companies - including Coca-Cola and Pepsi – are using more virgin plastic despite a pledge to reduce its use.

At the International Solid Waste Association (ISWA) World Congress on Wednesday (Sep 21), Minister Grace Fu said the Government sees it as a priority to “get our economic policies right, to signal that there is a high environmental cost to unsustainable practices”.

FILE Ñ FILE Ñ Shoppers at a mall in Beijing on Sept. 24, 2022. China on Monday, Oct. 24, 2022, reported a modest rebound in economic activity for the quarter ending in September. (Gilles Sabri/The New York Times)
Thailand generates about 2 million metric tons of plastic waste annually, of which only about a quarter is recycled, according to the government.

site_title: Jobs-Skills Integrators: execution must go beyond coordination
summary: Singapore's Jobs-Skills Integrators (JSI) initiative aims to empower every Singaporean to have lifelong employability amid an uncertain world. The program seeks to address the complexities of the jobs-skills nexus by linking industry, training, and employment facilitation partners. To succeed, the JSI needs to connect with various stakeholders for a holistic view of the jobs-skills integration program, develop and curate training programs, consolidate worker supply, facilitate seamless matching, and manage programs and funding. Effective execution requires an agile mindset to learn, adapt, and course-correct as implementation scales up.

images.alt_text: Generic photo on growing our economy and equipping our workers

site_title: Tightening access to lower-skilled foreign workers more likely to improve job outcomes for locals: MOM
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Tan See Leng stated that tightening access to lower-skilled foreign workers is more likely to improve job outcomes for locals, as businesses can substitute cheaper foreign workers with locals, leading to locals taking on jobs at "slightly higher levels". However, there is a limit to tightening access due to the small population, and the government will maintain a disciplined stance in regulating foreign workers. This approach aims to balance access to high-quality professionals with regulated foreign worker quotas and levies.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore does not adjust the number of EPs and S Passes  it issues in response to business fluctuations, said Manpower Minister Tan See Leng

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, Venture Corp, SingLand, Raffles Medical, ComfortDelGro, Hotel Properties
summary: Several Singaporean companies reported earnings for the second half of 2022, with notable declines seen at Olam Group, Singapore Land Group, and UOB Kay Hian, while Raffles Medical Group, ComfortDelGro, and Hotel Properties posted significant gains. Venture Corporation also reported an increase in net profit. The STI rose 0.5% amid the mixed earnings reports, snapping a four-day losing streak.

images.alt_text: In the wider Singapore market, advancers outnumbered decliners 293 to 250, with 1.37 billion securities worth S$1.17 billion traded.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades Grab to ‘buy’; raises target price on recovery prospects
summary: Maybank Securities has upgraded Grab to a "buy" rating and raised its target price to US$3.80 from US$3.40, citing recovery prospects due to easing competition, rising ride demand, and earlier breakeven guidance. The research house expects the delivery segment to deliver US$183 million in Ebitda for FY2023, driven by expansion in margins and growth in GMV. Meanwhile, the mobility segment is projected to grow by 45% due to recovery of tourism and reduced incentives. The upgrade follows Grab's narrower-than-expected net loss for FY2022 and analyst Kelvin Tan's revised revenue forecasts.

images.alt_text: Grab's attempts to scale up its supply comes as commuters face longer waiting times and fare surges due to the driver shortage.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop on rate fears as US inflation runs hot
summary: Asian markets dropped on Monday as US inflation data reinforced expectations of continued interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. The report on the personal consumption expenditures price index followed blockbuster jobs figures and slower-than-expected price declines. This has wiped out optimism for a pause in monetary tightening and potential borrowing cost cuts before the end of the year. Traders will monitor comments from bank officials this week for a more hawkish direction, potentially leading to further rate hikes.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore Exchange, losers outnumber gainers 83 to 35 after 63.8 million securities worth S$49.8 million changed hands.

site_title: Developing a talent strategy to build new businesses
summary: Business leaders in Asia-Pacific are prioritizing building new businesses as a top-five strategic priority, with 71% expecting 28% of future revenue to come from these ventures. Successful corporate ventures require a deep bench of tech talent and experienced leadership, with key factors including finding an experienced CEO, adopting a flexible recruitment strategy, and providing beyond compensation. A well-structured compensation model, workplace flexibility, and prioritizing employees' mental health and wellness are also crucial for attracting and retaining talent. By focusing on these areas, business leaders can enable their corporate ventures to succeed in today's digital environment.

images.alt_text: One advantage of Indonesia is the market of about 280 million people, but SBF's country head for Indonesia Hisyaamuddin Abu Bakar noted that the Indonesia market is a “marathon game” for companies.
Under Forrest Li, Sea Ltd has built up a huge war chest, and taken quick action to refocus on profitability rather than growth.

site_title: Billionaire owners of luxury hotels plan to start cruise ship operations
summary: Billionaire hotel owners are planning to enter the luxury cruise ship market, with Marriott International and Aman Resorts set to launch their offerings in 2025. Four Seasons, owned by Bill Gates and Prince Al-Waleed bin Talal, is also planning to debut its luxury cruise line. This move comes as existing operators struggle to pay down debts incurred during the pandemic and seek to capture the premium market. The new entrants aim to offer high-end experiences, including residential-style suites and exclusive amenities, to attract high-spending customers.

images.alt_text: US travel spending in December 2022 totalled US$97 billion, 3 per cent above 2019 levels and 7 per cent above 2021 levels, according to the US Travel Association.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop 1.4% as miners drag, US rate-hike bets spook investors
summary: Australian shares fell 1.4% to 7202.1, marking the third consecutive weekly loss, amid concerns over a prolonged US interest rate hike cycle following stronger-than-expected economic data. Mining stocks led losses, with BHP and Rio Tinto down 2.8% and 2.6%, respectively. The Reserve Bank of Australia has flagged additional rate hikes to control inflation. US rate-hike bets spooked investors, with technology stocks down 1.7% and healthcare down 1.4%.

images.alt_text: Best World International reported a 7.1 per cent year on year dip in net profit to S$47.7 million.
Australia's move comes after a rise in cyber attacks since late last year with breaches reported by at least eight companies, including health insurer Medibank and telco Optus, owned by Singtel.

site_title: 'Ant-Man' stumbles but still tops North America box office
summary: "Disney's 'Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania' topped the North American box office with an estimated US$32.2 million in ticket sales, a 70% drop from its opening weekend. In second place was Universal's 'Cocaine Bear', followed by Lionsgate's 'Jesus Revolution'. The top 5 films were: 'Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania', 'Cocaine Bear', 'Jesus Revolution', 'Avatar: The Way of Water', and 'Puss in Boots: The Last Wish'. Despite a decline, 'Quantumania' remains the highest-grossing film of the weekend."

images.alt_text: That rather paltry total for the Warner Bros film, Magic Mike’s Last Dance starring Channing Tatum and Salma Hayek was doubtless hurt by National Football League’s Super Bowl.

site_title: Australia plans to reform cyber security rules, set up agency
summary: Australia plans to reform its cyber security rules and establish an agency to oversee government investment and coordinate responses to cyber attacks. The move comes after several high-profile breaches, including those at health insurer Medibank and telco Optus. Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil said current rules are "not fit for purpose" and need reform, while Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will meet industry leaders to discuss a new cyber security strategy. The agency will be set up within the department of home affairs and will aim to improve cyber security in partnership with businesses.

images.alt_text: Australian Federal Police last month said Russia-based hackers were behind the Medibank cyberattack, which compromised the details of almost 10 million current and former customers.
TPG Telecom, which has its head office in Sydney, Australia, is among at least eight other Australian companies that have gone public about hacks since October.

site_title: Singapore’s key foreign policy priorities and principles for 2023
summary: Singapore Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan outlined the country's foreign policy priorities and principles for 2023, amid a "perfect storm of multiple interlocking crises". Key priorities include supporting international law, deepening bilateral relationships with Indonesia, Malaysia, and Brunei, and maintaining neutrality in global conflicts. Balakrishnan emphasized the importance of pragmatism and quiet confidence in navigating the complex geopolitical landscape, while also promoting regional integration and cooperation. Singapore will continue to uphold its sovereignty and national interests, and engage with other countries to address shared challenges such as climate change and economic disruption.

images.alt_text: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said he and Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim had had a fruitful discussion, including on how to make progress on “outstanding bilateral issues” during the latter's first official visit to the Republic.

Vietnam Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (left) and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong have met regularly since the latter took office in April 2021, including at this meeting in Washington, DC in May 2022.

site_title: China property price fall to deepen in H1 before rising faster in 2023: poll
summary: China's new home prices are expected to fall 1% in the first half of 2023 before rebounding at a faster pace of 2.5% in 2023, according to a Reuters poll. The expected decline in the first half is deeper than the 0.5% forecast in a previous poll, while sales are expected to slump 9% in the first half. Analysts attribute the expected price fall to a recovering economy, improving sentiment, and a housing supply exceeding demand. A sustainable recovery is expected to begin in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: This aerial photo taken on December 3, 2022 shows a housing complex by Chinese property developer Evergrande in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Singapore services receipts growth slows to 10.9% in Q4 2022, will continue to ease in 2023
summary: Singapore's services industry experienced a slowdown in growth in Q4 2022, with a 10.9% year-on-year increase in business receipts. The easing of Covid-19 restrictions contributed to the growth, but reopening tailwinds are dissipating as sectors normalize to pre-pandemic levels. Economists expect services growth to continue easing in 2023 due to slowing global growth, but not contracting. The recreation and personal services industry saw the largest jump in takings, up 36.8% year-on-year, driven by increased earnings from the gaming and attractions segment.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Seeing the largest yearly increase in revenue in Q3 was the recreation and personal services industry, which Singstat said was mainly attributed to higher earnings of firms in the gaming and attractions segment.
On a seasonally adjusted, monthly basis, manufacturing output falls 1.1 per cent in January, reversing from an expansion in December 2022.

site_title: Hot stock: AEM falls to near 3-year low after H2 results release
summary: Semiconductor equipment maker AEM reported second half-year earnings of S$44 million, down 30% from the previous year, due to a 12% drop in revenue. The company warned of continued weakness in FY2023 due to a global slowdown and rising interest rates. DBS Group Research downgraded its call to "sell" and lowered its price target to S$2, citing a sluggish outlook for Intel, AEM's key customer. AEM's shares fell 9.8% to a near three-year low.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
AEM Holdings' headquarters at 53 Serangoon North Avenue 4.

site_title: Raffles Medical H2 profit rises 87.5% to S$83.8 million
summary: Raffles Medical Group reported an 87.5% increase in net profit for the second half of 2022 to S$83.8 million, driven by better cost control, manpower deployment, and lower inventories. Revenue rose 1.1% to S$384.2 million. The healthcare services provider saw a return of foreign patients to Singapore, while its China operations were impacted by the country's zero-Covid-19 policy. The group expects its core healthcare business in Singapore to continue growing and expanding, with a final dividend proposal of S$0.038 per share.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

The shortage of healthcare staff, particularly nurses, in Singapore is a concern for healthcare players

ST PHOTO : MALCOLM MCLEOD
Raffles Medical noted that year-to-date, net profit has surged 57.3 per cent to S$98.2 million.
CGS-CIMB has maintained an “add” rating on Raffles Medicap Group at a higher target price of S$1.60, up from S$1.50.

site_title: Public-sector healthtech agency IHiS to be anchor tenant at Elementum in one-north: sources
summary: IHiS, Singapore's public health technology agency, will be the anchor tenant at Elementum in one-north, relocating from its current space at 6 Serangoon North Avenue 5. IHiS will occupy approximately 200,000 sq ft of business park space, while other related entities will also join the project, which is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter of this year. The lease will be negotiated at a preferential rate, with market estimates suggesting a gross effective monthly rental of around S$6-plus per square foot.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
A general view shows office buildings in the Raffles Place financial business district in Singapore on January 12, 2023. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,272.89, down 9.41 points. The market saw 83 losers and 35 gainers, with Halcyon Agri and Sembcorp Marine being the most actively traded counters. Local banks had mixed activity, with OCBC and UOB remaining flat, while DBS fell 0.2%. The decline follows losses in US and European markets, which were influenced by hot inflation data and fears of monetary policy rate hikes.

images.alt_text: In the wider Singapore market, advancers outnumbered decliners 293 to 250, with 1.37 billion securities worth S$1.17 billion traded.

site_title: Most UK businesses optimistic about medium-term economic growth: survey
summary: UK businesses are optimistic about medium-term economic growth, with 61% expecting growth to be "somewhat or significantly better" in 2025. 63% also anticipate revenue growth over the next three years. This contrasts with the Bank of England's forecast of 0.7% annual growth in 2024 and 2025 without generating inflationary heat. Despite this, executives expect inflation to persist and 56% plan to increase prices. Meanwhile, over three-quarters of respondents expect their headcount to remain the same or grow, while 20% plan to cut staff.

images.alt_text: The CBI said its survey showed retailers were gloomy about their prospects for the coming three months amid “acute” price pressures.
While the Biden administration push, described by economists as an industrial policy, has opened opportunities for some companies, significant hurdles remain.
Labour, led by Keir Starmer, has promised to ensure Britain has the fastest growing economy among the G7 on a sustained basis if it wins power.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank says CapitaLand Investment fairly valued, downgrades to ‘hold’
summary: Maybank Securities downgraded its call on CapitaLand Investment to "hold" from "buy" due to a more balanced risk-reward profile at current valuations. The brokerage cut its price target to S$3.65 from S$4.30, accounting for lower market capitalization and a holding company discount. Analyst Krishna Guha expects a challenging capital recycling process, with a lower FY2023 profit forecast 38% below consensus. Despite this, Guha likes the stock for its restructuring story, steady fee business, and improving operations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The board has proposed a core dividend of S$0.12 per share and a special dividend-in-specie of 0.057 CapitaLand Ascott Trust units per share – valued at S$0.059 apiece.
The data centre development projects are expected to be completed in 2025 and will deliver over 100 megawatts (MW) of power.
The sale consideration of 13.5 billion rupees represents a premium of some 9 per cent to CLI’s valuation for the site in December 2021.

site_title: Twitter cuts more engineering, product jobs to curb costs
summary: Twitter has laid off dozens of employees, including those in engineering and product, as part of cost-cutting measures under Elon Musk's ownership. The layoffs follow Musk's previous elimination of 3,700 jobs last year. Employees were informed of their terminations via email or by being unable to log into the internal system. The exact number of affected employees is unclear, but sources suggest it's in the dozens. This move comes after Musk's US$44 billion acquisition of Twitter.

site_title: Singapore banks wrap up 2022 with record earnings, still positive on outlook for 2023
summary: Singapore's three major banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, reported record earnings for 2022, with DBS posting a 69% increase in net profit to S$2.34 billion. The banks remain optimistic about their 2023 performance, with DBS and UOB expecting interest rates to boost net interest margins (NIM) and DBS guiding for a peak NIM of 2.25%. The banks also raised their dividend payouts, with DBS paying a special dividend of S$0.50 per share. Analysts expect the banks to deliver further improvements in 2023, with UOB's acquisition of Citi's regional consumer banking business seen as a key growth driver.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
OCBC's net interest income for Q4 is up 60 per cent to S$894 million, driven by a 79 basis points rise in net interest margin.
UOB declared a dividend of S$0.75 per share for the period, up from S$0.60 in H2 2021.
XX

The rate of NIM expansion has likely started to moderate in the fourth quarter of 2022, analysts said. Nevertheless, the banks’ high capital levels and above-regulation provisioning coverage mean an upside surprise in dividends.

site_title: Offer for Boustead Projects was not so dull
summary: Boustead Singapore made a general offer to buy Boustead Projects at S$0.90 per share, sparking speculation of a potential price increase. However, the offer price remained unchanged at S$0.95 per share after the offeror revised its terms, citing a 90% threshold to cross. Minority shareholders dissatisfied with the offer price should hold out until the offeror crosses the 90% threshold, as there is no possibility of obtaining better terms. The Singapore Exchange allows a company to delist if the general offer is deemed fair and reasonable, and a determination by an independent financial adviser (IFA) could pave the way for delisting.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul

Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore. The company’s S$0.90 per share offer translates to a premium of 7.8 per cent over Boustead Projects’ last traded price per share of S$0.835 on the Singapore Exchange on Feb 3.
The revised offer price of S$0.95 per share will now represent 75.1 per cent of Boustead Project’s last reported NAV.

site_title: Dollar holds 7-week peak as inflation stays high
summary: The US dollar reached a seven-week peak as inflation data showed no signs of slowing, with the PCE price index rising 0.6% in January and consumer spending jumping 1.8%. The dollar index surged 0.6% to 105.20, while the euro was on pace for its largest weekly loss since September. Interest rate expectations remain high, with Fed funds futures pricing a peak rate of 5.395% in September and sustained above 5% for the year.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index – which measures the US currency against six others – was 0.2 per cent higher at 104.80, its highest since Jan 6.

site_title: USDJPY: Signs point to further upside
summary: The USD/JPY currency pair has rebounded to hover slightly below 135 after retracing 16% from its peak in October 2022, with technical analysts predicting further upside. A bullish breakout from an inverse head and shoulders pattern and an imminent bullish cross of the 20 EMA above the 50 EMA suggest the trend is gaining pace. Although a full-blown bull run is unlikely, the pair is expected to retrace slightly, retest, and establish support at levels around 132.88 and 131.58 before extending its gains to a technical target of 138.5.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index – which measures the US currency against six others – was 0.2 per cent higher at 104.80, its highest since Jan 6.

site_title: Condo resale prices fall for the first time in over two years; transactions dip 22.6% in January: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo resale prices in Singapore fell 0.6% month-on-month in January, marking the first decline in 28 months. According to SRX and 99.co, prices dropped due to a 22.6% decline in transactions. The decline was more pronounced in the Outside Central Region (OCR), where prices fell 1.2%, while the Core Central Region (CCR) saw a 2.5% increase. The decline was attributed to a decrease in demand, particularly in city fringe and suburban areas.

images.alt_text: MPs call for even more support for families' housing aspirations, extend support for unwed single mothers.
To address high housing prices, supply needs to be increased by ramping up BTO supply and catching up with pandemic-related delays, says DPM Wong.

site_title: Goldman turns to ‘make-or-break’ unit as CEO Solomon put to test
summary: Goldman Sachs' CEO David Solomon is set to present his plan to investors on the firm's "make-or-break" unit, Asset Wealth Management (AWM), which is seen as crucial to unlocking a higher valuation. The unit has faced criticism for its consumer banking strategy, which lost nearly $6 billion, and its use of the bank's balance sheet for investments. Executives plan to reassure investors that AWM can smooth out earnings and print profits through good times and bad, while also expanding its private wealth business and global banking and markets division. The presentation comes after a year of profits slumping by half and a failed foray into consumer banking.

images.alt_text: Stripe Inc. headquarters in San Francisco. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Olam H2 profit falls 24.5% on higher net financing costs
summary: Olam Group's net profit for the second half of 2022 fell 24.5% to S$200 million due to higher finance costs, which doubled over the period. Revenue grew 9.5% to S$26.5 billion, while earnings per share decreased 28.8%. The company proposed a final dividend of 4.5 cents per share, the same as the previous year. Despite a challenging year, Olam's co-founder and CEO Sunny Verghese said the group's reorganisation has led to a "sharper focus" and improved operating performance. The company remains committed to its IPO plans for Olam Agri and OFI.

site_title: WealthBT: Can critical illness cover be future-proofed? (Ep 23)
summary: WealthBT's podcast series discusses enhancing critical illness cover, which many people have but find insufficient. Financial expert Genevieve Cua advises taking up a multi-pay rider to cover recurrence of critical illnesses. This can future-proof one's coverage and provide more comprehensive protection. The podcast aims to educate affluent individuals on how to protect and grow their wealth, offering valuable insights for those seeking to optimize their financial security.

site_title: Can Singapore companies make a four-day week work? Here’s why it’s worth trying
summary: A six-month UK trial involving 60 companies and over 3,000 employees found that 91% of participating companies plan to continue a four-day work week after experiencing revenue gains, reduced turnover rates, and lower worker burnout. The concept has been successfully trialed in other European countries, Australia, Japan, and the UAE, with positive results. However, in Singapore, where five-day work weeks are the norm, companies may be hesitant to adopt the change due to concerns about productivity, employee retention, and costs. A "100-80-100" model, where workers retain 100% of pay, work 80% of existing work time, and maintain 100% productivity, is being advocated as a possible solution.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan

Companies that tested a four-day work week registered gains in revenue and employee productivity, as well as drops in absenteeism and turnover. Workers on a four-day schedule also were more inclined to work from the office than home.

A worker pours a pint of beer at Pressure Drop Brewery, in north London; Pressure Drop is hoping the experiment will not only improve their employees’ productivity but also their well-being. At the same time, it will reduce their carbon footprint.
Flexing a 4-day week to work the right way
The 4-day week: how workplaces can successfully establish it

site_title: Hi-P plans return to public market, aspiring to achieve S$10b in annual sales by 2029
summary: Singapore-based contract manufacturer Hi-P International aims to list on the public market by 2024 or 2025, with plans to achieve S$10 billion in annual sales by 2029. The company, led by 83-year-old executive chairman Yao Hsiao Tung, has grown 10-fold in revenue over the past seven years and aims to boost its top line by 10 times in the next seven years. Hi-P's customers include major global tech and consumer companies, and the company plans to pursue mergers and acquisitions to support its expansion plan, which includes setting up a manufacturing facility in India.

site_title: Best World posts 7.1% drop in Q4 profit, no dividend proposed
summary: Best World International reported a 7.1% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$47.7 million for Q4 2022, driven by a 14.6% increase in revenue to S$211 million. The company attributed the decline to a decline in revenue in certain markets and higher costs, including a loss from an impaired investment and foreign currency losses. No dividend was declared for the period, citing short-term commitments and uncertain business climate. The group expects challenges in the road ahead, including a looming US recession and weakened global demand.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Best World International is set to resume trading on the Singapore Exchange on Monday Nov, 14 after being suspended for 3.5 years
Best World International headquarters at Tai Seng

site_title: Setting out growth plan, UK opposition Labour warn Britain is in downward spiral
summary: The UK's Labour Party, led by Keir Starmer, warns that Britain's economy could fall behind that of Poland by 2030 and eventually Hungary and Romania if it doesn't change course. The party cites an analysis of economic output per head, stating that on its current trajectory, Britain would be $12,000 per person behind Romania and $8,000 behind Hungary by 2040. Labour promises to ensure Britain has the fastest growing economy among the G7 on a sustained basis if it wins power, aiming to reverse the country's economic decline.

images.alt_text: Closing-down signs at a shop in Huddersfield, UK. A study by the Centre of Economic Reform suggests that UK gross domestic product is 5.5 per cent lower than it would have been if Brexit had not happened.

In a speech in Manchester, Labour Party leader Keir Starmer will say his first mission will be growing the economy, with a focus on “change for all” and helping “shape markets rather than serving them”.

site_title: CIA chief says US ‘confident’ China mulling arms for Russia
summary: US CIA director William Burns stated that the US is "confident" China is considering providing lethal equipment to support Russian forces in Ukraine, but no final decision has been made. China has denied any involvement. Burns warned that such a move would be "a very risky and unwise bet," and US officials have stepped up warnings to Beijing about the potential consequences. The US has yet to detect any arms shipments, and President Joe Biden has told Chinese President Xi Jinping that providing lethal support would have dire economic repercussions.

images.alt_text: Roman Abramovich was forced to put his prized London possessions up for sale, including Chelsea Football Club.

Indian Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman says: “Although there was not what we would call a communique, but only an outcome statement, we still think we’ve made some progress in having all the ministers on board.”

site_title: Nanofilm touts ‘deep tech’ edge to hit S$500m revenue target despite volatility
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a Singapore-based company, aims to reach a revenue target of S$500 million by 2025 despite facing supply chain constraints and pandemic disruptions in China. CEO Gary Ho emphasizes the company's "deep tech" edge in emerging industries such as electric vehicles and hydrogen power, citing proprietary technology and patents. Nanofilm is developing a joint venture with Chinese companies to provide sustainable coatings for EV batteries and is also exploring opportunities in hydrogen fuel cells. The company is taking a long-term view, focusing on educating investors on its technology and seeking mergers and acquisitions to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
UOB Kay Hian says that the increase in valuation multiple for Nanofilm is due to a less challenging outlook for 2023.
Earnings per share for H2 2022 stood at 3.8 Singapore cents, down from 6.71 Singapore cents in the same period a year ago.

site_title: Is it time for a new wave of tokenisation?
summary: A new wave of tokenisation in the digital asset market may be on the horizon, with investors seeking safer opportunities and traditional finance players capitalizing on demand. Tokenization of traditional assets, such as real estate, bonds, and carbon credits, could bring new asset classes to the market, increasing liquidity and potentially sparking more investing activity. Governments are also moving to support stronger asset protections, with regulations and guidelines being published in various countries. This shift could unlock the potential of digital assets and pave the way for widespread adoption of tokenisation.

images.alt_text: The development of various digital currencies over the past few years implies a need for digital representations of money, and it is the job of the central banks to meet this need, said Agustin Carstens, general manager of BIS.

Investors shift away from cryptocurrencies but continue to pour money into blockchain-based solutions like real-time payment settlement pre-validation, streamlining cross-border payments and tokenising assets.

site_title: Hong Kong may scrap mask mandate by early March: report
summary: Hong Kong may scrap its mask mandate by early March, allowing residents to remove both indoor and outdoor mask requirements, although face coverings will still be required at high-risk places like hospitals. This move comes as the city works to return to normal and reclaim its status as a global business hub. The decision follows easing of mask regulations in neighboring Macau, which has a stable Covid-19 situation.

site_title: New sports centre, polyclinic, library and town park in Toa Payoh to be ready by 2030
summary: Singapore's Toa Payoh Integrated Development, featuring a regional sports centre, polyclinic, public library, and town park, is expected to be completed by 2030. The 12-hectare development will offer various sporting facilities, including swimming pools, indoor sports halls, and a football stadium, as well as amenities such as a gym, fitness studios, and a water activity centre. The project is part of the Sports Facilities Master Plan, a key initiative of the national sports blueprint Vision 2030.

site_title: Man United win League Cup to end six-year trophy drought
summary: Manchester United won the League Cup, ending a six-year trophy drought, with a 2-0 victory over Newcastle at Wembley Stadium. Casemiro's header and Sven Botman's own goal in the first half set the tone, and United held firm despite Newcastle's second-half pressure. Manager Erik ten Hag's side celebrated their first major trophy since 2017, with the Dutchman hailing it as a "transformative" first season. United's win sets them up for a strong finish in the Premier League and European competitions.

images.alt_text: Manchester City's Erling Haaland (right) celebrates with his teammates after scoring the third goal in his team's 3-1 win over Arsenal on Wednesday.

Manchester United, which has won a record 13 Premier League titles, has consistently been able to attract the game’s biggest stars, including the likes of Cristiano Ronaldo, Paul Pogba and Zlatan Ibrahimovic.

site_title: Healthy appetite for Thailand hotels as investors stay bullish
summary: Thailand's hotel industry is experiencing a strong recovery, with investors remaining bullish despite the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. New hotels are opening in Bangkok, with around 7,000 new rooms set to come online in 2023 and 2024. The luxury segment is seeing a faster rebound, with international tourists returning from China. The Thai government is also introducing regulations to attract wealthy foreigners and digital nomads. Despite the competition, hoteliers are welcoming the increased competition, with some even targeting niche markets to differentiate themselves.

images.alt_text: There were 22 major hotel transactions in Thailand worth a combined 12.3 billion baht (S$484.7 million) in 2021.
The Bank of Thailand has raised the key rate by a total of 100 basis points since August to 1.50 per cent.
Thailand has for long mooted an entry fee for foreign travellers but its implementation was delayed by the pandemic.

site_title: US agency says Covid likely emerged from China lab leak: reports
summary: The US Department of Energy now says the Covid-19 pandemic likely emerged from a Chinese laboratory leak, according to a classified report. The determination was made with "low confidence" and marks a shift from the Energy department's previous indecision on the issue. The White House maintains that American intelligence remains divided on the matter. The origin of Covid-19 remains a topic of debate among different agencies, with the World Health Organization and China's government attributing the outbreak to animal transmission.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) building in Beijing.Source: Bloomberg

Macau authorities say that they would drop Covid 19-related mask requirements for most locations, except for public transportation, hospitals and a handful of other areas, with the rule change takes effect from Monday.
Since August 2018, Hong Kong’s workforce has dropped about 5 per cent to 3.8 million people, according to the latest official figures.

site_title: Binance Australia derivatives business reviewed by regulator
summary: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) is conducting a "targeted review" of Binance's local derivatives business, focusing on the classification of retail and wholesale clients. Binance had closed the positions of 500 Australian users due to incorrect classification, and the company will compensate affected customers. ASIC is aware of Binance's social media posts but has not reported the matter, citing compliance with local laws. The review comes amid scrutiny of the crypto industry following the collapse of FTX last year.

images.alt_text: Reserves for one major stablecoin were also not properly documented between 2020 and 2021, at times leaving gaps of up to US$1 billion in externally visible funds.

site_title: Terra Hill sells more than a third of units at launch
summary: Terra Hill, a luxury freehold residential development in Pasir Panjang, Singapore, sold 38% of its 270 units during its booking exercise on Feb 24-25, with 102 units sold at an average price of S$2,650 per square feet. The sales are considered reasonable for the city fringe, with interest rates and proximity to the Greater Southern Waterfront attracting buyers. The take-up rate is expected to be around 30-40% for subsequent launches this year.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Terra Hill will comprise 270 residential units across nine five-storey blocks, with amenities such as a 50-metre lap pool and children's play area.
Landed houses, homes and private property in the Novena area on December 30, 2022.
The latest December sales figure is 73.8 per cent less than the 650 units sold in the same month in 2021, and is the lowest since January 2009, when just 108 units were transacted.

site_title: Hong Kong airline worker shortage hits city’s push to reopen
summary: Hong Kong's airline industry is struggling with a severe worker shortage, hindering its efforts to reopen and regain its status as Asia's premier financial hub. The city's workforce has dropped 5% to 3.8 million people since August 2018, and the airport has only reached 68% of its pre-pandemic capacity. Airlines are delaying resuming routes and local start-up Greater Bay Airlines is struggling to add flights due to labor constraints. The government is exploring measures to address the shortage, including bringing in workers from mainland China and revising labor policies.

images.alt_text: At a soiree of some 90 people on a recent Friday evening in the centre of Hong Kong’s financial district, women in white gloves hobnobbed with Sotheby’s executives as they admired Hermes collectibles.

site_title: Real estate valuers must start accounting for embodied carbon: Schroders
summary: Schroders' global head of real estate, Sophie van Oosterom, urges real estate valuers to account for embodied carbon in their properties, as the industry continues to transition to net-zero. Schroders includes carbon emissions in its underwriting, considering the cost of environmental impacts and regulatory costs. This approach is atypical in the industry, where valuers often rely on third-party valuations. Van Oosterom believes that incorporating sustainability into building efficiency will drive long-term sustainable income and performance for clients. Schroders is also looking for opportunities in global upheavals, particularly in the Grade B office market and retail spaces, which are expected to face challenges but also present potential for long-term growth.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
With 80% of buildings in mature cities still set to be in use in 2050, the focus must be on addressing the existing stock through retrofitting to achieve net zero carbon ambitions.
Visitors and tenants at CapitaSpring can immerse themselves in the Green Oasis which is spread over four levels from the 17th floor.

Some Reits produce an ESG sustainability report that is more voluminous than their annual report. Reit stakeholders and investors are overwhelmed by universal data that fill up space in the report, resulting in Information asymmetries. There is a risk that some truly pertinent data will get submerged or distorted.

site_title: Chinese bank says missing chairman is cooperating with Chinese authorities in an investigation
summary: Chinese bank Renaissance Holdings' missing chairman Bao Fan is cooperating with Chinese authorities in an investigation, according to the bank's exchange filing on Sunday. Bao, known for his role in tech mergers, was reported missing 10 days ago and his disappearance comes amid a sweeping anti-corruption campaign led by President Xi Jinping. The bank's business operations continue normally, and no details about the investigation were shared.

images.alt_text: Fan Bao, chairman and chief executive officer of China Renaissance Group, pauses during a Bloomberg West television interview in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Wednesday, June 15, 2016. China Renaissance Partners provides financial solutions na advisory services operating as an investment bank providing services to entrepreneurs, multi-nationals and institutional investors. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: SpaceX Dragon crew to blast off for ISS
summary: A SpaceX Dragon Crew-6 mission is set to launch from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, carrying two NASA astronauts, a Russian cosmonaut, and the second Emirati to the International Space Station. The crew, consisting of Stephen Bowen, Warren Hoburg, Andrey Fedyaev, and Sultan al-Neyadi, will spend six months on the orbiting space station, conducting experiments and research. The mission is scheduled to dock with the ISS at 2:38 am GMT on Tuesday, marking the sixth time a SpaceX rocket has transported astronauts to the station.

images.alt_text: The uncrewed missions will be launched out of Cape Canaveral, Florida, or Vandenberg Space Force Base in California and the contract could run for as many as 10 years through February of 2033.

South Korea’s breakup with Moscow will be a harsh blow to Russia’s rocket programme, one of the nation’s strongest post-Soviet industries outside oil, and highlights the impact of international pressure.

site_title: Tech leaders in Israel wonder if it’s time to leave
summary: Veteran entrepreneur Yanki Margalit has concluded that Israel is no longer the right place to launch a new venture due to the government's planned judicial overhaul. The proposed changes, led by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, aim to curtail the court's independence and give the ruling coalition more control over the judiciary. This move has prompted a surge in the outflow of Israeli tech leaders, with several companies relocating or moving money out of the country. The tech sector's reaction is of greatest concern, as it provides a significant portion of Israel's economy, with potential losses estimated to be devastating.

images.alt_text: Israelis demonstrating in front of parliament on the day Israel's constitution committee is set to start voting on changes that would give politicians more power on selecting judges while limiting Supreme Court powers to strike down legislation.

site_title: Most G20 nations condemn Russia for war, China silent
summary: Most G20 nations condemned Russia for its war in Ukraine, with China and Russia itself declining to sign a joint statement. Despite disagreements, the G20 issued a statement condemning the war, citing immense human suffering and exacerbating global economic fragilities. The meeting also discussed debt restructuring, with some initial progress made on language, but no concrete deliverables. India pushed for tougher regulation of private crypto assets, which gained wider support.

images.alt_text: “This is a war. And this war has a cause, has one cause, and that is Russia and (Russian President) Vladimir Putin. That must be expressed clearly at this G20 finance meeting,” said German Finance Minister Christian Linder.

site_title: Supply chains have healed, yet their mark on inflation endures
summary: Global supply chains have largely recovered from the pandemic, but their impact on inflation remains. Shipping container costs have returned to pre-Covid levels, but long-term contracts continue to drive prices higher. This stickiness contributes to persistent inflationary pressures, with US producer prices rebounding in January and underlying inflation in the euro area hitting a record. Temporary factors, such as labor shortages and price cuts during the pandemic, also persist. As supply chains continue to heal, it may take time for inflationary trends to work through, with some analysts predicting that price reductions may not be immediate.

images.alt_text: The LBCT container terminal at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Thursday, Feb. 16, 2023. The Long Beach Container Terminal announced the final steps in its 10-year, $2.5 billion redevelopment project that will make it the first fully emission-free marine facility by 2030. Photographer: Lauren Justice/Bloomberg

site_title: UK and EU on the cusp of Northern Ireland Brexit deal but concerns remain
summary: The UK and EU are on the cusp of a deal to address trade and political disruption in Northern Ireland caused by Brexit, with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak saying he's "giving it everything" to get a deal done. A year of negotiations has led to progress, but concerns remain, particularly from eurosceptic critics and the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which has set seven tests for any deal. A deal's success will depend on DUP approval, which is uncertain, and may impact Sunak's domestic agenda and the Conservative Party's national election prospects.

images.alt_text: The UK and EU have made similar proposals to separate goods only going to Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK versus those which will continue into the EU.

site_title: Jewel Changi Airport regains its glitter, but for some tenants it’s too little, too late
summary: Jewel Changi Airport saw a surge in new tenants in 2022, with 54 opening up, but the mall's prospects have been impacted by tenant exits, including 74 over the last two years. Some 54 tenants opened, but 74 have left, with more than half due to changes in Jewel's Basement 1 space. The mall's retail sales reached a best-ever monthly record in December 2022, but the going has been tough for some tenants, including British retailer Marks & Spencer, which will soon shut its Jewel store.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

Travelers with baggage at Jewel Changi Airport mall in Singapore, on Wednesday, April 20, 2022. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), in its policy statement, said it expects the economy to grow “above-trend” for a second year in 2022, with the output gap turning “slightly positive” and GDP fully recovering from the pandemic. Photographer: Lauryn Ishak/Bloomberg

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for Feb 24, 2023, highlights a significant change in the tanker and dry bulk market. Despite disappointing results from Rio Tinto and BHP, activity increased in the Atlantic and West Australia, leading to significant jumps in indices. Capesize rates surged to $5,271, with West Australia to China rates reaching near $7. Panamax rates also surged, with the North Sea market experiencing double-digit gains. Ultramax and Supramax vessels saw gains, with period cover increasing. Clean and VLCC rates took a slight negative turn, while Suezmax and Aframax rates remained stable. LNG and LPG rates rose, with period discussions focusing on sublet tonnage.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Feb 17, 2023).

site_title: Brazilian favela 'shack' wins house-of-year award
summary: A Brazilian favela resident, Kdu dos Anjos, has won the "house of the year" award from the website ArchDaily for his modest 66-square-meter dwelling. The two-story structure, built in 2017, features horizontal casement windows and a large terrace, and was recognized for its environmental quality and innovative design. Dos Anjos, a 32-year-old artist, says the prize is a victory for him and his community, and he plans to use the recognition to improve his home and the surrounding area.

images.alt_text: The facade is a collage of features and openings, while the boundary wall and side gate are made of perforated sheets that provide visual connectivity to the street.

site_title: How Italy's generous green homes scheme turned 'wicked'
summary: Italy's "superbonus" scheme, a green homes initiative, has been criticized for its "out of control" costs and potential impact on the deficit. Introduced in 2020, the scheme paid 110% of the cost of making homes energy efficient, but has since cost the state 61.2 billion euros. The government has reduced the subsidy from 110% to 90% and stopped using tax credits, citing fraud and a "parallel currency" that risks devastating the budget. Experts warn that the scheme's impact on Italy's finances could be substantial, and that it has not achieved its intended goal of promoting green housing.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s government  halted the tax credit system, which threatened the solidity of Italy’s finances.

site_title: Gambling hub Macau drops Covid mask mandate for most locations
summary: Macau authorities have dropped Covid-19-related mask requirements for most locations, except public transportation, hospitals, and a few other areas, effective Monday. The decision comes after a stable epidemic situation over the last two months. In contrast, Hong Kong, a neighboring Chinese special administrative region, still imposes a mask mandate until March 8. Residents are advised to wear masks if they develop flu-like symptoms, and face masks are recommended for commuting.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Macau residents can apply for temporary stay permits in Taiwan starting Feb 20.

site_title: With backing from business lobby, Japan PM calls for workers' pay hikes
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has called for workers to receive pay hikes that surpass inflation rates, urging the government to spread wage growth nationwide to combat rising inflation. Backed by a major business lobby, Kishida emphasized the need for "structural wage hikes" to enhance competitiveness and attract workers amid labor shortages. Large firms are expected to offer significant pay hikes, but the pace may still fall short of consumer inflation rates. Kishida's proposal aims to stimulate private consumption and promote economic growth.

site_title: French documentary, Spanish girl clinch top prizes at Berlinale
summary: The Berlin film festival awarded its top prize, the Golden Bear, to French director Nicolas Philibert's documentary "On the Adamant", a film about a floating day-care centre for people with psychiatric problems in Paris. The festival also awarded an eight-year-old Spanish girl, Sofia Otero, the gender-neutral acting prize for her role in the film "20,000 Species of Bees". The jury praised the films for pushing boundaries and challenging traditional notions of cinema.

images.alt_text: Peter Jackson’s original three "Lord of the Rings" movies grossed nearly US$3 billion at theatres, and won 17 Oscars, including best picture for 2003 trilogy finale "The Return of the King".

site_title: US travel companies experience high demand but economic worries cloud outlook
summary: US travel companies reported a rebound in bookings in the fourth quarter of 2022, with US travel spending reaching $97 billion in December 2022, 3% above 2019 levels and 7% above 2021 levels. Despite this, economic worries and inflation concerns may curb travel demand in the second half of 2023, with analysts citing a slowdown in the economy and declining discretionary purchases. Bookings are still holding up, with some companies like Airbnb and Hilton reporting faster rates of bookings in 2023 than in 2019.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, jumped 1.8 per cent last month, the Commerce Department said.

site_title: IMF flags debt restructuring hurdles, says banning crypto should be an option
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva stated that debt restructuring for distressed economies faces hurdles, with disagreements among lenders. China called for a fair analysis of global debt issues and suggested banning private cryptocurrencies as an option to maintain financial stability. The IMF's global sovereign debt roundtable is considering all public and private creditors for debt restructuring, and Georgieva agreed that strong regulation of cryptocurrencies is necessary to prevent financial risks.

images.alt_text: The IMF had hit out at El Salvador in late 2021 when the central American country became the first to adopt bitcoin as legal tender.
International financial institutions and commercial creditors should follow the principle of “joint action, fair burden” in debt settlements, said .Chinese Finance Minister Liu Kun.

site_title: JPMorgan could reach US$1 trillion market value by 2030, Morgan Stanley says
summary: Morgan Stanley analysts predict JPMorgan Chase's market capitalization could reach US$1 trillion by 2030, more than doubling its current value of US$410 billion. This would put the US bank in elite company globally, alongside only a few stocks such as Apple, Microsoft, and Saudi Aramco. Analyst Betsy Graseck cites a potential soft landing for the economy and improved net interest income as drivers of this growth.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan also cut hundreds of mortgage employees this month.

site_title: Staff, athletes, and beneficiaries have fun at inaugural OCBC Aquatics 2022
summary: OCBC Bank organized the inaugural OCBC Aquatics 2022 event at the Singapore Sports Hub, featuring activities such as diving, flippa ball, and aquatic dancing for over 120 employees, staff volunteers, and beneficiaries from the Movement for the Intellectually Disabled of Singapore (Minds) and the Singapore Children's Society. The event aimed to provide opportunities for underprivileged children and individuals with disabilities to engage in aquatic sports and build water confidence. Participants, including beneficiaries and caregivers, enjoyed the activities and reported increased motivation and social skills. The event was a success, with plans to scale up next year's iteration and make it open to the public.

images.alt_text: Helen Wong (left), Group CEO, OCBC Bank with Lim Khiang Tong, Group chief operating officer,  harvesting the lettuce at the OCBC Centre carpark.

site_title: The busy furniture hustlers of Silicon Valley
summary: Tech companies in Silicon Valley are cutting costs and downsizing their physical footprints due to the pandemic-induced shift to remote work and economic slowdown, resulting in a furniture glut. Behind-the-scenes specialists, including professional liquidators, Craigslist flippers, and startups, are capitalizing on the trend. Furniture specialists are buying and selling high-end, designer furniture from companies like Dropbox and WeWork, which are often left behind when employees transition to remote work. The Bay Area, particularly San Francisco, has seen a significant increase in commercial vacancy rates, with some companies downsizing their office space or giving up expensive downtown headquarters.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Ericsson logo is pictured at the Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Shanghai, China, June 28, 2019. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
US cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase Global this week indicated that more layoffs could be in store, after cutting 20 per cent of its workforce in January.
Meta plans to push some leaders into lower-level roles without direct reports, flattening the layers of management between top boss Mark Zuckerberg and the company’s interns.
Companies in industries from finance to technology to retailing are reducing staff amid a slowdown in demand and predictions of a looming recession.

site_title: Thai economy to grow 3.8% this year, inflation to ebb: minister
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3.8% this year, driven by a rebound in the tourism sector and domestic spending. The government will accelerate large project investments to support growth. Inflation is forecast to cool to the target range of 1-3% as the central bank continues to curb consumer prices. Despite falling export volumes, a favorable baht exchange rate of 34-35 to the dollar will help export prices. The finance minister attributed the growth to the return of Chinese tourists and measures to control inflation.

images.alt_text: Thailand generates about 2 million metric tons of plastic waste annually, of which only about a quarter is recycled, according to the government.
Thai move to lure affluent foreigners with tax breaks and other financial incentives, which mirrors steps by countries including Singapore and the United Arab Emirates.

site_title: Pigs called in to deep-clean Champagne vineyards
summary: French champagne vineyards are using kunekune pigs to deep-clean the vineyards, an alternative to chemical or mechanical means. The 40kg pigs, originally from New Zealand, are trained to avoid eating valuable earthworms and cannot attack the vines' leaves and branches. Their thorough work can fight weeds, mildew, and fungi, aerating the soil and reducing the need for chemical treatments. The experiment, first tested in Bordeaux last year, may help the champagne industry achieve its goal of certifying 100% eco-friendly growers by 2030.

images.alt_text: Champagne sales reached an all-time high last year at 5.7 billion euros ($8.2 billion), as the relaxation of pandemic-related curbs fuelled a surge in exports.

site_title: Venture Corp H2 net profit rises 13.8% to S$195.3 million on more customer demand, new products
summary: Venture Corp reported a 13.8% rise in H2 2022 net profit to S$195.3 million, driven by higher customer demand and new product introductions. Revenue grew 23.4% to S$2.1 billion, with significant contributions from healthcare, life sciences, and test and measurement portfolios. The company proposes a final dividend of 50 Singapore cents per share. Net profit for the full year ended Dec 31, 2022, rose 18.4% to S$369.6 million. Despite uncertain global macroeconomic and geopolitical conditions, Venture plans to invest in new capabilities.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Maybank raises its target price for Venture Corporation after the electronics manufacturing services provider "handily beat" the research house's projections for Q3 FY2022.
In its outlook, Venture Corporation said that its Malaysian entities delivered the most impressive contributions to its overall performance.

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway reports major investment losses in 2022
summary: Berkshire Hathaway reported a significant loss of $22.8 billion in 2022, primarily due to unrealized losses on investments. Despite this, Warren Buffett expressed continued faith in the US economy, stating he has never seen a reason to bet against America. The company's operating earnings were a record $30.8 billion, and its cash reserves have grown to $125 billion. However, several subsidiaries reported losses, including consumer products and insurance businesses, due to economic forces affecting the US.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Warren Buffett, CEO of Berkshire Hathaway Inc, pauses while playing bridge as part of the company annual meeting weekend in Omaha, Nebraska U.S. May 6, 2018. REUTERS/Rick Wilking/File Photo

site_title: Meta heats up Big Tech's AI arms race with new language model
summary: Meta has released its new large language model, LLaMA, under non-commercial license to researchers and entities affiliated with government, civil society, and academia. The model, trained on 20 languages, can generate human-like content and answer questions. LLaMA is said to require less computing power than previous offerings and can outperform competitors with 13 billion parameters. Meta attributes its performance to "cleaner" data and architectural improvements. The move heats up the AI arms race among Big Tech companies, including Microsoft-backed OpenAI, Alphabet, and China's Baidu, as they integrate the technology into their products and impress investors.

images.alt_text: Meta plans to push some leaders into lower-level roles without direct reports, flattening the layers of management between top boss Mark Zuckerberg and the company’s interns.

Facebook's parent company Meta is piloting a subscription in Australia and New Zealand before it appears in larger markets. The service will cost US$11.99 on the web and US$14.99 on the iOS and Android mobile platforms.

site_title: Vice CEO’s departure signals fallen hopes for digital media
summary: Vice Media CEO Nancy Dubuc is leaving the company, marking a significant setback for digital media. Dubuc's departure follows her failed attempt to sell the company, which was valued at $5.7 billion in 2018. Despite efforts to reduce reliance on advertising and improve finances, Vice is now expected to sell for far less than its initial valuation. The company's struggles highlight the fallen fortunes of digital media companies, which have struggled to live up to their lofty ambitions and face increasing competition from tech giants and streaming services.

images.alt_text: Netflix is lowering prices in countries that account for a small percentage of its subscriber base.
Warner said it paid Paramount and “South Park” creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone more than US$500 million in 2019 for the exclusive right to stream 333 episodes domestically on HBO Max.

site_title: S-Reits increase exposure to data centre assets
summary: Reit Watch: CapitaLand Investment has established a China data centre development fund, committing to invest in two hyperscale data centre projects in Greater Beijing, adding approximately S$1 billion to its funds under management. This follows a trend of emerging markets, with hyperscale tenants and colocation providers evaluating new projects worldwide. S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascendas Reit and CapitaLand India Trust have increased exposure to the data centre segment, with some having significant portfolios in the space.

images.alt_text: Five Singapore Reits took up spots among the 10 stocks which recorded largest institutional net inflows for most of last week.

site_title: Blame the warmth: Famed skating rink in Ottawa won't open this year
summary: The Rideau Canal Skateway, Canada's largest open-air ice rink and a UNESCO World Heritage Site, will not open this year due to a mild winter. The rink requires temperatures between -10 and -20°C for nearly two weeks to open safely, which has not been achieved. This is the first time in its history that the Skateway will not open. The Ottawa facility is preparing for climate change, which has caused abnormally high temperatures in the area, making it difficult for the ice to form.

images.alt_text: The closed Rideau Canal Skateway in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, Feb. 16, 2023. The skateway is unlikely to open for the first time since it was built in 1971 due to unusually warm weather that’s left cracks and occasional puddles along what’s normally a patch of ice strong enough to support more than 20,000 skaters a day. Photographer: David Kawai/Bloomberg

site_title: US consumer spending surges in January; inflation heats up
summary: US consumer spending surged 1.8% in January, the largest increase since March 2021, driven by wage gains and inflation. Consumer spending accounts for over two-thirds of the US economy and indicates the economy is far from a recession. Despite financial market fears, the Federal Reserve is expected to continue raising interest rates through summer. Inflation accelerated to 0.6% in January, with the personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index rising 5.4% over the past 12 months.

images.alt_text: Economists expect strong employment growth in February, though the pace probably slowed from last month’s eye-popping 517,000 jobs.

site_title: SGX RegCo reminds Golden Energy directors that IFA opinion on offer must ‘withstand scrutiny’
summary: SGX RegCo has reminded Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) to ensure its independent financial adviser's opinion on a proposed distribution and exit offer withstands scrutiny. The deal involves a distribution of 62.5% stake in Indonesian thermal coal producer Golden Energy Mines and a delisting of Gear from the Singapore Exchange. Market watchers argue the deal undervalues Gear's assets and is unfair to minority investors. Gear is citing environmental and social governance pressures in the energy coal industry as the reason for the distribution and delisting.

images.alt_text: Joan Ng
Gear said a key rationale for the deal is to cut its exposure to the thermal coal business conducted by Gems, which faces ESG pressures
Gear has pushed the long-stop date for the deal from Apr 9 to Aug 9
Gear has rationalised its break-up and privatisation with an ESG narrative
Golden Energy and Resources had on Nov 9 sounded its intention to give shareholders an option of cash, or a combination of cash and shares, to delist from SGX.
The series of proposals come as Gear seeks to reduce its exposure to energy coal by shifting away from its existing energy coal business currently conducted by Gems through the proposed distribution.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Ant Group plans to pare stake in India’s Paytm
summary: Ant Group, backed by Jack Ma, is considering selling some of its shares in Paytm, the operator of Indian financial technology firm, to keep its stake within a required threshold. The decision follows Ant affiliate Alibaba Group's sale of its stake in Paytm amid growing geopolitical tensions in India. Ant plans to reduce its stake after a buyback of 8.5 billion rupees, while Indian telecommunications tycoon Sunil Mittal seeks to acquire a stake in Paytm by merging his financial services unit into the fintech giant's payments bank.

images.alt_text: The announcement comes after Reuters reported in November that SoftBank Group sold a 4.5 per cent stake.
Paytm, which is also backed by China’s Ant Group and Japan’s SoftBank Group, has been under pressure to turn profitable ever since its dismal listing in November 2021.

site_title: Wilmar chairman Kuok Khoon Hong adds to stake following FY22 results
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index declined 1.4% over five trading sessions, with institutions net selling S$135 million worth of stocks. Wilmar International chairman Kuok Khoon Hong increased his stake in the company following FY22 results, which saw a record US$2.40 billion net profit. Other companies with notable transactions include Keppel Corporation, Singtel, and DBS, which were among the top net institutional outflows, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Mapletree Logistics Trust, and Genting Singapore were among the top net institutional inflows.

images.alt_text: Singapore's STI gained 2.3 per cent over the week, having spent four days in positive territory

site_title: Warner Bros Discovery sues Paramount over 'South Park' streaming rights
summary: Warner Bros Discovery has filed a lawsuit against Paramount Global, seeking hundreds of millions of dollars in damages over streaming rights for the animated comedy series "South Park." The company claims it paid Paramount and creators Trey Parker and Matt Stone over $500 million in 2019 for exclusive streaming rights on HBO Max, but only received 14 of the 30 promised episodes. The lawsuit alleges Paramount breached the agreement by launching its own Paramount+ streaming service and producing alternative content, including new "South Park" episodes.

images.alt_text: Peter Jackson’s original three "Lord of the Rings" movies grossed nearly US$3 billion at theatres, and won 17 Oscars, including best picture for 2003 trilogy finale "The Return of the King".
Netflix is lowering prices in countries that account for a small percentage of its subscriber base.

site_title: Temasek, other institutions sued for ‘aiding and abetting’ FTX fraud
summary: A class action lawsuit was filed in Miami, Florida, naming Temasek and 17 other defendants as conspirators with FTX to defraud customers. The lawsuit claims that the defendants, including venture capital firms, aided and abetted fiduciary breach by launching FTX's house of cards to its multibillion-dollar scale. The complaint alleges that the firms were aware of fraud being committed by FTX and had conducted due diligence checks prior to their investments. The class members are seeking compensatory and punitive damages.

images.alt_text: The new indictment hit Bankman-Fried with additional charges of conspiracy to commit bank fraud and conspiracy to operate an unlicenced money transmitting business.

site_title: Chief executive of Vice Nancy Dubuc steps down
summary: Nancy Dubuc, CEO of Vice Media, is stepping down as the company explores a potential sale. Dubuc, who took over in 2018, aimed to improve the company's culture and finances. During her tenure, Vice became less reliant on advertising and made strides toward financial independence. The company's board stated that Dubuc positioned Vice for long-term success and will announce new leadership soon. Dubuc's departure follows struggles with profitability and a culture overhaul following investigations into incidents of sexual harassment.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ Nancy Dubuc, C.E.O. of Vice Media, at The New York Times DealBook conference in New York on Nov. 1, 2018. Dubuc, who attempted to improve the companyÕs culture and steady its finances after taking over nearly five years ago, is stepping down, she said in an email to employees on Friday. (Mike Cohen/The New York Times)

site_title: The time of Poland in Europe
summary: Poland has emerged as a key player in European security policy, particularly in the response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The country has welcomed over 1.5 million Ukrainian refugees and provided significant military aid, including hundreds of tanks. Polish leaders have been instrumental in persuading Germany to send tanks to Ukraine, and have called for tougher sanctions against Russia. Poland's leadership has helped fill a geopolitical vacuum created by the decline of other European powers, and has forged strong bonds between the Polish and Ukrainian people. As the conflict in Ukraine continues, Poland is likely to play a leading role in shaping the region's future geopolitics.

images.alt_text: The issue of supplying the German-made Leopard 2 tanks to Ukraine has dominated recent discussions among Western allies about how much and what sort of material aid they should give Ukraine as the first anniversary of the Russian invasion nears.

President Joe Biden is welcomed by President Andrzej Duda of Poland at the Presidential Palace in Warsaw. Biden arrived in the Polish capital Warsaw late on Monday after a surprise visit to Kyiv just days ahead of the anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine on Feb 24, 2022.
While tensions remain between the United States and Europe, the transatlantic alliance has largely recovered from the nadir of the Trump era.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble as inflation comes in hot again
summary: US stocks plummeted Friday as inflation data surged 5.4% from January 2022, fueling concerns over the Federal Reserve's ability to curb rising interest rates. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note climbed closer to 4%, signifying increased expectations for future rate hikes. The S&P 500 dropped 1.1% and the Dow Jones fell 1.0%, with Boeing and Autodesk also suffering significant losses. The economic data raises questions about the Fed's ability to prevent a recession.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 17, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: US billionaire financier Thomas Lee dies at 78
summary: US billionaire financier Thomas Lee, 78, died from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head at his Manhattan office on February 23. Lee, founder of Lee Equity and former chairman of Thomas H. Lee Partners, was responsible for over $15 billion in investments across 46 years. He was also a philanthropist and trustee for various organizations, including the Lincoln Center and Harvard University. Lee's family asked for privacy as they grieved, stating they were "extremely saddened" by his death.

images.alt_text: Author of several anime and manga series Leiji Matsumoto  is the recipient of several awards from the Japanese government, as well as the Knight of the Order of Arts and Letters from the French government.

site_title: Ericsson to lay off 8,500 employees worldwide
summary: Ericsson plans to lay off 8,500 employees globally as part of a cost-cutting plan, the largest in the telecoms industry. The company will cut 1,400 jobs in Sweden, with headcount reductions varying by country. CEO Borje Ekholm stated that the management of these reductions will differ depending on local practices. The layoffs are attributed to economic conditions, with Ericsson aiming to reduce costs in response to the challenging market.

site_title: US new home sales jump to 10-month high in January, prices fall
summary: US new home sales surged to a 10-year high in January, reaching 670,000 units, with prices declining 0.7% to a median $427,500. This marks a turnaround from the 7 straight quarters of declining residential investment, the longest such stretch since 2009. However, a resurgence in mortgage rates, which rose to 6.50% this week, may slow the housing market recovery, and economists predict a turnaround is still far off.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity, jumped 1.8 per cent last month, the Commerce Department said.
The average for a 30-year, fixed loan fell to 6.95 per cent after surging past 7 per cent last week, Freddie Mac said on Thursday (Nov 3) in a statement.

site_title: Thin isn’t everything for Piaget CEO
summary: Piaget CEO Benjamin Comar emphasizes the importance of creating elegant watches over breaking thinness records. Despite competition from brands like Bulgari and Richard Mille, Comar prioritizes aesthetic and quality over record-breaking thinness. He attributes Piaget's success to its expertise in both watchmaking and jewelry, which he believes is the key to its prominence in the industry. The brand's "extra-legan-za" philosophy, which combines elegance and extravaganza, is evident in its latest watches, including the Polo Calendar Perpetual Ultra-Thin, which retails for $85,000.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Swiss watch exports hit a new record in 2022, climbing 11.4 per cent year-on-year to 24.8 billion Swiss francs.

site_title: Elite motor racing without the elitism
summary: US Legend Cars International, a racing series focused on big fun over big money, is making its Singapore debut as part of Goodstock Speedfest in August. The series features 30 drivers from around the world competing on an oval track for a $100,000 prize and kudos, with affordable, low-maintenance cars costing around $24,000. The event aims to bring professional racing to a more accessible and fun experience, with drivers as young as eight allowed to participate. The series, founded in 1992, has produced notable alumni including the Busch brothers and Dale Earnhardt Junior.

images.alt_text: The Mistral is Bugatti’s first open-top car in a decade, a layout that adds rarity points but also makes the driving experience more visceral.
To help lower emissions, F1 is developing a zero-emission petrol that can also be used by planes and vessels.

site_title: US: Wall St tumbles at open as inflation data fuels Fed worries
summary: Wall Street tumbled at the open on Friday, February 24, as inflation data fueled concerns the Federal Reserve will maintain its hawkish stance. The Dow Jones fell 154.72 points, or 0.47%, to 32,999.19, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened lower. The declines were attributed to a surge in consumer spending and inflation in January, sparking worries about the Fed's interest rate decisions.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 17, 2023.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Fool me twice: The digital asset industry must learn from its mistakes
summary: Institutional investors are increasingly seeking exposure to the crypto market, with a growing focus on governance and regulatory standards to ensure a safe environment.
