Despite recent market volatility, including the collapse of FTX and Terra Luna, institutional investors are raising exposure to crypto derivatives, with volumes up 76.1% in January. To attract institutional investors, the industry must prioritize corporate governance, regulation, and high licensing standards, similar to traditional financial markets. With the right safeguards in place, the industry can unlock significant growth and investment, but regulatory and governance standards must be strengthened to match those in traditional markets.

images.alt_text: Some US$2 trillion in value has been wiped out from the overall cryptocurrency market since the peak in mid-2021, due to a wave of failures and bankruptcies
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies Bitcoin, Ethereum and DogeCoin are placed on PC motherboard in this illustration taken, June 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo
Tether now commands 52.6 per cent of the stablecoin market.
To enforce Basel’s crypto rules, the EU could either propose a new law, or expand the banking law it is now finalising as called for by the European Parliament.

site_title: Goldman expects US$2.3 billion more in potential losses from legal disputes
summary: Goldman Sachs expects to incur an additional US$2.3 billion in potential losses from ongoing legal disputes, surpassing its previous US$2 billion projection. The losses stem from various lawsuits, including the 1MDB scandal, Archegos Capital Management collapse, and a long-running gender bias lawsuit. The bank has already cut 3,200 jobs to reduce costs and approved a US$30-billion stock buyback program. Goldman's CEO, David Solomon, is set to present plans to reach key financial goals at an upcoming investor day.

images.alt_text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) is looking into the company's credit-card practices, including how it resolves incorrect bills and processes refunds, Goldman said in a regulatory filing on Thursday (Aug 4).

site_title: China to encourage loan issuance for rental housing groups to revitalise housing stock
summary: China plans to support the issuance of operating loans for housing leasing and strengthen credit support for rental housing development and construction. The central bank and banking regulator will enhance lending capacity and broaden bond financing channels for rental housing firms. Firms with stable cash flow will be allowed to launch innovative housing rental guarantee covered bonds. This move aims to revitalise housing stock and address living problems for young people in big cities, following China's economic slowdown in 2022.

site_title: Uber says Delhi’s plans to allow only electric bike taxis to impact millions
summary: Uber warns that Delhi's plans to only allow electric bike taxis could impact millions of drivers and riders, risking the livelihood of over 100,000 drivers in the city. The local government's new policy aims to regulate vehicles used by ride-hailing companies and reduce pollution. Uber has set a 2040 target for 100% of its rides to be in zero-emission vehicles or micro-mobility. The company urges the government to initiate industry dialogue, citing the potential consequences of such a decision.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A screen displays the company logo for Uber Technologies Inc. in New York, U.S., May 10, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Russia’s richest lose US$67 billion of wealth after a year of war
summary: Russia's 23 billionaires, who ranked among the world's 500 wealthiest people, have collectively lost US$67 billion in net worth over the past year, a 20% drop. The biggest losers include Alexey Mordashov, who lost US$6.7 billion, and Vladimir Lisin, who lost US$5.8 billion. Meanwhile, Andrey Guryev has gained US$2.1 billion due to a surge in PhosAgro's stock price. The sanctions have had a limited long-term effect, with the billionaires' collective net worth bottoming out weeks after the invasion.

images.alt_text: “The sanctioned amount is only a fraction of all Russian assets in Switzerland,” said Erwin Bollinger, Seco’s head of bilateral economic relations.

site_title: Bird flu situation ‘worrying’; WHO working with Cambodia
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is working with Cambodian authorities to address the situation of two confirmed human cases of H5N1 bird flu, following the death of an 11-year-old girl due to the virus. The WHO describes the situation as "worrying" due to the recent rise in cases in birds and mammals. The organization is reviewing its global risk assessment and has noted that the virus is spreading widely among birds and has infected mammals, including humans. WHO officials emphasize the need for heightened vigilance and urge countries to be prepared for any potential human-to-human transmission.

images.alt_text: Workers prepare ducks at a market in Phnom Penh on February 24, 2023. - The father of an 11-year-old Cambodian girl who died earlier in the week from bird flu tested positive for the virus, health officials said. (Photo by TANG CHHIN Sothy / AFP)

site_title: Tennis: Murray saves five match points to reach Doha final
summary: Andy Murray saved five match points to defeat Jiri Lehecka 6-0 3-6 7-6(6) in the Qatar Open, reaching his first ATP Tour final since June last year. The 35-year-old Briton showed great resilience in his comeback victory, pointing to learning from past defeats and the "Law of Averages" as key factors. Murray will face Daniil Medvedev in the final, following Medvedev's 6-4 7-6(7) win over Felix Auger-Aliassime.

images.alt_text: Britain's Andy Murray celebrates his win against Czech Republic's Jiri Lehecka (not pictured) after a tennis semi-final match of the Qatar Open in Doha, on February 24, 2023. (Photo by KARIM JAAFAR / AFP)

site_title: Singapore’s ‘tight’ fiscal position makes growth crucial for redistribution: DPM Wong
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for economic growth to address the country's tight fiscal position. The government has no "fiscal slack" and will focus on growing the economic pie to cover increasing public spending. Wong rejected suggestions to raise revenue through taxes, citing concerns that it could price Singapore out of the competition. Instead, he proposed measures to support SMEs and workers, including short-term support and investment in skills and human capital to help workers progress in their careers.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

“We want to help Singaporeans tackle cost of living pressures, but we must be careful not to inadvertently generate more demand and worsen inflation,” said Finance Minister Lawrence Wong in Parliament.

Addressing MPs who questioned if the government has moved from a pro-growth approach to a pro-redistribution one, Wong said the government remains focused on growing the economic pie, adding that Singapore “must redouble our efforts to raise our game” amid the more challenging external environment.
To address high housing prices, supply needs to be increased by ramping up BTO supply and catching up with pandemic-related delays, says DPM Wong.

site_title: Oil flat on week as US inventories rise but Russia cuts supply
summary: Oil prices were flat on the week, supported by potential Russian supply cuts but pressured by rising US inventories and concerns over global economic activity. Brent crude futures settled at $83.16 a barrel, up 95 cents, while West Texas Intermediate US crude futures settled at $76.32 a barrel, rising 93 cents. US oil inventories reached their highest level since May 2021, and Russia plans to cut oil exports by up to 25% in March. Despite this, analysts expect oil prices to drift lower, citing global growth headwinds and excess inventory.

images.alt_text: Indonesia plans to offer 10 oil and gas working areas to contractors this year, including a block in the South China Sea, amid efforts to make new discoveries and reach one million barrels of oil per day by 2030.
Brent crude futures settled US$1.61 higher, or 2 per cent, to US$82.21 a barrel, compared with about US$98 a barrel on the eve of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine a year ago.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance H2 profit up 113.7% to S$85.8 million on strong loan growth, higher asset yields
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 113.7% increase in net profit to S$85.8 million for its second half of 2022, driven by strong loan growth and higher asset yields. The company's net interest margin expanded to 2.11%, resulting in a 64.3% increase in net interest income. The group also saw a 26.7% growth in fee and commission income. A final dividend of 13.25 cents per share is recommended, up from 8.25 cents in the previous year.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Hong Leong Finance branch at Hong Lim Complex.

site_title: Double whammy for Healthbank Holdings – trade-with-caution alert, compliance notice
summary: Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has issued a "trade-with-caution" alert on Healthbank Holdings, citing unusual trading activity from August to November 2022. The regulator found that a small group of market participants accounted for 80% of the total volume traded during this period. SGX RegCo is reviewing the trades and may refer the case to statutory authorities if necessary. The company's proposed acquisition of New Energy International Investment Holdings has also been classified as a "very substantial acquisition," requiring further review and shareholder approval.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Gear said a key rationale for the deal is to cut its exposure to the thermal coal business conducted by Gems, which faces ESG pressures

site_title: Tuan Sing narrows H2 net loss to S$5.1 million on higher revenue, improved margins
summary: Tuan Sing Holdings reported a narrowed net loss of S$5.1 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, from a net loss of S$17.1 million the previous year, driven by higher revenue and improved margins. Revenue for the second half rose 8% to S$111.3 million, while gross profit gained 57%. The board proposed a final dividend of 0.7 Singapore cents per share, unchanged from the previous year. The company adopted a cautiously optimistic outlook for the real estate market due to rising interest rates and construction costs.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The acquisition of SP allows Tuan Sing to reduce the duplication of compliance and associated costs in maintaining the listing status of both companies.
Tuan Sing CEO William Liem pictured on 30 August, 2021.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia posts 38% drop in H2 earnings to S$12 million on lower revenue
summary: Hong Leong Asia's net profit fell 38.3% to S$12 million in the second half of 2022, driven by a 14.8% decline in revenue to S$1.8 billion. Lower revenue from its Yuchai diesel engines unit in China, down 19.8%, contributed to the decline. However, the building materials unit's revenue increased by 22.2%. The group expects improved economic activities in China to lead to greater growth opportunities for Yuchai's powertrains and engines, with shares closing 2.9% higher at S$0.71.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Stephen Ho, chief executive officer of Hong Leong Asia.
A recovery in Singapore's construction industry will likely offset the slower growth in Hong Leong Asia's diesel engine segment.

site_title: LTA, EDB to push on with autonomous vehicle development despite ST Engineering’s withdrawal from bus trials
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Economic Development Board (EDB) will continue to work on autonomous vehicle (AV) trials and deployment despite ST Engineering's withdrawal from bus trials. ST Engineering cited significant financial resources required, estimated at over S$150 million, as the reason for its decision. LTA and EDB acknowledged the challenges in the AV industry, stating that near-term commercial viability will be challenging globally and locally. The agencies will partner stakeholders to develop necessary policy and legislative frameworks to support AV deployment, with the goal of achieving greater public acceptance.

images.alt_text: A MooVita autonomous vehicle seen on 30 November 2019. Local autonomous vehicle start-up MooVita is developing a software solution that transforms various vehicle types into autonomous vehicles for different driving conditions and applications.
sT Engineering proposed a final dividend of 4 Singapore cents, to be paid on May 9 after books closure on Apr 27.

site_title: Sabana Reit’s independent directors recommend unitholders accept Volare’s partial offer
summary: Sabana Reit's independent directors recommend unitholders accept Volare's partial offer of S$0.465 per unit for 10% of units, a 9.4% premium above the volume-weighted average price. The offer price is also at a premium of 5.7-15.4% to historical VWAPs and implies a P/NAV ratio of 0.87 times, similar to peers. The closing date of the offer will be after the declared books closure date of the DPU, with an ex-distribution offer price of S$0.4504.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The partial offer for Sabana Reit is not particularly compelling, but could have implications for its future direction.
Volare says it is launching the partial offer to diversify its business away from fossil fuels and build up its real estate portfolio.

Quarz noted that Volare’s voluntary conditional offer to acquire an additional 10 per cent of Sabana Reit units at S$0.465 per unit is more than 50 per cent above a previous offer that the directors had recommended as “fair and reasonable”.

site_title: China's economy to rebound in 2023 under precise, forceful monetary policy
summary: China's economy is expected to rebound in 2023 under a precise and forceful monetary policy, according to the central bank's quarterly policy implementation report. The People's Bank of China will focus on supporting domestic demand expansion and stabilizing economic growth and prices while avoiding "flood-like" stimulus. The report notes that the external environment remains "severe and complex" and that the property sector requires time to transition, while balancing local government fiscal revenue and expenditure persists. The central bank aims to keep liquidity reasonably ample and maintain effective credit growth.

images.alt_text: International financial institutions and commercial creditors should follow the principle of “joint action, fair burden” in debt settlements, said .Chinese Finance Minister Liu Kun.

site_title: AEM’s H2 earnings sink 30% to S$44 million
summary: AEM, a semiconductor equipment manufacturer, reported a 30% decline in second-half earnings to S$44 million, down from S$62.4 million the previous year. Revenue for the six months ended December 31, 2022, dropped 12% to S$330 million, from S$373.2 million. Despite a 54% increase in full-year revenue to a record high of S$870.5 million, the earnings decline was attributed to a weaker second half.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Maybank expects AEM's orderbook to fall in 2023 following a robust H1 2022.

site_title: Air India to hire over 4,200 cabin crew, 900 pilots after record aircraft deal
summary: Air India plans to hire over 4,200 cabin crew and 900 pilots in 2023 as part of a major overhaul following a record aircraft deal for 470 jets from Airbus and Boeing. The airline aims to capitalize on India's growing base of fliers and strong demand for air travel. The move follows a revamp initiated after Air India returned to the Tata Group's fold last year to repair its reputation. The airline had previously recruited 1,900 cabin crew and is also seeking to step up hiring of pilots and maintenance engineers.

images.alt_text: Founded under Tata in the 1930s, Air India is attempting to win back traffic from Emirates and Qatar Airways.

site_title: QAF’s H2 earnings halved to S$11.2 million despite higher revenue
summary: QAF, the maker of Gardenia bread, posted a net profit of S$11.2 million for the second half of 2022, down 54% from the previous year due to the absence of earnings from discontinued operations. Revenue increased 6% to S$307.1 million, while full-year earnings fell 63% to S$19.4 million. The group expects 2023 to be a "challenging operating environment" and has proposed a final dividend of S$0.04 per share.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
QAF says its H2 performance is “typically” better than H1, although it had been challenging to comment on the trend in the current volatile environment.

site_title: Credit Suisse cuts property fund payouts as withdrawals mount
summary: Credit Suisse cut payouts on its 3.25 billion Swiss franc real estate fund, citing a 10% drop in net asset value due to rising interest rates. The fund's payouts are expected to limit distributions to as low as 35 francs a share, down from 40 francs a share. Investors have sought to pull their cash after valuations were hit by rising interest rates, which have negatively impacted global real estate values. This move follows other property funds, such as BlackRock's UK fund and Blackstone's US$69 billion real estate trust, which have also seen withdrawal requests.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse has agreed to compensate Georgian billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili for failing to “police the perimeter” of his wealth from theft.
The new bond, to be sold by Credit Suisse’s operating company, will mature in August 2026

site_title: New tender category will give SMEs better access to government contracts
summary: Singapore's government has introduced a new "Tender Lite" category for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to access government contracts, with fewer and simpler conditions. The category will cover over 70% of current SME tenders, allowing firms to participate in contracts valued between S$90,000 and S$1 million. Additionally, the government aims to include sustainability requirements in all procurement within the next five years, with up to 5% of evaluation points set aside for sustainability-related considerations. The government also launched eGuarantee@Gov and InvoiceNow to simplify processes and improve efficiency.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Some MPs wanted small- and medium-sized enterprises to get more help to offset high operating costs, and enhanced productivity and digitisation initiatives.
There are real business costs to some policies in Budget 2023, even after accounting for transitory government aid to mitigate some of these expenditures
SMEs must commit to digital innovation, upskilling and R&D collaboration to maintain growth

site_title: Hotel Properties H2 net profit rises to S$74.5 million on higher revenue
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd reported a net profit of S$74.5 million for the second half of 2022, up 518% from the same period in 2021, driven by higher revenue of 58.1% to S$276 million. The company attributed the growth to better hotel performance as borders reopened. A first and final cash dividend of S$0.04 per share and a special dividend of S$0.01 per share have been recommended. Despite challenges, Hotel Properties expects to complete several projects, including a London Underground ticket hall and Bankside Yards development.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
DBS noted that the Hotel Properties’ revenue or revenue per available room (revpar) has returned close to 90 per cent of pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Orix weighs cutting contribution to JIP’s Toshiba offer, sources say
summary: Orix, a major stakeholder in the JIP-led consortium pursuing a Toshiba takeover, is considering reducing its financial contribution from 300 billion yen to 200 billion yen. This move could revive concerns about funding issues for the consortium's multi-billion dollar offer to acquire Toshiba. Other co-investors are also requesting to cut their stakes, adding another hurdle to the buyout. The consortium still needs to finalize financing and set up a special purpose company, which is dependent on co-investors signing legally binding agreements.

site_title: UOBKH posts 10.6% drop in H2 net profit on lower revenue
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) posted a 10.6% drop in H2 net profit to S$52.6 million, down from S$58.9 million previously, due to lower commission and trading income. Revenue fell 9.3% to S$260.5 million, with commission and trading income decreasing 32.6%. Despite a 68.9% increase in interest income, the brokerage expects an eventual market recovery. A final dividend of 6 Singapore cents per share has been proposed, down from 8.8 cents previously.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
UOBKH says it will work with an external party to implement recommendations raised and ensure that the remedial measures are effective in addressing regulatory concerns.

SGX RegCo said on Tuesday (Dec 27) after market close that it is barring UOBKH from undertaking new mandates to act as an issue manager or full sponsor for IPO adn RTO submissions on the local bourse.

site_title: Investors dumping equities, cash amid fears of hawkish fed, Bank of America says
summary: Investors are shifting assets from equities and cash to bonds amid concerns over the Federal Reserve's hawkish policy moves, according to Bank of America. Global equity funds lost $7 billion in outflows, while US cash funds saw $3.8 billion leave, while bonds drew $4.9 billion for an eighth consecutive week. Bank of America strategist Michael Hartnett predicts the S&P 500 could decline to 3,800 points by March 8, implying a 5% drop from its latest close.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that Singapore cannot cut land prices to address high housing costs, as this would not effectively increase supply. The country's manufacturing sector is expected to continue contracting in the first quarter of 2023. The latest Singapore Savings Bond tranche received S$261.1 million in applications, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.5% on Friday, snapping a four-day losing streak.

site_title: ComfortDelGro H2 earnings up 63.3% to S$57.8 million, proposes special dividend
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transport operator, reported earnings of S$57.8 million for the second half of 2022, a 63.3% increase from the same period in 2021. Full-year earnings rose 40.7% to S$173.1 million. The company proposes a final dividend of S$0.0176 per share and a special dividend of S$0.0246 per share to commemorate its 20th anniversary.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The downgrade comes amid concerns over ComfortDelGro's market leadership in the public bus sector after two of its bus contracts were put up for tender.
ComfortDelGro's venture arm has not made investments at a regular pace as its peers, and having a separate head and team running its US$100 million fund could help fulfil its potential.
The investment in Shift4Good was made through ComfortDelGro’s US$100 million venture capital fund.

site_title: Indonesia Battery eyes surge in electric scooters sales on incentive plan
summary: Indonesia Battery Corporation is targeting a 25-30% market share in electric motorbike sales, aiming for 75,000-100,000 units in production capacity within the next few years. The company is part of the government's efforts to boost electric vehicle adoption, with a goal of 2 million electric motorbike sales by 2025. This would represent a significant increase from the less than 40,000 units sold between 2019 and 2022.

site_title: Latest Singapore Savings Bond less than half subscribed
summary: Singapore's latest tranche of Savings Bonds (SSBs) received 43.5% of the allotted S$258.3 million in applications, totaling S$261.1 million, out of the S$600 million offered. This marks another undersubscribed issuance, following a similar trend last month. The average 10-year return for the latest round of SSBs was 2.9%, lower than the previous tranche's 3.47%.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
A staff counts Singapore dollar currency notes at a money changer booth at Raffles Place financial business district in Singapore on October 6, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Sun, sand and no inheritance tax fuel property boom in Mauritius
summary: Mauritius' luxury real estate market is experiencing a boom, fueled by its white-sand beaches, blue lagoons, and lack of inheritance tax. Kerzner International is investing $100 million in 52 ultra-exclusive villas, with over 80% of units sold. Foreign direct investment in high-end property has reached $1.8 billion, with France and South Africa being key markets. The island's tourism and hospitality sector is thriving, employing 100,000 people, and property sales are driving foreign currency inflows. Developers are responding to demand with lavish properties and expanding into the mid-range market, with the market expected to continue growing despite challenges.

images.alt_text: The Generali Tower at the CityLife district designed by Zaha Hadid; CityLife is a mixed-use luxury district on the north-east outskirts of Milan featuring swanky buildings by starchitects Daniel Libeskind, Hadid and Arata Isozaki.

In expatriate-dominated Dubai, though, home prices and rents have surged amid an influx of Russians looking to protect their wealth after the invasion of Ukraine, and as bankers fled strict lockdowns in Asia.
The Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat property is situated in perhaps France’s most expensive location, a magnet for royals, Hollywood icons and technology billionaires.

site_title: Chinese company discusses selling drones to Russia: Der Spiegel
summary: China is in talks with Russia to sell 100 drones, the ZT-180, capable of carrying a 35-50kg warhead, according to German magazine Der Spiegel. The drones, similar to Iran's Shaheed-136, have been used in military exercises and have a "first-class" technical strength. The sale has been met with warnings from Western countries, including the US, Germany, and others, which have urged China not to supply weapons to Russia amid its war against Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The US believe Iranian drones were used on Monday in a morning rush hour attack on the Ukrainian capital Kyiv.

site_title: Germany wants 'war' mentioned in G20 statement
summary: Germany is pushing for a joint G20 statement to explicitly mention "war" in reference to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, amid India's reluctance to use the word. German Finance Minister Christian Linder stated that mentioning "war" is necessary to clearly condemn Russia and President Vladimir Putin. This comes as Russia is a G20 member but did not attend the finance ministers meeting. The issue may hinder a joint statement, similar to previous gatherings, and reflects the ongoing diplomatic tensions between Russia and the international community.

images.alt_text: Speaking in a closed-door meeting on Friday (Feb 24) in Bengaluru, India, where G-20 finance ministers and central bank governors are gathered, Yellen reiterated calls to her counterparts to redouble efforts to restrict Russia’s capacity to wage war.

site_title: US dollar rises to fresh seven-week high on rate outlook; yen slides
summary: The US dollar index reached a seven-week high at 104.80, driven by strong US economic data and expectations of higher interest rates. The yen slid 0.45% against the US dollar after Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda warned of maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy. Investors expect US rates to peak in July at 5.35% and remain above 5% until the end of the year, with the US dollar holding firm against other major currencies.

images.alt_text: The first U.S. banknotes printed with two women's signatures are seen at an unveiling event in Fort Worth, Texas, U.S., December 8, 2022.   REUTERS/Shelby Tauber

site_title: Malaysia unveils record RM388 billion budget; higher tax on the rich
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has unveiled a record RM388.1 billion budget, focusing on sustainable economic growth, reducing social inequality, and tackling corruption. The budget includes a new luxury tax, increased tax on high-income earners, and a tax reduction for middle-income earners. The national debt stands at RM1.2 trillion, above 60% of Malaysia's GDP, and the government aims to narrow the deficit to 5% of GDP this year. The budget also includes measures to attract investors and improve healthcare services.

images.alt_text: Anwar is expected to present a revised government budget on Feb 24.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is set to table the country's revised 2023 budget to parliament on Feb 24.

site_title: Singapore a potential claimant from loss, damage financing: Grace Fu
summary: Sustainability and Environment Minister Grace Fu stated that Singapore, classified as a developing country, may be a potential claimant to the loss and damage financing for climate change. The country is already dedicating S$100 billion to adaptation measures. Fu emphasized that Singapore will engage constructively with the transitional committee set up to determine the fund's details, including how developing countries will access it.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Displaced flood-affected children attend a mobile school class near a makeshift camp in the flood-hit area of Dera Allah Yar in Jaffarabad district of Pakistan's Balochistan province, Jan 9, 2023.

site_title: Singapore stocks snap 4-day losing streak; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week down 1.4% after snapping a four-day losing streak, closing at 3,282.30 with a 0.5% gain on Friday. Advancers outnumbered decliners 293 to 250, with 1.37 billion securities worth S$1.17 billion traded. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike fears continue to impact investor sentiment, with SPI Asset Management's Stephen Innes stating the Fed is unlikely to cut interest rates until a growth risk emerges.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
On the Singapore Exchange, gainers outnumber losers 66 to 50 after 79.2 million securities worth S$57.1 million changed hands.
Fed chairman Jerome Powell said last week, "We can now say, I think for the first time, that the disinflationary process has started."

site_title: Audi plans electric car factory in US due to IRA, CEO says
summary: Audi plans to build an electric car factory in the US due to the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), according to CEO Markus Duesmann. The joint plant, likely with Volkswagen, would take advantage of the IRA's subsidies and tax incentives for US-made electric vehicles. This move comes as carmakers shift production to the US to reduce logistics costs. Volkswagen has also announced plans to invest $7.1 billion in North America and add 25 new electric vehicles by 2030, with Audi expected to follow suit.

site_title: China prepares to police AI as ChatGPT frenzy spreads
summary: China is set to introduce regulations to govern the use of artificial intelligence (AI) across various industries, amid the growing popularity of AI-powered chatbots like ChatGPT. The regulations aim to ensure safe and controllable AI services, with a focus on censorship of undesirable content online. The move is seen as a strategic industry for China, with the government also monitoring the evolution of AI to address ethical concerns. The regulations are expected to benefit companies like Baidu Inc., providing clearer ground rules for future services.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT: Has artificial intelligence come for our jobs?
Baidu is regarded as at the forefront of efforts to create a Chinese rival to the AI platform developed by OpenAI and backed by Microsoft.
Google could face a US$6-billion hike in expenses by 2024 if ChatGPT-like AI were to handle half the queries it receives with 50-word answers, analysts projected.

The rise of AI tools like ChatGPT, which can churn out text in natural-sounding language in a variety of styles, has sparked concern in many sectors, particularly with regards to plagiarism and cheating in exams.
While the Fudan University team had on Monday initially described MOSS as a conversational language model like ChatGPT, on Tuesday they played down the comparison, saying they had much to improve.

site_title: China’s services trade deficit widens as outbound tourism resumes
summary: China's service trade deficit widened to US$15.4 billion in January, driven by a surge in outbound tourism after Beijing reopened its borders. Tourism contributed US$14.5 billion to the deficit, up from US$12.5 billion in December. The wider deficit poses headwinds, with consumption by Chinese tourists outside the country accounting for up to 85% of the service deficit before the pandemic. The yuan weakened to 6.9442 per US dollar, and economists warn of looming downside pressure on the Chinese currency due to weaker exports and rising domestic capital outflows.

site_title: China calls for ‘joint action’ in debt settlements at G20
summary: China's Finance Minister Liu Kun urged G20 nations to adopt a "joint action, fair burden" principle in debt settlements, calling for a comprehensive and effective solution to global debt issues. China has been critical of multilateral lenders for not taking haircuts on bilateral loans, while being asked to do so on credit extended to debtor countries. Officials from the IMF, World Bank, and G7 nations will meet to discuss debt restructuring, with China expected to play a key role in the G20 Common Framework.

images.alt_text: "It is now up to you – the custodians of the leading economies and monetary systems of the world, to bring back stability, confidence and growth to the global economy,” said Prime Minister Modi.
Attendees at the second meeting of the G20 Finance and Central Bank Deputies on Feb 22, in Bengaluru, India

site_title: Singapore’s total fertility rate hit record low in 2022, help for aspiring parents
summary: Singapore's total fertility rate (TFR) hit a record low of 1.05 in 2022, with more people delaying marriage and parenthood. The government will support aspiring parents with measures such as increased support for first-timer families, a higher co-matching cap in the Child Development Account, and government-paid paternity leave. The government will also review flexible work arrangements and childcare leave to better support new parents. Amidst a slowing workforce growth and aging population, the government aims to strengthen the social compact and develop a more cohesive society through immigration and upskilling initiatives.

images.alt_text: A pregnant lady at the Raffles Place MRT station, 2 August 2022.

site_title: Gallant Venture reverses H2 loss, but remains in the red for FY2022
summary: Gallant Venture, a developer and manager of industrial parks and resorts in Batam and Bintan, reported a net profit of S$4 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, reversing a net loss of S$30.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 26% to S$91.1 million, driven by higher occupancy and improved resort segment. Despite this, the company remains in the red for FY2022 with a net loss of S$12.8 million, and has committed to using its cash resources to further develop its industrial parks businesses.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

Aerial view of the upcoming halal industrial park, which is part of Bintan Industrial Estate. The Bintan park will focus on food and beverage products, while the Batam park will specialise in non-food products such as cosmetics.
The latest result follows consecutive years of losses, but narrows losses from the year ago period.

site_title: China to overhaul financial system giving Xi more control
summary: China is set to overhaul its financial system, centralizing decision-making under President Xi Jinping. The move could lead to a powerful committee reviving the Central Financial Work Commission, with Xi's chief of staff Ding Xuexiang potentially becoming its head. Vice Premier He Lifeng is also being considered for the role of party secretary at the People's Bank of China, elevating the central bank's role in financial regulation. The overhaul aims to consolidate Xi's power and increase control over key economic policies, with significant implications for China's $60 trillion financial sector.

images.alt_text: International financial institutions and commercial creditors should follow the principle of “joint action, fair burden” in debt settlements, said .Chinese Finance Minister Liu Kun.

site_title: Cutting land prices for HDB flats risks destabilising  entire property market: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong has stated that cutting land prices for HDB flats to lower prices risks destabilizing the entire property market. He notes that current high prices are not due to land costs, but rather supply issues caused by the pandemic. Wong suggests that increasing funding to make new flats cheaper would be required, but instead proposes addressing the root cause by ramping up Build-To-Order (BTO) supply and catching up with delays.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Generic photo of condos and private properties
MPs call for even more support for families' housing aspirations, extend support for unwed single mothers.

site_title: Credit – what is it good for?
summary: Singapore's young adults are gaining easier access to credit, but may not be getting the necessary financial literacy to use it responsibly. Data from Credit Bureau Singapore shows a 20% growth in young adults (21-30) taking up credit cards between 2019 and 2022, with average charges increasing by 6.3%. Late payments and defaults among this demographic are also on the rise, with a 3% increase in late payments and 0.08% default rates in Q4 2022. Experts warn that overspending and lack of financial literacy can lead to debt spirals, negatively affecting mental and cognitive abilities. Digital banks are expanding to serve underserved segments, but the industry must ensure credit is commensurate with customers' creditworthiness.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
To compete with emerging BNPL players, several banks have introduced new cards or features that resemble BNPL products.

site_title: German economy shrinks 0.4% in fourth quarter, weak start to 2023 seen
summary: Germany's economy contracted 0.4% in the fourth quarter of 2022, more strongly than expected, due to inflation and the energy crisis affecting household consumption and capital investment. Consumer spending decreased 1.0% and investment in construction and machinery fell, while exports of goods and services dropped 1.0%. The drop in the Ifo's current assessment component and weak consumer confidence suggest a contraction in the first quarter, increasing fears of a winter recession.

site_title: ChatGPT’s reaction to Singapore Budget 2023 – a great mismatch
summary: ChatGPT, a popular AI tool, struggled to produce a thoughtful reaction to Singapore's Budget 2023, highlighting its limitations in reading and analyzing new issues. The AI failed to grasp nuances in the budget, such as the Chinese idiom "spring wind into rain," and didn't fully understand the implications of the Global Anti-Base Erosion (GloBE) Rules and Domestic Top-up Tax (DTT). The tool's inability to provide "eureka moments" and its lack of emotional intelligence also became apparent, leading to the conclusion that ChatGPT is not yet capable of achieving the level of thought leadership for a solid op-ed.

images.alt_text: The thrill of AI is undeniable, but we need to step back and ask the tough questions that only humans can.
Bill Gates, Microsoft co-founder, says: "The new programs like ChatGPT will make many office jobs more efficient by helping to write invoices or letters. "
Prompted by worries about plagiarism, ChatGPT has already been banned in schools in New York and Seattle, according to media reports.

site_title: Incoming Bank of Japan chief Ueda says current low rates appropriate
summary: Incoming Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda stated that maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy is appropriate due to Japan's trend inflation being driven by surging import costs, not strong domestic demand. Ueda warned that uncertainties remain, and if trend inflation lacks strength, the central bank may consider normalizing monetary policy. He hinted at phasing out the yield curve control (YCC) policy, which has been criticized for distorting market functions, but declined to comment on specific measures.

images.alt_text: Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes volatile fresh food but includes energy costs, rose 4.2 per cent in January from a year earlier, matching a median market forecast.
Among nearly 500 major companies polled, 47 per cent said the Bank of Japan should modify policies that allow interest rates to go negative.

site_title: Zee’s insolvency proceedings halted by Indian appeals tribunal
summary: An Indian appeals court has halted Zee Entertainment's insolvency proceedings, providing a major respite for the media company. The National Company Law Appellate Tribunal (NCLAT) ordered a detailed hearing of Zee's appeal against a bankruptcy court's order, which was initiated due to unpaid dues by a financial creditor. The halt comes as Zee was set to merge with a Sony Group subsidiary, threatening a $10 billion media giant. The NCLAT's decision allows the merger to proceed, with Zee's shares rising 3.1% on the news.

images.alt_text: Sony and Zee decided to merge their television channels, film assets and streaming platforms in December last year.

site_title: Chemical giant BASF to cut 2,600 jobs to save costs amid energy crisis
summary: BASF, Europe's largest chemical company, plans to cut 2,600 jobs, or 2% of its global workforce, to save costs amid the energy crisis. The company will close two ammonia plants and related fertilizer facilities in Germany, resulting in 700 job losses. BASF cited high energy prices, particularly gas costs, as a major factor in its decision. The company had previously targeted annual cost cuts of 500 million euros, and now expects lower operating profit this year due to the ongoing energy crisis.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on October 5, 2022 A corporate flag waves at the headquarters of German chemical company BASF in Ludwigshafen, Rhineland-Palatinate, western Germany. - German chemicals group BASF said on January 17, 2023 that it expected a net loss of 1.4 billion euros ($1.49 billion) for 2022 after taking a massive write-down on the value of its Russian gas operations, disrupted by Moscow's invasion of Ukraine. (Photo by ANDRE PAIN / AFP)

site_title: Nearly 30 residential projects carrying 1,400 unsold units face critical sales deadline in 2023
summary: Nearly 30 residential projects in Singapore are approaching a critical sales deadline, with nearly 1,400 unsold units at risk of not being cleared by the end of 2023. The projects, mostly in the prime Core Central Region, have yet to sell all their inventory since acquiring their sites. Developers face a hefty stamp duty payment, estimated to be tens of millions of dollars, if they fail to clear their inventory.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
The higher marginal BSD for higher-value residential and non-residential properties are expected to affect 15 per cent of residential properties.
As almost 90 per cent of resident households own their homes, one's home is a key asset for many people.

PropNex is urging for the additional buyer’s stamp duty remission treatment for married couples upgrading from HDB flats to private homes to be aligned with that of those upgrading to new executive condominiums from developers.

site_title: Taiwan plays down US troop presence as Pentagon boosts support
summary: Taiwan's Defence Minister Chiu Kuo-cheng has denied that US troops are permanently stationed on the island, despite the Pentagon's plan to increase its presence to train local forces, which would grow to 100-200 troops. The US support for Taiwan is seen as a sign of its willingness to raise tensions with China. The development comes as US-China relations have frayed since a US-China summit in Indonesia, with China denouncing the US for shooting down a Chinese spy balloon that crossed the US mainland.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese troops at a training exercise inside a military base in Taoyuan, Taiwan. The deployment of between 100 and 200 American troops to the island is to take place in the coming months.

site_title: Taiwan central bank sold US$13 billion in forex intervention in 2022
summary: The Taiwan central bank sold a net US$13 billion in foreign exchange intervention in 2022 to prop up the Taiwan dollar, which lost almost 10% of its value against the greenback last year. However, the dollar strengthened around 1% this year. The bank raised its policy rate by 12.5 basis points to 1.75% and signaled an end to rate hikes in 2023 as inflation is under control. Maintaining relative stability of the Taiwan dollar exchange rate is crucial, according to the central bank.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product is forecast to have expanded 2.9 per cent in 2022 from a year earlier.

site_title: SingLand H2 net profit falls 60% to S$95.3m; Wee Cho Yaw retires from board
summary: SingLand Group reported a 60% fall in net profit to S$95.3 million in the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, due to a fair-value loss on investment properties. The company also announced the retirement of veteran banker Wee Cho Yaw as chairman, replaced by his son Ee Lim. Revenue rose 26% to S$346.9 million, driven by hotel operations recovery, and the board proposed a final dividend of 3.5 Singapore cents per share.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Singapore Land Tower at 50 Raffles Place

site_title: Digital detox is a fantasy
summary: A digital detox, as popularized by wealthy individuals like Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff, is often seen as a fantasy due to the modern workplace's reliance on digital tools and constant notifications. A 2022 meta-analysis found that digital breaks may mitigate symptoms of depression in some individuals, but have no consistent impact on behavior, mood, or performance. Instead, experts suggest focusing on adding offline experiences and activities to one's life to mitigate the negative effects of excessive screen time, such as replacing screen time with hobbies, reading, or socializing.

images.alt_text: Quakers at a prayer vigil in front of the armed forces recruitment booth in Times Square, New York City, in 1961.
Alex Mearns, founder of Levitise
Off the grid ways to enjoy nature

site_title: Hong Kong home prices end seven-month decline with 0.6% rise in January
summary: Hong Kong private home prices rose 0.6% in January, ending a seven-month decline, due to the reopening of the border with mainland China and expectations of peaking interest rates. This follows a 15.2% drop in 2022, the first annual decline since 2008. The Hong Kong government lowered stamp duties for first-time home buyers of properties valued at HK$10 million or less to ease the burden on ordinary families. Real estate experts expect a recovery in the housing market in the second half of the year, driven by increased Chinese investment and slower interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: At a soiree of some 90 people on a recent Friday evening in the centre of Hong Kong’s financial district, women in white gloves hobnobbed with Sotheby’s executives as they admired Hermes collectibles.
Hong Kong’s strict policies during Covid-19 deterred businesses and visitors in the past three years, leading to lacklustre demand for the city’s traditionally sought-after real estate.

site_title: British Airways parent IAG flies back into annual profit
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways and Iberia, reported a net profit of 431 million euros (S$613.9 million) in 2022, reversing a loss of 2.9 billion euros in 2021. The global aviation sector's recovery from Covid lockdowns drove the profit. IAG aims to return to higher pre-Covid profit levels within the next few years. The company has restored 87% of its 2019 flying capacity and recently acquired Air Europa for 500 million euros.

images.alt_text: The International Civil Aviation Organization expects passenger demand to recover to pre-Covid levels on most routes this quarter and then to about 3 per cent higher than 2019 levels by year-end.

site_title: Yellen says ending war most important thing for global economy
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that ending the war in Ukraine is the most important thing for the global economy, as she accused Russian officials of being complicit in atrocities. Yellen reiterated calls to restrict Russia's capacity to wage war and increased financial support to Ukraine, with the US providing over $46 billion in assistance. She also warned Russian officials that they bear responsibility for the harm caused globally. Yellen's comments come on the one-year anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: India’s self-nomination as the leader of the Global South is the culmination of messaging on the global stage that it will not simply play by the rules and norms of more powerful nations.

site_title: The China imperative for MNCs
summary: Multinational companies (MNCs) operating in China must reassess their strategies due to shifting market dynamics and rising risks. Local companies are competing fiercely for market share, and MNCs are losing ground. Despite opportunities in emerging technologies and a large market, MNCs face unique challenges, including rising tensions, debt, and an ageing workforce. To succeed, MNCs must reconfigure their businesses, making key decisions on capital, ownership, supply chains, innovation, branding, talent, and technology and data. Those that adapt will be tomorrow's winners in a rapidly changing China.

images.alt_text: SHANGHAI officials are seeking to revive confidence among multinational firms bruised and frustrated by the city’s Covid-19 lockdown, by holding multiple meetings with foreign firms and easing a key border requirement for overseas workers.

The Yahoo! Inc. logo is displayed on an Apple Inc. iPhone 5s and laptop computer in this arranged photograph in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Tuesday, April 15, 2014. Yahoo! Inc. expected to release earnings figures after the market close on April 15. Photographer: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg

site_title: Modi flags emerging market debt risk as G20 finance chiefs meet
summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi warned G20 finance chiefs about the threat of unsustainable debt levels for developing nations, citing countries like Sri Lanka and Zambia. He urged collective action to strengthen multilateral banks and address global challenges like climate change. The UN also called for urgent liquidity injection and debt restructuring, citing unsustainable debt levels. The G20 meetings come at a time of heightened geo-political tensions, with India seeking to avoid using the term "war" in statements, amid strengthened trade links with Russia.

images.alt_text: Attendees at the second meeting of the G20 Finance and Central Bank Deputies on Feb 22, in Bengaluru, India

site_title: China’s BYD has three South-east Asian countries vying for plant
summary: China's BYD is in advanced discussions with the Philippines and Vietnam to host an electric vehicle assembly plant, as the company pivots away from the combustion engine. BYD, the world's second-largest EV maker, is considering the Philippines due to its growth potential and is exploring options for a full assembly plant or a final-assembly facility in the country. Indonesia is also competing for the investment, with the government offering tax holidays and incentives to convince BYD to set up there.

images.alt_text: The BYD HAN EV is displayed during an exhibition test drive as the Chinese electric-vehicle producer announces its expansion to the consumer market next year in Mexico, in Toluca, Mexico November 29, 2022. REUTERS/Toya Sarno Jordan
After wild success at home selling affordable electric cars to the masses, BYD is looking beyond China.
BYD plans to open more than 100 dealerships in Japan by the end of 2025, but faces a tough task in a country where  nine in 10 cars sold annually are built by domestic firms such as Toyota.
BYD sold 1.86 million new energy vehicles last year, more than the previous four years combined.

site_title: Sustainable Fitch assigns HDB mid-tier ESG rating of three
summary: Sustainable Fitch assigned the Housing and Development Board (HDB) an ESG entity rating of three, with a combined ESG instrument rating of three for its inaugural green bonds. The rating reflects a negative overall environmental view on the buildings sector due to construction activities and resource consumption. Despite HDB's commitment to green bonds and low-income housing schemes, it lags behind the labelled bond market in publicly disclosing environmental and social metrics.

images.alt_text: A staff counts Singapore dollar currency notes at a money changer booth at Raffles Place financial business district in Singapore on October 6, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: China’s ceasefire proposal for Ukraine gets quick dismissal
summary: China has proposed a 12-point ceasefire plan for the ongoing Ukraine-Russia conflict, but it appears to have little chance of gaining broad support. The proposal, which includes measures that could benefit Russian President Vladimir Putin, was met with skepticism from the US and most European countries. US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan said China's proposal should have ended after the first bullet point, calling for "respecting the sovereignty of all countries." The proposal's release came as Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva signaled his intention to mediate an end to the war, but its impact is uncertain due to China's reputation as an impartial mediator in the conflict.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin shakes hands with China's top diplomat Wang Yi during their meeting in the Kremlin on 22 Feb 2023.

site_title: UK’s soaring mortgage costs mean it’s cheaper to rent a home
summary: The UK's soaring mortgage costs have made renting a home cheaper than buying for the first time in 14 years, according to an analysis by Capital Economics. Average mortgage repayments have surpassed £1,000 per month, while rent payments remained relatively stable at £900-£1,000 per month. This trend is expected to persist until mid-2024, with the gap between mortgage costs and rent payments widening further. The surge in mortgage costs is also expected to trigger a slump in house prices and a sustained correction in the UK property market.

site_title: Of bot farms, triangulation and double dips
summary: Fraudsters are increasingly using advanced tactics to target merchants, including human 'bot' farms, where trafficked individuals are used to conduct brute force attacks, and low-tech address manipulation, where fraudsters write variations of an address to evade rule-based solutions. Other trends include triangulation, where stolen items are sold through marketplaces, and double-dipping, where bad actors file chargebacks or returns to receive money back. Friendly fraud, which includes chargeback fraud and returns abuse, is also on the rise. To combat these tactics, merchants are shifting towards using identity-based solutions, which can pinpoint the identity behind an interaction and block fraudulent transactions.

images.alt_text: ecommerce, online, shop

site_title: Singapore has no ‘fiscal slack’ but must be careful with corporate tax moves: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the country has a tight fiscal position, with no "fiscal slack" to raise taxes. The government aims to balance support for cost-of-living pressures with inflation concerns. Wong emphasized the need to carefully consider alternative revenue sources, such as corporate taxes, due to global tax changes and competition. The government will implement a domestic top-up tax to achieve a minimum effective tax rate under the Base Erosion Profit Shifting (BEPS) 2.0 initiative. Wong also defended the government's decision not to hike the Goods and Services Tax (GST), citing the need for a diversified revenue base and progressive redistribution policies.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

ST20230214-202336309352-Lim Yaohui-pixbudget/

Mr Lawrence Wong, Minister for Finance, arriving at Parliament House to deliver his Budget Statement speech on Budget Day, Feb 14, 2023.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)
Combining government expenditure, operating revenue and net investment returns contribution projections, government spending will likely be balanced by total revenue in the coming years.
File photo of Non-Constituency MP Hazel Poa from the Progress Singapore Party speaking in Parliament on Nov 28, 2022.

site_title: Replacing unproductive jobs is part of healthy economic growth: DPM Wong
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for economic growth, stating that the government remains focused on growing the economic pie despite the challenging external environment. Replacing unproductive jobs is part of healthy economic growth, with new, better roles being created in their place. To support workers, the government is investing in skills and human capital, including the newly-announced Jobs-Skills Integrator, and considering temporary financial support for involuntarily unemployed workers. The government aims to balance growth with support for displaced workers, particularly mature workers, to ensure the economic pie continues to grow.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
To address high housing prices, supply needs to be increased by ramping up BTO supply and catching up with pandemic-related delays, says DPM Wong.
MPs covered a wide range of issues during the Budget debate on Thursday, seeking greater support for vulnerable workers, even as they called for larger businesses to do more to contribute to society.
MPs call for even more support for families' housing aspirations, extend support for unwed single mothers.
Some MPs wanted small- and medium-sized enterprises to get more help to offset high operating costs, and enhanced productivity and digitisation initiatives.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Inflation worries cause market jitters (Ep 33)
summary: Inflation worries continue to cause market jitters, with investors increasingly concerned about the economic impact of rising prices. Claressa Monteiro, host of the Market Focus podcast, explores the macroeconomic activity that's driving market movements. This week's episode delves into the effects of inflation on various markets, with a focus on the Asia region. Experts analyze the potential consequences of inflation on the economy and provide insights into market trends.

images.alt_text: How did markets react after Singapore Budget 2023?
How were markets this week? Podcast editor Claressa Monteiro finds out.

site_title: Credit Suisse, Mizuho join banks on US$1 billion Olam Agri IPO
summary: Olam Agri, a Singapore-headquartered agricultural commodity trader, plans to list its agricultural business in Singapore and Saudi Arabia, aiming to raise up to $1 billion. Credit Suisse, Mizuho, EFG Hermes, and SNB Capital are among the banks working on the deal, with Citigroup, DBS, HSBC, and Morgan Stanley already involved. The listing would be Olam Agri's first global company listing in Riyadh, potentially boosting the kingdom's stock exchange. The move follows a successful IPO in Saudi Arabia and the UAE last year, which raised $23 billion.

images.alt_text: Olam International's new office at Straits View, Marina One East Tower. It has an 18-metre long green wall, designed to capture the spirit of their business and create a living green space.
Olam among first in Singapore market to report detailed natural capital accounts

site_title: IMF lays out crypto action plan, recommends against legal tender status
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has released a nine-point action plan for countries to handle cryptocurrency assets, with the top recommendation being not to grant cryptocurrencies like bitcoin official currency or legal tender status. The plan aims to safeguard monetary sovereignty and stability, guard against excessive capital flows, and establish international arrangements for supervision and regulation. The IMF warns that widespread adoption of crypto assets could undermine monetary policy effectiveness and exacerbate fiscal risks.

images.alt_text: US cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase Global this week indicated that more layoffs could be in store, after cutting 20 per cent of its workforce in January.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies Bitcoin, Ethereum and DogeCoin are placed on PC motherboard in this illustration taken, June 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: Adobe signs chip supplier Qualcomm for marketing tech software
summary: Adobe has signed a deal with chip supplier Qualcomm to use its cloud-based marketing software, aimed at tracking and optimizing website elements to attract customers. The deal comes as Qualcomm expands its business into computing chips for various applications. The software will help Qualcomm tailor its website to different customer groups, such as Android developers and automotive companies. The companies did not disclose the deal's value. This marks Adobe's continued growth, having nearly doubled its revenue since 2018.

images.alt_text: “The Commission will now ask Adobe to notify the transaction. Adobe cannot implement the transaction before notifying and obtaining clearance from the Commission,” European Commission said.
Adobe’s US$20 billion offer was delivered in early July 2022.

site_title: Adani Group to hold Asia fixed-income roadshow next week
summary: The Adani Group will hold a fixed-income investor roadshow in Asia next week, following a critical report from Hindenburg Research that led to a slump in its bonds and stocks. The roadshow will take place in Singapore on Feb 27 and Hong Kong on Feb 28-31. The group is seeking to repair damage caused by the report, which alleged accounting fraud and stock manipulation, and faces debt maturities by the end of next year. Adani has denied the allegations and has taken steps to calm traders concerned about its access to financing.

images.alt_text: Signage of Adani Group in Mumbai, India, on Friday, Jan. 27, 2023. Shares of Adani Group’s companies have lost more than $30 billion in market value in less than two sessions, as a selloff sparked by US short seller Hindenburg Research’s scathing report deepened on Friday. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the wall of its realty office building on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
More than 500 funds registered in the European Union as “promoting” ESG goals hold Adani stocks, either directly or indirectly, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: Six dead, dozens still missing after China mine collapse
summary: A mine collapse in northern China's Inner Mongolia region has killed six people and left dozens missing. A rescue operation involving hundreds of workers is ongoing after a 180-metre-high slope gave way at the open-pit mine in the Alxa Left Banner area. 47 people remain unaccounted for, with six recovered alive and six found dead. The cause of the collapse is still unknown, and authorities are conducting a comprehensive investigation.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of rescue vehicles working at the site of a collapsed coal mine in Alxa League, north China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region.

site_title: Despite the bullish talk, Wall Street has China reservations
summary: Western financiers are cautious about investing in China due to growing risks, including Xi Jinping's capricious attitude towards business and the country's increasing economic concentration. Despite China's potential for growth, investors are cutting back their exposure to the country, with some even labeling it "uninvestable." China's economy is reopening after years of lockdowns, but the country's relations with the West continue to sour, raising the prospect of further economic estrangement.

images.alt_text: Most economists recognise that China’s gradual rebalancing to a more consumer-led economy can help to mitigate some of headwinds and challenges it faces.
With yuan-denominated funds, investing in and exiting a local portfolio would be easier in the current macroeconomic environment, some investors said.

site_title: EV maker Nio plans new 40 GWh battery plant in China: sources
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, plans to build its first battery plant in China, with an annual capacity of 40 GWh, enough to power around 400,000 units of long-range EVs. The plant, located in Hefei city, aims to reduce the company's reliance on suppliers like CATL. Nio's founder and chairman William Li previously stated plans to start producing 800-volt lithium-ion battery packs in the second half of 2024, similar to Tesla's strategy.

site_title: Bond yields are jumping at US Fed phantom shadows
summary: US Treasury yields are nearing 4% as the Federal Reserve tightens aggressively, with 10-year yields approaching the 4% mark. Despite this, investors should consider adding to bond holdings, not reducing them. Shorter maturities, such as the two-year US yield, are leading the way, reaching 4.7% and its highest since the global financial crisis. This trend is expected to continue, driven by market expectations of further Fed tightening, which may have a lagging negative impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve delivered a string of 75-basis-point and 50-basis point rate hikes in 2022 in its battle to curb inflation that had climbed to 40-year highs.
While China is still the largest overseas holder of Treasuries after Japan, its stockpile has now fallen to the lowest level since June 2010.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 39.74 points, or 0.12 per cent, at the open to 33,169.33.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed, Tokyo boosted by BoJ nominee
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Friday, with Tokyo rallying after Japan's next central bank head nominee, Kazuo Ueda, said the country's ultra-loose monetary policy was "appropriate". The Fed's interest rate hike concerns have weighed on global equities this month, with the PCE price index release expected to provide further insight into inflation. Despite this, Ueda's comments suggest the BOJ may keep rates low to support the economy.

images.alt_text: Among nearly 500 major companies polled, 47 per cent said the Bank of Japan should modify policies that allow interest rates to go negative.
Incoming Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the recent rise in consumer inflation was driven mostly by surging import costs of raw material, rather than strong domestic demand.

site_title: Singapore manufacturing contraction likely to persist as January data disappoints
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector is expected to contract for the first half of 2023 due to lackluster external conditions. The country's manufacturing output fell 1.1% in January, reversing from a 2.6% expansion in December 2022. This marks the fourth consecutive month of decline, with a 2.7% drop on the year. Economists predict stabilization in the second half of the year. The disappointing January data follows a "worst streak" since 2015, according to senior economist Alvin Liew.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
On the whole, NODX to Singapore's top 10 markets shrink in January, mainly due to .
Excluding the typically volatile biomedical manufacturing cluster, factory output expanded 0.3 per cent year on year, reversing November’s 5.8 per cent contraction.

site_title: ChatGPT: Has artificial intelligence come for our jobs?
summary: Artificial intelligence has reached a significant milestone with the release of ChatGPT, a chatbot capable of speaking in natural human language, performing tasks previously done by humans, and processing vast amounts of data. The AI has garnered over 100 million users, prompting concerns about job displacement. However, experts argue that AI is not a replacement for human thought and creativity, and that it can be a tool to simplify work processes and improve efficiency. Singapore's government is exploring the integration of ChatGPT in civil services, and businesses are encouraged to adapt to the new technology and focus on tasks that require human expertise.

images.alt_text: Stefanie Yuen Thio

One 2022 meta-analysis found that in people with symptoms of depression, a digital break mitigated their symptoms, but that otherwise, there was no consistent impact on detoxers’ behavior, mood or performance.

site_title: ST Engineering’s H2 net profit slips 7.1% on energy inflation, higher expenses, lower state support
summary: ST Engineering's H2 net profit fell 7.1% to S$255 million due to energy inflation, higher expenses, and reduced government support. Revenue rose 17.9% to S$4.8 billion. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.04 per share. Despite challenging operating conditions, the group reported a "strong recovery in underlying performance." Revenue from commercial aerospace rose 21%, driven by aviation recovery, and the group aims to achieve Ebit margin breakeven this year.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Yong Hui Ting
Gross proceeds from the rights issue will be used to partially fund the inflight caterer and ground handler’s acquisition of Paris-based Worldwide Flight Services.
Chinese tourists are welcomed as they arrive at Phnom Penh International Airport in Phnom Penh, Cambodia on Feb 7, 2023.

site_title: Gold drifts higher on softer dollar, eyes on US data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,824.88 per ounce, driven by a softer US dollar. The dollar index eased off a seven-week high, making gold less expensive for foreign buyers. Economic data, including unemployment claims and GDP growth, is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's rate-hike stance, which could impact gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation.

site_title: Google limits access to news in Canada as it tests proposed law
summary: Google has temporarily blocked access to news sites in Canada as part of a test for a proposed law requiring digital giants to pay for local journalism content. The restricted access affects 4% of Canadian users and will last for five weeks. The law, similar to Australia's New Media Bargaining Code, aims to help Canada's struggling news sector, which has seen over 450 outlets close since 2008. Google has previously signed agreements with French newspapers to pay for content, and its spokesperson warns that the Canadian law needs fixing to avoid impacting products Canadians rely on.

images.alt_text: Google could face a US$6-billion hike in expenses by 2024 if ChatGPT-like AI were to handle half the queries it receives with 50-word answers, analysts projected.
Alexandra Technopark accounted for 9.8 per cent of FLCT’s portfolio value as at end December.
Baidu is regarded as at the forefront of efforts to create a Chinese rival to the AI platform developed by OpenAI and backed by Microsoft.

site_title: Crypto retrenchment persists with over 2,000 jobs lost in 2023
summary: The digital assets industry has seen over 2,000 job losses in the first two months of 2023, with major companies such as Coinbase, Crypto.com, and Gemini announcing layoffs. These job cuts are attributed to the slow retail trading market, which has been impacted by failures and scandals in the sector last year. Other companies, including Chainalysis, Messari, and Polygon Labs, have also reported significant layoffs, with some cutting up to 30% of their workforce. This retrenchment persists despite a partial recovery in crypto prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies Bitcoin, Ethereum and DogeCoin are placed on PC motherboard in this illustration taken, June 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: Facebook, Instagram roll out paid subscription in Australia, New Zealand
summary: Facebook and Instagram have launched a paid subscription service, Meta Verified, in Australia and New Zealand, costing $11.99 and $14.99, respectively. The service offers verification, customer support, and increased visibility. Meta aims to mine more revenue from its 2 billion users, particularly creators and influencers. However, ordinary users seem hesitant to pay for the service, with many considering it unnecessary. Experts see this as part of a broader strategy to condition users to pay for social media services, potentially leading to subscription-based models for future features.

images.alt_text: The logos of Facebook and Instagram and the words "Monthly subscription" are seen in this picture illustration taken January 19, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/I
The new law would require digital giants to make fair commercial deals with Canadian outlets for the news and information that is shared on their platforms, or face binding arbitration.

site_title: Thai Airways 2022 operating loss narrows amid boom in air travel
summary: Thai Airways' operating loss narrowed 84% in 2022, reaching 4.6 billion baht (S$177.6 million), down from a 29.2 billion baht deficit in 2021, following the easing of pandemic-related border restrictions and a rebound in global air travel. The airline plans to exit a court-supervised debt restructuring earlier than scheduled in late 2024, citing increased cash flow and reduced loan needs. Thai Airways also announced plans to increase flight frequencies and add new routes, expand its fleet, and resume trading its stock in 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thai Airways aircraft are parked on the tarmac at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi International Airport March 27, 2015.  REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: Goldman Sachs offers rich clients access to Stripe’s multibillion fundraise
summary: Goldman Sachs is offering its richest clients access to a fundraising round for Stripe, a payments giant, to raise approximately $4 billion. The funds will be used to cover a looming tax bill and cash out veteran employees' restricted stock units. This deal mirrors Goldman's 2015 strategy for Uber Technologies, allowing high-net-worth clients to invest in private companies like Stripe before they become public. The offering is expected to augment Goldman's offerings for high-net-worth clients and help Stripe remain private for longer.

images.alt_text: Stripe was among tech firms that spent more heavily on adding talent and pushing into new areas during the depths of the pandemic when it saw spending volumes soar.
Stripe and other tech firms have seen valuations drop as the growth in online spending slowed in the aftermath of the pandemic.
Stripe in November cut its headcount by about 14 per cent, saying that the payments startup had overhired and grew operating costs too quickly.

site_title: TSMC’s second Japan plant to reportedly cost over 1 trillion yen
summary: TSMC, the world's most advanced chipmaker, plans to build its second chipmaking plant in Japan's Kumamoto prefecture with a total investment of over 1 trillion yen ($10 billion). The plant, expected to be completed in late 2020s, could utilize more advanced 5 nanometre or 10 nm manufacturing processes. TSMC is in negotiations for government subsidies and investment from customers, following similar incentives offered by the US and Japan. The company has partnered with Sony Group on the new facilities in Japan, further solidifying its presence in the region.

site_title: Can lab-made dairy find its whey into Singaporean hearts?
summary: Perfect Day, a California-based startup backed by Temasek, has launched Very Dairy, a lab-made milk alternative that contains cow's whey protein but is produced using a bioengineered fungus Trichoderma reesei. The company aims to cater to those who are allergic to lactose or prefer vegan options while still enjoying dairy's benefits. Very Dairy is now available in Singapore, where it retails at S$4.95 per liter, and has received positive reviews for its taste, although some find it confusing. Perfect Day plans to continue improving its formula to replicate the taste of cow's milk.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The days of unicorns running rampant may well be over.
Darren Teo and Elaine Teo, both Manging Partner, of Apricot Capital
Singapore plant-based milk startup sings a new Oat to joy

site_title: World’s third-largest IPO this year is set to debut in Jakarta
summary: PT Pertamina Geothermal Energy, Indonesia's largest geothermal unit, is set to debut in Jakarta with a $799.8 million IPO, making it the third-largest in the world this year. Almost two-thirds of the 21 companies that listed in Jakarta over the past decade finished their debut session higher than the listing price, with the average increase being 11%. The IPO is part of the government's efforts to raise funds and reduce reliance on the state budget, with more state-owned firms expected to list this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of state-owned oil giant Pertamina's refinery unit IV  in Cilacap, Central Java, Indonesia January 13, 2016. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo
The government is divesting stakes in state companies to fund expansion and reduce reliance on the state budget.
The IPO comes as Pertamina aims to double its geothermal capacity by 2027-2028, which may cost an estimated US$4 billion.

site_title: Booking Holdings says quarterly revenue up 36% on strong travel demand
summary: Booking Holdings reported a 36% year-over-year increase in quarterly revenue to $4 billion, exceeding estimates. The company booked over 95 million room nights in January 2023, a new record. Gross bookings rose 44% to $27.3 billion, driven by sustained travel demand despite economic concerns. CEO Glenn Fogel attributed the growth to consumers' strong desire to use the company's platforms when booking travel. The company's full-year revenue increased 56% to $17.1 billion, with gross travel bookings rising 58% to $121.3 billion.

images.alt_text: A picture shows screens displaying the logo and the website of the online travel and accommodation services platform Booking.com in Toulouse, southwestern France on January 25, 2023. - Dutch hotel booking platform Booking.com told AFP on January 25, 2023 that it had reached a "mutual agreement" with the French tax authorities to pay 153 million euros for a tax reassessment covering the period 2006-2018. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)

site_title: UK consumer confidence has sharpest rebound in almost two years
summary: UK consumer confidence has rebounded by the most in almost two years, jumping seven points to a minus 38 in February, according to GfK's consumer confidence indicator. This marks a 10-month high and suggests resilience among households, potentially helping prop up the economy through what's expected to be one of the longest slumps on record. The rebound is attributed to improved expectations for personal finances and the economic backdrop, with predictions of falling energy bills and declining inflation.

site_title: No rush to privatise ahead of rule changes; rising cost of debt should make listed status attractive
summary: Market watchers expect Singapore-listed companies to consider factors other than rule changes when deciding to privatize, citing rising debt costs and uncertain macroeconomic conditions. The proposed Companies Act amendments, set to raise the bar for controlling shareholders, may not significantly impact privatisation decisions. Instead, companies may prioritize equity fundraising over private sales, and minority shareholders should carefully consider privatisation offers.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
