Presently, the Companies Act allows an offeror to exercise the right of compulsory acquisition once it obtains at least 90 per cent of a target company's shares that it and its related companies did not already own.
Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within Frasers Hospitality Trust.

site_title: Japan’s consumer inflation hits 41-year high, keeps BOJ under pressure
summary: Japan's core consumer price index rose 4.2% in January, a 41-year high, exceeding the Bank of Japan's 2% target for nine straight months. The increase, driven by higher fuel and raw material costs, puts pressure on the central bank to phase out its stimulus program. Incoming Governor Kazuo Ueda faces a challenge in sustaining yield control policy amid market expectations of interest rate hikes. The data underscores the economic dilemma, with private consumption holding up despite rising living costs and uncertainties over the global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Japan is now experiencing a “rare” environment in which pent-up demand, driven by huge household savings accumulated during the Covid-19 pandemic, is underpinning the economy even as rising import costs push up inflation, BOJ board member Naoki Tamura said in a speech.

Toyota Motor (left) agreed to give the largest wage hikes in two decades according to its union and Honda Motor said it will raise wages by 5 per cent, including the biggest increase in base pay in about 30 years.

site_title: New ‘Lord of the Rings’ films announced by Warner Bros
summary: Warner Bros announced plans to create multiple new "Lord of the Rings" films, following the success of Peter Jackson's original trilogy, which grossed nearly US$3 billion and won 17 Oscars. The new films are set to be developed by studio chiefs Mike De Luca and Pam Abdy, who signed a deal to produce more movies based on JRR Tolkien's epic fantasy books.

images.alt_text: Triangle Of Sadness, a sharp satire of the moneyed class, has earned several awards and nominations, including the Oscar for Best Picture.
Alec Baldwin was holding a Colt .45 during rehearsals for the film in New Mexico when it discharged, killing Halyna Hutchins in October 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong’s rich are ready to party again as VIP events multiply
summary: Hong Kong's luxury art and shopping scene is resuming its pre-pandemic levels with the return of in-person VIP events ahead of the Art Basel fair. Global auction houses such as Sotheby's and Christie's are hosting exclusive gatherings, while the city's economy is benefiting from a "Hello Hong Kong" charm offensive and a giveaway of free air tickets to tourists. Despite lingering pandemic restrictions, collectors are eager to attend in-person events, with 69% preferring physical exhibitions over online purchases. The resurgent scene is expected to boost sales and attract more wealthy mainland Chinese patrons.

images.alt_text: The city is looking to kickstart its economy as it sees rising competition from Singapore to be Asia’s top destination for business, talent and capital.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit’s H2 DPU rises marginally to 0.08494 euro
summary: Cromwell E-Reit posted a half-year distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.08494 euro, a 0.4% increase from its previous year. Gross revenue rose 13.4% to 114.7 million euros, while net property income increased 5.1% to 69.4 million euros. The Reit's income growth is expected to be supported by high occupancy, rising market rents, and indexation, according to its manager.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The Reit's latest valuation represents a drop of 1.6 per cent from June last year, as the Reit’s assets in most countries’ saw a valuation decline.
The Reit’s gross revenue gains 10.4 per cent to 55.9 million euros from 50.7 million euros, while net property income grows 4.1 per cent to 34.5 million euros from 33.1 million euros.
Cromwell E-Reit’s manager does not expect the transaction to have a material effect on the Reit’s net tangible assets.
Cromwell European Reit has signalled its pivot to light industrial and logistics, with its acquisition of assets woth 57.8 million euro in the UK and the Netherlands

site_title: Bankman-Fried and others made more than 300 illegal political donations, new indictment says
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried and his co-conspirators made over 300 illegal political donations totaling tens of millions of US dollars in the US, according to a new indictment. The donations were made using straw donors or corporate funds, evading contribution limits on individual contributions to candidates. The indictment contains four fraud charges and eight conspiracy charges, including conspiracy to commit bank fraud and operating an unlicensed money transmitting business. Bankman-Fried previously faced eight counts of fraud and money laundering charges related to the collapse of FTX.

images.alt_text: FTX slid into a chaotic bankruptcy on Nov 11, leaving more than a million creditors around the world stranded and exacerbating a downturn in the world’s crypto industry.
The fund’s closure would see clients receive 90 per cent of the money not trapped on FTX, with the remaining 10 per cent temporarily held back until discussions with the FTX estate are finalised.
Sam Bankman-Fried, who has pleaded not guilty to fraud charges over the collapse of FTX, has deep ties to Stanford.

site_title: BT unveils new audio-visual studios
summary: BT unveils new audio-visual studios with over 2,000 sq ft of space, featuring two video studio spaces, a podcast studio, and four audio pods. The studios are designed to accommodate various types of filming and podcast sessions, with high-end equipment and acoustically treated spaces. The move is seen as a strategic step to boost BT's video and podcast capabilities, with the publication's editor-in-chief stating that it's an "essential, critical step" to stay ahead in the media landscape.

images.alt_text: Dhany Osman
Optimising your finances has never been more important than during inflaitonary times.
What is the criteria that will get one’s HDB home to command premium pricing?

site_title: Nearly half of Japan firms want BOJ to revise negative rate policy: poll
summary: Nearly half of Japan's major firms, 47%, believe the Bank of Japan should revise its negative interest rate policy, while 62% say a normalization of monetary policy would have no significant impact on their businesses. A majority of respondents, 46%, gave Governor Haruhiko Kuroda a middling to positive rating for his tenure, with 40% rating him in the top two quintiles. The poll, conducted by Reuters, surveyed nearly 500 major companies and found corporate managers remain pessimistic about the near-term environment, with 80% expecting conditions to be "not so good" to "bad" in the next three months.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor (left) agreed to give the largest wage hikes in two decades according to its union and Honda Motor said it will raise wages by 5 per cent, including the biggest increase in base pay in about 30 years.
Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes volatile fresh food but includes energy costs, rose 4.2 per cent in January from a year earlier, matching a median market forecast.

site_title: OCBC’s Q4 profit up 34% at S$1.3 billion; final dividend at S$0.40
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 34% increase in net profit to S$1.3 billion for the fourth quarter of 2022, driven by a 60% rise in net interest income. The bank declared a final dividend of S$0.40 per share, and its CEO, Helen Wong, expects interest rates to plateau in the second half of 2023. Wong also noted that the bank's diversified business franchise will deliver growth, particularly as the China reopening supports regional economies. The bank's CET1 ratio stood at 15.2% as of December 2022.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Michelle Zhu

The rate of NIM expansion has likely started to moderate in the fourth quarter of 2022, analysts said. Nevertheless, the banks’ high capital levels and above-regulation provisioning coverage mean an upside surprise in dividends.
Generic shots of Singapore Exchange (SGX).

site_title: Oil settles up 2% on tightening supply, demand concerns linger
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday, driven by expectations of steep cuts to Russian production and concerns over demand. Brent crude futures settled at $82.21 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose to $75.39 a barrel. Despite a stronger dollar, analysts expect lower Russian production and China's reopening to tighten the oil market, supporting prices. However, US crude inventories rose for the ninth time in a row, stoking demand worries.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled US$2.45, or 3 per cent, lower at US$80.60 per barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: RBNZ’s silk sees upside risks to inflation outlook
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) raised the Official Cash Rate (OCR) by 50 basis points to 4.75%, with assistant governor Karen Silk stating there are upside risks to the inflation outlook. The forecast peak OCR is 5.5% to bring inflation back within the 1-3% target band. Silk emphasized that the bank will continue to review its position as more information becomes available, and that a pause in tightening is not being contemplated at this point.

images.alt_text: The central bank reiterated it expects a recession starting in the second quarter of this year, but the economy is seen bouncing back a little sooner next year.
In its November projections, the RBNZ signalled the OCR would rise to around 5.5 per cent in mid-2023 and push the economy into recession.

site_title: Asian Pay TV Trust posts Q4 DPU of S$0.0025; profit after income tax rises over 14 times
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust posted a Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0025, unchanged from the previous year, and a profit after income tax of S$8.2 million, a 14-fold increase from the same period last year. The trust reaffirmed its full-year distribution guidance of S$0.0105 per unit, 5% higher than the previous year. Revenue dropped 8.9% to S$69.4 million, primarily due to a decline in basic cable television and premium digital cable television segments, but the broadband segment's revenue rose 4.9%.

images.alt_text: APPT's profit after income tax for the quarter rose to S$13.5 million, almost tripling from S$4.6 million the year before.

site_title: One billion users, but bans mount up for TikTok
summary: TikTok, with over 1 billion active users, faces mounting bans globally, including from the European Commission, amid concerns over its links to China and data security. The app has denied spying for Beijing, but US President Trump's accusations have sparked scrutiny. Despite the bans, TikTok's growth continues, with the app grabbing $11 billion in advertising revenue last year. Critics have raised concerns over disinformation, child safety, and manual promotion of content, but the app has taken steps to address these issues, including verifying content with fact-checking organizations.

images.alt_text: A smartphone with a displayed TikTok logo is placed on a computer motherboard in this illustration taken February 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Alec Baldwin pleads not guilty to “Rust” manslaughter
summary: Alec Baldwin pleaded not guilty to manslaughter over the death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins on the set of film "Rust" in October 2021. Baldwin was holding a Colt .45 during rehearsals when it discharged, killing Hutchins and wounding director Joel Souza. Both Baldwin and film's armourer Hannah Gutierrez-Reed face two alternative counts of voluntary manslaughter. Prosecutors often use alternative charges to increase the likelihood of a conviction.

site_title: Using AI and data analytics to fight insurance fraud
summary: The General Insurance Association of Singapore found that 20% of motor claims in Singapore are fraudulent. This led to a 2021 crackdown on 17 individuals and 5 men charged in 2022 for suspected involvement in motor insurance fraud. The industry estimates that fraudsters can earn up to S$20,000 a month. Insurers are now using AI and data analytics to detect and prevent fraud, which is expected to reduce the impact on the industry.

images.alt_text: Chief executive Eunice Chua says that the mediator’s indication “may help parties resolve their disputes without adjudication, which will save them time and costs,” noting that a majority of cases involving these had not gone to adjudication.

site_title: Opendoor plans to accelerate selling in recovering home market
summary: Opendoor Technologies reported an adjusted net loss of US$467 million in the fourth quarter, slightly better than expected. The company aims to sell through two-thirds of its acquired homes by the end of the first quarter, now expecting to complete sales earlier than initially anticipated. A recovering home market, driven by increased consumer demand, is expected to help the company sell off old inventory and return to positive margins by the second half of 2023. The company must navigate high mortgage rates and uncertain future rate movements.

images.alt_text: The average for a 30-year, fixed loan fell to 6.95 per cent after surging past 7 per cent last week, Freddie Mac said on Thursday (Nov 3) in a statement.

site_title: Europe: Upbeat corporate guidances lift shares, Nvidia forecast boosts chip stocks
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% on Thursday, driven by upbeat corporate guidance and a positive forecast by US semiconductor designer Nvidia. Financial stocks and chipmakers benefited from the news, with AXA and semiconductor stocks gaining 3.2% and 0.4-1.2% respectively. Despite lingering concerns about interest rate hikes, the Stoxx 600 has risen nearly 9% this year, more than double the S&P 500's 3.9% gain.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3 per cent higher at 33,153.91 on Thursday.

site_title: North Korea test-fires four strategic cruise missiles: KCNA
summary: North Korea has test-fired four strategic cruise missiles into the sea, according to state media. The "Hwasal-2" missiles were fired from North Hamgyong province towards the East Sea, traveling 2,000 km before hitting their target. The test, which occurred on Thursday, demonstrated the war posture of the North's nuclear combat force, according to the Korean Central News Agency. The move has heightened fears of a potential nuclear test by the North, which has conducted a series of provocative weapons tests in recent months.

site_title: US dollar index hits seven-week high on higher-for-longer US rates
summary: The US dollar index reached its highest level in nearly seven weeks, reaching 104.68, due to expectations of further interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Despite minutes from the Fed's last policy meeting showing nearly all policymakers favoring a slower pace of rate hikes, the index still rose due to underlying inflation concerns and a strong US economy. The US dollar index is still below its 20-year high of 114.78, and market analysts expect it to continue its upward trend if inflation remains high.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as Nvidia offsets Fed jitters
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by Nvidia's strong sales forecast, which boosted chipmakers. The Dow Jones rose 130.30 points, or 0.39%, to 33,175.39, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. Despite a surprise fall in weekly jobless claims, worries about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes persisted.

site_title: IAG announces acquisition of Air Europa for 500 million euros
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways and Iberia, has announced the acquisition of Air Europa for 500 million euros. The deal includes the acquisition of the remaining 80% stake, with the first 100 million euros paid in IAG shares and 100 million euros in cash upon closing, followed by additional payments of 100 million euros in cash on both the first and second anniversary of the final deal. The agreement is subject to regulatory and other approvals, expected to take around 18 months.

images.alt_text: UOBKH has lowered its target price to S$5.35 from S$5.40 as it believes valuations are now “stretched”, with the stock trading about 1.9 standard deviation points above its historical mean before the pandemic.
SIA will suspend direct flights between Singapore and Vancouver from October while Scoot will end its services to Gold Coast in July.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 3,267.99 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 66 to 50, driven by gains in US and European markets. Sembcorp Marine was the most actively traded counter, up 1.6% on its shares. The rally marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data scheduled for release next week.

site_title: US banking regulators step up warnings on crypto market risks
summary: US banking regulators have stepped up warnings about the liquidity risks tied to stablecoin-related reserves and other funding sources from crypto firms. Deposits with stablecoin reserves can be susceptible to large and rapid outflows, including unanticipated redemptions or dislocations. This warning comes after recent events in the crypto-asset sector have highlighted the potential heightened liquidity risks. Regulators urge banks to exercise caution when dealing with crypto-related funding sources.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, ST Engineering, Haw Par Corp, Riverstone, HRnetGroup
summary: OCBC reported a net profit of S$1.3 billion for the fourth quarter, rising 34% year-over-year, with a record full-year profit of S$5.7 billion. ST Engineering's profit fell 7.1% due to reduced Covid-19 government support and energy inflation. Haw Par Corp's net profit rose 24.5% to S$71.1 million, while HRnetGroup's profit increased 11.4% to S$32.9 million. Riverstone Holdings' net profit declined 62.1% due to cyclical weakness in the medical glove industry.

images.alt_text: UOB senior economist Alvin Liew expects two more 25-basis point hikes to the terminal Federal Funds Target Rate to 5.25 per cent at the March and May 2023 FOMC meetings.

site_title: Boeing halts deliveries of 787 again on fuselage issue
summary: Boeing has halted deliveries of the 787 Dreamliner due to new issues with a fuselage component, following a previous pause in August. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) said the issue needs to be addressed before deliveries resume. The company attributed the pause to an analysis error by its supplier and noted that production continues, with no immediate safety concerns for the in-service fleet. Deliveries were suspended again after the company uncovered manufacturing flaws and additional issues in 2020, which led to a significant decrease in production levels.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on December 15, 2009, Boeing's new 787 Dreamliner taxis for take off at Paine Field in Everett, Washington. - Boeing reported a hefty fourth-quarter loss on January 26, 2022, on mounting costs associated with the widebody 787, of which it has suspended deliveries due to quality problems. The US aviation giant accounted for a total of $3.8 billion in one-time expenses associated with compensating airlines for delayed deliveries and more costly production processes. (Photo by Paul Joseph Brown / AFP)

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; fourth-quarter GDP growth trimmed
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell to 192,000 for the week ended Feb 18, below economists' forecast of 200,000. This marks the fourth consecutive week of claims below 200,000, indicating persistently tight labor market conditions. Despite high-profile layoffs in the technology sector, claims have remained low, staying within the 183,000-206,000 range this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Hundreds of people line up outside a Kentucky Career Center hoping to find assistance with their unemployment claim in Frankfort, Kentucky, U.S. June 18, 2020. REUTERS/Bryan Woolston/File Photo

site_title: Netflix lowers price of plans by up to 50% in over 100 countries
summary: Netflix is lowering prices in over 100 countries, mostly in lower-income regions, with the price of its basic subscription plan dropping by up to 50%. The price cuts will impact over 10 million subscribers in countries such as Vietnam, Indonesia, and Thailand. The move aims to improve the company's members' experience and comes as streaming services have been increasing prices to capture more revenue. The price changes are part of Netflix's efforts to crack down on account sharing and are also seen as a response to slow growth in some markets.

images.alt_text: Tennis balls at the Australian Open tournament in Melbourne. This week, Netflix’s latest sports documentary series, Full Swing, which focuses on men’s professional golf, became available, just weeks after its tennis-focused series, Break Point, debuted.
Netflix lost subscribers in the first half of 2022 amidst stiff competition from rivals.

site_title: US mortgage rates climb for third straight week, reaching 6.5%
summary: US mortgage rates rose to 6.5% for the third straight week, the highest level since November. The average 30-year, fixed loan increased from 6.32% last week. Higher borrowing costs are translating into weaker demand, with mortgage applications dropping to the lowest level since 1995 and sales of previously owned US homes declining for a 12th straight month. The Federal Reserve's benchmark rate hikes are attributed to strong economic growth, a tight labor market, and inflation concerns, with borrowing costs rising over the past year by an average of $965 for a $600,000 mortgage.

site_title: Due-diligence moves to be mandatory for corporate finance advisers, says MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has made due-diligence requirements mandatory for corporate finance advisers, effective from October 2023. The new requirements aim to improve industry standards and enable investors to make informed decisions. Key requirements include conducting background checks, site visits, and assessing third-party service providers, as well as mitigating conflicts of interests. The move follows a consultation paper issued in 2021 and is designed to safeguard investor interests and the integrity of Singapore's capital markets.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Proposed due diligence requirements for CF advisers timely: industry experts
MAS should match its proposed due diligence requirements with aggressive enforcement

site_title: China anti-graft body vows crackdown on finance sector corruption
summary: China's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (CCDI) vowed to crack down on corruption in the financial sector, following the disappearance of Bao Fan, founder of investment bank China Renaissance. The CCDI will "seriously punish corrupt elements" in finance, state-owned enterprises, and grain purchasing entities, amid President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign. This move suggests the campaign is shifting towards the corporate sector, following years of targeting government officials. The CCDI's power and influence have helped Xi consolidate power and tackle widespread graft, which has been popular among the public.

images.alt_text: The Bank of China said that the ruling party has removed 61-year-old chairman Liu Liange as party chief, without providing a reason.

site_title: China finance veteran Zhu set to head central bank: sources
summary: Zhu Hexin, a 54-year-old finance veteran, is expected to become the governor of China's central bank after Yi Gang's retirement next month. Zhu, chairman of Citic Group and former vice governor of Sichuan province, will replace Yi Gang, who was dropped from an elite Communist Party body. He Lifeng, a longtime Xi Jinping confidant, is likely to become the central bank's Communist Party chief and vice premier in charge of the economy. The appointments signal the end of a reform-minded generation of officials under Xi's tightening grip on power.

site_title: Biden nominates former MasterCard chief Banga to head World Bank
summary: US President Joe Biden has nominated Indian-American business executive Ajay Banga to become the next president of the World Bank, a position that oversees billions of dollars in funding. Banga's nomination, made public on Thursday, is seen as a strong candidate to lead the institution, which is undergoing reforms to address climate change and other global challenges. With over three decades of experience in managing global companies, Banga's nomination is expected to meet the World Bank's dual objectives of eliminating extreme poverty and expanding shared prosperity.

images.alt_text: The proceeds of the five-year bond will be used to support the World Bank’s sustainable development activities globally.

site_title: Alternative protein is booming in Asia because it meets a genuine need
summary: Investments in alternative proteins in Asia have surged by 43% to $562 million in 2022, with the region accounting for 58% of global investments. This trend is driven by the need to address inefficiencies in conventional food production, with animal agriculture generating 800% waste. Countries like Singapore and China are leading the charge, with government support and private funding driving growth. Experts predict sustained investment is needed to meet Asia's massive protein demand, with sovereign wealth funds and creative capital sources playing a crucial role in propelling the sector forward.

site_title: G7 raises Ukraine support to US$39 billion for 2023, urges IMF programme by March
summary: The Group of Seven (G7) nations have increased their economic support to Ukraine to $39 billion for 2023, with a focus on immediate financial assistance and post-conflict rebuilding. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is also urged to provide a $15 billion programme by the end of March. The decision comes as the conflict's first anniversary approaches, with G7 finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in India. Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki emphasized the need to assess the effectiveness of current sanctions on Russia before deciding on further action.

site_title: Thailand to rope in private firms to lure wealthy foreigners
summary: Thailand plans to enlist private companies to boost its long-term resident visa program, targeting highly-skilled foreign workers and wealthy pensioners. The program, which offers tax breaks and other incentives, aims to attract 1 million applicants over the next five years. Since its rollout last year, about 2,800 foreigners have applied for the visas, with pensioners making up 35% of the applicants. The move mirrors steps taken by countries like Singapore and the UAE, as Thailand seeks to bolster its economy, which grew 2.6% last year, the slowest pace in South-east Asia.

site_title: ECB posts loss as it pays price for its own rate hikes
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) posted a 1.6 billion euro loss last year due to interest rate hikes, writedowns on its own-funds portfolio, and paying interest to eurozone member countries. The loss is covered by provisions, but raises concerns about the ECB's financial buffers and potential future costs. The ECB has yet to address the valuation of hundreds of billions of euros worth of bonds bought under its stimulus program, which could impact national central banks that made most of the purchases.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The building of the European Central Bank (ECB) is seen in fog before the monthly news conference following the ECB's monetary policy meeting in Frankfurt, Germany, December 15, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: Nvidia surges after AI computing push drives upbeat outlook
summary: Nvidia's stock surged 13% after the company provided a bullish revenue outlook for the current quarter, driven by its push into AI computing chips. The forecast signals that Nvidia's foray into AI is paying off, with sales expected to reach $6.5 billion. The company also announced its own AI cloud service, teaming up with Oracle, Microsoft, and Google to offer AI processing via simple browser access. This move is seen as a response to the growing interest in artificial intelligence, with CEO Jensen Huang stating that the value will come from tailoring AI to companies' own needs.

site_title: Oman opens airspace, joining Saudi in Israeli airline corridor
summary: Oman has opened its airspace to all civilian carriers, allowing Israeli airlines to utilize a Saudi-Oman corridor to cut flight times to Asia. The move, described as a "historic decision" by Israeli Foreign Minister Eli Cohen, will shorten flight routes by more than two hours and help Israeli airlines become more competitive. The corridor, which was previously blocked by Oman, will enable flights to and from Israel to expand to other destinations, including Australia and India. The development follows Saudi Arabia's decision to open its airspace to all carriers last summer.

images.alt_text: Present routes to those popular destinations bypass Saudi airspace by flying south over the Red Sea around Yemen.

site_title: US to increase training forces in Taiwan: report
summary: The US plans to significantly increase the number of American military personnel deployed in Taiwan to train local forces, with deployments of 100-200 troops expected in the coming months. This move comes amid heightened tensions between the US and China over a Chinese surveillance balloon shot down by a US warplane. The increased deployment will focus on military maneuvers and American weapons systems training, amid China's claims Taiwan is part of its territory. The US supports Taiwan's right to decide its future, despite diplomatically recognizing Beijing.

images.alt_text: epa10481021 Taiwanese military personnel participate in a practical shooting training exercise inside a military base in Taoyuan, Taiwan, 21 February 2023. Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) extended appreciation to the US Secretary of State for his conversation with the Chinese Foreign Minister in which he reiterated support for peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.  EPA-EFE/RITCHIE B. TONGO

site_title: Unity on Ukraine is unity on peace and justice for all
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has raised profound questions about the world's international relations and the need for a renewed commitment to the post-1945 international order. Former UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon and Nobel Peace Prize laureate Juan Manuel Santos emphasize the importance of sovereignty, independence, and human rights in preventing autocratic and aggressive regimes. They urge countries to work together to achieve a just and sustainable peace, rather than retreating from international law and universal rights. The article highlights the need for fairer systems of global governance and greater consistency in applying the rules, particularly for regional powers like India, Brazil, and South Africa.

images.alt_text: While tensions remain between the United States and Europe, the transatlantic alliance has largely recovered from the nadir of the Trump era.
US President Joe Biden is escorted by President Volodymyr Zelenskyy of Ukraine as he visits St. Michael’s Golden-Domed Monastery in Kyiv, Ukraine’s embattled capital, on Monday Feb 20, 2023.

site_title: US: Stocks snap losing streak as Nvidia soars
summary: US stocks ended a four-day losing streak, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.3% to 33,153.91, following a rollercoaster session. Tech shares led the market, boosted by Nvidia's solid earnings. The 10-year US Treasury yield edged lower after flirting with a four-per-cent rate, easing concerns about aggressive interest rate hikes. Despite ongoing market volatility, stocks recovered from a mid-day slump, snapping the losing streak and ending a tumultuous week for equities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Wall Street entrance to the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is seen in New York City, U.S., November 15, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid//File Photo

site_title: HRnetGroup H2 net profit up 11.4% to S$32.9 million on lower expenses
summary: HRnetGroup reported a 11.4% increase in H2 net profit to S$32.9 million, driven by lower employee benefit expenses. This resulted in earnings per share of 3.30 Singapore cents, up from 2.95 cents in the same period of 2021. The company's lower expenses were the main factor in the profit increase.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

The positive outlook comes as the analyst noted how Singapore has shown resilience in the face of the pandemic, global volatility surrounding the Russia-Ukraine war, US-China tensions as well as supply chain disruptions.
HRnetGroup said the S$1 million in share capital is being used to fund the increased working capital requirements of the subsidiary, RecruitFirst Taiwan, and its branches in Taipei and Kaoshiung.

site_title: UK retail sales flat in Feb after Jan fall, outlook gloomy: CBI
summary: UK retail sales remained flat in February after a decline in January, with retailers expressing gloomy prospects for the coming months due to "acute" price pressures. The CBI's distributive trades index rose to +2, but expected sales volumes fell to -18, indicating a pessimistic outlook. This comes amid rising cost of living and inflation concerns, with households expected to spend less in the coming months as recession fears loom.

images.alt_text: A slump in inflation that sharp would be a major boost to Rishi Sunak’s government, which has made easing the cost-of-living crisis a key pledge.

site_title: SIA to stop direct flights to Vancouver, Scoot no more flying to Gold Coast in Australia
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will suspend direct flights to Vancouver from October and end services to the Gold Coast in Australia by July, affecting travelers planning to take these routes. SIA returned to the Canadian market in 2021 and added non-stop flights to Vancouver in 2022. Scoot, the only airline flying directly from Singapore to the Gold Coast, will reduce its flights to three times a week from February 28. The changes are part of Scoot's plans to resume flights to China and increase its operations in other destinations.

site_title: MPs worry about impact of higher resale grants, suggest more support for families
summary: Singaporean MPs expressed concerns over the impact of higher resale housing grants on the market, suggesting more support for families and non-first-timers. MPs called for data on resale flat price increases and advocated for alternative solutions, such as incentivizing the sale of private properties and increasing the supply of BTO flats. Some MPs also proposed extending baby bonus and parenthood policies to single and unwed mothers, citing unequal access to benefits and structural roadblocks.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

Generic photo of Toa Payoh HDB estate covered in mist on a rainy day on January 25, 2023. 
Can be used for property, low visibility, rain, weather, climate stories.

Amid the current supply crunch of Build-To-Order flats, the government will give first-timer families with children and young married couples aged 40 years and below an additional ballot for their BTO flat applications starting later this year, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong on Tuesday (Feb 14).
Over 10,000 first-time homebuyers will benefit from the increase in the Central Provident Fund Housing Grant in its first year, said the Ministry of National Development.

site_title: Eurozone core inflation at record set to embolden ECB hawks
summary: Eurozone core inflation reached a record 5.3% in January, exceeding initial estimates, and headline inflation ticked up to 8.6%. This data is expected to embolden the European Central Bank to raise interest rates by another half-point in March, despite overall gauge retreats. ECB hawks are focused on underlying price pressures, and the report's findings will further support their plan. Officials plan to lift the deposit rate to 3% from 2.5% and are expected to continue monetary tightening beyond March 16.

images.alt_text: S&P Global’s flash composite purchasing managers’ index has climbed to 52.3 in February, from 50.3 in January.

site_title: Grab’s FY2022 losses drop 51% to US$1.7b, brings forward adjusted Ebitda breakeven guidance
summary: Grab reported a 51% year-over-year drop in FY2022 losses to US$1.7 billion, with revenue surging 125% to US$1.4 billion. The company's delivery segment turned positive Ebitda, with revenue growth driven by contributions from Jaya Grocer and reduced incentives. Grab also closed dark stores and launched new initiatives to improve delivery profitability, with Ebitda breakeven guidance brought forward to Q4 2023. The company expects FY2023 revenue of US$2.2-2.3 billion and adjusted Ebitda of US$275-325 million.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Platform workers are often more vulnerable than other workers because they cannot find other jobs, or require flexible hours due to caregiving or medical needs.
Member of Parliament Tin Pei Ling joined the Nasdaq-listed company in January.
Grab said in a statement on Friday (Feb 10) that Tin will helm a “corporate development role”, instead of being its Singapore director of public affairs and policy.

site_title: China to step up support to southern Hengqin and Qianhai economic zones
summary: China's financial regulators have rolled out 30 measures to boost the Hengqin and Qianhai economic zones, aiming to promote cross-border trade and investment. Qualified financial institutions in Hong Kong will be encouraged to set up subsidiaries in Qianhai, while overseas institutions can establish subsidiaries and issue bonds in Macau. The measures also facilitate cross-border capital flow and credit financing for Macau citizens. The goal is to deepen financial cooperation between China, Hong Kong, and Macao, and further promote China's financial opening-up and innovation.

site_title: Axa plans 1.1 billion euro buyback as underlying earnings rise
summary: Paris-based insurer AXA plans to repurchase up to 1.1 billion euros of its shares as its underlying earnings for 2022 rose 12% to 3.08 euros a share, exceeding its earnings-per-share growth target. The company expects to surpass its target by the end of 2023 and will pay a 10% higher dividend of 1.70 euros a share. AXA's total underlying earnings rose 7% to 7.26 billion euros, while net income fell 8% to 6.68 billion euros due to rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Zurich willkeep to its dividend policy, which targets a pay-out ratio of around 75 per cent of net income attributable to shareholders.
The retrenchment exercise at AXA Singapore reportedly began on Thursday and spilled into Friday, with over 20 staff retrenched.

AXA Investment Managers has completed registration for a private fund unit in Shanghai, as Chinese regulators streamline processes to help foreign and local asset managers revive businesses amid Covid-19 outbreaks.
HSBC's new insurance chief eyes 'crucial' new China expansion

site_title: SEC opposes Binance.US’ US$1 billion Voyager deal: CoinDesk
summary: US regulators, including the SEC and New York State's Department of Financial Services, oppose Binance.US' $1.02 billion deal to purchase Voyager's assets, citing potential law infringement in repaying former customers. Voyager, a defunct crypto lender, entered into an asset purchase agreement with Binance.US in February. The deal's fate remains uncertain, pending a future court hearing. The opposition raises concerns over Voyager's unlawful activities in New York State.

site_title: Commodities have better track record as inflation hedge than other assets: report
summary: Commodities have historically outperformed other assets as an inflation hedge, according to the Credit Suisse Global Investment Returns Yearbook 2023. Over the last 123 years, inflation has negatively impacted both bonds and equities, while commodities have shown a low correlation with equities and negative correlation with bonds. A balanced portfolio of commodity futures has provided attractive risk-adjusted long-run returns, despite large drawdowns. The authors estimate that a balanced portfolio of collateralised commodity futures is likely to provide an annualised long-run future risk premium of around 3 per cent.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Hard to find assets that do well during rate hikes, but diversification can reduce risk: report
Getting ahead in a low-return world: Go for lower-fee funds

site_title: IReit Global posts 14.7% fall in H2 DPU to 1.28 euro cents on higher expenses
summary: IReit Global reported a 14.7% decline in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.28 euro cents, mainly due to increased property operating expenses, higher tax costs, and management fees. Despite this, gross revenue rose 10.7% to 31.6 million euros and net property income grew 5.2% to 24.4 million euros. The decline in DPU was attributed to higher expenses related to portfolio vacancy and increased tax costs.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
His replacement will be announced at a later date.
Analysts anticipate that the interest rate hikes and leasing slowdowns will put “some downward pressure” on IReit’s portfolio revaluation in December.

site_title: Alibaba beats quarterly revenue estimates as Covid curbs ease
summary: Alibaba reported better-than-expected quarterly revenue of 247.76 billion yuan, driven by China easing Covid-19 curbs. The company weathered a weak economy in China, with retail sales contracting 1.8% in December. Net income rose 69% to 46.82 billion yuan, but customer management revenue fell 9% year-over-year. Analysts expect retail spending in China to remain weak, but stimulus policies and consumer savings are expected to occur around springtime.

images.alt_text: Jack Ma has since late 2022 gradually resumed the globetrotting that once defined China’s best-known entrepreneur..
The decline in Alibaba's share price underscores doubts about the strength of the economy, as excitement over China's reopening cools.

site_title: US manufacturers see big boost from government subsidies and tax breaks
summary: US manufacturers are seeing a significant boost from government subsidies and tax breaks, with companies like Intel and Battle Motors receiving incentives for producing electric vehicles and semiconductors. The 2022 CHIPS and Science Act provides $52.7 billion in federal subsidies, and the Biden administration's industrial policy aims to improve the US's standing in the global supply chain. While some challenges remain, including labor shortages and supply chain issues, the push is seen as a rare bipartisan effort to support strategic industries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An employee works on the line at automaker General Motors (GM) Brightdrop unit's CAMI EV Assembly, Canada's first full-scale electric vehicle manufacturing plant, in Ingersoll, Ontario, Canada December 5, 2022.  REUTERS/Carlos Osorio/File Photo

site_title: China's consumer market shows 'strong' recovery in January
summary: China's consumer market showed a "strong" recovery in January, according to the commerce ministry, with rises in factory and services activities. This optimism comes as the country's economy struggles to recover from a weak 3% growth rate last year, exacerbated by Covid-19 curbs. The government plans to take measures to revive and expand consumption, with Fitch raising its forecast for China's economic growth. A recovery is expected, but its nature and speed remain uncertain, according to a chief economist.

site_title: Nominations open for EY Entrepreneur of the Year awards
summary: The annual EY Entrepreneur of the Year awards in Singapore are now open for nominations until April 21. The awards aim to recognize outstanding entrepreneurs across four criteria: entrepreneurial spirit, growth, purpose and impact. The winner will receive an award title and represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur of the Year award next year. The theme this year is "The Art of Entrepreneurship," emphasizing the importance of passion, determination, and skills in creating successful businesses.

images.alt_text: Top (from left): Lim Wai Mun, founder and CEO of Doctor Anywhere; Akshay Garg, co-founder and group CEO of FinAccel; Mr. Julian Ng CEO and executive director of Grand Venture. Lim Wai Mun of Doctor Anywhere, picked as the EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2022 Singapore, will go on to compete with other global contenders at the EY World Entrepreneur of the Year in June next year.

site_title: Support the unemployed and self-employed, draw Singaporeans to skilled trades, say MPs
summary: Singaporean MPs called for increased support for vulnerable workers, including the unemployed and self-employed, during the Budget debate. They also urged larger businesses to contribute more to society. Key MPs, such as Patrick Tay, advocated for short-term financial support to help workers upgrade their skills and find employment. Additionally, there was a focus on drawing Singaporeans into skilled trades and industries to address labor shortages.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Generic photo on growing our economy and equipping our workers

site_title: Munich Re profits soar despite Hurricane Ian, Ukraine war
summary: Munich Re reported a 16% increase in net profit to 3.4 billion euros in 2022, beating forecasts. The company absorbed costly claims from natural disasters, including Hurricane Ian, and the Russia-Ukraine war. Premium takings rose 12.7% to 67 billion euros, driven by higher prices and new business. Munich Re plans to propose a 11.60 euros per share dividend and buy back shares worth up to one billion euros. The company expects a higher net profit of 4 billion euros this year, despite facing "considerable uncertainty" due to ongoing conflicts and market volatility.

site_title: Apac Realty H2 earnings down 46.2% to S$9.9 million
summary: Apac Realty reported a 46% drop in net profit to S$9.9 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, due to the impact of property cooling measures. Revenue fell 5% to S$360 million. Despite this, the company plans to focus on its regional presence in Asean, particularly in Vietnam, where it expects to participate in the long-term growth of the residential property market.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

Pham Thanh Tuan, CEO of ERA Vietnam and Marcus Chu, CEO of APAC Realty during the signing ceremony on Jan 9, 2023.
