site_title: Economists still expect monetary policy tightening in April
summary: Barclays economist Brian Tan contradicts other economists, predicting no monetary policy tightening in April due to high core inflation, which is expected to remain above 5% year-over-year. Core inflation rose to 5.5% in January, driven by higher prices for services, food, and retail goods. Tan cites the GST hike and tourism recovery as unlikely factors contributing to inflation, and believes the Monetary Authority of Singapore will re-centre the S$NEER policy to signal against inflation expectations.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Patrons at Chong Boon Market and Food Centre on January 8, 2023. Can be used for stories on HDB estates, community, food and beverage, hawker centre, hygiene, neighbourhoods, shopping, the elderly, residents and Singapore.

site_title: Grab’s apples not the same as GoTo’s
summary: A new report by Momentum Works highlights the challenges of comparing key metrics among tech platforms, such as gross merchandise value (GMV), annual transacting users (ATU), and net revenue. Companies like Shopee and GoTo use these metrics, but reporting approaches differ, making it hard for investors to compare businesses at a glance. The report advises investors to focus on metrics like take rate, contribution margin, and user engagement, which provide a more accurate picture of a platform's value and growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
CGS-CIMB raises its call on GoTo to "add" from "hold" with a higher target price of 150 rupiah.

site_title: Riverstone posts 62.1% fall in Q4 earnings to RM42m
summary: Riverstone Holdings reported a 62.1% fall in Q4 earnings to RM42 million, with revenue down 42.7% to RM235.2 million. The decline is attributed to "typical cyclical weakness" in the medical glove industry, with demand and average selling prices normalizing from Covid-19 peaks. The company plans to shift focus towards its cleanroom segment and has proposed a special interim dividend of 8 sen and a final dividend of 10 sen per share. This follows a 76.2% drop in Q3 earnings to RM63.5 million in the previous quarter.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Riverstone executive chairman and chief executive Wong Teek Son said that despite normalisation of demand for healthcare gloves, its clean room segment continues to hold steady.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid mixed regional showing; STI down 1.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1.1% or 35.11 points to 3,264.93, with 276 gainers beating 249 losers in trading of 1.6 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion. The mixed regional performance was attributed to the latest FOMC meeting minutes, suggesting the Federal Reserve is not near the end of its tightening cycle. Asian markets also showed mixed performance, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 0.4% and Japan's Nikkei 225 down 1.3%.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Gross proceeds from the rights issue will be used to partially fund the inflight caterer and ground handler’s acquisition of Paris-based Worldwide Flight Services.
A signage of Sembcorp Marine.

site_title: Haw Par H2 earnings up 24.5% to S$71.1 million on improved consumer demand
summary: Haw Par Corporation, the manufacturer of Tiger Balm products, reported a 24.5% rise in net profit to S$71.1 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022. Revenue increased 14.9% to S$86.6 million, driven by improved consumer spending on health products. The healthcare segment saw significant improvements, while the non-healthcare segment's revenue rose 7.7% due to strong performance at Underwater World Pattaya. However, the group warned that a slowdown in the global economy may impact consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

For the 6 months to June 2022, the manufacturer of the Tiger Balm line of products delivered a 45.8 per cent year-on-year jump in net profit from S$53 million in the previous corresponding financial period.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation rose to 6.6% in January, slightly under economists' forecasts, while core inflation was 5.5%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained their 2023 inflation forecasts. Meanwhile, about 200 people were granted permanent residency through the Global Investor Programme from 2020 to 2022. IHH Healthcare's CEO Kelvin Loh unexpectedly resigned amid a string of boardroom changes, and a new incubator, Ghostwriter, aims to minimize restaurant startup risks by offering rent-free opportunities.

site_title: Jokowi tells Indonesians to spend, spend, spend as consumption dips
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged citizens to spend more money to boost economic growth, as savings accounts hold approximately $60.9 billion in idle funds. With pandemic restrictions lifted, local leaders are encouraged to promote shopping, concerts, and sporting events to stimulate consumption. The president aims to increase economic growth, which is forecast to expand 5.1% this year, driven mainly by consumption.

images.alt_text: President Jokowi proposed a budget of 3,041.7 trillion rupiah (S$284 billion) for next year, with a deficit of 2.85 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), the smallest budget gap since 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong’s biggest developer Sun Hung Kai sees 36% profit drop
summary: Hong Kong's largest developer, Sun Hung Kai Properties, reported a 36% decline in first-half profit due to Covid-19 restrictions and a population outflow. The company's underlying earnings fell to HK$9.5 billion. Another developer, New World Development, saw a 14% decline in underlying profit. Despite this, major developers expect new-home sales to rebound with stronger demand from mainland Chinese following border control removals.

images.alt_text: Light public housing, which will feature modular construction for speed, has been presented as a temporary fix when supply of traditional public rental apartments is struggling to keep pace with demand.

site_title: IHH Healthcare chief Kelvin Loh’s surprise resignation follows slew of boardroom changes
summary: IHH Healthcare's chief executive officer Kelvin Loh has resigned as managing director, following a string of boardroom changes. Loh's departure was unexpected and comes on the heels of his leave since early January. The 49-year-old healthcare veteran's resignation has surprised the market, which is still reeling from the recent changes at the company. IHH Healthcare, one of the world's largest private healthcare operators, has a market value of nearly S$16 billion and is dual-listed in Malaysia and Singapore. The company's future direction remains uncertain after Loh's sudden departure.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

The shortage of healthcare staff, particularly nurses, in Singapore is a concern for healthcare players

ST PHOTO : MALCOLM MCLEOD
Kevin Loh, managing director and chief executive of IHH Healthcare, notes that the group is taking steps to ensure its operations can cater for demand in its core business.
Exterior of Gleneagles Hospital on Napier Road.
Dr Loh assumed the managing director and chief executive position at IHH Healthcare on Jan 1, 2020.

site_title: Malaysia's Pet World Nutritions eyes Singapore IPO as early as end-2023
summary: Pet World Nutritions, a Malaysian pet food maker, is planning an initial public offering (IPO) in Singapore to raise up to US$100 million, the largest IPO in the city-state in over a year. This could boost Singapore's IPO activity, which was US$68.7 million in 2022, compared to US$1.94 billion in 2021. The IPO would be the first of 2023 and could potentially surpass Digital Core Reit's record-breaking US$977.35 million IPO in December 2021.

images.alt_text: The reception area at the Singapore Exchange Ltd. (SGX) headquarters in Singapore, on Tuesday, Feb. 7, 2023. SGX is scheduled to release earnings results on Feb. 9. Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg
Earnings per share has risen to S$0.266 in H1 2023 from S$0.204 in H1 2022.

site_title: New EV brand Seres to debut here within the year
summary: A new electric vehicle (EV) brand, Seres, is set to debut in Singapore by the end of the year. The Seres 3 SUV will be available with a 163 horsepower motor and a claimed range of 300 km. The car is aimed at budget-minded buyers and will require a Category B Certificate Of Entitlement. Hong Seh Evolution, a company handling Chinese brands DFSK and Seres in Singapore, has secured the distribution rights for the Seres 3 and will also launch a refrigerated version of the DFSK EC31 electric truck for cold-chain logistics operators.

images.alt_text: High lithium prices have spurred the development of sodium-ion cells even though lithium carbonate has weakened by around 30 per cent from its November peak.

site_title: Who governs sustainability in companies? The right approach makes the difference, says report
summary: A new report found that companies in Australia, Malaysia, and Singapore can adopt effective sustainability governance structures by integrating sustainability responsibilities into existing committees or forming a separate board sustainability committee. The report also highlighted the importance of appointing a chief sustainability officer (CSO) with relevant expertise and experience. Key findings include: 93% of companies disclosed their sustainability governance structures, 38 companies formed a board sustainability committee, and 62% of CSOs are women. The report emphasizes the need for companies to move beyond treating sustainability as a peripheral consideration and integrate it into their governance structures to address sustainability risks and opportunities.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Associate professor Mak Yuen Teen, co-director of the Corporate Governance and Financial Reporting Centre (CGFRC), NUS Business School, at launch of Governance and Transparency Index (GTI).

Incorporating ESG metrics into executive remuneration is not a simple matter of merely selecting some measures and linking them to executive remuneration; ESG must be integrated into strategies, policies and practices of a company, says Prof Mak Yuen Teen

His team plans to issue regular reports on different areas of ESG, such as on how climate risk affects various outcomes such as cost of capital, ESG issues in supply chains, implications of ESG for directors’ duties, and so on, says Prof Mak Yuen Teen.
Political opposition to environmental, social and governance investing in Republican US states has not dented the finance industry's commitment to sustainability, according to a Barclays study.

site_title: Central bank governor nominated due to ‘vast experience’, says Indonesia president
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo nominated incumbent central bank governor Perry Warjiyo for a five-year term due to his vast experience. In a television broadcast, Widodo stated that "in this global turmoil, we cannot take risks" on posts that hold monetary authority. The nomination was made after Parliament received a letter containing the request from the president. The decision aims to provide stability in the country's monetary system amidst global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Governor of Bank Indonesia Perry Warjiyo, 63, is a career central banker who has played a key role in reforming Bank Indonesia’s (BI) monetary policy mix and its pandemic response.

site_title: US lawmakers warn of China’s ‘cognitive war’ after Taiwan visit
summary: US lawmakers, including Representative Mike Gallagher and Representative Ro Khanna, returned from visits to Taiwan warning of China's "cognitive war" against the island. Taiwan is bolstering its defenses against cyberattacks and disinformation, with Gallagher calling it a "wake-up call" on the risks of an aggressive neighbor. The lawmakers urged US technology companies to address China's online offensives and support Taiwan's efforts to limit semiconductor exports to China. The US has promised to arm Taiwan, but a backlog of equipment and resources remains. China views Taiwan as part of its territory and has threatened to use force to prevent formal independence.

images.alt_text: The regulations prohibit Lockheed Martin and Raytheon Missile and Defense Corporation, a subsidiary of Raytheon Technologies, from “engaging in import and export activities related to China”.

site_title: A house for parties and private retreats
summary: A Singaporean family's 30-year-old corner terrace house was rebuilt to create "The House of Many Faces," a contemporary home conducive to both lively gatherings and calm, quiet spaces. Designed by architect Fiona Tan of Design Studio Atelier IF, the house features a unique facade with various opening sizes, a semi-outdoor setting, and a mix of private and social spaces. The interior design incorporates playful elements, such as portholes for bathroom windows, and a clean material palette of oak and grey tones. The home was completed in December 2022 and showcases a blend of functionality and tranquility.

images.alt_text: Architect Melvin Keng in his patio just behind his front door.

site_title: Yellen says global economic outlook improving
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that the global economy is in a better position than predicted months ago, citing improved economic outlook and resilient US economy. She also emphasized the importance of supporting Ukraine on the eve of its one-year anniversary of Russia's invasion, with the US providing over $46 billion in aid and planning to provide an additional $10 billion. Yellen stressed the need for continued, robust support for Ukraine to degrade Russia's military-industrial complex.

images.alt_text: “China understands the problem, may be willing to work to make faster progress,” US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said.

site_title: EU manufacturers eye offshore wind turbine plants in Vietnam
summary: EU manufacturers are considering investing hundreds of millions of US dollars in Vietnam to build offshore wind turbine plants, taking advantage of the country's strong winds and shallow waters near coastal areas. Vestas, a Danish turbine maker, is one of the potential investors, along with other industry sources. Vietnam has set ambitious targets for the offshore wind sector, but has struggled to approve clear rules, with no projects currently in operation. The country's industrial strength and proximity to advanced offshore wind markets in East Asia make it an attractive location for manufacturers.

site_title: Top sommeliers offering tuition-free wine classes to minority students
summary: Top sommeliers are offering tuition-free wine classes to minority students, particularly those from underrepresented communities. The Wine Empowered non-profit, founded by Victoria James and others, provides education and mentorship to Black, Indigenous, and people of color. The program has already supported nearly 100 students, with alumni achieving sommelier accreditation and securing paid apprenticeships. Experts such as Carlton McCoy Jr and Cheron Cowan are partnering with Wine Empowered, and other organizations like the Court of Master Sommeliers are also taking steps to increase diversity in the industry.

images.alt_text: Fiona Masuku sniffs a wine at Great Heart Wines in Franschhoek, South Africa. White South Africans control a vast majority of the country’s wine industry, but it’s growing increasingly possible to support Black winemakers and owners.

site_title: Lexus RX 350h review: Let’s get digital
summary: The Lexus RX 350h is a hybrid SUV that breaks from its predecessor with a new design and updated features. The interior boasts big digital screens, touch-sensitive pads, and adjustable cabin lighting, creating a more contemporary look. The car's petrol-electric hybrid powertrain provides smoothness and efficiency, with a fuel efficiency of 5.6 L/100 km. The RX 350h's performance is impressive, with a 0-100km/h time of 7.9 seconds and a top speed of 180 km/h. With a starting price of S$431,800, the Lexus RX 350h is a luxury SUV that offers a unique blend of style, comfort, and technology.

images.alt_text: Koji Sato takes on leadership of Toyota at a watershed moment, with the carmaker facing criticism for its reluctance to plough headlong into electric vehicles.

site_title: Taiwan’s Delta Electronics sees EVs powering its double-digit growth
summary: Taiwan's Delta Electronics expects double-digit annual growth for the next five years driven by the electric vehicle (EV) boom. Chairman Yancey Hai attributed the growth to the shift from traditional petrol-powered vehicles to EVs, with components such as fans now going into EVs. The company reported a 32% year-on-year increase in fourth-quarter gross profit. Despite some minor chip shortages, Hai expressed confidence in the company's growth prospects, citing the expansion of data centers and Tesla's US$7.5 billion federal program to promote EVs.

site_title: Taiwan to give tourists NT$2.5 billion in perks to aid economy
summary: Taiwan is offering 500,000 tourists a cash or discount incentive worth NT$5,000 each as part of a NT$5.3 billion package to boost its post-pandemic travel industry. The incentives, worth NT$2.5 billion, will be distributed through lucky draws or airlines, and may be handed out electronically or as discounts for accommodations and purchases. The move aims to accelerate and expand international tourist arrivals, which had dropped significantly due to the pandemic and China's travel ban. The tourism industry is expected to play a crucial role in Taiwan's economic growth this year.

images.alt_text: in Taipei, Taiwan, on Sunday, Dec. 31, 2017. *** SECOND SENTENCE HERE ***. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: New Rolls-Royce boss says more to come after profit beat
summary: Rolls-Royce CEO Tufan Erginbilgic forecast more profit growth in 2023 after beating expectations, citing a 57% rise in underlying operating profit. His transformation plan aims to improve efficiency, commercial outcomes, and reduce working capital. Erginbilgic stated that the company is capable of "much more" as the plan progresses, indicating potential for further growth and improvement.

site_title: Hotel group Accor beats on core earnings, bullish on Chinese tourists
summary: Accor, Europe's largest hotel group, has forecast a 5-9% increase in revenue per available room (RevPAR) for 2023, driven by the expected return of Chinese tourists. The company's core profit beat expectations, with a 2% increase in RevPAR compared to pre-pandemic levels in 2019. Accor's regional division in India, Africa, and the Middle East saw a 73% rise in RevPAR in the last quarter, while the Asia-Pacific region is expected to rebound this year following China's relaxation of zero-Covid policies.

site_title: Mazda won’t chase premium market with EVs
summary: Mazda's first electric vehicle, the MX-30, was launched in Singapore at a lower price point than other Japanese brands, with a starting price of S$184,888. The brand's program manager, Koichiro Yamaguchi, stated that Mazda prioritizes delivering driving pleasure over premium pricing, and the MX-30's unique features, such as the "freestyle door" concept, were designed to provide a new driving experience. Despite criticisms, Mazda plans to use feedback from the MX-30 to develop its next EVs, with a focus on maintaining affordability and a driving experience comparable to its internal combustion engine models.

images.alt_text:
jumazda19




Source/copyright/credit: Big Fish Publishing

site_title: Vietnam property debt crisis deepens as major developer delays bond payment
summary: Vietnam's property debt crisis deepens as Novaland, the country's second-largest developer, delays bond repayment by two months. The developer is seeking debt extensions or converting the principal into real estate products. This is the latest addition to a growing list of developers struggling with debt payments, following an anti-graft campaign and crackdown on corporate bond issuance. Analysts predict more debt extensions, restructurings, and defaults, potentially triggering a broader crisis in the Vietnamese banking sector and economy.

images.alt_text: The lay-offs come after PouYuen put 20,000 of its workers on paid leave in rotation at the end of last year.
VinFast was awarded an “Air Permit”, the company said, adding it was still seeking other permits for the Chatham Country factory, but would start a tender for construction.

site_title: Hyaluronic acid: Miracle molecule or just plain hype?
summary: Hyaluronic acid, a naturally occurring molecule in the body, is touted as a miracle ingredient in skincare products, but its effectiveness and quality vary greatly depending on the brand and product. While it can attract up to 1,000 times its weight in water, making it a hydrating agent, its absorption and retention are influenced by its molecular size. A 2% concentration of hyaluronic acid is considered safe, and it's essential to look for products with multiple molecular sizes and minimal preservatives. Reputable brands and a moisturizer application after hyaluronic acid serum can enhance its benefits, making it a versatile and safe ingredient for various skin types.

images.alt_text: Paul Soileau, at the Market Hotel in New York, Nov. 30, 2022. Christeene is the drag alter ego of Soileau, a musician and performance artist whose punk theatrics have been described as watching “Beyoncé on bath salts.” (Tanyth Berkeley/The New York Times)

Shoppers and pedestrians walk along Nanjing Road in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, June 6, 2021. Consumers in China remain cautious even though the Covid-19 outbreak has been under control for much of the past year. Photographer: Qilai Shen
Adolf

site_title: Apple’s Chinese contract manufacturer to develop AR device: Nikkei
summary: Apple has partnered with Chinese contract manufacturer Luxshare Precision Industry to develop its long-awaited augmented reality (AR) device. Luxshare took over the AR development team in Shanghai, previously owned by Taiwan's Pegatron, which first helped Apple develop the device. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) and Sony are also contributing to the project by developing micro OLED displays.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Apple Inc logo is seen at the entrance to the Apple store in Brussels, Belgium November 28, 2022. REUTERS/Yves Herman/File Photo
Apple’s earlier plan was to unveil the product in early spring at a launch event aimed at consumers.

site_title: Families in China on path to buying homes again: survey
summary: A survey in China found that 16.6% of families plan to buy a home in the next three months, up from 7% in the previous quarter. This increase comes after lockdowns and a surge in Covid infections sapped buyer sentiment and property foreclosures soared. Stabilizing the property sector will be a key challenge for Chinese policymakers this year as they try to revive the economy.

images.alt_text: epa10476862 A general view shows real estate buildings in Beijing, China, 19 February 2023. New home prices in China rose for the first time in a year in January 2023, according to official data released by the National Bureau of Statistics.  EPA-EFE/WU HAO
Economic activity accelerated in February as residents returned to work after many took an extended Lunar New Year break.
There were positive developments on both the demand and supply sides in China's commercial property sector in January, says HSBC Holdings group chief executive Noel Quinn.
Sources say the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) sent informal instructions earlier this month to some lenders, asking them to issue loans “under an appropriate growth rate”.
A report that JD.com is launching a subsidy campaign to fight back against the advances of rival PDD Holdings slammed shares in both firms and their larger e-commerce rival Alibaba Group Holding.
China is aiming to bring emissions to a peak by 2030, though it currently remains unclear at what level they will peak.

site_title: SPH Media Trust committee should be given ample time for thorough investigation: Josephine Teo
summary: Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo advises the SPH Media Trust (SMT) committee to be given ample time for a thorough investigation into the issue of overstated circulation data, which affects SMT's publications. The committee's findings will determine when the report is completed and released. The investigation's impact on public funds is minimal, as circulation data is not used for funding decisions. Teo emphasizes SMT's responsibility to maintain public trust in its newsrooms and journalists.

images.alt_text: Nikkei & SPH Media explore strategic collaboration on newsroom exchange, new digital products
SPH Media Holdings Board has also directed its audit and risk committee to further investigate the overstatement of circulation data and consider its next steps.
SPH Media chief executive Teo Lay Lim said data on reach and readership is collected periodically via a survey panel that is statistically representative of the Singapore population.

site_title: China halts some classes amid school Covid cluster, flu’s return
summary: China has halted classes at some schools amid a surge in Covid cases and the return of flu and other illnesses, following the easing of pandemic restrictions. The country reported over 10,000 new Covid cases daily, with flu cases also on the rise. This resurgence parallels global trends after countries lifted social distancing rules. Chinese authorities allow schools to pause classes to prevent wider outbreaks, a measure also used before the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Many countries and the World Health Organization have speculated China was underreporting deaths for months.
China’s mortality rate is falling at the fastest pace of all the places globally that saw massive Omicron waves last year, defined as killing at least 150 people a day at their peak.
The WHO has become more vocal about holding China to account, after a major Omicron surge swamped the world’s most populous country.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel climbs as much as 21.3% as shares trade ex-distribution; Sembmarine falls
summary: Keppel Corporation surged 21.3% in morning trade after shares started trading ex-distribution basis following the merger completion with Sembmarine. This change affects investors who buy the stock, no longer entitled to the in-specie distribution of 19.1 Sembcorp Marine shares per Keppel share held. Keppel's shares rose to S$5.80, with 12.9 million shares changing hands by 10:33 am.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
A signage of Sembcorp Marine.
The plunge in Sembmarine's stock on Monday came on the back of record short-selling volume which accounted for 24 per cent of the day's total trades
As at 10.32am, the offshore and marine giant rose as much as 9.5 per cent or S$0.011 to S$0.127.
The offshore and marine giant shed as much as 8.4 per cent or S$0.011 to S$0.12 as at 10.41am after 307.4 million securities changed hands.
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger.

site_title: Make more profitable companies pay more in taxes, says NCMP Hazel Poa
summary: NCMP Hazel Poa proposes recalculating corporate tax based on profits before tax to ensure more profitable companies pay a higher percentage of their profits as taxes. Data from 2018-2021 shows that companies with higher profits paid a lower percentage of their profits as tax. If companies with profits above S$1 billion pay 3% of their profits as tax instead of 0.9%, an additional S$5 billion in tax revenue would be raised annually.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

ST20230214-202336309352-Lim Yaohui-pixbudget/

Mr Lawrence Wong, Minister for Finance, arriving at Parliament House to deliver his Budget Statement speech on Budget Day, Feb 14, 2023.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

Pillar 2 of BEPS 2.0 introduces a minimum effective tax rate of 15 per cent for multi-national enterprise (MNE) groups with annual group revenues of at least 750 million euros. This will be implemented in Singapore on or after Jan 1, 2025.

site_title: Movies and TV shows hit out at wealth inequalities
summary: A recent wave of movies and TV shows is satirizing wealth inequalities, reflecting growing concerns about late capitalism and its unequal distribution of wealth. Films like "Triangle of Sadness," "The Menu," "Glass Onion," and "The Forgiven" critique the exclusive world of the wealthy, while TV shows like "Succession," "The White Lotus," and "Loot" explore the effects of money and power on relationships. These titles have garnered numerous awards and nominations, resonating with a generation of viewers concerned with social justice. However, some critics argue that these satires are oversimplified or compromise their message for commercial appeal.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

hysatire23 - Triangle of Sadness movie still

Credit : NEON

site_title: About 200 granted PR under Singapore’s Global Investor Programme in last three years
summary: About 200 individuals were granted permanent residency through Singapore's Global Investor Programme (GIP) from 2020 to 2022. Over the 11-year period from 2011 to 2022, GIP investors brought in S$5.46 billion in business expenditure and generated 24,000 jobs. GIP investors have also injected S$1.62 billion into approved funds, with 65.6% invested in Singapore-based companies. The government has facilitated integration and philanthropic activities for PRs under the GIP, but the conversion to citizenship is assessed independently by the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority.

images.alt_text: Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.

site_title: Finland says it is ready to join Nato, even without Sweden
summary: Finland is prepared to join NATO if it receives the last outstanding ratifications for its membership bid, regardless of Sweden's progress, according to Finnish President Sauli Niinisto. Finland's parliament is set to vote on the matter on February 28, while Hungary's lawmakers will debate the alliance's enlargement on March 1. Sweden's entry continues to be obstructed by Turkey, which has indicated it no longer has a problem with Finland's membership. Niinisto expressed optimism that both countries will be members by mid-July, when NATO's summit will take place.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden is welcomed by President Andrzej Duda of Poland at the Presidential Palace in Warsaw. Biden arrived in the Polish capital Warsaw late on Monday after a surprise visit to Kyiv just days ahead of the anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine on Feb 24, 2022.
Finland – which shares a 1,300 km border with Russia – and Sweden applied to join Nato last year after Moscow’s invasion of Ukraine, ending decades-long policies of military non-alignment.
At the Nato summit in Madrid this week, the road now looks clear for the alliance to expand by encompassing Finland and Sweden.
“We will make sure we are able to protect all allies, including Finland and Sweden,” Nato Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg said.

site_title: Binance semi-automates B-token reserves management after errors
summary: Binance has implemented a semi-automated process for managing the reserves of its B-token, following years of mismanagement that led to gaps in externally visible funds and reserve documentation issues. The exchange has set up dedicated collateral wallets and ensures that new B-Tokens are backed by collateral after it has been added to the wallet. This change aims to increase transparency and security, with the system only allowing minting after collateral has been added. The semi-automated process reduces security risks but may not fully automate the process, as seen in previous instances of mismanagement.

images.alt_text: Some US$2 trillion in value has been wiped out from the overall cryptocurrency market since the peak in mid-2021, due to a wave of failures and bankruptcies
Binance’s native token, Binance Coin, fell on the news but has since recovered and was last steady at US$306.96.
BUSD has a US$16 billion market value and acts as a cog both in billionaire Changpeng “CZ” Zhao’s Binance ecosystem and the wider crypto sector.

site_title: Philippine developer SM Prime revives US$1 billion Reit IPO
summary: SM Prime Holdings, the largest shopping-mall developer in the Philippines, is reviving plans to list its shopping mall portfolio as a real estate investment trust (Reit) with a potential IPO of up to $1 billion, surpassing the country's largest Reit listing. The company has restarted discussions with advisers and could list its assets in the fourth quarter of 2023. This would be the largest Reit listing in the Philippines, following RL Commercial Reit's $450 million offering in 2021.

images.alt_text: The cost of onions in the Philippines surged from around pesos 70 pesos (S$1.69) per kg in April last year to as much as 700 pesos in December, making them more expensive than meat.
Inflation in the Philippines is running at 14-year highs, with January's rate coming in at a faster-than-expected 8.7 per cent.

site_title: Economists urge China to think ‘beyond GDP’ to head off climate risks
summary: A team of economists, including two former World Bank chief economists, urged China to adopt a "wellbeing" development model to meet its 2060 net-zero emissions goals and combat climate change. The report recommends capping total fossil fuel consumption, establishing a detailed emissions reduction pathway, and promoting public transport and low-carbon agriculture. China aims to peak emissions by 2030 but lacks a clear target. The report's authors hope it will influence China's 2026-2030 "five-year plan" and provide clarity to its decision-making process.

images.alt_text: China will take measures to improve market expectations and consolidate economic growth momentum, and there is still room for tax and fee cuts to take effect, said Chinese Premier Li Keqiang.
As the world’s biggest polluter, China is trying to catch up with global peers on reporting standards and meet a net zero target by 2060.

site_title: Labour MPs suggest more support for the self-employed, unemployed
summary: Labour MPs in Singapore suggest providing more support to self-employed individuals and the unemployed to aid in their job search. Yeo Wan Ling, MP for Pasir Ris-Punggol GRC, notes that self-employed persons face a paradox: upskilling to earn more requires time, which eats into their income. Expanding the government training allowance for self-sponsored trainees to include self-employed persons is proposed to help them afford time off to upskill. This move aims to address the challenges faced by self-employed individuals and support their productivity.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Some MPs wanted small- and medium-sized enterprises to get more help to offset high operating costs, and enhanced productivity and digitisation initiatives.

site_title: Philippines’ GIC-backed Metro Pacific Hospital reviving US$1 billion IPO: sources
summary: Philippines' largest private hospital group, Metro Pacific Hospital Holdings, backed by KKR & Co and Singapore's GIC, is considering reviving its US$1 billion initial public offering (IPO) after shelving the plan in 2019. The company may buy out minority stakes in some hospitals to pave the way for the potential IPO, which could take place as early as the first half of next year. The IPO would raise US$500 million to US$1 billion, with no guarantee of proceeding.

images.alt_text: The sudden resignation of Dr Loh as managing director of IHH Healthcare has surprised the market
Dr Loh assumed the managing director and chief executive position at IHH Healthcare on Jan 1, 2020.

site_title: Adani’s brother plays opaque, powerful role at embattled dynasty
summary: The Adani Group, a $10.5 billion conglomerate in India, has denied allegations by Hindenburg Research that its brother, Vinod, holds a significant role in the company's operations. The report, which sparked a $140 billion decline in Adani shares, claimed that Vinod manages a vast network of offshore shell entities. However, the Adani Group has published a 413-page rebuttal denying all allegations. Vinod, who is 74 and lives in Dubai, is described as a key negotiator for the Adani Group and is involved in planning the group's strategic direction, but does not hold any formal positions or participate in daily operations. The Adani family's use of complex business structures has raised concerns about transparency and potential risks for investors and regulators.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Adani Group is seen on the wall of its realty office building on the outskirts of Ahmedabad, India, January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
More than 500 funds registered in the European Union as “promoting” ESG goals hold Adani stocks, either directly or indirectly, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

Seven listed firms of the Adani Group have shed some US$125 billion in market value since the report which alleged improper use of tax havens and stock manipulation by the ports-to-energy conglomerate.

Signage of Adani Group in Mumbai, India, on Wednesday, on Feb. 15, 2023. Adani Group said it has adequate cash reserves and its listed companies are able to refinance their debts, in a credit report aimed at reassuring investors after a critical investigation by US short-seller Hindenburg Research last month.. Photographer: Indranil Aditya/Bloomberg

site_title: Australian dollar rebounds after hitting six-week low; kiwi outperforms
summary: The Australian dollar rebounded 0.4% to US$0.6833 after hitting a six-week low, while the kiwi rose 0.4% to US$0.6247. The Aussie's recovery was fueled by the Federal Reserve minutes reinforcing concerns of higher US interest rates, while the kiwi benefited from a hawkish Reserve Bank of New Zealand. Despite strong economic data in the US, the Aussie remains vulnerable to the downside, with traders awaiting a positive turn in risk sentiment.

images.alt_text: Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Thursday showed private capital spending climbed a real 2.2 per cent in the fourth quarter, beating forecasts of a 1.3 per cent increase.

site_title: Heathrow reports smaller annual loss, no dividend planned
summary: Heathrow Airport reported a smaller annual loss of £684 million in 2022, down from £1.27 billion in the previous year, as it recovers from the pandemic. Passenger numbers trebled to 61.6 million, exceeding forecasts. The airport's financing remains conservative, with no dividends planned for 2022 or 2023. Despite this, Heathrow's outlook for 2023 is consistent with previous forecasts, which predicted 60-62 million passengers.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH downgrades SIA to ‘sell’, lowers target after Q3 earnings miss
summary: UOB Kay Hian has downgraded its call on Singapore Airlines to "sell" due to a slowdown in the company's growth momentum, citing a significant forex loss in Q3 earnings and slower cargo demand. The research house lowered its target price to S$5.35 from S$5.40, citing valuations as "stretched". Despite maintaining FY2024 and FY2025 net profit forecasts, analysts expect core profitability to peak in Q3 FY2023, with a possible recovery in passenger volume in Q4.

images.alt_text: In January, SIA said it continued to see strong passenger traffic and load factors across all route regions including East Asia.

site_title: World Bank board aims to pick next president by early May, US nominee expected soon
summary: The World Bank's executive board aims to select a new president by early May, with the US expected to nominate a candidate soon. The board, under pressure to reform the bank's operations, has committed to a transparent and merit-based process. The bank has never had a permanent woman president, and countries are encouraged to nominate women candidates. The US, largest shareholder, could announce its nominee as early as Thursday, with top contenders including Samantha Power and Rajiv Shah.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange profit down 20%, challenges to persist: CEO
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEX) reported a 19.6% drop in profits for 2022, with profit attributable falling to HK$10.078 billion. Fee income was hit by rising rates, while geopolitical tensions curbed trading and listing activities. CEO Nicolas Aguzin attributed the challenges to persisting into 2023, including inflationary pressures, economic malaise, and the lasting effects of the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite this, the bourse saw 21 new listings in the last month of 2022.

images.alt_text: For the fourth quarter, investment income amounted to HK$76.4 billion, compared to HK$48.2 billion in the same period of 2021.
The city — in cooperation with mainland exchanges — is changing rules to allow China’s retail investors to buy shares of overseas-based companies listed on the local bourse for the first time.
Finance Secretary Paul Chan says Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing will study a series of proposals on maintaining operation of the market under inclement weather.

site_title: Gold inches lower after US Fed meeting minutes
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,823.69 per ounce after US Federal Reserve minutes indicated higher interest rates to combat inflation. Traders expect benchmark rates to peak at 5.362% in July and remain above 5%. Rising interest rates dull gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation. Spot silver was little changed, while platinum and palladium also fluctuated. The dollar index remained steady, making gold more expensive for foreign buyers.

images.alt_text: Bullion is seen as a hedge against inflation, but rising interest rates dull the non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: 🤔 Is it a good time to move out?
summary: Rent prices in Singapore have increased by 30% on average over the past year, making it a challenging time for those considering moving out of their family home. Experts warn that it's one of the worst times to rent a place, with prices expected to rise 10-15% this year. However, renting can still be a viable option for those who can afford it, offering benefits such as independence and quality of life. To make the most of renting, it's essential to plan finances carefully, consider one-year leases, and weigh the pros and cons before making a decision.

images.alt_text: Daryl Choo

site_title: Singapore CEOs likely to get even richer after being forced to reveal pay
summary: Singapore's new rule requiring listed companies to disclose CEO pay, starting with financial years ending on or after December 31, 2024, may lead to CEOs receiving raises. Research suggests pay disclosures have done more to increase executive compensation than to suppress it, with companies facing pressure to raise pay to retain top employees. The move marks a sea change in Singapore, where pay and competition concerns are often sparse. Experts warn companies must ensure pay structures are legitimate and differences can be explained to avoid negative reactions.

images.alt_text: THE OPW will cover general drivers, such as lorry drivers, and specialised drivers, such as bus drivers.
Corporate income tax is the largest source of tax revenue for Singapore, but watchers see limited room for raising the rate.
Overall, median salaries increased to S$4,200 in 2022.

site_title: Chinese EV maker explores sodium-ion batteries as cheaper lithium alternative
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Anhui Jianghuai Automobile Group is exploring sodium-ion batteries as a cheaper alternative to lithium-ion cells due to high lithium prices. The company, backed by the state, has partnered with HiNa Battery Technologies to develop short-range sodium-ion batteries. A demonstration car powered by one of HiNa's batteries was unveiled, with a range of approximately 250 kilometers per charge. This development aims to reduce costs and increase the adoption of electric vehicles in China.

site_title: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding H2 profit down 30% after financial unit spin-off
summary: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding reported a 30% fall in H2 net profit to 1.4 billion yuan due to the absence of 973.1 million yuan from discontinued operations following the spin-off and listing of Yangzijiang Financial Holding. On a continuing-operations basis, profit rose 33% to 1.1 billion yuan, with revenue increasing 17% to 11 billion yuan. The company remains focused on long-term goals and expects to generate healthy cash flow, allowing for sustainable returns to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Ren Letian, executive chairman and CEO of Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, said: “As one of the leading shipyards in China, we are determined to be a major part of providing greener solutions."

site_title: Singapore inflation higher in January after GST hike; headline at 6.6%, core at 5.5%
summary: Singapore's inflation rose to 6.6% in January, driven by higher accommodation and core inflation, partially offset by easing private transport costs. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private transport, rose to 5.5% year-on-year, exceeding economists' median estimates. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained their 2023 inflation forecasts, with headline inflation expected to average 5.5-6.5% and core inflation at 3.5-4.5%.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

The Monetary Authority of Singapore building in Singapore, on Wednesday, Oct. 27, 2021. Singapore is seeking to cement itself as a key player for crytocurrency-related businesses as financial centers around the world grapple with approaches to handle one of the fastest growing areas of finance. Photographer: Wei Leng Tay/Bloomberg

ST20221226-202288710689-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/

People shopping for shoes at Pedro at Wisma Atria on Dec 26, 2022. 

The goods and services tax (GST) rate will be raised from 7 to 8 per cent from January 2023 and to 9 per cent from 2024.

From 2023, the new rate will also apply to any item valued up to $400, defined as low-value goods, bought from GST-registered sellers or platforms, such as e-commerce sites, and imported into Singapore via air or post.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: Pay cuts and layoffs at China’s WM motor show EV industry stress
summary: China's WM Motor, an electric vehicle maker backed by tech giant Baidu, is facing financial struggles, with only about 108,000 of its EVs sold and registered since 2018. The company has implemented pay cuts and layoffs, reducing its workforce by at least 40% and delaying payments to suppliers. WM Motor is seeking to list through a reverse merger in Hong Kong, a move that could provide much-needed funding. The company's struggles are a symptom of the intense competition in China's auto market, where many smaller players have collapsed or run out of funds.

images.alt_text: Chinese electric vehicle manufacturer WM Motor Holdings is considering raising about US$1 billion in a Hong Kong initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH upgrades Nanofilm Tech to ‘hold’ as challenges ease in 2023
summary: UOB Kay Hian upgraded Nanofilm Technologies from "sell" to "hold" with a target price of S$1.28, citing a less challenging 2023 outlook. The brokerage raised its earnings estimates for FY2023 and FY2024, expecting 7% and 54% year-on-year growth, respectively. Nanofilm's China operations are expected to recover in the second half of the year, and the company's nanofabrication business unit showed significant revenue growth. The stock currently trades at 20 times its FY2023 price-to-earnings ratio estimates, but analysts see potential share price catalysts from the nanofabrication business.

images.alt_text: Earnings per share for H2 2022 stood at 3.8 Singapore cents, down from 6.71 Singapore cents in the same period a year ago.

site_title: A US$33 billion hit shows China’s newest stock worry
summary: China's tech stocks are facing a new threat as firms, including JD.com and PDD Holdings, ramp up a battle for business at home. A subsidy campaign by JD.com and hiring moves by Meituan have led to a US$33 billion loss in market value for the three companies. Analysts warn that the sector's focus on domestic growth will result in rising competition, including on pricing, and potentially extreme behavior from companies. The sector's optimism, which had been boosted by Beijing's regulatory easing, is now ebbing, leaving investors concerned about the impact on companies' bottom lines and financials.

images.alt_text: In China, the company has been battling a slowing economy and the impact of strict Covid curbs.

site_title: ARA H-Trust H2 DPS rises to US$0.01627 on travel recovery
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust reported a second-half distribution per stapled security (DPS) of US$0.01627, higher than US$0.00355 in 2021, due to improved revenue and net property income. Revenue increased 12.8% to US$87.8 million and net property income grew 28.9% to US$20.3 million. Distributable income more than tripled to US$9.4 million. The full-year DPS was US$0.03054, with revenue and net property income rising 29.3% and 66.4%, respectively. Portfolio occupancy and revenue per available room (RevPAR) also increased.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand India Trust announced a proposed acquisition of International Tech Park Pune in India for S$221.9 million.

site_title: Ex-Coinbase president joins crypto startup MoonPay as COO
summary: MoonPay, a cryptocurrency startup, has appointed Asiff Hirji, former Coinbase president and COO, as its new president and COO. Hirji aims to push MoonPay's expansion into the NFT token market, despite market concerns and regulatory hurdles. He believes NFTs will eventually outstrip other tokens due to their ability to connect artists and entertainment brands with fans. MoonPay, which raised $555 million at a $3.4 billion valuation, is actively hiring new employees amid layoffs at other crypto companies, now boasting a team of around 300 people.

images.alt_text: Ford said on Wednesday it expected to post a US$112 million loss in the fourth quarter of 2018 as the automaker implements a massive restructuring in the United States and Europe.

site_title: Bank of Korea holds rates after year of non-stop hikes
summary: The Bank of Korea held its policy interest rate steady at 3.50% for the first time in a year, following a unanimous call by 42 economists in a Reuters poll. This decision ends the bank's non-stop hike cycle, which began in 2022. The move is seen as a response to the country's slowing economic growth and inflation concerns. The decision is in line with market expectations, and the central bank will continue to monitor the economy and adjust rates as needed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Bank of Korea is seen in Seoul, South Korea, November 30, 2017.  REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: US housing market posts US$2.3 trillion drop, biggest since 2008
summary: The US housing market experienced its largest decline since the 2008 crisis, with a 4.9% drop in the second half of 2022, totaling $2.3 trillion. This followed a peak of $47.7 trillion in June 2022. Despite record-high prices, the median sale price of US homes was $383,249 in January, down from a peak of $433,133 in May 2022. However, some areas, such as Florida, saw significant gains, with Miami's market value increasing 20% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage jumped by 23 basis points to 6.62 per cent for the week ended Feb 17.

The rebound in business activity fits in with recent robust data on retail sales, the labour market and manufacturing production, which have suggested solid momentum in the economy at the start of the year.
Home resales, which account for a big chunk of US housing sales, plunged 36.9 per cent on a year-on-year basis in January.

site_title: Australia business investment hits 7-year top in Q4, outlook upbeat
summary: Australia's private capital spending rose 2.2% in the fourth quarter, beating forecasts, with investment in retail and accommodation contributing to a 7-year high. Firms plan to invest A$159 billion this year and A$129.7 billion for 2023/24, surpassing forecasts. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to raise interest rates further to combat inflation, with markets predicting a peak rate of 4.35%. The strong economic outlook is expected to boost GDP growth to 2.7% annually, despite slowing later this year due to high interest rates and falling house prices.

images.alt_text: Rates have climbed 325 basis points since last May, easily the most aggressive tightening in modern history.
Australia's annual pay growth picked up to 3.3 per cent, from a revised 3.2 per cent, but again was under forecasts of 3.5 per cent.

site_title: UK must align sustainable rules with EU where possible or risk losing capital, say advisers
summary: The UK risks losing green capital if its sustainable finance legislation diverges from EU and US rules, according to advisers. The European Union and US are implementing massive green subsidies and pro-green business pushes, but the UK has yet to follow suit. To remain competitive, the UK must align its green taxonomy with EU standards and advocate for global harmonization, experts say. The UK's green taxonomy pause in December has raised concerns, and the government must ensure its legislation is science-based and maintains investor certainty.

images.alt_text: HSBC said greenwashing is “an important emerging risk that is likely to increase over time as we look to develop capabilities and products to achieve our net-zero commitments.”
The proceeds of the five-year bond will be used to support the World Bank’s sustainable development activities globally.

site_title: Car-sharing platform GetGo raises S$20 million from family-backed Treis Group
summary: GetGo, a car-sharing platform, has raised S$20 million from family-backed investment firm Treis Group. The funds will be used to expand the platform's electric fleet, with a goal of having 10,000 greener vehicles by 2030. This investment comes as the government increases taxes on private cars, making shared mobility more appealing. GetGo aims to serve over a million households in Singapore, reducing car ownership and contributing to the country's Green Plan 2030. The funding also strengthens the platform's technology and operations.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Singapore must continue cross-sector green push in 2023
summary: Singapore is expected to continue its push for a green economy in 2023, with the government and private sector working together to reduce carbon emissions and promote sustainable practices across various industries. The fashion and textile industry is seen as a key sector to focus on, with 66% of consumers considering sustainability when purchasing clothes. The government has also introduced regulations and incentives to encourage businesses to adopt green practices, such as carbon pricing and green financing. Singapore aims to reduce its carbon footprint by 36% by the end of the decade and is committed to leading the way in the region's ESG and fintech hub.

images.alt_text: MAS said the "measures-based" approach is proposed as it is difficult for the industrial sector to determine science-based metrics and thresholds under the “amber” category based on emissions performance of the activity.
Singapore can seek to deepen its sustainable financing capabilities by fostering an enabling environment to scale sustainable finance in the region.

site_title: Retail space beckons investors
summary: Retail space in Singapore is expected to see a boost in income-generating potential this year and beyond, driven by the recovery of tourism. The sector's attractiveness has increased, with investors drawn to prime locations and established malls. Key considerations for retail investments include location, physical attributes, and total returns, which may be affected by financing costs and interest rates. Despite risks, quality retail assets can provide room for capital appreciation, and investors should conduct due diligence on tenants and understand their risk appetite. With tourism forecast to double this year, the sector is poised for growth, making it an attractive investment opportunity.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in Singapore's Orchard Road shopping belt.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment H2 profit falls 33.8% on lower asset recycling activities, foreign exchange losses
summary: CapitaLand Investment reported a 33.8% drop in H2 2022 net profit to S$428 million, mainly due to lower asset recycling activities and foreign exchange losses. Despite a 22.3% increase in revenue to S$1.5 billion, the company remains cautious about the coming year, particularly with China's reopening. The lodging sector emerged as a significant contributor to earnings, with a 38% share of Ebitda. The company's board proposed a core dividend of S$0.12 per share and a special dividend-in-specie, totaling S$918 million.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
While CapitaLand Investment navigates choppy waters, there is room for the group to surprise shareholders by distributing units of listed trusts that it owns.
The data centre development projects are expected to be completed in 2025 and will deliver over 100 megawatts (MW) of power.

CapitaLand Investment (CLI) has partnered with Ally Logistic Property (ALP) and Pruksa Holding PCL (PSH) to establish a S$1 billion logistics fund. The sale consideration of 13.5 billion rupees represents a premium of some 9 per cent to CLI’s valuation for the site in December 2021.

OCBC’s research team said it is expecting more divestments of assets by CapitaLand Investment, having nearly reached its annual divestment target of S$3 billion back in 2022 despite challenging capital markets and an elevated interest rate environment.

site_title: Hot stock: UOB drops 4.5% to S$29.61 despite posting record interest income
summary: UOB shares dropped 4.5% to S$29.61 despite posting a record net interest income of S$2.6 billion for its second half of 2022. Analysts view this as an "accumulation" opportunity due to UOB's accretive acquisition of Citigroup's Asean operations, expected to bear fruit over the next one to two years.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

The rate of NIM expansion has likely started to moderate in the fourth quarter of 2022, analysts said. Nevertheless, the banks’ high capital levels and above-regulation provisioning coverage mean an upside surprise in dividends.

site_title: With inflation still the focus,  Fed minutes show openness to higher rates endgame
summary: The US Federal Reserve's latest policy meeting minutes show policymakers are open to higher interest rates to curb inflation, but are also seeking to balance the pace of rate hikes with the economy's growth. The minutes indicate that inflation risks remain a key factor in shaping the policy outlook, and that interest rates will need to move higher and stay elevated until inflation is clearly on a path to 2%. The median projected year-end policy rate is expected to rise to 5.6%, with some predicting a possible recession this year due to a still-large degree of uncertainty about the economy.

images.alt_text: The average contract rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage jumped by 23 basis points to 6.62 per cent for the week ended Feb 17.
The US dollar index was up 0.13 per cent at 104.28, not far off the six-week high of 104.67 hit at the end of last week.

site_title: Star Entertainment raising US$545 million after record loss, suspends dividends
summary: Star Entertainment Group has raised A$800 million (S$729.5 million) through a capital raising, comprising a A$685 million 3-for-5 rights offer and a A$115 million institutional placement, to repay debt and increase liquidity. The move comes after the company reported a record statutory loss for the first half of the year due to tough business conditions in Sydney. Regulatory restrictions and competition from Crown Resort have contributed to the decline in profits. Star has suspended dividend payments as part of its restructuring efforts.

images.alt_text: Star Entertainment warned of an up to A$1.6 billion (S$1.48 billion) impairment charge in first-half earnings from a proposed casino duty hike in New South Wales, sending its shares tumbling 22 per cent to a record low.

site_title: UK inflation to fall to just above 2% by end of 2023, Citi says
summary: UK inflation is expected to fall to just above 2% by the end of 2023, according to Citigroup. The slump in gas prices is driving the change, with consumer-price growth slowing sharply from 10.1% to 2.4% in the fourth quarter. This forecast is a major boost to the UK government, which has made easing the cost-of-living crisis a key pledge. The Bank of England's expectations of inflation falling to 4% by the end of the year may be revised downward, with some private-sector forecasters predicting an even sharper easing in price pressures.

images.alt_text: Customers use fuel pumps at a petrol station in London, UK. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

site_title: Eyeing power, Labour pledges five ‘missions’ to fix UK’s biggest problems
summary: Labour Party leader Keir Starmer will outline five "national missions" to address the UK's biggest problems, including fixing the economy and tackling a healthcare crisis, ahead of a pivotal year for both parties. The plans, set out in a speech in Manchester, will focus on "change for all" and "helping markets rather than serving them". The missions will be laser-targeted on complex problems and come with clear, measurable outcomes. The Labour Party currently leads in opinion polls, but the challenge to the governing Conservatives will intensify as an election is expected next year.

images.alt_text: “I’ve always been of the belief that no one individual should be dominant in any system for too long.” Scotland’s First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said.
China and the EU should “bring bilateral exchanges back to pre-epidemic levels as soon as possible”, Wang Yi has said at the Munich Security Conference.

site_title: Mass-market condos’ demand and prices supported by firm fundamentals
summary: Singapore's mass-market condominiums, accounting for half of all condominium sales, continue to drive demand and prices, despite rising HDB resale prices and median household income. This segment, consisting of non-landed properties in the Outside Central Region, has consistently been the largest in terms of housing units transacted over the past 19 years. Low mortgage rates and economic stability have supported the segment's performance, but caution is advised due to an uncertain economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Rents in December advance 3 per cent from the previous month.
Private properties along Paterson Road

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust posts H2 DPU of S$0.0261, in line with forecasts
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust posted a half-year distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0261 for the period from July 1 to December 31, 2022, in line with forecasts despite missing gross revenue and net property income expectations due to currency effects. The occupancy rate remained at 98.6% and average rent increased by 3%. The manager attributed the resilient performance to the quality of properties with long weighted average lease expiries, and expressed cautious optimism on the immediate outlook of the logistics sector in Japan.

大和房屋物流信托上市时的其中一个房地产——DPL川崎夜光（DPL Kawasaki Yako）。（大和房屋物流信托提供）

site_title: Steak-ing it on e-commerce amid the pandemic
summary: Adirect Singapore's online platform saw low sales initially, but gained traction when the pandemic led to restaurant closures. By having a headstart in e-commerce, the company continued selling premium meats, including wagyu beef, directly to consumers. CEO Jackie Goh attributed the success to dedicating more resources to the online platform in 2018, despite initial skepticism from competitors. This strategic move allowed Adirect Singapore to capitalize on the shift to online sales and maintain its business operations during the pandemic.

images.alt_text: ITCAN chief executive officer Amit Sujan (centre, in blue suit) and IT managing director Sippy Sujan (centre, in red dress) attending a company event with employees. The Sujans see company culture as key to attracting and retaining talent.
Oilfield Services & Supplies general manager Michael Lim, managing director Kay Ong and business development manager Kenneth Loh at the Enterprise 50 Awards 2021 ceremony.

site_title: Singapore shares slip at Thursday’s open tracking global retreat; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks started Thursday on a softer note, slipping 0.1% or 3.8 points to 3,296.24, following a global retreat. Local banks and index counters traded mixed, with Keppel Corp declining 27.9% due to an ex-distribution basis. Banking stocks, including DBS and OCBC, were mostly down, while Singapore Airlines rose 1% and CapitaLand Investment shed 0.5%. The decline was attributed to the release of minutes from the last Federal Reserve meeting, which revealed nearly all policymakers were in favor of a smaller interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
UOB reports a 24 per cent climb in profits as it made S$2.6 billion in the second half of the year ended Dec 31, 2022, up from S$2.1 billion in the year-ago period.

site_title: Wells Fargo lays off mortgage bankers: CNBC
summary: Wells Fargo has laid off hundreds of mortgage bankers as part of its strategic shift, affecting top producers who exceeded $100 million in loan volumes last year. The layoffs include bankers who attended an internal sales conference for high achievers. In an emailed statement, Wells Fargo cited a decrease in mortgage volumes and alignment with previously announced plans for "displacements" across its home lending business.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed but little joy as traders eye more Fed hikes
summary: Asia markets were mixed on Thursday, with little buying enthusiasm following minutes from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting, which indicated interest rates will likely keep rising longer than expected. The jobs report and sticky inflation data have dealt a blow to earlier expectations of a pause in monetary tightening. Fed officials have warned traders that rates need to keep rising until the labor market weakens and prices are under control. Markets have stabilized after a sell-off on Wednesday, with Seoul, Wellington, Taipei, and Jakarta edging up, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, and Manila markets fell.

images.alt_text: A man on a bicycle stands in front of an electronic board showing Shanghai stock index, Nikkei share price index and  Dow Jones Industrial Average outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: CDL’s H2 profit rises 42% on disposal gains, higher revenue; group advances on fund management ambitions
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) reported a 42% increase in H2 net profit to S$165.8 million, driven by disposal gains and higher revenue. Revenue grew 27% to S$1.8 billion, primarily from the hotel operations segment. The group's board recommended a final dividend of S$0.08 and a special final ordinary dividend of the same amount for FY2022. CDL plans to launch three residential projects this year and expand its living sector portfolio, aiming to grow its assets under management by four times. The group also approved a share buyback plan, pending a predetermined share price.

Kalpana Rashiwala
City Developments Limited (CDL) headquarters along Robinson Road. The company said on Monday that it is in talks to acquire the St Katharine Docks (SKD) development in London

CDL noted that sales have surged to 1,417 units worth S$2.8 billion as at Nov 30, mainly led by the October launch of its JV project, Copen Grand executive condominium.

site_title: Core Central Region condominiums: long-term repricing potential
summary: The Core Central Region (CCR) condominium market in Singapore is seen as a long-term investment opportunity, despite underperforming in recent years. With private residential prices at historical peaks and expected to trend higher in 2023, the value proposition of CCR properties is increasingly attractive. The CCR market's price gap with the Rest of Central Region (RCR) and Outside Central Region (OCR) is narrowing, and rental yields have risen to 3.3% for 99-year leasehold properties. A limited supply pipeline and expected increase in demand from wealth influx and government efforts to attract top talent are driving growth.

The apartment listed on the market with Singapore Realtors Inc. is in a neighborhood that's walking distance from the famous Orchard Road shopping district in Singapore, where home prices jumped by a record 4.1% in the first half as tycoons across Asia seek a safe harbor. site_title: What to watch in Singapore’s industrial and logistics space this year
summary: Singapore's industrial and logistics space is expected to see rising rents in 2023 due to inflation and strong demand for logistics and food factory space. Companies will accelerate the use of technology and automation to build resilience in supply chains, leading to a greater concentration of activity in the modern logistics space sub-sector. Advanced manufacturing, food and novel food consumer services, and logistics and supply chain industries are expected to do well this year.

images.alt_text: Based on JTC's latest market report, on the quarter, rent of industrial spaces inched up by 2.1 per cent while prices rose 1.7 per cent.
As many as 17 of the 20 stocks outpace the Straits Times Index’s (STI’s) 8 per cent total returns.
Venture capital and private equity firms risk being left behind as governments and big companies bet on the physical infrastructure future.

Last week, Ascendas Reit proposed to acquire a cold storage logistics facility in Singapore for S$191.9 million.

site_title: Oil drops 3% as high inflation risks stoke demand worries
summary: Oil prices dropped 3% as Brent crude futures settled at $80.60 per barrel, with West Texas Intermediate crude futures falling to $74.05 per barrel. The decline was attributed to concerns over high inflation risks and potential interest rate hikes by central banks, which could pressure economic growth and fuel demand. The US dollar Index also rose, making greenback-denominated oil more expensive for holders of other currencies.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled US$1.02, or 1.2 per cent, lower at US$83.05 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Resale executive condominiums gaining popularity
summary: Resale executive condominiums (ECs) have gained popularity in Singapore as buyers seek affordable alternatives amid rising interest rates and macroeconomic uncertainties. In 2022, 2,005 resale ECs were sold, with median prices increasing by 59% from S$710 per square foot in 2012 to a record high of S$1,129 per square foot. ECs are favored for their affordability and larger living spaces, with 36.7% of units sold between 1,200 and 1,600 square feet. The demand is expected to remain strong, with over 11,000 new homes set to be launched in 2023, but some buyers may turn to resale condos if the price gap narrows.

images.alt_text: Eligible buyers on Dec 3 bought 447 units at Tenet EC, which had an average launch price of about S$1,360 per square foot.
An artist's impression of Tengah Town's first executive condominium, Copen Grand.
The record gross profit for an EC in 2021 is S$1.38 million for a resale unit at CityLife@Tampines (pictured), followed by S$1.02 million for a resale unit at The Quintet in Choa Chu Kang.

The supply of new ECs will remain limited, according to real estate agency OrangeTee & Tie. Apart from the newly launched North Gaia (pictured) at Yishun Close, most ECs are completely sold or have a handful of balance units.

site_title: Apollo discusses US$750 million First Boston leveraged-finance bet
summary: Apollo Global Management is in talks to invest US$750 million in Credit Suisse's investment-banking spinoff First Boston, potentially providing the unit with US$1.5 billion in capital. This could create US$7.5 billion in lending capacity for Single B-rated borrowers. The discussions are separate from a possible investment in First Boston itself, and no agreement has been reached. Terms may change or negotiations collapse, according to sources.

site_title: Google hails ‘key milestone’ in quantum computing
summary: Google scientists have achieved a key milestone in quantum computing by reducing the rate of errors in their system, a major obstacle for the technology. The study, published in Nature, demonstrated that error-correcting code can detect and fix errors without affecting information, a significant step forward. This breakthrough could give Google an edge over rivals like IBM and pave the way for a useable quantum computer, despite still needing to achieve an absolute low error rate.

images.alt_text: Google headquarters in Mountain View, California, US, on Monday, Jan. 30, 2023. Alphabet Inc. is expected to release earnings figures on February 2. Photographer: Marlena Sloss/Bloomberg
Google could face a US$6-billion hike in expenses by 2024 if ChatGPT-like AI were to handle half the queries it receives with 50-word answers, analysts projected.
Alexandra Technopark accounted for 9.8 per cent of FLCT’s portfolio value as at end December.

site_title: Homing in on luxury condominiums
summary: Singapore's luxury condominium market saw a positive story in 2022, with 453 units worth S$3.65 billion changing hands, surpassing pre-pandemic levels. Local buyers accounted for around 45% of transactions, while foreigners, particularly Chinese buyers, made up about 55%. The top-selling projects included The Avenir, 15 Holland Hill, Park Nova, Boulevard 88, and Les Maisons Nassim. The optimal price range for foreign buyers was between S$5 million and S$10 million, while Chinese buyers mostly purchased units between S$5 million and S$11 million. New launches in 2023 are expected to offer over 2,000 units, attracting both local and foreign buyers, and the market is poised for further traction despite the steeper Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty.

images.alt_text: Despite the decline in luxury property transactions over Q4, Huttons sees the market benefiting from the lifting of border measures by China this year.
Relocating to Singapore puts the wealth of China’s richest beyond the reach of Beijing, whose recent high-profile crackdowns have rattled billionaires.

site_title: Gems await buyers in HDB resale market
summary: The HDB resale market in Singapore is expected to remain steady, with over 15,000 flats reaching their five-year Minimum Occupation Period (MOP) and becoming eligible for resale. Prices rose 10.4% in 2022, but may moderate due to cooling measures and elevated interest rates. Affordable options are available, including five-room flats with a balance lease of at least 70 years, and buyers should focus on their needs and budget rather than location. Resale volume is expected to hit 28,000 to 30,000 units, with prices rising 7-9% in 2023.

images.alt_text: The highest transacted price for a HDB flat in January comes from a five-room unit at The Pinnacle @ Duxton, which was sold for about S$1.3 million.
Sound reasons exist for some buyers to pay over a million dollars each for certain HDB resale flats.

site_title: Heavy snow snarls travel as winter storms hit US
summary: Winter storms lashed the US, dumping up to 60cm of snow across a vast area, grounding flights and knocking out power to tens of thousands. Blizzards swept across the West Coast to the Great Lakes, with heavy snowfall expected in areas like Los Angeles and Minnesota. Over 1,450 flights were cancelled, and 150,000 properties lost power. Unusually warm temperatures were also forecast for eastern areas, with temperatures 40+ degrees above average. Travel restrictions were advised due to hazardous road conditions and whiteout conditions.

images.alt_text: People push a vehicle out of the snow on Mountain View Parkway in in Lehi, Utah, on February 22, 2023. - 29 US states are under winter weather alerts as people brace for a winter storm expected to bring heavy snow, wind, and freezing temperatures from the west to east coast. (Photo by GEORGE FREY / AFP)

site_title: Mercedes enlists Google’s help in hunt for software billions
summary: Mercedes-Benz has partnered with Google to develop a new software-based operating system, expected to generate $14.2 billion in additional revenue by 2030. The operating system, debuting around 2025, will be integrated into all Mercedes models and provide features such as navigation, live-traffic services, and hands-free driving. The company aims to spend 25% of its R&D budget on software by 2025, following Volkswagen's similar move. Mercedes will keep a tight grip on technology to prevent revenue from slipping away to tech competitors, shifting focus to its top-end vehicles like the G-Wagon.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 27, 2021 Raindrops are seen on the bonnet of a Mercedes Benz car with its logo, in Berlin's Kreuzberg district. - German carmaker Mercedes-Benz is recalling nearly one million older vehicles worldwide due to a potential problem with the braking system, the federal transport authority (KBA) said on June 4, 2022. (Photo by DAVID GANNON / AFP)

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, CapitaLand Investment, City Developments, Yangzijiang, Keppel Corp
summary: UOB reported a 24% climb in profits to S$2.6 billion in the second half of 2022, with full-year profits at S$4.6 billion. CapitaLand Investment dropped 33.8% to S$428 million, while City Developments Limited rose 42% to S$165.8 million. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding posted a 30% drop in H2 net profit, and Keppel Corporation's shares will trade ex-distribution. Meanwhile, SBS Transit's net profit more than doubled to S$33.4 million, and Boustead Singapore raised the offer price to take its real estate subsidiary Boustead Projects private.

images.alt_text: Losers beat gainers 304 to 246 on the Singapore Exchange, after 1.7 billion securities worth S$1.3 billion changed hands.

site_title: ‘Tech’-ing a reality check – what’s in it for the office market?
summary: Singapore's office market is poised for a more balanced leasing activity in 2023, driven by sectors such as non-banking financial institutions, fast-moving consumer goods, and co-working spaces, which are experiencing a structural recovery. The tech sector, which has been a major driver of demand, is expected to slow down amid hiring freezes and job cuts. However, the tight supply of office space, estimated at 0.97 million sq ft per annum, presents opportunities for occupiers to upgrade to better-quality offices. The government's focus on decentralization and digitalization is also expected to support growth in the sector.

images.alt_text: Guoco Midtown has injected 709,000 sq ft of new premium Grade A office space in the Downtown Core business district as its 30-storey office tower achieved its Temporary Occupation Permit.

ST20221029-202253130955-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) along the Singapore River on Oct 29, 2022.

site_title: US: Wall St edges higher as investors focus on Fed minutes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, February 22, as investors awaited the release of Federal Reserve policy minutes for clues on interest rates.
