The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 39.74 points, or 0.12%, to 33,169.33, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. The focus on Fed minutes came after the previous day's worst performance of the year, indicating investors are seeking fresh guidance on the trajectory of interest rates.

site_title: Baidu’s ChatGPT-like app will revolutionise its search engine, says CEO
summary: Baidu, China's leading search engine, plans to launch a "revolutionary" version of its search engine powered by its ChatGPT-like app Ernie Bot, CEO Robin Li announced. The integration aims to enhance user experience, increase dependence on the search engine, and boost online advertising revenue. Over 400 companies have signed up to use Ernie Bot, and Baidu plans to build an AI ecosystem around it. This move is seen as a response to declining market dominance, as competitors such as WeChat and Douyin have chipped away at Baidu's market share.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 6, 2022 shows an employee walks past the company logo at Baidu's headquarters in Beijing. - Chinese internet giant Baidu on November 22, 2022, reported third-quarter revenues of 32.5 billion yuan ($4.6 billion), representing a year-on-year increase of 2 percent, according to the company's earnings report. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP)

site_title: UOB to ride on Citi acquisition to drive growth in 2023; posts S$1.2b Q4 profit
summary: UOB posted a 13% rise in Q4 net profit to S$1.2 billion, driven by a 53% increase in net interest income to S$2.6 billion. The lender expects its Citi portfolio acquisition to be a main growth driver in 2023, with the acquisition set to add around S$1 billion in revenue and bring its customer base to over 8 million in the South-east Asia region. The bank declared a dividend of S$0.75 per share for the half-year period, and shares fell 4.8% after the results were announced.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Yong Hui Ting
While the Fed has seemed to slow its hikes, analysts expect it will have to continue tightening its monetary policy to bring down persistent inflation.
UOB has priced S$850 million in 5.25 per cent perpetual capital securities on Thursday (Jan 12), which will be first callable in 2028.

site_title: Europe: Rate-hike fears dent shares ahead of Federal Reserve minutes
summary: European stocks closed 0.3% lower due to fears of interest rate hikes, despite upbeat economic data. The European Stoxx 600 index fell, with banks and basic resources sectors also declining. Investors await the release of US Federal Reserve minutes, which could provide more cues on monetary policy tightening. Data showed French and German economic activity retreated into growth territory, and energy prices slid due to rate-hike fears and concerns over demand from top consumer China. Investors now expect interest rates to remain higher for longer, with some predicting up to three hikes in quick succession.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.3 per cent lower at 33,045.09 on Wednesday.

site_title: What to consider when taking up a mortgage or refinancing
summary: Homeowners and property investors in Singapore can consider several key factors when taking up a mortgage or refinancing. Hybrid loans offer a balance of stability and flexibility, allowing borrowers to benefit from declining interest rates. Adjusting loan tenure can improve cash flow, while partial lump sum repayments can save on interest. Selecting the right mortgage features, such as interest offset, can also help mitigate risks. Understanding rules and regulations for growing a property portfolio is crucial, including loan eligibility and CPF utilization. Deciding on a suitable manner of holding can also impact estate planning and future plans. A holistic approach is necessary to consider all factors and reap benefits when needed.

images.alt_text: Be aware that prepaying down your mortgage does come with opportunity costs or “reduced capacity”.

With rate volatility expected to continue into 2023, the best thing you can do for yourself is not to sign your rights away for anything more than 12 months, in a year when the interest rate cycle is turning.  As events unfold, you’ll want to be able to freely negotiate for the best terms, be it on floating or fixed rates.

site_title: Pimco-owned office landlord defaults on US$1.7 billion mortgage
summary: Columbia Property Trust, an office landlord controlled by Pimco, has defaulted on approximately $1.7 billion of mortgage notes on seven buildings in major US cities, including San Francisco, New York, and Boston. The default is attributed to rising interest rates and property values falling 20% since the pandemic began. The company has engaged in restructuring talks with lenders and aims to find "thoughtful solutions" that reflect current market conditions.

images.alt_text: Homebuyers, already facing record-high prices, took an additional hit from mortgage rates which more than doubled last year.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly down after latest Federal Reserve minutes
summary: US stocks ended mostly down on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.3% to 33,045.09, and the S&P 500 shedding 0.3% to 3,991.05. The Federal Reserve minutes revealed that nearly all policymakers favor a smaller interest rate hike, but January data showed acute pricing pressures, potentially prolonging the rate-hiking cycle. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.1% to 11,507.07, with Palo Alto Networks jumping 12.5% after lifting full-year targets.

images.alt_text: The European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.3 per cent lower with focus on Fed minutes that could provide more cues on the monetary policy tightening path of the world’s most influential central bank.

site_title: Amazon says it has completed US$3.49 billion deal for One Medical
summary: Amazon has completed its $3.49 billion acquisition of One Medical, a primary-care provider with over 200 medical offices in 26 US markets. The deal, which was not challenged by the US Federal Trade Commission, gives Amazon its largest healthcare move to date. One Medical's subscription-based model, which offers quality, convenient, and affordable primary care, will be integrated into Amazon's health offerings, including Amazon Pharmacy and Amazon Clinic. CEO Amir Dan Rubin will remain in charge, and Amazon will offer discounted memberships for a limited time.

site_title: Keppel Corp shares to trade ex-distribution on Feb 23; SGX says short sellers must deliver shares
summary: Keppel Corporation will distribute 49% of its shares, equivalent to 19.1 Sembcorp Marine shares, to its shareholders on Feb 23. This means those buying the stock from Feb 23 will no longer be entitled to the distribution. Short sellers who sold Keppel short before Feb 23 must deliver Keppel cum-distribution shares or Sembmarine shares. Failure to deliver shares may result in buying-in or procurement of shares at the seller's cost, and a failed trade penalty.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The plunge in Sembmarine's stock on Monday came on the back of record short-selling volume which accounted for 24 per cent of the day's total trades
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger.

site_title: Landed homes: a grounded investment in high-rise Singapore
summary: In post-pandemic Singapore, landed homes have gained popularity, driven by increased affluence and a desire for larger living spaces. Despite limited land availability, landed home prices rose 25.7% from Q4 2019 to Q4 2022, outpacing non-landed residential prices. The market's momentum slowed in 2022 due to economic challenges, but is expected to continue growing organically in the medium- to long-term as the wealthy population increases. With a limited saleable landed inventory, transaction activity is likely to be subdued in 2023, but landed homes are poised to remain a sought-after investment.

images.alt_text: Private home prices up 0.4% in Q4 for full-year gain of 8.6%, but future increases expected to slow

site_title: Google to give up part of premises leased at FLCT’s Alexandra Technopark from Feb 2024
summary: Google Asia-Pacific will surrender approximately 1.7% of its leased space at Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust's (FLCT) Alexandra Technopark property from February 2024. The tech giant's exit constitutes 1.7% of FLCT's gross rental income for the month ended December 2022. Despite this, FLCT expects its distribution per unit for the financial year ending September 30, 2023, to remain unaffected. The Reit manager will continue to carry out proactive leasing initiatives and asset management strategies for the commercial property.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
FLCT's property of Blythe Valley Park, a business park located in Birmingham, the United Kingdom.  Its overall occupancy for Q1 FY 2023 came in at 95.9 per cent.
Robert Wallace, CEO of the manager of Frasers Logistics Commercial Trust, will remain at his post until May 31 before returning to Australia to be with his family.

site_title: As chatbots boom, Nvidia sales outlook beats Wall Street expectations
summary: Nvidia's sales outlook for the first quarter beat Wall Street expectations, with forecasted revenue of US$6.50 billion, exceeding analyst estimates of US$6.33 billion. The company's dominance in the market for graphics processing units (GPUs) for artificial intelligence (AI) technologies is expected to drive growth, with research firms predicting revenue from GPUs used for AI work to reach US$12.17 billion by 2026. Nvidia's shares rose 8% in extended trading, while the company reported a slight miss on revenue from its data center business but beat analyst estimates on gaming chip sales.

images.alt_text: A demo of Microsoft's new Bing search engine using artificial intelligence, at the company's campus in Redmond, Washingto on Feb 7, 2023.
Google scientists said on Wednesday they have passed a major milestone in their quest to develop effective quantum computing, with a new study showing they reduced the rate of errors.

site_title: Giving entrepreneurs a chance to run a restaurant rent-free
summary: Singapore's Ghostwriter incubator space offers rent-free opportunities for entrepreneurs to test-bed food and beverage concepts. The space, located on the second floor of a shophouse, has a kitchen, bar, and seating for up to 25 guests. Founded by Jay Gray, CEO of Sago House group, Ghostwriter aims to minimize the risk of failure in the competitive F&B industry, providing a platform for both veteran and newcomer entrepreneurs to refine their ideas.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Like many of its concoctions, Low Tide's namesake cocktail is rum-based, also featuring a homemade allspice pimento dram liqueur.

site_title: Meta preparing for fresh round of job cuts: Washington Post
summary: Meta Platforms is planning a fresh round of job cuts, affecting thousands of workers, as part of a reorganization and downsizing effort. The company had previously let go of 11,000 employees, or 13% of its workforce, in 2022. This latest move will see top leaders reassigned to lower-level roles without direct reports, flattening management layers. The decision comes amid soaring costs and a weak advertising market, with Meta not immediately commenting on the move.

site_title: Market for Good Class Bungalows tenacious despite economic headwinds
summary: The Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market in Singapore saw a slowdown in sales momentum in 2022 due to global economic headwinds and geopolitical uncertainties. Despite this, bungalow prices increased sharply to S$1,870 per square foot (psf) in 2022, a 10.5% rise from 2021. The total transaction value was S$1.186 billion. New buyers, mainly newly naturalised citizens, contributed to the demand, and the impact of the hike in buyer's stamp duty (BSD) on actual buyers was minimal. The rental market for bungalows also saw significant growth, with some 40 bungalows leased at monthly rentals of S$50,000 and above. Experts expect the transaction volume of GCBs in 2023 to remain similar to 2022 levels, with prices holding firm, but with potential surprises in the luxury market.

images.alt_text: Despite the decline in luxury property transactions over Q4, Huttons sees the market benefiting from the lifting of border measures by China this year.
It makes more financial sense for wealthy individuals to purchase properties under their own names, rather than through the family offices, experts noted.
Propnex believes rental demand and interest from high net-worth foreigners for luxury landed homes will likely stay elevated in the near term.
This house on 17,905 sq ft of land in Tanglin Hill and completed in 1997 is currently on the market with an asking price of S$52 million or S$2,904 psf.

site_title: Euronext makes bid for Allfunds
summary: Euronext has submitted an indicative offer of 5.5 billion euros (S$7.83 billion) for British fund management firm Allfunds, sparking a 20% jump in Allfunds' shares. The offer is conditional on agreement with existing shareholders, including private equity firm Hellman & Friedman and French bank BNP Paribas, which own 46.4% of Allfunds' capital. Euronext's move is seen as a strategic bid to expand its services in the fund management sector.

images.alt_text: The more emitters have to pay for EU carbon permits to cover each tonne of C02 they produce, the greater the incentive to invest in low carbon technologies and switch to less polluting fuels.

site_title: Financing climate solutions for the Global South
summary: Countries in the Global South are facing irreconcilable loss and damage due to climate-related disasters, despite existing financial constraints. At COP27, developing countries called for a new global climate finance target of trillions of dollars by 2024, and a "loss and damage" fund was announced to aid vulnerable nations. However, the operational details of the fund remain undefined, and developed nations have fallen short of their COP21 pledge of US$100 billion annually. A recent report found that the world needs US$3.8 trillion annually to meet climate needs, with only 16% currently met, highlighting the need for more robust data systems and transparency to address the widening climate financing gap.

images.alt_text: Developing countries win big at COP27 – but only in theory for now
Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience

site_title: PropertyBT: Do million-dollar HDB resale flats make sense? (Ep 16)
summary: Million-dollar HDB flats have gained popularity in Singapore, with buyers willing to pay premium prices for certain attributes. According to property analysts, these homes typically have a high ceiling, spacious living areas, and a prime location. Dr. Tan Tee Khoon suggests that these homes are worth buying for their potential long-term appreciation in value. However, Leonard Tay advises young couples to consider other factors before making a decision, as the benefits of buying a resale flat may outweigh the costs.

images.alt_text: Is there scope for new types of property-related taxes to be introduced?
What are the roperty trends in the Orchard Road belt and suggestions to make Orchard Road vibrant?

site_title: IHH Healthcare CEO Kelvin Loh resigns
summary: IHH Healthcare CEO Kelvin Loh has voluntarily resigned, effective immediately, without specifying a reason. Loh had taken over as managing director and chief executive in January 2020, succeeding Tan See Leng. Shares of IHH Healthcare rose 0.6% after the announcement. No replacement has been named for Loh at this time.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Dr Kelvin Loh, Managing Director and CEO of IHH Healthcare, in his office on May 11, 2021.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit’s H2 DPU falls 2.6% to US$0.0297 despite higher revenue
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported a 2.6% decline in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.0297, despite higher revenue. The adjusted DPU for the period would have been 5.7% higher than the previous year. CEO Robert Schmitt attributed the stability to the company's unique positioning in fulfilling essential needs of US consumers, particularly in grocery and necessity properties. The DPU will be paid on March 31.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Robert Schmitt, CEO of the manager of United Hampshire US Real Estate Investment Trust (UHREIT).
United Hampshire US Reit's portfolio currently comprises 21 grocery and necessity properties at two self-storage properties.

site_title: High business, parenting costs among MPs’ top concerns on first day of Budget debate
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 debate saw MPs focus on rising business and parenting costs, with calls for SMEs to receive aid and enhanced productivity initiatives. Some MPs advocated for fiscal prudence amid uncertainty, while others emphasized the need for Singapore to stay competitive for growth. The debate also touched on issues such as Central Provident Fund contributions and upskilling.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

Redistribution must be at the core of government policies, but the government should also carefully manage social frictions arising from pitting high-income earners against those not as well off, said Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh.
Corporate income tax is the largest source of tax revenue for Singapore, but watchers see limited room for raising the rate.
Upskilling will be important for platform workers' economic welfare in the long run, industry observers say.
The CPF salary ceiling, the maximum amount of ordinary wages that employee and employer contributions are calculated on, was last raised to S$6,000 from S$5,000 in 2016.

site_title: Banks tweak card offerings to compete with buy-now-pay-later players
summary: Several Singaporean banks have introduced new cards or features to compete with emerging "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) players, offering shorter instalment periods and rewards to woo customers. This move aims to counter the growing influence of BNPL vendors such as Atome, Grab, and ShopBack. BNPL is expected to account for 4.1% of e-commerce payments value in the Asia-Pacific region by 2026, according to GlobalData.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Members of the code's compliance body will be voted in by the BNPL working group, which includes members like Atome (pictured) and Grab.
Each BNPL provider will permit customers to accumulate no more than S$2,000 in outstanding payments at any given time.

Keeping credit data in the hands of individual BNPL players creates a “blind spot” for other lenders. It works against individuals hoping to build a good credit score, but whose timely payments are not captured by the system.

site_title: 305 nominations for Nobel Peace Prize
summary: The Nobel Institute announced that 305 nominations have been submitted for this year's Nobel Peace Prize, comprising 212 individuals and 93 organizations. The nominations include those involved in the conflict in Ukraine and opponents of Russian President Vladimir Putin, such as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and jailed Putin opponents. The identities of the candidates remain confidential for 50 years, but those who nominated them are free to disclose their names.

images.alt_text: Former United States Federal Reserve chair Ben Bernanke was one of three laureates of the Nobel memorial prize for economic research in 2022, for their work on bank runs.

site_title: Qantas rebounds to record profit as demand outpaces capacity
summary: Qantas, a Sydney-based airline, has rebounded to a record profit of A$1 billion for the six months ended Dec 31, driven by surging travel demand post-pandemic. The airline's half-year net income is a significant improvement from a loss of A$456 million in the same period last year. Additionally, Qantas announced a stock buyback of up to A$500 million, building on its existing A$400 million program. This move underscores the airline's confidence in its recovery and growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Qantas is due to report record six-month earnings on Feb 23.
All three planes were Boeing 737s, the workhorse of the carrier’s Australian fleet.
Multiple Australian media outlets reported that a Qantas plane - QF144- had issued the mayday alert after encountering issues with one of its engines.

site_title: Japan auto giants offer biggest raises in decades amid BOJ focus
summary: Japan's two largest automakers, Toyota Motor and Honda Motor, have agreed to significant wage hikes amid the Bank of Japan's focus on a wage-price cycle. Toyota will give the largest wage hikes in two decades, while Honda will raise wages by 5%, including a 30-year high in base pay. These moves are seen as a sign of upward momentum in the wage trend, putting pressure on other companies to follow suit. The Bank of Japan seeks stronger wage growth to sustain its 2% inflation target.

images.alt_text: Japan is now experiencing a “rare” environment in which pent-up demand, driven by huge household savings accumulated during the Covid-19 pandemic, is underpinning the economy even as rising import costs push up inflation, BOJ board member Naoki Tamura said in a speech.

site_title: Retrofits: the better way to decarbonise the real estate industry
summary: Retrofitting older buildings is a more cost-effective and quicker way to decarbonize the real estate industry than building new ones. With 80% of mature city buildings expected to remain in use by 2050, addressing existing stock through retrofitting is crucial to achieve net-zero carbon ambitions. Currently, only 1% of buildings are being retrofitted annually, but this rate needs to triple to meet global targets. Investing in older buildings can boost the supply of green buildings and accelerate the industry's decarbonization, making it a vital aspect of sustainability in the built environment.

images.alt_text: Visitors and tenants at CapitaSpring can immerse themselves in the Green Oasis which is spread over four levels from the 17th floor.
The IEA estimates that the investible opportunity for the global energy sector to reach net zero by 2050, is about US$126 trillion over the next 30 years.

site_title: A US$33 billion hit shows China’s newest stock worry
summary: China's tech stocks have taken a hit after JD.com launched a subsidy campaign to counter rival PDD Holdings, causing a US$33 billion loss in market value. The move has sparked concerns about price wars and increased competition in the domestic market, as firms struggle to expand internationally. Analysts warn that the sector's regulatory blues may be far from over, with no clarity on what behavior is acceptable and what is not, leading to anxiety among investors.

images.alt_text: Many firms have found it difficult to do business in China over the last three years during Covid Zero.

site_title: Google to cut 240 jobs in Ireland as part of global layoffs
summary: Google's parent company, Alphabet, will cut 240 jobs in Ireland, a 4.3% reduction in its 5,500-strong workforce, as part of a global 6% headcount reduction. The job losses include 85 sales roles, 80 engineering and technology jobs, and 75 support function roles. This move is less severe than the global cut, which affects a broader range of positions.

images.alt_text: The departure of these veterans may be a sign that Google is drifting away from a business that has weathered significant privacy and antitrust scrutiny.

site_title: China deepens ties with Russia as Biden rallies Nato over Ukraine
summary: China strengthened ties with Russia as Chinese diplomat Wang Yi pledged to deepen cooperation during a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin. The move comes amid escalating tensions between Russia and the US, with US President Joe Biden discussing security with Nato leaders. In Ukraine, schools are taking online classes due to fears of Russian missile attacks. Meanwhile, Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to deliver a "peace speech" on Friday, while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy reiterated that there can be no talk of peace with Russian troops in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Russia’s decision to suspend its participation in the New Start treaty for nuclear disarmament was met with widespread international condemnation.

site_title: Another year of pain for tenants
summary: Singapore's rental market is expected to see a 10-15% increase in rents in 2023, driven by rising interest rates and new property completions. The Urban Redevelopment Authority's rental index jumped 29.7% in 2022, with factors such as active hiring, hybrid work, and rising interest rates contributing to the surge. However, a slowdown in the construction industry and slower economic conditions may moderate rent increases. Additionally, property tax increases and interest rate movements are expected to impact rents. New homes typically command higher rents, and the influx of businesses from China may boost rental demand.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, an acute supply crunch and an influx of wealth has pushed up rents.
Rents in December advance 3 per cent from the previous month.

site_title: Intel slashes dividend 66%, reaffirms first-quarter forecast
summary: Intel slashed its quarterly dividend payment to 12.5 cents per share, the lowest level in 16 years, to preserve cash and focus on a turnaround effort amid a slowdown in personal-computer sales. The company reiterated its first-quarter forecast, expecting revenue between $10.5 billion and $11.5 billion with a loss of 15 cents per share. This move undermines Intel's standing in the industry, where chipmakers are competing to offer higher returns, and reflects the company's efforts to create long-term value amidst macroeconomic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The US chip giant already has extra land where its plant is based, and an expansion in Vietnam would help it better manage supply disruptions.

site_title: TalkMed Group posts 29% rise in H2 net profit to S$18.4 million on more patient visits
summary: TalkMed Group reported a 29% rise in H2 net profit to S$18.4 million, driven by higher patient visits and revenue from oncology services. Revenue rose 38.4% to S$44.1 million, with oncology services accounting for S$42.1 million. Employee benefits expenses also increased by 17%. The company expects further uplift in regional patient numbers as connectivity and traffic levels are restored to pre-Covid 19 levels.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
hypertension, high blood pressure, heart disease

site_title: Bill Gates buys Heineken stake, despite saying he’s ‘not a big beer drinker’
summary: Bill Gates, Microsoft's co-founder, purchased 10.8 million Heineken shares worth 883 million euros, gaining a 3.76% stake in the Dutch drinks giant. Gates previously stated he was "not a big beer drinker," but bought shares for the "vibe" of other beer drinkers. The purchase was made from Mexico's FEMSA, which is selling out of Heineken Holding, a company that owns a controlling stake in the brewer.

site_title: Biden meets eastern Nato allies after Putin's nuclear warning
summary: US President Joe Biden met with leaders of Nato's eastern flank in Warsaw, Poland, on Wednesday, amid heightened tensions with Russia following Moscow's suspension of a nuclear arms control treaty. Biden expressed support for their security and discussed support for Ukraine, where Russia's invasion anniversary was on February 24, 2022. The meeting comes as Russia, under President Vladimir Putin, warned of nuclear tests and an existential threat from Nato, prompting leaders to call for more military aid to Ukraine and increased involvement from the US.

images.alt_text: Russia’s decision to suspend its participation in the New Start treaty for nuclear disarmament was met with widespread international condemnation.

site_title: US Reit Realty Income to invest US$1 billion for vertical farming with Softbank-backed startup
summary: US Reit Realty Income has partnered with Softbank-backed vertical farming startup Plenty Unlimited Inc to invest up to $1 billion in building farming space leased to the startup. As part of the agreement, Realty Income will invest $42 million into Plenty's strawberry farm in Virginia, marking the startup's first facility on the East Coast. This investment aims to address the significant expense of building new farms to increase production in indoor vertical farming, a challenge faced by the industry.

images.alt_text: Rubber tapper Wanida Hityim, 41, plays with her dog as natural latex drips from a rubber tree in the early hours of the morning at her plantation in Thailand's southern Surat Thani province, Jan 17, 2023.

site_title: China plans measures to consolidate economic growth momentum: cabinet meeting
summary: China plans to take measures to improve market expectations and consolidate economic growth momentum, following the country's 3% GDP growth in 2022, its worst rate in nearly half a century. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang stated that there is still room for tax and fee cuts to take effect. The economy is stabilizing but faces many challenges, indicating the need for further policy adjustments to support growth.

site_title: Satires on the wealthy are movie gold
summary: Satires targeting the wealthy have become a lucrative genre in movies and TV shows, with films like "Triangle of Sadness" and "The Menu" receiving critical acclaim. However, the question remains whether these satires are fair to the population's top 1% or based on stereotypes and prejudice. Critics argue that these films score big with audiences who are more attuned to inequality, but whether they accurately represent the wealthy remains a topic of debate.

images.alt_text:
hysatire23 - Triangle of Sadness movie still

Credit : NEON

site_title: Indonesia president nominates central bank governor for second term
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has nominated Bank Indonesia Governor Perry Warjiyo for a second term, paving the way for another five years in charge. Warjiyo, 63, is a career central banker who has played a key role in reforming the central bank's monetary policy mix and pandemic response. He is the sole candidate, according to a senior lawmaker. His first term ends on May 23.

site_title: Tesla scales back German battery plans, won over by US incentives
summary: Tesla plans to focus its cell production in the US due to incentives from the Inflation Reduction Act, despite initially planning to assemble batteries in Germany. The company will instead produce cell components like electrodes in Germany and send them to the US. Cars produced in Germany will contain locally assembled batteries in the near future. The move is seen as a response to the US tax incentives, which have raised concerns among EU leaders about companies relocating to the US.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Tesla Model S charges at a Tesla supercharger station in Cabazon, California, U.S. May 18, 2016.  REUTERS/Sam Mircovich/File Photo

site_title: Boustead Singapore raises offer to S$0.95 per share to privatise real estate unit
summary: Boustead Singapore has raised its offer price to S$0.95 per share to privatize its real estate subsidiary Boustead Projects, up from the previous offer price of S$0.90. The revised offer represents 75.1% of Boustead Projects' last reported net asset value (NAV), addressing investor concerns of undervaluation. The move comes after the Securities Investors Association of Singapore (Sias) called for a higher offer price, citing a significant discount to asset value.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Boustead Singapore is looking to take Boustead Projects private at S$0.90 per share.
One of Boustead Projects' buildings, business park development Alice@Mediapolis. No married deals were recorded in early trade for either counter.

Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore. The company’s S$0.90 per share offer translates to a premium of 7.8 per cent over Boustead Projects’ last traded price per share of S$0.835 on the Singapore Exchange on Feb 3.

site_title: China lends Pakistan further US$700 million to shore up FX reserves
summary: Pakistan will receive a $700 million loan from China to boost its foreign exchange reserves, which are at their lowest in 10 years and can only cover less than three weeks of crucial imports. The loan, made through the state-owned China Development Bank, is expected to increase reserves by 20%. This comes as Pakistan negotiates a $6.5 billion bailout with the International Monetary Fund to prevent economic collapse.

site_title: Central bank digital currencies necessary to meet demand: Bank for International Settlements
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) emphasizes the need for Central Bank Digital Currencies (CBDCs) to meet growing demand for digital representations of money. General Manager Agustin Carstens says CBDCs are part of central banks' evolutionary process to provide the public with what they demand. He notes that CBDCs can facilitate a more efficient financial system and proposes a unified ledger combining monetary and real claims. BIS is exploring CBDCs, fast payment systems, and tokenization of assets, and recommends a public-private partnership to build trust in such systems.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The Bank of England is looking at the case for issuing a digital pound.
The central bank has said it does not see a compelling use case for retail central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), as electronic payments in Singapore are already pervasive.
MAS managing director Ravi Menon said central banks must continue to stay resolute in tackling high inflation and restoring price stability.

site_title: For tech giants, AI like Bing and Bard poses billion- dollar search problem
summary: Tech giants like Google are facing a significant challenge with the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into their search engines, as the high cost of computing power required to handle AI-powered queries could lead to a substantial increase in expenses. If Google were to handle half of its queries with 50-word answers, it could face a $6-billion hike in expenses by 2024. The cost of AI is due to the computing power involved, which is a significant factor in the expense, and analysts estimate that it could chip into Alphabet's bottom line with several billion dollars of extra costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Google LLC is seen at the Google Store Chelsea in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: MOM does not “micro-manage” foreign work pass numbers: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Tan See Leng stated that the country will not reduce foreign work pass issuance despite a potential dip in hiring demand in the fourth quarter of 2022. The decision aims to maintain a stable job market. The move comes amid concerns about the information and communications sector, particularly following recent retrenchments by Big Tech companies.

images.alt_text: Singapore needs to make these foreign talent moves now to strengthen its position as a global hub for talent, said Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.
Companies eligible for M-SEP are aligned with Singapore's economic goals.

A Microsoft office in New York, US, on Friday, Jan. 20, 2023. US technology stocks are about to hit their next hurdle when earnings season for the most influential segment of the S&P 500 Index gets underway in the coming week: vanishing profits. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia picks consortia to explore three oil and gas blocks
summary: Indonesia has chosen consortia to explore three oil and gas blocks: Peri Mahakam, Sangkar, and Bunga. The blocks are located onshore and offshore in East Kalimantan and East Java provinces. The consortiums include Pertamina, Eni, Posco International, and Saka Eksplorasi Timur. The exploration aims to increase Indonesia's oil production to 1 million barrels per day by 2030.

site_title: Hong Kong to consider allowing stock trading during severe weather
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is considering allowing trading during severe weather, a move seen as a response to the global finance industry's shift to remote working and increasing extreme weather events. Finance Secretary Paul Chan announced that Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing will study proposals to maintain market operations under inclement weather. The move comes as rival hub Singapore has never halted trading due to weather-related events, and Hong Kong's current practice of halting trading due to typhoons may be seen as antiquated.

images.alt_text: For the fourth quarter, investment income amounted to HK$76.4 billion, compared to HK$48.2 billion in the same period of 2021.

site_title: Milan Fashion Week opens with celebrity stardust, industry growth
summary: Milan Fashion Week kicked off with celebrity appearances and industry growth, despite global uncertainty. Top brands such as Gucci, Dolce & Gabbana, and Fendi showcased their autumn/winter 2023-2024 collections, with 59 catwalk shows scheduled. Italian luxury brands reported significant sales increases, with LVMH and Kering posting 23% and 14% rises in sales and net profit, respectively. The industry is buoyed by bumper sales results, with the sector recording 98.3 billion euros in revenue in 2022, up 18% on the previous year.

site_title: US mortgage interest rates jump to highest level since November: MBA
summary: US mortgage interest rates jumped to 6.62% per cent, the highest level since November, due to the Federal Reserve's potential to continue tightening policy to subdue inflation. Stronger-than-expected retail sales and labor market data, combined with robust inflation readings, led to a spike in US Treasury yields and a second straight weekly increase in mortgage rates. This has caused potential buyers to sit on the sidelines, with the MBA's Purchase Composite Index dropping 18.1% from the prior week to its lowest level since 1995.

site_title: US dollar builds on gains as economy shines in February
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.13% to 104.28, near its six-week high, due to strong economic data and traders' expectations of further interest-rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. A survey showed US business activity rebounded in February, reaching its highest in eight months, while the eurozone's activity gauge surged to a nine-month high. The euro fell 0.15% to US$1.063, and investors expect the Fed to raise interest rates to peak around 5.35% in July.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad emphasized the need for businesses and industries to transform alongside workers to improve productivity. Local security agency Apro reached a settlement with the Union of Security Employees over a wage dispute. Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh warned against a split in society where the well-off are pitted against others. SATS plans to issue 363.1 million new shares, while CapitaLand Investment established a China data centre development fund. Singapore shares declined 0.2% amid regional market downturns.

site_title: SBS Transit H2 net profit more than doubles to S$33.4m on higher demand
summary: SBS Transit's second-half net profit more than doubled to S$33.4 million in 2022, driven by increased demand for services as Singapore emerged from the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue rose 16.8% to S$782.9 million, while operating costs increased 71% due to fuel and electricity costs. The company expects demand to grow as Singapore moves closer to pre-pandemic normalcy, but faces increased cost pressures. A final dividend of 5.45 Singapore cents per share for H2 2022 has been proposed.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Jeffery Sim, 46, has been with SBS Transit since 2015. He will be promoted to Group CEO from Jan 1, 2023.
SBS Transit’s operating profit for Q3 FY2022 stood at S$19 million, higher than the S$14.1 million in the year-ago period, which included S$13.9 million in Covid-19 government reliefs.

site_title: China, Japan square off at first security talks in four years
summary: China and Japan held their first formal security talks in four years, amid growing tensions between the two Asian powers. China expressed concerns over Japan's military build-up, while Japan cited Beijing's military ties to Russia and suspected spy balloon activities. The talks aimed to ease tensions and discuss issues such as Taiwan, the Senkaku/Diaoyu dispute, and regional security. The two countries agreed to establish a direct communication hotline and strengthen dialogue between their senior security officials.

images.alt_text: An unidentified flying object above Aoba Ward, Senda, Japan, June 17, 2020. Japan said it was coordinating with Washington as it re-evaluated unidentified aerial objects spotted over the country in past years after US forces shot down a Chinese surveillance balloon.

site_title: Baidu unveils US$5 billion buyback after revenue beats estimates
summary: Baidu announced a $5 billion share buyback after beating revenue estimates, with sales slipping to 33.1 billion yuan (S$6.43 billion) for the three months ended December. The company reported almost 5 billion yuan in net income, driven by its cloud computing service offsetting an advertising lull during China's economic downturn. Baidu's shares rose 6% in pre-market trading, and the company is now embracing anticipations of an economic rebound as China's giant internet sector emerges from a two-year drought.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT supports Chinese language interaction and is highly capable of conversing in Chinese, which has helped drive its unofficial adoption in the country.

site_title: India prepares for unpredictable G20 year
summary: India is set to host the G20 summit in 2023, amidst a highly unpredictable global landscape, with tensions over Russia's invasion, China-West relations, and energy security. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi aims to navigate these divisions by focusing on green development, women empowerment, and sustainable development. The summit will discuss pressing global issues, including the world economy, cryptocurrencies, debt troubles, and food security, with Modi calling for international cooperation to address these challenges. With the involvement of Russia uncertain, the outcome of the summit remains unpredictable, but Modi is determined to stamp his mark as host.

images.alt_text: Attendees at a G20 meeting in Bengaluru, India. Financial leaders from the Group of Seven nations will meet on the sidelines of another meeting on Thursday to discuss measures against Russia.
India’s self-nomination as the leader of the Global South is the culmination of messaging on the global stage that it will not simply play by the rules and norms of more powerful nations.

site_title: South Korea to scrap Covid test on arrival rule for travellers from China
summary: South Korea will scrap its Covid-19 test on arrival rule for travellers from China starting March 1, following a significant drop in positive Covid cases among Chinese arrivals from 18.4% to 0.6%. The country will maintain pre-departure tests for passengers from China until March 10 to monitor the impact of the rule relaxation. This easing of measures comes as South Korea continues to ease its quarantine restrictions due to an improved Covid situation in its neighbour, China.

images.alt_text: A South Korean soldier wearing personal protective equipment (PPE) leads a group of Chinese tourists to the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) testing centre upon their arrival at the Incheon International Airport in Incheon, South Korea, January 12, 2023. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: Top brands pull out of Russia, but remain easy to find
summary: Top brands such as Coca-Cola, Zara, and Ikea have largely exited Russia due to the country's actions in Ukraine, but their products remain easily accessible to consumers. Sellers have been advertising imported goods as authentic, allowing buyers to purchase Western brands despite the companies' withdrawal. This has resulted in minimal impact on Russian consumers, with many still able to find and purchase Western products through local online marketplaces and cross-border imports.

images.alt_text: Workers load wheat onto the bulk carrier Valsamitis at the Black Sea port of Chornomorsk near Odesa, Ukraine. Shipping in the Black Sea came under attack in the early weeks of the war in Ukraine, but a recent agreement has allowed shipping to resume.
While tensions remain between the United States and Europe, the transatlantic alliance has largely recovered from the nadir of the Trump era.

site_title: Crypto: A regulatory balancing act
summary: The cryptocurrency market has faced significant turmoil since 2021, with a $2 trillion loss in value due to failures and bankruptcies, including FTX and Terra Luna. Amidst the crisis, Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission has proposed a regulatory framework to license digital-asset trading platforms and allow retail investors to trade, subject to robust safeguards. In contrast, Singapore has taken a cautious stance, introducing targeted regulatory measures to mitigate risks and protect consumers. The US Securities and Exchange Commission has also filed separate complaints against Bankman-Fried, further highlighting the need for regulatory clarity in the industry.

images.alt_text: Tether now commands 52.6 per cent of the stablecoin market.
Digital-asset investors have their own terms for those who hold — or “hodl” — through even the roughest of times.

site_title: China urges state firms to drop Big Four auditors on data risk
summary: China's Ministry of Finance has urged state-owned firms to drop Big Four auditors due to concerns over data security. The guidance, given to some state-owned enterprises (SOEs) as recently as last month, aims to bolster the local accounting industry and reduce reliance on US-linked global audit firms. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to rein in the influence of the US and ensure data security, with no deadline set for the changes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk by office towers in the Lujiazui financial district of Shanghai, China October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

EY is on track to hire around 220,000 people in the 12 months to July 2023, having achieved its highest growth in nearly two decades in the previous period – and this is before a potential break-up of its auditing and consulting divisions takes effect. The break-up will create more jobs as well.

A China-US agreement in August allows US regulators to inspect China-based accounting firms that audit New York-listed companies to help resolve a dispute that threatened to boot more than 200 Chinese companies from US exchanges.

site_title: Applications open for 2023 edition of Lim Kim San Memorial Scholarship
summary: Applications are now open for the 2023 Lim Kim San Memorial Scholarship, a bond-free scholarship funded by the SPH Foundation. The scholarship, launched in 2006, aims to support Singaporean students from modest backgrounds pursuing full-time language, linguistic, and humanities degree courses. Scholarship holders will receive full course fees, an annual allowance, and internship opportunities at SPH Media. Eligible candidates must be Singaporean citizens from households with a monthly income of S$5,000 or less, with a closing date for applications set for April 28.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

A memorandum of understanding was signed between MBS, Las Vegas Sands and the 6 IHLs on Monday; (From L to R): Lim Peng Hun, deputy principal (academic), Singapore Polytechnic; Loh Chuu Yi, deputy principal (academic), Nanyang Polytechnic; Chua Kee Chaing, president, Singapore Institute of Technology; Ron Reese, senior vice-president of global communications and corporate affairs, Las Vegas Sands; Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan; Paul Town, chief operating officer, Marina Bay Sands; Lim Kok Kiang, principal & CEO, Ngee Ann Polytechnic; Peter Lam, principal & CEO, Temasek Polytechnic; and Michael Koh, deputy principal (academic services), Republic Polytechnic.
Grab's new headquarters brings about 3,000 employees and a research and development centre under one roof.

site_title: Germany wants tax credits for green energy to counter US Inflation Reduction Act
summary: Germany plans to introduce tax credits for solar, wind, and grid investments in response to the US Inflation Reduction Act, which offers US$370 billion in subsidies for renewable energy. The European Union has struggled to respond, and Germany's proposal would support a Europe-wide tax credit system. The move aims to boost Germany's photovoltaic industry and reduce its dependency on China. The government plans to set up guarantees for wind power production and a transformation fund by summer 2023.

images.alt_text: Solar panels in Spain. While the EU is still widely seen as ahead of the US in rolling out green tech, the latter's Inflation Protection Act has made the US a more attractive investment environment for several key green industries.
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt walks outside his house in London, Britain, October 18, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville

site_title: Sci-fi magazine bans hundreds of AI chatbot authors
summary: A US science fiction magazine, Clarksworld, has banned hundreds of authors, including over 500 in February, after receiving "machine-generated submissions" written by artificial intelligence (AI) chatbots. Editor Neil Clarke stated that the rise of AI tools like ChatGPT has led to a significant increase in plagiarism and cheating concerns. Clarksworld's guidelines already prohibit AI-written works, but the influx of submissions has overwhelmed the magazine. Clarke blames the proliferation of influencers promoting ChatGPT as a profitable "side hustle" for the problem, stating that a solution is still needed.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on January 23, 2023 in Toulouse, southwestern France, shows screens displaying the logos of OpenAI and ChatGPT. - ChatGPT is a conversational artificial intelligence software application developed by OpenAI. (Photo by Lionel BONAVENTURE / AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks in the red amid regional rout; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.2% on Wednesday, February 22, 2023, following a regional rout, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 6.82 points to 3,300.04. Losers outperformed gainers 304 to 246, with major Asian markets also in the red. The US two-year and 10-year yields rose overnight, driven by higher-than-expected US Purchasing Managers' Index figures. Local banks UOB rose 1.1%, while DBS and OCBC fell 0.6% and 1.1%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
OCBC holds an 87 per cent stake in Great Eastern.
Gross proceeds from the rights issue will be used to partially fund the inflight caterer and ground handler’s acquisition of Paris-based Worldwide Flight Services.

site_title: TikTok creators: new fame, age-old exploitation
summary: TikTok creators are speaking out against the Carter Agency, a talent agency that represents popular TikTok creators, alleging exploitation and withholding of payment for deals negotiated on their behalf. Dozens of creators claim they were not paid for deals worth up to $10,000, with some receiving only 10-20% of the agreed-upon amount. The agency's founder, Josh Popkin, was previously a TikTok creator and has been accused of targeting vulnerable creators, particularly those of color. The creators are seeking answers and resolution, with some exploring legal action, but the agency has not responded to allegations.

images.alt_text: The logos of Facebook and Instagram and the words "Monthly subscription" are seen in this picture illustration taken January 19, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/I
TikTok also reported on average 125 million monthly active users in EU between August 2022 to January 2023, subjecting it to stricter EU online content rules known as the Digital Services Act (DSA).
The new numbers signal that the app can continue to expand its user base, which may help counter major declines in its digital ad business.

site_title: Rio Tinto annual profit falls 37.9% on slower China demand
summary: Rio Tinto's annual profit fell 37.9% due to slower demand from China, particularly during the COVID-19 curbs, which lowered iron ore prices from $143.8 to $106.1 per dry metric tonne. Higher wages and raw material costs also impacted earnings. The company reported underlying earnings of $13.3 billion, down from $21.4 billion in 2021. Rio Tinto also halved its dividend to $4.92 per share, down from a record $10.40 per share in 2021.

site_title: Willowmore raises Series A+ funding from Seeds Capital
summary: Willowmore, a smart lock and facilities management company, has raised a Series A+ round from Seeds Capital, the investment arm of Enterprise Singapore. The funding, valued at US$3 million, will be used to grow the company's Singapore market and expand internationally, drive technology development, and increase its headcount by 50% over the next year. With existing customers including security firms and telcos, Willowmore aims to bring its innovative solutions to more customers globally. The investment will also support research and development investments, including expanding its smart lock and security solutions product range.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Venture capital funding has flowed away from Series C startups to earlier stages in 2022, as total investment amount in South-east Asia declined compared to 2021.
Transcelestial's Singapore manufacturing plant can produce up to 2,400 CENTAURI devices (pictured above)

Investors shift away from cryptocurrencies but continue to pour money into blockchain-based solutions like real-time payment settlement pre-validation, streamlining cross-border payments and tokenising assets.

site_title: German inflation remains high at start of year
summary: Germany's inflation rate remained high at 9.2% in January, driven by energy and food price pressures due to the war in Ukraine. Consumer prices rose 0.5% from December and 8.7% from the previous year, according to the federal statistics office. Energy product prices increased 23.1% year-over-year, with food prices rising 20.2%. Experts predict the European Central Bank should continue raising interest rates to combat inflation, which remains at a high level despite a slowdown in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Compared with December 2022, German producer prices fell 1.0 per cent, which was above consensus for a drop of 1.6 per cent.

site_title: China mulls mandatory ESG disclosures for domestic public firms
summary: China is considering making environmental, social, and governance (ESG) disclosures mandatory for domestic public firms as part of efforts to reduce its carbon footprint and meet a net-zero target by 2060. Regulators are working on a framework with advisory bodies and rating agencies to design a standard recognized by the international community. The first step would be a "comply or explain" basis, with Chinese state-owned enterprises expected to lead compliance by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience
Political opposition to environmental, social and governance investing in Republican US states has not dented the finance industry's commitment to sustainability, according to a Barclays study.

site_title: India does not want G20 to discuss Russia sanctions: sources
summary: India's government does not want the G20 to discuss additional sanctions on Russia due to its invasion of Ukraine. Senior Indian officials stated this during a G20 meeting of finance ministers and central bank chiefs. Financial leaders from the G7 nations, including Japan's finance minister, will meet on Thursday to discuss measures against Russia, focusing on the war's macroeconomic impact. The discussion aims to address the war's effects, but India's reluctance to take action suggests a divergence in the group's stance on Russia sanctions.

images.alt_text: Beverages imported from Japan and China on sale in Vladivostok, Russia. Sellers have been advertising drinks such as Coca-Cola as imported, so buyers know it is the real thing.
Russia’s decision to suspend its participation in the New Start treaty for nuclear disarmament was met with widespread international condemnation.
India’s self-nomination as the leader of the Global South is the culmination of messaging on the global stage that it will not simply play by the rules and norms of more powerful nations.

site_title: Danone eyes better margins in 2023, Q4 sales top estimates
summary: Danone's Q4 sales exceeded market expectations with 7% growth, driven by price increases amid surging raw materials and energy costs. The company's full-year operating margin is expected to moderate, with a 12.2% operating margin in 2022, down from 13.7% in 2021. Danone's 2023 forecast is in line with its mid-term sales growth target of 3-5%, and CEO Antoine de Saint-Affrique has implemented a revival plan to address mounting input costs and uncertainty.

site_title: Taiwan revises down 2023 GDP growth forecast on export slump
summary: Taiwan's statistics agency has revised down its 2023 GDP growth forecast to 2.12%, lower than the initial 2.75% due to a decline in exports. The country's exports are now expected to contract by 5.84% compared to last year, attributed to global inflation, interest rate hikes, and the war in Ukraine. Consumer price index is forecast to rise 2.16% this year, up from the initial 1.86%. This marks a slowdown from the 2.45% growth in 2022.

site_title: COE prices up across the board, Open category hits record high of S$118,001
summary: The Certificate of Entitlement (COE) price in Singapore's Open category reached a record high of S$118,001 in the latest tender exercise, up 12.4% from S$105,002 in the previous exercise. This surpasses the previous record of S$116,577 set in November 2022. The commercial vehicle COE also set a new record price of S$87,790, while premiums for other categories increased. The record-breaking price reflects the growing demand for new vehicles in Singapore.

images.alt_text: With the new Additional Registration Fees in place, a Bentley Flying Spur’s ARF climbs from S$600,000 to S$840,000.

site_title: Xi calls for China to speed basic research to counter US curbs
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged the country to accelerate fundamental scientific research to counter US sanctions on critical technologies, emphasizing the need for a "national laboratory system with Chinese characteristics" and developing "high-level basic research talents." The government will provide more policy support and funding for research efforts, with a focus on strengthening the nation's "strategic technology power" and replacing foreign technologies with homegrown alternatives.

images.alt_text: Investors track key political events in China for word on GDP growth target and national security policy

site_title: Hong Kong Budget: Tax rate cut for first-time home buyers
summary: Hong Kong has lowered the tax rate for first-time home buyers, with properties valued up to HK$9 million (S$1.5 million) taxed at a lower rate of 3% compared to 3.75% previously. The measure aims to ease the burden on ordinary families and benefit 37,000 buyers, costing the government approximately HK$1.9 billion annually. The plan may boost the city's property market, which saw prices slump 16% last year due to higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: The city is looking to kickstart its economy as it sees rising competition from Singapore to be Asia’s top destination for business, talent and capital.
China started its crackdown on crypto in 2017 and banned trading in 2021, leading some of its biggest homegrown names, such as Binance and Tron, to exit the country.
Hong Kong’s real estate market is one of the world’s most expensive, and housing has been a perennial issue for the city’s leaders.

site_title: Bangladesh banks' profits to be pressured by high funding costs: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service warns that Bangladesh banks' profits will be pressured by high funding costs due to liquidity pressures in 2023. High inflation is expected to keep deposit growth low, while economic uncertainty may reduce exporters' earnings, leading to reduced foreign-currency liquidity. The rating agency forecasts inflation to be 7-8%, higher than pre-pandemic levels. Banks, particularly Islamic banks with smaller liquidity buffers, may face difficulties in obtaining funding, hurting their net interest margins and profitability. The central bank's efforts to ease liquidity may not fully abate the pressures.

images.alt_text: The benchmark repurchase rate was increased to 6 per cent from 5.75 per cent effective from Monday (Jan 16), Bangladesh Bank said in a statement on Sunday.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts lift Sembcorp targets on higher growth expectations
summary: Brokerages have lifted their near-term earnings projections for Sembcorp Industries, resulting in higher price targets. UOBKH raised its target price to S$4.57, while Maybank Securities lifted its target to S$4.35. DBS Group Research also increased its target to S$4.60, citing strong contributions from the conventional energy business and growing renewable energy segment. Analysts expect higher earnings from these segments, with some maintaining a "buy" or "add" call on the stock.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Current deputy chairman Tow Heng Tan will take over as non-executive and non-independent chairman.
The group attributed the improved profits to higher contributions from its renewables and conventional energy segments.
Transforming our energy sources from fossil fuels will be one of the largest capital expendi­tures in history.
The facility has enough capacity to meet the daily electrical needs of nearly 17,000 four-room Housing and Development Board flats in a single discharge.

site_title: Citigroup expects ‘less hard’ landing for global economy this year
summary: Citigroup has revised its global growth forecast, expecting the economy to grow at 2.2% this year, the slowest pace in 40 years, but a "less hard" landing. The bank attributes this to improved macroeconomic trends, including a stronger China, stagnation in the euro area, and resilience in the US. However, stubbornly high inflation globally, estimated at 6-7%, may temper growth. The bank also expects the US Federal Reserve to hike rates three times this year, taking the Fed funds rate beyond 5%.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A shopping cart is seen in a supermarket in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., June 10, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: South Korea to examine bank pay schemes, competition
summary: South Korea launched a task force to study ways to improve business practices and pay schemes at banks, following President Yoon Suk-yeol's call to help curb the cost-of-living burden on vulnerable people. The panel aims to boost competition, diversify business practices, and improve pay structures, with the goal of making the Korean financial markets more attractive to investors. Major banks have already lowered lending rates in response to Yoon's comments, which have led to a decline in the Korea Exchange Bank Equity Index. The task force will respect financial firms' decisions on shareholder returns.

images.alt_text: Jeonse tenancy has been particularly popular among people in their 20s and 30s.
In January, the BOK raised its policy interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.50 per cent, the highest since late 2008.
Exports began to fall late last year as the world economy deteriorated, making global trade one of the biggest risks for South Korea’s outlook.

site_title: Never look back: actor Vincent Cassel, France's scary star
summary: French actor Vincent Cassel is set to dominate the entertainment industry in 2023, starring in two blockbuster French films, Apple TV's spy thriller Liaison, and a biopic of Antoine de Saint-Exupery. Cassel attributes his international success to Apple's global reach, stating that the tech giant's power can instantly reach 150 million people. He is paired with fellow French export Eva Green in Liaison, and the two are also set to star together in The Three Musketeers. Cassel emphasizes his focus on mental and physical health, and the upcoming projects, rather than past accomplishments.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on February 12, 2023, French actress Eva Green and French actor Vincent Cassel pose upon their arrival for the avant-premiere of the British-French television series developed for Apple TV+ "Liaison" at the Publicis Drugstore in Paris. - Three and a half years after its launch, the American platform AppleTV+ is finally targeting the French public with its first Franco-British series "Liaison", a political-love thriller under adrenaline, carried by the French and glamorous duo Vincent Cassel / Eva Green. (Photo by Christophe ARCHAMBAULT / AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong Budget: More cash vouchers to boost economy
summary: Hong Kong's government will give out HK$5,000 cash vouchers to consumers this year as part of a fiscal policy aimed at boosting the economy. The city is expected to run a fiscal deficit, with a forecasted GDP expansion of 3.5-5.5% in 2023. The move comes as Hong Kong faces competition from Singapore for business, talent, and capital, and is looking to kickstart its economy.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong at the end of October pivoted to a pro-crypto stance, part of a wider effort to restore the city’s credentials as a financial centre.
Qantas is due to report record six-month earnings on Feb 23.

site_title: Retail lost crypto money as whales sold in 2022 crash, report finds
summary: A report by the Bank for International Settlements found that retail investors, referred to as "krill," lost money on their cryptocurrency investments in 2022 as larger investors, known as "whales," sold their assets before steep price declines. The study analyzed crypto exchange data and found that as prices rose, more users entered the market, but as prices fell, larger investors profited at the expense of smaller investors. The report suggests that the industry needs greater investor protection to mitigate this trend.

images.alt_text: Tether now commands 52.6 per cent of the stablecoin market.
More can be done for decentralised policy processes through the use of Web 3.0 technologies such as blockchain.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies Bitcoin, Ethereum and DogeCoin are placed on PC motherboard in this illustration taken, June 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/File Photo

site_title: Frasers Property secures 5-year A$340 million and US$75 million sustainability-linked loan
summary: Frasers Property Australia secured a 5-year, A$340 million and US$75 million sustainability-linked loan with interest rate savings if it meets emission reduction targets until 2028. The loan aims to reduce annual greenhouse gas emissions from FY2019 footprint to net-zero by 2028, with targets covering direct, indirect, and embodied carbon. If met, interest rate savings will be achieved from the second year of the loan, supporting the company's sustainability goals.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Frasers Property's recent purchase of a stake in Nex may not add value to its shareholders.

site_title: China’s bond markets price in policy tightening; analysts disagree
summary: China's bond markets have seen a sharp jump in short-term yields, prompting analysts to question the need for policy tightening. Despite a swift lifting of pandemic curbs and better-than-expected economic data, analysts believe policymakers must first address consumption levels, stabilize the property market, and boost economic growth before considering monetary tightening. Experts expect the People's Bank of China to cut interest rates in the coming months, with some predicting a rate cut after the annual session of China's Parliament in March.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese Yuan banknotes are seen in this illustration picture taken June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia launches carbon trading mechanism for coal power plants
summary: Indonesia launched the first phase of a mandatory carbon trading mechanism for 99 coal power plants, aiming to boost renewable energy and achieve net zero emissions by 2060. The mechanism covers 33.6 GW of power plants and allows those emitting excess carbon to buy credits from under-quota plants or renewables. The price of carbon credits is estimated to range between $2 and $18 per tonne, with a goal of reducing carbon emissions by 36 million tonnes by 2030.

images.alt_text: Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience

site_title: Rents surging most in 15 years set to smash Australia households
summary: Australian rents are expected to surge 7.5% this year, the highest since 2008, further straining household budgets. Average prices will increase on top of the 4% rise in 2022, affecting one-third of households that rent. Economists warn that renters, mostly low- and middle-income households with limited savings, will have to cut spending to meet higher rental costs.

images.alt_text: Australia's annual pay growth picked up to 3.3 per cent, from a revised 3.2 per cent, but again was under forecasts of 3.5 per cent.
Rates have climbed 325 basis points since last May, easily the most aggressive tightening in modern history.

site_title: Hot stock: Great Eastern, OCBC slip over 1% following fall in insurer profits
summary: Great Eastern's profits declined 37% in H2 2022 due to negative financial market movements, impacting insurance contract liabilities. The company attributed the decline to a challenging business climate with geopolitical uncertainty and inflationary pressures. As a result, shares of Great Eastern and its largest shareholder OCBC fell over 1% each, with Great Eastern slipping 1.6% to S$18.49 and OCBC dropping 1.3% to S$12.87.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: ‘Confidential’ settlement reached between security agency Apro and union over officers’ wage dispute
summary: Apro, a local security agency, has reached a confidential settlement with the Union of Security Employees (USE) over a wage and rank adjustment exercise. The terms of the agreement are not disclosed, but both parties agreed to work together to address concerns and strengthen the labor-management partnership. The USE had declared a deadlock in negotiations earlier this month, with labor chief Ng Chee Meng criticizing Apro's plans to make officers work longer hours. Apro's deputy managing director Li Xiaowen said the firm is now focused on explaining the necessary adjustments to officers.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
An APRO security guard at work.
Under the Progressive Wage Model for the outsourced private security sector, security officers’ monthly basic wages before overtime start at S$1,650.

site_title: Business, industry transformation must accompany workers’ productivity gains: Zaqy
summary: Senior Minister of State for Manpower Zaqy Mohamad emphasized the need for workers, businesses, and industries to transform in tandem to improve productivity. He stated that the outcomes vary depending on how companies and sectors progress. Zaqy highlighted the role of industry transformation maps, or ITMs, which map out growth and transformation plans for 23 sectors across the economy. This approach complements progressive wage moves to drive productivity gains.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
THE OPW will cover general drivers, such as lorry drivers, and specialised drivers, such as bus drivers.
The newly-launched Progressive Wage Mark scheme aims to encourage consumers to support lower-wage workers by purchasing from accredited firms.

site_title: Progressivity is not about pitting the well-off against others: Pritam Singh
summary: Singaporean Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh emphasizes the need for progressive policies addressing income inequality. He warns that framing the government's budget as a "Robin Hood" Budget may pit high-income earners against lower and middle classes, potentially leading to social frictions. Singh advocates for careful management of social frictions and calls for the government to address the issue of high housing prices hindering social mobility. He also highlights the threat of emerging "two Singapores" – one affluent and connected, and another struggling with slowing social mobility.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Progressive tax policies, in which the better-off help the less well-off, can also help to strengthen the social fabric and build national resilience.

Amid the current supply crunch of Build-To-Order flats, the government will give first-timer families with children and young married couples aged 40 years and below an additional ballot for their BTO flat applications starting later this year, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong on Tuesday (Feb 14).
Over 10,000 first-time homebuyers will benefit from the increase in the Central Provident Fund Housing Grant in its first year, said the Ministry of National Development.
The CPF salary ceiling, the maximum amount of ordinary wages that employee and employer contributions are calculated on, was last raised to S$6,000 from S$5,000 in 2016.
The government will pilot the scheme in the precision engineering, retail and wholesale trade industries.

site_title: Sats falls as much as 4.4% after announcing issue of 363.1 million new shares at S$2.20 apiece
summary: SATS shares fell 4.4% on Wednesday after the in-flight caterer and ground handler announced a 363.1 million new share issue at S$2.20 apiece to raise S$798.8 million. The shares will be used to partially fund the acquisition of Paris-based Worldwide Flight Services, expected to cost S$1.8 billion. The rights issue represents 32.3% of existing shares and will be underwritten by DBS, BOA, Citi, OCBC, and UOB.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Rights issue is expected to launch in Q1, 2023. Temasek, which holds 39.7 per cent of Sats through subsidiary Venezio Investments, has indicated it intends to subscribe for its pro-rata entitlement.
Last month, Sats' shareholders voted in favour of its proposed acquisition of Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services.
Sats net profit plunged 90.2 per cent to S$0.5 million for the third quarter.
Sats' share price fell precipitously after the company said it would acquire WFS, the largest air cargo handling firm in the world
Sats’ acquisition of WFS is expected to cost the company S$1.8 billion.
ISS said that as a split-funded purchase, the proposed acquisition also gives the company flexibility to not put too much pressure on any one funding stream.
Kerry Mok, chief executive of Sats, said the company is working on a mix of 4 funding options that will give it the “right funding structure to maximise benefits for shareholders”.
Sats' recent share price trajectory has been an accurate barometer of the financial implications of its proposed acquisition of WFS
Worldwide Flight Services is being acquired by Sats, pending regulatory approval.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop as traders contemplate higher-for-longer rates
summary: Asian markets declined, with Tokyo, Seoul, Taipei, and Manila falling more than one percent, as traders await the release of US Federal Reserve policy meeting minutes and expect higher interest rates. The US economy showed strong data, despite rate hikes and inflation, fueling fears of a recession. Retailers like Walmart and Home Depot downbeat 2023 projections further exacerbated the dark mood, with many predicting the Fed will continue rate hikes. The Fed minutes release is expected to provide clarity on interest rate expectations, with traders anticipating a possible rate hike to 5.3 percent.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong dipped along with Tokyo, Sydney, Taipei, Manila and Wellington, while Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Jakarta and Bangkok edged up.

site_title: Bank of Japan board member calls for keeping ultra-easy policy for now
summary: Bank of Japan board member Naoki Tamura called for maintaining ultra-easy monetary policy to assess whether recent inflation rise will lead to higher wages. Tamura cited Japan's "rare" environment of pent-up demand driven by household savings during the pandemic. He warned that inflation could overshoot forecasts, but emphasized the need to maintain policy easing to scrutinize a positive wage-inflation cycle. The comments come amid market expectations of interest rate hikes when Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's term ends in April.

site_title: Sembcorp chairman Ang Kong Hua retires, Tow Heng Tan appointed
summary: Sembcorp Industries announced that chairman Ang Kong Hua will retire at the upcoming annual general meeting on Apr 20. Current deputy chairman Tow Heng Tan will take over as non-executive and non-independent chairman, bringing extensive business and management experience to the role. Non-executive and independent director Lim Ming Yan will be appointed as lead independent director, and Tham Kui Seng will step down after 11 years on the board. The company's leadership change is seen as a continuation of its brown to green transformation strategy under Ang's leadership.

images.alt_text: The group attributed the improved profits to higher contributions from its renewables and conventional energy segments.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% at the open on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 3.75 points to 3,303.11. Losers outnumbered gainers 80 to 38, with Sembcorp Marine, Mapletree Logistics Trust, and Genting Singapore experiencing declines. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and UOB gaining, while OCBC slipped. The decline follows losses in US and European markets, which were driven by concerns over Federal Reserve interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Wilmar says that all its key business segments reported higher profits, along with higher contributions from associates and joint ventures, and lower tax rates.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB raises target price on Wilmar, warns of challenging FY2023
summary: CGS-CIMB raised its target price on Wilmar International to S$4.82 from S$4.68, citing the market capitalization of the group's subsidiaries. The brokerage expects a more challenging FY2023 for Wilmar, with a 16% year-on-year decline, driven by lower crude palm oil prices and higher effective tax rates. Despite this, CGS-CIMB maintains its "add" call on the stock, citing an attractive PE valuation multiple of 10 times and a 4% dividend yield.

images.alt_text: Including the interim dividend of S$0.06 per share paid out last August, the total dividend paid and proposed for FY2022 stands at S$0.17 - the highest cash dividend paid out by Wilmar since its listing.

site_title: Gold ticks higher with focus on Fed meeting minutes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,836.43 per ounce as investors awaited the release of the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes, potentially influencing interest rate hikes. Money markets expect the Fed to raise benchmark rates above 5% by May. Meanwhile, US business activity rebounded in February, with inflation subsiding, while existing home sales dropped to a 12-year low in January. The dollar eased, making gold less expensive for buyers holding other currencies.
