images.alt_text: [1/2] An employee shows gold bar at the Prioksky Non-Ferrous Metals Plant in Kasimov, Russia February 14, 2017. Picture taken February 14, 2017. REUTERS/Sergei Karpukhin
Higher interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding zero-yield bullion.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on rate worries with Dow falling 2.1%
summary: US stocks plummeted 2.1% on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling nearly 700 points to 33,129.59. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped 2.0% and 2.5% respectively, as investors anxiously awaited more Federal Reserve interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The yield on the 10-year US Treasury climbed to nearly 4%, and retailers' lackluster forecasts added to the decline. Analysts say the market's pullback reflects a more sober assessment of the Fed's actions, with hopes for a quick pivot being replaced by more realistic expectations.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 127.00 points, or 0.38 per cent, at the open to 33,699.69.

site_title: Australia wage growth picks up to 3.3%, short of forecasts
summary: Australia's annual wage growth increased to 3.3% in the December quarter, the fastest pace in a decade, but fell short of forecasts of 3.5%. This may ease pressure on policymakers to raise interest rates, as high inflation could lead to a damaging price-wage spiral. The local dollar dropped following the news.

images.alt_text: Workers cast shadows as they stroll among the office towers Sydney's Barangaroo business district in Australia's largest city, May 8, 2017. REUTERS/Jason Reed

site_title: South Korea inches towards same-sex equality, but broader bill is stalled
summary: South Korea's National Assembly is stalled on a bill that would provide protections for LGBTQ individuals, despite growing public support. The bill, introduced in 2021, would solidify protections for various groups, but its inclusion of LGBTQ people has led to fierce opposition from conservative Christian groups. The bill has faced repeated attempts to pass, but has been blocked by the governing People Power Party, which relies on churchgoers as a key voting bloc. The failure to pass the bill has sparked widespread criticism, with many viewing it as an example of South Korea's laws remaining out of step with the times.

images.alt_text: Thilaga Sulathireh from transgender rights group Justice for Sisters said the move was part of “a broader trend of censorship that we are seeing in the last couple of years”.
Jeonse tenancy has been particularly popular among people in their 20s and 30s.

site_title: Hong Heng Mansions up for collective sale with S$133 million reserve price
summary: Hong Heng Mansions, a freehold development in District 26, Singapore, is up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$133 million. The site, built in the 1990s, comprises 17 commercial and 41 residential units on a land area of 78,644 square feet. The tender closes on April 18, and the site's potential redevelopment could add value to the area, which is undergoing significant transformation. The land rate is approximately S$1,208 per square foot per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: Hong Heng Mansions
Generic photo of condos and private properties
The higher marginal BSD for higher-value residential and non-residential properties are expected to affect 15 per cent of residential properties.
Five Singapore Reits took up spots among the 10 stocks which recorded largest institutional net inflows for most of last week.

site_title: Sleepwalking towards catastrophe, once again?
summary: US President Joe Biden visited Ukraine's capital, Kyiv, on Feb 20, 2023, amid ongoing tensions. The visit was seen as a show of support for Ukraine amidst the ongoing conflict with Russia. Historian Christopher Clark's book "The Sleepwalkers: How Europe Went to War in 1914" highlights how mutual misunderstandings and unintended signals led to World War I, with a similar scenario potentially unfolding in Ukraine. The visit serves as a reminder of the ongoing global implications of the conflict.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken told CBS that China was now “considering providing lethal support” to Moscow ranging “from ammunition to the weapons themselves.”
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken had warned Beijing’s top diplomat Wang Yi (top) against providing weapons to Russia in its war with Ukraine.
President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said he and US leader Joe Biden discussed long range weapons during the visit, and Biden will announce more sanctions on Russia and military support for Ukraine.

site_title: Shipping industry grapples with ways to cut cargo fires at sea
summary: Global shipping companies, including Evergreen Line, HMM, Maersk, and ONE, are exploring ways to boost safety in transporting cargo at sea due to increasing fire risks. The companies are conducting feasibility studies to improve detection and response to fires on board ships, with a focus on providing early indications and speeding up response times. According to Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty, there were over 70 reported fires on board container ships in the past five years, highlighting the need for industry-wide solutions to address the root cause of cargo fires.

images.alt_text: Leading global container shipping group AP Moller Maersk said there had been significant damage to logistics and transport infrastructure around the earthquake epicentre, including at the Port of Iskenderun.

Migrants prepare to get on board the Ocean Viking ship sailing in the international waters off Libya in the Mediterranean Sea, after being rescued by European maritime-humanitarian organization "SOS Mediterranee" on October 25, 2022. - Migrant rescue group SOS Mediterranee said on November 3, 2022 it had called on the governments of France, Greece and Spain to help find a port for 234 people rescued while trying to reach Europe, after Italy and Malta failed to answer. (Photo by Vincenzo CIRCOSTA / AFP)

site_title: New Zealand delivers half-point rate hike, still sees 5.5% peak
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) raised interest rates by half a percentage point to 4.75% as expected, signaling further hikes to tame inflation. The central bank expects a recession starting in the second quarter of this year but forecasts the economy will bounce back sooner next year. Inflation is expected to peak at 5.5% this year and return to the target range of 1-3% by the third quarter of 2024. The decision brings the RBNZ's pace of tightening closer to global peers, but still puts New Zealand at the upper end of recent increases.

images.alt_text: Most local bank economists are predicting the central bank will resort to a 50-point hike next week after a record 75-point move at its previous review in November.

site_title: Investment into China picks up in January after late 2022 drop
summary: Foreign investment into China rebounded in January with 128 billion yuan (S$24.9 billion) in new actually utilised foreign investment, the highest level since June 2022. This marks a 14.5% increase from the same period last year, with a 75% jump in investment into high-tech manufacturing. The government's efforts to attract more investment come as many firms have struggled to do business in China due to Covid Zero policies and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: A ticket for a round trip that leaves for Beijing on Dec 30 and returns to Singapore on Jan 10 costs $2,789.

site_title: Australia’s Woolworths’ first-half profit jumps, inflation pressures loom
summary: Australia's Woolworths Group reported a 25% rise in first-half profit to A$845 million, driven by 2.5% sales growth at its top unit and non-recurrence of Covid-19 costs. Despite solid sales momentum expected in the second-half, operating earnings growth is forecast to be lower sequentially due to rising wages, energy, and supply chain costs. The company declared an interim dividend of 46 cents per share.

images.alt_text: Woolworths Group and Coles Group will likely see growth in their half-year profit, according to analyst estimates, helped by higher shelf prices and lower Covid-19 related costs.

site_title: US business activity rebounds to eight-month high in February: S&P Global survey
summary: US business activity rebounded to an eight-month high in February, according to a survey, with the services sector driving the growth. The S&P Global Composite PMI Output Index rose to 50.2 from 46.8 in January, ending seven months of contraction. Inflation subsided, and economists see the rebound as a sign of solid economic momentum. However, the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike campaign may continue, with markets expecting another rate hike in June.

images.alt_text: Home resales, which account for a big chunk of US housing sales, plunged 36.9 per cent on a year-on-year basis in January.

site_title: Microsoft insists videogame merger won’t hurt competition
summary: Microsoft has assured that its planned $69-billion takeover of Activision Blizzard won't harm competition, despite EU regulators' concerns. The deal aims to create the world's third-largest gaming company by revenue. Microsoft dismissed antitrust concerns, saying the acquisition would be beneficial for consumers. British regulators had previously stated that the deal could significantly harm competition and consumer choice, but no further action has been announced.

images.alt_text: A demo of Microsoft's new Bing search engine using artificial intelligence, at the company's campus in Redmond, Washingto on Feb 7, 2023.
Microsoft expects the more human responses from the Bing AI chatbot will generate more users for its search function and therefore more advertisers.

site_title: Crypto technology firm Polygon eliminates 20% of workforce
summary: Crypto technology firm Polygon has eliminated 20% of its workforce, approximately 100 employees, as part of a business unit consolidation. The impacted employees will receive three months of severance pay. Despite the layoffs, Polygon's treasury remains healthy with a balance sheet worth over $250 million. The move comes amidst deep job cuts across the industry following the collapse of token prices last year.

images.alt_text: Crypto markets have since held mostly steady after an initial drop, as investors grappled with the implications of the development.

site_title: Credit Suisse shares hit record low on outflow claims probe
summary: Credit Suisse shares hit a record low after a report alleged that Chairman Axel Lehmann's comments about stopping client outflows may have been misleading. Lehmann said outflows "basically have stopped" after disclosing a loss of 84 billion francs in client assets, but analysts claim more than 85% of outflows occurred in October and November. Swiss financial regulator Finma is investigating whether Lehmann's remarks were misleading, which may impact the bank's capital raise.

images.alt_text: Swiss Financial regulator Finma is reviewing whether Credit Suisse chairman Axel Lehmann’s statements about the bank's outflows were potentially misleading.
Credit Suisse is grappling with a string of senior banker departures as it undertakes a sweeping overhaul of its business to restore profitability after scandals and missteps.
Credit Suisse has agreed to compensate Georgian billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili for failing to “police the perimeter” of his wealth from theft.

site_title: Japan Post says it’s considering options after report of US$9 billion JP Bank share sale
summary: Japan Post Holdings is considering various options after a report suggested it may sell around a third of its stake in Japan Post Bank, worth nearly US$9 billion. The company aims to reduce its 89% ownership stake to 60% by the end of March. Shares in Japan Post Bank slid over 6% on the news, while Japan Post Holdings fell 1.8%. The company has denied any decision has been made, stating they will make a formal announcement when a decision is made.

images.alt_text: Ueda, a professor at Kyoritsu Women's University, was a BOJ board member from 1998-2005.
Factory output and new orders decreased for an eighth straight month and at faster rates than January.

site_title: Britain lacks millions of homes due to tight planning laws: think tank
summary: Britain's strict planning laws are to blame for the country's housing shortage, with the UK lacking 4.3 million homes if regulations were more relaxed, according to a study by the Centre for Cities think tank. The laws, established in 1947, allow local authorities to reject developers' applications, resulting in a 40% decline in housebuilding rates since then. The UK needs to build 442,000 new homes annually for the next 25 years to close the backlog, with the government's current target of 300,000 new homes per year being insufficient.

images.alt_text: Years of soaring asset prices have allowed older generations to build enough wealth to allow them to retire comfortably.

The sharp uptick in February was driven by rising customer demand and increasing confidence among business executives after a subsidence in the market turmoil triggered by then-Prime Minister Liz Truss’s budget plan.
With Britain facing a cost of living crisis, consumer groups worry cash-strapped people are getting into debt by using BNPL to buy food or pay energy bills.

site_title: No income tax for banks as Indonesia seeks new capital investors
summary: Indonesia is offering tax breaks to lure companies to its new capital, Nusantara, in Borneo. Banks and insurers will pay no income tax for up to 25 years if they invest before 2035, while those investing before 2045 can get up to 20 years of tax breaks. The government is also offering incentives such as tax holidays, super tax deductions, and waived import taxes to support the relocation of businesses and industries to the new capital. The goal is to attract investments of $52.9 billion to build a renewable-powered and technologically advanced city.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Central Bank governor Perry Warjiyo has been popular among many bankers in Indonesia who credit him with helping to maintain a strong economy despite challenges of Covid-19 and geopolitical turmoil.

Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati speaks during a side event on the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors Meeting in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, 14 July 2022. Made Nagi/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: US investors want US$3 million in savings for comfortable retirement
summary: US investors believe a retirement fund of $3 million to $5 million is sufficient for a comfortable retirement, according to a Bloomberg survey of 553 investors worldwide. Most respondents expect stocks and bonds to move in opposite directions this year, with fixed income serving as a cushion for potential losses. However, uncertainty remains about whether investors will have enough saved to maintain their lifestyle in retirement, with less than half confident in their ability to do so.

images.alt_text: Fixed deposits are currently attractive, but over the long run, cash is unlikely to keep up with inflation.
Positive returns do not necessarily mean you have accumulated enough for retirement.

site_title: Olam among first in Singapore market to report detailed natural capital accounts
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-listed food and agri-business company, has become one of the first companies to release a detailed natural capital account, a monetary valuation of material natural capital impacts and dependencies. This move is seen as a step towards standardizing natural capital accounting and reporting, with Olam's approach similar to that of Puma, which pioneered the practice in 2011. The report provides a common financial unit for tracking natural capital performance, including greenhouse gas emissions, water consumption, and biodiversity. The move is expected to lead to more companies adopting this practice, with regulators and international bodies aiming to standardize natural capital accounting and reporting in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Overseas investors bought US$6.6 billion worth of bonds in India, Indonesia, Malaysia, South Korea and Thailand after withdrawing a net US$3.2 billion in the previous month.
Khaitan International’s chairman and founder Pawan Khaitan (left) with his son, senior executive Manish Khaitan (right), at the 2018 Enterprise 50 Awards.

The facility comprises a 2- and 3-year revolving credit facility as well as a 3-year loan, with its interest margin linked to the achievement of sustainability targets across ESG (environmental, social and governance) areas.
Olam Group shares jumped as much as 3.4 per cent on Friday, touching their highest intraday level in nearly six months.
Once completed, the move will result in concurrent listings in Singapore and Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Investors may need deeper pockets as Reits raise cash for expansion
summary: Realty investment trusts (Reits) in Singapore are raising cash for expansion amid a stellar start to 2023, with interest rate fears easing and China's reopening post-Covid boosting market optimism. However, this may not be the best time for investors, as Reit managers are using the funds to de-risk their balance sheets and position themselves for potential acquisitions, potentially diverting funds from investors. ESR-Logos Reit recently raised S$300 million through a private placement and preferential offering to fund acquisitions and asset enhancements.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The company plans to use the proceeds for repaying debts and pursuing investment opportunities.
As at 9.15 am, the Reit hits a 4-month low of S$0.325, down S$0.025 or 7.1 per cent from Monday’s closing at S$0.35 before the trust issued a trading halt

site_title: Putin suspends US nuclear treaty, Biden vows Russia will never win
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin suspended Moscow's participation in the New Start treaty with the US, a nuclear disarmament agreement, amid escalating tensions in Ukraine. US President Joe Biden vowed that Russia would never win in Ukraine, while accusing the West of escalating the conflict. International condemnation followed Russia's decision, with NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg calling it a "critical moment" for the arms control architecture. Biden met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and reaffirmed Washington's commitment to Ukraine, while China expressed concern over the conflict's intensification.

images.alt_text: The central bank projects growth may resume this year.
Japan's PM says there is still a need to assist people whose livelihoods have been destroyed by the war, and to restore destroyed infrastructure.

Russian President Vladimir Putin walks to deliver his annual address to the Federal Assembly in Moscow, Russia February 21, 2023. Sputnik/Sergei Karpukhin/Pool via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY.

site_title: Airlines turn market darlings as Covid forces financial clean up
summary: Airlines are experiencing a remarkable turnaround after the COVID-19 pandemic, with many carriers reporting profits for the first time in years. Passenger demand is expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels this quarter, and airlines are capitalizing on a surge in travel. The International Civil Aviation Organization forecasts airlines will generate $4.7 billion in profits in 2023, a significant increase from the $200 billion in losses over the past three years. Airlines are streamlining operations, reducing debt, and increasing efficiency, allowing them to weather periodic demand shocks and invest in growth.

images.alt_text: An airplane prepares to land at Cointrin airport in Geneva, Switzerland December 5, 2017. REUTERS/Pierre Albouy

site_title: Stocks to watch: Wilmar, SIA, CapitaLand Investment, Great Eastern, Nanofilm, Vicom
summary: Wilmar International reported an 8.6% rise in net profit to US$1.2 billion for its second half, with all key business segments and associates experiencing higher profits. Singapore Airlines posted record operating profits for its third quarter, rising 11.4% to S$755 million. CapitaLand Investment established a China data centre fund, adding S$1 billion to its funds under management. Great Eastern's profit slipped 37% due to financial market movements, while Nanofilm Technologies dropped 43.6% due to revenue and expense increases. Vicom's net profit rose 2.4% and a final dividend was proposed.

images.alt_text: SPI Asset Management managing partner Stephen Innes believes that it will take "little more" than improving macroeconomic data for investors to turn bullish on Chinese equities again.

site_title: Oil falls more than 1% as growth fears offset China demand hopes
summary: Oil prices fell more than 1% on Tuesday as concerns about global economic growth outweighed supply curbs, prompting investors to take profits on the previous day's gains. The US Federal Reserve's meeting minutes, due on Wednesday, will focus attention on interest rates. Despite supply cuts by Russia and the partial restart of a US liquefied natural gas export plant, Brent crude settled at $83.05 a barrel, down 1.2% from the previous day.

images.alt_text: China and India have become major buyers of Russian crude amid Western sanctions on Russian oil and more recently, embargoes and price caps because of the Ukraine war.

site_title: Nikkei seen hitting 30,000 by end of 2023 on economic recovery: poll
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 share index is expected to reach 30,000 by the end of 2023, according to a Reuters poll of 15 analysts. This would be a 9% gain from the current level. The forecast is based on a better domestic corporate and global economic outlook, particularly due to China's economic recovery. The median estimate has remained the same as a poll taken three months ago, but the mid-year view is 2,000 points lower. This follows the International Monetary Fund's slight increase in global growth outlook due to resilient US and European demand.

images.alt_text: The opening numbers of the Nikkei 225 are displayed on the first trading day of the new year at the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on January 4, 2023. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

site_title: US green subsidy act ‘very real competitive threat’, says UK’s Hunt
summary: UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt stated the US Inflation Reduction Act, providing $369 billion in subsidies for clean technologies, is a "very real competitive threat" for British businesses. Hunt acknowledged the US is "coming from behind" in its climate efforts, but emphasized the significant financial incentive this presents.

images.alt_text: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt walks outside his house in London, Britain, October 18, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville

site_title: China removes PICC, Bank of China chairmen from party roles
summary: China has removed 61-year-old chairman Liu Liange as party chief of Bank of China and 61-year-old chairman Luo Xi as party chief of PICC, without providing a reason. The moves come as China's ruling party is seen as tightening its grip on the financial sector. The removals follow online criticism of Luo's alleged personality cult and the demand for employees to recite his "golden quotes". The actions have sparked concerns of a renewed clampdown on the sector, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Sources say the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) sent informal instructions earlier this month to some lenders, asking them to issue loans “under an appropriate growth rate”.
Economic activity accelerated in February as residents returned to work after many took an extended Lunar New Year break.

site_title: US grand jury to recommend charges in Trump probe: forewoman
summary: A US grand jury has recommended indictments of multiple people, including former President Donald Trump, for election interference in Georgia in 2020. The forewoman, Emily Kohrs, revealed that the jury's report, most of which remains sealed, includes a "not a short list" of people and crimes. Kohrs stated that over a dozen individuals were in the crosshairs, but did not name targets. This development marks a significant escalation in the investigation and raises potential legal jeopardy for Trump.

images.alt_text: Former South Carolina governor and former US ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley announces her run for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination at a campaign event in Charleston, South Carolina, Feb 15, 2023.

FILE PHOTO: Rupert Murdoch, Executive Chairman of News Corp and 21st Century Fox, takes part as a judge during a global start up showcase at the Wall Street Journal Digital Live (WSJDLive) conference at the Montage hotel in Laguna Beach, California, October 20, 2015. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: McKinsey plans to eliminate about 2,000 jobs in one of its biggest rounds of cuts
summary: McKinsey & Co plans to eliminate approximately 2,000 jobs, its largest round of cuts in history, as part of a restructuring plan dubbed Project Magnolia. The move aims to preserve the compensation pool for partners by centralizing support staff roles. The 45,000-strong workforce is expected to see changes, with the final number of roles to be eliminated still pending. This comes as companies in various industries, including finance and technology, reduce staff amid a slowdown in demand and predictions of a looming recession.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan also cut hundreds of mortgage employees this month.
. The outlook supports the Fed’s view that a so-called “soft landing” for the economy is achievable.

site_title: Signs of populism losing sheen?
summary: Populism's appeal is waning in Western democratic countries as voters become increasingly disenchanted with politicians who promise social stability and economic prosperity but fail to deliver. The shift from a populist wave to a more cynical attitude is attributed to the accelerated democratization process, which has allowed more citizens to participate in elections but also led to the election of unqualified leaders, such as Donald Trump. The article concludes that while the process of democratization has created checks and balances, it has also led to a pendulum swing from respect for public figures to populist hysteria, often exploited by self-serving elites.

images.alt_text: American consumers get a US$7,500 tax credit for purchasing an EV that meets requirements for US-made content; and the federal government will be subsidising new EV-battery production to the tune of US$7 billion.

site_title: Walmart sees lower 2023 performance in time of economic uncertainty
summary: Walmart forecasted lower-than-expected earnings for 2023 due to economic uncertainty, with shares rising 0.4% on the news. The company expects full-year earnings of $5.90-$6.05 per share, below analysts' estimates of $6.50 per share. Tight consumer spending and higher costs for rental housing and food are seen as potential pressures on profit margins. Walmart's CEO, Doug McMillon, noted that consumers are still spending, but the outlook is uncertain, with "stubborn inflation" in certain categories.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 127.00 points, or 0.38 per cent, at the open to 33,699.69.
Amazon has paused expansion of its Fresh supermarkets and cashier-less convenience stores until it finds the right recipe for success, chief executive Andy Jassy said on Thursday.
Nearly all technology employees across the company would be expected to work in their offices for at least two days a week.

site_title: For financial institutions, data management is key
summary: Financial institutions in Asia and globally face significant data challenges, including data silos, manual processes, and security weaknesses, hindering their ability to drive decision-making and improve customer retention and risk transparency. A survey found that 87% of financial services organizations struggle to use data to drive decision-making, with 98% citing data siloes within their organization. Implementing modern data management technologies, such as smart data fabrics, can provide real-time, consistent access to data, delivering better insights and a competitive advantage.

images.alt_text: Donald MacDonald was appointed group data office head in June 2022 – a new role created to drive the bank’s data strategy.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment sets up China data centre development fund
summary: CapitaLand Investment has established a China data centre development fund, CapitaLand China Data Centre Partners, with a total equity commitment of S$530 million. The fund will develop two hyperscale data centre projects in the Greater Beijing area, expected to be completed in 2025 and delivering over 100 megawatts of power. Existing and new global institutional investors hold an 80% stake, with CapitaLand Investment holding 20%. The fund is part of the company's strategy to grow its portfolio of new economy assets and enhance long-term business resilience.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
While CapitaLand Investment navigates choppy waters, there is room for the group to surprise shareholders by distributing units of listed trusts that it owns.
Within Q3 2022, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit announced two acquisitions in Singapore across the industrial and logistics sub-segments, totalling purchase consideration of S$296.7 million.
The two private funds will add over 8.2 billion yuan (S$1.6 billion) to CapitaLand Investment's funds under management when fully deployed, it said.
The group’s half-year earnings per share also fell 66.4 per cent to S$0.084 from S$0.25 previously, despite a 29.1 per cent gain in revenue to S$1.35 billion from S$1.05 billion in H1 2021.

site_title: Amazon Web Services pairs with Hugging Face to target AI developers
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) has partnered with Hugging Face, a software development hub, to make it easier for developers to create AI-based software in AWS's cloud. The collaboration aims to provide tools and services for AI developers, following Microsoft's and Google's generative AI services. AWS already offers proprietary computing chips, such as Trainium, to reduce AI development time and costs. The partnership will enable developers to run Hugging Face's open-source code and models on AWS, with significant engineering resources dedicated to building shared products.

site_title: China buyer picks up duplex penthouse at Klimt Cairnhill for S$27.5 million
summary: A duplex penthouse at Klimt Cairnhill in Singapore has been sold for S$27.5 million, working out to S$4,645 per square foot. The 5,920 sq ft freehold unit features five bedrooms, all en suite, and a double-volume living area. The sale comes as 35 of the project's 138 units have been sold, with buyers including those from China and South-east Asia. The sale was made possible before the increase in buyer's stamp duty rate announced in the Budget on February 14.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

krklimt - Artist's impression of Klimt Cairnhill


Source/Copyright: Low Keng Huat

site_title: Great Eastern H2 profit falls 37% to S$281.3 million
summary: Great Eastern's profit for the second half of 2022 fell 37% to S$281.3 million, due to lower sales in single premium products and negative financial market movements impacting insurance contract liabilities. Gross premiums for H2 fell 21% to S$7.7 billion, while total weighted new sales dropped 9% to S$449.1 million. The insurer attributed the decline to rising interest rates and an inverted yield curve in Singapore, which affected savings product sales. Despite this, the company expects a growing emphasis on the protection market to boost sales in 2023.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Yong Hui Ting
The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 December 2019.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit by rate rise concerns
summary: European shares declined 0.2% on Tuesday due to concerns over higher interest rates, despite strong economic data and a quarterly profit surge from London-listed HSBC. The Stoxx 600 index fell 1.5% in the rate-sensitive technology sector, while euro zone bond yields reached their highest levels in over a decade. Goldman Sachs expects the European Central Bank to raise interest rates three times this year, and investors await the US Federal Reserve's rate decision on Wednesday, which may fuel concerns about sticky inflation.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 2.1 per cent lower – down nearly 700 points – at 33,129.59 on Tuesday.

site_title: Fintech innovation will help drive growth for businesses in Singapore
summary: Singapore's growth prospects are slowing amid inflationary pressures and global economic uncertainty, but fintech innovation may be a bright spot. The 2023 Budget highlighted the need to nurture innovation, and companies must adapt to a constantly shifting landscape. Three key fintech trends to watch include: 1) empowering brands through embedded finance, such as Banking as a Service (BaaS) and embedded payments; 2) betting big on DeFi technology, which can automate, accelerate, and open markets; and 3) solving the complexities of ESG data, which is critical for competitiveness and growth.

images.alt_text: Investors shift away from cryptocurrencies but continue to pour money into blockchain-based solutions like real-time payment settlement pre-validation, streamlining cross-border payments and tokenising assets.
earth, internet, globalization

site_title: Coinbase posts quarterly loss; revenue falls less than forecast
summary: Coinbase, the largest US cryptocurrency exchange, reported a fourth-quarter revenue decline of $629.1 million, less than forecast by analysts. The company experienced a net loss of $557 million and missed trading volume estimates. Despite a 75% rally in shares this year due to a crypto price rally, Coinbase faces mounting uncertainty due to regulatory scrutiny and losing market share to Binance. The company expects first-quarter subscription and services revenue between $300 million and $325 million, citing a "strong foundation" to benefit from regulatory focus in 2023.

images.alt_text: The case against the Wahis was the first to charge insider trading in the cryptocurrency space, according to prosecutors
The suit alleges that Coinbase promoted the sale of the tokens by providing users with descriptions and their purported value.
Customers will have until Feb 16 to withdraw their fiat and crypto holdings, Coinbase said in a blog post on Wednesday (Jan 18).

site_title: EU carbon hits record 100 euros as cost of polluting soars
summary: The European Union's carbon market has hit a record high of 100 euros per tonne, with the benchmark EU Allowance (EUA) contract reaching 100.70 euros per tonne. This increase is driven by rising demand for CO2 permits from fossil fuel power generators and speculators, as well as EU policymakers' efforts to meet climate targets. The price hike is seen as a crucial step towards incentivizing the transition to low-carbon technologies and fuels, with investments in hydrogen production from renewable energy becoming economically competitive above 100 euros per tonne.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smoke billows from the chimneys of Belchatow Power Station, Europe's biggest coal-fired power plant, in this May 7, 2009 file photo. REUTERS/Peter Andrews/File Photo

site_title: US: Wall St slides at open as Walmart, Home Depot forecasts disappoint
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, Feb 21, as retailers Walmart and Home Depot forecasted disappointing earnings, fueling concerns about higher interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 127 points, or 0.38%, to 33,699.69, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped. This marked a return to trading after the long weekend, with investors worried about the impact of higher interest rates on the economy.

site_title: Indonesia president to back central bank chief Warjiyo for rare second term: sources
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo plans to nominate Central Bank governor Perry Warjiyo for a second five-year term, according to sources. Warjiyo has been credited with maintaining a strong economy despite the challenges of COVID-19 and geopolitical turmoil. Widodo will not nominate any other candidates for the post, effectively backing Warjiyo for a second term.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati speaks during a side event on the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors Meeting in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, 14 July 2022. Made Nagi/Pool via REUTERS

FILE PHOTO: Worker loads palm oil fresh fruit bunches to be transported from the collector site to CPO factories in Pekanbaru, Riau province, Indonesia, April 27, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo
Bank Indonesia has held rates for the benchmark seven-day reverse repurchase at 5.75 per cent.

site_title: Thailand to ban plastic waste imports from 2025 to cut pollution
summary: Thailand plans to restrict plastic waste imports and ban scrap shipments starting in 2025, aiming to cut pollution. The country generates 2 million metric tons of plastic waste annually, with only a quarter recycled. From this year, imports will be limited to 14 manufacturers in Thailand's free trade zone, with inflows cut by half next year. This move aims to curb the flow of plastic waste from rich countries to poorer nations, where it often pollutes air and water, and threatens marine life and food systems.

site_title: Online fashion retailer Zalando to cut hundreds of jobs
summary: German online fashion retailer Zalando plans to cut hundreds of jobs due to over-expansion and a challenging economic environment. The company cited a decrease in tailwinds from the pandemic and a more difficult macroeconomic environment since 2022. The job cuts will affect several hundred overhead roles across various teams, excluding frontline operations roles. Zalando's workforce is expected to shrink by up to 5%. The company's shares fell 1.6% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of fashion retailer Zalando is pictured in Berlin, Germany, April 10, 2019. REUTERS/Hannibal Hanschke/File Photo

site_title: More taking up second job, another sign of a tight US job market
summary: The US job market continues to show signs of strength, with nearly 8 million people holding a second job, a 5% share of the employed workforce. This trend is not driven by financial necessity, but rather by the availability of jobs and the desire for flexible working arrangements. Many workers, especially those with higher education, are taking on side hustles to pursue their passions or earn extra income. This trend is not a recessionary signal, and the prevalence of multiple jobholders has remained steady even ahead of past recessions.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on August 17, 2022 A "We Are Hiring" sign is posted in front of a restaurant in Los Angeles, California. - Hiring in the US economy slowed slightly in September, as expected, while the jobless rate ticked back down to the same level as July, the government reported on October 7, 2022. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Sembmarine-Keppel O&M merger D-day draws short sellers into the fray
summary: Sembmarine's stock plummeted 11.5% on Monday, with record short-selling volume of 175.6 million shares, as investors anticipated selling from Keppel shareholders receiving Sembmarine shares in the merger deal. However, the stock recovered on Tuesday, gaining 10.35% to close at S$0.128. Analysts attributed the sell-off to concerns about Keppel shareholders selling Sembmarine shares and short selling from market participants anticipating selling from active investors. The merger deal, which includes Keppel's offshore and marine unit, has also led to Sembmarine's inclusion in the MSCI Singapore Free Index, potentially attracting buying support.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
As at 10.30 am, the index counter shed as much as 4.8 per cent or S$0.37 to trade at S$7.28 after 4.8 million shares changed hands.
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger.
The offshore and marine giant shed as much as 8.4 per cent or S$0.011 to S$0.12 as at 10.41am after 307.4 million securities changed hands.
As at 10.32am, the offshore and marine giant rose as much as 9.5 per cent or S$0.011 to S$0.127.

site_title: US existing home sales fall in January, but pace slowing
summary: US existing home sales plummeted 36.9% in January, reaching a 12-year low of 4.00 million units, the lowest level since October 2010. The decline slowed, with sales falling 0.7% from the previous month. The slowdown in sales pace raises cautious optimism that the housing market slump may be nearing its end, with sales rising in the South and West.

images.alt_text: The rebound in business activity fits in with recent robust data on retail sales, the labour market and manufacturing production, which have suggested solid momentum in the economy at the start of the year.

site_title: Canada annual inflation rate slows to 5.9% in January
summary: Canada's annual inflation rate slowed to 5.9% in January, lower than the expected 6.1% due to a base-year effect. Food and mortgage interest costs continued to rise, with food prices up 10.4% and mortgage interest costs increasing 21.2% annually. The Bank of Canada raised interest rates to 4.50% to combat inflation, forecasting it to slow to 3% by mid-2023 and reach its 2% target next year.

site_title: Nanofilm H2 profit falls 43.6% to S$25m on lower revenue, higher expenses
summary: Nanofilm Technologies reported a 43.6% drop in net profit to S$25 million in the second half of FY2022, primarily due to lower revenue and higher expenses. Revenue fell 16% to S$126.1 million, while administrative expenses rose 27.8% to S$24 million. Despite the decline, the company remains focused on achieving its 2025 targets of S$500 million in revenue and S$100 million in net profit.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
纳峰科技的真空镀膜技术可以用在许多3C产品。（纳峰科技提供)

site_title: UK’s long housing boom helped trigger exodus of older workers
summary: A long housing boom in the UK has led to the early retirement of older workers, exacerbating staff shortages and inflation. Soaring house prices and gold-plated pensions have enabled many Baby Boomers to retire comfortably, with research showing that older, wealthy professionals are disproportionately driving this trend. The average UK home price has increased by 28% since the pandemic, fueling a decade-long property market boom. This has resulted in a deeper labour force participation gap, pushing up wages and inflation across the UK.

site_title: Porsche stuns private debt market with record 2.7 billion euros sale
summary: Porsche Automobil Holding has broken records in the Schuldschein market with a 2.7 billion euro ($3.9 billion) debt sale, marking the largest-ever deal for the German debt. The offering, initially marketed at 500 million euros, attracted 120 investors from Europe, Asia, and the US. The sale signals a growing demand for Schuldschein debt, a niche German instrument, and is the second-largest Schuldschein deal in 2022. This follows Porsche's record-breaking stock offering last year, which was Europe's biggest in a decade.

site_title: Dubai airport sees surge in arrivals, bolstered by Russian influx
summary: Dubai's airport saw a significant surge in arrivals in 2022, with 66 million passengers welcomed, a year-on-year growth of 127%. The main contributor to this growth was Russia, accounting for 1.9 million passengers, more than double the 912,000 recorded in 2021. This surge is attributed to the "huge growth" in Russian travelers, following tensions between Ukraine and Russia. The UAE's neutral stance towards the conflict has made Dubai a top destination for Russian emigres fleeing Western sanctions.

images.alt_text: The closing ceremony of Expo 2020 Dubai in Al Wasl, Dubai, on Mar 31, 2022.  The Expo’s 192 country pavilions drew 24 million visits, despite the coronavirus pandemic that delayed the event by a year.

site_title: Philippine lawmakers ratify entry to world’s largest trade pact
summary: The Philippines has ratified its entry into the world's largest free trade bloc, the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP). The deal, signed in 2020, includes 10 Southeast Asian economies and 6 major countries, accounting for 30% of global GDP. Supporters argue it will boost investment and jobs, while detractors warn it could hurt farmers. The pact's entry is seen as a significant move for the country's economy, with President Ferdinand Marcos' administration and business leaders citing benefits for local consumers, businesses, and the economy.

images.alt_text: Inflation in the Philippines is running at 14-year highs, with January's rate coming in at a faster-than-expected 8.7 per cent.

site_title: Italy faces upward deficit revisions on ‘reckless’ stimulus plan
summary: Italy's government is expected to revise its budget deficit for recent years, potentially bringing it near 10% of last year's gross domestic product, due to the incorporation of the impact of generous tax credits into national accounts. The tax break, known as the "superbonus," was halted by Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's government after Finance Minister Giancarlo Giorgetti called it "reckless." The revisions may undermine confidence in Italy's public finances and prompt investors to reassess the country's debt. The exact impact is unclear, with data from the statistics agency Istat still being evaluated.

images.alt_text: Italy’s national building association ANCE estimates that to meet these goals, some 1.8 million residential buildings will have to be upgraded over the next 10 years at a cost of 400 billion euros (S$572 billion). A further 190 billion euros will be needed to bring business properties to the required standards, it has forecast.

site_title: China central bank asks banks to slow lending in February
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has instructed some banks to slow lending in February to contain risks after new bank loans jumped to a record in January. The instructions, or "window guidance," aim to control the pace of new loans and avoid issuing loans at a too-rapid pace. The move comes as Chinese banks face pressure to accelerate credit support to prop up a slowing economy. The PBOC sent informal instructions earlier this month to some lenders, asking them to issue loans "under an appropriate growth rate."

images.alt_text: The loan rates are based on one of the PBOC’s key interest rates, which was kept unchanged last week amid signs of a recovery in corporate loan demand.
The PBOC urged fund managers to comprehensively and prudently assess the impact of such major money market funds on investors, the broad capital markets and the financial system.
The People’s Bank of China has offered 835 billion yuan (S$162.7 billion) of cash via seven-day reverse repurchase contracts on Friday.

site_title: Chinese provinces give 30 days' paid 'marriage leave' to boost birth rate
summary: Chinese provinces are introducing 30-day paid marriage leave to boost the country's flagging birth rate. This is a more generous allowance than China's current minimum of three days. The move aims to encourage marriage and increase fertility, particularly in economically slow-developing areas. Experts say other supporting policies, such as housing subsidies and paid paternity leave, are also needed to address the issue. China's birth rate has been declining, with a record low of 6.77 births per 1,000 people in 2022, largely due to a one-child policy and rising education costs.

images.alt_text: The population declines seen today in some countries have come about largely as a happy story of greater longevity and freedom.

site_title: Thailand agrees 81.2 billion baht more in borrowing to help energy subsidy fund
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved an additional 81.2 billion baht (S$3.1 billion) in borrowing for the 2023 fiscal year to support subsidies and manage oil prices, aiming to slow inflation that reached a 24-year high last year. The borrowing plan will increase the Oil Fuel Fund Office's debt to 110 billion baht, bringing total new borrowing to 1.13 trillion baht. This move is expected to keep public debt at 61.14% of GDP, within the approved limit of 70%.

site_title: Euro eases, but robust services data stems losses
summary: The euro eased 0.3% against the US dollar, despite robust services data, which rose to its highest in nine months, suggesting the European Central Bank might raise interest rates. Manufacturing activity declined, but the eurozone's overall economic health gauge, the S&P Global Composite PMI, reached its highest in nine months. The euro has lost nearly 2% in February, but is up 1.5% against the Japanese yen. The US dollar index gained nearly 2% in February, putting it on track for its strongest monthly performance since September.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the US dollar against six other major currencies, has slipped 0.1 per cent to 103.91.

site_title: China tech giants tumble amid growing fears of price wars
summary: China's tech giants are revving up efforts to outdo each other amid Beijing's easing of internet crackdowns, sparking a surge in competition that threatens margins and spooks investors. Initiatives include subsidy campaigns, hiring efforts, and expansion into new markets, such as Hong Kong. This renewed competition is expected to depress profit margins, weighing on tech shares, including Alibaba and JD.com. Experts warn that the aggressive campaigns suggest the industry's superiority in logistics isn't enough to thwart competition from newer entrants.

images.alt_text: Most economists recognise that China’s gradual rebalancing to a more consumer-led economy can help to mitigate some of headwinds and challenges it faces.

site_title: Tencent in talks with Meta to sell Quest VR headsets in China
summary: Tencent Holdings is in talks with Meta Platforms to distribute Meta's Meta Quest line of virtual reality (VR) headsets in China, according to three people familiar with the matter. The talks began last year and are at an early stage, with details yet to be agreed upon. This move comes as Tencent has scrapped plans to develop its own XR hardware due to profitability issues. The partnership would mark a significant entry for Meta into China's virtual reality market, where TikTok owner ByteDance's Pico is a main rival.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest video game publisher had previously launched an “extended reality” unit in June last year, for which it hired nearly 300 people.

site_title: Holiday Inn-owner IHG misses revenue estimate; plans another buyback
summary: IHG, the owner of Holiday Inn, reported full-year revenue of US$1.84 billion, missing expectations, due to Covid-19 curbs in China. Operating profit rose 55% to US$828 million, also missing forecasts. The company plans another US$750 million share buyback despite a 1.6% drop in its share price. IHG cited a surge in demand during the Chinese New Year and RevPAR exceeding pre-pandemic levels in the second half of the year as positives. The company proposed a 10% rise in final dividend.

site_title: China property market outlook is improving: HSBC CEO
summary: HSBC Holdings group chief executive Noel Quinn stated that China's commercial property sector is improving, citing positive developments on both demand and supply sides in January. This comes after the bank booked higher-than-expected charges in the fourth quarter linked to its exposure to developers. Quinn attributed the turnaround to significant policy measures, which contrast with the more negative sentiment in the fourth quarter. The positive outlook suggests a recovery in the sector.

images.alt_text: Economic activity accelerated in February as residents returned to work after many took an extended Lunar New Year break.
This photo taken on November 16, 2022 shows residental buildings in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
Some cities have relaxed rules requiring developers to list only finished homes for sale.
The property downturn has slashed government revenue from land sales, which in the past made up about 30 per cent of local authorities’ income.

site_title: China Fudan University team apologises after ChatGPT-style platform crashes hours after launch
summary: A team from China's Fudan University apologized after a ChatGPT-like chatbot platform, MOSS, crashed hours after its launch due to a surge of traffic. The platform, which was initially touted as a Chinese rival to OpenAI's ChatGPT, was shut down after experiencing technical difficulties. The team acknowledged that MOSS was "still a very immature model" and had much to improve, with limited computing resources and insufficient engineering experience. The crash highlights the challenges faced by China's domestic AI industry in competing with international rivals.

images.alt_text: An attendee interacts with the AI-powered Microsoft Bing search engine and Edge browser at the company's headquarters in Redmond, Washington, Feb 7, 2023.
Microsoft-backed OpenAI’s hit chatbot ChatGPT has become the fastest-growing consumer application in history and is rapidly raising awareness in China about how advanced US AI is.
ChatGPT supports Chinese language interaction and is highly capable of conversing in Chinese, which has helped drive its unofficial adoption in the country.

site_title: Tears and photos as Japan sends giant panda 'home' to China
summary: A giant panda, Xiang Xiang, born at Tokyo's Ueno Zoo, departed for China, marking the end of a six-year stay in Japan. Originally set to return in December 2020, the move was delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic. Xiang Xiang, the zoo's first naturally-conceived panda, was a popular attraction, and her departure was met with tears and farewell waves from fans. The panda is being returned to China under an agreement where China maintains ownership of loaned bears and their offspring.

images.alt_text: Born in the wild of mainland China’s Sichuan province, An An was 1 of a panda pair gifted to Hong Kong by Beijing to celebrate the second anniversary of the city’s handover from Britain in 1999.

site_title: Clar manager appoints investment banking veteran Choo Oi Yee as independent director
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit appointed Choo Oi Yee, a 49-year-old investment banking veteran, as a non-executive independent director. Choo previously served as CEO and director of digital securities exchange ADDX since January 2020. She will also join the Investment Committee. The board expressed confidence in her ability to contribute to the Reit's deliberations. Choo's appointment follows the Reit manager's statement that she brings "qualifications and experience" to the role.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Choo Oi Yee, chief executive of ADDX.

site_title: Full-house turnout at BT Property Outlook Seminar
summary: The BT Property Outlook 2023 seminar, held on February 18, drew about 130 readers and subscribers, with BT subscribers receiving a discounted price of S$15 per head. The event featured a panel discussion on "Opportunities Amidst Volatility" with experts from PropNex, Edmund Tie & Company, and NUS Business School. The discussion covered topics such as residential property prices and new launch prices. The seminar was part of BT's efforts to engage its readers and provide value to loyal subscribers, with attendees praising the event and expressing interest in signing up for a BT subscription.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

The panel at BT's Property Outlook 2023 (left to right): PropNex Realty chief executive Ismail Gafoor; Qian Wenlan, professor of finance and real estate, and Ng Teng Fong chair professor in real estate at NUS Business School; Edmund Tie chief executive Desmond Sim; BT senior property correspondent Leslie Yee.
The Property Insights newsletter will be produced by deputy news editor Michelle Low and senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
Learn now to look for opportunities in the Singapore property market from BT's upcoming seminar.

site_title: Credit Suisse chairman's comments draw scrutiny from financial watchdog: sources
summary: Swiss financial regulator Finma is reviewing whether Credit Suisse chairman Axel Lehmann's statements about the bank's outflows were misleading. Lehmann stated that outflows had stabilized in early December, but the regulator is seeking to establish if he was aware that clients were still withdrawing funds at the time. This scrutiny adds to Credit Suisse's challenges, which have been rocked by scandals in recent years, and comes after the bank reported significant outflows in its annual results report.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse has agreed to compensate Georgian billionaire Bidzina Ivanishvili for failing to “police the perimeter” of his wealth from theft.
Credit Suisse is grappling with a string of senior banker departures as it undertakes a sweeping overhaul of its business to restore profitability after scandals and missteps.

site_title: Sri Lanka election commission lacks funds to hold polls
summary: Sri Lanka's election commission lacks funds to hold local council elections scheduled for March 9. The commission has instructed lawyers to inform the Supreme Court about the financial constraints, citing a lack of funds and required support from agencies. The move comes amid opposition protests and petitions against alleged attempts to block the polls. Sri Lanka is facing a severe economic crisis and is seeking a $2.9 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund. The court's decision is expected to be announced soon.

images.alt_text: An activist of Sri Lanka's main opposition and Samagi Jana Balawegaya party throws back a stones towards police during a protest held to urge the government to hold local council election as scheduled in Colombo on February 20, 2023. (Photo by ISHARA S. KODIKARA / AFP)

site_title: Wilmar posts 8.6% rise in H2 earnings; plans to pay record dividend
summary: Wilmar International posted an 8.6% rise in net profit to $1.2 billion for its second half of 2022, driven by higher profits from all key business segments and lower tax rates. The company proposed a record dividend of $0.11 per share for the period, totaling $0.17 for the full year. Revenue rose 2.8% to $37.3 billion, with the feed and industrial products segments contributing to the growth. Wilmar chairman Kuok Khoon Hong expects FY2023 to be challenging, citing pressure on plantation profits and palm processing margins, but sees a positive sign in China's reversal of its zero-Covid policy.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Adani Wilmar says its edible oil business, its largest, has climbed nearly 4 per cent on an uptick in festive and wedding demand.
Wilmar’s chief financial officer Charles Loo said sustainable financing remains part of its holistic approach to integrate sustainability principles into every aspect of the business operations.

site_title: Quarz urges Sabana Reit not to ‘waste money’ on IFA for Volare partial offer
summary: ACTIVIST investor Quarz Capital urged Sabana Industrial Reit's management and board not to hire an independent financial adviser to evaluate Volare Group's partial offer to acquire an additional 10% of Sabana Reit units at S$0.465 per unit, which is over 50% above a previous recommended offer. Quarz questioned the need for an IFA, citing a previous merger offer that was deemed "value destructive" and spent 15% of half-yearly distribution per unit. The offer is near the highest price Sabana Reit units had traded at in the last five years.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Volare says it is launching the partial offer to diversify its business away from fossil fuels and build up its real estate portfolio.
Sabana Industrial Reit's NTP+ at 151 Lorong Chuan. The Reit portfolio valuation for its 18 properties is up by 2.3 per cent on-year to S$885.7 million as at end-2022.
The partial offer for Sabana Reit is not particularly compelling, but could have implications for its future direction.

site_title: Qualcomm announces software business around its supply chain chips
summary: Qualcomm announced a paid cloud software service called Qualcomm Aware, allowing customers to program and update chips used in supply chain tracking devices from a central spot. The service, launched on February 21, 2023, will help companies track goods and materials through supply chains, leveraging Qualcomm's wireless communication expertise. The software aims to simplify the process of updating and managing chips used in tracking devices, such as shipping containers and pallets.

site_title: Vicom’s H2 earnings up 2.4% to S$13.1 million on higher revenue
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection company, reported a 2.4% increase in net profit to S$13.1 million for the second half of 2022, driven by higher revenue of 6.3% to S$55 million. The company's vehicle testing business saw a record 534,840 periodic inspections in FY2022, while demand for non-vehicle testing services improved post-Covid restrictions. Vicom's full-year earnings rose 5.7% to S$26.2 million, with a proposed final dividend of S$0.0332 per share for FY2022.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

Vicom said its vehicle inspection business has largely been stable, except for lower demand for new car registrations and emission testing services as a result of low Certificates of Entitlement quotas and the worldwide shortage of microchips affecting vehicle productions.
Vicom's wholly-owned subsidiary, Setsco Services, will undertake the development of the plot.

site_title: UK companies unexpectedly show first growth in six months
summary: British companies reported their first growth in six months, driven by rising customer demand and increased confidence among business executives. The S&P Global survey showed a "sustained increase" in prices and a composite reading of private sector output rose to 53, beating economists' expectations. This reduces the risk of a recession early this year and increases the likelihood of the Bank of England raising interest rates further to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The ONS reported self-assessment income tax receipts of £21.9 billion, the highest January figure since monthly records began and £5.5 billion more than last year.

site_title: JPMorgan cuts about 30 investment banking jobs in Asia-Pacific
summary: JPMorgan Chase is cutting about 30 investment banking jobs in Asia-Pacific, primarily in Hong Kong and China, due to declining deal flows in the region. The move, which affects mostly junior-level bankers, is part of the bank's efforts to reduce costs globally. This is not the first job cut for JPMorgan in the region, following hundreds of mortgage employee layoffs earlier this month. The cuts come as investment banks seek to adapt to a sluggish market, with Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley also reducing staff in the region.

site_title: China leaders pledge stronger growth as recovery takes hold
summary: China's top leaders have pledged to boost the economy and meet social development goals this year, amid a recovering economy. President Xi Jinping reiterated plans to expand the economy and improve quality of growth, with economists predicting GDP growth to rebound to above 5% this year. Economic activity accelerated in February as residents returned to work after the Lunar New Year break, but sales of big-ticket items continue to decline, reducing demand for commodities. The recovery is seen as lopsided, with the biggest hurdle being the property slump.

images.alt_text: The two regulators say implementation of the new rules will leave capital adequacy ratios in the banking sector generally unchanged, though the ratios for some banks would change slightly.

site_title: Global firms are eyeing Asian alternatives to Chinese manufacturing
summary: Global companies are shifting away from China's manufacturing hubs due to rising labor costs and geopolitical tensions. Instead, they're exploring alternative Asian suppliers, known as "Altasia," which comprises countries like Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, and India. Altasia offers a diverse range of strengths, including low wages, skilled labor, and access to advanced technology. The region has already made significant strides in electronics manufacturing, with countries like Malaysia and Vietnam emerging as major chip exporters. However, integrating Altasia's supply chain faces challenges, including infrastructure gaps and regulatory hurdles, which may slow its growth as a rival to China.

images.alt_text: The US chip giant already has extra land where its plant is based, and an expansion in Vietnam would help it better manage supply disruptions.
Migrant workers’ reluctance to return to the big factory hubs that account for about a third of the world’s manufacturing output is exacerbating long-term structural problems in China’s labour market

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's PayNow service is now linked to India's Unified Payments Interface (UPI), enabling real-time payments between the two countries. This collaboration allows individuals in Singapore and India to send instant payments to each other. The service is available for customers from DBS and fintech firm Liquid Group. This integration aims to enhance cross-border financial transactions and provide a seamless payment experience for users.

site_title: China’s Nio to build factory for budget EVs: sources
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, plans to build a factory in Chuzhou city to produce budget EVs under new brand names "Alps" and "Firefly". The factory will cater to the growing demand for affordable EVs in China, where over a quarter of new cars sold in January were either pure electric or plug-in hybrids. This move aims to increase Nio's market share and compete with premium brands such as BMW, Audi, and Mercedes-Benz in China and Europe.

images.alt_text: Battery swapping allows drivers to replace depleted packs quickly with fully charged ones, rather than plugging the vehicle into a charging point.

site_title: Cryptoverse: Tether tightens grip on wobbling world of stablecoins
summary: Tether, a US-based stablecoin issuer, now commands 52.6% of the stablecoin market, amid a shift in the US$137 billion market. Paxos Trust Company, which issues Binance's BUSD stablecoin, will cease issuing new tokens after US regulators labeled the asset an unregistered security. This move has left investors questioning the future of the stablecoin market, which is typically backed by traditional assets like US dollars and US Treasuries. The seismic shift may lead to changes in the market's structure and stability.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins are intended to hold a set value, for example US$1, and come in a variety of forms.

site_title: Investors track key political events in China for word on GDP growth target and national security policy
summary: Chinese investors closely monitor the country's major annual political meetings, known as the "two sessions", for pro-growth policies and GDP growth targets. President Xi Jinping's consolidation of power in October 2022 will be reviewed during the meetings, which are expected to reaffirm the government's focus on boosting confidence and addressing income inequality. Economists predict Beijing will set a 2023 GDP target above 5% and allocate a record-high quota for local government special bonds. A reshuffling of top government officials is also expected, with Li Qiang likely to succeed Li Keqiang as premier and Zhu Hexin a frontrunner to succeed Yi Gang as governor of the People's Bank of China.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: SIA Q3 posts record operating profit on robust demand for air travel
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) posted record operating profits for its third quarter, rising 11.4% to S$755 million, driven by robust demand for air travel. The airline's passenger capacity reached 80% of pre-Covid levels in December 2022, and revenue gained 8% to S$4.8 billion. Net profit for the nine months ended December 2022 more than doubled to S$1.6 billion, reversing a net loss from the same period in 2021. SIA expects demand for air travel to remain robust in the fourth quarter, but faces headwinds from air freight due to macroeconomic concerns.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

The E190-E2 is the latest variant of Embraer’s line of regional jets, and has the capacity to seat 112 passengers in a single-class configuration. Scoot will deploy the aircraft on short-and medium-haul flights of up to five hours
In January, SIA said it continued to see strong passenger traffic and load factors across all route regions including East Asia.

site_title: Asia central banks may need to keep hiking rates if core inflation stays high: IMF
summary: Asia-Pacific central banks may need to continue raising interest rates if core inflation remains above target, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Despite a slowdown in headline inflation, core inflation still exceeds target, and policymakers must stay alert, especially considering China's potential reopening and its impact on prices. The IMF advises central banks to remain hawkish, monitoring second-round effects and the potential for price gains.

images.alt_text: Rates have climbed 325 basis points since last May, easily the most aggressive tightening in modern history.
The loan rates are based on one of the PBOC’s key interest rates, which was kept unchanged last week amid signs of a recovery in corporate loan demand.
The PBOC urged fund managers to comprehensively and prudently assess the impact of such major money market funds on investors, the broad capital markets and the financial system.

site_title: Of trapped ships and brave seafarers in the Ukraine war zone
summary: The war in Ukraine has resulted in 331 seafarers being trapped on 62 vessels in nine ports, including Odessa and Mariupol, with some ships remaining in Ukrainian-held ports due to the ongoing conflict. International shipping organizations, including the International Chamber of Shipping, have called for the safe evacuation of the seafarers, citing the need for their lives to be prioritized. Despite efforts to facilitate grain shipments, the seafarers remain stranded, with some ships deteriorating over time. Shipping organizations have urged the United Nations to take immediate action to evacuate the seafarers and their ships, highlighting the need for a concerted international effort to resolve the crisis.

images.alt_text: Sinopec, as well as PetroChina and Cnooc have started and will continue to ramp up their procurement of Russian grades in the coming months

Under EU guidelines, India is likely operating within the rules. When Russian crude is processed into fuels in a country outside of the bloc such as India, the refined products can be delivered into the EU because they’re not deemed to be of Russian origin.
Ukrainian troops in a tank in the Bakhmut district of eastern Ukraine. The West has committed to sending advanced battle tanks to help Ukraine against Russia.

site_title: Putin accuses West of stoking global war to destroy Russia
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin vowed to continue Russia's year-long war in Ukraine, accusing the US-led Nato alliance of fanning the flames of the conflict. Putin stated that a majority of Russians supported the war and that Russia would never yield to Western attempts to divide its society. He claimed that Western-backed Ukraine had been planning to attack Russian-controlled Crimea, prompting Russia's actions. Putin emphasized Russia's resolve to "carefully and consistently resolve the tasks facing us."

images.alt_text: The central bank projects growth may resume this year.

site_title: Japan’s key yield rises above BOJ cap on policy tweak bets
summary: Japan's benchmark yield briefly rose above the Bank of Japan's 0.5% cap for the first time since January, driven by speculation of a potential policy tweak. The 10-year yield climbed to 0.505% before erasing its advance. Investors are awaiting confirmation hearings for Kazuo Ueda, the BOJ's nominee for governor, who may hint at a future removal of the negative-rate policy. The BOJ's yield-curve control program is seen as unsustainable, leading to increased bets on further policy changes.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, a former member of the BOJ's policy board, is seen in this photo in Tokyo, taken by Kyodo July 2, 2008. Kyodo via REUTERS ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. JAPAN OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN JAPAN

site_title: Philips management will not receive bonuses for 2022
summary: Dutch health technology company Philips' top management will not receive bonuses for 2022 due to the company's poor performance, including a 70% plunge in market value following a global recall of respiratory devices. The current management board waived the annual incentive payouts, citing a "very disappointing year" for the company and its stakeholders. Former CEO Frans van Houten will still receive his short-term bonus of €208,370. Philips is in negotiations with the US Department of Justice over a settlement related to the recall.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Philips Healthcare headquarters is seen in Best, Netherlands August 30, 2018. Picture taken August 30, 2018. REUTERS/Piroschka van de Wouw/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts positive on Aztech Global outlook despite FY2022 forex hit
summary: Brokerages Maybank Securities and DBS Group Research have raised their target prices on Aztech Global, citing a stronger outlook for the tech solutions provider despite its FY2022 results missing expectations. Maybank upgraded its call to "buy" and increased its target price to S$1.02, while DBS lifted its target price to S$1.15. Analysts expect revenue growth in the near term and a strong order book, driving a likely strong earnings rebound in FY2023.

images.alt_text: Aztech Global's net profit in H2 2022 fell 45.9 per cent to S$24.3 million on foreign exchange loss, said the group on Friday.

site_title: Eurozone business growth at 9-month high, backed by services: flash PMI
summary: The eurozone business growth reached a 9-month high in February, driven by a surge in services sector activity, according to S&P Global's flash composite purchasing managers' index. The index rose to 52.3, beating forecasts and expectations, indicating a faster-than-expected expansion. The services sector PMI also rose to 53, its fastest pace since June 2022, while factory activity declined at a slightly sharper pace. The news suggests that recession fears are fading, and optimism about the year ahead improved, with business expectations index reaching a 9-month high.

images.alt_text: Assembly line worker at automotive factory in China's eastern Shandong province. Economic reopening alone in China is unlikely to lift the country to a significantly higher growth trajectory. For that to happen, the free fall in the property sector has to be arrested.
FILE PHOTO: A worker transports packaged pasta at De Cecco's factory in Fara San Martino, Italy, November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Remo Casilli/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks flat amid regional declines; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,306.86 points on Tuesday, trading flat amid regional declines. Investors remain cautious due to China's recovery and underperformance of Chinese equities. SPI Asset Management's Stephen Innes believes it will take improving macroeconomic data for investors to turn bullish on Chinese equities again. The top performer was Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, while Keppel DC Reit and the trio of banks (DBS, OCBC, UOB) declined.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The group attributed the improved profits to higher contributions from its renewables and conventional energy segments.

site_title: North London property prices jump as buyers return to capital
summary: London's north, particularly Camden, has seen a surge in property prices as young professionals return to the capital, with asking prices rising 17.2% year-over-year and 6% in the past month. This trend hints at a burgeoning strength in the UK's housing market, where soaring mortgage rates have strained affordability. Despite concerns of a potential crash, property search website Rightmove expects a "transition towards a more normal level of activity" in the market, driven by first-time buyers and the increasing cost-effectiveness of buying over renting.

images.alt_text: It’s true that super-prime property in London proved resilient and bounced back faster than expected. But those who bought at the peak may have overpaid.
London saw the weakest annual price rise of all English regions with prices in the capital up 6.7 per cent, the ONS said.
The exodus of tenants marks a reversal of 2021 when more homeowners fled London than renters for the first time in a decade.

site_title: Pay hikes for 5,000 drivers, 32,000 admin staff under new progressive wage move
summary: Singapore's Occupational Progressive Wages (OPW) scheme has introduced pay hikes for 5,000 drivers and 32,000 admin staff, covering 56,000 full-time lower-wage workers. The wage requirements range from S$1,500 for administrative assistants to S$2,000 for administrative executives, and S$1,750 for general drivers to S$1,850 for specialized drivers. The wage increases take effect on March 1, with a six-month "run-in" period for employers to adjust and comply.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The PWCS provides transitional support for employers from 2022 to 2026, and encourages employers to voluntarily raise the wages of their lower-wage employees.
The newly-launched Progressive Wage Mark scheme aims to encourage consumers to support lower-wage workers by purchasing from accredited firms.
Workers at quick-service establishments, including food courts, will see minimum wages set at S$1,750 from Mar 1 this year.

site_title: Warburg Pincus raising 3 billion yuan in maiden yuan fund for China deals: sources
summary: Warburg Pincus, a US private equity firm, is raising 3 billion yuan in its maiden yuan-denominated fund, primarily focusing on the healthcare and industrial technology sectors in China. This move comes as US investors have become more cautious about deploying fresh capital in China due to regulatory crackdowns, Covid-19 lockdowns, and Sino-US tensions. The fund will be used to invest in and exit local portfolios, providing a relatively independent and self-sustainable investment opportunity.

site_title: Assessing a mixed bag of macro challenges
summary: Global investors are shifting focus from inflation and interest rates to the depth of the global slowdown and when policymakers will offer support. The US risk of recession in 2023 remains elevated, with a potential 4% contraction, while Europe faces a higher likelihood of stagflation due to energy imports and economic growth. China's economic reopening, despite its impact, is unlikely to significantly boost growth without arresting the free fall in the property sector. Policymakers may offer rate cuts by the end of 2023 to pivot towards a more neutral posture, but structural headwinds, including debt-driven investment, pose long-term challenges to growth.
