images.alt_text: The European Central Bank remains wary of underlying price pressures and is continuing to raise interest rates.
Most economists recognise that China’s gradual rebalancing to a more consumer-led economy can help to mitigate some of headwinds and challenges it faces.

site_title: NBA, Ant Group launch strategic partnership in China
summary: The NBA and Chinese fintech giant Ant Group announced a strategic partnership in China, focusing on video content, program broadcasting, and membership. Fans in China will have access to NBA video content on Alipay, and the collaboration will also cover joint marketing campaigns and digital collectibles. This partnership comes after a 2019 rift between the NBA and China's state broadcaster CCTV due to a tweet by Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey supporting Hong Kong protests. Despite this, basketball fans in China have shown a strong interest in watching NBA games, with viewership levels close to pre-2019 levels.

images.alt_text: Ant Group has been focusing on its business rectification and optimisation.
This comes as Ant adjusts its voting rights structure.

site_title: HSBC eyes special payout after profit jumps, bonus pool cut
summary: HSBC reported a 92% increase in adjusted pretax profit to $6.83 billion in the fourth quarter, beating analyst estimates. The bank plans to consider a special payout of $0.21 per share after the sale of its Canadian unit, which is expected to close later this year. HSBC also announced it will resume paying quarterly dividends from the first quarter and bring forward its consideration of buybacks. The bank's shares rose 0.4% in Hong Kong trading, driven by the improved profit results and plans to increase shareholder returns.

images.alt_text: As a slowing economy and crackdowns on industries from technology to real estate roil the world’s second-largest economy, HSBC is looking further afield to India — despite risks there as well.

A crane operates on construction of a new residential apartment building near to a row of terraced residential housing in London, U.K., on Thursday, Nov. 16, 2017. London's housing market is being battered from all sides. A survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors showed a price gauge at its lowest level for seven years, and far below the national average. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Thai election to be held in May: PM
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha announced that a general election will be held in May, following the dissolution of parliament in March. This move comes as the economy struggles and the tourism sector is hit hard by the pandemic, with Prayut's popularity at an all-time low. The election will be the first since 2020's mass youth-led protests, with calls for political reform and changes to the monarchy. The main opposition party Pheu Thai is polling well and is expected to nominate Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, as a candidate for premiership.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on August 17, 2022, Thailand's Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha addresses an award function in Bangkok. - Thailand's Constitutional Court ruled on September 30 that suspended prime minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha can resume office. (Photo by Manan VATSYAYANA / AFP)

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS downgrades Genting Singapore to ‘hold’ on limited upside
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Genting Singapore to "hold" from "buy" due to limited upside and potential compression on the integrated resort operator's valuation multiples. The research team believes it's time to take profit following the stock's "stellar run" and notes that earnings recovery has been largely baked into the share price. The target price is now S$1.05, implying only a 5% upside from the last trading price. Genting's earnings recovery is expected to take time, and the stock is trading above pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Net profit for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, rose to S$255.7 million from S$95.1 million in the same period a year prior.
Construction of the new facilities has been pushed back more than once by Marina Bay Sands due to the onset of the pandemic.
Analysts are expecting Genting Singapore to be a key beneficiary of an influx of tourists following China’s reopening.

site_title: Trade-off puzzle: diversity, risk and returns
summary: A study by CFA Singapore found no trade-off between diversity and investment performance, contradicting a common assumption. Based on 56 studies and 50 years of data, the research indicates that diversity is associated with performance comparable to the mean, and there's no indication that women take more risk than men. The review also found that studies examining racial and ethnic diversity yielded mixed results.

images.alt_text: While DEI disclosure is nascent in Singapore, the US Securities and Exchange Commission in 2020 required companies to disclose enhanced human capital management details.

site_title: Sri Lanka to make US$2.6 billion in loan repayments in first half of year
summary: Sri Lanka's cabinet has approved loan repayments worth US$2.6 billion in the first half of 2023, in line with its debt suspension plans. The repayments include US$2 billion in foreign loan repayments, US$540 million in interest payments, and US$709 million in US dollar-denominated bonds. Sri Lanka is in talks with the IMF for a US$2.9 billion bailout, and has received support from India and Paris Club members, but is still negotiating with China. The repayments will be made within the borrowing limits set in the 2023 budget, as the country works to put its debt on a sustainable path.

images.alt_text: While Sri Lanka president Ranil Wickremesinghe has been credited with bringing about some normalcy to the country, he has been criticised for aligning with the Rajapaksas, and clamping down on protests.

site_title: South Korea’s ‘jeonse’ rent-free renters hit by property downturn
summary: South Korea's rent-free "jeonse" rental system, popular among 20-30 year olds, is facing a downturn due to a decline in home prices. Median house prices have fallen 12% and jeonse prices 7% over two years, leading to landlords failing to return deposits, causing financial difficulties for tenants. Financial authorities are working to support affected tenants and landlords, while police are cracking down on jeonse-related crimes. The crisis poses limited macroeconomic risks but could exacerbate risks for the property market, prompting predictions of interest rate cuts to engineer a soft landing.

images.alt_text: In January, the BOK raised its policy interest rate by 25 basis points to 3.50 per cent, the highest since late 2008.
Exports began to fall late last year as the world economy deteriorated, making global trade one of the biggest risks for South Korea’s outlook.

site_title: Exploring South Africa’s Black wine scene
summary: South Africa's wine industry is shifting towards greater diversity, with Black winemakers and owners gaining prominence. Carmen Stevens is believed to be the first Black person to fully own a wine production facility in the country. Meanwhile, Fiona Masuku is exploring the Black wine scene at Great Heart Wines in Franschhoek. The industry, currently dominated by White South Africans, is opening up to support Black winemakers and owners, offering a fresh perspective on the country's wine culture.

images.alt_text: NFTs offer a way to revolutionise how wine is bought and enjoyed.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate with rates set to go higher
summary: Asia markets fluctuated on February 21, with Hong Kong and Tokyo declining while Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Jakarta, and Bangkok edged up. Traders await the release of Federal Reserve minutes, which may signal higher interest rate hikes than previously expected. Several Fed officials have warned that borrowing costs will need to increase for longer to control inflation, which has been above the Fed's target. The market's uncertainty reflects the ongoing economic uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore stocks open muted on Tuesday; STI down 0.04%
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.04% to 3,307.59. Gainers outnumbered losers 66 to 46, led by Sembcorp Marine's 5.2% gain. Singtel, Thomson Medical, and local banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS also saw notable trading. The STI fell despite European market gains, with US markets closed due to the Presidents' Day holiday.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore Exchange, losers beat gainers 302 to 239 after 1.7 billion shares worth S$847.7 million changed hands.

site_title: Qantas spends A$100 million on new lounges in Hong Kong, Heathrow
summary: Qantas invests A$100 million in new lounges at Hong Kong, Heathrow, and other airports, signaling strong demand for premium travel as aviation recovers. The investment includes a new flagship first-class lounge at Heathrow, set to open in 2025, and refurbished lounges in Melbourne, Sydney, and Auckland. The airline is also planning nonstop flights from Sydney to London and New York, the world's longest direct commercial services. CEO Alan Joyce said the return to profit allows for long-term investments, citing soaring fares and demand outstripping available seats.

site_title: Budget 2023 – Dealing with climate realities
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 aims to deepen its sustainable financing capabilities by fostering an enabling environment for sustainable finance. The government plans to increase climate spending and introduce a S$5 billion Coastal and Flood Protection Fund. To support this, measures such as refinements to capital risk charges, development of credible transition finance frameworks, and tax incentives and grants for ESG businesses will be implemented. The government will also encourage early-stage investments in climate tech solutions and support the development of capabilities across sectors. This move aims to position Singapore as a regional hub for sustainable finance and carbon solutions.

images.alt_text: The plans announced in Budget 2023 will chart paths to create resilience for Singapore's continued prosperity in a changing world.
Encouraging climate tech breakthroughs will not only facilitate Singapore’s green ambition, it will also position Singapore as a sustainability innovation hub, said professional services firm PwC.

site_title: UK government runs unexpected budget surplus in January: ONS
summary: The UK government reported a £5.42 billion budget surplus in January, exceeding economists' expectations, due to strong income tax receipts. This surplus could provide Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt with more flexibility in his upcoming budget. However, the Office for Budget Responsibility is expected to downgrade its economic growth rate estimates, limiting the scope for tax cuts or spending increases. The government spent over £10 billion on energy support and £2.3 billion on EU customs duties in January.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: British pound coins are seen in this illustration taken, November 9, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: South Korea’s household credit falls for first time in a decade
summary: South Korea's household credit declined for the first time in nearly a decade in the fourth quarter of 2022, falling 0.2% or 4.1 trillion won to 1,867.0 trillion won. This marks the largest percentage decline since 2009. The quarterly decline is attributed to the central bank's interest rate hikes, totaling 300 basis points since August 2021. The annual growth rate of household credit also slowed to 0.2%, its slowest pace since data collection began in 2002.

site_title: HSBC takes US$300 million hit on Russia business sale, says deal on track for 2023
summary: HSBC reported a US$300 million loss on the expected sale of its Russia business, which is still pending regulatory approval. The sale, initially agreed in July 2022, is expected to be completed in the first half of 2023. The bank's operations in Russia consisted of corporate banking services to domestic and multinational customers, employing around 200 people. Regulatory hurdles, including Russian government approval, have slowed the process, despite many multinational corporations exiting Russia following the invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: HSBC is among banks who have been seeking to increase shareholders returns as rising interest rates propel profits, but its outlook has long been complicated by geopolitical tensions.
As a slowing economy and crackdowns on industries from technology to real estate roil the world’s second-largest economy, HSBC is looking further afield to India — despite risks there as well.

site_title: Former Rakuten, Khazanah and Ninja Van execs join 500 Global as partners
summary: Former executives from Rakuten, Khazanah, and Ninja Van have joined 500 Global as partners to lead growth initiatives in South-east Asia. Saemin Ahn, Shahril Ibrahim, and Martin Cu bring significant investment and operational expertise to the venture firm. 500 Global, which has backed over 340 companies in the region, aims to scale up its capital and expertise to support entrepreneurs. The new partners will support the firm's growth practice, which includes companies like Grab, Bukalapak, and Carsome. Their addition is seen as a boost to the venture firm's ambitions in the region.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine shares rebound on Tuesday after previous day’s decline
summary: Sembcorp Marine shares rebounded 9.5% on Tuesday after a decline the previous day, reaching a high of S$0.127. The stock was the top-traded counter by value and volume, with 264.6 million shares worth S$32.6 million traded. Its share price later eased to 8.6% higher at S$0.126.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence improves to highest in a year
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence has reached its highest level in a year, increasing to -19 in February, according to the European Commission. This rise is attributed to a mild winter and slowing inflation, which may help the region avoid an economic downturn. Despite this, the European Central Bank remains cautious of underlying price pressures and continues to raise interest rates. The improved confidence is seen as a positive sign for the eurozone's resilience, but policymakers will continue to monitor the situation closely.

site_title: FTX unit in Japan becomes first to resume customer withdrawals
summary: FTX Japan KK, a subsidiary of the failed crypto exchange FTX, has announced plans to resume customer withdrawals, becoming the first FTX group business to do so. The move marks a victory for Japan's financial regulator, which has implemented strict rules to protect clients. The resumption of withdrawals, which will start on February 21, may be followed by the US entity, according to FTX co-founder Sam Bankman-Fried's spokesperson. The Japanese exchange had approximately 10 billion yen in net assets and 17.8 billion yen in cash and deposits at the end of September.

site_title: PayNow links up with India’s UPI, enabling real-time payments between Singapore and India
summary: Singapore's PayNow and India's Unified Payments Interface (UPI) have linked, enabling real-time cross-border payments between the two countries. The service, launched by Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and India Prime Minister Narendra Modi, allows customers of participating financial institutions to send and receive funds in real time. The service, initially available for DBS and Liquid Group customers, will be extended to all customers by March 31, with a daily transfer limit of S$1,000. The linkage aims to bring migrant workers and students into the formal banking sector, increasing transparency and reducing informal remittance channels.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
MAS managing director Ravi Menon said central banks must continue to stay resolute in tackling high inflation and restoring price stability.
Singapore, India to link real-time payment systems PayNow and UPI by 2022
Singapore, Thailand link real-time payment rails for faster, cheaper cross-border transfers

site_title: When investing in stocks, prepare, don’t predict
summary: Investors often extrapolate current trends into the future, leading to inaccurate predictions. Economic slowdowns are predicted, but recessions are notoriously difficult to forecast. Instead of focusing on the future, investors should build a robust portfolio by investing in blue-chip businesses, brand names, and companies with consistent dividend increases. Maintaining an opportunity fund and being mentally prepared to adjust investments based on new information can also help navigate uncertainty. The stock market's ability to discount future expectations into current prices can be a useful guide, and forward thinking may not be as crucial as previously thought.

images.alt_text: blur, chart, computer

site_title: Gold edges higher as dollar eases ahead of Fed minutes, data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,843.23 per ounce, as the dollar eased off a six-week high, making gold cheaper for buyers holding other currencies. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates above 5% by May, increasing the opportunity cost of holding zero-yield bullion. Investors await the release of Fed minutes and US core personal consumption expenditure data, which could impact the gold market.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a hedge against soaring inflation, but high interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: EV maker Nio to build 1,000 battery-swap stations in China in 2023
summary: Chinese electric vehicle startup Nio plans to build 1,000 battery-swapping stations in China by the end of 2023, bringing the total to 2,300. The stations will focus on highways and urban areas, particularly in third- and fourth-tier cities. Nio aims to improve user experience and mitigate power grid strains. This move is part of the company's expansion of battery swapping, a power solution for electric cars, as Tesla has previously dismissed it. Nio's plan marks a significant step in the adoption of battery swapping technology in China.

site_title: G20 host India taps soft power as it champions new world order
summary: India, as the host of the G20, is using its influence to champion issues important to developing economies in Asia, Africa, and Latin America, such as debt relief. The country is seeking to leverage its growing strategic and economic heft, and its self-nomination as the leader of the Global South is a culmination of its messaging on the global stage. India is pushing for reforms in multilateral institutions, assistance for low and middle-income countries on debt vulnerability, and climate initiatives. The country's efforts have garnered allies, including Indonesia, and have received support from the US, which is warming towards New Delhi's call for the need to revamp multilateral institutions.

site_title: More funding flowed to earlier-stage companies in 2022: January Capital report
summary: Venture capital funding in South-east Asia declined by US$4.8 billion in 2022, with total investment amounting to US$10.4 billion, a decrease from US$15.2 billion in 2021. Funding shifted to earlier stages, with seed, Series A, and B rounds receiving US$5.4 billion, while Series C received US$5 billion. Average deal sizes and pre-money valuations rose across all stages, but investors became more cautious in the second half of 2022, with reduced follow-on investment and smaller deal sizes.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

Investors shift away from cryptocurrencies but continue to pour money into blockchain-based solutions like real-time payment settlement pre-validation, streamlining cross-border payments and tokenising assets.

site_title: Sustainable investing and the rabbit
summary: A financial expert draws parallels between a rabbit's unique features, such as its 360-degree vision and ability to rotate its ears, and the benefits of sustainable investing through Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) factors. ESG can help portfolios mitigate risks and identify opportunities, much like a rabbit's keen senses. The author highlights the importance of considering sustainability trends, such as the transition to a net-zero world, and the potential for ESG factors to generate alpha in emerging markets like China.

images.alt_text: Environmental activists stage a protest to commemorate the 2019 collapse of Vale's mining-waste dam in the Brazilian town of Brumadinho. The Church of England Pensions Board exited its entire vale stake after the collapse, which killed 270 people, and spearheaded a campaign to improve mine safety.
Generics on sustainability and ESG and climate resilience

site_title: Hong Kong plans to let retail sector trade larger crypto tokens like Bitcoin
summary: Hong Kong has outlined a plan to allow retail investors to trade larger crypto tokens like Bitcoin and Ether, part of a broader effort to restore the city's credentials as a financial center. The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) will license exchanges to provide safeguards, and the consultation period ends on March 31. The goal is to allow retail trading in the new regime by June 1, with Bitcoin and Ether likely to be listed. The move contrasts with a crackdown in the US and aims to attract digital asset executives and investors, potentially opening a conduit to mainland Chinese investment.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s real estate market is one of the world’s most expensive, and housing has been a perennial issue for the city’s leaders.
The comments come before Chan delivers a budget presentation on Wednesday as part of efforts to chart a course for a rebound.

site_title: India invokes emergency law to force coal-based power plants to up output
summary: India has invoked an emergency law to force power plants that run on imported coal to increase output by 8% in the financial year ending March 2024, amid expected record surge in power usage this summer. The directive, effective March 16, aims to maximize coal power output from plants with a total capacity of 17 gigawatts, including those owned by Adani Power and Tata Power in Gujarat. The move comes ahead of a peak demand of 229 gigawatts in April and aims to address the expected surge in power consumption.

images.alt_text: India’s headline inflation remained above the central bank’s target ceiling of 6 per cent for most part of last year due to high food prices, which comprise about half of the inflation basket.
The Reserve Bank of India is seen increasing interest rates again in its April review amid inflation topping estimates and further tightening by global central banks.

site_title: South Korea’s early trade data shows export slump persisting
summary: South Korea's early trade data shows a decline in exports persisting this month, with average daily shipments dropping 14.9% in the first 20 days of February compared to the same period last year. This follows an 8.8% decline in January and a 43.9% drop in chip sales. Shipments to China also decreased 22.7%, with the decline barely improving from January despite favorable seasonal factors. The data fuels concerns about the economic outlook ahead of the central bank's decision this week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Trucks used to transport containers are seen at the Hanjin Shipping container terminal at the Busan New Port in Busan, about 420 km (261 miles) southeast of Seoul, August 8, 2013. Picture taken August 8, 2013. REUTERS/Lee Jae-Won (SOUTH KOREA - Tags: BUSINESS MARITIME)/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong’s budget dilemma is how to revive city and cut deficit
summary: Hong Kong's financial secretary, Paul Chan, is set to unveil a budget addressing the city's economic revival and fiscal deficit. The government is expected to focus on attracting foreign talent, particularly high-skilled workers, after years of strict pandemic curbs. Measures to bring in talent include salary tax exemptions and incentives for businesses, with some economists suggesting a shift away from consumption vouchers. The budget aims to balance the city's economic recovery with fiscal pressures, with a median estimate of a HK$15.5 billion fiscal surplus this year.

images.alt_text: The comments come before Chan delivers a budget presentation on Wednesday as part of efforts to chart a course for a rebound.
Hong Kong's population has fallen by about 187,300, or 2.5 per cent, from the end of 2019 through 2022.

site_title: UK healthcare strikes to intensify as junior doctors vote to walk out
summary: UK junior doctors have voted 98% in favor of a 72-hour walkout next month, adding to ongoing strikes by nurses and ambulance workers. The British Medical Association claims junior doctors have suffered a 25% real-terms pay cut since 2008, leading to demoralization and a desire to leave the profession. The strikes will put pressure on the already strained NHS, which is experiencing staff shortages and record backlogs.

images.alt_text: Labour union Verdi called on workers from Germany's major airports to strike on Friday (Feb 17). The union is demanding a pay increase of 500 euros (S$713) a month for some workers, and higher holiday-shift compensation for others.
The latest survey by Ifop-Fiducial shows that opposition to the pension reform has ticked back up three points to 72 per cent.

Britain has been hit by a wave of strike action over the last six months, its worst in a generation, with walk-outs by rail workers, teachers and postal staff demanding higher wages as inflation surges.

site_title: Australia’s central bank abandoned pause option for February rate hike
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia abandoned plans to pause its interest rate hike in February, instead raising the cash rate to a 10-year high of 3.35% and committing to more rate hikes to tame inflation. The decision comes amid a 325 basis point increase in rates since last May, the most aggressive tightening in modern history. The RBA cited an uncertain global outlook, rising inflation, and strong demand as reasons for the decision, with further increases likely in the months ahead.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) in Sydney May 5, 2015.    REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo                    GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD - SEARCH GLOBAL BUSINESS 27 MAR FOR ALL IMAGES

site_title: Governance in a Web 3.0 future
summary: Singapore can explore new ways to enhance policy processes and foster social cohesiveness through Web 3.0 technologies like blockchain. Decentralization, facilitated by blockchain, enables peer-to-peer transactions and collaboration, bypassing bureaucratic red tape. This can lead to more efficient and accurate decision-making by key stakeholders. Blockchain also holds potential for transparent information sharing, verifying digital assets, and facilitating trust among members. Decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs) can channel resources across sectors, promoting self-governance and social cohesion. By leveraging Web 3.0 protocols, Singapore can create platforms for decentralized governance, optimizing public sector resources and fostering social trust.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins like BUSD, Tether’s USDT and Circle’s USDC are crypto tokens that are intended to hold a set value, for example US$1.

The growing use of tokenisation, which creates digital representation of real-world assets on the blockchain, can extend efficiency gains to the vast markets for stocks, bonds, commodities, and other major assets.

site_title: Japan’s factory activity shrinks at fastest pace in 2-1/2 years: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity contracted at its fastest pace in 30 months in February, with the au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to 47.4 from 48.9 in the previous month. This marked the largest decline since August 2020, and the index stayed below the 50-level separating contraction from expansion for a fourth consecutive month. The contraction is a worrying sign for Japan's economy, which is facing weakening demand and struggling to tame cost pressures.

images.alt_text: Market participants are staying cautious ahead of a week packed with Federal Reserve speeches and US data releases, culminating in a parliamentary testimony by the incoming Bank of Japan leadership team on Friday.
The core CPI is set to reach 4.2 per cent in January versus the same month a year earlier, accelerating from December’s 4.0 per cent, the poll showed.

site_title: Europe: Miners lift shares, but fall in Telecom Italia caps gains
summary: European stocks rose 0.1% on Monday, driven by gains in miners as demand recovery in China offset a decline in industrials and Telecom Italia shares. The Stoxx 600 index closed higher ahead of economic data releases. The basic resources index climbed 2.4% after industrial metals prices rose due to China demand recovery hopes and supply disruptions.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.2 per cent lower on Friday, after having touched its highest level in a year in the previous session on a boost from French blue-chip shares.

site_title: Hong Kong’s crypto hub ambitions win quiet backing from Beijing
summary: Hong Kong's efforts to become a cryptocurrency hub have gained quiet backing from Beijing, with mainland Chinese firms expressing interest in setting up operations in the city. Representatives from China's Liaison Office have been visiting Hong Kong's crypto events, exchanging information with local operators. The low-key support suggests Beijing's willingness to use Hong Kong as a testing ground for digital assets while maintaining control on the mainland. Mainland firms are expected to return, with some already planning to expand operations in Hong Kong, as the city aims to capitalize on its favorable regulatory environment.

images.alt_text: bitcoin  crypto   Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Develop vaccines for all animal influenza strain, says incoming WHO chief scientist
summary: Incoming WHO chief scientist Jeremy Farrar recommends investing in vaccines for all animal influenza strains as an insurance policy in case of an outbreak in humans. This comes after countries such as the US, Britain, France, and Japan have suffered record poultry losses due to avian flu outbreaks. Farrar expressed concern that the world may not be prepared if a human pandemic were to occur, citing the need for pharmaceutical companies to conduct clinical trials for all influenza strains to facilitate global manufacturing.

site_title: Sats halts trading pending announcement
summary: SATS has halted trading pending an announcement, following the announcement of a net profit of S$500,000 for its third quarter ended December 2022, reversing two consecutive quarters of losses. The company expects to complete its proposed S$1.8 billion acquisition of Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services by March or April this year. A joint venture with Air India was also selected to design, build, finance and operate a five-tier integrated multi-modal cargo hub at the Noida International Airport.

images.alt_text: SATS Ltd air cargo operations.

site_title: Russian economy shrank 2.1% last year, less than once expected
summary: Russia's economy contracted 2.1% in 2022, less than the 3% decline expected, due to surging commodity exports offsetting the impact of US and European sanctions. Wholesale and retail trade, manufacturing, and transport were hardest hit, while mining, agriculture, construction, and government spending grew. The central bank projects growth may resume this year, but economists predict a small contraction of 1-2% in 2023. The economy is expected to lose $190 billion in GDP by 2026 relative to its pre-war trajectory.

site_title: Oil rises 1% on China demand hopes and supply concerns
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Monday, driven by optimism over Chinese demand and concerns about global supply. Brent crude settled at $84.07 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 1.1% to $77.19. The increase was attributed to China's continued demand for Russian crude amid Western sanctions and embargoes due to the Ukraine war, as well as production curbs by major producers.

images.alt_text: Brent crude slid 9 cents, or 0.1 oer cent, to US$82.91 a barrel by 0051 GMT on Monday.

site_title: It’s shape up or ship out for e-commerce logistics players facing slowing demand
summary: South-east Asian logistics company Ninja Van has consolidated parcel sorting stations due to slowing e-commerce demand, with parcel volumes experiencing flat or slightly negative growth for the first time. The company cited economic headwinds, including higher fuel prices, as contributing factors. This trend is expected to impact other logistics companies in the region, forcing them to increase efficiency and consolidate resources to adapt to the economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
CGS-CIMB raises its call on GoTo to "add" from "hold" with a higher target price of 150 rupiah.
A full third of GXO's operations are automated, and the company is keen to invest more in technology.

site_title: Sembcorp H2 profit up 54% to S$358 million
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 54% increase in its second-half net profit to S$358 million, driven by higher contributions from its renewables and conventional energy segments. Earnings per share rose 54% to 20.09 Singapore cents. The company's renewables arm saw a 75% increase in net profit to S$56 million, while its conventional energy segment grew 67%. Sembcorp has proposed paying out a final dividend of S$0.04 per share, pending approval at its annual general meeting on April 20.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Commissioned in six months, the Sembcorp ESS (energy storage system) is Southeast Asia’s largest ESS and is the fastest in the world of its size to be deployed
The offshore and marine giant shed as much as 8.4 per cent or S$0.011 to S$0.12 as at 10.41am after 307.4 million securities changed hands.

site_title: Singapore can pay for higher social spending without hiking income taxes for the time being: analysts
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 aims to fund a social agenda without drastic tax hikes, citing a modest deficit of 0.1% of GDP. Analysts expect no personal or corporate income tax increases in 2024, instead suggesting alternative revenue sources such as a 10% GST hike, property-related taxes, or a capital gains tax on property sales. Wealth-related taxes, including those on high-end properties and luxury cars, may also be introduced to raise revenue. The government may need to consider raising the GST rate beyond 2024 to fund increased spending.

images.alt_text:

Mr Lawrence Wong, Minister for Finance, arriving at Parliament House to deliver his Budget Statement speech on Budget Day, Feb 14, 2023.
