Progressive tax policies, in which the better-off help the less well-off, can also help to strengthen the social fabric and build national resilience.
Budget 2023: Singapore expects second straight deficit, narrowing to S$0.4b in FY23

site_title: Taiwan January export orders fall more slowly, downside risks remain
summary: Taiwan's January export orders fell 45.9% from a year earlier, marking the fifth consecutive month of decline, due to weak Chinese demand and global consumer spending. Orders for telecoms products rose 9.8% due to an improving supply chain in China. Despite semiconductor demand helping in the first quarter, downside risks in the global economy remain high, affecting export orders. The Ministry of Economic Affairs expects orders to be 6.9-10.8% lower than in February 2022.

images.alt_text: Liu Xiaodong, deputy head of the Shanghai office of China's Taiwan Affairs Office and head of the delegation of Chinese officials visiting Taiwan, walks out of the arrival hall at Songshan Airport in Taipei, Taiwan, Feb 18, 2023.
The regulations prohibit Lockheed Martin and Raytheon Missile and Defense Corporation, a subsidiary of Raytheon Technologies, from “engaging in import and export activities related to China”.

site_title: Navigating China’s new cross-border data transfer rules
summary: China has tightened its cross-border data transfer rules, imposing strict controls on companies exporting data abroad. The new regulations, including the updated Security Certification Specifications and Measures for Data Security Management, aim to balance economic growth with national security interests. Companies must undergo security assessments or obtain certifications to transfer data out of China, with exceptions for international treaties and agreements. The move is expected to raise operating costs for multinationals and potentially hinder innovation, with some companies already adjusting by duplicating data centers or creating separate product offerings.

images.alt_text: Data breaches are notoriously common.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Genting Singapore, Sembcorp, SingPost, China Everbright Water, Hiap Hoe
summary: Stocks to watch on Feb 21, 2023, include Genting Singapore, which reported a 169% increase in net profit to S$255.7 million due to travel recovery, while Sembcorp Industries posted a 54% increase in net profit to S$358 million. Singapore Post's third quarter operating profit fell 9.7% year on year, and China Everbright Water secured a S$130.1 million industrial waste water treatment project. Hiap Hoe failed to obtain requisite consent for the collective sale of Orchard Towers, and trading halts were issued for Mencast Holdings, The Place Holdings, and Sats.

images.alt_text: On the Singapore Exchange, losers beat gainers 302 to 239 after 1.7 billion shares worth S$847.7 million changed hands.

site_title: China's new rules for offshore listings spark concern about lengthy approval process
summary: China has introduced new rules for offshore listings, potentially leading to a lengthy approval process for companies seeking initial public offerings in New York. The rules, which provide clarity after a regulatory crackdown since 2021, require companies to obtain approval from multiple domestic government agencies. This is unlikely to spark a rush of Chinese firms seeking listings in the US due to existing tensions between the two countries and increased regulatory requirements. The rules are seen as a step towards providing clarity, but may slow down listings by Chinese firms in the US.

images.alt_text: Under the new system, stock exchanges will be responsible for vetting IPOs with a focus on information disclosure, while the CSRC will only make sure listings are in line with national industrial policy.

site_title: Global sustainability standards chief expects strong take up of climate rules
summary: The International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) approved climate-related reporting rules, forming a global baseline for companies to assess risks and opportunities. ISSB chair Emmanuel Faber expects over 40 countries to adopt the rules by 2024, despite patchy data. The rules aim to facilitate a low-carbon economy, with ISSB planning to expand its climate-related issues and consulting on its next goal.

site_title: Upskilling for gig workers poses different problems needing different solutions
summary: Gig workers in Singapore face job stagnation due to lack of job mobility and flexible working conditions. A survey found 46% of ride-hailing drivers couldn't find other suitable work due to caregiving responsibilities. Experts emphasize the need for paid training schemes and better working conditions to boost job mobility. The gig economy is not a viable option for those who desperately need flexibility, and a greater emphasis on work-life balance for blue-collar work is required.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Platform workers who are below 30 years old when the changes are implemented from 2024 will be required to make increased CPF contributions.
Upskilling will be important for platform workers' economic welfare in the long run, industry observers say.

site_title: Orchard Towers collective sale falls through
summary: A collective sale attempt for Orchard Towers, a 1970s development in Singapore, has failed to secure 80% consent from unit owners, halting the process. Mainboard-listed property developer Hiap Hoe, which owns 59 strata lots at the site, announced the failure in a bourse filing. Orchard Towers has a plot ratio of 4.9 and a site area of approximately 6,130 square meters. The collective sale committee did not meet the required threshold, leading to the halt in the process.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
JLL says the site presents significant upside potential for redevelopment into a super luxurious high-rise residential location with spectacular city views.
Women in revealing attire outside a beauty salon in Orchard Towers at lunchtime on Aug 25, 2022. These two women work at one of many beauty spas and salons found there.

site_title: SingPost reports 9.7% lower operating profit of S$33.9 million
summary: SingPost reported a 9.7% lower operating profit of S$33.9 million for the third quarter ended December 2022, down from S$37.5 million the previous year. Despite a 13.4% year-over-year growth in group revenue to S$495.1 million, operating expenses increased 15.3% to S$460.8 million. Higher logistics revenue from Freight Management Holdings (FMH) offset lower revenue from the post and parcel segment and freight forwarding business. The company expects a challenging operating environment in 2023 due to high inflation and a weak global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Two electric motorbikes serving selected areas in Districts 9 and 10 will be used for three months during the trial, SingPost said.
Vincent Yik, Group CFO, Singapore Post
Singpost’s subsidiary QSI was also granted two put options by Cainiao to dispose of its equity interest in 4PX.
UOBKH expects SingPost’s increased stake in FMH to boost the group’s profitability from the first quarter of 2024 onwards, given the Australian subsidiary’s robust operating profit growth.
Upon completion of the transaction, SingPost’s total stake in FMH will increase from 51 per cent currently, to 88 per cent.

site_title: With an eye on China, the Philippines moves closer to US interests
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr has adopted a more muscular foreign policy approach, seeking alliances and prioritizing the country's territorial dispute with China in the South China Sea. He has granted the US military access to four new defense sites and restarted joint patrols with the US. Marcos' decisions aim to counter China's influence and strengthen ties with the US, Japan, and South Korea. The move is seen as a welcome change by the Americans, but officials in the Philippines hope to maintain independence by modernizing the military through joint exercises and cooperation.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. gestures as he delivers his first State of the Nation Address, in Quezon City, Metro Manila, Philippines, July 25, 2022. Aaron Favila/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: China launches pilot scheme to boost private investment in real estate
summary: China has launched a pilot scheme to boost private investment in the real estate sector, requiring at least 30 million yuan (S$5.84 million) of fundraising in its first round. Institutional investors must offer at least 10 million yuan each to participate. The scheme will invest in residential and commercial housing, as well as infrastructure projects. China is also encouraging foreign investment through a Qualified Foreign Limited Partnership program.

site_title: New Zealand set to moderate tightening pace as inflation peaks
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), is set to moderate its pace of interest-rate increases by a half-percentage point to 4.75% from 4.25%. This decision comes in response to signs that inflation has peaked, following Cyclone Gabrielle's devastation, which destroyed infrastructure and flooded homes. Despite initial concerns about the impact of the cyclone on inflation, economists expect the RBNZ to maintain its hawkish stance, citing ongoing inflation pressures and a need to bring interest rates closer to global peers.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand in Wellington. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: Portugal to force owners of vacant homes to find tenants
summary: Portugal's government plans to force owners of vacant homes to rent them out to long-term renters in an effort to increase housing supply and address the country's unaffordable real estate market. The policy, part of the "More Housing" plan, has been met with opposition from property owners, who claim it violates their constitutional right to private property. The government estimates that about 730,000 homes are empty, and the policy is expected to be finalized by March, pending public discussion and parliamentary approval.

images.alt_text: Over the past 10 years, Portugal has brought in nearly 6.8 billion euros (S$9.7 billion) in exchange for having issued 11,600 residence permits.

site_title: UK, 30 others vow support for ban on Russian, Belarusian athletes
summary: More than 30 countries, including the US, UK, and France, have pledged support for banning Russian and Belarusian athletes from international sporting events due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The move increases pressure on the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to avoid the 2024 Paris Olympics being disrupted. The British government stated that Russian and Belarusian athletes' participation as neutrals is unlikely due to state funding, while Paris 2024 organisers have insisted they will abide by the IOC decision. Ukraine has threatened to boycott the Games if Russian and Belarusian athletes compete.

site_title: Growing danger of a nuclear conflict over Ukraine
summary: The ongoing Russia-Ukraine war has shown no signs of ending, with both sides gearing up for a potential spring offensive. Despite Western economic sanctions targeting Russian fossil fuel exports, Moscow has managed to maintain its economic wherewithal, selling its oil to global markets. The war has resulted in significant damage to Ukraine's infrastructure, displacement of five million people, and control of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant by Russia. The risk of escalation, including the use of nuclear weapons, is increasing, particularly if Ukraine manages to retake occupied territories, potentially drawing in NATO forces.

site_title: Biden's weekend: Church, dinner, and secret trip to Kyiv
summary: US President Joe Biden made a secret trip to Kyiv, Ukraine, on February 20, 2023, visiting President Volodymyr Zelensky amidst a "historic" and unprecedented visit to a country at war. Biden's trip was preceded by a weekend of relaxation, including church and dinner, and was kept under wraps despite hundreds of journalists covering the White House. The White House revealed that direct contact was made with Moscow before Biden's arrival, but details of the trip remain unknown, including whether any US forces provided cover. Biden's visit was seen as a significant symbolic gesture, with the US pledging $500 million in new military aid to Ukraine.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden (L) speaks with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky (R) as they attend a joint press conference in Kyiv, on February 20, 2023. - US President Joe Biden made a surprise trip to Kyiv on February 20, 2023, ahead of the first anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, AFP journalists saw. Biden met Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in the Ukrainian capital on his first visit to the country since the start of the conflict. (Photo by Evan Vucci / AFP)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's fresh graduates saw higher full-time employment rates and median salaries, with median salaries reaching S$5,625, up from S$5,000 in 2021. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates, potentially affecting bond yields, and Singapore firms' business sentiment has become gloomier due to poor Q4 performance.

site_title: Launched: Programme that prepares women in technology for board roles
summary: A new one-year programme has been launched in Singapore to prepare women in technology for board director roles. The initiative, a collaboration between the Singapore Institute of Directors and the Singapore Computer Society, aims to build a robust pipeline of board-ready women in technology and encourage more women professionals to take up board appointments. Registration for the programme opened on February 20, targeting C-suite executives and professionals with senior leadership experience interested in pursuing board directorship roles.

images.alt_text: While DEI disclosure is nascent in Singapore, the US Securities and Exchange Commission in 2020 required companies to disclose enhanced human capital management details.

site_title: China Everbright Water bags 668 million yuan wastewater treatment project in Shandong
summary: China Everbright Water secured a 668 million yuan wastewater treatment project in Shandong province with a 30-year concession period. The project, valued at S$130.1 million, will have a combined daily wastewater treatment capacity of 60,000 cubic meters. Everbright Water will hold an 98% equity interest and will build and maintain the project. The deal marks the largest industrial wastewater treatment capacity and highest discharge standard secured by the company to date, according to executive director Hu Yanguo.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
China Everbright Water's wastewater treatment project in Qingdao. The company has secured its first municipal-level sludge disposal project

The project will be based on a build-operate-transfer model and comprises a waste water treatment plant with a designed daily waste water treatment capacity of 20,000 cubic metres as well as an ancillary pipeline network of about 37.1 km.

site_title: Inflation in India feels higher than what official data reveal
summary: India's headline inflation remained above the central bank's target ceiling of 6% for most of last year, driven by high food prices. Real inflation, as calculated by India Ratings & Research, was 40 basis points higher, eroding purchasing power for the poor. The effective inflation rate for the bottom 50% of the population stood at 7.2%, while the top 50% experienced a 6.9% real inflation rate. To contain price pressures, the government and RBI have taken measures, including curbing exports and raising borrowing costs. Further interest rate hikes are expected.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India is seen increasing interest rates again in its April review amid inflation topping estimates and further tightening by global central banks.

site_title: Ericsson to cut 1,400 jobs in Sweden
summary: Ericsson plans to cut approximately 1,400 jobs in Sweden as part of a global cost-cutting plan. The company aims to reduce costs by $880 million by the end of 2023, amid slowing demand in some markets. Ericsson made deep cuts in 2017 and is now negotiating with its employee union in Sweden to manage headcount reductions. The company has reached an agreement with Swedish unions to implement the cuts through a voluntary program.

site_title: Developing countries’ debt troubles in focus at G20 talks, says Germany’s finance minister
summary: German Finance Minister Christian Lindner emphasized the need to test the Common Framework (CF) with poorer nations before expanding it to middle-income countries to address growing debt troubles among developing countries. The CF aims to help poor countries delay debt repayments, and Lindner supports its expansion but wants to ensure its effectiveness. He also highlighted the importance of maintaining unity among Western nations in supporting Ukraine, particularly in the face of Russia's invasion.

site_title: Frasers Property’s board should act with some urgency to address weak share price
summary: Frasers Property's board is urged to address its weak share price, which may not be enhanced by its recent purchase of a stake in Nex. The property group, which is trading at a 66% discount to its end-September 2022 net asset value, may consider creating a listed Reit to distribute its assets to minority shareholders, potentially boosting the trust's size and improving liquidity. FPL's chairman Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi has a deemed interest of 87% in the company, and improving the free float could be a way to increase value for all shareholders.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok, the first residential launch in Bedok Town Centre in 10 years.
Analysts say the joint acquisition makes Frasers Centrepoint Trust the “largest suburban retail landlord” in Singapore.
Frasers Centrepoint and sponsor Frasers Property has acquired a 50 per cent stake in NEX for S$652.5 million

site_title: Indonesia plans to narrow 2024 fiscal deficit, sees higher GDP growth
summary: Indonesia plans to narrow its fiscal deficit in 2024, aiming for a deficit of 2.16-2.64% of GDP, down from 2.84% in 2023. The country's economic growth is expected to accelerate, reaching 5.3-5.7% in 2024, driven by investments, household consumption, and energy transition. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati emphasized the need to maintain confidence and keep investment momentum strong, while anticipating export disruption due to geopolitical issues.

images.alt_text: Bank Indonesia put out its latest rate transparency report last week, showing banks offering loan rates that are 4.75 per cent more than the policy rate of 5.75 per cent.

site_title: Biden, in Kyiv, pledges US$500 million in new military aid to Ukraine
summary: US President Joe Biden pledged $500 million in new military aid to Ukraine during an unannounced visit to Kyiv, ahead of the one-year anniversary of Russia's invasion. The aid package, to be announced on Tuesday, includes more ammunition for High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems. Biden's visit was seen as a major show of support for Ukraine, with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy calling it an "extremely important sign of support." The aid comes as Russia continues its winter offensive in eastern Ukraine, with scant gains reported in recent weeks.

images.alt_text: While tensions remain between the United States and Europe, the transatlantic alliance has largely recovered from the nadir of the Trump era.

site_title: Vietnam shoe maker for Nike, Adidas to cut 6,000 jobs
summary: Vietnam-based shoe manufacturer PouYuen Vietnam, a unit of Pou Chen Group, will cut 3,000 factory workers and not renew 3,000 contracts due to a slump in orders. The layoffs follow the company's decision to put 20,000 workers on paid leave in rotation at the end of last year. The move is attributed to a decline in production orders in 2023, primarily due to the cost-of-living crisis in major markets in Europe and the US. PouYuen Vietnam, Vietnam's largest employer, has around 50,000 employees.

site_title: Prayuth narrows gap in poll on top choice for Thailand PM
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has narrowed the gap in a recent poll, gaining support among Bangkok residents and surpassing frontrunner Paetongtarn Shinawatra, daughter of ousted former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra. The survey by Super Poll showed Prayuth as the top choice in Bangkok, while Paetongtarn received 21.3% support in the capital. The election, set for May, will showcase the bitter rivalries at the heart of Thailand's 17 years of on-and-off political turmoil.

images.alt_text: Though yet to be named as Pheu Thai’s prime ministerial candidate, Paetongtarn Shinawatra (above) is far ahead in opinion polls for premier.

site_title: EU calls for fast-track crypto capital rules for banks
summary: The European Union's executive body has called for fast-tracking crypto capital rules for banks to meet a January 2025 deadline set by the Basel Committee of banking regulators. The EU is considering proposing a new law or expanding its existing banking law to ensure compliance. Banks have expressed interest in trading cryptoassets on behalf of clients, but currently have low exposures. A delay could impact banks' ability to enter the cryptomarket and risks from cryptoassets need to be adequately addressed.

images.alt_text: The fund’s closure would see clients receive 90 per cent of the money not trapped on FTX, with the remaining 10 per cent temporarily held back until discussions with the FTX estate are finalised.

site_title: Leiji Matsumoto, manga creator of epic space sagas, dies aged 85
summary: Leiji Matsumoto, renowned manga and anime creator of epic space sagas, has died at 85 due to heart failure. He is best known for creating series like Galaxy Express 999, Space Pirate Captain Harlock, and Space Battleship Yamato. Matsumoto's work aimed to promote peace and protect the Earth, as stated in a 2015 interview. He received several awards from the Japanese government and the Knight of the Order of Arts and Letters from the French government. Matsumoto's legacy will be remembered through his influential works in the anime and manga industry.

site_title: Uber to introduce EVs in India in push to clean cars
summary: Uber plans to introduce electric vehicles (EVs) in India for ride-sharing, aiming to reach 100% zero-emission rides by 2040. The company will buy 25,000 EVs from Tata Motors over three years, stepping up competition with BluSmart, a local electric mobility start-up. Uber's president, Prabhjeet Singh, emphasized the need for affordable vehicles, a mature financing ecosystem, and widespread charging infrastructure for electric ride-hailing to take off. This is the largest deal for EVs by a ride-sharing company, and Uber is in talks with other carmakers and financiers for its EV push.

images.alt_text: Uber, which operates in more than 70 countries and 10,000 cities, says that new ride-sharing products are boosting its revenue.

site_title: Private equity’s crafty lawyers offer universal lessons
summary: Private equity's lawyers have been accused of driving the degradation of lending standards in loan contracts, accepting weaker safeguards from debt investors in a booming market for financing private equity deals. This trend, which began around 2018, has led to a loss of power for investors and a rise in risky contractual terms. As interest rates and economies slow, debt refinancing problems and workouts are likely to increase. Market regulators in the UK and other countries are investigating practices used by lawyers, and investors are now hiring second, shadow lawyers to protect their interests.

images.alt_text: Corporates bloated with US$6 trillion of debt revive an arcane corner of Wall Street

site_title: Dubai in talks to attract 50 hedge funds to Mideast finance hub
summary: Dubai's financial centre is in talks with over 50 hedge funds to set up in the Middle East business hub, following industry heavyweights such as Millennium Management and ExodusPoint Capital Management. The Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) is offering reduced licensing fees and capital requirements, attracting hedge funds with global investments spanning North America to Asia. Revenue in 2022 reached a record of $288.6 million, mirroring Dubai's economic resurgence following the Covid pandemic.

site_title: Positive returns do not mean enough returns
summary: Investors who achieve positive returns on their investments may not necessarily have accumulated enough for retirement. A study analyzing four portfolios with different asset allocations over a 33-year period (1990-2023) found that even with positive returns, some portfolios failed to meet their planning returns, with differences ranging from 0.1% to 3.6% per year. The key takeaway is that staying invested for a long time increases the probability of meeting planning returns, but it's not a guarantee. Investors must also ensure they have a suitable asset allocation, strong financial health, and a well-planned strategy to achieve their financial goals.

images.alt_text: Leverage and attempting to time the market raise the risks of a permanent loss of capital.
Countless studies show that time in the market beats timing the market. Bull markets last longer than bear markets.

site_title: Japan PM pledges US$5.5 billion in additional Ukraine aid
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida pledged an additional $5.5 billion in aid to Ukraine, focusing on supporting people whose livelihoods have been destroyed by the war and restoring damaged infrastructure. This comes ahead of the first anniversary of Russia's invasion on February 24, 2022. Kishida also announced plans to amend relevant laws and seek parliament's approval for the funds. The announcement follows US President Joe Biden's promise of increased arms deliveries for Ukraine during an unannounced visit to Kyiv.

images.alt_text: For Japan, maintaining an alliance with the US is by far the safest and most cost-effective option.

site_title: US dollar edges lower from six-week peak, Swedish krona jumps
summary: The US dollar index slipped 0.1% to 103.91, edging lower from a six-week high, amid expectations of tighter monetary policy from the Federal Reserve. Economic data reinforced this expectation, pointing to a still-tight labor market and stubborn consumer prices. Analysts say the US dollar's move may have run its course, with interest rates expected to peak at around 5.3% by July. The Swedish krona jumped, while the euro fell 1.1% against it, as hawkish comments from Fed officials and policymakers in Sweden signaled more rate hikes to control inflation.

site_title: Malaysia PM Anwar’s first budget on Friday: Five things to watch out for
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is set to unveil the country's first budget on Friday, addressing key challenges including a high cost of living, escalating core inflation, and slower economic growth. The budget is expected to include cash handouts and subsidies to tackle cost-of-living issues, with possible reductions in fuel subsidies to bring spending down. The government may also introduce a carbon tax and incentives for electric vehicles. Infrastructure development and expanding government coffers are also expected, with measures to narrow the fiscal deficit and maintain fiscal discipline.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim will be tabling the revised Budget 2023 on Feb 24, the market is hopeful that the first budget by the unity government could provide some fresh leads on the country's future direction.

site_title: Bain Capital expects pickup in China’s struggling private equity market
summary: Bain Capital expects a recovery in China's US$539 billion private equity market as early as this year, driven by the end of Covid Zero, recovery in consumer sentiment, and a rebound in Chinese stock markets. The market is expected to benefit from a "significantly higher" economic expansion rate, easing restrictions on internet companies, and a meaningful recovery in the benchmark CSI 300 Index. However, the industry may struggle to reach past levels of deal activity, with a recovery to a lower level than previous years.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk by office towers in the Lujiazui financial district of Shanghai, China October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Asia-Pacific’s biggest crane owner said to weigh Australia exit
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, Asia-Pacific's largest crane owner, is considering selling its Australian business, Tutt Bryant Group, in a deal valued at over US$500 million. The Singapore-based company is working with a financial adviser on the potential divestment, which is still in its early stages. Tutt Bryant, founded in 1938, serves Australia's construction, mining, and engineering sectors, and was previously listed on the Australian Securities Exchange. There is no guarantee Tat Hong will proceed with the planned sale.

site_title: British craft beer firm BrewDog in JV deal for China expansion
summary: British craft beer firm BrewDog has entered a joint venture with Budweiser China to produce its beers in China, with the goal of growing sales in the country. The partnership will see BrewDog's beers produced at Budweiser China's Putian Craft Brewery in Fujian province, and sold across the country through its sales and distribution network. The move aims to tap into China's growing craft beer market, which BrewDog believes will see significant growth, with plans to open several new bars in China by 2026.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street losses; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to 3,308.75 on Monday, following US Federal Reserve rate hike expectations. Losers beat gainers 302 to 239, with real estate investment trusts and local banks among the biggest losers. Major Asian markets, however, rose, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index up 0.8% and Japan's Nikkei 225 edging up 0.1%. Market analyst Yeap Jun Rong attributed the decline to mixed US economic data and growing bets on further rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
While the Fed has seemed to slow its hikes, analysts expect it will have to continue tightening its monetary policy to bring down persistent inflation.

site_title: Adani decides against bid for stake in state-backed PTC India
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani has decided against bidding for a stake in state-backed electricity trader PTC India, citing a desire to preserve cash amid criticism from a US short-seller. Adani was among the possible bidders reviewing preliminary information on the Mumbai-listed company. The decision comes as Adani's business empire looks to maintain its financial stability.

images.alt_text: More than 500 funds registered in the European Union as “promoting” ESG goals hold Adani stocks, either directly or indirectly, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: ‘All Quiet on the Western Front’ triumphs at BAFTA Awards
summary: The German remake of the anti-war classic "All Quiet on the Western Front" won seven awards at the British Academy Film Awards (BAFTAs), including best film, adapted screenplay, and film not in the English language. The film, based on the 1928 novel by Erich Maria Remarque, tells the story of a young German soldier who is misled by nationalist propaganda and experiences the horrors of World War I. The wins marked a significant milestone for a non-English language film, with Netflix's "All Quiet on the Western Front" also leading the nominations with 14 nods.

site_title: Maersk nears complete Russia exit after selling logistics sites
summary: Maersk, a shipping and logistics group, has agreed to sell its two logistics sites in Russia to IG Finance Development Limited. The sites, which include an inland depot and a chilled and frozen warehouse, have obtained regulatory approvals and will be operated by Arosa, a large food importer in Russia. This sale marks the end of Maersk's business activities in the country, with the company still needing to sell four tug boats under its Svitzer brand.

site_title: Crypto investor Galois to shut flagship fund after FTX collapse
summary: Galois Capital, a crypto investment firm, is closing its flagship fund due to the collapse of cryptocurrency exchange FTX. The fund had lost nearly half its assets in the FTX disaster and sold its claim for cents on the US dollar. Clients will receive 90% of the money not trapped on FTX, with 10% temporarily held back until discussions with the FTX estate are finalised. Galois co-founder Kevin Zhou stated that the fund's closure marks the end of an era, but the firm's work has not been in vain.

site_title: Commerzbank to rejoin Germany’s DAX after historic exit in 2018
summary: Commerzbank is set to rejoin Germany's DAX Index after a four-year absence. The bank will replace industrial-gases producer Linde, which is delisting from the Frankfurt Stock Exchange on February 27. Linde's removal will be replaced by Unicredit on the Euro Stoxx 50 Index and Sinch on the Stoxx 600 Index. This move follows Commerzbank's initial exit in 2018, which was made to accommodate rising star Wirecard, whose subsequent collapse led to its removal from the index.

images.alt_text: Net profit of 472 million euros (S$674.1 million) in the quarter was higher than 421 million euros a year earlier.

site_title: Cyclone recovery expected to cost New Zealand billions
summary: New Zealand is expected to incur billions of dollars in costs to recover from Cyclone Gabrielle, which has claimed 11 lives and left 15,000 households without power. The national state of emergency has been extended for another week, with Prime Minister Chris Hipkins warning the final death toll could rise. Finance Minister Grant Robertson has pledged NZ$300 million in relief, but predicts the total cost will be "billions of dollars." Recovery efforts are ongoing, with highways, power, and telecommunications being re-established.

images.alt_text: Homes are damaged after a storm battered Titirangi, a suburb of New Zealand's West Auckland area, on Feb 13.

site_title: Malaysia’s January exports rise 1.6%, missing forecast; dragged by lower palm oil product exports
summary: Malaysia's exports rose 1.6% in January, missing the forecast, due to lower palm oil and natural rubber product exports. This was the smallest gain since October 2020 and the fifth straight month of growth slowdown. Imports declined 2.3% year-on-year, reaching RM2.2 billion, and the trade surplus narrowed by 2.1% to RM18.2 billion. Despite this, exports to major trading partners, such as Asean and Japan, recorded double-digit growth, driven by petroleum, liquefied natural gas, and electrical and electronic products.

images.alt_text: The Port of Tanjung Pelepas, in Iskandar Puteri, Johor, Malaysia, on Thursday, Feb. 9, 2023. The shipping market has normalized after two years of exceptionally high freight rates, when supply snarls and and a shortage of vessels allowed Maersk and its peers to charge higher prices for their services and pocket record profits. Photographer: Lionel Ng/Bloomberg

site_title: Chinese ride-hailing player Dida revives US$200 million IPO
summary: Chinese ride-hailing company Dida is planning a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) worth around $200 million, according to sources. The IPO could happen as early as June, following assurances from Chinese regulators. Dida's previous attempts at an IPO were unsuccessful due to regulatory issues, but the company's main apps have returned to Chinese mobile stores, paving the way for the listing. This could mark the first successful IPO by a Chinese ride-hailing startup since Didi Global's failed US IPO in 2021.

images.alt_text: Vehicles travel along a road in Beijing, China, on Wednesday, Feb. 15, 2023. President Xi Jinping's push for a consumer-led economic recovery has hit a new barrier: Chinese citizens misusing cheap consumer loans. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: China says US in no position to make demands after Blinken warning
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned China's top diplomat Wang Yi against providing weapons to Russia in its war with Ukraine, prompting China to say the US is in no position to make demands. China's comprehensive partnership with Russia is based on non-alignment and non-confrontation, and China will not accept US coercion or accusations about its relations with Russia. This comes amid strained US-China relations, following the US military shooting down a Chinese spy balloon and a report by Chinese state media accusing the US of seeking "hegemony" since World War II.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken told CBS that China was now “considering providing lethal support” to Moscow ranging “from ammunition to the weapons themselves.”

site_title: Salman Rushdie attacks Dahl rewrites as 'absurd censorship'
summary: Author Salman Rushdie has condemned the re-edited children's books of Roald Dahl, calling it "absurd censorship" by "bowdlerising sensitivity police". Publishers Puffin have made hundreds of reported changes, including making Oompa-Loompas in "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" gender neutral, altering Augustus Gloop's description, and changing Mrs. Twit's appearance. Rushdie criticized these changes, arguing that they compromise the original stories' essence.

images.alt_text: Salman Rushdie's first book since he was attacked in August 2022 has hit store shelves in the United States.

site_title: Transatlantic ties transformed on Ukraine war anniversary
summary: The transatlantic alliance has largely recovered from the Trump era, with the US and Europe showing unity in the face of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. US President Joe Biden's visit to Poland this week highlights the restoration of the alliance, with the Biden administration's statecraft credited for this revitalization. Despite ongoing tensions, including the US Inflation Reduction Act, the West has provided over $110 billion in support for Ukraine since February 2022. Economic decoupling between Russia and the West is also a key factor, with the EU-wide consumer confidence indicator at historically low levels.

images.alt_text: A pedestrian walks past a residential building damaged by Russian shelling in Kherson, Dec 2022. The World Bank has estimated the cost of Ukraine's post-war reconstruction at over 600b euros.

A farmer drives a combine harvester to collect soybeans under hanging solar panels on an agrivoltaic site in Amance, eastern France, Oct 2022. Rather than offering inefficient subsidies to existing technologies, governments should be funding R&D for new ones.
The Ukraine conflict is, as EC president Ursula von der Leyen declared, "fundamentally changing" Europe's peace architecture.

site_title: Scottish Finance Minister Kate Forbes to run for country’s leadership
summary: Scottish Finance Minister Kate Forbes has announced her intention to run for the country's leadership, becoming the third candidate to do so after Nicola Sturgeon's surprise resignation. Forbes, elected to the Scottish parliament in 2016, takes on the role of third contender after Sturgeon's exit. The leadership contest follows the Westminster government's blockage of the SNP's attempts to hold a second vote on Scottish independence. Forbes' candidacy has sparked uncertainty over the SNP's fight for independence, with Sturgeon's resignation leaving a question mark over the party's future.

site_title: Tycoon Agarwal’s plan to trim debt hits roadblock in India
summary: Indian billionaire Anil Agarwal's plan to trim Vedanta Group's massive debt pile has hit a roadblock after the government threatened to stop the sale of a zinc manufacturing unit to its subsidiary Hindustan Zinc. The government plans to oppose the sale, which was initially set to raise $3 billion to pay off debt. Vedanta Resources' debt scores may come under pressure if it fails to raise $2 billion or sell international zinc assets. The government will explore all legal avenues available if the company decides to proceed with the sale.

site_title: ‘Ant-Man’ crawls to top of North America box office
summary: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania dominated the North American box office, earning an estimated $118 million over the Presidents Day weekend. The film, starring Paul Rudd and Evangeline Lilly, exceeded predictions and had one of the strongest totals for a four-day US holiday weekend. Despite receiving "uncharacteristically soft" reviews and audience scores, the film's strong opening is considered excellent business and a big step up for the title, according to analyst David A Gross.

images.alt_text: The third instalment of the Ant-Man series, Quantumania delivered the highest opening of the three.

site_title: Japan yields rise after spike in Treasuries
summary: Japan's government bond yields rose on Monday following a spike in US Treasury yields, as investors expect higher US interest rates for longer. The two-year JGB yield increased 0.5 basis points to minus 0.045%, while the 10-year yield remained flat at 0.5%. Benchmark 10-year JGB futures rose 0.04 yen to 146.65. Investors are cautious ahead of Federal Reserve speeches and US data releases, including a parliamentary testimony by the incoming Bank of Japan leadership team on Friday, which may signal an end to the BOJ's yield-curve control policy.

images.alt_text: The core CPI is set to reach 4.2 per cent in January versus the same month a year earlier, accelerating from December’s 4.0 per cent, the poll showed.
The move, which was widely expected, will follow two years of experiments the central bank has been conducting to decide whether to issue a CBDC.
Ueda will join as BOJ governor on Apr 9.
A man passes an electronic quotation board displaying the closing numbers of the Nikkei Stock Average at the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on October 18, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia seen returning to rate pause after a final hike to 3%
summary: Malaysia's central bank is expected to raise its overnight policy rate by 25 basis points in the next quarter, before a final hike to 3% in the following quarter. This decision comes after a series of rate hikes last year, with the benchmark rate currently at 2.75%. Economists predict a slight improvement in exports, with a 9% growth forecast, but also warn of downside risks including tighter monetary policy and weaker global demand. The central bank's decision is seen as a response to the country's strong economic growth, with a 4% expansion in 2023.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Industrial Production Index expanded by 6.9 per cent in 2022, driven by robust manufacturing activities.
Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim is set to table the country's revised 2023 budget to parliament on Feb 24.

site_title: Countries gather to thrash out UN ocean protection treaty
summary: Countries from over 100 nations will meet in New York to discuss a new UN ocean protection treaty, aiming to protect 11 million square kilometers of ocean annually between now and the end of the decade to meet the 30 by 30 target. Key sticking points include financing, marine genetic resources, and ocean environmental impact assessment rules. Despite progress, major concessions are still being sought, with China playing a crucial role in negotiations. The talks, set to conclude on March 3, hinge on the finance question and the success of the treaty depends on a comprehensive agreement.

images.alt_text: Scientists have warned that climbing temperatures have wrought major changes to ocean stability faster than previously thought
A year's worth of washed-up plastic from one small beach, ready to be taken away for disposal.

site_title: Singapore’s fresh grads see higher salaries, full-time employment rates in 2022
summary: Singapore's fresh graduates saw higher full-time employment rates and median salaries in 2022, with information and digital technology graduates leading the way. The median monthly gross salary for full-time jobs was S$4,200, and the full-time employment rate was 87.5%, up from 84% in 2021. Unemployment rate rose to 6.2% from 5.6% in 2021. The top-paying graduates were those in computing, business, and law, with median salaries ranging from S$5,625 to S$6,400.

images.alt_text: Generic photo on growing our economy and equipping our workers

site_title: Regions in US, China most at risk for climate damage: report
summary: A comprehensive analysis by The Cross Dependency Initiative (XDI) ranks regions globally most at risk from climate change-driven weather extremes. China and the US are among the most vulnerable, with nine of the top 10 most at-risk regions in China and two in the US, specifically Jiangsu and Shandong provinces. The analysis models damage from 1990 to 2050 based on a 3°C global warming scenario, highlighting inland and coastal flooding, extreme heat, and other risks. The report could inform climate and economic policy, impact investment decisions, and even lead to capital flight as investors reassess financial risks in vulnerable areas.

images.alt_text: China has said it aims for renewable power to account for more than 50 per cent of its electricity generation capacity by 2025.
Homes are damaged after a storm battered Titirangi, a suburb of New Zealand's West Auckland area, on Feb 13.

site_title: Is there relative value with suburban landed homes?
summary: In Singapore, suburban landed homes may offer relative value, particularly for those looking for larger living spaces. Despite a large pricing gap between suburban and prime areas, some suburbs have experienced significant improvements, supporting strong demand for suburban condos. Landed homes may offer greater privacy, flexibility, and potential for rebuilding, making them more attractive to some buyers. However, the lower cost of suburban landed homes may not outweigh the higher property taxes for owner-occupied homes with high annual values. High-income earners may be drawn to larger suburban landed homes, but buyers should consider rebuilding costs and tax implications.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Some 24 units of Pollen Collection have been released for sale so far, with four units sold, said developer Bukit Sembawang Estates.

site_title: Standard Chartered to hire up to 500 staff in Hong Kong after reopening
summary: Standard Chartered plans to hire 300 to 500 staff in Hong Kong this year, anticipating "double-digit" growth in wealth management income and "single-digit" loan growth due to the city's reopened borders to mainland China. The lender expects to boost its Hong Kong workforce after a 23% slump in operating income in its wealth management unit last year. With wealthy mainland clients able to travel to Hong Kong, rival banks like HSBC also predict growth in the region.

site_title: Chinese home sales post third weekly rise in a row: survey
summary: Chinese home sales in 16 cities posted a third consecutive weekly rise, with sales growth of 7.9% from Feb 12-18 compared to the previous week. The slowdown was attributed to reduced transactions in first-tier cities, such as Shanghai, which saw a 20.2% decline. Relaxation of curbs on homebuyers and property developers, including lower mortgage rates and support for financing, has contributed to the stabilization of demand. The sector, accounting for a quarter of China's economy, is showing signs of recovery, but the pace of growth remains patchy.

site_title: India’s economic activity cools in January amid slowdown fears
summary: India's economic activity cooled in January, driven by a slowdown in demand at home and abroad. Business activity, including manufacturing and services, slacked due to lower new orders and exports fell 6.58% to $32.9 billion. However, consumer activity showed some resilience, with goods and services tax collections rising 10.5% and new vehicle registrations surging 14%. The Reserve Bank of India is expected to increase interest rates again in its April review amid inflation topping estimates and global central bank tightening.

images.alt_text: Australia and India, along with the US and Japan, are members of the so-called Quad – a group of democracies that have been ramping up security and economic ties to counter China’s growing influence.

Seven listed firms of the Adani Group have shed some US$125 billion in market value since the report which alleged improper use of tax havens and stock manipulation by the ports-to-energy conglomerate.
Activists from the Hindu right-wing organisation Hindu Sena protesting outside the BBC office in New Delhi, India, 15 Feb 2023.

site_title: New Zealand records strongest population growth in three years as border reopens
summary: New Zealand recorded its strongest population growth in three years, with a net inflow of migrants contributing to a 0.4% increase in the estimated population of 5,151,600. The quarterly inflow of 16,300 migrants is the highest since early 2020, and the population's natural increase was 5,300. This growth lifts the population to its highest level since the first quarter of 2020. The reopening of the border has eased labour market tightness, reducing the need for interest-rate increases.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS initiates coverage on Hotel Properties Limited, portfolio primed for revenge travel
summary: DBS initiated coverage on Hotel Properties Limited (HPL), recommending a "buy" and a target price of S$4.35. Analysts Elizabelle Pang and Derek Tan expect HPL's RevPAR to reach 109% and 115% of pre-pandemic levels in FY2023 and FY2024, driven by pent-up travel demand. The group's medium-term earnings are expected to lift with completed mixed-use property development projects in London. DBS also noted potential positive catalysts, including unlocking the group's stake in Cuscaden Peak, which could drive an upside to HPL's net asset value and share price.

After a torrid 2022, investors have been betting that a swift recovery in China’s economy will somewhat cushion the impact of a global slowdown and possible recession.

site_title: Hot stock: Sembmarine falls as much as 8.4% following approval of merger with Keppel O&M
summary: Sembcorp Marine's shares fell 8.4% following approval of its merger with Keppel O&M at an extraordinary general meeting, with over 95% of shares voting in favour. The merger was seen as a significant move to create a "premier global player in the energy sector", but also poses risks such as restructuring costs and cost inflation issues. The combined entity's share price activities came after heavy trading volumes, with 307.4 million securities changing hands on the first day of trading.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger

site_title: Asia: Markets swing on lingering rate concerns
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday as traders considered the prospect of more US interest rate hikes to combat high inflation. Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, and Taipei markets rose, while Tokyo, Sydney, and Manila were flat. The Federal Reserve's minutes from its recent policy meeting are awaited to gauge officials' views on their next steps, with some warning of higher borrowing costs and a potential recession. Analysts expect further rate hikes, but some see the market as overly optimistic, with companies facing an earnings recession.

images.alt_text: The tighter policy environment has renewed fears on trading floors that the US economy will tip into recession.

site_title: China quietly pivots from land sale limits to stem housing slump
summary: China is quietly lifting restrictions on land sales by local governments to revive the housing market and boost income. Authorities introduced limits in 2021 to curb speculative bidding, but private developers have largely avoided land auctions. Instead, local governments are stepping up auctions to lure new buyers, with the Ministry of Natural Resources issuing a notice allowing multiple land sales events this year. This shift aims to improve the centralized land supply system and address the financial pressure facing debt-laden cities, with bonds worth 15 trillion yuan due in the next five years.

images.alt_text: The two regulators say implementation of the new rules will leave capital adequacy ratios in the banking sector generally unchanged, though the ratios for some banks would change slightly.

site_title: Multilateralism is still better
summary: The US has continued its isolationist and protectionist policies under the Biden administration, rejecting multilateralism and undermining the global trading system. This includes introducing sweeping subsidies for domestic industries and imposing tariffs on foreign imports. The move risks starting a new trade war, as allies and trade partners view these actions as inimical to their interests and WTO rules. Multilateralism remains essential for achieving shared global objectives, particularly in areas such as environment and public health. The US needs its partners to ensure effective support for Ukraine and sanctions against Russia.

images.alt_text: The US Inflation Reduction Act provides a US$7,500 subsidy to US buyers of electric vehicles, provided they are both made in America and composed predominantly of American parts.

site_title: China’s taking control of LNG as global demand booms
summary: China has become a top LNG importer, sealing the most LNG purchase agreements and becoming the sector's key import intermediary, with firms in China accounting for 15% of all contracts through 2027. China's control over the global market could be a double-edged sword, providing stability during global shortages but also risking supply and price hikes. The country is estimated to have resold at least 5.5 million tons of LNG last year, equivalent to 6% of total spot market volume, making it a significant swing supplier.

site_title: Oil prices little changed, nurse last week’s losses on improved supplies
summary: Oil prices remained largely unchanged in early Asian trade on Monday, following a 4% decline last week. Rising US supplies and forecasted interest rate hikes cooled optimism over China's demand recovery. Brent crude fell 9 cents to $82.91 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 6 cents to $76.40 a barrel. The US Federal Reserve's plans to release 26 million barrels of crude from its Strategic Petroleum Reserve also contributed to the stability of oil prices.

site_title: Indonesia posts 2022 current account surplus on commodity boom
summary: Indonesia posted a current account surplus of $13.2 billion in 2022, the largest since 2009, driven by high commodity prices and exports. The country's exports reached a historic high of $291.98 billion, resulting in a trade surplus of $54.46 billion. However, economists predict a potential deficit in 2023 due to moderating commodity prices and improving domestic economy, with a projected deficit of around 0.5% of GDP.

site_title: Jack Ma spotted in Australia in a nod to Alibaba’s global roots
summary: Jack Ma, Alibaba co-founder, was spotted in Australia, the latest stop on his months-long global tour. This visit comes as signs emerge that Beijing is relenting on its crackdown on Internet giants, following Ma's cession of controlling rights to his Ant Group fintech empire in January. Ma has been on the move since late 2022, visiting Tokyo, Thailand, and Hong Kong. His presence in Australia has emotional resonance, as he spent time with the Morley family in the 1980s, who played a major role in shaping his future.

site_title: Hong Kong finance chief warns of challenges from fiscal deficit
summary: Hong Kong Financial Secretary Paul Chan warned that the city's fiscal deficit poses an obstacle to its economic recovery from the pandemic. A fiscal deficit has accumulated due to a weak external economy, and the city's economy contracted 4.2% in the October-to-December quarter, worse than estimated. Chan stated that the economy is regaining momentum and on the road to normalcy, but investment in the future needs to be supported. A budget presentation by Chan is scheduled for Wednesday as part of efforts to chart a course for a rebound.

images.alt_text: China’s move to reopen borders with Hong Kong, coupled with pent-up demand to travel for the Chinese New Year break, has fuelled the surge in passengers.
Hong Kong's population has fallen by about 187,300, or 2.5 per cent, from the end of 2019 through 2022.

site_title: FWD to buy majority stake in Malaysian life insurer ahead of IPO
summary: FWD Group Holdings, a pan-Asian insurance company, has agreed to buy a 70% stake in Gibraltar BSN Life, a Malaysian life insurer, ahead of its planned initial public offering (IPO). The deal will allow FWD to expand into the Malaysian market, which is the fourth-largest life insurance market by premium in South-east Asia. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the transaction is expected to close in the second quarter. FWD plans to partner with Bank Simpanan to further develop and grow Gibraltar BSN.

site_title: Top profitable Indonesian banks spur Jokowi’s call to rein in margins
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has called for banks to rein in their margins, citing high interest rates that are 4.75% above the policy rate of 5.75%. The largest banks, including state-owned PT Bank Rakyat Indonesia and PT Bank Mandiri, have the widest net interest margins globally, with some as high as 11.99%. The president warned that high margins may impact small borrowers and urged banks to offer more competitive rates to support economic growth. The Financial Services Authority plans to evaluate ideal bank margins.

images.alt_text: Bank Indonesia has held rates for the benchmark seven-day reverse repurchase at 5.75 per cent.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.1% to 3,324.65. Losers outnumbered gainers 75 to 62, with Sembcorp Marine and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit among the most actively traded counters. The US and European markets also declined due to concerns over Federal Reserve rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine was Friday's most actively traded counter by volume, with 324 million shares transacted a day after its shareholders voted in favour of the merger with Keppel Corp's offshore and marine unit.

site_title: South Korea joins space race in tech drive as Russia’s isolation deepens over war in Ukraine
summary: South Korea is preparing a domestic rocket development program as part of its ambitious drive to carve out a larger slice of the global space economy. The country's breakup with Russia will be a blow to Russia's rocket program, one of its strongest post-Soviet industries outside oil. South Korea has successfully launched its first indigenously built rocket and plans to land a craft on the moon by 2032 and Mars by 2045. The country aims to increase its share of the global space economy to 10% by 2045, with a focus on satellite data, navigation, medicine, and energy.

images.alt_text: Virgin Orbit, which normally operates from the Mojave Desert, put plans for a pre-Christmas UK launch on hold amid last-minute snags.

site_title: UK property asking prices show weakest Feb gain on record: Rightmove
summary: UK property asking prices rose by £14 (S$22.50) in February, the smallest January to February increase on record, according to Rightmove data. This minimal increase suggests sellers are pricing their homes realistically amid a slowing market. Compared to a year earlier, prices are still 3.9% higher. Economists forecast a decline in prices, but Rightmove sees this flat price as a positive sign for the housing market, indicating a softer landing than expected.

images.alt_text: Purplebricks posted a loss in the 2022 fiscal year, hurt by the failure of an ambitious international expansion and a change in its business model to make sales agents permanent employees.

site_title: TPG’s Rise Fund leads US$300 million Malaysia education deal
summary: TPG's Rise Fund led a US$300 million investment in the Asia Pacific University of Technology and Innovation (APU) in Malaysia, acquiring a controlling stake in the private university. The investment was made with co-investors including Malaysian funds Kumpulan Wang Persaraan and Employee Provident Fund. APU was previously valued at US$300 million. This marks TPG's second education investment in Malaysia, following earlier investments in Sri KDU, Real Schools, and GEMS as part of XCL Education.

images.alt_text: TPG, which has US$135 billion of assets under management globally, has been expanding in South-east Asia in recent years, including in Malaysia.

site_title: How to assess a B2B marketplace
summary: B2B marketplace platforms, which connect micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises, are expected to account for 40% of the global online retail market within the next five years. However, these platforms require more than just a simple matching exchange, necessitating a range of "managed services" such as escrow accounts, payment terms, and supply chain management. The growth of B2B commerce platforms in emerging economies like South-east Asia and India presents a significant opportunity for investors, with micro businesses accounting for 97% of all businesses in the region and employing 69% of the workforce.

site_title: Gold edges down on firmer dollar, US rate-hike worries
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,837.59 per ounce due to a stronger dollar and concerns over US interest rate hikes. The dollar index rose 0.2%, making gold less attractive for international buyers. Money markets now expect the Federal Reserve to raise rates above 5% by May, with a peak of 5.3% in July. This increases the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, despite gold's inflation-hedging properties.

images.alt_text: Gold is known as a safe investment amid inflation woes, but high-interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Japan to invite Australia, India to G7 summit: NHK
summary: Japan is inviting Australia, India, and potentially Ukraine to its May G7 summit to discuss Ukraine, nuclear disarmament, and climate change. The summit is part of Japan's efforts to counter China's growing influence and strengthen security and economic ties with like-minded democracies. Other countries, such as South Korea and Indonesia, may also be invited, according to local media reports.

site_title: North Korea fires ballistic missiles, warns of turning Pacific into ‘firing range’
summary: North Korea fired two ballistic missiles off its east coast, with the projectiles reaching Japan's EEZ and falling outside its territorial waters. The launches come after a previous ICBM launch off Japan's west coast and joint air exercises by the US and South Korea. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's sister, Kim Yo Jong, warned against increased US strategic assets on the peninsula, stating the Pacific could become a "firing range" if not addressed. The incident raises tensions and poses a threat to regional and international security.

site_title: Facebook-owner Meta to roll out paid subscription
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, is launching Meta Verified, a paid subscription service starting at $11.99/month to authenticate accounts. This move follows a similar initiative by Twitter's Elon Musk. The service aims to increase authenticity and security across Meta's services, marking a shift from its traditional advertising-based business model.

images.alt_text: An exodus of workers since Musk’s acquisition has raised concerns about whether Twitter can sustain its operations and regulate content
Susan Wojcicki, 54, will be replaced by her deputy Neal Mohan, a senior advertising and product executive who joined Google in 2008.

site_title: Goldman strategists see 24% jump in Chinese stocks by yearend
summary: Goldman Sachs strategists predict a 24% increase in the MSCI China Index by year-end, reaching 85, driven by China's economic reopening and windfall profits for businesses. The growth impulse is expected to be heavily tilted towards the consumer economy, with the services sector operating below pre-pandemic levels. This shift from reopening to recovery is expected to drive gains, with earnings growth and delivery becoming the primary drivers of potential gains.

site_title: Australian supermarkets set to capitalise on high inflation, but softer demand ahead
summary: Australian supermarkets Woolworths Group and Coles Group are expected to see growth in their half-year profit due to high inflation and lower Covid-19 costs, but analysts warn of a softer second-half as households face mounting expenses. Higher grocery and energy bills, combined with increased mortgage payments, are squeezing budgets. Analysts predict a cautious outlook for retailer top-lines, with some warning of a potential shrink in sales once interest rates peak.

images.alt_text: New Zealand’s high grocery prices reflect the fact that 2 companies - Foodstuffs New Zealand and the local unit of Australia’s Woolworths - form a dominant duopoly.
Flooding and heavy rain across Australia’s east coast this year have led to shortages of a lot of household staples.

site_title: Current pullback of STI expected to be temporary
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) showed resilience in 2022, with a 4% price gain and an 8% total return, making it the strongest Asian-Pacific and developed index performance for the year. Despite a recent pullback, technical analysis suggests the breakout at the start of 2023 could lead to further gains. The index's golden-cross technical signal, formed on January 5, and the crossover of its 100-day and 200-day Simple Moving Averages on February 1, indicate an uptrending phase. A potential consolidation phase is expected, but the index is expected to hold above the 3,300 breakout level and attempt another push towards the 3,400 resistance level.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, SIA Engineering, Aztech Global, Challenger, Hafary
summary: Singapore Airlines subsidiary Scoot will add nine Embraer E190-E2 aircraft to its fleet, supporting its network growth strategy. SIA shares fell 0.2% on the news. SIA Engineering Company reported a 64.1% year-on-year fall in net profit due to higher group expenditure. Aztech Global saw a 45.9% fall in net profit, while Challenger Technologies declined by 40%. Hafary posted a 187.1% year-on-year profit increase, despite a trading halt for AsiaPhos.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine was Friday's most actively traded counter by volume, with 324 million shares transacted a day after its shareholders voted in favour of the merger with Keppel Corp's offshore and marine unit.

site_title: US says China mulling arming Russia in Ukraine war
summary: The US has accused China of considering arming Russia in its war against Ukraine, citing Secretary of State Antony Blinken's statement that China is "considering providing lethal support" to Moscow, including ammunition and weapons. This comes amid rising tensions between the US and China, following the US downing of a Chinese spy balloon. EU officials have also sounded the alarm over Ukraine's dwindling munitions supplies, warning of a critical situation. The US has warned China that such support would cause a serious problem and strain their relationship.

images.alt_text: China has repeatedly asserted its right to maintain trade with Russia since the war started.
US Navy sailors recover the downed Chinese surveillance balloon off the coast of South Carolina on Feb 5, 2023. China has accused the US of more than 10 illegal flights into Chinese airspace.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH initiates coverage on Delfi with ‘buy’
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) initiated coverage on Delfi with a "buy" call and target price of S$1.42, citing the confectionary's undervalued status at 11 times of the brokerage's estimates for FY2023. The analysts expect Delfi's earnings to grow 20% in FY2022 and 10% in FY2023, driven by premiumisation trends and a strong cash flow. The stock is valued at 17 times price-to-earnings ratio and has a 5% dividend yield, with a possibility of a special dividend.

site_title: Golden Energy’s big deal: IFA evaluation of exit offer warrants closer examination by regulators
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) is set to break up and delist, with a proposed exit offer of S$0.16 per share, sparking concerns from minority investors. Shareholder Jeremy Raper claims the deal undervalues Gear's assets, particularly its 64% stake in Australia-listed Stanmore Resources. Raper urges regulators to examine the deal more closely, arguing that the exit offer should be evaluated separately from the distribution of Gear's stake in Indonesia-listed Golden Energy Mines (Gems). The proposed deal could set a precedent for future delistings, potentially allowing IFAs to justify lower exit offers.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul

site_title: Deutsche Bank criticised by ECB over derivatives probe: FT
summary: European banking regulators, including the European Central Bank (ECB) and German financial supervisor BaFin, have expressed dissatisfaction with Deutsche Bank's internal review into mis-selling foreign-exchange derivatives. The probe, known as Project Teal, found that some employees deliberately circumvented controls to make profits. Regulators cited methodological shortcomings and a slow investigation, suggesting a broader sample of transactions would have been more effective. Only a dozen employees have been sanctioned, with some leaving or receiving bonus cuts. Deutsche Bank has acknowledged taking "appropriate action" and improving its processes and controls.

images.alt_text: The Deutsche Bank headquarters in the financial district of Frankfurt, Germany. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: ‘Ant-Man’ is first big film of 2023 with US$104 million opening
summary: The film "Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania" opened with a domestic box office of $104 million, exceeding Disney's forecast of $95 million. It became the highest opening of the three Ant-Man films, with a global total of $225 million. Despite poor reviews from critics, audiences rated it higher. The film marks the start of a fifth phase for the Marvel Cinematic Universe and features returning stars Paul Rudd, Evangeline Lilly, and Michael Douglas.

images.alt_text: Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania Source: Walt Disney Co.

site_title: Strategy or tactics - which is right for now?
summary: A leader's success depends on strategy, not just tactics. Without a clear strategy, tactics will not lead to a satisfactory outcome. Many people are planning extensively, but their plans often lack direction, resulting in burnout and despair. To achieve success, leaders must raise their eyes above the horizon and define their strategy, bringing tactics into line with it. This requires clarity and a clear vision, rather than just endless planning and activity.

site_title: Beijing wants to meet EU leaders as ties with US fray
summary: China's top foreign policy official, Wang Yi, has called for a meeting of EU leaders, seeking to strengthen bilateral ties amid worsening relations with the US. Wang urged both sides to "bring bilateral exchanges back to pre-epidemic levels" and cooperate on global production and supply chains. The move comes as China lobbies nations to counter US restrictions on chip exports. Wang also met US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, urging a change in handling of the US-China balloon incident.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Optimise your finances with Budget 2023 (Ep 137)
summary: Budget 2023 has provided some financial relief, but experts question its ability to blunt the impact of rising prices. Hugosave CEO David Fergusson emphasizes the need for sustainable financial planning, rather than relying on handouts. The conversation highlights the importance of budgeting, avoiding unnecessary expenses, and exploring alternative investment options. While the budget offers support for lower-income individuals and platform workers, it is not a long-term solution to inflation.

site_title: US plans new Russia export controls, sanctions on key industries
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration plans to impose new export controls and sanctions on Russia, targeting key industries such as defense, energy, and finance. The measures are aimed at preventing evasion and circumvention of existing sanctions, and disrupting support Russia receives from third countries. The European Union may also force banks to report sanctioned Russian assets, and the Group of Seven nations and the EU will step up cooperation on enforcing sanctions. The move comes a year after Russia's invasion of Ukraine and aims to increase pressure on companies helping Russia skirt sanctions.

site_title: Ho Bee Land’s twin-engine growth strategy propels high ROEs
summary: Ho Bee Land, a Singapore-listed property group, has achieved a high return on equity (ROE) of at least 7.5% for nine out of the past 10 years due to its diversified business strategy. The group has successfully transitioned from a predominantly residential development focus to a stronger recurring income business from investment properties. This twin-engine approach has enabled the company to maintain a strong balance sheet and drive good cash flows. Despite a forecasted decrease in FY2022 ROE, the group's revenue and operating profit have increased due to higher sales of development properties and rental income from investment properties.

site_title: Armed with new retail brands, Malaysia malls go all out to court shoppers
summary: Malaysia's malls are experiencing a resurgence in shopping traffic, with many international brands entering the market, including Paris Baguette, Apple, and Shake Shack. According to analysts, occupancy and rental rates have not yet fully recovered from the pandemic, but traffic is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels by the end of 2023. New entrants such as Eslite Spectrum, luxury brands, and Italian jewelry brand Roberto Coin are attracting locals and boosting sales. The Malaysian government's efforts to reconfigure mall spaces and tenant mixes are also contributing to the recovery.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's tourism-related stocks have gained buying interest as analysts expect the Chinese tourists will catalyse the country's economy.

site_title: New Zealand’s a2 Milk expects to incur higher costs in FY23
summary: New Zealand's a2 Milk expects revenue growth in the low double-digits in FY23, lower than its previous forecast of high single-digit growth. The company anticipates increased distribution costs due to a China label transition and challenging headwinds in the China infant milk formula market, driven by declining birth rates. This is largely due to a drop in sales through the company's corporate "daigou" channel, a reseller network for Chinese consumers.

site_title: China refining capital and risk management of commercial banks
summary: China's banking regulator and central bank jointly released amended draft rules to better prevent risks in the country's financial system. The new rules, set to take effect on Jan 1, 2024, will adopt a more differentiated regulatory system for assessing commercial banks' capital adequacy and risk management. The system will divide lenders into three groups based on business scale and risk level, with stricter capital requirements and more information disclosure for larger or riskier banks. Capital adequacy ratios are expected to remain generally unchanged, with slight changes for some banks.

images.alt_text: The PBOC urged fund managers to comprehensively and prudently assess the impact of such major money market funds on investors, the broad capital markets and the financial system.

site_title: Carmaker Stellantis upbeat about future of German brand Opel
summary: Stellantis' Europe chief Uwe Hochgeschurtz expressed optimism about the future of German brand Opel, stating that the brand has great capacity for development and its design centre is one of the most modern in the company. Hochgeschurtz attributed Opel's loss of market share to inadequate transport capacity to deliver cars to sellers, particularly due to the lack of truck drivers. He identified Latin America, Turkey, and North Africa as promising export markets, with Europe remaining the core market. Hochgeschurtz believes Opel can continue to operate as a separate brand.

site_title: Singapore firms gloomier about H1 after poorer Q4 performance: BT-SUSS poll
summary: Singapore firms have become gloomier about their business prospects for the next six months, with the transport and communications sector being the most optimistic. The latest Business Times-Singapore University of Social Sciences (BT-SUSS) Business Climate Survey found that business performance dimmed in the fourth quarter, with all three performance indicators deteriorating. The net balance for profits fell 11 percentage points to -18%, indicating a contraction. This marks a further worsening of performance compared to a quarter ago.

site_title: Even super-prime London property can’t defy market forces
summary: London's super-prime property market, characterized by luxury homes, has shown resilience but buyers and sellers may have overpaid. Despite the market's recovery, those who purchased at the peak may have overpaid, with some owners misjudging their property's value. Historically, house prices and stocks tend to rise, leading to a misconception of market inevitability. Additionally, owners often have a misguided perception of their home's value, making it difficult to accurately assess its worth.

images.alt_text: A sign for online estate agent Purplebricks is pictured outside a property in a residential street in London. According to agents and consultants of both buyers and sellers, quality apartments and houses in London and the south of England are in short supply.
