site_title: Philippines president summons China envoy over laser incident
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr summoned China's ambassador over a laser incident in the South China Sea, where a Chinese coastguard ship directed a "military-grade laser" at a Philippine ship supporting a resupply mission on February 6. The incident has heightened diplomatic tensions between the two countries, following Marcos' state visit to China last month. The Philippine foreign ministry has called on Beijing to stop its "aggressive activities" in the disputed waterway.

images.alt_text: The Philippines says a Chinese coast guard ship directed a “military-grade laser” at its vessel in the South China Sea during a supply mission on Feb 6.

site_title: Automation and labour mobility: Unlocking the pathway to Singapore Economy 2030
summary: Singapore's workforce is shifting towards high-paying roles in the digital economy, driven by Fourth Industrial Revolution technologies. Automation and digital skills are crucial for workforce resilience, with a growing need for workers to upskill and reskill. The government and private sector are investing in initiatives such as the TechSkills Accelerator program and partnerships between industry experts and academic institutions. Low-code platforms and citizen programmers are making technology more accessible, allowing non-technical users to work alongside AI and automate tasks. A holistic approach to workforce resilience is necessary to ride the tide of economic uncertainty and drive sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: Coursera for Business is an online learning platform that helps companies address rapidly evolving training and development needs.

site_title: Why Australia’s economy matters to South-east Asia
summary: Australia aims to deepen its economic engagement with South-east Asia, a dynamic and growing economic region. The Australian government has appointed a South-east Asia Economic Strategy to 2040 to bolster two-way trade and investment between Australia and the 10 Asean member states and Timor-Leste. With a strong track record as a reliable trading partner, Australia offers opportunities for South-east Asia's dynamic markets, including trade diversification, sustainable agriculture, and expertise in education, energy, and mining. The Australian government is committed to working with South-east Asia to build a resilient, clean energy sector and address shared challenges like climate change.

images.alt_text: The RBA has raised rates by 3.25 percentage points since May to the current 3.35 per cent, the highest level since late 2012.

A man walks past the Reserve Bank of Australia building in the central business district of Sydney on June 7, 2022. - Australia's central bank raised interest rates by a higher-than-expected half percentage point on June 7 and warned of more increases, trying to rein in "significantly" increased inflation. (Photo by Muhammad FAROOQ / AFP)
The export windfall has aided Australia’s budget outlook, with both its debt and deficit position among the best in the developed world.

site_title: Budget 2023: Phased raising of CPF monthly salary cap will help employers to adjust
summary: Singapore's Central Provident Fund (CPF) monthly salary ceiling will be raised to S$8,000 by 2026 in four steps, with phased increases starting from S$6,300 in September 2023. This change aims to keep pace with rising salaries and help middle-income Singaporeans save more for retirement. Employers will need to adjust to the added costs, while the government seeks to alleviate immediate concerns for small and medium enterprises.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
For senior workers aged above 55 to 70, total CPF contribution rates will be raised by up to 1.5 percentage points from Jan 1, 2024.
Platform workers who are below 30 years old when the changes are implemented from 2024 will be required to make increased CPF contributions.

site_title: GIC is still exploring China investment opportunities
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC will continue to explore long-term investment opportunities in China, despite stepping up scrutiny of risks. GIC maintains significant exposure to China's large markets and is looking at various industries, including those driven by a rising middle class and China's decarbonization efforts. The fund has not announced any big sales of privately held Chinese companies over the past year and counts large listed Chinese companies in its portfolio. GIC's group chief investment officer has said China's regulatory environment has become clearer, and investors may benefit from investing in small companies in China.

images.alt_text: In the past five years, China (above, Wuhan, in Hubei province) has swung from being a huge source of profit for many firms to becoming nearly uninvestible, amid heavy government interventions and pandemic restrictions. Now it is seeking to jump-start its economy, engage with the world and welcome investors.

site_title: Budget 2023: Upskilling is key, though CPF support for platform workers may ease near-term pain
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 introduces the Platform Workers CPF Transition Support (PCTS) scheme, which will offset part of platform workers' share of the year-on-year increase in CPF contribution rates for four years. The scheme applies to workers earning S$2,500 or less per month, including those from other employment sources. While the short-term measure eases near-term pain, industry observers emphasize the need for upskilling and career advancements to ensure long-term economic welfare. The government is encouraged to expand training and wage subsidies to help platform workers reskill and take up higher-paying jobs.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Platform workers who are below 30 years old when the changes are implemented from 2024 will be required to make increased CPF contributions.
This is part of Singapore’s move to provide platform workers with employee-like protections.

site_title: Colombia's bullfighting custom under fire for animal abuse
summary: Colombian bullfighting, known as corralejas, is under fire for animal abuse, with some politicians seeking to ban the practice. The events, which take place in the Caribbean north, involve amateur bullfighters and spectators entering the ring with bulls, with the risk of injury or death. Lawmakers have submitted a bill to parliament, backed by President Gustavo Petro, to regulate corralejas and tighten rules on animal welfare, after the country's top court recognized the events as a cultural tradition.

images.alt_text: One of the “forcados” literally has the task of grabbing the bull by the horns, suffering powerful headbutts to the stomach as his companions wrestle with the animal.

site_title: World economy faces growing services-trade barriers
summary: The world economy's recovery from the Covid pandemic and war in Ukraine is hindered by governments imposing more restrictions on services trade. The OECD index shows a five-fold increase in new measures in 2022 compared to 2021, affecting audiovisual, computer, and physical infrastructure services. Efforts to liberalize services regulations are being counterbalanced by fresh barriers, including limits on business travel and foreign investments. The OECD estimates that implementing commitments on services regulations could save importers and exporters $150 billion annually. This hinders economic growth and resilience to future shocks.

site_title: Budget 2023: Scheme extensions will help SMEs manage costs, ride through challenges
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced the extension of the Enterprise Financing Scheme and Energy Efficiency Grant until March 31, 2024, to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) cope with rising costs and inflationary pressures. The schemes aim to provide financing and funding assistance to SMEs, with enhanced government risk shares and capped annual assistance of up to $30,000. The extensions are expected to ease pressure on SMEs and encourage financial institutions to continue supporting them.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Finance Minister Lawrence Wong delivered his Budget speech on Tuesday (Feb 14).

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open after mixed inflation data
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on February 14, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 51.84 points, or 0.15%, to 34,194.09, due to mixed inflation data. Consumer prices accelerated in January but at a slower pace than expected, potentially keeping the Federal Reserve on track for moderate interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 10.59 points, or 0.26%, to 4,126.70, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 83.59 points, or 0.70%, to 11,808.20.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Ford to cut one in nine jobs in Europe in electric revamp
summary: Ford plans to cut one in nine jobs in Europe, totaling around 3,800 positions, as part of a global effort to reduce costs and compete in the electric vehicle market. The job cuts, mainly in product development and administration, will be achieved through voluntary programs, primarily affecting sites in Cologne, Aachen, and the UK. This move aims to "revitalise business in Europe," according to the company.

images.alt_text: Ford will begin offering LFP batteries in its Mustang Mach-E model later this year and in its F-150 Lightning plug-in pickup truck next year.

site_title: Hong Kong mandates national security law promotion on free TV, radio
summary: Hong Kong's government has mandated that free TV and radio broadcasters air weekly programs promoting Chinese "national identity" and the national security law, as part of licensing requirements announced by the government. The stipulations come as Beijing works to remould the territory, cracking down on a protest movement that championed a distinct Hong Kong identity. The new rules require at least 30 minutes of programming per week on national education, national identity, and the National Security Law, in addition to existing requirements.

images.alt_text:
A general view shows Mount Nicholson, a luxury housing development, in Hong Kong on November 21, 2017.
Another record price for a home in Asia was set after a Hong Kong residential unit at a mountain-top luxury apartment building was sold for over 70 million USD. / AFP PHOTO / ANTHONY WALLACE

site_title: World Bank most concerned about Lebanon and Tunisia
summary: The World Bank is concerned about Lebanon and Tunisia due to high debt levels and inflation. Lebanon's public debt is becoming "extremely problematic," with people feeling the impact of the financial sector's almost-collapse. Tunisia is experiencing a slow reform drive, while Egypt is making progress with its country partnership framework and plans to sell state companies. The World Bank has committed US$900 million to Egypt and may commit more. Transparency in public debt is crucial for reform, according to World Bank Vice President Ferid Belhaj.

images.alt_text: Children walk through a flooded area due to high tide in Baseco, one of the biggest slums in Manila on Aug 15, 2022. The Vulnerable Group of Twenty (V20) – a group of 55 economies exposed to the fallout from climate change – expect debt service payments to rise to US$69 billion by 2024.

site_title: UK basic pay speeds up but jobs market shows some cooling
summary: Britain's jobless rate held near a five-decade low despite recession fears, while basic pay rose 6.7% in the last quarter of 2022, its fastest growth since 2001. Employment grew, but the labour market showed signs of cooling, with vacancies falling for a seventh time in a row. The Bank of England monitors pay growth as it gauges interest rate hikes, with some economists suggesting more rate hikes may be needed to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The expected median annual pay awards in the UK rose to 5 per cent in 2023 – the highest since CIPD records began in 2012 – from 4 per cent in the previous three months.

site_title: Coca-Cola forecasts upbeat annual profit as demand defies price hikes
summary: Coca-Cola has forecast upbeat annual profit, defying price hikes due to rising costs. The company's demand for sodas remains steady, and its near duopoly in the global carbonated drinks market allows it to raise prices. Shares rose about 1% in premarket trading, exceeding Wall Street expectations. Despite higher freight, commodity, and labor costs, Coca-Cola's profit growth is expected to outpace expectations, driven by steady demand for its products.

images.alt_text: PepsiCo said it expects fiscal 2023 core constant currency earnings of US$7.20 per share, compared with estimates of US$7.28.

site_title: Jobs figures send euro, sterling higher; US dollar slips before CPI
summary: The euro and sterling rose against the US dollar, with sterling reaching an 11-day high at US$1.2192. Eurozone employment increased by 0.4% quarter-on-quarter, exceeding economists' expectations. This data suggests the labour market remains tight, leading to increased expectations of interest rate hikes. Markets are pricing in an 80% chance of a BOE hike in March and a 74% chance of a 50 basis point interest-rate hike by the European Central Bank in March.

site_title: Vista Equity’s Finastra explores US$7 billion banking unit sale
summary: Finastra, a financial technology company owned by Vista Equity Partners, is exploring the sale of its universal banking unit for up to $7 billion. The unit, which generates $1.7 billion in revenue and $500 million in earnings, is being carved out as Finastra prepares for a sale process. Potential buyers include private equity firms and rivals in the financial software space. The sale process is expected to begin in the coming weeks, with Finastra working with a financial adviser. No deal is currently guaranteed.

site_title: Samsung borrows US$16 billion from display unit to fuel investment
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to borrow approximately $16 billion from its display-making subsidiary, Samsung Display, to secure working capital. The loan, valued at 20 trillion won (S$20.9 billion), carries a 4.6% interest rate and matures in August 2025. The move supports Samsung's capital expenditure plans, which are expected to remain unchanged from 2022's $39 billion, despite market challenges. The loan aims to fuel investment in future technology and production capacity, with executives viewing the current market situation as an opportunity for early investments.

site_title: Footwear maker Bata India’s Q3 profit rises on festive season bump
summary: Bata India, a footwear manufacturer, reported a 15% increase in quarterly profit to 831.9 million rupees in the third quarter, driven by a festive season bump. The company's diversification into comfort and casual wear helped boost sales. This is typical for retailers and manufacturers, as the October to December quarter sees a surge in sales due to festivals and weddings.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thailand's Central Bank Governor Veerathai Santiprabhob poses with the Bank of Thailand logo after an interview with Reuters in Bangkok, Thailand, August 5, 2016.  REUTERS/Chaiwat Subprasom/File Photo

site_title: Budget 2023: Higher luxury car tax not expected to slow down car sales
summary: Singapore's 2023 budget introduces higher luxury car tax, with buyers of cars with Open Market Value (OMV) between S$40,000 and S$80,000 facing a 190-250% Additional Registration Fee (ARF) increase. Despite this, market observers expect demand for luxury cars to remain unaffected due to high price inelasticity among buyers. Some retailers anticipate a "rush" of purchases in the short term, but predict buyers will eventually return as they can absorb price increases. The revised ARF structure will apply from the second COE bidding exercise in February 2023 onwards.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
THE Additional Registration Fee (ARF) will be adjusted to better differentiate between higher-end cars. Luxury cars will also be taxed at a higher rate.
Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong arrives in Parliament to deliver this year's Budget statement.

site_title: India tax officers search BBC offices after critical documentary
summary: Indian tax authorities raided the BBC's offices in New Delhi and Mumbai on February 14, 2023, weeks after a BBC documentary critical of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's role in 2002 riots was released. The documentary, which focused on Modi's leadership during the riots, sparked widespread criticism and condemnation from various groups, including the opposition Congress party and media rights advocates. The BBC has cooperated with the tax authorities, but the searches have raised concerns about government intimidation of news organizations critical of the ruling establishment.

images.alt_text: Indian opposition parties hold protests in front of state-owned institutions to highlight what they describe as risks to millions of small investors, due to these entities' exposure to Gautam Adani's companies.

site_title: EU parliament votes to ban petrol car sales by 2035
summary: The European Union parliament voted to approve a ban on new sales of carbon-emitting petrol and diesel cars by 2035, with EU member states set to formally approve the legislation. The ban aims to support the EU's goal of becoming a "climate neutral" economy by 2050. Despite opposition from conservative MEPs, the law passed with 340 votes to 279, with 21 abstentions. Supporters argue the ban will give European carmakers time to switch to zero-emission electric vehicles, while opponents warn of job losses and the impact on the internal combustion engine industry.

site_title: Budget 2023: Boost to Assurance Package, GST voucher scheme to target rising cost of living
summary: The Singapore government will allocate an additional S$3 billion to the Assurance Package, increasing its size to S$9.6 billion. The package will be distributed in cash, account top-ups, rebates, and CDC vouchers to help Singaporeans cope with the rising cost of living. The government aims to provide one-off support measures to address inflation and GST increases. The enhancements will also include increasing the amounts paid via GST vouchers and CDC vouchers.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Vivienne Tay
Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong arrives in Parliament to deliver this year's Budget statement.

For FY2022, Singapore is expected to post a deficit of S$2 billion – or 0.3 per cent of GDP.
MOF expects the enhanced GST voucher cash scheme to benefit about 1.5 million adult Singaporeans in August every year.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2023 in 90 seconds
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong delivered Singapore's 2023 Budget Day speech, introducing an expansionary budget with Valentine's Day-themed measures for those hardest hit by inflation, including seniors, platform workers, and parents. Key announcements include higher stamp duties for higher-value properties, increased support for inflation and cost of living, and a new Enterprise Innovation Scheme to encourage innovation. The government also increased the monthly income ceiling for CPF contributions and introduced new measures to support parenthood and platform workers. Total government expenditure for FY2023 is S$123.7 billion, comprising 18.2% of GDP.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan

site_title: Stubborn Philippines inflation fuels higher for longer rate bets
summary: The Philippines' inflation has reached a 14-year high, prompting the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) to raise borrowing costs by another 75 basis points in upcoming meetings, according to a Bloomberg survey. Policymakers may extend monetary tightening and hit a higher-than-expected peak policy rate, with some analysts seeing an end to rate increases as late as June. Inflation forecasts have been revised upward, with analysts predicting 5.4% average price gains this year, above the initial estimate of 4.4%.

site_title: Budget 2023: new Enterprise Innovation Scheme a ‘bold and sharp’ move needed in these times
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Enterprise Innovation Scheme (EIS) to boost local businesses' investments in innovation, with tax deductions of up to 400% for qualifying expenditures. The scheme includes a cash payout option for less-profitable businesses and will work in conjunction with a $4-billion top-up to the National Productivity Fund to support investment promotion. Observers praise the move as a "potential game-changer" to build a more vibrant economy and better jobs, with tax benefits of nearly 70% being the highest in the world.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Finance Minister Lawrence Wong warned of the major uncertainties ahead for the economy.
Budget 2023: Singapore expects second straight deficit, narrowing to S$0.4b in FY23

The Singapore Global Enterprises initiative, which helps large local enterprises (LLEs) with customised assistance in areas such as innovation, internationalisation and fostering of partnerships with other firms, will receive a S$1 billion shot in the arm in Budget 2023.

site_title: Budget 2023: Singapore to implement global tax floor for corporates on Jan 1, 2025
summary: Singapore will implement a global minimum corporate tax of 15% on multinational enterprises (MNEs) with income exceeding $1.1 billion, starting on January 1, 2025. The Domestic Top-up Tax will raise the effective tax rate to 15% and aims to level the playing field with other jurisdictions. The country will also update industry development schemes to remain competitive in attracting and retaining investments. While some experts believe the measures will affect the competitiveness of Singapore's incentives regime, others argue that the tax floor will allow the country to compete on non-tax incentives.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong is expected to announce cost of living support while taking a longer-term view in this year's Budget Statement.

site_title: Budget 2023: Singapore to implement Pillar 2 of BEPS 2.0 tax recommendations from 2025
summary: Singapore will implement Pillar 2 of the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) 2.0 tax recommendations from 2025, requiring multinational enterprise (MNE) groups with annual group revenues of at least 750 million euros to have a minimum effective tax rate of 15%. This move aligns with international efforts to standardize minimum global corporate tax rates for large MNE groups. The government will review and update industry development schemes to maintain competitiveness, while providing companies with sufficient notice before any changes to tax rules or schemes.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

site_title: Thai central bank wants to see household debt below 80% of GDP
summary: The Bank of Thailand aims to reduce household debt levels below 80% of GDP to mitigate economic and financial risks. Currently, Thailand's household debt stands at 86.8% of GDP, and if left unchecked, it is projected to reach 84% by 2027. The central bank plans to introduce responsible lending rules in the third quarter of this year and consult on interest rate ceilings for retail lenders. The goal is to promote sustainable debt management and reduce the risk of long-term economic growth and financial stability.

site_title: Budget 2023: Child relief for working mothers will be in fixed amounts from 2024
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 introduces changes to support working mothers, including a fixed tax relief of $8,000 for the first child, $10,000 for the second child, and $12,000 for the third and subsequent children. The government also doubles paid paternity leave from two weeks to four weeks, and increases the Baby Bonus Cash Gift by $3,000. Unpaid infant-care leave is extended to 12 days annually. The government aims to provide more targeted support to families, particularly those with greater needs.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

site_title: Prepare to pay up to enjoy the safety of investing in Singapore property
summary: Singapore has introduced higher marginal Buyer's Stamp Duty (BSD) rates for higher-value residential and non-residential properties. The new rates, effective February 15, tax properties above S$1.5 million and S$1 million respectively at 5% and 6%. This will affect 15% of residential properties and 60% of non-residential properties, with potential buyers of luxury homes and major commercial buildings facing significant increases. The government expects the higher BSD to raise tax revenue, which will be used to fund healthcare needs due to the country's ageing population.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
The higher duties are expected to affect 15 per cent of residential properties.
Property owners in Singapore may need to brace for higher transaction and recurring taxes in the year ahead.

site_title: Budget 2023: Tobacco excise duty increased by 15%
summary: The Singapore government has increased tobacco excise duty by 15% across all tobacco products, effective immediately. The tax hike is expected to generate approximately S$100 million in additional revenue per year. New tax rates range from S$378/kg for smokeless tobacco products to S$446/kg for unmanufactured and cut tobacco. This move aims to discourage tobacco consumption and raise revenue for the government.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Thailand to impose 300 baht entry fee for foreign travellers from June as tourism booms
summary: Thailand will impose a 300 baht (S$11.8) entry fee for foreign travelers flying into the country, starting June, as part of a plan to collect 3.9 billion baht in fees this year. The fee will also apply to land and sea border crossings. The revenue will be used to provide health and accidental insurance cover for tourists and fund local tourist attractions. Foreign tourist arrivals are expected to reach 30 million this year, up from 11.2 million last year, following the relaxation of pandemic-era curbs and China's Zero-Covid policy.

site_title: Taiwan to reopen borders to Hong Kong, Macau residents next week
summary: Taiwan plans to reopen its borders to Hong Kong and Macau residents starting February 20, allowing Hong Kong residents to apply for temporary stay permits. This move is part of Taiwan's easing of Covid-19 prevention measures, but mainland visitors still face restrictions. The reopening was under evaluation for a long time, with Deputy Minister Liang Wen-chieh stating that cross-Strait relations are expected to improve in the spring.

images.alt_text: People wearing masks to prevent the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), walk past shops at Taipei’s Taoyuan International Airport, in Taiwan, October 23, 2020. REUTERS/Ben Blanchard/ File Photo

site_title: Silverlake Axis half-year profit up 5%
summary: Silverlake Axis reported a 5% increase in profit after tax for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, to RM99.7 million, driven by higher contributions from project-related revenue segments. Revenue grew 9% to RM392.3 million, with software licensing revenue increasing 39% to RM56 million. The company expects to continue investing in cloud and AI technologies to expand its suite of solutions, despite macroeconomic challenges.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Andrew Tan, SAL’s group managing director, said: “We are confident of our prospects going into the new financial year and while there are multiple headwinds that potentially can affect our continued growth, we are prepared and have the right mix of products and project delivery to meet any challenges. "
Google Cloud grew 32 per cent, the slowest rise since the company began reporting the measure in 2019.
The telegraph and telephone in the 19th century, and later, containerised shipping and better infotech, allowed multinational companies to subcontract ever more tasks to ever more places.

site_title: Sembmarine says fully virtual EGM ‘most practical and effective’ way to vote on Keppel O&M merger
summary: Sembmarine has chosen a fully virtual extraordinary general meeting (EGM) for its proposed merger with Keppel's offshore and marine unit, citing logistical difficulties and the risk of Covid-19 transmission among shareholders. The company believes this approach will allow the largest number of shareholders to participate, contrary to a suggestion to delay the meeting until an in-person option is available. The EGM will take place on February 16, and the company has addressed concerns from shareholders through public dialogues and responses.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

Holding general meetings in person allows shareholders to interact not just with the company's directors and management, but also with other shareholders, says Sembcorp Marine shareholder Mano Sabnani.
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger
The queries from SIAS come ahead of Sembmarine’s extraordinary general meeting (EGM) next Thursday (Feb 16) where shareholders would vote on the proposed merger.
Sembmarine said its independent directors recommend that shareholders vote in favour of its merger with Keppel O&M.

site_title: Budget 2023: New job-skills integrators to optimise training, job placement in certain sectors
summary: Singapore's government plans to pilot a scheme to develop labour market intermediaries, or Job-Skills Integrators, to bridge skill gaps and optimize training and job placement in precision engineering, retail, and wholesale trade industries. These intermediaries will link industry, training, and employment partners to ensure training translates into positive outcomes. The pilot scheme will focus on mature workers and small- to medium-sized enterprises, and the government has full confidence and support for the mission to stay relevant.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Singapore shares buck regional gains on Tuesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) slipping 6.5 points to 3,318.20, amid traders' cautious stance ahead of US inflation data. Losers outnumbered gainers 252 to 248 on the wider bourse, with 1.2 billion securities worth S$880.4 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
NetLink NBN Trust will explore opportunities in overseas telecoms infrastructure businesses.
Worldwide Flight Services is being acquired by Sats, pending regulatory approval.
On the Singapore Exchange, gainers outnumbered losers 76 to 41 after 41 million securities worth S$45.3 million changed hands.

site_title: Malaysia to cut subsidies to manage ballooning debt: Anwar
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim plans to cut subsidies to manage the country's ballooning debt, which stands at about RM1.5 trillion (S$459.2 billion), or 82% of its GDP. Instead of introducing a goods and services tax, Anwar will focus on improving governance and reducing public spending, particularly for the wealthy. The government will also review public spending without burdening the poor. Anwar's revised 2023 budget will be tabled to parliament on February 24, aiming to tackle the nation's rising debt levels through subsidy reduction and good governance.

images.alt_text: Anwar is expected to present a revised government budget on Feb 24.
The premier’s approval rating stood at 68 per cent, just two months after the country’s general election resulted in a hung parliament last November.

site_title: 'Rebirth' in Rio as carnival street parties return
summary: Rio de Janeiro's Carnival is making a full comeback after a three-year hiatus due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The iconic street parties, known as "blocos," have returned, with thousands of people parading through the city's hillside neighborhoods. This year's festivities were watered down in 2022 but have now resumed to their usual scale, bringing joy to locals like Brazilian domestic worker Vera Lucia da Silva, who described street carnival as "everything that's good in life."

images.alt_text: This year marked the return of Children for Children to a physical event after two years of virtual activities due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Budget 2023: More support to lower-income platform workers when CPF contributions kick in from 2024
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced in the Budget 2023 speech that platform workers below 30 years old will be required to make increased CPF contributions when the changes kick in from 2024. The government will provide CPF transition support for the first four years after implementation to help platform workers cope with lower take-home pay. This move comes after the government accepted recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Platform Workers to align CPF contribution rates with those of employees and employers over five years.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The government is looking to better integrate the common functions across the different programmes that support lower-income families, and deliver them through the Social Services Offices.
MOF will top up the ElderCare fund by S$500 million to support means-tested subsidies for seniors who need home-based, centre-based or institutional care.
For senior workers aged above 55 to 70, total CPF contribution rates will be raised by up to 1.5 percentage points from Jan 1, 2024.

site_title: Chinese chip designer Unisoc seeks to raise 10 billion yuan in private funding
summary: Chinese chip designer Unisoc is seeking 10 billion yuan (S$1.9 billion) in private funding, valuing the company at 70 billion yuan (S$13.6 billion). The funding round, expected to close by the end of June, will be approached by state-backed investment funds amid China's push for domestic chip self-sufficiency. Unisoc competes with Qualcomm, MediaTek, and Samsung Electronics, offering mobile processors for smartphones and simpler chips for Internet-connected devices.

site_title: Sats’ acquisition target WFS posts 58.7 million euros in adjusted Ebitda for Q4
summary: Worldwide Flight Services (WFS), an acquisition target of Singapore's Sats, posted 58.7 million euros in adjusted Ebitda for Q4, a 16.5% jump. Revenue rose 19.9% year-over-year to 514.4 million euros, driven by strong performance from ground handling and ancillary services. Cargo accounted for 74.9% of turnover, with ground handling and ancillary services making up the remaining portion. The acquisition by Sats is pending regulatory approval.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

site_title: Budget 2023: CPF monthly salary ceiling raised to S$8,000 by 2026; senior worker contribution rate to rise
summary: Singapore's government is raising the Central Provident Fund (CPF) monthly salary ceiling from S$6,000 to S$8,000 by 2026 to keep pace with rising salaries. The move will also increase senior worker contribution rates by up to 1.5 percentage points from 2024. Employers will receive a one-year CPF Transition Offset to mitigate business costs. The minimum CPF monthly payout for seniors on the Retirement Sum Scheme will also be increased to S$350 a month.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Arguably, an increase in CPF contribution is a matter of when, not if.
Platform workers who are below 30 years old when the changes are implemented from 2024 will be required to make increased CPF contributions.
The PWCS provides transitional support for employers from 2022 to 2026, and encourages employers to voluntarily raise the wages of their lower-wage employees.
MOF will top up the ElderCare fund by S$500 million to support means-tested subsidies for seniors who need home-based, centre-based or institutional care.

site_title: Budget 2023: Child relief for working mothers to be fixed from 2024
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced changes to tax reliefs for working mothers in the 2023 Budget. Starting in 2024, higher-income mothers will receive a fixed amount of tax relief for children, rather than a percentage of their income. The government will also allow the foreign domestic worker levy tax relief to lapse from the year of assessment 2025. These adjustments aim to provide more relief to working mothers while ensuring the sustainability of the tax system.

site_title: Budget 2023: Higher marginal ARF rates for cars with OMV of more than S$40,000
summary: Singapore's Additional Registration Fee (ARF) rates will be adjusted to differentiate between higher-end cars, with luxury cars taxed at a higher rate. The rate for cars with an open market value (OMV) of over S$80,000 will increase to 320% of the OMV, while those between S$40,001 and S$60,000 will face a 190% rate. The changes, expected to affect the top one-third of cars by OMV, are expected to generate S$200 million in additional revenue per year.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
The higher duties are expected to affect 15 per cent of residential properties.

site_title: Budget 2023: FY2022 fiscal deficit revised down to S$2b; FY2021 posts surplus instead of deficit
summary: Singapore's fiscal deficit for FY2022 was revised to S$2 billion, down from an earlier estimate of S$3 billion, thanks to higher-than-expected tax takings and increased spending. Total expenditure for FY2022 was revised to S$107 billion, higher by S$4.5 billion or 4.4% than the original estimate. The FY2021 fiscal surplus was S$1.9 billion, largely due to higher operating revenue and lower total expenditure. The government's fiscal deficit narrowed to S$4.2 billion excluding non-cash adjustments.

images.alt_text: A weaker economic outlook weighs on businesses and households, but handouts will need to be carefully calibrated, with a continued eye on longer-term needs, economists said.

site_title: Budget 2023: S$300 million top-up to ComCare Endowment Fund to help needy families
summary: Singapore's government has allocated S$300 million to boost the ComCare Endowment Fund, supporting lower-income families with basic living expenses. The move aims to integrate common functions across social assistance schemes and deliver them through the Social Services Offices. Additionally, initiatives such as ComLink and Kidstart will be expanded nationwide, providing support for families with children. The government also plans to create 22,000 more full-day childcare places and expand Ministry of Education kindergartens. These measures aim to help families meet basic needs and work towards stability and self-reliance in the high-inflation environment.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The PWCS provides transitional support for employers from 2022 to 2026, and encourages employers to voluntarily raise the wages of their lower-wage employees.
Additional one-off measures will be introduced this year, including a Cost-of-Living Special Payment of between S$200 and S$400 for eligible adult Singaporeans.

site_title: Budget 2023: Tax deduction for donations extended again; volunteer scheme enhanced
summary: The Singapore government has extended tax incentives and enhanced existing schemes to encourage charitable giving and corporate volunteerism. The 250% tax deduction for qualifying donations to institutions of a public character will be extended until the end of 2026. The Corporate Volunteer Scheme will also be expanded to include virtual volunteering activities and increase the cap on qualifying expenses for institutions to S$100,000.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Platform workers who are below 30 years old when the changes are implemented from 2024 will be required to make increased CPF contributions.

The government is looking to better integrate the common functions across the different programmes that support lower-income families, and deliver them through the Social Services Offices.

site_title: Credit Suisse leads US$65 million funding for digital-asset firm
summary: Taurus, a Swiss firm developing market infrastructure for digital assets, has raised $65 million in an equity round led by Credit Suisse Group. The funding will be used to hire more staff, develop technology, and expand internationally. Other investors include Deutsche Bank, Pictet Group, and Arab Bank Switzerland. The deal values Taurus at several hundred million dollars, despite the prolonged crypto winter. This investment shows larger financial institutions are sticking with digital assets, with plans to develop blockchain technology offerings and launch a digital assets custody service with Taurus.

site_title: Budget 2023: Progressive Wage Credit Scheme to get S$2.4 billion top-up
summary: The Singapore government will increase its co-funding share for the Progressive Wage Credit Scheme (PWCS) by up to 25 percentage points in 2023, providing up to S$2.4 billion in support. The scheme encourages employers to raise wages of lower-wage employees and offers two tiers of support: 75% for wages up to S$2,500 and 45% for wages above S$2,500. The government aims to support employers from 2022 to 2026 and promote fair wages for lower-wage workers.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Budget 2023: Buyer’s Stamp Duty hike unlikely to hurt property demand; some see it as wealth tax
summary: Singapore introduces a higher marginal Buyer's Stamp Duty (BSD) for higher-value residential and non-residential properties, effective Feb 15. The change is expected to generate S$500 million in additional revenue annually. The BSD hike will primarily affect 15% of residential properties and 60% of non-residential properties, with higher tax rates ranging from 4% to 6%. Market watchers believe the move will not significantly impact property demand, particularly for big-ticket deals and luxury properties, as wealthy buyers are not deterred by the extra BSD.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

Amid the current supply crunch of Build-To-Order flats, the government will give first-timer families with children and young married couples aged 40 years and below an additional ballot for their BTO flat applications starting later this year, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong on Tuesday (Feb 14).

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore introduces a higher marginal Buyer's Stamp Duty (BSD) for higher-value residential and non-residential properties, effective from Feb 15, 2023. The BSD rate increases to 5% for properties valued between S$1.5 million and S$3 million, and 6% for those valued above S$3 million. This is an increase from the current 4% rate. The change aims to discourage speculation and encourage more affordable housing.

images.alt_text: Generic properties in Singapore

site_title: Japan’s weak GDP rebound poses challenge for BOJ’s exit path
summary: Japan's economy rebounded less than expected in the fourth quarter of 2022, expanding 0.6% annually, despite averting a recession. The economy grew 1.1% in 2022, down from 2.1% the previous year. The weak GDP rebound poses a challenge for the Bank of Japan's exit path from its massive stimulus program, as inflation exceeds its 2% target. Analysts expect uncertainties over the global economic outlook to weigh on Japan's delayed recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: The expected appointment of Ueda came as a surprise to many investors who expected the job to go to a career central banker like deputy governor Masayoshi Amamiya.
In Japan, mortgage holders haven’t had to worry about rising interest rates for more than a decade, with the central bank keeping borrowing costs at rock-bottom levels to combat deflation.

site_title: Budget 2023: New tax incentive scheme for donors with family offices
summary: Singapore has introduced a new Philanthropy Tax Incentive Scheme for Family Offices, allowing donors with family offices to claim a 100% tax deduction for overseas donations through qualifying local intermediaries. The scheme caps the deduction at 40% of the donor's statutory income, with donors required to have a fund under the Monetary Authority of Singapore's section 13O or 13U schemes and meet incremental business spending of S$200,000. More details will be provided by MAS by the end of June 2023.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Budget 2023: Singapore expects second straight deficit, narrowing to S$0.4b in FY23
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 is expected to run a second consecutive deficit of S$0.4 billion, or 0.1% of GDP, as the government shifts from pandemic management to addressing cost of living and global uncertainties. The budget includes S$10.2 billion in basic deficit, driven by an expansionary stance, and S$3.6 billion overall balance when including contributions from invested reserves. The government plans to reduce the size of the Contingencies Funds via a Constitutional amendment, and may introduce further hikes to income taxes or NIRC to balance the budget.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
A general view shows the city skyline in Singapore on December 1, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Combining government expenditure, operating revenue and net investment returns contribution projections, government spending will likely be balanced by total revenue in the coming years.

site_title: Budget 2023: First-time homebuyers to get up to S$30k in increased CPF housing grants, additional BTO ballot
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced measures to support first-time homebuyers, increasing CPF Housing Grants by up to S$30,000 for eligible families and singles buying resale flats, and providing an additional BTO ballot for specific groups, including first-timer families with children and young married couples aged 40 and younger. The increased grant amounts kick in for applications submitted on or after Feb 14, with the new amounts set to take effect from April this year.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The highest transacted price for a HDB flat in January comes from a five-room unit at The Pinnacle @ Duxton, which was sold for about S$1.3 million.

site_title: Like Finland, imagine everything that could go wrong
summary: Natural disasters, such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions, can have devastating consequences, resulting in loss of life and property. While we cannot prevent these events, we can prepare for them by anticipating and planning for the worst. According to Italian author Niccolò Machiavelli, "constructive paranoia" involves being prepared for bad luck and taking proactive measures to mitigate its effects. Countries like Finland, Vietnam, and Australia have successfully implemented measures to prepare for disasters, including enforcing seismic construction codes and stockpiling essential supplies. The international community should learn from these examples and take proactive steps to prepare for future disasters.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker checks steel coils at a steel collection facility in Tokyo August 19, 2009. Japan's crude steel output dropped 24.9 percent in July from a year earlier to 7.66 tonnes, falling for the tenth straight month, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said on Wednesday.    REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Budget 2023: Paid paternity leave to be doubled to four weeks from Jan 2024
summary: Singapore will double paid paternity leave from two weeks to four weeks starting January 2024, on a voluntary basis for now, with employers reimbursed by the government for the additional two weeks. Unpaid infant care leave for each parent will be extended from six days to 12 days annually. The changes aim to increase parental leave for working couples, with the total leave period potentially reaching up to 26 weeks in the child's first year.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

Ms Low Mei Lin, with her son Julian, and daughter Lauren at their home in Dover Rise. The business functions solutions and market development director at Polycom has been working from home every day for the past five months. All the company’s employees in Singapore can choose to work from home or other locations as well.
A 5-day-old baby boy at home on Nov 11, 2019.
A breastfeeding mother expressing milk at her desk at work.
Alex Gable, who was laid off from his job while on paternal leave, with his son, in Washington, Feb. 1, 2023.

site_title: Budget 2023: More support for employing persons with disabilities, ex-offenders
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced enhanced support for companies that employ persons with disabilities (PWDs) and ex-offenders in the 2023 budget. The Enabling Employment Credit will now cover a larger proportion of wages for PWDs, and a new Uplifting Employment Credit will be introduced to encourage companies to hire ex-offenders, offering time-limited wage offsets. The schemes aim to provide opportunities for PWDs and ex-offenders to gain employment, with outcomes to be reviewed in 2025.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Budget 2023: New scheme enhances tax deductions for innovation activities
summary: Singapore is introducing a new Enterprise Innovation Scheme, raising tax deductions for five key innovation activities to 400% of qualifying expenditure. The activities include research and development, intellectual property registration, and innovation with polytechnics and Institutes of Technical Education. Businesses can also convert 20% of their qualifying expenditure into a cash payout. The government aims to encourage businesses to boost innovation, with tax savings of nearly 70% possible. The scheme is designed to support companies that have yet to turn profitable or have insufficient profits to maximize benefits.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The enhancements to the EFS include trade loans, working capital loans and support for domestic construction projects via project loans, which saw extensions from Mar 31 this year to Mar 31, 2024.
Investments will include supporting businesses here in building new capabilities, adding greater value to the domestic ecosystem, and upskilling workers.
Companies like Moderna are examples of  investments in companies that can build their solutions around long-term trends and enduring behaviours.

site_title: China must fix business confidence post-covid zero: EU chamber
summary: European businesses in Shanghai are urging China to restore foreign investment confidence and repair international ties following the end of Covid Zero. The European Chamber of Commerce's Shanghai chapter recommends eliminating barriers to investment, promoting the yuan's internationalization, and strengthening financial support for smaller companies. Foreign businesses slowed down investments in China in 2022 due to lockdowns, housing slumps, and rising geopolitical tensions, with net foreign direct investment falling 20% below 2021 levels. The Chinese government has expressed confidence in improving the foreign investment outlook, but the uncertainty remains a concern.

site_title: Budget 2023: S$4 billion top-up for National Productivity Fund
summary: Singapore's National Productivity Fund will receive a S$4 billion top-up as part of Budget 2023, with investments focusing on businesses building new capabilities, upskilling workers, and adding value to the domestic ecosystem. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that these efforts aim to lead to better-paying jobs for Singaporeans. This is the third S$1 billion injection to the NPF, following previous increases in 2017 and 2023.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

site_title: Budget 2023: Enhancements to enterprise financing schemes, Energy Efficiency Grant extended to Mar 2024
summary: The Singapore government will extend the Enterprise Financing Scheme (EFS) and Energy Efficiency Grant (EEG) for another year, until March 31, 2024, to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with tighter financial conditions and higher energy prices. The EFS enhancements include trade loans, working capital loans, and project loans for domestic construction projects, with a 70% government risk share maintained.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
There is a need for fiscal consolidation on the government’s part, after a “substantial” amount of fiscal bullets were used during the pandemic, said DBS senior economist Irvin Seah.

site_title: Fave co-founder Joel Neoh leaves company
summary: Fave co-founder and CEO Joel Neoh is leaving the company on March 1, handing over business operations to co-founder Yeoh Chen Chow and general managers Avantika Jain and Aik Kuang Heng. Despite Neoh's departure, Fave has reported its highest ever transaction volume and 40% quarter-on-quarter growth in 2022. Neoh will contribute to Southeast Asia's technology ecosystem, having previously founded Says.com and Groupmore. Fave was acquired by Pine Labs for US$45 million in 2021.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: The ethics of AI tools like ChatGPT can’t be an afterthought
summary: The ethics of AI tools like ChatGPT are being overlooked as investment dollars pour into the technology. Despite its capabilities, ChatGPT has been accused of having biases, including a "woke" bias and perpetuating racist enquiries. The tool's creators and users acknowledge that AI models are prone to biases due to the data used to train them and the algorithms applied. To address this, researchers are pushing for "explainable AI" and increased funding for data privacy efforts, as the technology's massive data consumption raises concerns about sensitive information handling.

images.alt_text: Microsoft-backed OpenAI’s hit chatbot ChatGPT has become the fastest-growing consumer application in history and is rapidly raising awareness in China about how advanced US AI is.
Prompted by worries about plagiarism, ChatGPT has already been banned in schools in New York and Seattle, according to media reports.
The battle for Internet search

site_title: Budget 2023: More cash and support measures to cushion impact of GST hike
summary: The Singapore government is allocating an additional S$3 billion to the Assurance Package (AP), increasing its size to S$9.6 billion to help Singaporeans cope with the impact of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike. The package will provide cash payouts, account top-ups, rebates, and Community Development Council (CDC) vouchers. Key measures include a Cost-of-Living Special Payment of S$200 to S$400 for eligible adult Singaporeans and a doubling of U-Save Rebates for households. The government aims to cushion the impact of the GST hike on households for at least five years.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Finance Minister Lawrence Wong warned of the major uncertainties ahead for the economy.
MOF expects the enhanced GST voucher cash scheme to benefit about 1.5 million adult Singaporeans in August every year.
A weaker economic outlook weighs on businesses and households, but handouts will need to be carefully calibrated, with a continued eye on longer-term needs, economists said.

site_title: VinFast founder has no plans to inject more money into EV maker
summary: VinFast's billionaire founder, Pham Nhat Vuong, has no plans to personally invest more money in the electric vehicle maker, despite the company's financial struggles. VinFast has lost billions of dollars in 2021 and expects to incur operating losses in the near term. The company plans to continue construction of its US factory, but has delayed deliveries, and has cut staff in North America. VinFast aims to produce 1.1 million vehicles annually by 2026 and currently has nearly 70,000 reservations for its models.

images.alt_text: VinFast is gearing up to expand in the US, where it hopes to compete with existing automakers.

An electric vehicle from VinFast, a Vietnamese automaker producing electric cars and SUV on display at a showroom in California. Last December, VinFast filed for a US listing, which was once reported to help the company raise about US$2 billion.

site_title: Budget 2023: Baby bonus cash gift upped by S$3,000 for eligible Singaporean children born from Feb 14
summary: The Singapore government has announced an extension of the Baby Bonus Cash Gift, increasing the one-off payment to S$3,000 for eligible children born between Oct 1, 2022, and Feb 13, 2023. The grant will be disbursed in the second half of the year. Additionally, the government will increase its contributions to the Child Development Account to offset preschool and healthcare expenses.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
A 5-day-old baby boy at home on Nov 11, 2019.

site_title: Fighting back against plastic pollution of the oceans
summary: A joint pilot project by Wartsila and Carnival Corporation aims to reduce plastic use in marine operations, aiming to boost maritime sustainability and lower CO2 emissions. The project involves replacing plastic packaging with recycled-paper material, resulting in a 40% reduction in plastic use. The companies plan to implement the change for deliveries to Wartsila customers in both marine and energy sectors, aligning with the International Maritime Organization's goal of achieving zero plastic waste discharge by 2025.

images.alt_text: A year's worth of washed-up plastic from one small beach, ready to be taken away for disposal.

site_title: Budget 2023: S$1 billion top-up to Singapore Global Enterprises initiative; S$150 million for SME co-investments
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 includes a S$1 billion top-up for the Singapore Global Enterprises initiative, aiming to develop a "healthy pipeline" of internationally successful companies. The initiative will provide customized assistance in innovation, internationalization, and partnership-building. Additionally, S$150 million will be allocated to the SME Co-Investment Fund, which has already co-invested S$1 billion in 60 Singapore-based companies, leading to over S$2 billion in private sector investments and a doubling of total revenue for these companies.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Tax deductions for five innovation activities will be raised to 400 per cent of qualifying expenditure.
In total, EnterpriseSG supported 18,100 Singapore companies in 2022, to deepen their capabilities in productivity, innovation and internationalisation.

site_title: Budget 2023: More support for employers hiring senior workers
summary: Singapore's government plans to encourage employers to hire senior workers by extending support for wage offsets and employment grants until 2025. The Senior Employment Credit, which provides wage offsets, and the Part-time Re-employment Grant will be extended. This aims to tap into the skills of older workers and address labor shortages. The move is part of the government's efforts to boost the labor market and support employers in investing in senior workers.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Budget 2023: Government will not draw from past reserves for FY23 Covid-19 expenditures
summary: The Singapore government will not tap past reserves to pay for Covid-19 public health expenditures in FY2023, instead relying on its revenues. The total draw on past reserves from FY2020-FY2022 is expected to be S$40 billion, lower than the initial S$52 billion. The government expects a slight deficit of S$2 billion or 0.3% of GDP for FY2022. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong attributed this prudent approach to drawing on reserves judiciously, citing a tight fiscal position despite the economy's recovery.
