site_title: Budget 2023: Singaporeans to receive up to S$200 more in GST vouchers in 2023
summary: The Singapore government has announced that it will increase the amount of GST vouchers given to eligible individuals. Starting in 2023, those living in homes with an annual value below S$13,000 will receive S$700, S$200 more than before. This amount will increase to S$850 by 2024. The enhanced GST voucher scheme aims to benefit about 1.5 million adult Singaporeans, with the goal of cushioning the impact of the goods and services tax hike. The move is expected to benefit most retirees and lower-income households.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Australia to do more to counter foreign interference: minister
summary: Australia's Home Affairs Minister Clare O'Neil announced plans to "out" foreign interference operations targeting politicians, academics, and community leaders. Foreign interference poses a core threat to democracy, with overseas governments attempting to influence Australian politics and universities. The government will work with intelligence agencies to counter these operations, which include surveillance and collection of sensitive personal information. This move comes amid repaired diplomatic ties with China, which has eased trade blocks on Australian coal and agricultural products.

images.alt_text: The RBA has raised rates by 3.25 percentage points since May to the current 3.35 per cent, the highest level since late 2012.

A man walks past the Reserve Bank of Australia building in the central business district of Sydney on June 7, 2022. - Australia's central bank raised interest rates by a higher-than-expected half percentage point on June 7 and warned of more increases, trying to rein in "significantly" increased inflation. (Photo by Muhammad FAROOQ / AFP)

site_title: China’s economic bonanza from record trade surplus is fading
summary: China's record trade surplus is expected to narrow sharply this year, with economists predicting a 1.4% current account surplus, down from 2.3% in 2022. The slump in exports due to a global slowdown will put pressure on the yuan, potentially leading to a depreciation. The trade slowdown will also dampen business and household income, adding to China's challenges in expanding domestic demand. China's economy may see a trade deficit in 2023, dragging down GDP growth and profits.

images.alt_text: The PBOC is expected to keep policies accommodative in the near term in terms of liquidity injection and credit supply to solidify the recovery.

site_title: GS Building sold to JVA Venture for S$67 million
summary: GS Building, a three-storey industrial building with 18 strata units, has been sold to JVA Venture for S$67 million, exceeding its reserve price of S$65 million. Located at 16, 18 and 20 Lorong Ampas, the freehold site spans 3,426.7 square meters and is zoned Business 1 under the Urban Redevelopment Authority Master Plan 2019.

images.alt_text: GS Building has a land area of approximately 3,426.7 sq m (36,885 sq ft).

site_title: Asian issuers turn to convertible bonds for cheap funding
summary: Asian companies are turning to convertible bonds as a cheap funding option amid high interest rates, with issuance reaching $46 billion in 2022, the lowest since 2016. Companies from Japan to Singapore and Taiwan are tapping the market, with Chinese issuers expected to dominate this year. Convertibles allow companies to borrow at lower rates, and investors can profit from rising underlying share prices. Firms are refinancing convertible bonds before maturity, and high-rated companies are considering equity-linked notes for their cost advantage.

images.alt_text: Bondholders will be entitled to receive a pro rata share of 67,738.6364 shares for each S$250,000 principal amount of bonds, at the initial exchange price of HKD$22.00 for the exchangeables.

site_title: Straits Trading’s secured exchangeable bonds 1.9 times subscribed
summary: Straits Trading's S$370 million secured exchangeable bond offering received applications for 1.9 times the amount on offer, totaling approximately S$700 million in demand. The bonds, listed on the Singapore Exchange, will have interest payable semi-annually starting from August 13, 2023. The proceeds will be used to carry out the company's growth strategy.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Amid higher interest rates, convertible bonds are seen as a cheaper way to raise funds and refinance debt.

site_title: Budget 2023: Higher housing grants may shift demand to HDB resale market: analysts
summary: Singapore's government will increase housing grants for first-time buyers, providing up to S$190,000 in subsidies when buying a resale flat, and up to S$80,000 for those buying a Build-To-Order (BTO) flat. This move aims to alleviate concerns of young families securing their first homes amid the supply crunch in BTO flats. However, analysts predict that the increased grants may lead to rising resale flat prices, with some expecting a 8-10% increase in prices. The increased grants are expected to boost demand in the HDB resale market, particularly for smaller unit types.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Additional one-off measures will be introduced this year, including a Cost-of-Living Special Payment of between S$200 and S$400 for eligible adult Singaporeans.
MOF expects the enhanced GST voucher cash scheme to benefit about 1.5 million adult Singaporeans in August every year.
The enhancements to the EFS include trade loans, working capital loans and support for domestic construction projects via project loans, which saw extensions from Mar 31 this year to Mar 31, 2024.
Finance Minister Lawrence Wong warned of the major uncertainties ahead for the economy.

site_title: 2023: A time to consolidate
summary: In 2023, investors should focus on consolidating their finances to retire well, as cash may not keep up with inflation in the long run. The recent economic downturn has been offset by booming stock markets, with trillions of dollars injected into economies by governments and central banks. However, with governments now seeking to consolidate their finances, investors should consider shifting their focus to inflation-beating assets. This shift is driven by the need to manage national debt and avoid excessive interest payments, making it a logical step for governments and investors alike.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised its main rate by a quarter point on Feb 7.

site_title: Indonesia’s Pertamina Geothermal considers issuing green bonds to fund expansion
summary: Indonesia's Pertamina Geothermal Energy is considering issuing green bonds to fund its expansion, which aims to double its geothermal capacity by 2027-2028 at an estimated cost of US$4 billion. The company's IPO, set for February 20-22, will value it at up to 9.11 trillion rupiah (S$797.2 million). Green bonds are among the funding mechanisms being reviewed, with the company planning to issue them "shortly".

images.alt_text: The IPO comes as Pertamina aims to double its geothermal capacity by 2027-2028, which may cost an estimated US$4 billion.

site_title: George Soros loaded up on corporate bonds ahead of 2023 rally
summary: George Soros' investment firm, Soros Fund Management, has purchased approximately $255 million worth of iShares iBoxx $ Investment Grade Corporate Bond ETF, accounting for 4.4% of its $5.7 billion US equities portfolio. This move comes as yields on fixed-income securities hit multi-year highs, with the benchmark 10-year Treasury yield exceeding 4.3% in October. Soros, 92, has a net worth estimated at $8.5 billion and has been investing in the bond market to take advantage of the highest yields in years.

site_title: Budget 2023: Major uncertainties in year ahead; government to plan for potential downside scenarios
summary: Singapore's economic growth prospects for 2023 remain strong, with expected "positive but slower" growth of 0.5-2.5%, according to Finance Minister Lawrence Wong. However, there are uncertainties and downside risks due to global economic declines, high inflation, and potential escalations in the Ukraine war or Covid-19 variants. Wong emphasized the need to prepare for these risks and develop contingency plans to respond swiftly. Despite this, industries that were hit hard by Covid-19 are seeing continued recovery, and Singapore's 2022 GDP growth was lower than expected at 3.6%.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong delivers the 2023 Budget Statement.
The enhancements to the EFS include trade loans, working capital loans and support for domestic construction projects via project loans, which saw extensions from Mar 31 this year to Mar 31, 2024.
Fourth-quarter  growth in gross domestic product (GDP) came in at 2.1 per cent year on year, moderating from the 4 per cent expansion seen in the previous quarter.

site_title: Examining valuation drivers for China equities
summary: China's offshore listed equity markets have surged nearly 50% since October 2022, more than doubling A-share equities, driven by share buyback programmes from major internet platform companies. The Chinese yuan has strengthened by 7% against the US dollar. Despite the rebound, MSCI China remains below long-run average valuations as the economy reaccelerates. This trend is historically typical, following policy pivots during times of crisis. The reacceleration of the economy suggests China's equities may eventually catch up with long-run valuations.

images.alt_text: The decline in the number of foreign residents living in China was listed as a concern in the report, which said that 25 per cent of Germans living in Shanghai left the city after the 2022 lockdown.

site_title: Air New Zealand to resume flights after cyclone Gabrielle impacts 592 flights
summary: Air New Zealand plans to resume flight services from mid-afternoon on February 14 after 592 flights were impacted by Cyclone Gabrielle. The airline will initially resume turboprop operations but may face challenges due to strong high winds. All domestic flights in and out of Auckland have been cancelled for the remainder of Tuesday. This marks the second significant weather event to hit Auckland and the upper North Island in recent weeks, following record rainfall that caused floods and killed four people last month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An area flooded during heavy rainfall is seen in Auckland, New Zealand January 27, 2023, in this screen grab obtained from a social media video. @MonteChristoNZ/via REUTERS/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam exporters fret over potential trade fallout of US rules on Xinjiang
summary: Vietnam-based exporters are concerned about complying with the US ban on imported products using raw materials from China's Xinjiang, amid the US Uyghur Forced Labour Prevention Act. The US has halted over 1,500 shipments worth $500 million due to alleged human rights abuses in Xinjiang. Vietnam, a major US trading partner, is particularly at risk due to its reliance on Xinjiang for polysilicon, a key component in solar panels. Executives warn that compliance risks exist, especially for smaller companies with complex supply chains.

images.alt_text: The police are seeking information by Feb 20 from Viet Capital Securities about transactions concerning Eximbank shares made by Vietnam Enterprise Investments Limited, a fund controlled by Dragon Capital, which is the biggest foreign investor in Vietnam’s stock market.
The US chip giant already has extra land where its plant is based, and an expansion in Vietnam would help it better manage supply disruptions.

site_title: Riding on agribusiness opportunities as food demand rises
summary: Despite recession fears, the global food and agriculture market remains a necessity, with demand expected to rise as China's reopening drives consumption. China is increasing its foreign grain purchases, while a growing global population and rising middle class create long-term investment opportunities. The sector's resilience is due to its essential nature, and investors can capitalize on these trends, despite current supply chain disruptions and price volatility.

images.alt_text: Last year, testimony gathered by non-profit Human Rights Watch described the prevalence of child labour in the mining industry of the Democratic Republic of Congo, which sits on about 70 per cent of the world’s cobalt.
The Food and Agriculture Organization’s (FAO) price index, which tracks the most globally traded food commodities, averaged 131.2 points last month against 132.2 for December.

site_title: Assessing the odds of a US recession
summary: The near-term odds of a US recession have edged up, according to prediction models based on key monthly and weekly indicators. A probit framework applied to selected economic and financial data suggests a probability of less than 20% through January, but a weekly model indicates a 60% probability through early February. Despite the uncertainty, the US economy is not currently in a recession, with pertinent labor and broader economic data not worsening sufficiently on balance. However, financial indicators suggest a cautionary signal, and the differing views on the terminal rate may risk an abrupt tightening of financial conditions.

images.alt_text: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 13: People shop in a Target store on February 13, 2023 in Los Angeles, California. January's Consumer Price Index (CPI) will be released tomorrow showing the latest inflation data and providing perspective on possible future interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.   Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS Q4 results draw mixed reactions from analysts
summary: DBS' Q4 earnings drew mixed reactions from brokerages, with some raising their target prices and forecasts. UOB Kay Hian lifted its target price to S$45.80, citing lower specific provisions, while RHB Research upgraded its target price to S$42, accounting for lower provisions and a 4% environmental premium. The mixed reactions stem from differing views on DBS' ability to continue expanding its net interest margins.

images.alt_text: XX

site_title: A huge, uncharted experiment on the US economy is about to begin
summary: The Biden administration is launching a massive experiment on the US economy, investing $25.8 billion in hydrogen and renewable energy projects through various laws, including the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, the CHIPS and Science Act, and the climate-focused Inflation Reduction Act. The goal is to create a robust, high-capacity, and re-industrialized economy, but concerns arise about the government's ability to spend the money effectively, coordinate its actions, and understand the companies it's trying to help. The experiment also raises questions about the difficulty of decarbonization and the need for a more nuanced approach to addressing climate change.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden's landmark climate bill, the Inflation Reduction Act, provides billions of dollars in tax credits and other incentives to develop green industries.
Transforming our energy sources from fossil fuels will be one of the largest capital expendi­tures in history.

site_title: Biden to name Federal Reserve’s Lael Brainard as top economic adviser
summary: US President Joe Biden is expected to name Federal Reserve Vice Chair Lael Brainard as his top economic adviser, replacing White House National Economic Council Director Brian Deese, who has announced his resignation. Brainard will oversee economic policy, while Jared Bernstein is expected to replace Cecilia Rouse as chair of the Council of Economic Advisers. The moves are part of a broader shake-up in the White House's economic team.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised its main rate by a quarter point on Feb 7.
Governor Michelle Bowman said restoring price stability is essential to support a sustainably strong labour market.

site_title: Malaysia will not reintroduce goods and services tax: PM
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced that the country will not reintroduce a goods and services tax (GST) or any other broad-based consumption tax. Instead, the government plans to reduce subsidies enjoyed by the wealthy to aid low-income groups, amidst high government debt levels and rising living costs. Anwar, who also serves as finance minister, ordered a review of Malaysia's subsidy programme.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's central bank governor  Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus said the country’s economy is growing at a moderate pace but Malaysia will not go into recession this year.

site_title: China’s wind and solar are now almost enough to power every home
summary: China's wind and solar power output surged 21% in 2022 to 1,190 terawatt-hours, nearly matching residential power consumption of 1,340 terawatt-hours. This growth highlights the rapid expansion of renewable energy in China, but also underscores the country's reliance on industry, which accounts for 60% of electricity needs. Despite clean energy covering most homes, China's generators still rely on fossil fuels to meet growing demand, which is expected to rise with the lifting of Covid Zero restrictions.

site_title: Twilio to cut 17% staff, close offices to focus on profitability
summary: Twilio, a cloud communications company, is restructuring to focus on profitability. The company will cut 17% of its staff and close some offices, dividing operations into two units: Twilio Data and Applications and Twilio Communications. This move is the second instance of job cuts in six months. The restructuring is expected to improve the company's profitability, and shares rose 2% following the announcement.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,336.18, following gains in the US and European markets. The most actively traded counters were Halcyon Agri and Thai Beverage, while local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also rose. The rally follows Wall Street's 1.1% gain ahead of key inflation data and comes after a 5-day rally.

images.alt_text: On the broader local bourse, turnover comes in at 1.2 billion units worth S$1.1 billion; losers outpace gainers 306 to 253.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust H2 DPS rises 13.1% to S$0.0173 as operational performance improves
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) reported a 13.1% rise in its second-half distribution per stapled security (DPS) to S$0.0173, driven by higher net property income, lower finance expenses, and divestment gains. The trust's operational performance improved, with gross revenue and net property income growing 2.2% and 2.3% respectively. The hospitality sector experienced a positive recovery, with improved demand from corporate groups and travelers, leading to higher average daily rates and revenue per available room.

images.alt_text: Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.
The resumption of high-impact events, including the Formula One (F1) race in Singapore, brought throngs of business cum leisure (b-leisure) travellers back to the island.

site_title: FLCT manager’s chief executive steps down for family reasons
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust's (FLCT) manager CEO Robert Wallace is stepping down for family reasons, effective May 31, 2023. Wallace will remain at his post until then to ensure a smooth transition. During his 7-year tenure, FLCT's portfolio value quadrupled from S$1.6 billion to over S$6.6 billion. Wallace's replacement will be announced in due course, and the board chairman praised his strong leadership and dedication to the trust.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
FLCT's property of Blythe Valley Park, a business park located in Birmingham, the United Kingdom.  Its overall occupancy for Q1 FY 2023 came in at 95.9 per cent.
The divestment of Cross Street Exchange, coupled with weaker exchange rates, resulted in a lower year-on-year adjusted net property income and half-year revenue, said the trust’s manager.
Some S$171.7 million has been committed for a forward-funding L&I acquisition in the UK.
Located within the Hooton Business Park in Cheshire in North West England, the property will sit on a 14.4-hectare site and will have a total lettable area of 667,185 square foot.

site_title: Hong Kong property stocks sink over new security clause in land auctions
summary: Hong Kong's property stocks plummeted on Monday as the government added a national security clause to land auctions, affecting major developers. New World Development's shares dropped 7% following the announcement. The clause disqualifies buyers who engage in activities endangering national security or public order. Hong Kong's leader, John Lee, defended the move, stating it's in accordance with protecting national security and has no impact on business decisions. The inclusion of the clause raises risks for tycoons controlling Hong Kong's biggest developers.

images.alt_text: The move by the China Securities Regulatory Commission is to discourage illegal money outflows.

A general view shows Mount Nicholson, a luxury housing development, in Hong Kong on November 21, 2017.
Another record price for a home in Asia was set after a Hong Kong residential unit at a mountain-top luxury apartment building was sold for over 70 million USD. / AFP PHOTO / ANTHONY WALLACE

site_title: Singapore’s Aspire snags US$100 million even as VC market slows
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup Aspire raised US$100 million in a Series C round, more than doubling its valuation. The deal, led by Lightspeed and Sequoia Capital South-east Asia, was struck despite a slowdown in the VC market. Aspire, founded in 2018, provides financial services to businesses, including international payments and invoice automation. The funding round comes at a challenging time for tech startups, with global venture funding in Q4 2022 reaching its lowest level in over two years.

site_title: Gold inches higher, spotlight on US inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,856.01 per ounce as the dollar pulled back, amid anticipation of US inflation data. Investors expect a 0.4% month-on-month increase in the core CPI figure, which may prompt the Federal Reserve to continue raising interest rates. Rising rates decrease gold's appeal, increasing its opportunity cost. Silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, with the International Monetary Fund predicting a strong US economy and China's reopening.

images.alt_text: Physical gold buyers in some Asian hubs were drawn to a dip in domestic prices last week, while central bank demand kept premiums firm in China.

site_title: Walmart to close three tech hubs, relocate staff
summary: Walmart is closing three US technology hubs, including offices in Austin, Texas, Carlsbad, California, and Portland, Oregon, and relocating hundreds of workers to hubs in San Bruno, California, or Bentonville, Arkansas. Nearly all technology employees will work in offices for at least two days a week. The company will cover transfer costs and make severance payments to those who decide to leave. This move follows similar requirements from other US companies, including Disney, Uber, and Starbucks, as they adopt a hybrid work model with a focus on in-office work.

images.alt_text: Walmart is boosting the pay range at US stores to between US$14 and US$19 an hour from the prior US$12 to US$18 an hour.

site_title: New Zealand house prices edge higher in January: Reinz
summary: New Zealand's house prices edged higher in January, rising 0.2% seasonally adjusted from the previous month, but remain 13.2% lower than a year ago. The Real Estate Institute of New Zealand attributed this to high interest rates and lower borrowing capacity, with homes staying on the market longer. Despite this, the pace of decline is steadying, and the market is showing signs of new life, according to Chief Executive Jen Baird.

site_title: Asia: Most markets track Wall Street rally ahead of US inflation data
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, following Wall Street's gains ahead of US inflation data. Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, and other markets tracked the US rally. Despite a bright January, investors are cautious due to the prospect of further Federal Reserve interest rate hikes to control the economy. A recent jobs report led central bank officials to commit to tightening monetary policy. Analysts warn that the optimism might be overdone, and markets await the inflation data release later in the day.

images.alt_text: A man on a bicycle stands in front of an electronic board showing Shanghai stock index, Nikkei share price index and  Dow Jones Industrial Average outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan September 22, 2022. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon

site_title: Lynas faces part closure of Malaysian rare earths plant by July
summary: Lynas Rare Earths, the world's largest producer of rare earths outside China, faces potential part closure of its Malaysian plant by July due to operating licence conditions. The company's unit in Malaysia received an operating licence renewal, but conditions restricting imports and processing of rare earths concentrates will remain in place until July 1. Lynas will need to close its cracking and leaching plant if the conditions are not removed. The company plans to appeal the decision, citing unfair treatment as a foreign investor and significant employer.

images.alt_text: Indian businessman Prateek Gupta and his companies, against whom Trafigura secured a US$625 million freezing order this week, have a checkered history in the trading world.

site_title: Australia’s consumer confidence plunges on RBA tightening signal
summary: Australia's consumer confidence plummeted 6.9% to 78.5 in February, the lowest reading since the early-1990s recession, due to mounting cost of living pressures and expectations of further interest-rate increases. The Reserve Bank of Australia's rate hike of 3.25 percentage points since May has reached 3.35%, the highest level since 2012. Senior Economist Matthew Hassan attributed the decline to stronger-than-expected inflation and the RBA governor's signal of further tightening, predicting a peak rate of 3.85% by May.

images.alt_text: A man walks past the Reserve Bank of Australia building in the central business district of Sydney on June 7, 2022. - Australia's central bank raised interest rates by a higher-than-expected half percentage point on June 7 and warned of more increases, trying to rein in "significantly" increased inflation. (Photo by Muhammad FAROOQ / AFP)

site_title: Britain sets out legislation to regulate buy-now-pay-later credit
summary: Britain is set to introduce legislation to regulate "buy now pay later" (BNPL) credit, aiming to protect consumers from potential harm caused by unaffordable short-term loans. The sector nearly quadrupled during the pandemic, with consumer groups warning that cash-strapped people are getting into debt by using BNPL to buy essentials. The Financial Conduct Authority will be given new powers to authorise operators and their activities, with mandatory affordability checks, licencing, and fair marketing to be considered. The move follows previous warnings from the FCA and a call from consumer groups for urgent regulation.

images.alt_text: The expected median annual pay awards in the UK rose to 5 per cent in 2023 – the highest since CIPD records began in 2012 – from 4 per cent in the previous three months.

The Consumer Prices Index has leapt 11.1 per cent in October and then ticked down to 10.5 per cent in December. Official figures due on Wednesday (Feb 15) are likely to show it remained above 10 per cent in January.

site_title: US military says it recovers key sensors from downed Chinese spy balloon
summary: US military recovers critical electronics from the suspected Chinese spy balloon downed off South Carolina's coast on Feb 4, including key sensors for intelligence gathering. The balloon had flown over the US and Canada for a week before being shot down by a US fighter jet. The incident strained ties between the US and China, leading to an unprecedented three shootdowns of unidentified objects in three days. US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin assured Americans that the objects do not pose a military threat, but present a risk to civil aviation and intelligence collection.

images.alt_text: The suspected Chinese spy balloon drifts to the ocean after being shot down off the coast in Surfside Beach, South Carolina, U.S. February 4, 2023.  REUTERS/Randall Hill

site_title: Green Link Digital Bank hopes to be the China connection for Asean SMEs
summary: Green Link Digital Bank aims to be a key connection between ASEAN small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and China. Chairman Geng Jing sees Singapore as a window to ASEAN, positioning the bank to play a significant role in facilitating trade between the two regions. Since its launch in October, the bank has approved S$50 million in loans to SMEs, with a focus on suppliers to the Singapore government, commodities, and tech companies.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

Green Link Digital Bank aims to expand its service coverage and create more supply chain financing products to cater to business demands from various areas, including high-growth potential industries.
Angel Zhao, president of Ant’s international business group, says e-wallets are a “valuable and effective” channel for digital marketing.
ANEXT is the latest digital bank to be unveiled in Singapore.

site_title: New Zealand declares state of emergency as Cyclone Gabrielle strikes
summary: New Zealand has declared a national state of emergency due to Cyclone Gabrielle, which is causing widespread destruction, power outages, and flooding on the North Island. Tens of thousands of homes are without electricity, and roads are closed in northern regions. The cyclone has disrupted over 45,000 flights, and emergency services are searching for a missing firefighter. The declaration is the third national state of emergency in New Zealand's history, allowing for coordinated emergency response efforts.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit posts 19.6% lower DPU for H2 on vacant investment properties
summary: Elite Commercial Reit reported a 19.6% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) for the half year ended December 2022, resulting from vacant investment properties that led to lower income and higher property operating expenses. Revenue declined 2.5% to £18.4 million, while net property income fell 3.8% to £17.6 million. Despite this, the Reit's portfolio occupancy remained at 97.9% and its gearing ratio stood at 45.8%. The Reit's valuation declined 9.9% to £466.2 million due to market factors, including rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Great Western House, Birkenhead. The 58 properties have a total net lettable area of 1.3 million square feet, and include Great Western House in Birkenhead (pictured), and a building in Newport Road,

site_title: Botched Ntegrator to Watches.com name change is just the tip of the iceberg in its remaking journey
summary: Watches.com, a Catalist-listed company, has reversed its name change from Ntegrator International due to a non-binding letter of intent with the domain name seller Watchismo LLC expiring. The company is seeking shareholders' approval for the name change. Meanwhile, Watches.com faces uncertainty due to ongoing probes by Hong Kong customs and a probe by the Singapore Exchange Regulation over its acquisitions. The company has also suspended trading and appointed a joint independent reviewer to address the issues. Shareholders question the company's diversification strategy and the feasibility of its omnichannel retailing of watches.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Tokyo condo market shows early cooling signs on BOJ policy risks
summary: Tokyo's condo market is showing early signs of cooling due to speculation about rising mortgage burdens and interest rates. The number of existing apartments up for sale in central Tokyo's popular bay area rose for two consecutive weeks in January, with second-hand apartments increasing 30% from a year earlier. Experts attribute the trend to the Bank of Japan's policy tweaks, including widening its cap on 10-year bond yields, and the upcoming replacement of BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda. While the cooling is not yet widespread, it may signal a shift in the market's dynamics.

images.alt_text: High-rise residential buildings in Kachidoki area of Tokyo. Photographer: Kosuke Okahara/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Wall St climbs higher on megacap boost
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 18.12 points, or 0.05%, to 33,887.39. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, driven by gains in megacap growth stocks. Meta Platforms rose on reports of fresh layoffs.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as defence stocks rally, focus on US inflation data
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Monday, driven by gains in defence stocks following India's plan to triple its annual defence exports to $5 billion by 2024/25. The Stoxx 600 index was led by Swedish defence equipment maker SAAB, which jumped 7.4%. The focus on US inflation data later this week is expected to have a lesser impact, with Eurozone economic growth forecast to be stronger than expected this year and inflation expected to be lower than initially predicted.

images.alt_text: UK’s FTSE 100 added 0.6 per cent after data showed the British economy eked out 0.1 per cent growth in November, helped by a boost from World Cup drinkers and video game sales.

site_title: BlackRock cuts Japanese stocks to ‘underweight’ on hawkish BOJ risks
summary: BlackRock Investment Institute downgraded Japanese stocks to "underweight" due to a potential shift in the Bank of Japan's monetary policy. A new BOJ governor, likely Kazuo Ueda, may roll back ultra-loose policies, increasing global yields and reducing risk appetite. This could lead to higher term premiums for long-term government bonds and dampen global risk sentiment. Japan's inflation has reached four-decade highs, fueling wage growth and potentially aligning the country with other major economies in raising interest rates.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies push lower as regulatory pushback spreads
summary: Cryptocurrency markets have declined amid a regulatory crackdown, with most cryptocurrencies lower. Binance Coin dropped 11% to $279.50, while the BUSD stablecoin lost value after the New York State Department of Financial Services directed Paxos Trust to stop issuing new tokens. Other altcoins, such as Cardano and Solana, also fell. Bitcoin remained largely unchanged. The decline comes as investors grapple with the implications of increased regulatory pushback in the digital-asset sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of the Ripple, Bitcoin, Etherum and Litecoin virtual currencies are seen on a PC motherboard in this illustration picture, February 14, 2018. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Crypto exchange-traded products rocketed in popularity during 2021’s boom in token prices.

site_title: Ford is investing US$3.5 billion in EV battery plant with Chinese firm
summary: Ford Motor is investing $3.5 billion in an electric vehicle battery plant in southwest Michigan, partnering with Chinese battery maker Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL). The plant, set to open in 2026, will produce enough batteries to power 400,000 EVs annually and employ 2,500 workers. Ford will own and operate the facility, controlling manufacturing, production, and workforce. The arrangement has drawn criticism over geopolitical tensions between the US and China. The plant will produce lithium iron phosphate batteries, which will make Ford's EV lineup more affordable, helping the company achieve an 8% margin goal on EVs by 2026.

images.alt_text: Ford is moving ahead with the project despite uncertainty around how the US Treasury Department will interpret requirements in President Joe Biden’s signature climate package, the Inflation Reduction Act.
Ford last was involved in F1 in 2003, when it earned its last victory with Giancarlo Fisichella driving in Brazil, and 2004.

site_title: Amazon’s self-driving car shuttles people on public roads for the first time
summary: Amazon's self-driving car startup Zoox has successfully deployed its fully autonomous vehicle on public roads for the first time. The electric vehicle, which doesn't have a steering wheel, carried staff between Zoox's two main buildings in Foster City, California, for a mile-long route. The company plans to expand its service to the public after securing additional clearances, marking a significant milestone in the development of robotaxis.

images.alt_text: Cruise’s plans for aggressive growth come at a time of increased scrutiny targeting self-driving cars.
CEO of Zoox, Aicha Evans said she believes the development of Zoox’s so-called robotaxis is the “beginning of a wave” for autonomous driving.

site_title: US: Stocks rally ahead of January inflation data
summary: US stocks rose on Monday ahead of the release of January inflation data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.1% to 34,245.93. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also climbed 1.1% and 1.5% respectively. Market expectations of moderation in inflation have eased pressure on the Federal Reserve to prolong interest rate hikes, with the 10-year US Treasury yield dipping. Analysts, however, expressed caution ahead of the data, warning of potential price pressures and economic risks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 18.12 points, or 0.05 per cent, at the open to 33,887.39.

site_title: EU countries urged to move toward more prudent fiscal positions
summary: EU Commission Vice President Valdis Dombrovskis urged EU countries to adopt more prudent fiscal positions as the economic outlook improves. The EU raised its GDP growth forecast for this year, citing a mild winter and strong labor market. Dombrovskis emphasized the need to reduce budget deficits to avoid fueling inflation and to prepare for potential interest rate hikes by the European Central Bank. The EU is also reviewing its fiscal rules, aiming to introduce legislative proposals in the coming months. This shift towards fiscal discipline aims to balance economic support with monetary policy tightening.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sats, NetLink, Paragon Reit, Far East Hospitality Trust, First Reit, Food Empire
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean stocks saw new developments on February 14, 2023. Sats reported a reversal in net profit to $500,000 for its third quarter ended December 31, 2022. NetLink Trust increased its profit after tax by 24.2% to $81.8 million for the nine months ended December 31, 2022. Paragon Reit maintained its distribution per unit at 1.72 Singapore cents, while Far East Hospitality Trust rose 13.1% to $0.0173. First Reit reported a DPU of $0.0066, unchanged since the fourth quarter of 2021. Food Empire expected a substantially higher profit after tax for FY2022.

images.alt_text: On the broader local bourse, turnover comes in at 1.2 billion units worth S$1.1 billion; losers outpace gainers 306 to 253.

site_title: US dollar gains on yen as American yields rise
summary: The US dollar rose 1% to 132.76 yen, its highest rate since January 6, as investors bet on the Federal Reserve keeping monetary policy tight. US yields rose to fresh six-week highs, driving the yen lower. The euro fell to a one-month low, while the British pound rose 0.3%. The US dollar index steadied at 103.55, despite expectations that the week's main event, US consumer price data, could challenge or underscore the Fed's tight policy stance.

images.alt_text: As the data continued to show positive US momentum, the US dollar was on pace for its second weekly rise against a basket of six currencies, a run it has not seen since October.

site_title: Beijing to support key firms in building ChatGPT-like AI models
summary: China's Beijing city plans to support key firms in building large artificial intelligence (AI) models comparable to Microsoft-backed OpenAI's ChatGPT. The city's economy and information technology bureau will provide support for firms to invest in an open-source framework and accelerate data supply. Beijing is home to 29% of China's total core AI companies, and the city aims to cultivate talent and conduct research in areas such as ethical governance. The move aims to promote domestic AI development and challenge US AI dominance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A response by ChatGPT, an AI chatbot developed by OpenAI, is seen on its website in this illustration picture taken February 9, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Budget 2023 will strengthen social compact, give assurance for families: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced the 2023 Singapore Budget theme "Moving forward in a new era", focusing on securing the country's prospects in a troubled world. The budget aims to strengthen the social compact, give assurance to families, and build collective resilience. It will include updates to the Assurance Package, a support package for offsetting the effects of the goods and services tax hike, and enhancements based on feedback from the Forward Singapore consultation exercise. The budget will be delivered in Parliament on Tuesday.

site_title: Japan names academic Ueda as next central bank governor
summary: Japan's government named academic Kazuo Ueda as the country's next central bank governor, a surprise choice that could lead to the end of its yield control policy. Ueda, a 71-year-old former Bank of Japan policy board member, will succeed Haruhiko Kuroda on April 8. The move is seen as a shift towards higher interest rates, which could help address Japan's inflation rate, which exceeded the central bank's 2% target. Ueda faces the task of normalizing the ultra-easy monetary policy that has drawn public criticism, and analysts expect him to dismantle the yield curve control policy sooner rather than later.

images.alt_text: Japan’s government is likely to appoint academic Kazuo Ueda as the next Bank of Japan governor when Haruhiko Kuroda’s second term ends in April.

site_title: Amazon CEO doubles down on grocery store business: FT
summary: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy has vowed to double down on the company's struggling grocery store business, citing a lack of normalcy during the pandemic as a contributing factor to recent stumbles. The company has paused expansion of its Fresh supermarkets and cashier-less convenience stores until it finds the right recipe for success. Amazon has closed some grocery shops and impaired certain assets, resulting in a $720 million charge in the fourth quarter. Jassy aims to "go big" on bricks-and-mortar stores, despite the company's failure to dominate brick-and-mortar retail since its 2017 acquisition of Whole Foods Market.

site_title: Freeport Indonesia suspends some work at Grasberg mine after floods
summary: Freeport Indonesia has temporarily halted mining and processing work at its Grasberg mine due to flooding and debris flow from heavy rains and landslides. The damage affected the milling complex, and operations are expected to be restored by the end of February. Despite the disruption, the company's daily output was nearly 5 million pounds of copper and 5,000 ounces of gold. There were no casualties in the recovery effort, and the situation is under control. Preliminary estimates indicate no long-term impact on Freeport Indonesia's plans.

site_title: Adani attack shows need for firms to have a contingency response plan
summary: The Adani Group's attack by Hindenburg Research has raised concerns about the need for companies to have contingency response plans to address market concerns. Short-selling, although not illegal, can have significant effects on companies, particularly those trading at high valuations. Companies should have clear and transparent communication strategies to address concerns and provide shareholders with accurate information. A contingency plan should include halting trading to minimize share price damage, and companies should be prepared to respond quickly and effectively to mitigate the impact of a short-selling attack.

images.alt_text: The scores for “business ethics controversy” for Adani Total Gas and Adani Transmission were downgraded from “low” to “moderate,” the ratings agency said.

site_title: Towards a costless war against China?
summary: The US is considering a "costless war" against China, with the Biden administration planning to restrict investments by US firms in China, particularly in areas like advanced computing. The move comes amid a surge in anti-China sentiment in Washington, with Republicans and Democrats united in their opposition to China's military and economic ambitions. However, experts question whether this strategy can effectively balance US national security concerns with economic interests, as China remains a significant trading partner for the US. The administration's efforts to restrict Chinese access to advanced technologies may not be enough to address US concerns, raising concerns about the effectiveness of the "costless war" strategy.

images.alt_text: FBI special agents processing remnants from a suspected Chinese balloon at a laboratory in Quantico, Va., on  Feb 9, 2023.  US warplanes shot down another flying object on Sunday, this time over Lake Huron on the US-Canadian border.

White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre, speaking separately to reporters on Air Force One, described the balloons as part of a “fleet” and said they had been spotted around the world for several years.

site_title: First Reit Q4 DPU unchanged at S$0.0066
summary: First Reit, a healthcare-focused real estate investment trust (REIT), maintained its quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) at S$0.0066 for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2022, unchanged from a year ago. The DPU for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, rose 27.8% to S$27.2 million. The REIT aims to increase its portfolio in developed markets to more than 50% by 2027, with a focus on diversification and capital-efficient growth.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) has proposed to acquire an 80 per cent interest in phases one and two of the Singapore-Hangzhou Science and Technology Park (pictured).

site_title: Fed’s Bowman expects more rate hikes to reach inflation goal
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Michelle Bowman expects further interest rate hikes to bring inflation down to the Fed's goal, despite potential economic slowdown and labor market softening. Bowman stated that restoring price stability is essential for a sustainably strong labor market, and that the costs of allowing inflation to persist outweigh the costs of tightening monetary policy. The Fed has already lifted interest rates, and officials forecast rates peaking at 5.1% this year, with investors largely in line with this projection following the strong January jobs report.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised its main rate by a quarter point on Feb 7.

site_title: Singapore SMEs, startups venturing into Indonesia for expansion, opportunities
summary: Singaporean companies are expanding into Indonesia, taking advantage of the country's large market of 280 million people. The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and Enterprise Singapore are supporting companies through the GlobalConnect@SBF program, which has facilitated 489 business advisories and 297 unique companies in Indonesia in 2022. SMEs and startups are particularly interested in the Indonesian market, with some companies looking to establish partnerships with hospitals and healthcare providers, while others are exploring opportunities in e-commerce, fintech, and logistics. Companies must have a sound understanding of the market to succeed, with "acting local" being key to capturing the domestic market.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

The decision to cut fuel subsidies was “not an easy choice” given its political sensitivity, said Indonesia's finance minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati, but it “had to be done” to create a more equitable society.
Formed via a merger of ride-hailing provider Gojek and e-commerce firm Tokopedia, GoTo raised US$1.1 billion in one of last year’s largest initial public offerings.
Fixed broadband adoption in Indonesia has grown in recent years as users stream more video.

site_title: China, US to participate in first meeting of new debt roundtable on Feb 17
summary: China and the US will participate in the first virtual meeting of a new sovereign debt roundtable on February 17, co-chaired by the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, and India. The meeting brings together officials from countries requesting debt relief, including Zambia, Ethiopia, Ghana, Sri Lanka, Suriname, and Ecuador, to discuss the slow pace of debt relief discussions. The event comes ahead of the G20 finance officials' meeting in Bengaluru, India, on February 23-25, with an in-person meeting of the roundtable expected on February 25.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Euro, Hong Kong dollar, U.S. dollar, Japanese yen, pound and Chinese 100 yuan banknotes are seen in this picture illustration, January 21, 2016.   REUTERS/Jason Lee/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Rising panic over blocked imports in crisis-hit Pakistan
summary: Pakistan's textile and garment industry, accounting for 60% of the country's exports, is severely crippled by the import ban due to critically low US-dollar reserves. The ban has led to widespread job losses, with thousands of factories forced to close and smaller plants shutting down due to lack of raw materials. The steel industry, construction industry, and pharmaceuticals are also severely affected, with severe supply-chain issues and record-high prices for steel bars. The government's bailout agreement with the IMF remains uncertain, leaving the economy in crisis.

images.alt_text: Bangladesh’s official inflation rate is around 8.7 per cent but independent economists say the true figure is substantially higher.
Pakistan’s grid desperately needs an upgrade that the government – which has lurched from one International Monetary Fund bail-out to the next – says it can ill afford.

site_title: Activists make European CEO heads roll on US$225-billion warpath
summary: Activist investors in Europe have successfully removed CEOs from companies with a combined market capitalization of over $225 billion in the past 18 months. Notable exits include Vodafone's Nick Read, Bayer's Werner Baumann, and Temenos' Max Chuard. Despite these wins, many activists are still seeking deeper structural changes, such as break-ups, to boost flagging share prices and position companies for the future. The complexity of the decision process and the size, risk, and cost of undertaking divestitures may be driving the focus on director removals instead.

images.alt_text: The change of tone comes as surging energy bills are threatening to put companies out of business and runaway inflation is leaving consumers struggling to pay their bills.

M&A activity in the United States plunged 40 per cent to US$456 billion in the second quarter, while Asia-Pacific was down 10 per cent, Dealogic data shows; The largest deal of the quarter was Broadcom’s US$61 billion cash-and-stock buyout of VMWare in the United States

site_title: Toyota’s new CEO assembles leadership team for EV future
summary: Toyota's new CEO, Koji Sato, has unveiled his leadership team for the company's electric vehicle future, emphasizing "inheritance and evolution" as key themes. Hiroki Nakajima and Yoichi Miyazaki have been appointed as chief technology and financial officers, respectively, and will join the board of directors. Sato aims to improve communication and shift the company's strategy to accelerate its electric vehicle rollout, with 30 models planned by 2030, and will announce further details on its new EV platform in April.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest automaker, like many global manufacturers, is grappling with the continued fallout from semiconductor shortage and the pain from rising costs.

site_title: China says US flew high-altitude balloons over its airspace
summary: China accused the US of flying high-altitude balloons over its airspace more than 10 times since 2022 without permission, amid a dispute that began after the US shot down a Chinese spy balloon. The US denies the allegations, with the US military saying the downed balloon was a civilian airship that had strayed off course. The incident has prompted a swift denial from Washington, with top diplomat Antony Blinken canceling a trip to Beijing to ease tensions.

images.alt_text: White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre, speaking separately to reporters on Air Force One, described the balloons as part of a “fleet” and said they had been spotted around the world for several years.

site_title: China to plant more soy, speed up GMOs to ensure food supply
summary: China aims to boost its soybean and edible oil output to reduce its reliance on imports, citing concerns over feeding its 1.4 billion people due to the pandemic, trade tensions, and climate disasters. The country plans to increase grain production capacity by 50 million tonnes, promote GMOs, and speed up the commercialization of biotech corn and soybeans. Additionally, China will reduce soymeal rations in animal feed, diversify agricultural imports, and protect soil and conserve water. The efforts are part of a broader push for self-sufficiency in key food supplies.

site_title: STI falls 1.1% as caution prevails ahead of US CPI data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.1% to 3,324.70, following a cautious market ahead of US CPI data release on Tuesday. The decline follows the biggest weekly drop in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq since December 2022. Local banks DBS and OCBC fell 2% and 1.4% respectively, while Thomson Medical Group rose 5.6%. The upcoming US data is expected to provide insights into the direction of the global economy and interest rate path.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Physical gold buyers in some Asian hubs were drawn to a dip in domestic prices last week, while central bank demand kept premiums firm in China.
Hong Kong, Tokyo, Seoul, Singapore, Sydney, Taipei and Wellington stocks were all in the red on Monday, although Shanghai eked out small gains.
Maybank analysts express confidence that Food Empire will pay its shareholders a special dividend that will bring the group’s total payout for FY2022 to S$0.04.

site_title: Biotech IPOs to bloom with spotlight on startups with human trial data
summary: Small biotech companies are poised for a comeback in IPOs as interest rate hikes slow and investors focus on firms with human trial data. After a dismal 2022, the biotech sector is expected to rebound in the second half of 2023, driven by a surge in clinical trial data and acquisitions. Companies with successful clinical trials and capable management teams are likely to attract investors, with areas such as obesity treatments and gene therapies gaining interest. Several biotech firms have already filed for an IPO this year, with successful market debuts expected.

site_title: World’s riskiest emerging-market bonds in play as distressed makes a comeback
summary: The world's riskiest emerging-market bonds are experiencing a comeback, with double-digit returns offered to investors willing to take on high default risk. The rally is driven by prices recovering from rock-bottom levels last year and investors shifting towards riskier investments. The best-performing developing-economy bonds are in distress, with yields over 10 percentage points above US Treasuries. Investors are attracted to the high upside potential of distressed countries, with some bonds yielding over 30% and others trading at 60% higher than their pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Rupiah sovereign notes reeled in US$467 million on Monday, the largest one-day inflow since August 2021.
Investors exited European and US bond funds of US$7.29 billion and US$4.16 billion respectively.
EM outflows could be disruptive for markets: IIF

Georgieva warned that 60 per cent of low-income countries are at or near a debt crisis, and reiterated her call for China, the biggest creditor to emerging countries, to cooperate with multiparty debt restructuring talks.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy grew 3.6% in 2022, revised down from 3.8%, with non-oil domestic exports' growth slowing to 3% in 2022. The country's GDP growth is moderating, standing at 2.1% year-on-year. Ahead of the 2023 Budget Statement, economists expect a return to prudence after two years of Covid-related spending, with some short-term support expected for Singaporeans.

site_title: Earthquake could cost Turkey up to US$84 billion: business group
summary: A 7.8-magnitude earthquake in Turkey has estimated costs of up to US$84.1 billion, including US$70.8 billion for home repairs and US$10.4 billion for lost national income. The disaster has resulted in a combined death toll of over 36,000 in Turkey and Syria, with the focus shifting to providing shelter, food, and psychosocial care. Economic growth is expected to be cut by up to two percentage points this year, with the government forecasting 5% growth in 2022 and 5.5% in 2023 before the quake.

images.alt_text: A White Helmet volunteer stands among rubble, in the aftermath of a deadly earthquake, in Harem, Idlib, Syria, Feb 10, 2023.
Collapsed buildings in Hatay, south-eastern Turkey, on Feb 8, 2023, two days after a strong earthquake struck the region.

site_title: Nissan, Renault to invest US$600m to make 6 new models in India
summary: Nissan and Renault are investing $600 million to produce six new models in India, aiming to address falling market shares in the rapidly growing market. The models, including three electric vehicles and three sports utility vehicles, will be built on joint platforms at the Chennai plant. This investment is part of a revamped alliance announced last week, which will also focus on Latin America and Europe. The move aims to capture the Indian market, now the third-largest in the world, and use India as a base for export.

images.alt_text: Under the landmark deal, Renault is expected to reduce its 43 per cent stake in Nissan to 15 per cent through an orderly disposal of stock over time.

site_title: India’s inflation flares up, returns to 6% level in January
summary: India's inflation surged to 6.52% in January, surpassing the Reserve Bank of India's target of 6% and breaching the top-end for the first time in four months. Food prices rose 5.94%, while fuel and light costs increased 10.84%. Core inflation, which strips out food and fuel costs, remained above the 6% mark for the 16th consecutive month, prompting concerns of persistent price pressures. The Reserve Bank of India may consider further interest rate hikes to contain inflation.

site_title: Qatar is said to prepare imminent bid for Manchester United
summary: Qatar is reportedly preparing to make an imminent bid for Manchester United, with a consortium expected to submit an initial offer by the end of the week. The bid, valued at over £4 billion, would be the largest ever deal involving a sporting franchise. The move is seen as part of Qatar's efforts to become a major player in global sports, following their successful takeover of Paris Saint-Germain FC. The Glazer family, Manchester United's current owners, have been open to selling a stake, and New York bank Raine Group is advising them on potential offers.

site_title: Court grants club member’s bid to wind up Laguna National club
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted a pioneer member of Laguna National Golf and Country Club's application to wind up the club, citing tens of millions of dollars in unpaid debt to debenture holders. The club's trustee, British and Malayan Trustees, is deemed to be in a position of conflict of interest due to its own potential claims by noteholders. The court ordered the club to be wound up and appointed new liquidators, with the costs of the proceedings to be taxed and paid to the applicant.

site_title: Love in a time of inflation: how much will Valentine’s Day set you back?
summary: This Valentine's Day, record food inflation in the UK is expected to make romantic dinners out more expensive. With inflation rates reaching 16.7% in the four weeks to January 22, Britons are paying more for food, flowers, and chocolates. Supermarkets like Morrisons and Tesco are offering stable prices for meal-deals, while restaurants like PizzaExpress and London's Ritz Restaurant are modifying their offerings to attract cash-conscious customers.

site_title: NetLink’s 9-month profit after tax rises 24.2%
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 24.2% profit after tax rise to S$81.8 million for the nine months to Dec 31, driven by higher ancillary project revenue and residential connections. Revenue increased 6.5% to S$299.8 million, with residential connections contributing 61% of total revenue. The trust plans to improve network reach and densification, while exploring overseas telecoms infrastructure investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
DBS Group Research raises its target price on NetLink from S$0.84 to S$0.98.

site_title: Paragon Reit posts DPU of S$0.0172 in latest 4-month period
summary: Paragon Reit posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.72 Singapore cents for the four months ended Dec 31, 2022, representing an annualized yield of 5.7%. This is unchanged from the previous year and marks the 16th month of the extended financial year-end. The Reit's gross revenue rose 1.8% to S$376.4 million, and net property income increased 3.3% to S$279.9 million, driven by recovering retail sentiment and a return of travel and leisure demand.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

SPH Reit's portfolio includes its anchor asset, Paragon, along with The Clementi Mall and The Rail Mall.

site_title: Economists ‘cautiously optimistic’ about Singapore economy in 2023, banking on China’s reopening
summary: Singapore's economists are cautiously optimistic about the country's economy in 2023, driven by China's reopening and a services sector recovery. Despite a weaker manufacturing sector, with a 2.5% growth rate, economists expect a "half-full" economy due to China's impact. The GDP growth forecast for 2023 remains at 0.5-2.5%, with some economists predicting a higher growth rate. The services sector is expected to provide a significant offset to weaker manufacturing activity, while the manufacturing sector's growth is seen as a concern.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Fourth-quarter  growth in gross domestic product (GDP) came in at 2.1 per cent year on year, moderating from the 4 per cent expansion seen in the previous quarter.

site_title: Link Reit falls 12.8% after rights issue triggers dividend qualms
summary: Link Reit, Asia's largest real estate investment trust, fell 12.8% to HK$54.75 following its plan to conduct a $2.5 billion rights offering. The company will issue up to 437.7 million shares at HK$44.2 each, primarily to repay debts and pursue investment opportunities. This move triggered dividend qualms among investors, resulting in the significant share price drop, the most since 2008.

images.alt_text: REIT. Real estate investment trust. Financial Market. Hand pressing button on screen.

site_title: Singapore marine fuel sales at two-year high in Jan
summary: Singapore's marine fuel sales reached a two-year high in January, with 4.38 million tonnes sold, a 4% month-on-month increase and 9% year-on-year increase. Stronger vessel arrivals and higher bunkering demand contributed to the increase. Low-sulphur and high-sulphur marine fuel oil sales both rose 9% year-on-year, while marine gasoil sales fell 7% year-on-year. However, demand has softened in February due to shippers holding out for more competitive prices, with delivered bunker fuel premiums falling.

site_title: Sats reverses two quarters of losses with Q3 net profit of S$500,000
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based in-flight caterer and ground handler, reported a Q3 FY2023 net profit of S$500,000, reversing two consecutive quarters of losses. Revenue surged 54.5% to S$475.7 million, driven by growth in the food solution and gateway services segments. The company attributed the improvement to the post-pandemic recovery in travel demand, with flights, passengers, and meals returning to around 71%, 72%, and 82% of pre-pandemic levels, respectively. Despite an operating loss of S$1.1 million, SATS is optimistic about China's reopening, which is expected to improve volume throughout the year.

site_title: Family of Dick Lee puts prime bungalows on market for S$60 million; proceeds to go to charity
summary: The family of Singaporean singer-songwriter Dick Lee is selling three adjoining freehold bungalows in District 11 for an indicative price of S$60 million, with proceeds going to charity. The properties, totaling 32,148 sq ft, have been vacant and are being sold on an as-is-where-is basis. The sale price translates to S$1,866 per sq ft, with interested parties able to bid for single or multiple bungalows. The neighbourhood has seen recent price benchmarks, with a new bungalow selling for S$3,805 per sq ft last August.

The IRAS building along Newton Road on 17 September 2018.

site_title: As ChatGPT’s popularity explodes, US lawmakers take an interest
summary: US lawmakers are taking notice of ChatGPT's rapid growth, with concerns over plagiarism, national security, and education. The AI program has reached 100 million monthly active users in just two months, prompting calls for regulation. Representative Ted Lieu introduced a resolution to ensure AI development is safe, ethical, and respects Americans' rights. OpenAI CEO Sam Altman met with lawmakers, including Senator Mark Warner, to discuss biases, data privacy, and transparency. Despite concerns, ChatGPT welcomes input from regulators and is developing mitigations to prevent misuse.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT supports Chinese language interaction and is highly capable of conversing in Chinese, which has helped drive its unofficial adoption in the country.
Bill Gates, Microsoft co-founder, says: "The new programs like ChatGPT will make many office jobs more efficient by helping to write invoices or letters. "

site_title: Hong Kong reports outbreak of African swine fever on farm
summary: Hong Kong reported an outbreak of African swine fever on a farm near the border with mainland China, with 45 pigs dying due to the virus. Samples taken from the farm tested positive, and five nearby farms were inspected without finding abnormalities. Movement of pigs on these farms was suspended, and samples will be tested. No reports of abnormalities have been received from pig farms outside the 3 km zone, and enhanced inspection and surveillance are ongoing.

site_title: Israeli parliament in uproar over Netanyahu plans to overhaul judiciary
summary: Israeli lawmakers are in uproar over plans by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to overhaul the judiciary, which would give politicians more power to select judges and limit the Supreme Court's ability to strike down legislation. Tens of thousands have demonstrated against the plans in weekly protests, with President Isaac Herzog warning of a constitutional collapse. The Knesset Constitution Committee voted to send the plan to the plenum for a first reading, sparking a rowdy start to the meeting. The changes have triggered widespread protests and raised concerns about the country's democratic institutions.

images.alt_text: An aerial view shows Israelis holding flags as they demonstrate on the day Israel's constitution committee is set to start voting on changes that would give politicians more power on selecting judges while limiting Supreme Court powers to strike down legislation, in front of the Knesset, Israel's parliament in Jerusalem, February 13, 2023. REUTERS/Ilan Rosenberg

Israelis protest against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's new right-wing coalition and its proposed judicial reforms to reduce powers of the Supreme Court, in Tel Aviv, Israel February 11, 2023. REUTERS/Ilan Rosenberg
Proponents of Israeli PM Netanyahu’s plan say it’s needed to restore balance between the three branches of government, arguing that the supreme court has become overly activist.

site_title: Boeing steps up India investment ahead of giant Air India order
summary: Boeing is investing $24 million in a logistics park and setting up a support center for airlines near New Delhi, India, to support its expected giant plane order from Air India. The logistics center will cater to local airlines and later support Boeing's global network, while the support center will run technical workshops and collaborate with regulators. Boeing estimates the Indian commercial fleet could nearly quadruple by 2041, and has secured about 290 possible orders from Air India, including 190 737 Max aircraft. The move aims to strengthen Boeing's service network in the competitive Indian aviation market.

images.alt_text: In a note to employees on Jan 27, the airline said it was “finalising a historic order for new aircraft”.

site_title: Philippines urges China to halt any ‘provocative act’ after laser is aimed at vessel
summary: The Philippines has accused China of using a "military-grade laser" to disrupt a supply mission to its troops in the South China Sea on February 6. The incident occurred at the Second Thomas Shoal, where a Chinese coast guard ship directed the laser beam at a Philippine vessel, temporarily blinding the crew. The Philippine military is urging China to restrain its forces and avoid any "provocative act" that could endanger lives. The incident is the latest in a series of tensions between the two countries in the region.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr (left) and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida conclude their joint remarks to reporters following their talks in Tokyo on Thursday (Feb 9). Marcos is on a five-day visit to Japan that began on Wednesday.

Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr's first visit to Japan since taking office in July comes after he signed an agreement last week granting the United States greater access to its military bases.
With China’s economy reeling and relations with neighbours and countries in Europe strained, restraint and prudence are in its own interests.
US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin meets with Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr in Manila on Feb 2. The US now has access to nine military bases in the Philippines.

site_title: Flights grounded, power cut as storm lashes New Zealand
summary: A tropical storm has hit New Zealand's northern area, grounding hundreds of flights and leaving tens of thousands of homes without power. The storm has caused high winds, torrential rains, and damaged roads, with trees toppled and power lines downed. A state of emergency was declared in five regions on the North Island, where almost a third of New Zealand's population lives. The government has announced an aid package of NZ$11.5 million to help recovery efforts, and Prime Minister Chris Hipkins has urged citizens to stay indoors and be prepared for the worst.

images.alt_text: A view shows high tides rising due to Cyclone Gabrielle in Arkles Bay, Auckland, New Zealand February 13, 2023 in this screen grab obtained from a social media video. site_title: India aims to triple defence exports to US$5 billion, sell fighter jets, choppers
summary: India aims to triple its annual defense exports to $5 billion over the next two years, targeting deals worth $9 billion at the Aero India air show. The country seeks to sell fighter jets, choppers, and other defense products, and attract foreign investment for joint product development. India's export ambitions reflect its growing clout as a defense partner, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi stating that the country is no longer just a market for defense companies, but a potential partner.

site_title: In China, Tesla could win electric vehicle price battle – but lose the war
summary: Tesla's electric vehicle sales in China increased 18% in January due to price cuts, but the company has lost market share to competitors like BYD and Nio. Despite its pricing strategy, Tesla lags behind in introducing new models, improving navigation systems, and offering luxury features, which are preferred by Chinese consumers. Analysts warn that Tesla's limited product mix and slow updates to its self-driving software may lead to a loss of competitiveness in the market, where EV sales are expected to surge by 35% in 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tesla China-made Model 3 vehicles are seen during a delivery event at its factory in Shanghai, China January 7, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Seven things to look out for in Budget 2023
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver Singapore's Budget Statement on Feb 14, focusing on cost-of-living support and taking a longer-term view. Expected enhancements include GST Assurance Package, family support for raising children, and income support for retrenched workers. The budget may also promote digitalization, internationalization, and sustainability for businesses, while encouraging green infrastructure projects and sustainability-focused staff. Corporate or wealth tax changes are unlikely, but property cooling measures and rule tweaks are possible.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
One group that could benefit from an expansion of the PWM is skilled non-degree holders, said one economist.
Tax authorities around the world face resource and compliance monitoring constraints as transactions become more digitalised.

Last year, the number of firms seeking government support for productivity improvements fell by 21.5 per cent, following a surge in 2020 and 2021, suggesting that many firms have already made the required changes.

site_title: Thai finance minister says pace of monetary tightening still “reasonable”
summary: Thailand's Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith stated that the pace of monetary tightening remains "reasonable" as the country's economy is expected to grow faster than forecast, driven by a rebound in the tourism sector. The Bank of Thailand has raised interest rates by 100 basis points since August to 1.50%, aligning with economic needs rather than mirroring the US Federal Reserve's aggressive pace. The government expects Thai GDP to beat a forecast of 3.8% growth this year, with tourism expected to support the economy, despite concerns over the impact of the strong Thai currency.

site_title: Commodities risk in ESG funds is now too big to ignore, says alliance of investors
summary: Investors are sounding the alarm on the environmental and social risks associated with ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) funds, particularly in the mining industry. The risks of human rights abuses and environmental damage through supply chains pose a threat to the clean-tech revolution. An alliance of investors, including the Church of England Pensions Board, aims to shine a spotlight on these systemic risks. The industry's demand for minerals and metals, such as copper and lithium, is driving instability in areas with unstable government structures and contributing to conflict.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s exports of processed nickel then swelled to more than US$30 billion in 2022 from about US$1 billion in 2015.
Nickel ore in a ferronickel smelter owned by state miner Aneka Tambang at Pomala district, Indonesia. DBS Group Research recommends "hold" on the stock with a target price of 2,100 rupiah.

The ESG investment industry’s sustainability claims have come under mounting scrutiny during the Biden administration, with the SEC proposing new marketing regulations and starting to sue firms over their disclosures.

site_title: China’s CNPC set to seal mega Qatari LNG deal
summary: China's CNPC is close to finalizing a 30-year deal to buy liquefied natural gas (LNG) from QatarEnergy, the Middle Eastern exporter's massive North Field expansion project. This would be the second long-term supply contract between Qatar and China, following a 27-year deal signed by Sinopec last November. The deal is seen as a move to diversify China's gas supply, replace coal, and cut carbon emissions. CNPC's talks follow its recent increase in gas imports from Russia, and comes as Beijing seeks to strengthen ties with Qatar amid strained relations with the US and Australia.

site_title: How to avoid permanent loss of capital
summary:
Investors can avoid permanent loss of capital by following five key strategies. These include: 

1. Diversifying investments across different assets, industries, and geographical locations to minimize risk.
2. Avoiding market timing and not expecting to buy low and sell high.
3. Being cautious with leverage to avoid margin calls and permanent loss.
4. Keeping emotions in check and staying disciplined in investment decisions.
5. Conducting thorough research on investment managers and funds to avoid mistakes.

By implementing these strategies, investors can protect their capital and avoid significant losses, ensuring their investments grow over time.

site_title: EU executive raises eurozone 2023 growth forecast, sees lower inflation
summary: The European Commission has raised its forecast for eurozone economic growth to 0.9% for 2023, up from 0.3% predicted last November. Inflation is expected to be lower than initially forecast, decelerating to 5.6% this year and 2.5% in 2024. The forecast hinges on the assumption that Russia's aggression in Ukraine will not escalate, but risks to growth and inflation are balanced, with potential factors including China's re-opening and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: The ECB is still expected to raise its key policy rate to a peak of 3.25 per cent from 2.5 per cent at present. That

site_title: Adani shares extend decline as spotlight shifts to Indian regulator
summary: India's market regulator is set to brief the federal government on its investigation into Adani Group's shelved share sale, amid a decline of over $100 billion in market value for the group's seven listed stocks since a short seller accused it of improper offshore tax-haven use and stock manipulation. The group has denied allegations, and its capital-raising plans have been cast in doubt, with the conglomerate halving its revenue growth target and scaling down fresh capital expenditure. The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is also under scrutiny by India's top court, which has asked the regulator to explain its regulatory frameworks and prevent investor losses.

images.alt_text: Adani Group has been focusing on staving off concerns about its financial health and shoring up sentiment.
