site_title: More remedies for workers, employer penalties proposed for Singapore’s anti-discrimination law
summary: Singapore's Tripartite Committee on Workplace Fairness proposes interim anti-discrimination laws to protect workers from 5 characteristics: age, nationality, sex, disability, and mental health conditions. Errant employers may face penalties, while workers can receive more remedies or compensation. Exceptions will be made for genuine business needs and small firms. Manpower Minister Tan See Leng emphasized the need for legislation to be "not overly onerous" for Singapore to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Under the new guidelines, employers should be sensitive to the cultures, values and beliefs of their employees when developing, promoting or implementing any non-work-related activities.
Pedestrians cross a road in the central business district of Singapore.
While some platforms do provide some form of insurance to their gig workers, coverage is incomplete.

site_title: The narrowing of China’s ‘gateway to Europe’
summary: China's planned gateway to Europe, a 2018 purchase in the Czech Republic, has stalled due to slow construction. The project, initially expected to be a major Chinese investment showcase, now lies dormant. Local farmers have taken over the land, using it to grow corn, as the project's progress has been hindered by bureaucratic delays and lack of funding. The project has become a symbol of the challenges faced by China's overseas business model, which relies on government support and local officials' backing. The site remains a muddy patch of terrain.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - US President Joe Biden (R) and China's President Xi Jinping (L) meet on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on November 14, 2022. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)
Among Europe's biggest lenders that have reported their 2022 earnings so far, 10 have boosted net lending revenue by 16 per cent, to a record 120.8 billion euros (S$173.1 billion).

site_title: Binance says stablecoin partner is set to stop minting BUSD
summary: Binance's stablecoin partner, Paxos, has been directed by the New York State Department of Financial Services to cease minting new BUSD, the third-largest stablecoin, due to regulatory concerns. This decision follows a US$2 trillion rout in the digital-asset industry and the bankruptcy of the FTX exchange. The move is expected to decrease BUSD's market value to around $16 billion. Paxos will continue to service the product and manage redemptions, with funds reportedly fully covered by reserves in their banks.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins are intended to hold a set value, for example US$1, and come in a variety of forms.

site_title: Asia: Markets take fresh hit on rate hike worries
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Monday, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, Seoul, Singapore, Sydney, Taipei, and Wellington all experiencing losses. Shanghai saw small gains, but concerns over US interest rates and a potential recession fueled the decline. The jobs market remaining tight in January, coupled with a possible stronger-than-forecast US consumer price index, led to increased rate hike worries. Experts predict rates could rise to 6% from 4.50-4.75%, potentially tipping the US economy into recession.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Jakarta stocks sank, though a weaker yen helped Tokyo post morning gains.

site_title: Magic Mike tops North America box office but Super Bowl wins out
summary: Magic Mike's Last Dance topped the North American box office with an estimated $8.2 million in ticket sales, but was hurt by competition from the Super Bowl. The film's performance was described as a "soft opening" by analyst David A. Gross. James Cameron's Avatar: The Way of Water took second place with $6.9 million, while a remastered 3D version of Titanic placed third. The top 5 films were Magic Mike's Last Dance, Avatar: The Way of Water, 80 for Brady, Knock at the Cabin, and Puss in Boots: The Last Wish.

site_title: Thought hiking rates was tough? Wait for the pause
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised its main interest rate by a quarter point on February 7, despite inflation still being above target and global growth slowing. The decision may be a temporary pause in rate hikes, but the RBA's confidence in this move is uncertain, making it a potentially perilous exercise. The RBA will reassess the future path of borrowing costs based on future data, making it unclear if the pause will be sustained.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - FEBRUARY 07: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell speaks during an interview by David Rubenstein, Chairman of the Economic Club of Washington, D.C., at the Renaissance Hotel on February 7, 2023 in Washington, DC. Against a basket of currencies, the US dollar index fell 0.18 per cent to 103.12 on Wednesday, after slipping 0.3 per cent in the previous session.

site_title: China’s weekly new home sales rise for second week in a row
summary: China's new home sales rose for the second consecutive week, with a 72% increase in tier-one cities including Shanghai and Beijing. Sales in 16 selected cities rose 40.9% from the previous week, driven by improved sentiment after Beijing's stimulus policies and lifted Covid-19 controls. Analysts warn the recovery is still patchy, but note that more cities may optimize policies and market sentiment in hot cities may further recover.

images.alt_text: The move comes in the midst of a fresh wave of mortgage repayments and a surge in complaints about banks placing restrictions on the practice.

site_title: Regulator watches as K-pop agencies battle for tie-up with SM Entertainment
summary: K-pop agencies HYBE and Kakao are battling for a tie-up with SM Entertainment, a rival agency. HYBE, manager of BTS, already holds 51.8% of K-pop record sales. Kakao has agreed to acquire SM shares as part of a partnership, but this is being opposed in a court action, potentially favoring HYBE's dominance in the market. HYBE has also agreed to buy 14.8% of SM shares and is offering to buy an additional 25%. The South Korean competition regulator may review the tie-up if either agency succeeds.

site_title: Hong Kong-listed brokerages fall on report of mainland China client ban
summary: Hong Kong-listed brokerages Guotai Junan International, Guolian Securities, and Haitong International fell on Monday after the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) reported that Guotai Junan had suspended opening accounts for mainland Chinese clients, potentially affecting its business. The move aims to discourage illegal money outflows. Similar bans were previously issued to online brokerages Futu Holding and UP Fintech Holding. The ban is expected to negatively impact Hong Kong-based brokerages' future businesses, particularly those reliant on mainland Chinese clients.

images.alt_text: The IPO reform is designed “to give the right of choice to the market,” and make IPOs more transparent and predictable, the CSRC said in a statement.

site_title: Commercial building Bugis Point up for sale at S$92 million
summary: A six-storey commercial building in Bugis Point, Singapore, with a site area of 2,784 sq ft, has been put up for sale via expression of interest with an indicative price of S$92 million. This translates to S$4,623 per square foot. The building is zoned for commercial use under the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Master Plan.

images.alt_text: Spanning 36,350 square feet (sq ft), the 99-year leasehold development along Shenton Way comprises 203 commercial units and a carpark.

site_title: Airbnb offers ‘Phantom of the Opera’-themed stay at Palais Garnier in Paris
summary: Airbnb is offering a unique "Phantom of the Opera"-themed stay at the Palais Garnier opera house in Paris starting March 1 for 37 euros. The stay includes a music recital, dinner in an ornate rehearsal room, and a behind-the-scenes tour of the 19th-century building. The listing will be available on a first-come-first-serve basis to applicants registered on Airbnb's platform. The stay also supports the renovation of the theatre's boxes and the Opera de Paris's online streaming platform.

The Commission’s proposal marks an effort to tackle the patchwork of different national laws across the EU regulating Airbnb and its rivals, while trying to balance the interests of cities and rural areas.

site_title: Sats joint venture to build multi-modal cargo hub at India’s Noida International Airport
summary: SATS, a joint venture with Air India, will build a multi-modal cargo hub at Noida International Airport in India. The hub, designed and operated by Air India Sats Airport Services, will span 87 acres and feature integrated cargo and logistics facilities. The 20-year concession agreement is expected to be finalized in the coming weeks, with a 37-year concession for the warehousing and logistics zone. The hub aims to facilitate seamless cargo experience and enhance regional supply chain efficiency.

images.alt_text: Sats’ acquisition of WFS is expected to cost the company S$1.8 billion.

site_title: Fret not over that shrinking private home
summary: Private homes in Singapore are getting smaller, with median floor areas for three-bedroom condominium units decreasing from 1,700-1,800 sq ft in the 1980s to around 1,000 sq ft since 2018. New condominium launches feature units as small as 900 sq ft and 700 sq ft. Despite smaller spaces, sound reasons such as increased land costs and rising construction costs drive this trend. Smaller homes need not result in poorer living conditions, as they often prioritize efficiency and functionality. This shift is driven by changing consumer preferences and economic factors.

site_title: Hong Kong adds security law provisions to land sales terms
summary: Hong Kong's Lands Department has added provisions from the National Security Law to land sales and short-term leases, allowing the government to disqualify bids and suspend leases due to national security reasons. This move has led to a 4.9% drop in Hong Kong property stocks, their lowest in six weeks. Developers are expected to be more cautious in bidding for land sales. The National Security Law, imposed in 2020, has been criticized for eroding freedoms and the rule of law, but Hong Kong and Chinese authorities say it is necessary for stability.

Hong Kong home prices sank 15.6 per cent in 2022, ending a 13-year rising trend after three years of Covid-19 dried up flows of property buyers from China and tourists.

site_title: The boom, bust and future of China’s real estate sector
summary: China's real estate sector is expected to receive support in 2023 after regulatory pressure is lifted, but structural weaknesses remain. The sector's growth was fueled by a massive investment binge and high savings ratio, leading to a real estate bubble that burst in 2021. The collapse led to a decline in housing prices, mortgage boycotts, and negative double-digit growth. Despite this, policymakers have decided to ease regulatory restrictions, attracting speculative investors. However, the sector's recovery is expected to be slow, and housing affordability will not improve quickly, posing a challenge to the government's objective of achieving "common prosperity."

site_title: Food Empire guides for higher profits; Maybank says special dividend likely
summary: Food Empire expects higher profits in FY2022, driven by better operating profit and one-off gains from asset disposal. Maybank Securities predicts a special dividend of S$0.04, up from S$0.022 in the previous year, with a yield of 5.6%. The analysts see Food Empire as an attractive takeover target and highlight its market leadership, strong presence in Russia and Vietnam, and resilience despite geopolitical uncertainties. The company is reducing its reliance on Russia and diversifying revenue sources.

images.alt_text: Steps taken to mitigate situation in affected markets Russia and Ukraine: Food Empire

site_title: European office demand rebounds from Covid to drive up rents
summary: European office space demand rebounded 15% in 2022 from pre-Covid levels, driven by businesses seeking to lure back staff. This surge in demand led to a 6.2% increase in rents, the strongest annualized reading since 2008, according to Cushman & Wakefield data. The rebound in leasing volumes has helped offset the impact of surging interest rates on the property market.

images.alt_text: The sagging demand has started affecting home prices, with Germany last month experiencing the first drop in residential home valuations in over a decade.

site_title: Dispute settlement reform a ‘priority’: WTO director general
summary: WTO Director General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala has emphasized the need for reforming the dispute settlement system, citing its stalled state due to Trump-era blockages. She expressed hope for delivering reforms by the end of 2025. Okonjo-Iweala also reiterated that global merchandise trade is expected to grow by 1% in 2023, despite concerns from developing countries about accessing the system. The US is leading negotiations to reboot the system, aiming for it to be fully functional by the end of 2024.

site_title: Giving back is more important to driving banking consumer trust than accessibility: poll
summary: A poll by the Association of Banks in Singapore found that giving back to local communities and impacting the environment and society is more important in building banking consumer trust than accessibility to physical branches or ATMs. The third annual Banking Trust Index for Singapore survey, conducted by Edelman Data and Intelligence, surveyed 3,515 residents and measured public trust in banks across four factors. The results suggest that banks can strengthen public trust by being more forthcoming about their business values and positive contributions to the community.

Analysts said rising interest rates could result in higher margins and a revival of wealth management income for local lenders, which would lift their overall earnings.

To position for 2023, analysts The Business Times spoke to recommended plays on interest rate movements as well as China’s reopening. But they also advised caution as there are still plenty of risks looming.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands facing further delays to S$4.5 billion expansion plans
summary: Marina Bay Sands' S$4.5 billion expansion plans are facing further delays due to the onset of the pandemic, with construction pushed back multiple times. The US-listed Las Vegas Sands company, which owns and operates MBS, is in discussions with the Singapore government on extending the timeline. The expansion, which includes a 1,000-room hotel tower and live entertainment arena, is part of a development agreement signed with the government, which requires MBS to commence construction by April 2023. If an extension is not obtained, MBS will be in breach of its obligations.

images.alt_text: Genting Singapore's gaming revenue rose 96 per cent on-year to S$382 million, while non-gaming revenue climbed to S$137.3 million from S$56.2 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: Singapore life insurance records lower 2022 sales as single-premium sales dip in Q4
summary: Singapore life insurance sales declined 9.2% to S$2.35 billion in 2022 due to a 28.8% drop in single-premium sales in Q4, attributed to rising interest rates and a volatile macroeconomic environment. However, annual premium product sales rose 16% year-over-year, driven by increased interest in protection products. Total weighted new business premiums reached S$5.1 billion, down 5.2% from 2021, with non-par products accounting for 35% of premiums.

images.alt_text: calculator, calculation, insurance
Single-premium products are seeing sustained growth and remain popular among Singaporeans.

site_title: Apple supplier Salcomp to boost Indian workforce to 25,000
summary: Salcomp, a major Apple supplier, plans to nearly double its workforce in India to 25,000 over the next three years, aiming to diversify the supply chain beyond China. The company, which currently employs 12,000 people, is also setting up a housing complex with entertainment and education for 15,000 people. This move follows Foxconn's plan to quadruple its workforce in an iPhone factory in India over two years. Apple is expected to manufacture 25% of its products outside China by 2025, with India set to be a key alternative.

site_title: China regulators querying banks on mortgage prepayment strain
summary: China's regulators are investigating how major lenders are handling the surge in mortgage prepayments as interest rates fall, amid complaints of restrictions on the practice. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission held a meeting with banks to discuss solutions to cope with the pressure. Regulators are advising banks to ensure they don't introduce hurdles for qualified homeowners to prepay mortgages, while exploring ways to adjust existing mortgage rates. The move comes as homeowners take advantage of falling interest rates to reduce debt, with Citigroup estimating 4.68 trillion yuan worth of mortgages prepaid last year.

images.alt_text: The PBOC is expected to keep policies accommodative in the near term in terms of liquidity injection and credit supply to solidify the recovery.
An increase in cash injection would add to evidence that China is continuing to ease monetary conditions to revive an economy handicapped by years of tough Covid restrictions.

site_title: Eurozone inflation seen lingering above ECB’s target into 2025
summary: Eurozone inflation is expected to remain above the European Central Bank's 2% target in 2025, averaging 2.1% according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. Core inflation, excluding volatile items, is predicted to peak at 5.2% in the first quarter before easing to 3.6% in the final quarter of 2023. The ECB is still expected to raise interest rates to a peak of 3.25% and may raise rates again in March and after that, before a first rate cut in the second quarter of 2024.

site_title: Geely’s EV brand Zeekr raises US$750 million in fresh funding round
summary: Zeekr, an electric car brand from China's Geely Automobile Holdings, has raised US$750 million in a funding round valued at US$13 billion. The proceeds will be used for technology research and global brand expansion. New investors include Amnon Shashua, the CEO of Mobileye Global, and the Guangzhou city municipal government's investment arm. Existing investors include Chinese battery maker CATL. The funding round supports Zeekr's efforts to expand its electric car models and technology capabilities.

site_title: The battle for Internet search
summary: Artificial intelligence-powered chatbots are revolutionizing the internet search landscape, challenging Google's dominance. ChatGPT, a leading chatbot, has been used by over 100 million people since its launch, and rival firms are investing heavily to develop their own versions. However, concerns arise about chatbots' accuracy, objectivity, and potential for bias and misinformation. Tech firms are exploring monetization models, including premium services and targeted advertising, but the business model's sustainability is uncertain. The emergence of chatbots may favor incumbents with existing services, but smaller firms have a chance to compete if they develop superior technology and business models.

images.alt_text: The Google-Anthropic partnership follows a high-profile US$10 billion investment by Microsoft in OpenAI.
Google posted a short GIF video of Bard in action via Twitter, describing the chatbot as a “launchpad for curiosity” that would help simplify complex topics.

site_title: Singapore eyes chips investments amid US-China tension
summary: Singapore aims to secure investments in semiconductor assembly and design amid US-China tensions. Chairman of the Economic Development Board, Beh Swan Gin, stated that the city-state will focus on its semiconductor value chain to compete for investments. Singapore currently accounts for 5% of global wafer fabs output and attracted a record S$22.5 billion in fixed-asset investment commitments in 2022. The government will provide "full confidence and support" for Singapore's mission to stay relevant in the industry.

images.alt_text: Some of the major investments secured by Singapore in 2022 came from the manufacturing industry.
Large manufacturing projects from the electronics sector accounted for 66.7 per cent of fixed asset investment commitments in 2022.

site_title: Hot stock: Global Dragon shares up over 15% after news of takeover bid
summary: Global Dragon shares rose 15.2% to S$0.121 after Fragrance Group founder Koh Wee Meng made a voluntary conditional cash offer to take the company private at S$0.12 per share. The stock had last reached S$0.12 in December 2021.

site_title: ChatGPT frenzy sweeps China as firms scramble for home-grown options
summary: ChatGPT, a US-based AI chatbot, has gained significant popularity in China despite Microsoft backing, with companies scrambling to integrate its technology into their products. The app is not officially available in China, but users can bypass restrictions using virtual private networks and foreign phone numbers. Chinese firms are developing rival solutions, and the tool's popularity is raising awareness about the country's lagging AI capabilities. Analysts predict that Chinese companies will eventually replace ChatGPT with local alternatives to comply with regulations.

images.alt_text: Bill Gates, Microsoft co-founder, says: "The new programs like ChatGPT will make many office jobs more efficient by helping to write invoices or letters. "

Software engineers work on a facial recognition program that identifies people when they wear a face mask at the development lab of the Chinese electronics manufacturer Hanwang Technology in Beijing, China, March 6, 2020. Hanwang Technology has risen as much as 129 per cent as of Wednesday.
Alibaba said it had been focused on large language models and generative AI for a number of years.

site_title: Sunak’s reshuffle gamble to spur UK growth
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has reshuffled his Cabinet, creating three new departments: the Department for Business and Trade, the Department for Energy Security and Net Zero, and the Department for Science, Innovation and Technology. The changes aim to deliver on policy priorities, including halving inflation and growing the economy. However, the reforms may amount to little more than rearranging deckchairs, with some critics arguing that they represent a "return to the past." The new science and technology department may help address the UK's innovation gap, but its impact on the economy remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Since entering Downing Street in October, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has been under pressure to stamp his authority not only on his government but also over his party.

site_title: Investors see Hong Kong property stocks, funds as reopening trades
summary: Global investors are seeking profit opportunities in Hong Kong's property sector as China reopens from pandemic controls. After a 15.6% drop in 2022, Hong Kong home prices are expected to rise, driven by tourism and retail consumption. Investors are attracted to beaten-down property stocks and real estate funds, with some rising over 10% this year. Fund managers see value in Hong Kong Reits due to their lower valuations and high dividend yields, and expect interest rates to fall, benefiting these investments.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has been pursuing a plan to become Asia’s digital-asset capital, including a licencing programme for crypto platforms set to be enforced in March that will allow retail trading.

site_title: Hong Kong hires banks for debut digital green bond sale
summary: Hong Kong's government has hired banks to arrange its debut sale of digital green bonds, aiming to raise HK$800 million (S$135.8 million) via tokenized green notes. The bonds will be issued on a distributed ledger technology-based platform provided by Goldman Sachs, offering faster settlement and payment. This move is part of Hong Kong's efforts to become Asia's digital-asset capital, including a licencing programme for crypto platforms set to be enforced in March, and to become a hub for sustainable financing.

images.alt_text: A general view of the Hong Kong skyline from the kowloon district of Hong Kong on February 2, 2023. - Hong Kong is ready to welcome the world back, its US-sanctioned leader told business and tourism heavyweights on February 2 as he pitched free flights and positive publicity to resurrect the once-vibrant global hub. (Photo by ISAAC LAWRENCE / AFP)
Authorities last month announced eight locations for the homes that would have a unit size of 140 to 330 square feet to accommodate families of one to five people.

site_title: The transatlantic subsidies race we need
summary: European leaders should avoid emulating the US Inflation Reduction Act's green industrial policy, which could lead to a subsidy race and favor domestic producers over international ones. The US law's "buy American" component has sparked concerns, but it's unlikely to guarantee US leadership in green industries. Instead, governments should focus on research and development for new technologies, rather than offering subsidies to existing ones. This approach would be more economically efficient and conducive to long-term emissions reductions.

images.alt_text: European Commission proposed loosening state aid rules for investments in renewable energy or decarbonising industry, on a temporary basis, until end 2025.
Transforming our energy sources from fossil fuels will be one of the largest capital expendi­tures in history.
The EU's plan to loosen subsidy rules within the bloc follows the US' Inflation Reduction Act, which includes about US$500 billion in new spending and tax breaks to benefit US companies.

site_title: Japan's 10-year bonds untraded as investors digest reports of new BOJ governor
summary: Japan's 10-year government bonds were untraded on Monday due to investors digesting reports of the new BOJ governor, Kazuo Ueda, who is expected to be dovish. The yield remained flat at 0.490% as of Friday's close. Yields on super-long dated notes fell after a firm auction, with the 20-year JGB yield decreasing 3 basis points to 1.305%. The market was supported by the view that Ueda would be a dovish governor, and benchmark 10-year JGB futures rose 0.1 yen to 146.64.

images.alt_text: Kazuo Ueda, an academic, has been nominated as the next governor of the Bank of Japan.

site_title: Oil falls on demand concerns as impact of Russian output cut fades
summary: Oil prices fell 0.8% to $85.70 a barrel on Monday, after rising 2% the previous session, due to concerns over short-term demand. Russia's planned 5% output cut in March, announced in response to western sanctions, has already been largely priced in, according to analysts. Refinery maintenance in Asia and the US also contributed to the price drop, despite optimism over China's oil demand recovery.

images.alt_text: Opec projects demand to further rise to 110 million barrels per day by 2025.

site_title: Gold ticks lower as dollar firms, US inflation data in focus
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,861.76 per ounce on Monday, as the dollar strengthened, making gold more expensive for foreign buyers. The US inflation data this week is expected to influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike path, with market participants anticipating the target rate to peak at 5.177% in July. Physical gold buyers in some Asian hubs were drawn to the dip in domestic prices, while central bank demand kept premiums firm in China.

images.alt_text: Gold is sensitive to high interest rates which lift the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Global bond bulls’ biggest BOJ fear already well under way
summary: Global bond investors are concerned that Japanese investors are shifting their assets from overseas to domestic bonds, with a record US$181 billion of foreign debt sold last year. The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) potential policy shift under new governor Kazuo Ueda could drive Japanese yields higher, tempting insurers and pension funds to return cash home. This could lead to a destabilizing spillover into global debt markets. Despite the BOJ's artificially capped 10-year yield, domestic institutions may favor local bonds over hedged US Treasuries due to high hedging costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen and U.S. dollar are seen in this illustration picture taken September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
Kazuo Ueda, an academic, has been nominated as the next governor of the Bank of Japan.

site_title: LMIRT flags potential negative effect on distributions after Moody’s rating downgrade
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) has faced a Moody's rating downgrade from B3 to Caa1, citing an "unsustainable capital structure and weak financial management." The downgrade may negatively affect the trust's distributions to holders of its units and perpetual securities. LMIRT's manager is exploring options to maintain a sustainable capital structure and reduce leverage, but these measures may impact distributions. The trust remains in compliance with financial covenants and aggregate leverage limits.

images.alt_text: Moody’s maintains its negative outlook on all ratings.

Although LMIRT demonstrated an ability to “tap banks and capital markets” even during the worst of the Covid-19 pandemic, Fitch analysts said execution risks have “increased significantly” as capital market conditions have turned unfavourable.

site_title: What to watch in the biomedical space over the next five years
summary: The biomedical sector is expected to remain a bright spot in the next five years, driven by long-term trends and enduring behaviors. mRNA innovations, fueled by the pandemic, are expected to continue growing. However, investors have become cautious due to macroeconomic headwinds, potentially leading to a correction in company valuations. Asia is expected to drive and gain from dollar asset diversification, with the region emerging as a key player in the field.

images.alt_text: Large manufacturing projects from the electronics sector accounted for 66.7 per cent of fixed asset investment commitments in 2022.
Some of the major investments secured by Singapore in 2022 came from the manufacturing industry.
Chu Swee Yeok helms government investment arm EDBI, whose investments include Moderna, ByteDance and Grab.
Dr Sean Fu (left), chief executive of RVAC Medicines, and Dr Koh Boon Tong, executive director of A*Star's Bioprocessing Technology Institute, at the signing ceremony of the collaboration agreement.

From left: A*STAR deputy chief executive (Research) Prof Andy Hor; Enterprise SG ACE Mr Soh Leng Wan; NTU Senior vice president (Research) Prof Lam Khin Yong;  NHG Deputy group ceo (Education and Research) Prof Benjamin Seet

site_title: DBS raises dividends amid record Q4 profit; CEO expects FY2023 outlook to remain robust
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, reported a record Q4 profit of S$2.34 billion, beating the S$2.16 billion average estimate. The bank's CEO, Piyush Gupta, expects FY2023 to remain robust despite interest rate hikes, citing strong asset quality and sustained loan momentum. DBS will pay a special dividend of S$0.50 per share and a final dividend of S$0.42 per share, totaling S$2 per share. The bank's net interest margins rose to 2.05%, and its non-performing loans ratio improved to 1.1%. DBS also announced several senior management changes.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Vivienne Tay

The rate of NIM expansion has likely started to moderate in the fourth quarter of 2022, analysts said. Nevertheless, the banks’ high capital levels and above-regulation provisioning coverage mean an upside surprise in dividends.
Investors can use funds within their CPF OA to purchase T-bills, by opening a CPF investment account with either DBS, UOB or OCBC.
UOB is CGS-CIMB’s top sector pick for its more attractive valuations, in the research house's view.
DBS raised the maximum interest rate on the Multiplier account to 4.1 per cent a year, up from 3.5 per cent previously.

site_title: As funding costs surge, China set to pump extra cash into money market
summary: China's central bank is expected to increase its cash injection into the money market this week, with a possible 450 billion yuan (S$87.8 billion) injection, to ease funding costs and support the economy. This move comes after a surge in overnight borrowing costs and a record 4.9 trillion yuan in new loans extended by Chinese banks in January. The injection will also replenish long-term funds for banks and maintain a pro-growth stance, despite questions about the sustainability of the consumption rebound and the risk of another Covid wave.

images.alt_text: The PBOC is expected to keep policies accommodative in the near term in terms of liquidity injection and credit supply to solidify the recovery.

site_title: Investors worldwide want to work from the beach
summary: Investors worldwide prefer working from Florida, particularly Miami, due to its low taxes and favorable climate. The state's housing market is expected to be the hottest residential market this year, with waterfront properties reaching record values. However, the US housing market is expected to decline, with mortgage rates above 5.5% and a cumulative 6.7% home price decline forecasted over the next two years, according to Fannie Mae. This could hurt confidence and spending, negatively impacting the broader economy.

images.alt_text: Consumers expect inflation to rise 2.9 per cent over the next five to 10 years, unchanged from the prior two months.
Workers remain scarce in some industries in the US. There were 1.9 job openings for every unemployed person in December, government data showed last week.

site_title: Tenants are fleeing London at record pace to escape rising rents
summary: London's tenant exodus accelerates, with 90,000 rental households leaving the city in 2022, a record high since 2012. This reverses the trend of 2021, when more homeowners fled than renters for the first time in a decade. The exodus is driven by pricey monthly payments, with four in 10 renters choosing to leave due to financial constraints. Rents show no signs of deviating from their upward trajectory, according to a report from Hamptons International.

images.alt_text: The expected median annual pay awards in the UK rose to 5 per cent in 2023 – the highest since CIPD records began in 2012 – from 4 per cent in the previous three months.

The Consumer Prices Index has leapt 11.1 per cent in October and then ticked down to 10.5 per cent in December. Official figures due on Wednesday (Feb 15) are likely to show it remained above 10 per cent in January.

site_title: Fragrance Group founder Koh Wee Meng to take Global Dragon private at S$0.12 per share
summary: Fragrance Group founder Koh Wee Meng has made a voluntary conditional cash offer to take Catalist-listed Global Dragon private at S$0.12 per share, valuing the company at S$81.8 million. Koh's offer is expected to save on compliance expenses and allow the company to focus on business operations. The deal has been supported by irrevocable undertakings from Koh and other parties, holding an 81.98% stake in Global Dragon. The offer price is 14.3% above the company's closing price on February 7.

images.alt_text: Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore. The company’s S$0.90 per share offer translates to a premium of 7.8 per cent over Boustead Projects’ last traded price per share of S$0.835 on the Singapore Exchange on Feb 3.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Monday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.4% or 14.74 points to 3,375.41. The benchmark index reversed last week's loss streak, with gainers outnumbering losers 80 to 43. Thomson Medical was the top traded counter by volume, rising as much as 4.2% during early trade. The gains come ahead of upcoming GDP data.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The mainboard-listed bank has posted a 69 per cent year-on-year rise in net profit to a record S$2.3 billion for its fourth quarter ended December.

site_title: China’s banks extend record loans as companies borrow more
summary: Chinese banks extended a record 4.9 trillion yuan (S$957 billion) in new loans in January, exceeding economists' estimates, as the government urged lenders to "front-load" credit extension. The surge in corporate loans and corporate bond issuance, while consumer borrowing remained subdued, may signal a recovery in some sectors following the abandonment of China's Covid Zero policy. The People's Bank of China is likely to stick to its supportive monetary policy stance, with economists expecting continued liquidity injections and credit supply to solidify the recovery.

images.alt_text: A woman takes pictures of the China Development Bank booth at the 2021 China International Fair for Trade in Services (CIFTIS) in Beijing, China September 3, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo
The economy broadly improved in January after the nation removed its Covid Zero restrictions at the end of last year.
A turnaround has emerged since November when Beijing stepped up efforts to salvage the ailing housing market as economic growth overtook Covid controls as policymakers’ top priority

site_title: Trafigura’s nickel nemesis was already notorious in metal circles
summary: Trafigura Group secured a US$625 million freezing order against Indian businessman Prateek Gupta and his companies, citing "systematic fraud" related to missing nickel cargoes. Gupta has a checkered history in the trading world, with previous companies, including Gunvor Group and TransAsia Private Capital, reporting losses. Several individuals and institutions, including banks and counterparties, have become uncomfortable with Gupta's trading activities. India's federal police is also investigating allegations of fraud against Gupta. The freezing order freezes Gupta's assets, effectively halting his business operations.

images.alt_text: Shaken by spiking commodities, trading houses adapt to survive
Zinc surged after one of Europe’s largest smelters announced it would halt production next month as the continent’s energy crisis threatens to hobble heavy industries.

site_title: Singapore’s export growth slows to 3% in 2022; expected to be flat or decline in 2023
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth slowed to 3% in 2022 from 12.1% in 2021, in line with earlier estimates. For 2023, trade performance is expected to moderate, with forecasts ranging from -2% to 0% for both NODX and total merchandise trade. Economists predict a potentially sharper contraction in NODX exports due to weak global demand, particularly in the semiconductor sector, and uncertainty over China's economy.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
NODX to XX
Given the weaker-than-expected December NODX print, Singapore's key exports are expected to contract further in the coming months, according to private-sector economists.

site_title: The climate pledges of leading global companies don’t add up
summary: A new report by Carbon Market Watch and the NewClimate Institute found that climate pledges by leading global companies fall short of required progress to avoid catastrophic global temperatures. The report analyzed 24 large corporations, finding that only five companies commit to decarbonizing their emissions by at least 90% by their net-zero target years. Most companies lack short-term ambition, and their climate strategies are often exaggerated, misleading, or lack transparency. The report calls for better enforcement of regulations and oversight to prevent "greenwashing" and misleading climate claims.

images.alt_text: The EU's plan to loosen subsidy rules within the bloc follows the US' Inflation Reduction Act, which includes about US$500 billion in new spending and tax breaks to benefit US companies.

investors are asking ESG-related questions relating to businesses – referring to sustainability ratings and metrics when assessing an organisation’s suitability for inclusion in their investment portfolios.

site_title: SoftBank’s Arm China lays off workers as outlook grim: sources
summary: SoftBank's Arm China, a joint venture, laid off 90-95 employees, mostly engineers, amid a challenging business outlook. The layoffs come as SoftBank prepares for a potential public listing of Arm this year. The China market has been a significant source of growth, but a two-year management dispute created challenges. Arm China had about 700 employees before the layoffs, and parent Arm stated that the business in China remains strong. The move follows global layoffs and regulatory hurdles affecting SoftBank's efforts to generate funds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: SoftBank Corp's logo is pictured at a news conference in Tokyo, Japan, February 4, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon/File Photo
Masayoshi Son’s decision to shy away from the spotlight comes as investors and creditors are questioning SoftBank’s ability to navigate daunting investment waters.
SoftBank shouldered big writedowns on investments in some of the world’s most high-flying startups, resulting in deep losses last year.

site_title: Star Entertainment warns of up to A$1.6 billion earnings hit, shares plumb record low
summary: Star Entertainment Group warned of an up to A$1.6 billion impairment charge due to a proposed casino duty hike in New South Wales, sending its shares tumbling 22% to a record low. The tax reform poses significant challenges to the company's Sydney operations, which made up half of its revenue in 2022. The company plans to review its operating model and assets if the proposal goes ahead, and expects underlying earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) of A$330-360 million for the year ending June 30, 2023.

images.alt_text: People walk past the Casino Lisboa operated by SJM Holdings during Lunar New Year in Macau, China, Jan 24, 2023.

site_title: Saudi Aramco says ESG investing threatens energy security
summary: Saudi Aramco's CEO, Amin Nasser, warned that an increased focus on climate change and Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) investing is threatening energy security. The company's comments come as global investments in clean energy reached $1.1 trillion in 2022, surpassing fossil fuel production for the first time. Nasser stated that ESG-driven policies could lead to underinvestment in oil and gas, posing serious implications for the global economy and energy affordability.

images.alt_text: The city — in cooperation with mainland exchanges — is changing rules to allow China’s retail investors to buy shares of overseas-based companies listed on the local bourse for the first time.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, ThaiBev, Sats, Thomson Medical, EC World Reit
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest lender, reported a record net profit of S$2.3 billion for its fourth quarter, a 69% year-on-year rise. The bank's total income rose 41% to S$4.6 billion, driven by higher net interest income. ThaiBev recorded a 4.9% year-on-year increase in sales revenue to S$3.2 billion in the first quarter. These developments may impact trading of their securities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: DBS signages are seen in Singapore, October 8, 2019. REUTERS/Feline Lim/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: Adani cuts growth target, capex in post-Hindenburg repair moves
summary: Gautam Adani's conglomerate has halved its revenue growth target to 15-20% for the next financial year and will delay capital expenditure as it seeks to rebuild investor confidence following a short seller attack by Hindenburg Research. The group is focusing on conserving cash, repaying debt, and retrieving pledged shares to undo the damage from the scandal. By scaling back investments, Adani aims to save around $3 billion, which can be used to pay down debt or boost cash reserves. The plans are being reviewed and finalized in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Television journalists are seen outside the premises of the Supreme Court in New Delhi, India, January 22, 2020. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis

Moody’s announced the a downgrade of the ratings outlook to negative from stable for four firms – Adani Green Energy, Adani Green Energy Restricted Group, Adani Transmission Step-One and Adani Electricity Mumbai.
The Securities and Exchange Board of India (above) is investigating the Adani Group and some of its investors, amid growing concern over allegations made by an activist short-seller.

site_title: UN admits aid failure for Syria as quake toll tops 33,000
summary: The United Nations has admitted to its failure in shipping aid to war-torn Syria, where over 33,000 people have died from the earthquake. A UN convoy with supplies arrived in north-west Syria via Turkey, but more aid is needed for millions affected by the disaster. The UN's relief chief, Martin Griffiths, criticized the agency's inability to reach millions in need, while the Syrian government has expressed readiness to consider additional border crossings for aid. The death toll is expected to rise further as rescue efforts continue.

images.alt_text: The World Food Programme wants more border crossings to open from Turkey into Syria which is experiencing severe shortages.
The United Nations warned that at least 870,000 people were now in urgent need of hot meals across Turkey and Syria. In Syria alone, up to 5.3 million people may have been made homeless.
Environment Minister Murat Kurum says that 24,921 buildings across the region had collapsed or were heavily damaged in the quake, based on assessments of more than 170,000 buildings.

site_title: Turkey’s once mighty developers under fire after quake
summary: Turkey's developers are under fire after a devastating earthquake struck the country, killing over 29,000 people. Investigations and arrests have been launched, with 114 warrants issued for individuals and 134 investigations underway. Critics argue that shoddy business dealings contributed to the disaster, with many buildings constructed across fault lines without proper safety standards. Turkey's adoption of California-style building codes has been undermined by developers striking private deals with companies responsible for inspections, allowing for lax enforcement and cost-cutting measures.

images.alt_text: Rescuers carry out search operations among the rubble of collapsed buildings in Adiyaman, Turkey on Feb 9, 2023, three days after a 7,8-magnitude earthquake struck south-east Turkey.
Environment Minister Murat Kurum says that 24,921 buildings across the region had collapsed or were heavily damaged in the quake, based on assessments of more than 170,000 buildings.
A White Helmet volunteer stands among rubble, in the aftermath of a deadly earthquake, in Harem, Idlib, Syria, Feb 10, 2023.

site_title: Singapore’s 2022 GDP growth lower than advance estimates at 3.6%, 2023 forecast kept at 0.5-2.5%
summary: Singapore's 2022 GDP growth slowed to 3.6%, lower than the initial estimate of 3.8%, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. This marked a decrease from the 8.9% growth rate in 2021. The fourth-quarter growth rate was 2.1% year-on-year, moderating from the 4% expansion in the third quarter. Despite this, the 2023 forecast remains unchanged at 0.5-2.5%, with economists maintaining a cautious outlook due to global headwinds and uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
A general view shows the city skyline in Singapore on December 1, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Are share buybacks good for investors? (Ep 28)
summary: Share buybacks, where companies repurchase shares from the market, can benefit exiting shareholders but may disadvantage continuing shareholders. Companies often pursue buybacks at the wrong time, and their methods can be opportunistic. Investor Warren Buffett's approach to buybacks should be emulated. Investors can also vote against share purchase mandates at Annual General Meetings. The practice of share buybacks can be seen as discriminatory and should be scrutinized by corporate boards to ensure fairness for all shareholders.

images.alt_text: SGX said in a report on Jan 9 that primary-listed companies repurchased S$1.69 billion worth of their own shares in 2022
Where are the potential opportunities and risks for investors in 2023?

site_title: Crude palm oil export restrictions creating demand for Oiltek’s services
summary: Oiltek International's chief executive, Henry Yong, notes a high order book due to Indonesia's crude palm oil export restrictions and a shortage of cooking oil, driving demand for the company's services. The company's FY2022 revenue grew 62.7% to RM163.7 million and earnings rose 30.5% to RM12.7 million. With RM196.1 million secured in 2022, the order book has grown to RM209.9 million, indicating the company's potential in 2023.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Oiltek will assess if the fire incident will have any material financial impact on its results for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2023.
The latest contract wins bring the Oiltek's current order book to RM236 million
The order book will be fulfilled over the next 18 to 24 months, barring unforeseen circumstances, said Oiltek International, a solutions provider in the oils and fats industry.

site_title: Goldman chief says bank’s job cuts should have been earlier: FT
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon expressed regret over the timing of the bank's job cuts, stating he should have acted sooner to reduce the workforce of 3,200 positions. The move was made in response to declining revenue and profit, with Solomon citing the underlying strength of Goldman's trading and investment banking operations. The job cuts are part of the bank's efforts to cut costs and adapt to changing market conditions.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 15, 2010 a plaque for investment banking giant Goldman Sachs reflects attendants at a press conference in Hong Kong. - Goldman Sachs plans to cut 3,200 jobs and could announce this as early as this week, a source close to the issue said on January 8, 2023, confirming press reports. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Battery giant LG Chem prepares to lock in raw material supply
summary: LG Chem, a major battery producer, is prioritizing securing raw materials for electric vehicle (EV) batteries, aiming to establish a self-sufficient global supply chain. The company's CEO, Shin Hak-cheol, emphasized the importance of securing raw materials over price, stating that the industry's supply chain fragility has been exacerbated by global events. LG Chem is exploring partnerships and investments in mining companies to achieve this goal, and is also diversifying its supply chain by focusing on three mega regions of the world.

images.alt_text: The logo of LG Chem is seen at its office building in Seoul, South Korea, October 16, 2020. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo
LG Chem’s new plant will make cathodes for batteries with a nickel, cobalt, manganese and aluminium (NCMA) chemistry

site_title: Co-living here to stay amid soaring housing costs: NUS poll
summary: A quarterly survey by the National University of Singapore Real Estate found that co-living spaces in Singapore are expected to continue growing, with over half of respondents believing it will remain a permanent fixture in the local property market. The survey also revealed that co-living is more likely to be chosen by those with lower household incomes, particularly in the face of rising housing costs. The market's growth is attributed to its affordability and community lifestyle, with developers more likely to collaborate with co-living operators rather than directly investing in the business.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
In Singapore, an acute supply crunch and an influx of wealth has pushed up rents.
Sound reasons exist for some buyers to pay over a million dollars each for certain HDB resale flats.
Chinese have been the largest foreign buyer group in Singapore since 2016 and made up 6.9 per cent of foreign purchases of private apartments last year.

site_title: Productivity is not enough – to tackle costs, Budget 2023 can offer help with sustainability
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 aims to address rising costs, particularly manpower costs, which have driven inflation. The country's tight labor market and high unemployment rates have led to a surge in wages, with nominal median income rising 8.3% last year. To offset these costs, the government may focus on sustainability efforts, encouraging companies to improve their efficiency and save resources. This approach could also help workers gain green skills, justifying wage growth. However, if productivity improvements hit a limit, companies may need to explore other cost-saving measures.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
A weaker economic outlook weighs on businesses and households, but handouts will need to be carefully calibrated, with a continued eye on longer-term needs, economists said.

site_title: US shoots down another object, this time over Lake Huron
summary: US warplanes shot down a flying object over Lake Huron on Sunday, the fourth in a series of incidents that began with the downing of a suspected Chinese spy balloon a week ago. The object was described as small and cylindrical, roughly the size of a Volkswagen car, and was shot down by US F-22 jets. The US military has not confirmed the origin of the object, but US lawmakers have accused China of "an act of belligerence." The incident has heightened tensions between the US and China, with the US reiterating its concerns about Chinese espionage.

images.alt_text: White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre, speaking separately to reporters on Air Force One, described the balloons as part of a “fleet” and said they had been spotted around the world for several years.
The incident is the latest in an escalating aerial drama that came to the forefront after an alleged Chinese spy balloon traversed the continent earlier this month.

site_title: Jumbo promotes executive director Christina Kong to chief operating officer
summary: Jumbo Group has promoted its 54-year-old executive director Christina Kong to chief operating officer, effective February 13. Kong will manage overall operations, while her human resource and training divisions will be reassigned. Kong was previously the manager of human resources and corporate affairs from 2008 to 2015 and was appointed an executive director in 2015. The promotion was approved by the board of directors, following recommendations from the nominating committee. Shares of Jumbo fell 1.6% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Jumbo Group's outlet at Chip Mong 271 Mega Mall in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.
CGS-CIMB analysts foresee a further ramp-up in FY2023 Singapore revenue for Jumbo Group.
JUMBO Seafood Chilli Crab / 泽良

site_title: Hong Leong Foundation holds Silver Sports Day for senior residents
summary: The Hong Leong Foundation held its annual Silver Sports Day event at M Hotel, benefiting senior residents from three senior homes. Over 80 elderly people, aged 60-100, participated in a specially customized workout program that tested their mobility, motor control, and hand-eye coordination. The event was aided by around 50 staff volunteers from various Hong Leong Group companies, including City Developments Limited and Millennium Hotels and Resorts. The charity event aimed to promote physical activity and engagement among senior residents.

images.alt_text: Guest-of-Honour Minister for National Development and Minister-in-charge of Social Services Integration Desmond Lee, UOL group chief executive Liam Wee Sin, PPHG executive director, sustainability partnerships, lifestyle and asset Wee Wei Ling, and PPHG chief executive Choe Peng Sum with children and families from ComLink at the launch of the UOL-PPHG Community Uplift Programme.
The festive bags, or fu dais, are packed by more than 1,300 volunteers over two days.

site_title: Texans of Chinese descent fret that ‘dreams have been smashed’
summary: Protesters in Houston, Texas, opposed a proposed bill that would ban Chinese nationals from buying properties in the state, citing discrimination and national security concerns. The bill, sponsored by Republican state Senator Lois Kolkhorst, has sparked fears among immigrants and Chinese Americans, who argue that it would unfairly target a specific group. Demonstrators, including veterans and business owners, marched through Chinatown, chanting slogans against the bill and calling for equal rights. Experts say the bill's ambiguity on issues like dual nationality raises concerns about its impact on legal residents and green card holders.

images.alt_text: Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin says the US has “politicised and weaponised economic cooperation”.

site_title: A spectacular, rain-free start as BT golf league returns with aplomb
summary: The BT Corporate Golf League returned with a spectacular start at Sentosa Golf Course, with Team Boss led by Jonathan Lee taking the first-leg honours. Lee's stellar performance with 37 points earned him top honours, beating teammates and Centurion's Eugene Teo on countback. The event, presented by Singapore Pools, prioritized networking and camaraderie, with over 100 golfers participating. Team Boss will be the team to watch in the second leg, while Team I-Kare topped the social section with 109 points.

images.alt_text: "The Business Times" editor Chen Huifen speaking at a networking event on Feb 2 to launch the BT Corporate Golf League 2023 tournament.

site_title: Nissan aims to make Europe core market for car sales: FT report
summary: Nissan plans to elevate Europe to a core market for car sales, alongside Japan, China, and the US, after gaining market share in the region. The company will reverse plans to reduce model range and increase electric and hybrid vehicles to 98% by 2026. Nissan will also introduce an entry-level electric vehicle and strengthen its collaboration with Renault. This move aims to increase car sales in Europe and follow the success of similar strategies in Japan, China, and the US.

site_title: Hang Seng Index consolidating for potential rebound
summary: The Hang Seng Index (HSI) has rebounded from a low of 14,597 in October 2022, supported by China's relaxation of zero-Covid policies and increased clarity on industry regulations. The index now sits above the 20,000 level, driven by China's growth kickstart policies and regulatory clarity. This rebound is attributed to the easing of pandemic restrictions and regulatory concerns impacting consumer confidence in technology and platform companies. The HSI's recent consolidation is seen as a response to the quick reversal of restrictions, with the index expected to continue its upward trend.

site_title: EC World Reit releases 198.9 million yuan of margin deposit from escrow for loan repayment
summary: EC World Reit has released 198.9 million yuan (S$38.9 million) from escrow to partially repay its offshore and onshore bank loans. The trust used the funds to pay 140.2 million yuan towards offshore loans and 58.6 million yuan towards onshore loans, saving on interest payments. The remaining margin deposit of 1.1 million yuan remains in escrow.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The long stop date for EC World Reit's proposed divestment of Bei Gang Logistics (above) and Chongxian Port Logistics has been extended to Feb 28, 2023.
EC World Reit's manager said lenders are in the process of obtaining the relevant internal approval for the repayment plan.

site_title: Crucial Sembmarine EGM should be in-person
summary: Sembcorp Marine's upcoming extraordinary general meeting (EGM) will be held via electronic means, despite the company's transformation into a multi-billion-dollar entity. Shareholders, including long-standing investor Mano Sabnani, are disappointed with this approach, citing the Covid-19 threat has largely subsided and authorities encourage physical or hybrid meetings. Sabnani argues that in-person meetings allow for better interaction with directors, management, and fellow shareholders, as well as active Q&A sessions and informal discussions. Sembcorp Marine can still allow shareholders to attend the meeting, even if it means postponing it, to demonstrate its commitment to transparency and shareholder engagement.

images.alt_text: The queries from SIAS come ahead of Sembmarine’s extraordinary general meeting (EGM) next Thursday (Feb 16) where shareholders would vote on the proposed merger.
Sembmarine said its independent directors recommend that shareholders vote in favour of its merger with Keppel O&M.
Keppel sky sign taken at Ocean Financial Centre.

site_title: Rising rentals a double-edged sword for co-living operators
summary: Co-living operators in Singapore are experiencing a surge in interest from tenants seeking alternative housing options due to rising private rentals. Occupancy rates remain high at 95-97%, with a 10% increase. However, co-living operators themselves face higher rentals on leased spaces, prompting business model shifts and sector consolidation.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Real estate honchos believe the co-living spaces, such as Figment (pictured above), is here to stay.
The hotel — Owen House by Hmlet — is a 106-key hotel with room sizes ranging up to 52 square meters.
LHN intends to operate the property – which currently houses a backpacker hostel – as a co-living space under its co-living brand Coliwoo.

site_title: A Singapore working mother’s three-item wish list for Budget 2023
summary: A Singapore working mother has compiled a three-item wish list for Budget 2023, based on a crowdsourced survey of over 200 working parents. The top requests include: (1) promoting flexible work arrangements to support working parents, (2) increasing the Child Development Account (CDA) to help with childcare fees, and (3) expanding childcare and parental leave policies, such as shared maternity leave and family care leave. The mother emphasizes the need for meaningful support to improve working parents' lives and strengthen their commitment to their work.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
Men and women are equal in the workplace, until they aren't
Singapore Airlines cabin crew at the departure hall in Terminal 3 of Changi Airport on 24 May 2022.

site_title: Aspen subsidiaries slapped with writ of summons for RM15 million refund
summary: Aspen Group's subsidiaries, Aspen Vision Land and Aspen Vision City, have received a writ of summons from the Penang Development Corporation (PDC) seeking a refund of RM15 million for the construction of an ingress leading into various parcels of land in Batu Kawan. Aspen denies the allegations, stating that the construction has not been frustrated or impossible to perform. The company is seeking legal advice and will update shareholders on material developments. The dispute is part of ongoing settlement negotiations between Aspen and PDC.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Aspen Glove's manufacturing facility. The glove manufacturer intends to contest the notice of termination and demand from Gas Malaysia Energy and Services.
Aspen Glove's manufacturing facility in  Kedah.

site_title: With cash infusion, developing nations boost sun-dimming research
summary: A UK-based non-government group, Degrees Initiative, is funding $900,000 in research into solar radiation modification in 15 developing countries to cool a hotter planet. The research aims to mimic volcanic eruptions by dimming sunshine with sun-reflecting sulphur, a move critics say distracts from better climate change solutions. The project, which will be conducted in countries such as Nigeria, Chile, and India, is part of a broader effort to explore geoengineering as a means to combat global warming.

images.alt_text: rice terraces, sunset, mountains
The IEA estimates that the investible opportunity for the global energy sector to reach net zero by 2050, is about US$126 trillion over the next 30 years.
Retreating glacier, at Diavolezza ski area near the Alpine resort of Pontresina, Switzerland July 21, 2022.  REUTERS

site_title: Multi-storey car park at Textile Centre in Jalan Sultan on the market for S$36 million
summary: A multi-storey car park at Textile Centre in Singapore's Jalan Sultan is up for sale with a guide price of S$36 million. The 685-lot car park, along with a 4,838 sq ft plot of land, is owned by Plaza Development and managed by Mack Parking. Experts say the car park has potential for conversion to higher-value uses, such as restaurants or self-storage facilities, given its proximity to a rapid transit system station. The sale is expected to fetch an annual revenue of about S$1.625 million, with a gross yield of 4.5% on the S$36 million guide price.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Car park owners may need to install more electric vehicle charging points to meet rising use of electric vehicles, and risk car parks becoming redundant if driverless cars are widely used.
位于牛车水一带的珍珠大厦（People's Park Centre）外观。

site_title: China spots unidentified object flying near Qingdao: Paper
summary: China is preparing to bring down an unidentified object spotted flying near the port city of Qingdao, according to a report. This comes after the US and Canada brought down three high-altitude airborne objects this month, with one Washington claimed was sent deliberately by China for surveillance. China has denied this, stating the object was a harmless weather-monitoring device. The object's nature and intentions remain unclear.

site_title: Thailand-listed Capital Engineering Network to buy 19.9% stake in Asti from non-exec chairman
summary: Capital Engineering Network, a Thailand-listed company, will acquire a 19.9% stake in Asti Holdings, a local chip manufacturing services company, from its non-executive chairman Michael Loh. Loh will receive 80 million shares in Capital Engineering Network for his stake in Asti, worth about 216.1 million baht. The acquisition is subject to shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting on March 15. This move follows Asti's previous announcement of a possible exit offer to other shareholders, which was made after the company was suspended from the watch list.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Michael Loh, non-executive chairman of Asti Holdings, made the announcement on behalf of the board.
Asti Holdings chief executive officer Michael Loh Soon Gnee (pictured) was dismissed by the company after more than 8 years as chief last December.
LITHIUM-ION battery manufacturer EoCell, an associate of Asti Holdings, has entered into a non-binding letter of intent with an unnamed publicly-traded SPAC for a potential combination.

site_title: Investors face growing commodities risk lurking in ESG funds
summary: Investors in ESG funds are facing growing risks due to the mining industry's involvement in human rights abuses and environmental damage. The demand for minerals like cobalt, copper, and lithium is expected to soar 500% by mid-century, driven by the renewables boom. The Church of England Pensions Board and other investors are forming an alliance to highlight these risks and push for more accountability. The European Union has introduced regulations to ensure companies screen their supply chains for ESG risks, while companies like Tesla are redesigning batteries to avoid certain materials.

images.alt_text: Prices for lithium-ion batteries rose last year for the first time since at least 2010 as materials pushed up the price.

site_title: US reopens Montana airspace after ‘radar anomaly’ sparks concern
summary: The US reopened Montana airspace after a temporary closure to investigate a "radar anomaly." The North American Aerospace Defense Command (Norad) detected the anomaly and sent fighter jets to investigate, but no object was identified. This incident follows the recent downing of two unidentified objects over North America, including a Chinese spy balloon shot down last week. Norad will continue to monitor the situation, amid an escalating aerial drama.

site_title: Anwar’s daughter joins finance ministry committee
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's daughter, Nurul Izzah, has stepped down as his senior adviser on economics and finance to co-head the secretariat of an advisory committee to the finance minister, a role her father also holds. Her appointment had sparked criticism of nepotism, but Anwar defended it, stating she was qualified for the role and not being paid. This move comes as Malaysia navigates economic challenges, including a recent rate cut and concerns over tariffs.

images.alt_text: Ms Nurul Izzah Anwar had previously voiced her intention to defend her Permatang Pauh seat in the upcoming polls.

site_title: The great Thailand hotel fire sale that never happened
summary: Thailand's hotel sector has recovered from the Covid-19 pandemic, with 22 major hotel transactions worth 12.3 billion baht (S$484.7 million) in 2021. Despite the industry's pain, occupancy rates averaged only 9% in 2021, and few hotel bargain sales were reported. International tourist arrivals have jumped from 428,000 in 2021 to 11.2 million in 2022, with an anticipated 22-25 million this year. Analysts say buy opportunities loom ahead, but Thai hotel owners have traditionally been reluctant to sell, and the government's leniency in collecting loans has also contributed to the lack of fire sales.

images.alt_text: Thailand expects more than 20 million foreign tourist arrivals this year.
In 2022, Thailand beat its tourism target with 11.15 million foreign visitors.

site_title: Sealing drafty UK homes to save energy raises a £19 billion tab
summary: The UK government proposes a £19 billion (S$30.5 billion) tab to require homes starting tenancies after April 2025 to have a minimum C energy performance rating, affecting 2.45 million properties. The move aims to reduce energy consumption and meet climate goals, but raises concerns about the financial burden on landlords, potentially leading to increased volatility in the real estate market and the withdrawal of private landlords.

images.alt_text: A sign for online estate agent Purplebricks is pictured outside a property in a residential street in London. According to agents and consultants of both buyers and sellers, quality apartments and houses in London and the south of England are in short supply.

site_title: Singapore must improve completeness of sustainability efforts: UN Global Compact chief
summary: Singapore's policymakers and businesses must improve the completeness of their sustainability efforts, according to Sanda Ojiambo, Assistant Secretary-General of the UN Global Compact. The country's sustainability journey should focus on addressing both environmental and social elements, as well as governance transparency. Ojiambo emphasized the need for businesses to report on their commitments, not just for compliance, but to make better business decisions and attract capital investment. She also praised Singapore's efforts in sustainability initiatives, such as the Green Plan 2030, but highlighted the importance of public-private collaboration to address global challenges.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
The green transition presents both a challenge and an opportunity.
Sustainable financing must make commercial sense for investors, market players say
Transforming our energy sources from fossil fuels will be one of the largest capital expendi­tures in history.

site_title: LHN unit Coliwoo buys GSM Building for S$80 million, matching valuation
summary: LHN unit Coliwoo has acquired the GSM Building at Middle Road in Singapore for S$80 million, matching the property's valuation. The building, with a tenure of 99 years, will be converted into serviced apartments, with the first and second levels retained for commercial use. The acquisition is expected to expand Coliwoo's portfolio and increase brand value, with potential capital appreciation and revenue generation opportunities.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
LHN says it will continue growing its co-living business as rising rental rates drive demand for alternatives.
Space @ Tampines, a 59-unit industrial property can host companies in general and special industries.
LHN intends to operate the property – which currently houses a backpacker hostel – as a co-living space under its co-living brand Coliwoo.

site_title: Turkey steps up collapsed buildings investigation, orders 113 arrested
summary: Turkey has ordered the detention of 113 suspects in connection with the collapse of buildings during the recent devastating earthquakes, with 131 suspects identified as responsible. Environment Minister Murat Kurum reported that 24,921 buildings had collapsed or were heavily damaged in the quake, which has resulted in over 28,000 deaths. The government vows to investigate thoroughly and has established earthquake crimes investigation bureaus in affected provinces.

images.alt_text: The United Nations warned that at least 870,000 people were now in urgent need of hot meals across Turkey and Syria. In Syria alone, up to 5.3 million people may have been made homeless.

site_title: Manulife US Reit’s manager and sponsor group need to deliver real value rather than just words
summary: Manulife US Reit, a real estate investment trust, is seeking to reposition its portfolio and improve financial flexibility despite its gearing breaching 40% in 2020. The manager has executed leases for 123,000 sq ft in Q4 2022 and is exploring options to enhance unitholder value. Analysts believe the Reit's battered units now offer a forward yield of 14% and have priced in operational challenges. The manager is retaining 9% of its H2 2022 distributable income and is in negotiations with the sponsor on a potential asset disposition. However, investors should keep expectations in check due to rising interest rates and a slowing US economy.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul

Among the major obstacles to Manulife US Reit addressing its leverage problem are that interest rates are rising and emerging hybrid work arrangements are creating uncertainty in the office property sector
The lobby of Figueroa, Manulife US Reit's 35-storey class A office building in Los Angeles. It makes up 44 per cent of the overall portfolio's valuation decline.
Manulife US Reit says that despite challenges in the Reit’s submarkets, portfolio occupancy remained stable at 88 per cent as at end-Dec, which was above the US Class A average of 83.3 per cent.

site_title: 9,700 households have sold part of their remaining leases back to HDB since 2009
summary: HDB's Lease Buyback Scheme has seen 9,700 households sell part of their remaining leases since 2009, with nearly 70% receiving between S$100,000 and S$200,000. Since 2020, the scheme has maintained a steady yearly take-up of around 1,500 households. Most households chose to retain 30 years of their lease, with 61% opting for this duration. The proceeds from selling part of their lease are used to top up CPF Retirement Accounts and purchase CPF Life plans, with 69% of households receiving cash balances.

images.alt_text: National Development Minister Desmond Lee highlighted that public housing affordability and accessibility cannot be solved with an oversupply of built-to-order flats.

site_title: Long-term investment outlook now brighter, says BlackRock’s Larry Fink
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink says long-term investment opportunities have opened up after interest rate hikes last year, with inflation expected to remain elevated at 3.5-4% in 2023. Fink notes that valuations have normalized towards a better long-term PE ratio and that bonds are becoming a more attractive investment option. However, he expresses concerns over China's long-term growth outlook, citing a shrinking and aging demographic, low birth rates, and a need for private sector-driven growth. Fink also emphasizes the importance of transformative technology, particularly in enhancing productivity, and the need for cheaper mechanisms for carbon sequestration and capture.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Larry Fink, Blackrock’s chief executive officer (CEO)
BlackRock's chief executive officer Larry Fink has been outspoken about investing with ESG goals, making it a focal point in his annual letters to the industry.
BlackRock had positive flows in its sustainable long-term products every quarter last year.

site_title: Two S-Reits lead the STI in early 2023
summary: Two Singapore Reits, Keppel DC Reit (KDCR) and Frasers Logistic & Commercial Trust (FLCT), have led the Straits Times Index (STI) in early 2023, with KDCR's prudent capital management and acquisitions helping it offset inflation's impact on costs. The STI has added 3.6% to its 2022 total return, forming a nine-month high, driven by regional markets focusing on China's economic growth outlook. FLCT's diversified portfolio and value-accretive acquisitions have also contributed to its strong performance, with the Reit maintaining a 13.6x interest cover ratio and 100% occupancy in its logistics and industrial portfolio.

images.alt_text: In 2022, Keppel DC Reit was among the 18 S-Reits that announced acquisitions, expanding its presence in London, and in Guangdong, one of China’s most established data centre markets.

site_title: Berlin’s barren housing market is putting its tech boom at risk
summary: Berlin's housing market shortage is putting its thriving tech sector at risk, with rising rents and unaffordable housing options forcing new recruits to take temporary housing or commute long distances. The city lacks 106,000 apartments, and the tech boom has contributed to the crisis by hiring thousands of high-paid workers. This has made recruiting more costly, with local companies cutting jobs to adapt to the housing crunch. The issue has significant political implications, with a vote on Sunday that could topple the incumbent mayor and impact Chancellor Olaf Scholz's party.

images.alt_text: The Generali Tower at the CityLife district designed by Zaha Hadid; CityLife is a mixed-use luxury district on the north-east outskirts of Milan featuring swanky buildings by starchitects Daniel Libeskind, Hadid and Arata Isozaki.

site_title: Opec expects demand to reach pre-pandemic levels this year
summary: Opec expects oil demand to reach pre-pandemic levels this year, surpassing 102 million barrels per day. The group projects demand to further rise to 110 million barrels per day by 2025, maintaining its commitment to supporting oil market stability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An OPEC sign is seen on the day of OPEC+ meeting in Vienna  in Vienna, Austria October 5, 2022. REUTERS/Lisa Leutner/File Photo

site_title: Sembmarine defends EGM decision, management performance after Sias queries
summary: Sembcorp Marine defended its management performance and board decisions in response to queries from the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) regarding its proposed merger with Keppel Offshore & Marine. The company stated it reviews its management performance regularly and has successfully secured a pipeline of new projects worth S$7 billion.
