Sembmarine's board believes the proposed combination is the best way forward for the company to unlock long-term value for its stakeholders, and the enlarged group will further accelerate its strategic transition into offshore renewables and cleaner O&M solutions.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The queries from SIAS come ahead of Sembmarine’s extraordinary general meeting (EGM) next Thursday (Feb 16) where shareholders would vote on the proposed merger.

site_title: Nato chief Stoltenberg plans to leave office in October
summary: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg plans to leave office in October, marking the end of his nearly nine-year tenure. Stoltenberg, who has served as a bridge between European allies and Washington, has no intention to seek another extension of his mandate. His departure comes as NATO faces ongoing challenges, including rising tensions with Russia and the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. Stoltenberg's successor has not yet been named.

images.alt_text: Biggest concentration of military forces in Europe now since Cold War: Stoltenberg

site_title: India discussing global crypto regulation in G20
summary: India is discussing a standardized global framework for regulating cryptocurrencies with G20 members, led by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, who emphasized the need for global consistency. Despite not banning trading, India introduced a harsh tax rate last year, significantly reducing crypto activity. This move echoes the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) call for robust, comprehensive, and globally consistent crypto regulation. India's G20 presidency this year is likely to focus on crypto regulation and climate change among other topics.

site_title: US dollar rises as investors look to inflation report; yen gains
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of six currencies, marking its second weekly gain, as investors anticipate a potentially higher-than-expected US inflation report. The yen also rose, driven by speculation that the Bank of Japan may adjust its monetary policy, although BOJ Governor-elect Kazuo Ueda stated that the current policy is appropriate. The dollar index reached 103.55, while the yen reached 131.435 against the US dollar, with the euro and sterling falling more than 1% against the yen.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen and U.S. dollar are seen in this illustration picture taken September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Link Reit plans HK$19.3 billion rights offering to expand war chest
summary: Link Reit, Asia's largest real estate investment trust, plans a HK$19.3 billion rights offering to expand its war chest. The company will issue up to 437.7 million shares at HK$44.2 each, primarily for debt repayment and investment opportunities. The move aims to strengthen its capital base and position it for accretive investments amid market repricing. Link Reit's net gearing ratio is expected to decrease to below 20%. The company has been actively expanding overseas, with recent acquisitions in Singapore and plans to diversify further in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of Hong Kong, China July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: A ‘People’s Budget’ that will almost certainly be expansionary
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 is expected to be expansionary, with reduced pandemic-related fiscal expenditures. The transition to a post-pandemic normal has led to new concerns, including cost of living worries and inflation. The government may provide fiscal firepower to strengthen the social compact. Key policy announcements include measures to strengthen the skills and training ecosystem, re-employment support, and incrementally more assurance for retirement security. The government may also introduce new taxes, including wealth taxes, to balance the budget. The budget will be closely watched for insights into how the fourth generation leaders will rally the people and corporate sector towards new definitions of success.

images.alt_text: Trust Bank Launch. Lawrence Wong, Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister
A common understanding of the key drivers of fiscal spending is needed for a realistic picture of the challenges ahead and how the country can marshal the resources to address them.
Combining government expenditure, operating revenue and net investment returns contribution projections, government spending will likely be balanced by total revenue in the coming years.

site_title: UK wage and inflation data set to fuel further BOE rate hikes
summary: The UK's Consumer Prices Index is expected to remain above 10% in January, fueling further interest rate hikes by the Bank of England (BOE). Economists predict double-digit price growth and record pay increases, supporting the BOE's argument for continued rate hikes. BOE Governor Andrew Bailey is near the end of the hiking cycle, but a tight jobs market and rising pay pressures pose a challenge in controlling inflation.

images.alt_text: Bailey says that he expects inflation to fall sharply this year, and that the UK may have turned the corner in terms of headline inflation.

site_title: US consumer sentiment hits more than one-year high
summary: US consumer sentiment reached a one-year high in February, increasing to 66.4 from 64.9 in January. Consumer expectations for inflation rose to 2.9% over the next 5-10 years, unchanged from prior months. The index of current conditions strengthened to 72.6, driven by optimism about personal finances and a rebound in stocks. However, concerns about rising unemployment and inflation are expected to lead to greater caution in spending in the months ahead.

images.alt_text: The consumer price index (CPI) edged up 0.1 per cent in December rather than dipping 0.1 per cent as reported last month, the Labor Department’s annual benchmark revisions of CPI data showed.

site_title: Next big debt wreck seen brewing in Indonesia builder binge
summary: Indonesia's top builders and developers, highly leveraged and facing looming maturities, are at risk of a debt wreck due to a decade of dramatic spending. The country's top four construction firms have seen their total debt surge 12-fold to 130 trillion rupiah, with state-owned PT Waskita Karya appealing for a fresh capital injection despite restructuring 29 trillion rupiah of bank loans in 2021. Rising interest rates are also sapping demand, further exacerbating the issue.

images.alt_text: Formed via a merger of ride-hailing provider Gojek and e-commerce firm Tokopedia, GoTo raised US$1.1 billion in one of last year’s largest initial public offerings.

site_title: Clock is ticking louder on a stock rally the pros never believed in
summary: US stocks started the year on a solid note, driven by softening inflation and better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings. However, the buying binge is nearing a point where past rebounds caved in, with the S&P 500's recovery reaching a half-way-point threshold that spelled doom for bulls in August. Despite this, the rally has been fueled by retail exuberance and short covering, with stocks rising an average of 0.45% on the day after a fall, a stronger rebound than any year since 1928. Experts warn that valuations are high and interest rates may continue to rise, posing a risk to the rally.

images.alt_text: A man walks past screens showing stock information at a brokerage house in Jiujiang, Jiangxi province, China October 8, 2018. REUTERS/Stringer

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary:
The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for February 10, 2023, highlights the tanker and dry bulk market trends. Key findings include:

- VLCC rates rose across the board, with a 3.5-point increase for the 270,000mt Middle East Gulf to China voyage.
- Capesize rates broke the $4,000 threshold, with a 15% rise compared to last Friday.
- Panamax rates remained turbulent, with limited support for Transatlantic and fronthaul trips.
- Ultramax/Supramax rates struggled due to prompt tonnage availability outstripping demand.
- Clean Product tanker rates improved, with available tonnage snapped up in the Middle East Gulf.
- Suezmax rates dropped, while Aframax rates rose in the North Sea market.
- LNG rates remained steady, with minimal movement in spot fixtures.
- Period interest remains, but the availability of ships is limited due to multi-year deals already cleared.

images.alt_text: The LPG market has continued its new year recovery and has regained the losses incurred since the start of January.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip, US dollar gains on tighter policy outlook
summary: Global equity markets fell on Friday as rising interest rates unsettled investors, with the US dollar gaining strength. The MSCI's US central index of stock market performance in 47 countries dropped 0.3%, while the dollar index rose 0.4%. European stocks, including Adidas, fell due to a dour outlook and higher interest rates. The yield on benchmark 10-year Treasury notes hit a more than one-month high, and the 10-year German bund posted its biggest weekly rise this year. Despite this, some investors remain bullish on the market, citing a longer-term view, and futures now price the Fed's target rate to peak at 5.2% in July.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 ended 0.6 per cent higher on Thursday, after hitting a near one-year high earlier in the session.

site_title: Rishi Sunak is privately drafting plans to rebuild Britain’s ties with the EU
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is privately drafting plans to rebuild Britain's ties with the EU, driven by the need for strong trading relations to address economic challenges and threats such as global supply shocks and China. Senior ministers and officials are working on proposals to improve cooperation in areas like defence, migration, and economic statecraft. This pivot towards the EU comes after years of acrimony since Brexit, amid the fallout from Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Since entering Downing Street in October, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has been under pressure to stamp his authority not only on his government but also over his party.

site_title: Air India seals record order for about 500 jets from Airbus, Boeing
summary: Air India has sealed a record order for approximately 500 new planes, valued at over $100 billion, with Airbus and Boeing. The deal, split 50/50 between the two manufacturers, includes 250 Airbus A320neos and A350s, and 220 Boeing 737 MAX, 787, and 777X jets. The order aims to modernize Air India's aging fleet and re-capture a share of international and domestic travel, positioning the airline as a major player in the global market.

images.alt_text: A bird flies over a logo of Air India airlines at the corporate headquarters in Mumbai, India, October 19, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas

site_title: As UK mortgage rates soar, residential property prices could see dips of up to 10%: analysts
summary: UK mortgage rates have surged to 4-6% over the last two years, leading analysts to predict a potential 10% drop in residential property prices over the next 12 months. Despite this, quality apartments and houses in London and the south of England remain in short supply due to high demand from wealthy buyers. Average UK rentals are expected to rise 10% by the end of 2023, and the British economy is forecasted to experience a shallow recession at worst.

images.alt_text: There were signs that the outlook for the property market had improved since December.
Barratt Developments' forward sales have increased to 10,854 homes as at Jan 29, compared with 10,511 at the end of the year.

A crane operates on construction of a new residential apartment building near to a row of terraced residential housing in London, U.K., on Thursday, Nov. 16, 2017. London's housing market is being battered from all sides. A survey by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors showed a price gauge at its lowest level for seven years, and far below the national average. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Oil-linked stocks gain in mixed Wall Street session
summary: US stocks closed with a mixed session on Friday, February 11, as oil-linked stocks rallied following Russia's announcement of a 500,000-barrel-per-day production cut. Chevron and Halliburton saw gains, while the Dow and S&P 500 finished positive, despite higher Treasury bond yields weighing on the Nasdaq. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.5%, and the S&P 500 climbed 0.2%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.6%. Investors await the consumer price index report, which will influence future Federal Reserve interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Ford plans to build battery plant in Michigan with Chinese partner
summary: Ford Motor is moving forward with plans to build a multibillion-dollar battery plant in Michigan with Chinese partner Contemporary Amperex Technology, despite uncertainty over US Treasury Department's interpretation of the Inflation Reduction Act's requirements on EV batteries. The facility, expected to create 2,500 jobs, is located about 100 miles west of Detroit and could be announced as early as next week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Ford logo is pictured at the 2019 Frankfurt Motor Show (IAA) in Frankfurt, Germany. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: It’s fine to sacrifice financial goals for a little indulgence
summary: A 33-year-old woman is reevaluating her financial priorities, choosing to indulge in experiences and travel instead of saving aggressively for long-term goals. After paying off her husband's student loans, they've reconfigured their budget to allocate more funds towards enjoying life now, rather than saving for the future. She encourages others to do the same, recognizing that life is seasonal and that certain opportunities may not be available in the future. By embracing the present, individuals can balance short-term indulgence with long-term financial planning, and prioritize experiences over savings.

images.alt_text: Protesters on a second day of nationwide strikes and protests over the government's proposed pension reform, on Jan 31, 2023, in Nantes, France.  Debate in parliament on the French government's plan to reform the pension system, which includes raising the minimum retirement age, began on Feb 6, 2023, with a third day of nationwide strikes and protests against the bill planned for Feb 7.
money, profit, finance

site_title: When having a baby and losing your job collide
summary: Tech companies that offered generous paid parental leave policies have laid off employees while on leave, leaving workers feeling the "whiplash" of mass layoffs. Many workers assumed their parental leave was job-protected, but this is not the case. Companies like Alphabet and Microsoft have cut 6% and 5% of their workers, respectively, while others, like Amazon, are offering severance packages. The lack of federal paid-family-leave policy in the US means workers on parental leave have limited protection against mass layoffs. This has led to a mental health toll, particularly for immigrants with visas tied to employment.

images.alt_text: Stripe is cutting more than 1,000 jobs, or 14 per cent of its workforce.
The reductions are “a necessary response” amid a “surge in interest rates and persistent inflation,” News Corp chief executive officer Robert Thomson said.

Microsoft won’t be getting more orders for its combat goggles anytime soon after Congress last month rejected the Army’s request for US$400 million to buy as many as 6,900 of them in the current fiscal year.
Yahoo’s restructuring will create a new division called Yahoo Advertising.
Deliveroo has been one of Britain’s most high profile success stories of recent years, riding the wave of the pandemic.
Earlier Wednesday, Disney announced upbeat financial results, led by big gains at its theme parks.

site_title: S-Reits see resilience in diversification
summary: Singapore Reits and property trusts continue to diversify, with diversified S-Reits now making up almost a quarter of the sector. Eight out of nine diversified S-Reits reported their latest financial results, with CapitaLand China Trust, CapitaLand India Trust, and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust seeing increases in net property income. Diversification has improved resilience to external shocks and allowed capture of growth trends across multiple segments. The sector's diversification is expected to continue, with more S-Reits entering new asset classes.

images.alt_text: Total property income for H2 grew 15 per cent to 6.2 billion Indian rupees (S$107.3 million), resulting in a 12 per cent rise for the full year to 11.9 billion rupees.

site_title: Moving up in the world of watches
summary: French watch brand Bell & Ross unveiled its new BR-X5 line in Kuala Lumpur, featuring a sophisticated mechanical movement designed by Swiss specialist Kenissi. The luxury watch is aimed at serious collectors and connoisseurs, marking Bell & Ross' entry into the higher-end market. With a budget of a six-figure sum, the launch was lavish, including a party and business-class flights for guests. The BR-X5 boasts a unique design, powered by a highly developed mechanical movement that signals Bell & Ross' maturity and sophistication.

images.alt_text: The BR 05 Sincere Green Steel is limited to 111 pieces.

site_title: US: Wall St edges lower
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, with the Dow Jones falling 28.34 points, or 0.08%, to 33,671.54. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 down 12.58 points, or 0.31%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 74.98 points, or 0.64%. The decline was driven by megacap growth companies under pressure after Treasury yields extended gains, and shares of Lyft plummeting after the ride-hailing firm forecast current-quarter profit below estimates.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO fights on all fronts as bank faces lost year
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Ulrich Koerner faces significant challenges as the bank struggles to regain client funds and recover from a substantial loss of assets. Despite a massive outreach campaign, many clients have departed, and some are unlikely to return. The bank's core wealth management business has been depleted, and plans for a carved-out investment bank remain vague. Investors are calling for a more radical solution, and Credit Suisse's low share price may attract rival interest in a takeover. The bank's turnaround strategy is uncertain, and it faces challenges in regaining trust and executing its plan, with Moody's rating downgrades exacerbating the situation.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse is still struggling to recover from outflows after a social media storm questioning the bank’s future led to depositor panic in the first few weeks of October, with outflows for the quarter totalling 110.5 billion francs.
Credit Suisse Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg
Sources say that measures to strengthen Credit Suisse's controls and monitor risks continue to be implemented and assessed.
The bank is seeking to cling on to talent contending with a restructuring of its Wall Street operations after a period of scandals and losses sparked a tide of departures
Credit Suisse is undertaking a sweeping overhaul of its business, following years of scandals and management missteps.

site_title: Children rescued as Turkey-Syria quake toll nears 24,000
summary: A devastating earthquake struck Turkey and Syria, resulting in over 24,000 deaths and leaving nearly 1 million people in urgent need of food. The United Nations warned that up to 5.3 million people in Syria may be homeless, and at least 870,000 people across Turkey and Syria require hot meals. Miraculous rescues continued over 100 hours after the quake, with a pregnant woman and her six-year-old daughter rescued from the rubble. The UN calls for an immediate ceasefire in Syria to allow aid to reach all victims, and a winter freeze has left thousands without shelter.

images.alt_text: Volunteers search for bodies in the old quarter of Antakya, Turkey, three days after the earthquake, Feb 9, 2023.
The World Food Programme wants more border crossings to open from Turkey into Syria which is experiencing severe shortages.

site_title: Investor ValueAct takes Spotify stake to back cost cuts at the music streaming leader
summary: ValueAct Capital Management has invested in Spotify Technology, backing the music-streaming company's strategy to tighten spending and become more efficient. CEO Daniel Ek has been focusing on cost cuts. ValueAct CEO Mason Morfit praised Spotify's innovative business model, which combined engineering breakthroughs with organizational abilities to create a new economic model benefiting creators and copyright owners. Morfit noted that Spotify's operating expenses and funding for content have exploded, but the company is now sorting out what was built to last and what was built for the bubble.

images.alt_text: A man checks his smartphone with the Spotify Technology logo behind him in an arranged photograph in London. MUST CREDIT: Bloomberg photo by Chris Ratcliffe.

site_title: Thousands of fintech jobs are gone as companies cut costs for first time
summary: Fintech companies are cutting thousands of jobs for the first time as they struggle with declining borrowing and rising interest rates. Stripe, Affirm Holdings, and Upstart Holdings are among those making deep cuts, with job losses ranging from 1,000 to 2,000 employees. Industry analysts attribute the layoffs to the industry's rapid growth and subsequent need to "mature and streamline." Despite the downturn, fintechs are expected to continue innovating, with smart banks and large financial institutions poised to absorb talent and ideas from struggling startups.

images.alt_text: PayPal saw headcount swell when the virus forced governments around the world to issue lockdown orders, spurring consumers to do more shopping online.

site_title: US consumer prices revised higher in December, November
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.1% in December, higher than the previously reported 0.1% drop, according to Labor Department data. The revision also increased November's price increase to 0.2% and October's to 0.5%. The changes were due to recalculated seasonal adjustment factors. The revised data raises concerns about potential higher inflation readings in the coming months, as economists interpret the revisions as a sign of ongoing inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Workers remain scarce in some industries in the US. There were 1.9 job openings for every unemployed person in December, government data showed last week.

site_title: Moody’s downgrades some Adani units, MSCI cuts weightage as concerns grow
summary: Moody's downgraded the ratings outlook to negative for four Adani Group entities, citing concerns over governance and a recent short-seller's report. MSCI also cut the weightage of Adani companies, including Adani Total Gas and ACC, due to uncertainty surrounding investors. The stock rout has wiped $110 billion off Adani's value, with protests in Parliament demanding an investigation. The conglomerate has denied wrongdoing, but the losses of confidence could impact Indian businesses as a whole.

images.alt_text: The Securities and Exchange Board of India (above) is investigating the Adani Group and some of its investors, amid growing concern over allegations made by an activist short-seller.
The scores for “business ethics controversy” for Adani Total Gas and Adani Transmission were downgraded from “low” to “moderate,” the ratings agency said.
Adani Group’s shares have rallied this week after the debt payment and as traders covered short positions.

site_title: KS Energy files for liquidation
summary: KS Energy, an Indonesian oil services firm founded by tycoon Kris Wiluan, has filed for liquidation. The company, under judicial management, made the application on January 27, following the cancellation of a deal to transfer its listing status to a logistics company. The High Court will hear the application on February 24, allowing creditors and shareholders to participate. The liquidation may not result in any distribution for shareholders, as payments will be made to creditors first. KS Energy's judicial managers have applied to be discharged and appointed as joint and several liquidators.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek

The traders had executed orders from their client, Indonesian tycoon Kris Wiluan, to purchase shares of now-collapsed oil services firm KS Energy, to create a false or misleading appearance for the counter’s share price.
KS Energy enters agreement to transfer listing status to Singapore logistics company
Indonesian tycoon Kris Wiluan fined S$480,000 for market rigging
KS Energy's judicial managers receive approval to wind up KS Drilling

site_title: The rise of the millionaire renters
summary: Millionaires are increasingly renting homes in major US cities, with 104 millionaires renting in Jersey City and triple that number in Washington, DC, between 2015 and 2020. This trend is driven by consumer preferences for city living, convenience, and security, as well as limited housing supply and higher prices. Nationally, the number of affluent renters grew by 82% and moderate-income renters by 10%, while low-income renters declined by 11%. As rents stabilize, the trend may indicate a shift in the housing market, with cities catching up to San Francisco in terms of their renter class.

images.alt_text: The housing market was pummelled last year as soaring borrowing costs sidelined would-be homebuyers.

site_title: Vietnam police probe possible stock market manipulation
summary: Vietnamese police are investigating possible stock market manipulation involving Eximbank shares, a domestic lender. The investigation, led by the State Securities Commission, seeks information from brokers about transactions made by a fund controlled by Dragon Capital, the largest foreign investor in Vietnam's stock market. The probe aims to determine if the share price was artificially driven down in the first weeks of this year, resulting in an 18% drop. Dragon Capital has stated that it is cooperating with the investigation and not under scrutiny. The investigation is part of an anti-corruption crackdown following the resignation of Vietnam's President Nguyen Xuan Phuc.

site_title: Ford cuts Rivian stake to about 1% amid production woes at EV maker
summary: Ford Motor has reduced its stake in struggling electric vehicle maker Rivian Automotive to 1.15% following the company's production struggles and financial losses. Rivian narrowly missed its full-year production target of 25,000 units last year due to supply-chain disruptions. Ford had previously written down the value of its Rivian investment by $7.4 billion in 2022. The move comes as Ford prepares for a tough year ahead, following a fall in profit.

site_title: SGX RegCo directs Lorenzo International to delist following multiple contraventions
summary: SGX RegCo is directing furniture manufacturer Lorenzo International to delist following multiple contraventions. The company's trading suspension in 2018 was not lifted after submitting a resumption proposal. A 29-page report by KPMG Forensic Services found discrepancies in the proposed disposal of a subsidiary, including an undisclosed sale price and failure to disclose a court judgment. The regulator also alleged potential contraventions of the Companies Act, and will report the alleged contraventions to the relevant authority.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Innopac to delist on June 30, no exit offer received

site_title: Honda reports 22% rise in Q3 operating profit, beating estimates
summary: Honda Motor reported a 22% rise in Q3 operating profit to 280.4 billion yen, beating estimates. The company cited a weak yen as a factor, offsetting rising raw material costs and lower vehicle production and sales due to chip shortages in China. Sales in China were down by half in January, but the company expects a recovery from February. Honda stuck to its annual operating profit forecast of 870 billion yen, despite a 6.1% cut in group unit sales to 3.9 million vehicles.

images.alt_text: The NHTSA said owners of those vehicles should not drive them until they get repairs, warning “the risk to vehicle occupants is dire”.
Honda officially withdrew from F1 after powering Max Verstappen to his maiden world championship with Red Bull in 2021.

site_title: North American companies notch another record year for robot orders
summary: North American companies ordered a record 44,100 robots in 2022, a 11% increase over the previous year, valued at $2.38 billion. The majority of orders came from automakers and suppliers, who are building new electric vehicle and battery factories. Demand for robots appears to have slowed down near the end of the year, raising questions about 2023's growth, due to shifting consumer behavior and rising interest rates.

images.alt_text:
ajsutdr10 - The GIRAFFE is one of many robotic R&D projects that will be tested and flown in the new AerialArena@SUTD.


Copyright/source: Ammiel Jr Wan
A DeliRo delivery robot moving along on a street outside Tokyo, part of an experiment businesses hope will tackle labour shortages and rural isolation.

site_title: Alibaba exits India’s Paytm, selling shares for 13.78 billion rupees
summary: Alibaba has sold its remaining stake in Indian digital payments firm Paytm for approximately 13.78 billion rupees (S$221.9 million) through a block deal. This exit comes days after Paytm posted its first-ever quarterly operating profit as a listed firm, nine months ahead of its target. The sale marks a significant development for Paytm, which has been under pressure to turn profitable since its dismal listing in November 2021.

site_title: Yen jumps as Ueda set to be named next BOJ governor
summary: The Japanese yen surged on Friday after reports that Kazuo Ueda, an academic, is set to become the next Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor, potentially signaling an end to ultra-loose monetary policy. The yen strengthened against the dollar, euro, and sterling, but Ueda later stated that the central bank's current policy was appropriate and should continue, leading to some reversal of gains. The dollar sank 1.2% to 129.8 yen, while the euro and sterling fell more than 1% against the yen.

images.alt_text: The US dollar has emerged as the preferred currency to invest in, contributing to the majority of foreign currency inflows among major banks.

site_title: ThaiBev posts 4.9% increase in revenue to 80.9 billion baht in Q1
summary: Thai Beverage (ThaiBev) posted a 4.9% year-on-year increase in revenue to 80.9 billion Thai baht in Q1, driven by the recovery of economic activity in Thailand and Vietnam. The company's beer business saw a 13.7% rise in sales revenue, while its spirits business fell 6.4% and its non-alcoholic beverages segment rose 15.6%. Ebitda fell 7.7% to 13.5 billion baht due to increased brand investment and marketing activities. ThaiBev's shares closed flat at S$0.70.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Thai Beverage's beer business, revenue was up 23.5 per cent to 122.5 billion baht in FY2022,  despite the increase of key raw material and packaging costs such as malts and bottles.

site_title: World Food Programme warns of stock shortage in quake-hit northwest Syria
summary: The World Food Programme (WFP) is warning of a stock shortage in northwest Syria due to severe humanitarian aid shortages following earthquakes in the region. The WFP, which relies on border crossings to deliver aid, is currently only using one crossing between Turkey and opposition-held Syria. The organization needs to open a second crossing to replenish its stocks and provide aid to the 90% of the population dependent on humanitarian assistance. WFP Regional Director Corinne Fleischer emphasized the need for a second crossing to address the transport delays caused by damaged roads.

images.alt_text: Trucks, containing humanitarian aid collected by Croatian government, Caritas and the Croatian Red Cross, line-up at the logistics center of the directorate of civil protection in Jastrebarsk, near Zagreb, on February 10, 2023, ready to deliver to areas of Turkey after a 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck early February 6 near the Turkish-Syrian border. - The death toll from the massive earthquake in Turkey and Syria kept on climbing on February 9, 2023, topping 21,000 as the first UN aid reached Syrian rebel-held zones but hopes of finding more survivors faded. (Photo by DENIS LOVROVIC / AFP)

epa10456793 People gather to obtain food and grocery supplies next to collapsed building in the city of Kahramanmaras, southeastern Turkey, 09 February 2023. More than 17,000 people have died and thousands more injured after two major earthquakes struck southern Turkey and northern Syria on 06 February. Authorities fear the death toll will keep climbing as rescuers look for survivors across the region.  EPA-EFE/ABIR SULTAN   BEST QUALITY AVAILABLE
Volunteers search for bodies in the old quarter of Antakya, Turkey, three days after the earthquake, Feb 9, 2023.

site_title: Let's work to keep peace, China tells visiting Taiwan KMT official
summary: China's Communist Party leader Wang Huning told Taiwan's opposition Kuomintang (KMT) deputy chairman Andrew Hsia to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait and oppose Taiwan independence. The meeting in Beijing came as China increases military and diplomatic pressure on Taiwan, which claims sovereignty. The KMT traditionally favors close ties with China, but denies being pro-Beijing. Wang Huning is a top theoretician and is set to join President Xi Jinping's elite seven-man Politburo Standing Committee. The meeting has sparked criticism from Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for being too close to Beijing.

images.alt_text: During the past three years, China has ramped up pressure on Taiwan to accept Chinese sovereignty.

site_title: New drone-flying arena launched for testing, showcases of aerial robots
summary: Singapore has launched its first aerial robotics arena, AerialArena@SUTD, to test and showcase drone flying projects. The four-storey courtyard space is a collaboration between the National Robotics Programme (NRP) and the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD). The arena will be used for drone pilot training, test-bedding, and competitions, with plans to book the space for universities and companies later this year. The NRP has also launched a new technical reference standard for robot deployment in the healthcare sector, providing guidelines for safe and effective deployment.

images.alt_text:
ajsutdr10 - The GIRAFFE is one of many robotic R&D projects that will be tested and flown in the new AerialArena@SUTD.




Copyright/source: Ammiel Jr Wan

A Google robot carrying a bag of chips during a media demo at a micro-kitchen in Google’s robotics research space in Mountain View, California, US; August 2022.  Particularly in the hospitality and healthcare sectors in Singapore, critical business needs will demand an acceleration of robotics adoption.

Niels Delore, the Singapore-based managing director for Apac of Flyability Asia Pacific, says: "Our drones are designed to keep humans out of dangerous places to perform the most demanding inspection tasks. Industrial inspection in confined spaces and at height is incredibly dangerous and costly."
A DeliRo delivery robot moving along on a street outside Tokyo, part of an experiment businesses hope will tackle labour shortages and rural isolation.

site_title: Preview of Terra Hill condo in Pasir Panjang pegs starting price at S$1.5 million
summary: Terra Hill, a freehold luxury condo in Pasir Panjang, Singapore, began previews with prices starting at S$1.5 million for a 2-bedroom unit. The 270-unit project features a 50-metre lap pool, children's play area, and private lifts in some units. Developed by Hoi Hup Realty and Sunway Developments, Terra Hill is located near the Greater Southern Waterfront and National University Hospital, with average prices around S$2,600 per square foot.

images.alt_text: The 14 residential projects will supply some 5,300 private homes in Q1 2023, said Huttons senior research director Lee Sze Teck.
The site has direct access to the West Coast Park and is 2 kilometres from the National University of Singapore and National University Hospital.

site_title: Oil prices rise over 2% on Russian plan to cut output
summary: Oil prices rose over 2% on Friday, with Brent crude futures reaching $86.39 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures reaching $79.72, due to Russia's announcement of plans to cut oil production next month following price caps imposed by the West. The price increases resulted in weekly gains of 8.1% for Brent and 8.6% for WTI.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The sun is seen behind a crude oil pump jack in the Permian Basin in Loving County, Texas, U.S., November 22, 2019. REUTERS/Angus Mordant//File Photo
Brent crude settled at US$84.50 a barrel, losing 59 cents, or 0.7 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Cross-border travel resumption with China gives much-needed boost to Macau, Hong Kong
summary: Macau and Hong Kong have seen a significant boost in tourism and economic activity following the resumption of cross-border travel with mainland China. Macau's gross gaming revenue reached 1.9 billion Macanese patacas in the first five days of February, a 45% plus recovery from pre-Covid levels in 2019. Analysts expect the return of mainland travelers to lift the outlook for Macau's gaming, aviation, and domestic consumption sectors, as well as Hong Kong's landlords, insurers, and securities firms. The resumption of travel mobility is also expected to drive overseas listings and energize Hong Kong's financial sector.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Flag of China

Shoppers and pedestrians walk along Nanjing Road in Shanghai, China, on Sunday, June 6, 2021. Consumers in China remain cautious even though the Covid-19 outbreak has been under control for much of the past year. Photographer: Qilai Shen
Investors will have to weigh L’Oreal’s slowing momentum even as it continues to beat expectations.

site_title: India's top court says investor interests must be protected after Adani report
summary: India's top court ruled that investor interests must be protected, particularly for the middle-class investors who make up a significant portion of the stock market. The court's decision comes after a US short seller's report accused the Adani conglomerate of improper use of offshore tax havens and stock manipulation, leading to a $100 billion loss in market value. The court is hearing petitions related to the report and plans to take action against those responsible, including Nathan Anderson of Hindenburg Research. The court aims to protect investors from potential losses.

images.alt_text: Television journalists are seen outside the premises of the Supreme Court in New Delhi, India, January 22, 2020. REUTERS/Anushree Fadnavis
The Securities and Exchange Board of India (above) is investigating the Adani Group and some of its investors, amid growing concern over allegations made by an activist short-seller.

site_title: Murdoch’s News Corp to cut 5% of staff after earnings plunge
summary: News Corp to cut 5% of staff, or about 1,250 positions, due to a "surge in interest rates and persistent inflation." The reductions are a "necessary response" to earnings that plunged 30% to US$409 million in the fiscal quarter. Annual savings will be at least US$130 million. The cuts affect all News Corp businesses, including the Wall Street Journal, HarperCollins, and The Times and The Sun newspapers.

site_title: Office cake culture lives on in Britain despite health warning
summary: Britain's food regulator, Susan Jebb, has criticized office cake culture, comparing it to passive smoking. Jebb believes that bringing cakes into the office promotes unhealthy food choices, despite the fact that individuals can choose to eat or not eat them. In contrast, office workers in London say that cakes, such as beetroot cake, provide a welcome break and help build friendships. Experts warn that Britain's obesity levels, at 28% of the population, are expected to worsen, costing the NHS and society £60 billion annually.

site_title: Anwar gets approval ratings boost ahead of Malaysia local polls
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's approval rating has surged to 68% ahead of local polls, with 54% of voters satisfied with the new government's performance, according to a Merdeka Center survey. The positive ratings come two months after a hung parliament, with Anwar's approval rating lower than predecessors Mahathir Mohamad and Muhyiddin Yassin. The local polls, scheduled for this year, will gauge the new government's popularity among an electorate that has seen four prime ministers in four years.

images.alt_text: Anwar told Bloomberg TV he has a huge issue of having to introduce taxation policies or new initiatives when it affects the plight of the low-income group.

site_title: Japan’s 10-year bond yield hits BOJ policy limit on new governor report
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield rose 1 basis point to 0.5%, hitting the top end of the Bank of Japan's policy band, after a report confirmed Kazuo Ueda's nomination as the next governor. This is the first time since January 18 that the yield has reached the upper end of the band. Ueda, an academic, will be joined by Ryozo Himino and Shinichi Uchida as deputy governors, marking a shift in the central bank's leadership.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan (above) says it will extend five-year loans against collateral to financial institutions for the third time since January, with details to be announced on Tuesday.

A man looks at an electric quotation board flashing the Nikkei key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 12, 2017.
Tokyo stocks fell April 12 morning as the yen shot to five-month highs against the dollar over fears about growing tensions on the Korean peninsula and in the Middle East. / AFP PHOTO / Kazuhiro NOGI

site_title: IMF growth outlook for China puts Xi’s income goal out of reach
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has downgraded China's economic growth outlook, projecting an average annual growth rate of 4% from 2023 to 2027 and 3% from 2028 to 2032. This slowdown is expected to put President Xi Jinping's long-term economic ambitions, including reaching a "medium-developed country" GDP per capita by 2035, out of reach. The IMF attributes the slowdown to China's aging population, slowing aggregate productivity, and its investment-driven expansion model, which has fueled public debt risks.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - US President Joe Biden (R) and China's President Xi Jinping (L) meet on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on November 14, 2022. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)

site_title: Over 14,000 engaged in Forward Singapore; next phase to delve into issues and solutions: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced the next phase of Forward Singapore, a nationwide conversation on shaping Singapore's future and social compact. The exercise, which began with over 14,000 engaged participants, will delve deeper into specific issues and co-create solutions. The government will update its policies based on feedback and ideas, with plans to be shared in the upcoming Budget on Feb 14. The dialogues have been held in various locations, including neighbourhoods, schools, and online, and will continue to engage Singaporeans in the coming phase.

images.alt_text: Any unemployment support measures will likely be for vulnerable workers, such as those who are older, have lower-income, or are less educated, one economist told The Business Times.

site_title: Rising open interest in CNH and INR futures an indication of China, India strength
summary: China's reopening of its borders is expected to boost the global economy, with the International Monetary Fund predicting China and India will account for half of global growth this year. The reopening has led to a rise in open interest for CNH and INR futures, indicating increased investor interest in China and India. SGX's USD/CNH futures have seen a steady growth in open interest, moving from $9.3 billion to $12 billion, as investors take advantage of opportunities in China's $18-trillion economy. This suggests a positive outlook for global growth and highlights the significance of China and India in driving economic expansion.

images.alt_text: huangpu river, pudong, shanghai

Yuan loans extended by Chinese banks are expected to have surged to a record high in January as the central bank moved to shore up growth in the world’s second-biggest economy following a lifting of pandemic controls.
Washington is pressing ahead with plans to curb China’s access to sensitive semiconductor technology and is trying to get countries it considers allies to do the same.

The IMF said global growth would still fall to 2.9 per cent in 2023 from 3.4 per cent in 2022, but its latest World Economic Outlook forecasts mark an improvement over an October prediction of 2.7 per cent growth this year.

site_title: China Jan new bank loans jump more than expected to record 4.9 trillion yuan
summary: China's new bank loans surged to a record 4.9 trillion yuan in January, more than tripling the December tally, amid hopes of rapidly improving business and consumer confidence. The increase was seen as a sign of the central bank's efforts to shore up growth in the world's second-largest economy following the lifting of pandemic controls. The rebound in credit demand is crucial for the economy's recovery, which contracted to 3% in 2022 due to harsh Covid measures and a property sector crisis. The strong credit demand will be essential for the economy's growth this year.

images.alt_text: The PBOC kept its monetary easing measured in 2022 and relied more on structural tools to provide targeted support to the economy.

site_title: Saab expects strong 2023 as war fuels equipment demand
summary: Saab expects a strong 2023 as the war in Ukraine drives up demand for its equipment, with order bookings doubling in the fourth quarter. The company reported a 15% organic sales growth forecast and a 15% rise in operating profit, with shares surging 10% to a record high. Saab signed contracts in Poland and Britain, and plans to invest in India and the US to scale up production. Despite Ukraine's push for Saab's Gripen fighter aircraft, the company has no current initiatives in this direction.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz speaks next to a Leopard 2 battle tank of the German armed forces Bundeswehr as he visits troops on a training exercise at the military ground in Ostenholz, northern Germany, on Oct 17, 2022.
Pressure has been building for weeks on German Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government to send the tanks and allow other Nato allies to do the same.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Sembcorp Industries and Becamex IDC will establish five Vietnam Singapore Industrial Parks (VSIPs) in Vietnam, valued at approximately US$1 billion. Grab has moved MP Tin Pei Ling to a less visible role amid public disquiet over potential conflicts of interest. Malaysia's economy expanded 7% year-on-year in Q4, exceeding expectations, and the central bank does not foresee recession in 2023. The Ministry of Manpower has extended the heightened safety period until May 31 with additional measures.

site_title: Yellen says G20 to discuss China poor-nation debt revamp plan
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the G20 will discuss China's plan to have multilateral development banks offer debt relief to struggling nations, including Zambia. China, the world's largest sovereign creditor, has requested debt relief from struggling nations as part of a debt revamp plan. However, analysts warn that forcing lenders to take losses could undermine their standing and ability to continue their work. Yellen stated that China "understands the problem" and may be willing to work to make faster progress, but Beijing needs to "come to the table" to move forward.

site_title: China’s ports speed up clearing of Australian beef imports
summary: China's ports have accelerated the clearance of Australian beef imports, processing cargoes within one to two weeks, faster than the past two years. This improvement comes after Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong's visit to China in December, marking the first ministerial trip in three years. The development is a positive sign in thawing tensions between the two countries, following China's recent lifting of an unofficial coal import ban from Australia.

site_title: Thomson Medical H1 earnings jump 82.6% to S$22.8 million
summary: Thomson Medical Group reported an 82.6% year-on-year jump in net profit to S$22.8 million for the half year ended Dec 31. Revenue rose 26.6% to S$184 million, driven by a 14.6% growth in hospital and 41% growth in specialised services segments, mainly due to increased patient loads and higher average bill sizes.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
The group also announced the resignation of chief executive Wong Chiang Yin, who is leaving to pursue personal interests.

site_title: ChatGPT ‘will change our world’: Bill Gates
summary: Bill Gates believes ChatGPT, a chatbot developed by OpenAI and backed by Microsoft, will significantly impact office jobs, making many tasks more efficient. He states that ChatGPT's ability to understand content and generate human-like responses will "change our world." This technology has been rated the fastest-growing consumer app in history, with potential applications in writing invoices and letters. Gates' comments highlight the significant potential of ChatGPT in revolutionizing office work.

site_title: Adidas’s new CEO has a 1.2 billion euros pile of unsold Yeezy gear
summary: Adidas' new CEO, Bjorn Gulden, faces a significant challenge with the company sitting on a 1.2 billion euros pile of unsold Yeezy merchandise after terminating its lucrative branding deal with rapper Ye. In a worst-case scenario, Adidas could face an operating loss of up to 700 million euros in 2023. The company's shares slumped 11% after the announcement, and analysts predict a high-single-digit rate of sales decline in 2023. Gulden aims to refresh the brand and reignite profitable growth, but the company faces challenges in China and must figure out how to sell or repurpose Yeezy designs without the brand name.

site_title: Tin Pei Ling moves to less-visible Grab role amid public disquiet
summary: Grab has reclassified MP Tin Pei Ling from its Singapore director of public affairs and policy to a "corporate development role", amid public disquiet over potential conflicts of interest. Tin will focus on "realising synergies" across Grab's investments and acquisitions, and strategy development, without involvement in public affairs and policy work. Grab acknowledged the concerns and came to a mutual agreement with Tin, who is also a PAP MP, to separate her duties. The move aims to allow Tin to serve both roles without doubt or question.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Grab's attempts to scale up its supply comes as commuters face longer waiting times and fare surges due to the driver shortage.
Member of Parliament Tin Pei Ling joined the Nasdaq-listed company in January.

site_title: For a stable, strong core, forget about crunches
summary: A strong core is essential for everyday life, providing stability, balance, and reducing back pain. However, many people mistakenly focus on external abdominal muscles, such as those targeted by sit-ups and crunches, which are only one part of the core. A well-rounded core workout should include exercises that target the deep muscles in the pelvis, hips, and back, as well as rotation and balance exercises. Incorporating core exercises into daily activities, such as high-intensity running, squats, and deadlifts, can also be effective. By focusing on core strength and balance, individuals can improve their overall fitness and reduce the risk of injury.

images.alt_text: Cardio and strength training help the body in different ways.

site_title: Amid little fanfare, Real Madrid eye record-extending fifth world title in Morocco
summary: Real Madrid, the four-time Club World Cup winners, face Saudi Arabian side Al Hilal in the final on Sunday. The match is considered a mismatch, with Real Madrid's team consisting of global superstars and Al Hilal's modest squad. Real Madrid is the overwhelming favorite, with bookmakers offering odds of 20 cents for every dollar wagered on Madrid to win in 90 minutes. Al Hilal's manager, Ramon Diaz, has stated that his team deserves to be in the final and will be excited to play, but history is not on their side, with no team outside Europe or South America having ever won the competition.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

TOPSHOT - Real Madrid's Brazilian forward Vinicius Junior celebrates after scoring his team's opening goal during the FIFA Club World Cup semi-final football match between Egypt's Al-Ahly and Spain's Real Madrid at the Prince Moulay Abdellah Stadium in Rabat on February 8, 2023. (Photo by Fadel Senna / AFP)

site_title: MOM extends Heightened Safety Period till May 31
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) is extending the heightened safety period (HSP) in Singapore until May 31, 2023, with additional measures to boost workplace safety. The HSP was initially introduced on September 1, 2022, and was set to end on February 28. The extension aims to address rising workplace fatalities and major injuries, with the goal of achieving a fatality rate below 1.0 per 100,000 workers by 2028. The measures include mandatory WSH training, increased fines, and a national WSH campaign.

images.alt_text: Since the imposition of HSP, 760 composition fines and 48 stop work orders have been issued, MOM 'considering' extension of HSP beyond February.

site_title: Netherlands to sell part of its stake in lender ABN Amro
summary: The Dutch government plans to sell part of its 56% stake in lender ABN Amro, reducing its ownership to nearly half. The sale, initiated by Citigroup Global Markets Europe, will start in the coming days with an undisclosed minimum price. This move comes after ABN Amro's shares rose to their highest level in three years due to stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and a new share buyback. The bank was re-privatized in 2015 after a government bailout during the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: UK regulator probes Barclays over anti-money laundering systems
summary: The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is investigating Barclays for suspected failings in its anti-money laundering systems, following a request for an independent review last year. The FCA hired an independent firm to produce reports with recommendations for improvement. This comes after Barclays was fined £8.4 million (S$13.5 million) in 2022 for not providing full information about payment card costs. The investigation aims to assess the bank's compliance and anti-money laundering systems, with the FCA declining to comment further.

site_title: Indian market regulator probes Adani’s links to investors
summary: India's Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) is investigating Adani Group's links to investors in its aborted US$2.5 billion share sale amid allegations by US short-seller Hindenburg Research. The probe focuses on potential violations of Indian securities laws and conflicts of interest, particularly relationships between Adani and Mauritius-based companies that participated as anchor investors. The shares of Adani Group have lost over US$100 billion in market value since January 24, following the Hindenburg report accusing the group of improper use of offshore tax havens and stock manipulation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is pictured on the premises of its headquarters in Mumbai, India March 1, 2017. REUTERS/Shailesh Andrade/File Photo

site_title: AIIB launches US$130m venture capital programme for sustainable infrastructure
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has launched a US$130 million venture capital programme focusing on green and technology-enabled infrastructure. The three-year programme aims to support early-stage companies in adopting new technologies and creating sustainable infrastructure. AIIB will partner with reputable VC fund managers to build strategic partnerships and diversify its equity portfolio. This is AIIB's first foray into the Asian venture capital market since its founding in 2016, with an initial target portfolio of 12 to 15 VC funds.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Reality check on housing dreams in Singapore
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Singapore's public housing is often considered affordable, with data suggesting that close to 70% of Build-To-Order flats launched in 2022 are affordable for the median household income. However, young couples like Xie Jiawei and Hazel Wang are experiencing difficulties in securing affordable homes, with resale prices rising 22.4% over the past two years. The gap between data and sentiment on the ground suggests that the perception of unaffordability persists, with many feeling they are paying too high a price for homes, particularly in popular areas. Experts attribute this to a lack of granular data and high property prices.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
The pace of property price increases in the last quarter has moderated amid a drop in sales volume, says Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.
Resale prices rose 2.3 per cent quarter on quarter, making for the slowest growth in 2022.

site_title: CPF: Time for review?
summary: The Central Provident Fund (CPF) in Singapore is under review to address growing concerns over retirement adequacy and rising living costs. The CPF model, which encourages self-reliance, has been criticized for not providing enough support for those with immediate needs. The government has introduced various schemes to incentivize voluntary contributions and provide financial support for key life milestones. An increase in CPF contributions or the wage ceiling may be considered to address these concerns, with the latter potentially providing more benefits for higher-income earners without affecting lower-income individuals.

images.alt_text: The government said it would continue to watch the interest rate environment closely “to ensure that the CPF interest rate pegs remain relevant in the prevailing operating environment”, while taking into consideration the longer term outlook.
One group that could benefit from an expansion of the PWM is skilled non-degree holders, said one economist.

site_title: Global investors losing appetite for Chinese government bonds
summary: Global investors are reducing their holdings of Chinese government bonds, citing a peak in developed market rates and a desire for juicier stock markets in the reopened economy. Foreigners sold 616 billion yuan worth of bonds in 2022, taking their holdings down to 3.4 trillion yuan. Fund managers are shifting to more attractive markets, such as equities in Hong Kong, and some expect Chinese government bonds to attract some inflows as the yuan gains, but the trend is expected to continue.

images.alt_text: A turnaround has emerged since November when Beijing stepped up efforts to salvage the ailing housing market as economic growth overtook Covid controls as policymakers’ top priority

site_title: Investing in innovation: Energy transformation accelerates
summary: Investors are shifting focus to energy transformation from fossil fuels, driven by external shocks such as the Russia-Ukraine war and the US Inflation Reduction Act. This marks a turning point in the transition to new energy sources, including solar, wind, hydrogen, and nuclear power. With the world becoming more multi-polar, energy security will rise in importance, and economies with lower energy prices will gain a cost advantage. Active management is necessary to navigate hype cycles and find profit pools in the energy transformation sector.

images.alt_text: DO NOT USE THIS IMAGE FOR ANY FURTHER STORIES

site_title: Asia: Markets follow Wall Street down as rate hike fears persist
summary: Asian markets declined, following a loss on Wall Street, as interest rate hike fears persisted. The robust jobs report and inflation data led top Federal Reserve officials to warn of further rate hikes, despite recent disinflation trends. Analysts expect a key consumer price index release next week to influence the Fed's plans, with some predicting rate hikes in the third quarter. The economy's growth remains a concern, with some warning of a recession.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on bargain-buying following a recent sell-off and hopes about China’s post-Covid reopening.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS raises Sembcorp target price to S$4.50
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its target price on Sembcorp Industries to S$4.50 from S$3.80, citing a 25% compound annual growth rate in the renewables segment and a potential dividend yield of 2%. The research firm maintains its "buy" call on the stock, citing three acquisitions completed last November that will be completed in the first half of this year.

images.alt_text: The queries from SIAS come ahead of Sembmarine’s extraordinary general meeting (EGM) next Thursday (Feb 16) where shareholders would vote on the proposed merger.

site_title: Sembcorp teams up with Becamex to establish 5 industrial parks in Vietnam
summary: Sembcorp Industries and Becamex IDC have signed a memorandum of understanding to establish five Vietnam Singapore Industrial Parks (VSIPs) in Vietnam, valued at approximately US$1 billion. The VSIPs are envisioned to be smart and sustainable industrial parks with low carbon footprint, and will be developed in collaboration with the Vietnamese government. The move aims to boost economic cooperation between Singapore and Vietnam, with the two countries having a strong track record of collaboration in various sectors.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

The Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Park's (VSIP) decision to not exit despite the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis likely helped  co-developer SembCorp Development to "score points" and gain trust from its Vietnamese partners, VSIP co-chair Kelvin Teo said.
Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (left) met with Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong at the Istana on Feb 9, 2023 during his three-day official visit to Singapore.

Vietnam Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh (left) and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong have met regularly since the latter took office in April 2021, including at this meeting in Washington, DC in May 2022.

site_title: UK government looks to speed up post-Brexit insurance reforms
summary: The UK government is in talks with the Prudential Regulation Authority and insurers to speed up post-Brexit insurance reforms, aiming to release £100 billion of capital for investment. Officials are considering a two-stage implementation of the Solvency II reforms, allowing insurers to swap bonds for assets like green technology and housing, with other changes introduced more slowly. This move follows months of disagreements over the pace of change, with the Association of British Insurers estimating the reforms could free up £100 billion over a decade for investment.

site_title: Malaysia Q4 GDP growth up 7% on year; not likely to enter recession in 2023: central bank
summary: Malaysia's economy expanded 7% year-on-year in the fourth quarter, exceeding forecasts. The growth is attributed to robust domestic demand, with private consumption and investment driving the expansion. Despite global slowdowns and inflationary pressures, the central bank expects Malaysia to avoid a recession in 2023, citing a moderate pace of growth and an improving labor market. The government forecasts growth to slow to between 4% and 5% in 2023, but the central bank governor noted that this range could be revised.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s International Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Azizand the representatives from Yondr Group.
Malaysia’s Industrial Production Index expanded by 6.9 per cent in 2022, driven by robust manufacturing activities.

site_title: Local stocks end week flattish as investors take stock of inflation
summary: Singapore stocks ended the week largely unchanged, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.04% to 3,360.69. Investors took stock of inflation levels and the possibility of future US Federal Reserve rate hikes. The Nikkei 225 and Bursa advanced, while the Hang Seng index and ASX 200 fell. Key gainers included Jardine Matheson Holdings, UOB, DBS, and OCBC, while Nio and Jardine Cycle and Carriage were among the biggest losers. The US consumer price index figures will be a key data point for investors to watch in the coming week.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

A man looks at an electric quotation board flashing the Nikkei key index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 12, 2017.
Tokyo stocks fell April 12 morning as the yen shot to five-month highs against the dollar over fears about growing tensions on the Korean peninsula and in the Middle East. / AFP PHOTO / Kazuhiro NOGI
Focusing on fundamentals will allow investors to steer clear of fad investing.
After a torrid 2022, investors have been betting that a swift recovery in China’s economy will somewhat cushion the impact of a global slowdown and possible recession.
DBS Group Research maintains its "buy" call on the stock.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Jakarta stocks sank, though a weaker yen helped Tokyo post morning gains.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Markets driven by uncertainty ahead of Singapore Budget (Ep 31)
summary: Markets in Singapore and the region were driven by uncertainty ahead of the Singapore Budget 2023. In the latest episode of BT Market Focus, podcast editor Claressa Monteiro discusses how markets reacted in the run-up to the budget. SGX's wrap for the week, insights from The Business Times' newsdesk, and notable macroeconomic news are also highlighted. The podcast aims to provide general information and does not accept liability for any loss arising from reliance on the podcast or use of third-party products and services.

images.alt_text: Where were the bright spots which markets reacted to?
Despite a short trading week, why did investors seem enthusiastic?

site_title: Japan's 5-year bond yield falls after BOJ announces loan offer
summary: Japan's 5-year bond yield fell 0.5 basis points to 0.195% after the Bank of Japan announced it would provide five-year loans with the same maturity to banks to contain elevated yields. The move aims to support the financial system, but market participants question its sustainability. The BOJ last conducted a similar operation on January 31, and yields on super-long notes rose in line with US Treasury yields. The central bank's efforts to control yields may be limited, and policymakers are divided on wage and inflation outlook.

images.alt_text: The announcement underscores the central bank’s resolve to prevent simmering market speculation of a near-term interest rate hike from pushing up bond yields too much.
FILE PHOTO: Passersby are silhouetted as they walk past in front of an electric stock quotation board outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan October 18, 2022  REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

Japanese bond yields have crept up on market expectations that the Bank of Japan will phase out its yield-control policy and start raising interest rates under a new governor in April, when incumbent Haruhiko Kuroda steps down.
A pedestrian walks in front of the Bank of Japan (BoJ) head office building in Tokyo on April 27, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
Many of the central bank's board members agree on the need to retain ultra-loose monetary policy to support the economy and help companies raise wages.
“Our hope is that wages start to rise and that could make the 2 per cent inflation target to be met in a stable and sustainable manner,” Kuroda told a panel discussion on Friday (Jan 20) in Davos.
The BOJ kept its main policy settings unchanged Wednesday, leaving its negative interest rate at -0.1 per cent.
The BOJ has struggled to defend a 0.5 per cent cap on the 10-year bond yield set under YCC, as investors have sold off bonds in anticipation of a tweak to its ultra-loose monetary policy.

site_title: Utopia or bust
summary: Economist J. Bradford DeLong argues that humanity has failed to achieve utopia despite the means to do so, citing the post-World War II social-democratic "New Deal Order" and neoliberalism as failed options. He proposes four alternatives: reviving the New Deal, doubling down on neoliberalism, embracing ethnonationalism, or returning to an elite-driven society. However, DeLong concludes that none of these options are likely to bring improvement and questions whether a productive synthesis of these alternatives is still possible, suggesting that he will continue to push for one despite the alternatives.

images.alt_text: US monetary and fiscal policymaking since the 1960s seems almost like playing a never-ending game of Whac-A-Mole, says writer J Bradford DeLong.
Why can’t we all be rich?

site_title: JustCo eyes more expansion, exits China and Indonesia
summary: JustCo, a co-working operator backed by GIC, plans to expand in the Asia-Pacific region after hitting a profitability milestone in August 2022. The company has improved occupancy and selling rates, with average occupancy over 80% and selling rates increasing by at least 30% over the past year. JustCo exited China and Indonesia due to tough market conditions, and is shifting focus to management contracts with landlords. The company aims to grow its management contracts to 50% in the next three years, but faces challenges convincing landlords to let it manage spaces.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
CMG20201216-HoPY01/陈劲禾/黄少伟/Redefining the future of work and shaping a more connected future economy.访问总裁Kong Wan Sing[Centrepoint]

site_title: Japan’s PM Kishida picks academic Ueda to helm BOJ, reports say
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has nominated Kazuo Ueda, a 71-year-old academic and former Bank of Japan board member, to be the next BOJ governor from April, according to local media reports. Ueda's nomination was seen as a surprise, with some investors interpreting it as a hawkish choice, causing the yen to strengthen. Deputy BOJ governor Masayoshi Amamiya, who was seen as the top contender, declined the nomination. Ueda has a PhD from MIT and has maintained a close relationship with the BOJ as a professor, and will be joined by Shinichi Uchida and Ryozo Himino as deputy governors.

site_title: Hong Kong’s Lee faces stern test over US$3.4 billion bid to ease housing shortage
summary: Hong Kong's US$3.4 billion plan to build temporary housing faces criticism over high cost and lack of a longer-term solution. The plan aims to ease a massive housing shortage, which has seen house prices rocket by 350% in the past two decades. Chief Executive John Lee promised 30,000 units of "Light Public Housing" over five years to cut waiting times for public housing. However, critics argue that the plan does not address the root cause of the problem and may only provide a temporary fix.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, an acute supply crunch and an influx of wealth has pushed up rents.
Two buyers purchased the 4,596-square-foot home for HK$390 million (S$65.1 million) in late January. The seller bought the property for HK$520 million in 2018.

site_title: Sinopec among China’s oil giants seeking more Russian imports
summary: China's state-owned oil refining giants, Sinopec, PetroChina, and Cnooc, are ramping up purchases of Russian crude due to cheap cargoes. They are sourcing flagship Urals and ESPO, which load from western and pacific terminals. The move comes as demand recovers after China ditched its Covid Zero policy, allowing for increased imports. The companies are seeking to take advantage of Russian crude's lower prices.

images.alt_text: Logo of China Petroleum & Chemical Corp. (Sinopec) is displayed at one of the company's gas station in Beijing, China, on Friday, March 4, 2016. China announced they will ease market barriers for transport, oil and gas at the opening of the National People's Congress in Beijing on Saturday. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Keep a cool head when investing in Chinese equities
summary: Chinese equities have rebounded sharply since October 2022, driven by easing regulatory crackdowns and government support. However, investors must be cautious, as the economy is still grappling with Covid-19 cases and production disruptions. The property market is also not out of the woods, and regulators may reverse measures if excesses re-emerge. Despite this, the author remains overweight on Chinese equities, citing a potential strong economic recovery and reasonable valuations. Investors should take a strategic medium-term view, manage exposure within a diversified portfolio, and avoid excessive exuberance.

images.alt_text: Screen displaying the Hang Seng stock index outside Hong Kong Exchanges, in Hong Kong. Hong Kong and China equities have rallied this year.

“Chinese tech shares were once the easiest bet, and for most of the past decade you were able to win and see outperformance without doing much,” said Chen Da, managing director at Fortune Hill Asset Management.

site_title: Japan government debt tops 1,000 trillion yen, under pressure to spend further
summary: Japan's outstanding government debt has surpassed 1,000 trillion yen, exceeding 1 trillion USD, for the first time, according to Ministry of Finance data. The debt, which is more than double the size of the economy, has been fueled by massive stimulus measures during the Covid-19 outbreak. The heavily-indebted government has prioritized near-term economic growth over fiscal reform, raising concerns over runaway debt and its impact on the country's financial stability.

images.alt_text: Yen company bond spreads have increased from 54.9 basis points at the end of October.

site_title: Intel weighs boost to investment in Vietnam chip packaging plant: sources
summary: Intel is considering a significant expansion of its existing $1.5 billion investment in a chip testing and packaging plant in Vietnam, potentially worth up to $1 billion. The move aims to better manage supply disruptions and reduce reliance on China and Taiwan due to political risks and trade tensions. Vietnam is seen as a key player in the global semiconductor supply chain, with the country aggressively pushing to expand its chipmaking industry and attracting foreign companies. The expansion would signal a growing role for Vietnam in the industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. chipmaker Intel Corp's logo is seen on their "smart building" in Petah Tikva, near Tel Aviv, Israel. December 15, 2019.  REUTERS/Amir Cohen/File Photo

site_title: China factory gate prices fall in January, CPI rises
summary: China's producer price index (PPI) fell 0.8% in January, extending a 0.7% drop from the previous month and beating expectations. The consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.1% year-over-year, slightly missing forecasts. The drop in PPI suggests that domestic demand has not yet strengthened enough to boost upstream sectors, contradicting initial expectations after China's zero-Covid policy ended.

site_title: Keeping Singapore’s public finances on an even keel
summary: Singapore's public finances face challenges ahead, with public expenditure expected to rise from 18% to 20% of GDP by 2030, driven by healthcare costs. To maintain fiscal stability, the government should prioritize spending, build a fiscal buffer, limit unnecessary programs, intervene upstream, seek partnerships, and ensure equitable distribution of spending across generations. The Medium-Term Fiscal Projections report provides a framework for discussion on the government's spending priorities and plans, and the government's financial reserves can be used to address unexpected events.

images.alt_text: Combining government expenditure, operating revenue and net investment returns contribution projections, government spending will likely be balanced by total revenue in the coming years.

site_title: Investing lessons in 2023 from the dotcom crash and GFC
summary: Investors in 2023 can draw lessons from past market crashes, including the dotcom crash and global financial crisis (GFC), to develop a different investing playbook. Both crashes were caused by asset bubbles fueled by easy money and low interest rates, with central banks intervening to stabilize markets. In contrast, the current market environment is marked by high inflation and a tight labor market, driving efforts to curb inflation and fueling corrections in equity markets. To navigate this environment, investors must focus on fundamentals, diversify holdings, and be disciplined in their decision-making, using tools like stop-loss strategies and margin trading to manage risk.

images.alt_text: In 2022, the S&P 500 clocked in with its worst performance since 2008, an abnormality in the context of history.
In investing, keeping a level head is harder than it looks, especially if your conviction in the stocks you own starts to waver.

site_title: The key role of the founder for startups
summary: Entrepreneurs play a crucial role in a startup's success, and their personalities can significantly impact the company's fortunes. Founders must possess a sound business model, plan for profitability, and execute the plan. The article highlights successful entrepreneurs like Forrest Li of Sea Ltd, who refocused the company on profitability after a market downturn. In contrast, founders like Henn Tan of Trek 2000 and Ankiti Bose of Zilingo faced accounting fraud and mismanagement allegations, respectively. The article concludes that entrepreneurs can be pivotal in changing a company's direction and creating wealth, value, and jobs, but also emphasizes the need for proper corporate governance and caution when investing in founders.

images.alt_text: The era of low interest rates kept the cost of capital cheap and stoked a culture of excess and extreme liquidity, with private equity and venture capital funds taking the lead in looking for returns on investments. This led to too many startups raising at arguably inflated valuations; creating the perfect conditions for a crash.

Founder disputes have arisen more frequently as the startup ecosystem matures and more companies move into later stages of fundraising. Conflicts often revolve around existing or pending unequal contributions of founders, and often one or more co-founders choose to leave the company or is “forced” to exit.

site_title: Microsoft cuts jobs in HoloLens, Surface, Xbox as layoffs continue
summary: Microsoft has cut 10,000 jobs, including 617 in the Seattle area, as part of its previously announced 5% workforce reduction. The cuts affect units including Surface devices, HoloLens mixed reality hardware, and Xbox, with HoloLens hardware team reductions throwing doubt on a third iteration of the goggles.
