Focusing on fundamentals will allow investors to steer clear of fad investing.
The scores for “business ethics controversy” for Adani Total Gas and Adani Transmission were downgraded from “low” to “moderate,” the ratings agency said.
UOBKH has raised its target price on the stock to S$3.90 from S$2.96 to reflect a target price-to-earnings multiple 30 times, in line with DFI’s past five-year average.
Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on bargain-buying following a recent sell-off and hopes about China’s post-Covid reopening.

site_title: Will ACS (Primary) move turn Tengah into the new Bishan?
summary: The relocation of Anglo-Chinese School (Primary) from Bukit Timah to Tengah in 2030 is expected to boost interest and property values in the new town, with properties near top schools drawing a price premium of up to 15%. The move may also dampen nearby residential rents, but the immediate impact would be minimal. This development comes as part of the Draft Master Plan 2025, which aims to build capacity and attract skilled migrants to the area.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
The relocated ACS Primary will start operations in 2030 with only new Primary 1 pupils, in other words, those born in 2023.
An artist's impression of Tengah Town's first executive condominium, Copen Grand.
Resale prices rose 2.3 per cent quarter on quarter, making for the slowest growth in 2022.
While new HDB homes are priced to ensure they are affordable, some concerns over housing affordability in Singapore persist, possibly for valid reasons.

site_title: Angry Birds developer Rovio posts Q4 profit drop
summary: Finnish game maker Rovio, creator of Angry Birds, reported a 55% decline in adjusted operating profit for Q4 2022 to €5.9 million due to a failed 5G gaming platform subsidiary and Apple's app tracking transparency framework. Revenue declined 2.5%. Despite this, the company's games outperformed the market, and it expects flat revenue and profit development in 2023. Rovio initiated a strategic review and entered preliminary discussions with US-listed rival Playtika over a potential takeover offer.

images.alt_text: CMA said it had taken an initial view that the deal could result in a substantial lessening in competition, higher prices, fewer choices or less innovation for UK gamers, according to a statement published on Wednesday (Feb 8).
Valorant has grown to become one of the most popular esports titles.

site_title: Japan’s Nippon Steel to pay record FY dividend on rising profit
summary: Japan's Nippon Steel reported a 2% increase in April-December net profit to 517 billion yen, and plans to issue a green bond to co-finance eco-friendly car motors. The company will pay a record-high full-year dividend of 180 yen per share, up from 160 yen last year. Nippon Steel's underlying business profit forecast was raised by 60 billion yen to 690 billion yen, driven by a 21% increase in sales to 5.7 trillion yen. The company aims to expand its lower-emission business, including carbon capture and storage.

site_title: China’s planned curbs for solar wafer equipment exports not industry-targeted
summary: China's proposed restrictions on exports of solar wafer manufacturing equipment are not targeted at a specific industry, according to a commerce ministry spokesman. The move, proposed on December 30, could hinder efforts by other countries, such as the US and India, to establish solar manufacturing capacity. China dominates the global solar panel supply chain, manufacturing 98% of solar wafers in 2022. The restrictions could potentially hamper the growth of the solar industry globally.

site_title: German inflation slows to five-month low on energy aid
summary: Germany's inflation slowed to 9.2% in January, the lowest level in five months, due to government aid to ease energy costs. The country's energy aid includes a ceiling on heating, with households receiving reimbursements backdated for the first two months of the year. Despite the slowdown, underlying price pressures remain, with core inflation at a record 5.2%, prompting the European Central Bank to consider further interest rate hikes to prevent a wage-price spiral.

images.alt_text: A partly lit home on the outskirts of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, Sept. 1, 2022. German Economy Minister Robert Habeck said the country can't rely on gas supplies from Russia, as Europe braces for energy shortages this winter. Photographer: Ben Kilb/Bloomberg
Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, at a news conference unveiling the Green Deal Industrial Plan in Brussels, Belgium, on Wed, Feb 1, 2023.

site_title: Toshiba announces offer from JIP as saga enters its final stages
summary: Toshiba has received an offer from a Japanese group, Japan Industrial Partners (JIP), to purchase the company, marking a step towards ending its troubled history. The JIP-led group has made a final buyout offer of approximately 2 trillion yen (S$20.2 billion), in line with Toshiba's market value. A sale would prevent Toshiba's nuclear power business, deemed important to national security, from passing into foreign hands, addressing concerns over the potential transfer of ownership to an overseas firm.

site_title: Covid-19 testing, treatment no longer fully subsidised from Apr 1; vaccines still free
summary: Singapore will no longer fully subsidize Covid-19 testing and treatment, starting April 1, but vaccines will remain free. The shift marks the country's move towards treating Covid-19 as an endemic disease. Vaccination subsidies will continue for eligible individuals, while patients with higher risk of severe disease will receive free telemedicine support. Regular government subsidies and healthcare schemes will apply to testing and treatment, and community isolation facilities will no longer be required.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Masks no longer mandatory, Covid-19 border measures removed as Singapore enters Dorscon Green
Singapore has maintained its prevailing Covid-19 rules for incoming travellers from China.

site_title: South Korea’s household borrowing sees biggest monthly decrease in at least 19 years
summary: South Korea's household borrowing saw its largest monthly decrease in 19 years in January, with a 4.6 trillion won (S$3.64 billion) drop to 1,053.4 trillion won. The decline was attributed to rising interest rates, tightened loan regulations, and seasonal factors related to the Chinese New Year's holiday. This decrease follows a 25 basis point interest rate hike by the Bank of Korea in January, marking the highest rate since 2008.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians cross a road in front of the Bank of Korea headquarters in Seoul on July 13, 2022, after South Korea's central bank delivered a historic half-point interest rate hike to tame fast-growing inflation. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: HDB resale prices accelerate in Jan as million-dollar deals surge by 42%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Resale prices of Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats accelerated in January, with a 1.4% average increase compared to December, according to SRX and 99.co. This is the steepest incline in recent months. Million-dollar deals surged 42.9% to 40 transactions, with the highest price paid for a five-room unit at The Pinnacle @ Duxton for about S$1.3 million. Experts attribute the surge to genuine buyers and upgraders seeking larger spaces in the HDB resale market.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

Generic photo of Toa Payoh HDB estate covered in mist on a rainy day on January 25, 2023. 
Can be used for property, low visibility, rain, weather, climate stories.
PM Lee Hsien Loong said the government is working to ramp up the supply of flats, cool the resale market and keep flats affordable and accessible.
National Development Minister Desmond Lee highlighted that public housing affordability and accessibility cannot be solved with an oversupply of built-to-order flats.

site_title: Finding a love match for Valentine’s Day and beyond
summary: Singles are embracing in-person connections after nearly two years of safe-distancing measures, with the festive season from December to February being a peak dating period. According to Paktor group chief executive Alex Tam, this trend is driven by "revenge socialising," where individuals make up for lost time. Dating events organized by GaiGai's offline matchmaking arm have seen a surge in interest during this period.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
love, romance, couple
身处各地的人可以“虚拟分身”进入滨海湾花园元宇宙观赏演出，并且与歌手互动，舞台还结合烟花和巨型全息投影等特效，这些都是实体活动较难做到的。（第一通提供）
Speed dating, on the other hand, was a socially accepted way to vet potential partners in person — not to mention wildly efficient.
Tinder contributed nearly US$1.7 billion to Match's total revenue of US$3 billion in 2021

site_title: Major investments secured by Singapore in 2022
summary: Singapore secured a total of S$22.5 billion in fixed asset investments in 2022, according to the Economic Development Board. Notable investments include a US$5 billion commitment from United Microelectronics Corporation (UMC) in the electronics industry. These investments demonstrate Singapore's continued focus on the manufacturing sector and its efforts to drive economic growth.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

pixgenerics / ST20221117_202206612640 / Alphonsus Chern //

Generic photograph of people working on a rotary evaporator in a laboratory in GSK's High Potency Facility on 17 November 2022.
Large manufacturing projects from the electronics sector accounted for 66.7 per cent of fixed asset investment commitments in 2022.
Singapore secured S$6.3b in fixed asset investment commitments, and S$2.1 billion in total business expenditure in Q2.

Despite the potential advantages of various government measures to boost foreign investment, if put into action, industry observers expect the government to hold off on providing details at Budget 2023.
The latest public sector report found that real income growth of the 20th percentile earners was at 2.7 per cent per annum between 2016 and 2021.

site_title: Singapore scores record high of S$22.5b in fixed asset investment commitments in 2022
summary: Singapore secured a record S$22.5 billion in fixed asset investment (FAI) commitments in 2022, driven by large electronics manufacturing projects. The Electronics sector accounted for 66.7% of FAI commitments, up from 42.3% in 2021. Despite expected global macroeconomic uncertainties, the Economic Development Board (EDB) expects the investments to hold, with total business expenditure per annum expected to reach S$6.2 billion. The investments are expected to create 17,113 new jobs, with 61% in hub and business services.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Some of the major investments secured by Singapore in 2022 came from the manufacturing industry.
Singapore secured S$6.3b in fixed asset investment commitments, and S$2.1 billion in total business expenditure in Q2.

"As much as we want to think about nearshoring for resilience... no country, no region, is entirely self-sufficient," says Jacqueline Poh, managing director of the Singapore Economic Development Board.

site_title: Dhaka’s growing stake in the art world
summary: Dhaka's Dhaka Art Summit (DAS) has solidified its position as a major player in the art world, showcasing works by over 160 artists, architects, and designers. The event, which ran from February 9-11, 2023, featured a mix of established and emerging artists, with a focus on South Asian art and issues such as LGBTQ+ rights. The summit also included satellite exhibitions and parties, with attendees including high-profile figures and foreign curators. The event's success has been attributed to the Samdani family, who have been instrumental in promoting diversity and inclusivity in Bangladesh's arts scene. With works acquired by prominent museums and exhibitions invited to other parts of the world, the DAS has cemented its role in taking South Asian art to a global audience.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Cate Blanchett is a force of nature playing a famous conductor in Tar, though the film itself is highly problematic.

Poklong Anading of the Philippines is one of the over 60 artists featured in the book SEA: Contemporary Art In Southeast Asia. His photograph titled Counter Acts seeks to subvert photography's claim of capturing an image by having his subjects turn the lights towards the viewer instead, obscuring their own faces.
Yukiharu Furuno (left) and Takanao Todo are showing their ceramics at the Japanese Creative Centre.

site_title: FairPrice Group names first chief sustainability officer
summary: FairPrice Group has appointed Chan Tee Seng as its first chief sustainability officer, focusing on promoting a circular and low-carbon economy, supporting livelihoods and well-being, and serving customers. Chan, previously CEO of the group's food services businesses, aims to "inspire bold action" in support of sustainable development. Group CEO Vipul Chawla emphasized Chan's appointment highlights the group's growing emphasis on sustainability, citing his leadership experience and ability to navigate new developments and legislation.

site_title: Chinese state media, AI companies warn of risks in ChatGPT stock frenzy
summary: Chinese state media has cautioned investors against chasing local ChatGPT-concept stocks due to risks and unproven technology. Domestic AI companies, including Hanwang Technology and CloudWalk Technology, have seen their shares surge 129-217% amid intense interest in generative AI. However, the companies have warned of market risks and urged investors to be cautious, citing unproven products and services. The warning comes after Alphabet's ChatGPT rival shared inaccurate information, wiping out $100 billion in market value.

images.alt_text: The OpenAI website ChatGPT about page on laptop computer arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 12, 2023. Microsoft Corp. is in discussions to invest as much as $10 billion in OpenAI, the creator of viral artificial intelligence bot ChatGPT, according to people familiar with its plans. Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
Google said it will soon release an experimental chatbot called Bard as it races to respond to ChatGPT, which has wowed millions of people since it was unveiled at the end of November.
Microsoft recently announced a multibillion-dollar investment in OpenAI, solidifying ties with the startup to get the inside track on its AI models like ChatGPT and Dall-E.

site_title: Gold eases as steady dollar, US rate-hike outlook dent appeal
summary: Gold prices eased 0.1% to $1,874.58 per ounce, as the dollar steadied and US Federal Reserve officials indicated more interest rate hikes to curb inflation. Market participants expect the Fed's target rate to peak at 5.132% in July. The dollar's stability makes dollar-priced gold more expensive for buyers holding other currencies, contributing to the decline.

images.alt_text: Gold is sensitive to high interest rates, which lift the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Credit Suisse warns of substantial 2023 loss after cash exodus
summary: Credit Suisse warned of a substantial loss in 2023 after clients pulled a record amount of funds, totaling 110.5 billion francs, in the final quarter of 2022. The bank's net loss for the period was 1.39 billion Swiss francs, driven by losses in its wealth division and investment bank. Credit Suisse is refocusing on its core wealth management business and shedding 9,000 jobs to regain profitability by 2024. The bank's shares fell 4% in pre-market trading.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg
Sources say that measures to strengthen Credit Suisse's controls and monitor risks continue to be implemented and assessed.
The bank is seeking to cling on to talent contending with a restructuring of its Wall Street operations after a period of scandals and losses sparked a tide of departures

site_title: Security agency Apro disputes NTUC announcement of its right-sizing exercise; union stands by its actions
summary: Security agency Apro has disputed the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) announcement of its right-sizing exercise, which involved demoting some senior officers. Apro claimed the exercise was necessary due to insufficient demand for senior security officers, while the Union of Security Employees (USE) stated it stood by its actions, saying the demotions were "forced". The NTUC had characterized Apro's actions as attempting to reset the wages or employment terms of workers. Apro had offered an alternative scheme to affected workers, but the USE had brought the case to the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) for conciliation.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
Under the Progressive Wage Model for the outsourced private security sector, security officers’ monthly basic wages before overtime start at S$1,650.

site_title: Anglo-Chinese School (Primary) to move to Tengah and take in girls from 2030
summary: Anglo-Chinese School (Primary) will relocate from its Barker Road campus in Newton to Tengah in 2030, serving new Primary 1 pupils born in 2023 and accepting girls for the first time. The school will start with 11 Primary 1 classes, up from 8 currently. The relocated campus will be co-ed and will also house a special education school for students with autism spectrum disorder. Existing pupils will remain at the Barker Road campus until graduation in Primary 6.

images.alt_text: HDB Flats in the Bishan Ang Mo Kio area as seen from Ang Mo Kio Central on September 17, 2021.
The highest transacted price for a HDB flat in January comes from a five-room unit at The Pinnacle @ Duxton, which was sold for about S$1.3 million.
PM Lee Hsien Loong said the government is working to ramp up the supply of flats, cool the resale market and keep flats affordable and accessible.

site_title: Australia’s house prices set to plunge 15% in 2023, Jarden says
summary: Australian house prices are expected to plummet 15% in 2023, according to Jarden Securities, marking the largest property decline on record. The Reserve Bank of Australia is predicted to increase interest rates to 4.1% by May, driven by a debt-to-income ratio of 188.5%, making households vulnerable to rising borrowing costs. This prediction downgrades Jarden's previous forecast of a 15-20% peak-to-trough fall in house prices to a 20-25% correction, which could intensify recession risks.

images.alt_text: Demand for housing in Australia is set to swell further, as international students return to study there, and the pace of immigration roars back to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: US lifts import ban on Malaysian glove maker YTY
summary: The US has lifted a year-long ban on importing goods from Malaysian rubber glove maker YTY Industry Holdings Sdn Bhd, citing the company's resolution of suspected labor abuses. The US Customs and Border Protection had banned YTY products in 2022 due to evidence of "forced labor" in its manufacturing operations. YTY has taken remedial steps, including reimbursing migrant workers and conducting an independent social audit, which has led to the lifting of the ban.

site_title: Global banks seek to end drought in China property debt sales
summary: Global investment banks, including JPMorgan Chase & Co and UBS Group, are resuming efforts to gauge interest in Chinese developer bond sales, aiming to revive a key business that has been dormant for over a year. Recent market developments, such as Dalian Wanda Group's successful return to the primary market, have encouraged bankers to approach investors. Several major developers, including Country Garden Holdings and Yanlord Land Group, are being tested for investor appetite. This move aims to capitalize on China's economic growth and policymakers' shift in focus from COVID controls to economic growth.

images.alt_text: In a sign of how the record downturn has hurt bottom lines, defaulted developer Shimao Group Holdings’ main unit onshore is expected to record its first full-year loss in 21 years.

site_title: Adani Group companies see ESG ratings cut by Sustainalytics
summary: Sustainalytics downgraded ESG scores for several Adani Group companies, including Adani Total Gas and Adani Transmission, due to business ethics controversy. The scores were cut from "low" to "moderate" for these companies, while Adani Green Energy was assigned a "moderate" rating. The Adani Group has lost over $100 billion in market value since a report by Hindenburg Research accused it of stock manipulation and accounting fraud. MSCI and S&P Global are also reviewing the companies, which could lead to further selling and potential removal from key indexes.

site_title: JPMorgan to hire more than 500 small-business bankers over 2 years
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to hire over 500 small-business bankers by 2024, boosting its workforce serving small enterprises by 20% to 2,300. The move aims to support small business owners facing challenges such as inflation, supply chain disruptions, and expense pressure. Despite a worsening economic outlook, the bank's global headcount rose 8% to 293,723 last year, and it plans to add engineers worldwide. This hiring signals the company's commitment to supporting small businesses through the business cycle.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall as Federal Reserve warns rates to go higher for longer
summary: Asian markets fell as the Federal Reserve warned that interest rates will go higher for longer to combat decades-high inflation. Despite this, Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on bargain-buying and hopes for China's post-Covid reopening. Data showing a strong jobs market and key Fed officials acknowledging more pain before easing inflation concerns dampened optimism. The US interest rate hike prospects have led to a decline in global markets, with Asia being the worst hit.

images.alt_text: In early trade, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta all rose but Hong Kong, Shanghai and Tokyo fell on Wednesday.

site_title: Lakeside Towers owners try for en bloc again amid Jurong Lake District buzz
summary: Lakeside Towers, a 99-year leasehold condo in Singapore, has been put up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$350 million, a 14.8% increase from its 2018 price of S$305 million. The sale comes as the nearby Jurong Lake District (JLD) is being redeveloped, with plans for new homes, businesses, and amenities. The condo's land plot is zoned for residential use and can accommodate up to 395 apartments. The tender will close on April 12, 2023.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
The leisure and edutainment mall is located opposite Jurong East MRT interchange station and bus interchange.
This is the latest sale attempt by the owners of the 99-year leasehold Jurong condominium. The previous tender had also closed without a bid on Dec 22, 2021.
Chip Eng Seng, KSH and SingHaiyi are in talks to acquire 160-unit Park View Mansions for S$260 million.
Located at 9E and 9F Yuan Ching Road, the site spans 12,465.4 square metres (sq m) with a plot ratio of 2.1.

site_title: Crypto exchange Kraken faces US SEC probe over unregistered securities
summary: Kraken, a leading cryptocurrency exchange, is under investigation by the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) over potential unregistered securities offerings to American clients. The probe is at an advanced stage and could lead to a settlement in the coming days. A settlement could pressure other crypto firms to comply with SEC rules, and the agency has repeatedly stated that most tokens being offered are securities that should be registered. This probe follows FTX's collapse and the SEC's repeated warnings to the crypto industry.

images.alt_text: Kraken plans to ask clients to transfer their crypto token holdings into different wallets or exchange them into fiat currencies.

site_title: Boeing set to score 15 Max jet order from Hong Kong airline
summary: Boeing is set to receive a 15-order deal for 737 Max jets from Hong Kong airline Greater Bay Airlines, valued at US$783 million. The order, announced for 737-9 aircraft seating 200 passengers, is a win for Boeing over rival Airbus. The planes, 20% more fuel efficient than their predecessors, are expected to start deliveries from mid-2024.

images.alt_text: The tailfin of a Boeing 737 Max 10 aircraft. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Deutsche Bank’s asset management arm eyes crypto investments
summary: Deutsche Bank's asset management arm, DWS Group, is in talks to invest in two German cryptocurrency firms, Deutsche Digital Assets (DDA) and Tradias, as part of efforts to revive growth. DWS is seeking to expand into the digital assets space, following similar moves by other traditional finance firms. The investment would mark a significant move by DWS to restore its reputation after allegations of greenwashing. DWS CEO Stefan Hoops has been a vocal advocate of new technologies, and the investment could yield "interesting opportunities" for the asset manager.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank has signalled more cost-cutting measures in an effort to keep expenses at last year’s level in the face of “inflationary pressures.”

site_title: Twitter service stumbles as paying users get more room
summary: Twitter experienced technical issues on Wednesday, with reports of problems surfacing on Downdetector in Silicon Valley. The issues persisted for about two hours, with users reporting difficulties posting tweets. The problems were attributed to the company's new policy allowing paying users to post longer tweets, up to 4,000 characters. Twitter acknowledged the issue and stated that it was working to resolve the problem.

images.alt_text: Twitter has seen advertisers flee amid worries about Musk’s approach to content moderation rules, impacting its revenue.
Elon Musk last year completed a US$44 billion deal for Twitter that gave him control of the company for US$54.20 a share.

site_title: Masks no longer mandatory, Covid-19 border measures removed as Singapore enters Dorscon Green
summary: Singapore has removed Covid-19 border measures and made masks no longer mandatory, effective February 13, as it moves from Dorscon Yellow to Dorscon Green. This decision follows a stable Covid-19 situation despite increased travel during the year-end holidays and China's shift away from its zero-Covid policy. Remaining border measures and mask mandates will be removed, marking a significant easing of restrictions in the city-state.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Covid-19 testing and treatment will no longer be fully subsidised, though vaccines will continue to be offered free.
China reopening: Singapore businesses in country hit by Covid surge but remain optimistic

The use of TraceTogether (TT) and SafeEntry (SE) is also being stepped down. Most venues will no longer require check in using the TT application or token, except for larger events with more than 500 participants at any time, and certain nightlife establishments where VDS checks are still required.
Masks will still need to be worn on public buses and trains, including at the boarding areas within bus interchanges and MRT platforms.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH upgrades DFI to ‘buy’; raises target on better 2023 outlook
summary: UOBKH has upgraded DFI Retail Group to "buy" from "hold" with a raised target price of US$3.90 from US$2.96, reflecting a target price-to-earnings multiple of 30 times. Analyst Adrian Loh attributes this upgrade to better earnings momentum and potential margin expansion amid improving market and economic conditions, particularly following China's elimination of its zero-Covid strategy.

images.alt_text: DFI Retail Group, which owns supermarket brands Cold Storage and Giant in Singapore, is expected to post a strong earnings rebound in FY2023, DBS said.

site_title: Thai consumer confidence at 26-month high in January on tourism
summary: Thai consumer confidence reached a 26-month high of 51.7 in January, driven by a rebound in tourism and government stimulus measures. The tourism sector, particularly the return of Chinese tourists, contributed to the confidence boost. Despite the high cost of living, consumers felt the economy was recovering and expected to start spending more in the first quarter. The government forecasts 7-8 million Chinese visitors this year, with over 30 million foreign tourist arrivals expected, following a record 11.15 million foreign visitors in 2022.

images.alt_text: Tourists wait to check in for flights, ahead of brace of an influx of Chinese tourists as COVID restirction are dismantled, at Bangkok’s Suvarnabhumi airport, Thailand, January 4, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

site_title: Prime US Reit’s deputy CEO Harmeet Singh Bedi to take over the reins from Mar 8
summary: Barbara Cambon, CEO of Prime US Reit's manager, will retire on March 8. Harmeet Singh Bedi, the current deputy CEO and CFO, will take over as CEO, effective March 8. The current financial controller will cover Bedi's CFO duties until a new one is appointed.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: BNY Mellon says investors ‘absolutely interested’ in digital assets
summary: BNY Mellon's head of digital assets, Michael Demissie, stated that investors are "absolutely interested" in digital assets, citing a 2022 survey where 90% of clients planned to invest in tokenized assets. This comes despite the 2022 plunge in cryptocurrency markets due to rising interest rates and high-profile collapses. Demissie emphasized the need for clear regulation and responsible actors to offer reliable services, saying "we need to navigate this space in a responsible way."

images.alt_text: DWS isn’t the only firm with roots in traditional finance that’s mulling expansion in the digital assets space.

site_title: Netflix lays out plans to crack down on account sharing
summary: Netflix plans to crack down on account sharing, affecting an estimated 100 million users worldwide who share accounts. The company will set up primary locations and charge a few dollars for an extra member. Members can now manage account access, transfer profiles, and watch Netflix on personal devices or new TVs. The new measures will be rolled out in Canada, New Zealand, Portugal, and Spain starting today.

site_title: Turkish leader Erdogan acknowledges problems with earthquake relief effort as death toll surpasses 15,000
summary: Turkish President Erdogan acknowledged problems with the government's initial response to the devastating earthquake in southern Turkey, where the death toll has surpassed 15,000, with 12,391 deaths in Turkey and 2,992 in Syria. Erdogan visited the disaster zone, promising no one would be left homeless, but officials and medics reported a lack of equipment, expertise, and support to rescue those trapped. Criticism of the government's response has raised concerns about Erdogan's chances in the upcoming May election.

images.alt_text: People try to help victims at the site of a collapsed building after an earthquake in Diyarbakir, Turkey, 6 Feb, 2023.

site_title: Adani to prepay US$500 million loan as banks baulk at refinancing
summary: Adani Group plans to prepay a $500 million bridge loan due March 9, after some banks refused to refinance the debt amid a short seller attack that sent the group's assets tumbling. The conglomerate had previously prepaid $1.11 billion worth of borrowings backed by shares. The move comes as global banks scrutinize the group following the Hindenburg report alleging malpractices, with Citigroup's wealth arm stopping acceptance of Adani securities as collateral. Adani's shares have rallied this week after the debt payment and as traders covered short positions.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Adani logo and decreasing stock graph is seen in this illustration taken January 31, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Adani Wilmar says its edible oil business, its largest, has climbed nearly 4 per cent on an uptick in festive and wedding demand.

site_title: G7 weighs sanctioning Chinese, Iranian and North Korean firms for aiding Russia’s military
summary: The G7 is considering sanctioning companies in China, Iran, and North Korea for allegedly providing Russia with military parts and technology. The aim is to disrupt the flow of material to Russia by February 24, the one-year mark of its invasion of Ukraine. The US has already raised concerns with China about non-lethal equipment provided to Russia, while Ukraine's allies have sanctioned Iranian firms and called out North Korea for providing ammunition. Diplomatic efforts are underway to address potential loopholes in sanctions, with companies potentially including microchip suppliers and firms from the United Arab Emirates, Turkey, and India.

images.alt_text: From Feb 5, the coalition – which consists of Australia, Canada, Japan and the United States, plus the 27-nation European Union, will also impose price caps on Russian products, such as diesel, kerosene and fuel oil.

site_title: Singapore shares fall at Thursday’s open tracking Wall Street retreat; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% on Thursday, tracking a Wall Street retreat amid concerns over the US Federal Reserve keeping interest rates high. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 15.01 points to 3,373.51, with banking stocks starting the morning mostly in the red. Golden Agri-Resources rose 2% amidst the sell-off, while CapitaLand Ascendas Reit and Mapletree Logistics Trust declined. The US market fell 0.6% on Wednesday due to concerns over corporate earnings and interest rates.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
A unit of Keppel Land is selling its 100 per cent stake in Willowville for US$5.5 million, the company says on Wednesday.

site_title: SOTU : Biden launches his 2024 presidential bid
summary: US President Joe Biden launched his 2024 presidential bid through his State of the Union address, where he emphasized bipartisan cooperation and defended his economic record despite Republican opposition. Biden highlighted his achievements, including job growth, infrastructure spending, and climate change initiatives, while also warning that Republicans are intent on sabotaging his policies. The president's speech foreshadowed the shape of the 2024 presidential and congressional campaigns, with Biden portraying the Republicans as agents of chaos and Trumpism. Despite his efforts, Biden faces challenges, including low approval ratings and concerns about his age, which may impact his re-election bid.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden delivers his State of the Union speech, with Speaker Kevin McCarthy and Vice President Kamala Harris seated behind him, to a joint session of Congress at the U.S. Capitol in Washington, on Tuesday, Feb. 7, 2023. After his State of the Union address, President Biden had many questioning a key phrase. (Kenny Holston/The New York Times)

site_title: Disney to cut 7,000 jobs as Bob Iger seeks US$5.5 billion in savings
summary: Disney CEO Bob Iger announced plans to cut 7,000 jobs and achieve $5.5 billion in cost savings as part of a restructuring effort to improve profit margins. The company will be reorganized into three divisions: entertainment, ESPN, and theme parks. Iger aims to deliver value for shareholders and achieve profitability in its streaming business by 2024. The move follows earlier financial results, which saw a 7.8% revenue growth and a 99-cent profit per share.

images.alt_text: Bob Iger, 71, will share more of his plans when the company reports financial results on Feb 8, but he has already taken steps to reverse decisions made by his predecessor.

site_title: Singapore’s median household income edges up 0.2% in real terms in 2022, amid high inflation
summary: Singapore's median household income from work rose 0.2% in real terms in 2022, despite high inflation, according to a Singapore Department of Statistics report. This growth was driven by nominal growth of 6.1% and was largely due to increased household size, rather than wage increases. The top 10% of households saw a decline in real average household income, while the bottom 10% experienced the highest rise in income. Household income inequality decreased, with the Gini coefficient dropping to 0.378, its second-lowest value since 2000.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Office workers during the lunch hour in Raffles Place on 13 Aug 2020.

site_title: Biden says Xi faces ‘enormous problems’
summary: US President Joe Biden stated in an interview with PBS NewsHour that Chinese President Xi Jinping faces "enormous problems," including a fragile economy, and is constrained in confronting the US due to the need to protect international trade. Biden also acknowledged Xi's potential but noted his economy is not functioning well. The US-China relationship is described by Biden as the most consequential in the world, with Xi's muted support for Russia in the Ukraine invasion being a notable example of his limited ability to maneuver.

images.alt_text: Washington is pressing ahead with plans to curb China’s access to sensitive semiconductor technology and is trying to get countries it considers allies to do the same.

White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre, speaking separately to reporters on Air Force One, described the balloons as part of a “fleet” and said they had been spotted around the world for several years.

site_title: Some European firms may reverse last year’s big price hikes
summary: Some European companies, such as packaging giant Smurfit Kappa and Italian retailer OVS, may reverse last year's price hikes as inflationary pressures ease, potentially providing relief to consumers. Companies face higher wages and borrowing costs, but some expect prices to fall in the second half of the year. A soft landing for the euro zone economy has fueled a stock market rally, with prices expected to decline further if input costs continue to fall. However, not all companies will cut prices, with some protecting margins or facing higher costs.

images.alt_text: The British Retail Consortium said spending in store chains rose by 4.2 per cent in annual terms in January, weaker than December’s 6.9 per cent rise and lagging behind inflation which signified a fall in sales volumes.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang ticks all the right boxes, so why aren’t investors biting?
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates, a Singapore-based property developer, trades at a 7.5% discount to its net asset value, with a relatively healthy balance sheet and a sizeable land bank. The company's specialisation in luxury condominiums and landed properties may be a tailwind amid the current property boom. Despite a low debt-to-total assets ratio and a cash reserve, investors should be cautious of challenges such as rising interest rates and potential global economic recession. A privatisation offer is one possible option, but recent history suggests it may not be a favorable one.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The board expresses its appreciation to Mr Charles Chow for his past services and contributions.
Some 24 units of Pollen Collection have been released for sale so far, with four units sold, said developer Bukit Sembawang Estates.
The Bukit Timah Link land parcel is on a site area of 4,611.1 sq m and comes with a maximum GFA of 13,834 sq m.

site_title: Robinhood plans buyback of Sam Bankman-Fried’s contested stock
summary: Robinhood, an online brokerage, plans to repurchase shares previously controlled by Sam Bankman-Fried, with CEO Vlad Tenev announcing the cancellation of nearly $500 million in share-based compensation for co-founders. The company reported a wider-than-expected loss for the fourth quarter, with revenue climbing 5% to $380 million. Despite struggling to recapture traders' interest, Robinhood's stock rose 2.2% in extended trading after the announcement. The company aims to deliver value to customers and shareholders with its new products, including retirement accounts and crypto wallets.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried owns 90 per cent of the entity but no longer controls it, according to court papers.

site_title: SGX posts 30.1% rise in H1 profit to S$284.6 million
summary: SGX, the Singapore Exchange, reported a 30.1% increase in net profit to S$284.6 million for the first half of FY2023, driven by a 9.6% growth in revenue to S$571.4 million. Earnings per share rose to S$0.266, and an interim quarterly dividend of S$0.08 per share was declared. The bourse operator attributed the growth to derivatives trading and clearing revenue, and treasury income. Adjusted net profit was S$236.8 million, up 7% from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Full year revenue for SGX reached S$1.099 billion, a 4 per cent increase as compared with last year’s S$1.056 billion.

site_title: Temasek prices 4-year euro bonds at 3.25% and 10-year bonds at 3.5%
summary: Temasek, a state-owned investor, priced its 4-year and 10-year euro bonds at 3.25% and 3.5% respectively, worth 750 million euros each. The bonds, part of a US$25 billion guaranteed global medium-term note programme, drew strong interest from high-quality institutional investors. The dual-tranche offering, scheduled to close on Feb 15, 2023, has been rated "Aaa" by Moody's and "AAA" by S&P, and the proceeds will be used to fund Temasek's ordinary business operations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
FILE PHOTO: A Temasek logo is seen at the annual Temasek Review in Singapore July 7, 2016. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
The Temasek logo at the Temasek Holdings office at The Atrium@Orchard on 9 February 2021.
Temasek fully owns Singapore Technologies Telemedia, the parent of STT GDC.
Bonds or financial management concepts. investment plan.money market forecasting
HDB flats on Henderson Road. HDB is a quasi-government entity with government support. Its bonds offer a yield pick-up over T-bills.

site_title: Economists see earlier rate cut by Bank of Korea as risks rise
summary: The Bank of Korea is expected to cut its benchmark interest rate earlier than previously thought due to growing concerns over economic growth. Economists predict a rate cut to 3.25% in the last three months of this year, one quarter earlier than previously expected. This decision comes as South Korea faces record trade deficits, property-market downturns, and plunging exports. Despite the expected rate cut, two board members have expressed disagreement, suggesting the central bank may hold its next meeting on February 23.

site_title: US says China balloon ‘fleet’ is global as Nato voices concern
summary: The US says suspected Chinese spy balloons, like the one shot down, are part of a "fleet" that has been spotted globally for several years, violating the sovereignty of countries across five continents. The US shared information with dozens of countries, and Nato's Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg voiced concern, citing a pattern of Chinese behavior investing in new military capabilities and increased intelligence activities in Europe and Asia. China insists the balloons were for weather research, but the Pentagon described them as high-tech spying operations.

images.alt_text: With China’s economy reeling and relations with neighbours and countries in Europe strained, restraint and prudence are in its own interests.
US sailors recover remnants of a high-altitude surveillance balloon off the coast of Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, Feb 7, 2023.
Washington is pressing ahead with plans to curb China’s access to sensitive semiconductor technology and is trying to get countries it considers allies to do the same.
Rep Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia tried to shut President Joe Biden during his State of the Union address by calling him a liar.

site_title: UK property surveyors say buyers disappearing after rate rise
summary: UK property surveyors report a decline in buyer inquiries, agreed sales, and new instructions to sell, with prices dropping further due to higher interest rates and a tight cost-of-living squeeze. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) says the market is in a "muted" state, with all regions in England experiencing a retreat in prices. Price expectations are negative for most of the UK, except Northern Ireland, where they are expected to remain positive. The findings suggest the longest slump in the property market since the 2008 global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: A shopper enters a Marks & Spencer Group Plc (M&S) store in Guildford, UK, on Tuesday, Jan. 10, 2023. Marks & Spencer is due to give its Christmas trading update on Thursday. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Manulife US Reit to retain distributable income for the first time; H2 DPU drops 10.3% pre-retention
summary: Manulife US Reit has retained US$3.8 million (9% of distributable income) for the second half of 2022, marking the first time the real estate investment trust has retained any income since its listing in 2016. The trust announced a distribution per unit (DPU) of US$0.0214 for H2, down 18.6% from the previous year. Despite challenges in submarkets, portfolio occupancy remained stable at 88% as of end-December, above the US Class A average of 83.3%. The retention is part of the trust's efforts to improve financial flexibility amid an ongoing strategic review.

site_title: Oilfield equipment firm diversifies to fuel growth
summary: Oilfield Services & Supplies (OSS), a Singapore-based oilfield equipment firm, is diversifying its business to fuel growth. The company has invested in a Dutch climate start-up, FlexBase International, to develop floating structures with reduced carbon footprints. OSS aims to leverage FlexBase's expertise to establish successful operating models in Asia. With a compound annual growth rate of 6.8% over the past decade, OSS expects 8% revenue growth annually for the next five years. The company, founded in 1999, has established partnerships in multiple countries and remains family-run, prioritizing innovation and employee upskilling.

images.alt_text: From left: Acclaim chief executive Tony Lim; Acclaim-Heartware Endowment Fund 2021 recipients Dewi Murni binte Musa and Crystal Khoo Jinying; and Acclaim chairman Anthony Lim.

ITCAN chief executive officer Amit Sujan (centre, in blue suit) and IT managing director Sippy Sujan (centre, in red dress) attending a company event with employees. The Sujans see company culture as key to attracting and retaining talent.

site_title: JPMorgan cuts hundreds more mortgage workers amid housing woes
summary: JPMorgan Chase cut hundreds of mortgage employees amid the housing market's decline due to soaring borrowing costs. The bank's mortgage-origination volume dropped 60% last year, leading to job losses across the industry. This move is part of the thousands of reductions in the mortgage industry over the past year. Despite this, JPMorgan added over 22,000 jobs in the last year. The bank attributed the cuts to adjusting staffing according to changing business needs.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise on upbeat cues from Powell, strong earnings
summary: European shares rose 0.3% on Wednesday, driven by positive cues from US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks on disinflation and upbeat earnings from energy and chemicals firms. Despite a more hawkish tone from other Fed policymakers, investors focused on Powell's comments, which were seen as less hawkish than expected. The Stoxx 600 has gained around 8% this year, with more than half of the 93 companies reporting earnings beating market expectations.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.6 per cent to 33,949.01 on Wednesday.

site_title: CPF, EZ-Link services, multiple websites down after power outage at Microsoft Azure
summary: Multiple organizations, including the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Board, EZ-Link, the Esplanade, and Nanyang Technological University (NTU), experienced disruptions to their web services on February 8 due to a power surge at Microsoft Azure's data center in the South-east Asia region. The outage was caused by a utility power surge tripping cooling units, and services were restored after 9.36pm. The affected organizations pointed to Azure's outage as the reason for their service interruptions, with some advising visitors to use alternative services.

images.alt_text: CMA said it had taken an initial view that the deal could result in a substantial lessening in competition, higher prices, fewer choices or less innovation for UK gamers, according to a statement published on Wednesday (Feb 8).

site_title: Michael Jackson estate eyeing near-US$1 billion sale of music rights: report
summary: The Michael Jackson estate is reportedly closing in on a deal to sell half its interests in the singer's music catalogue for up to $900 million, with Sony and a possible financial partner involved. The sale could include publishing and recorded-music revenues, as well as Broadway show and biopic rights. This deal would be the largest in the music catalogue market, following recent transactions such as Bruce Springsteen's $600 million sale to Sony and Bob Dylan's $400 million sale to Universal Music.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on March 05, 2009 US popstar Michael Jackson addresses a press conference at the O2 arena in London. - The estate of Michael Jackson is closing in on a deal to sell half its interests in the megastar's music catalogue, in a deal worth up to $900 million, Variety reported on February 8, 2023. (Photo by Carl DE SOUZA / AFP)

site_title: UN aviation body sees recovery to pre-pandemic air travel in 2023
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organization predicts a full recovery in commercial air travel by 2023, with demand exceeding 2019 levels by around 3% by the end of the year. By the end of 2024, air passenger demand is projected to be 4% above 2019 levels. This recovery is expected to be "complete and sustainable," with most routes reaching pre-pandemic levels by the end of the first quarter.

images.alt_text: AirAsia joins peers including Thai Airways International in scrambling to right-size their fleets to cater for a jump in tourists from China, which now allows people to come and go freely without quarantine.

Capital A CEO Tony Fernandes (from right) and the company’s chief airport and customer experience officer Kesavan Sivanandam as well as AirAsia CEO Bo Lingam at the launching ceremony of the new AI-powered concierge “Ask Bo”.

site_title: US: Stocks fall on weakening corporate earnings outlook
summary: US stocks dropped on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.6% to 33,949.01, amid concerns about a deteriorating corporate earnings outlook and worries the Federal Reserve may overdo its efforts to counter inflation. The 12-month forecast for corporate earnings has fallen since analysts' estimates at the end of 2022. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, with Alphabet sinking 7.4% and Microsoft dropping 0.3%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 23.79 points, or 0.07 per cent, at the open to 34,132.90.

site_title: Ramping up green finance – how can Singapore take the lead?
summary: Singapore and its Asean neighbors aim to scale up investment in green infrastructure to achieve ambitious climate commitments. Decarbonization is expected to contribute up to 7% of Singapore's GDP by 2050, with $10 trillion in investment opportunities in Asean over the same period. To drive green finance, governments, financial institutions, and regulators must collaborate to accelerate investment in green projects. Leveraging blended finance, green bonds, and public-private partnerships can help mobilize capital for sustainable projects. Singapore can position itself as a regional hub for green financing and encourage private sector innovation to unlock opportunities in the energy transition.

images.alt_text: Greening the entire economy is said to be key to Singapore's transition to a sustainable economic model - and blended finance will play a crucial role. PHOTO: ST

site_title: UK experiencing largest loss of purchasing power since mid-1970s
summary: The UK economy experienced its largest loss of purchasing power since the 1970s oil crisis due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, causing a surge in energy prices. The Office for National Statistics reported a decline in gross domestic income of 0.2% in the year through the third quarter of 2022, despite a 1.9% rise in real GDP. The terms-of-trade effect, a measure of the ratio of export prices to import prices, fell by 6.2% during the 12 months, impacting living standards.

site_title: EU leaders must step up at big meeting
summary: EU leaders are set to convene a two-day meeting starting Feb 9 to address pressing issues including the one-year anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine, a massive new green industrial plan, and migration policy. The EU plans to impose a 10th package of sanctions on Russia, including capping the sales prices of refined petroleum products, and double down on support for Ukraine. Meanwhile, EU leaders must work together to implement a green industrial plan to counter China and the US, and balance migration control with labor shortages in member states.

images.alt_text: European Commission proposed loosening state aid rules for investments in renewable energy or decarbonising industry, on a temporary basis, until end 2025.

Solar panels in Spain. While the EU is still widely seen as ahead of the US in rolling out green tech, the latter's Inflation Protection Act has made the US a more attractive investment environment for several key green industries.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, SGX, Frasers Property, Prime US Reit, Manulife US Reit, BRC Asia, Straco
summary: A unit of Keppel Land is selling its 100% stake in Willowville for US$5.5 million, marking a significant development for the company. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 30.1% increase in net profit to S$284.6 million for the first half of FY2023, driven by an increase in derivatives trading and clearing revenue. These developments may affect trading of securities for the mentioned companies, including Keppel Corporation and SGX.

images.alt_text: Daily turnover came in at about 1.2 billion securities worth a collective S$962 million.

site_title: Keppel Land unit sells 100% stake in Willowville for US$5.5m
summary: Keppel Land Vietnam Properties is selling its 100% stake in Willowville for US$5.5 million to Oasis Asia Real Estate Investment. Willowville holds a 60% stake in a project company developing a site in District 1, Ho Chi Minh City. The sale is expected to take place in the first half of 2023, aligning with Keppel's Vision 2030 asset monetization plans to unlock capital.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: Europe's automakers need to boost domestic industry to face US IRA
summary: European automakers are urging policymakers to revamp licensing processes and energy pricing to attract key suppliers like battery makers in response to the US Inflation Reduction Act (IRA). The region needs to boost domestic industry, but protectionism should be avoided, according to car associations. With the IRA requiring 40% of critical minerals in US-made EV batteries to come from US miners or recycling plants, European carmakers face minimal impact. A major revamp is needed to attract suppliers, with localising production and sourcing batteries closer to plants being considered alternatives.

images.alt_text: European Commission proposed loosening state aid rules for investments in renewable energy or decarbonising industry, on a temporary basis, until end 2025.

site_title: Singapore banks may deliver special Q4 dividends along with margin growth: analysts
summary: Singapore's three local banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, are expected to deliver special Q4 dividends, driven by high interest rate environment and strong net interest margins. Despite moderate NIM expansion in the fourth quarter, analysts believe the banks can afford to pay out higher dividends due to high capital levels and above-regulation provisioning coverage. DBS and OCBC are seen as having the most upside potential for special dividends, with DBS expected to return its surplus capital to shareholders through a special dividend of S$0.80 per share.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The banks have been beneficiaries of policy rate hikes by the Fed, with their bread and butter - net interest margin - rising in tandem with higher borrowing costs.
Analysts said rising interest rates could result in higher margins and a revival of wealth management income for local lenders, which would lift their overall earnings.

site_title: Fox boosts buyback by US$3 billion as World Cup powers earnings
summary: Fox Corp expanded its share buyback plan by $3 billion, surpassing second-quarter revenue estimates with a 3.8% revenue rise to $4.61 billion. Ad revenue rose 4% to $2.5 billion, driven by the World Cup and US midterm election. CEO Lachlan Murdoch said the results will be used to deploy capital through mergers and acquisitions. Despite the boost, analysts warn that ad revenue may decline in the coming months as the World Cup's impact fades.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Fox News channel sign is seen at the News Corporation building in the Manhattan borough of New York City, New York, U.S., June 15, 2018. REUTERS/Eduardo Munoz/File Photo

site_title: Alibaba tests ChatGPT-style tool as AI buzz intensifies
summary: Alibaba is developing a ChatGPT-style tool, currently in internal testing, as part of its focus on large language models and generative AI. The move joins other tech companies, including Baidu, Alphabet, and JD.com, in the global race to showcase their AI capabilities. Alibaba's US-listed shares rose 3.2% after the news, while shares in other Chinese AI companies have surged in recent days due to investor excitement over OpenAi's ChatGPT.

site_title: Singaporeans will not have to worry about having an affordable home to call their own: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong assured citizens that the government is working to increase the supply of flats, cool the resale market, and keep Housing Board flats affordable and accessible. Following a 12-hour parliamentary debate, Lee stated that the government is ramping up BTO projects, studying ways to support first-time buyers, and prioritizing new flats for those with genuine housing needs. This effort aims to address the current BTO supply crunch and alleviate concerns about affordable housing.

Can be used for property, low visibility, rain, weather, climate stories.

site_title: BRC Asia posts 12.2% drop in Q1 net profit
summary: BRC Asia reported a 12.2% drop in Q1 net profit to S$11.7 million, with revenue falling 4.5% to S$341.2 million. The construction industry in Singapore grew 6.5% in 2022, but its value-added remained 19.3% below pre-pandemic levels. The company's sales order book stands at about S$1.4 billion, with project durations up to 5 years.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
BRC Asia saw increased sales volume and higher steel prices in the year, it said in a bourse filing on Tuesday (Nov 29).

site_title: Scam victims in S’pore lost S$660.7 million in 2022, almost S$1.3 billion in past two years
summary: Singaporeans lost a total of S$660.7 million to scams in 2022, with 31,728 reported cases, a 32.6% increase from 2021. The majority of victims (53%) were between 20 and 39 years old, debunking the myth that the elderly are the most vulnerable. Phishing scams were the most common, with 7,097 cases and a 52.6% decrease in total losses. Scammers often target young adults on social media, and most online scams are perpetrated by scammers based outside Singapore.

images.alt_text: SMSes is weak as an authentication factor, and users should be prepared to accept some inconveniences in exchange for stronger protections for their online accounts.

site_title: Temasek offers dual tranche of 4-year and 10-year euro bonds
summary: Temasek is offering a dual tranche of 4-year and 10-year euro bonds, unconditionally guaranteed by the state-owned investor. The bonds will be listed on the Singapore Exchange and offered outside the US to non-US citizens. Temasek has an overall corporate credit rating of "Aaa" by Moody's and "AAA" by S&P Global Ratings, and plans to use the net proceeds to fund its ordinary course of business.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: US: Wall Street edges lower on rate hike worries
summary: US stocks edged lower on Wednesday, February 8, 2023, as investors worried about potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 23.79 points, or 0.07%, to 34,132.90, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened lower. Microsoft rose after announcing its AI push, but overall market sentiment remained cautious due to rate hike concerns.

site_title: Japan may opt for milder chip-equipment curbs on China than US, says lawmaker
summary: Japan may adopt milder restrictions on chip-production machinery sales to China than those implemented by the US, despite agreeing on export curbs with the Netherlands and the US. Former Liberal Democratic Party minister Akira Amari stated that Japan shares the concern over equipment but questions the need to match US restrictions exactly.

images.alt_text: Washington is pressing ahead with plans to curb China’s access to sensitive semiconductor technology and is trying to get countries it considers allies to do the same.
China has been a major destination for capital spending by the largest semiconductor equipment companies.
TSMC holds a ceremony to start mass production of its most advanced 3-nanometre chips in the southern city of Tainan, Taiwan, Dec  29, 2022.
Japan's output and new orders contracted for a seventh consecutive month in January, although at a slower pace than in the previous two months, the S&P survey’s subindexes showed.

site_title: BMW and VW win appeal over UK antitrust information request
summary: BMW and Volkswagen have won an appeal in a London tribunal, overturning a fine and ruling that the UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) does not have the power to request information from companies based outside the UK. The CMA had demanded documents and information related to a probe into alleged anti-competitive conduct in vehicle recycling. The ruling substantially undermines the CMA's ability to investigate and deter anti-competitive conduct, with a CMA spokesperson stating that the decision "substantially risks undermining our ability to investigate, enforce against and deter anti-competitive conduct".

site_title: Oil settles up for third day as interest rate concerns ease
summary: Oil prices rose for a third consecutive day, with Brent crude settling up 1.7% to $85.09 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude up 1.7% to $78.47 a barrel. The increase was driven by easing concerns about future interest rate hikes following comments from US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. A weaker US dollar also contributed to the gains, making dollar-denominated oil cheaper for foreign buyers. Investors expect less aggressive interest rate increases to boost oil demand, which is also supported by China's easing of Covid-19 curbs.

images.alt_text: An oil pump jack at the New Harmony Oil Field in Grayville, Illinois, US, on Sunday, June 19, 2022. Top Biden administration officials are weighing limits on exports of fuel as the White House struggles to contain gasoline prices that have topped $5 per gallon. Photographer: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg

site_title: Microsoft’s US$69 billion Activision deal could harm UK gamers, watchdog finds
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has found that Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard could harm UK gamers due to potential reduced competition, higher prices, and fewer choices. The CMA has asked Microsoft to address its concerns by February 22, and a final report is set for April 26. The US Federal Trade Commission has also filed a lawsuit to block the takeover, while the European Commission will review the deal by April 11.

site_title: Prime US Reit DPU down 3.4% to US$0.0655
summary: Prime US Reit reported a 2% year-on-year increase in distributable income to US$77.2 million for FY2022, despite a 2.7% dip in net property income to US$97.9 million. For the second half of FY2022, distributable income fell 10.8% to US$35.8 million, while net property income dropped 13.3% to US$47.1 million.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's aggregate leverage stood at 37.5 per cent as at end September 2022.

site_title: Google AI chatbot Bard offers inaccurate information in company ad
summary: Google's AI chatbot Bard delivered an inaccurate answer in a company advertisement, contradicting the actual discoveries made by the James Webb Space Telescope. In the ad, Bard was asked to explain the telescope's findings to a 9-year-old, but provided incorrect information. The incident highlights concerns over the reliability and accuracy of AI chatbots, which Google has touted as a "launchpad for curiosity" to simplify complex topics.

images.alt_text: Google said it will soon release an experimental chatbot called Bard as it races to respond to ChatGPT, which has wowed millions of people since it was unveiled at the end of November.
Microsoft recently announced a multibillion-dollar investment in OpenAI, solidifying ties with the startup to get the inside track on its AI models like ChatGPT and Dall-E.
The viral success of ChatGPT has turned the spotlight on artificial intelligence (AI) on Wall Street.

Baidu has diversified in recent years into artificial intelligence, cloud computing and autonomous driving technologies as advertising revenue has remained sluggish in the face of tighter regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Fitch raises China’s growth forecast to 5% for 2023
summary: Fitch has revised its forecast for China's economic growth in 2023 to 5.0% from 4.1% due to a faster-than-anticipated recovery in consumption and broader activity after the end of the "zero-Covid" regime. Despite the upgrade, the agency expects a less vigorous rebound than in 2021, when the economy grew 8.4%. The property market remains weak, and net trade may drag on growth due to depressed export demand. Fitch forecasts a budget deficit of around 7% of GDP in 2023.

images.alt_text: Washington is pressing ahead with plans to curb China’s access to sensitive semiconductor technology and is trying to get countries it considers allies to do the same.

site_title: Adani Power profit slumps as fuel costs nearly double
summary: Adani Power, the power generating arm of the Adani Group, reported a 96% fall in third-quarter profit to 87.7 million rupees (S$1.4 million) due to rising fuel costs. The company attributed the decline to increased fuel costs, nearly doubling from the previous year. Adani Power has denied allegations of stock manipulation and tax evasion made by US short-seller Hindenburg Research. The group has also stated that it saw no material adverse impact from a possible independent review. The decline in profit follows a market rout for the Adani Group.

images.alt_text: Adani Wilmar says its edible oil business, its largest, has climbed nearly 4 per cent on an uptick in festive and wedding demand.

site_title: US dollar slips after Powell strikes balanced tone on inflation
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.18% to 103.12 against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, following Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's cautious tone on inflation. Powell reiterated that interest rates might need to rise higher than expected, but also mentioned a process of "disinflation" underway. The euro rose 0.14% to US$1.074, while the pound sterling rose 0.37% to US$1.209. Markets are now focusing on data rather than Fed officials, with expectations of interest rate hikes by the European Central Bank and Reserve Bank of Australia.

site_title: K-Pop godfather spurs rally in battle for music empire
summary: SM Entertainment, the K-pop agency managing groups like Girls' Generation and Super Junior, saw its stock price surge 9.5% to a record high after founder Lee Soo-Man vowed to block a 217-billion-won (S$228-million) deal with Kakao, a messaging and social media service operator. Lee, the largest shareholder, claims the deal would dilute his control and take action to block it. Analysts speculate a potential takeover battle between Lee's allies and Kakao, with Lee's stake potentially reduced to 16.8% of outstanding shares.

images.alt_text: The KPOP Index aims to measure the performance of Korean entertainment companies including HYBE, the agency that manages the South Korean boy band phenomenon BTS, JYP Entertainment, SM Entertainment and YG Entertainment.

South Korean singer and producer Psy at his music company's office in Seoul, South Korea on October 6, 2022. A decade on from his lightning-in-a-bottle moment, Psy has started his own music label and talent management company. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)

site_title: Indonesia tech linchpin shakes up top ranks after selloff
summary: Indonesia's tech giant GoTo Group is undergoing a major management reshuffle amid a steep market selloff. Group President Patrick Cao is stepping down to run a company endowment fund, while Tokopedia Chief William Tanuwijaya will step down as CEO but remain on the board. GoTo has also cut 12% of its workforce to reach profitability, joining other tech companies in the industry. The move aims to stabilize the company after a significant sell-off of its shares.

images.alt_text: Gojek riders wait for their delivery orders at a distribution centre in Surabaya on May 17, 2021, as Gojek and Tokopedia unveiled a merger to form GoTo Group, creating the largest tech firm in the world's fourth most populous country. (Photo by Juni Kriswanto / AFP)

site_title: Oil may hit US$100 amid China reopening, Iran’s Opec official says
summary: Oil prices may reach US$100 a barrel by the second half of 2023 due to China's economy emerging from lockdowns and potential constraints in the market, according to Afshin Javan, Iran's liaison to Opec. This comes as traders assess the impact of China's reopening on the global economy. Opec+ has committed to maintaining current output targets until at least June, when its next in-person meeting will take place.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures were up US$2.52, or 3.1 per cent, to US$83.51 a barrel by 1.07 pm EST (1807 GMT) on Tuesday.
Brent futures for April delivery rose US$1.05, or 1.3 per cent, to US$80.99 a barrel, after trading between US$79.10 and US$81.25.

site_title: Surprise jump in used-car prices adds to Fed’s inflation worries
summary: The US used-car market experienced a surprise 2.5% month-on-month price increase in January, reversing some of last year's 15% decline. This uptick in used-vehicle prices adds to the Federal Reserve's inflation worries, as it is a significant component of the Consumer Price Index (CPI). Experts predict that used-car prices will continue to rise, potentially denting hopes that inflation is headed lower. The increase in used-car prices may also lead to higher inflation rates, with every 1% increase translating to a 5 basis point rise in the overall inflation rate.

images.alt_text: Subaru hopes to reach global production of 1 million vehicles next financial year, CEO Katsuyuki Mizuma said.
Nissan is looking to become a “strategic investor” in Renault's electric vehicle unit Ampere, the carmakers say.
The NHTSA said owners of those vehicles should not drive them until they get repairs, warning “the risk to vehicle occupants is dire”.

site_title: China car sales down 38% in January as subsidies, tax cut end
summary: China's passenger-car sales plummeted 38% in January, reversing a 2.4% gain in the previous month, due to the expiration of tax cuts on combustion-engine cars and subsidies on electric vehicles. New-energy car sales also declined 6.3% after a 90% growth in 2022. The Chinese New Year and end of EV subsidies contributed to the decline. Despite this, Tesla's market share in China's battery EV sector rose to 12.5% in January.

images.alt_text: After wild success at home selling affordable electric cars to the masses, BYD is looking beyond China.
Tesla plans to produce a weekly average of nearly 20,000 units at its Shanghai factory in February and March.
BYD plans to open more than 100 dealerships in Japan by the end of 2025, but faces a tough task in a country where  nine in 10 cars sold annually are built by domestic firms such as Toyota.
FILE PHOTO: An Xpeng P5 electric vehicle (EV) is seen displayed during a media day for the Auto Shanghai show in Shanghai, China April 19, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Elon Musk sees the toughest competition for Tesla in China, home of the company he expects “most likely to be second” in electric vehicles.
LEVC aims to expand its suite of services, which include cars arranging their own maintenance and recognising their owner’s interests to help them book activities.
For most of this year, Tesla joined rivals in aggressively raising prices on its most popular vehicles, such as the Model Y SUV.

site_title: Investigators end MH17 downing probe despite ‘indications’ Putin was involved
summary: International prosecutors have ended their investigation into the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 (MH17) in 2014, citing "strong indications" that Russian President Vladimir Putin approved the use of a Russian missile system. However, evidence was deemed insufficient to lead to a criminal conviction. The investigation found that Putin's approval was necessary before a request for equipment could be granted to separatist forces. A Dutch court had previously convicted two Russian intelligence agents and a Ukrainian separatist leader of murder in connection with the downing of the plane.

images.alt_text: President Vladimir Putin threatened to personally target Boris Johnson (pictured) with a missile attack just before ordering Russian forces into Ukraine, the former UK prime minister has claimed.

site_title: Adani Wilmar posts 16% profit growth, shrugs off Hindenburg report impact
summary: Adani Wilmar reported a 16% increase in quarterly profit to 2.5 billion rupees, driven by strong demand for edible oil and food products during festivals and weddings in rural India. The company attributed the growth to "macro tailwinds" and a bumper kharif crop, despite being affected by a recent Hindenburg Research report. Adani Wilmar's shares rose 5% ahead of the earnings announcement, reversing a 30% decline following the report.

images.alt_text: SBI’s total exposure was 0.9 per cent of its total loan book, or around 270 billion Indian rupees (S$4.3 billion), chairman Dinesh Kumar Khara has said.

An activist of India's Congress party shouts slogans as he burns an effigy of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Indian tycoon Gautam Adani during a rally to press for a probe into allegations by a US short-seller against Adani Group which triggered its market rout.
The group’s flagship firm – Adani Enterprises - plunged 10 per cent after opening higher on Thursday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government revenue may fall short for FY2026-30 due to rising public spending, unless tax changes from Budget 2022 are maintained. China's reopening led to a surge in Covid infections, but businesses remain optimistic. Subang Airport's revamp into a premium city airport is seen as a "bold, brave and right decision" by Malaysian aviation tycoon Tony Fernandes. Glass waste is being repurposed for use on oil rigs, and Straco is set to report a "substantial net loss" for FY2022.

site_title: China’s Li Auto launches electrified SUV to rival Tesla Model Y
summary: Li Auto unveiled the L7, an electrified SUV with a starting price of 319,800 yuan (S$62,486.2) and a maximum driving range of 1,315 kilometers. The five-seater has a purely electric range of 210 kilometers and a four-cylinder petrol engine for added power. Deliveries are expected to start on March 1. The L7 competes with Tesla's Model Y and other luxury SUVs, but its price is higher due to reduced competition from Tesla's price cuts. Li Auto aims to redefine the family SUV market with its new model.

site_title: Church of England explores gender-neutral God
summary: The Church of England announced it will explore the use of gender-neutral terms to refer to God in prayers, following growing global awareness about pronouns causing offense. The decision reflects the institution's efforts to keep up with evolving notions around gender and sexuality. The Church's Faith and Order Commission will work with the liturgical commission to examine questions around gender terms, with no plans to abolish current services. No changes can be made without extensive legislation.

images.alt_text: “We have not loved you as God loves you, and that is profoundly wrong,” the bishops said in an open letter to LGBTQI+ people.

site_title: Budget 2022 tax changes will help plug revenue-spending gap in FY2026-30: MOF
summary: Singapore's government revenue would likely have fallen short for FY2026-2030 without the tax changes introduced in Budget 2022, which included a 9% GST hike, higher personal income tax rates, and increased property taxes. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) projects government spending to rise to 19-20% of GDP in FY2026-2030, driven by healthcare and infrastructure, while revenue is expected to remain around 18.5%. To close the gap, the government may need to increase revenue or cut back in existing areas to fund new priorities, with MOF noting that fiscal space is now "much tighter" compared to previous decades.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
A general view shows the city skyline in Singapore on December 1, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
The IRAS building along Newton Road on 17 September 2018.
A weaker economic outlook weighs on businesses and households, but handouts will need to be carefully calibrated, with a continued eye on longer-term needs, economists said.

site_title: ECB to zero in on soured loans this year as economy slows
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will focus on soured loans this year as the economy slows, with some eurozone banks having set too little money aside for bad debts. The ECB has already demanded more capital from 24 banks that fell short of coverage expectations, and warned that rising interest rates may affect customers' ability to pay back debts. The bank also found "persisting risk control deficiencies" in loan classification and governance issues, leading to demands for more capital or asset shedding.

images.alt_text: However, the first days of February showed central banks were not quite done yet with monetary tightening, with the US Federal Reserve adding 25 bps and the ECB and the BOE each hiking by 50 bps.

site_title: China’s rich and mass affluent live in a parallel universe
summary: China's rich and mass affluent are spending more, driven by a desire to maintain their quality of life and save for rainy days. Despite the pandemic, luxury spending in cities like Shanghai and Shenyang has recovered, with many consumers choosing local brands for their quality and innovation. The expectation is for Chinese spending on luxury goods to increase by 16-18% in 2023, with consumers more likely to spend domestically and on tourism, cosmetics, and consumer services. Chinese consumers have become more conservative, prioritizing savings and investing in property, with the housing market expected to see a long-term uptrend.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
