China has been a main driver of an explosion in demand for Swiss watches, jewellery and accessories in recent years.
Wuhan, China’s eighth-most populous city, will allow local families to buy an additional home in areas with purchasing caps.
China is already the world's biggest market for EVs based on annual sales volumes.
Bernard Arnault, chairman and CEO of LVMH, speaks during a news conference on the company's 2022 annual results in Paris, France, Jan 26, 2023.

site_title: Japan’s Sumitomo Metal raises FY profit forecast on higher prices
summary: Japan's Sumitomo Metal Mining has raised its full-year net profit forecast to 158 billion yen, a 15% increase from its November guidance, due to higher prices of nickel, copper, and gold. The company also increased its annual dividend forecast to 202 yen per share. However, its net profit for the April-December period fell 10.2% due to smaller gains from mining following the sale of its stake in a Chilean copper mine. The company's production at the Cerro Verde copper mine in Peru remains unaffected by protests.

site_title: ABN Amro beats estimates, announces US$536 million buyback
summary: ABN Amro reported a fourth-quarter profit of 354 million euros, beating analysts' expectations, as the Dutch lender restrained costs and announced a $536 million share buyback. The bank's strong capital position allows for further share buybacks, with CEO Robert Swaak aiming for a gradual reduction of capital over time. Loan loss provisions were lower than expected, and net interest income rose 17% from a year earlier, while CET1, the key measure of capital strength, was 15.2% higher than estimates.

images.alt_text: ABN Amro's headquarters in Amsterdam in the Netherlands. The Dutch lender on Wednesday (Aug 10) reported higher-than-expected profit as improvements in its loan book have enabled it to release provisions for bad debt.

site_title: Huawei’s Meng Wanzhou to take over as rotating chairperson
summary: Huawei Technologies has announced that Meng Wanzhou, the daughter of founder Ren Zhengfei, will take over as rotating chairperson on April 1. Meng returned to China in September 2021 after nearly three years of detention in Canada over alleged attempts by Huawei-linked companies to sell equipment to Iran in breach of US sanctions. Her appointment comes after an agreement with US prosecutors allowed her to return home.

site_title: Regulation, productivity and the meaning of life
summary: US construction productivity has stagnated or declined over the last 50 years, contrary to expected technological advancements. Overregulation, particularly safety and environmental rules, may be a contributing factor. However, these regulations have led to improved workplace safety and cleaner air, despite not showing up in productivity numbers. The author suggests that measured productivity isn't the only measure of economic success, and that prioritizing people's lives and well-being is essential.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in the SoHo neighborhood of New York. Even with 75 per cent of the public saying the economy is poor, a majority of Americans rate their own financial situation positively.

site_title: New York Times beats quarterly revenue estimates on subscriber additions
summary: The New York Times exceeded quarterly revenue estimates by $21.1 million, driven by 240,000 digital-only subscriber additions in the fourth quarter. The publisher reported $667.5 million in revenue, surpassing analysts' expectations of $646.4 million. The company also announced a $250 million share buyback. CEO Meredith Kopit Levien attributed the success to the bundling of news and lifestyle content, which has seen a record increase in both total bundle volume and new subscriber additions. The Times aims to reach 15 million subscribers by 2027.

site_title: Japan’s Subaru cuts annual output target as chip shortage drags on
summary: Subaru has cut its annual output target by nearly 10% due to ongoing semiconductor shortages affecting the global automotive industry. The company now expects to produce 880,000 vehicles this fiscal year, down from a previous forecast of 970,000 units. CEO Katsuyuki Mizuma stated that the shortages are most acute among parts for immediate delivery and are expected to last until around June before recovering. Subaru aims to reach global production of 1 million vehicles next financial year.

site_title: UK tax revenue to fall by £12.7 billion on low gas prices
summary: The UK's tax revenue is expected to fall by £12.7 billion in 2023-24 due to lower gas prices, which will limit Chancellor Jeremy Hunt's spending power. The government had forecast £12.8 billion in energy support but now expects to spend £1.5 billion. This reduction in energy support savings will offset the decrease in tax revenue, according to the Treasury. The decline in gas prices is attributed to a mild winter and strong imports of liquefied natural gas, but the low prices may not last due to market volatility.

images.alt_text: People walk along Regent Street during the second day of Boxing Day sales, in London, Britain, December 27, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: OCBC’s police report: Who is Susilo Wonowidjojo, and what’s the story with Gudang Garam?
summary: OCBC's Indonesian branch filed a police report against billionaire Susilo Wonowidjojo, president-director of Gudang Garam, alleging fraud involving over $87 million in troubled loans to a wig-making company. Susilo, Indonesia's 14th-richest man with a net worth of $3.5 billion, has been president-director of Gudang Garam since 2009 and owns the company, which is one of Indonesia's top clove cigarette makers. The investigation is related to loans totaling over $87 million, with OCBC NISP alleging $232 billion in troubled loans to the wig company.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan

PT Bank OCBC NISP filed the report against Susilo Wonowidjojo, an owner and president director of Gudang Garam, on fraud allegations relating to some 232 billion rupiah (S$20 million) in troubled loans, the lender’s lawyer Hasbi Setiawan says.

site_title: Barratt optimistic about UK home sales uplift in January
summary: Barratt Developments reports an increase in forward sales to 10,854 homes as of January 29, up from 10,511 at the end of last year. The company's net private-reservation rate rose to 0.49 in January, a 5% increase from the previous six months. CEO David Thomas expressed optimism about the UK housing market, citing early signs of improvement in trading conditions, but noted that continued momentum is needed to confirm a reversal in challenging market conditions.

images.alt_text: The UK housing market is facing multiple headwinds: rising borrowing costs, inflation that’s pushing up the cost of materials and the threat of a recession that’s curtailing demand for new homes.
Taylor Wimpey said it was aiming for annualised savings of around £20 million and cost-cutting efforts would involve lay-offs.

site_title: Japan rolls out ‘humble and lovable’ delivery robots
summary: Japan has introduced self-driving delivery robots, known as DeliRo, to tackle labor shortages and rural isolation. The robots, which can navigate streets under revised traffic laws, aim to provide elderly people in depopulated rural areas with access to goods. The experiment, set to begin in April, hopes to address chronic labor shortages in the country. Proponents believe the machines can help alleviate rural isolation and improve the quality of life for elderly residents.

images.alt_text: The Emobot is a device that continuously monitors the emotional state of the elderly to detect depression, anxiety and other mental health concerns using AI to interpret data collected by the Embot’s camera and microphone.

site_title: Singapore stocks end higher as traders mull inflation outlook, corporate earnings; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks ended higher, up 0.2%, following a US Federal Reserve chairman's remarks on inflation. Jerome Powell acknowledged cooling US inflation, but warned of potential rate hikes. The Straits Times Index rose 7.68 points to 3,388.52, with daily turnover reaching 1.2 billion securities worth S$962 million.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
In early trade, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta all rose but Hong Kong, Shanghai and Tokyo fell on Wednesday.
The telecommunications company shed as much as 8.1 per cent or S$0.09 to S$1.02 in morning trading.
Demand for housing in Australia is set to swell further, as international students return to study there, and the pace of immigration roars back to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Sutton Place to be relaunched for en bloc sale at unchanged S$285 million guide price
summary: Sutton Place, a 5-storey condominium in prime District 10, Singapore, is relaunched for collective sale on Feb 9 with a guide price of S$285 million. The site has a land area of approximately 93,183 sq ft and comprises 44 units, offering some buffer on land betterment charges. The reopening of China is expected to boost demand, particularly from well-heeled Chinese buyers. The public tender closes on Mar 9.

images.alt_text: Based on the indicative price of S$285 million and a development charge payable of about S$20.89 million, this will translate into a land price of S$2,052 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr).

site_title: Remaking Subang Airport as premium city airport a brave and right decision: Tony Fernandes
summary: Malaysian aviation tycoon Tony Fernandes has expressed support for the government's decision to revamp Subang Airport into a premium city airport and regional aviation hub. Fernandes, CEO of Capital A, believes this move will boost the country's aviation sector. He also announced that AirAsia has applied to operate from Subang Airport, targeting the premium market and travelers previously not served by AirAsia. The upgrade is expected to bring in more business, particularly after China's removal of certain COVID testing requirements for travelers.

images.alt_text: Capital A CEO Tony Fernandes (from right) and the company’s chief airport and customer experience officer Kesavan Sivanandam as well as AirAsia CEO Bo Lingam at the launching ceremony of the new AI-powered concierge “Ask Bo”.
Capital A posted an operating loss of 491.3 million ringgit (S$153.3 million) for the 3 months ended June 30, compared to a loss of 792.2 million ringgit in the year-ago period.
“The uncertainty of routes have now gone with China opening...And there’s a clear path to normalcy, to 2019 pre-Covid,” CEO of Capital A Tony Fernandes said.

site_title: Binance says full audit for Crypto’s biggest exchange remains some way off
summary: Binance, the world's largest digital-asset exchange, says its full audit of its assets and liabilities is "some way off" due to the lack of agreed standards for the crypto sector. The company aims to hire an auditor for its whole balance sheet, but big accountants are still learning about the sector's challenges, including price volatility. Binance has released a proof-of-reserves report, but a full audit remains elusive, and the company is working to separate collateral and customer funds, as well as produce an expanded proof-of-reserves statement.

images.alt_text: Crypto companies have had difficulties finding banking partners to facilitate the sending of money to buy and sell digital assets.

site_title: Glass waste destined for landfill finds new use on oil rigs
summary: Singapore-based SME Abraclean has established the country's first glass recycling facility, producing Abrablast, a glass abrasive material, to replace traditional metallic abrasives on oil rigs. The facility, launched in January, can process up to 50 tonnes of glass waste daily and has already processed 600-odd tonnes since July 2021. This initiative aims to reduce waste sent to landfills, with Abraclean processing up to 12,000 tonnes of glass waste annually, effectively preventing that amount from ending up in the landfill.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
TheSmartLocal’s regional push gets leg-up with acquisition of Malaysian tech firm

ITCAN chief executive officer Amit Sujan (centre, in blue suit) and IT managing director Sippy Sujan (centre, in red dress) attending a company event with employees. The Sujans see company culture as key to attracting and retaining talent.

site_title: After shouts of ‘liar’ and worse, Biden takes on his detractors in real time
summary: President Joe Biden's State of the Union address was marked by disruptions from Republican lawmakers, including Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene's shouted "liar" and "bullshit." However, Biden turned the tables on his opponents, engaging in real-time exchanges and appearing to relish the confrontations. The speech was seen as a start to his reelection campaign, with Biden emphasizing his commitment to various causes, including police reform and cancer research. Despite low approval ratings and flashing-red polling numbers, Biden appeared in control, using his experience and familiar phrasing to connect with the audience and push back against Republican criticism.

images.alt_text: The House chamber being prepped ahead of President Joe Biden’s State of the Union address, at Capitol Hill in Washington, Feb 7, 2023.

site_title: Services, transport ‘clear beneficiaries’ from reopening tailwinds; HRnet favoured: Maybank
summary: Maybank Securities predicts Singapore's economy will experience a "half-full" outlook in 2023, with sectors such as services, transport, and industrials showing greater expansion. The brokerage is bullish on companies like HRNet, Singtel, DBS, and CapitaLand Investment, citing strong competitive moats, potential for growth, and policy support. Key upside risks include restructuring efforts and rising ESG investments, while downside risks include a prolonged US or European recession and higher taxation. Maybank forecasts the Straits Times Index to reach S$3,629 over the 12-month period, with a price to earnings ratio of 13.9 times.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

Tourists visit the Grand Palace, one of the top tourist attraction spots as Thailand is expecting arrivals of Chinese tourists after China reopens its borders amid the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, in Bangkok, Thailand, January 7, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha
Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT)

site_title: COE premiums up for commercial vehicles and motorcycles in first tender under new quota
summary: The Singapore government's first tender under the increased quota for certificates of entitlement (COEs) has seen mixed results, with commercial vehicle and motorcycle premiums rising significantly. Commercial vehicle COE premiums increased by 10.4% to S$85,119, while motorcycle premiums rose 4.5% to S$11,602. In contrast, car and electric vehicle premiums remained unchanged. The Open COE premium dropped 1.9% to S$105,002. This marks the first tender under the increased quota announced in January 2023.

site_title: Uber eyes profits in 2023 as pandemic pain eases
summary: Uber aims to deliver profits in 2023, driven by a surge in airport and office ride demand and new products such as pre-booking and shared rides. The company reported a 49% revenue increase to $8.6 billion in Q4 2022, with ride-sharing revenue surging 82%. Uber forecasts adjusted Ebitda of $660-700 million for Q1 2023, beating analyst estimates. The company's active driver base reached an all-time high in Q4 2022 and continues to grow, alleviating concerns about a driver shortage.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 8, 2018 the Uber logo is seen at the second annual Uber Elevate Summit, at the Skirball Center in Los Angeles, California. - Uber is eyeing a valuation above $100 billion for its much-anticipated share offering due in 2019, which would be the biggest-ever in the tech sector, sources familiar with the plan said October 16, 2018.The sources told AFP the global ridesharing giant is considering speeding up its plans for an initial public offering (IPO) to the first half of 2019, rather than the second half of the year. (Photo by Robyn Beck / AFP)

site_title: Tencent plans Valorant gaming league in post-crackdown revival
summary: Tencent Holdings plans to launch a Valorant esports league in China, marking a revival of competitive online gaming after a two-year lull due to pandemic restrictions and government crackdowns. The league, set to debut in China this year, will help Tencent bolster its business, which has suffered from stricter online content scrutiny. The move follows Tencent's approval to roll out Valorant domestically in December, seen as a sign that the government is relaxing its grip on the gaming sector.

site_title: Death of the WTO is no ‘glass onion’ mystery
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) is withering, and its decline is largely due to the US's indifference towards the global trade architecture. The US, having driven for lower trade barriers since the 1930s, has convinced itself that trade is responsible for the plight of its workers. The US's decision to block the appointment of appellate judges for the WTO's dispute settlement system has significantly weakened the organization. China's aggressive posture and Russia's invasion of Ukraine have further eroded the US's commitment to the WTO. The US's approach to trade has been characterized as "sneering indifference," and its actions may lead to a new trade order without the WTO.

images.alt_text: The US Inflation Reduction Act provides a US$7,500 subsidy to US buyers of electric vehicles, provided they are both made in America and composed predominantly of American parts.
The US-led consultations with more than 70 countries over the past year involved 12 reform themes expected to result in concrete proposals, says Deputy US Trade Representative Maria Pagan.

site_title: NY Philharmonic lures LA’s star conductor Gustavo Dudamel
summary: Gustavo Dudamel, renowned Venezuelan conductor, has been appointed as the music and artistic director of the New York Philharmonic, starting in 2026. He will succeed Dutch conductor Jaap van Zweden and will lead the orchestra for five years. Dudamel, 42, has led the Los Angeles Philharmonic since 2009 and is known for his kinetic energy and work in promoting classical music in the Americas. His appointment is seen as a significant move, dealing a blow to the music world of Los Angeles.

images.alt_text: Shania Twain wants everyone to rejoice with her as the pandemic subsides.

site_title: China property player raises US$300 million in US dollar bond issue
summary: Wanda Properties Global, a unit of China's largest commercial property developer Wanda Group, raised US$300 million in a three-year US dollar bond issue with a 12.375% yield and 11% coupon. This is the company's second US dollar bond issue in a month, following a US$400 million sale in mid-January. The proceeds will be used to refinance WPG's existing debt, providing a rare bit of good news for China's high-yield bond market, which has struggled to emerge from a debt crisis.

images.alt_text: Screen displaying the Hang Seng stock index outside Hong Kong Exchanges, in Hong Kong. Hong Kong and China equities have rallied this year.
In a sign of how the record downturn has hurt bottom lines, defaulted developer Shimao Group Holdings’ main unit onshore is expected to record its first full-year loss in 21 years.

site_title: South Korea's parliament votes to impeach minister over Halloween crush
summary: South Korea's parliament voted to impeach interior minister Lee Sang-min over his responses to a deadly Halloween crush, which killed 159 people and injured 196. The motion was passed with a 179-109 margin, and the Constitutional Court will review the decision, which could take up to six months. Lee has apologized for the flawed responses but said he won't resign, citing his priority to prevent similar tragedies. The impeachment is seen as a renunciation of parliamentary democracy by President Yoon Suk-yeol's office, who rejected the opposition's demand for Lee's sack.

images.alt_text: Crime scene and forensic investigators at the site of a deadly crowd crush during Halloween festivities in the Itaewon district of Seoul, South Korea, on Monday, Oct. 31, 2022. The deadly surge of revelers in Seoul's Itaewon district on Saturday night hit citizens from at least 15 nations, prompting an outpouring of grief and offers of help from governments around the world.Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Dhaka throws an art party
summary: Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, has become a hub for hip cities, attracting international art enthusiasts with its Dhaka Art Summit, featuring over 140 artists, architects, and designers. The city also hosts exclusive dance parties, showcasing its vibrant nightlife. In other news, a Valentine's themed watch has been launched, and a new restaurant, Thevar 2.0, offers modern-Indian cuisine. Additionally, a charity event, NCSS, rallies partners to better engage volunteers, while CMC Markets partners with Sophia Women to drive financial literacy for women.

site_title: Northstar weighs sale of Singapore’s Innovalues in over S$500 million deal: sources
summary: Northstar Group, a Singapore-based private equity firm, is considering the sale of precision machine parts maker Innovalues in a potential deal valued over S$500 million. The firm, which acquired Innovalues in 2016, is exploring the sale with at least one adviser. This follows a surge in deal activities by private equity firms in South-east Asia, with the region's private equity deal value reaching an all-time record high of US$25 billion in 2021. A decision on the sale is yet to be made.

images.alt_text: Northstar Ventures I has a core focus on the consumer internet, financial technology and enterprise software sectors.

site_title: Jokowi threatens to fire police if haze engulfs Indonesia again
summary: Indonesian President Jokowi warned police to prevent large fires from engulfing the country due to the threat of El Nino, a dry weather pattern. He stated that local police chiefs would be held accountable and dismissed if fires occurred in their provinces. This warning comes amid concerns about intense dry seasons and haze, which has plagued the country in the past. Jokowi also emphasized the need to crack down on illegal mining to ensure the country's commodities exports are not disrupted.

site_title: Death toll from Syria-Turkey quake rises to more than 11,000
summary: A devastating earthquake in Turkey and Syria has resulted in over 11,000 deaths, with 13.5 million people affected across a 450km area. In Turkey, the death toll has risen to 8,574, while in Syria, it has climbed to over 2,612. Rescue efforts are being hindered by destroyed roads, poor weather, and a lack of resources, with aid officials warning of a significant increase in the death toll. Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan has declared a state of emergency in 10 provinces, but residents are expressing anger and despair at the slow response.

images.alt_text: Leading global container shipping group AP Moller Maersk said there had been significant damage to logistics and transport infrastructure around the earthquake epicentre, including at the Port of Iskenderun.
Aleppo's ancient citadel is damaged following a deadly earthquake that shook Syria.

site_title: India central bank hikes rates 25 bps as expected, hints at more tightening
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) hiked its key repo rate by 25 basis points as expected, but surprised markets by leaving the door open to further tightening. Core inflation remains high, prompting the central bank to maintain its focus on withdrawing accommodation. The decision marks the final increase in the RBI's current tightening cycle, which has raised rates by 250 basis points since May last year.

images.alt_text: The central bank’s commentary on inflation will also be closely watched, given China’s economic reopening could fuel demand and exert upward pressure on global commodity prices.

A man walks past the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai. India’s Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Feb 1 unveiled a 45 trillion rupees (S$715.1 billion) Budget for the next fiscal year starting April.

site_title: Straco to report ‘substantial net loss’ for FY2022
summary: Straco Corporation, which operates the Singapore Flyer, reported a "substantial net loss" for FY2022, down from the net profit recorded in FY2021. The decline in revenue from its China attractions, largely due to lockdowns and the zero-Covid policy, was a major contributor. Additionally, material exchange losses were incurred due to the weakened yuan against the Singapore dollar.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Flyer in Singapore's Marina Bay area had to close from Jan 16 to Apr 14 because of a technical issue, but this has since been resolved.

site_title: How Myanmar’s military hangs on to power despite sanctions
summary: Myanmar's military, which seized power in 2021, continues to maintain control despite international sanctions. Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi, the former leader, is expected to spend the rest of her life in jail after being convicted on various charges. The military has used brutal tactics to subdue its enemies, resulting in over 2,900 deaths and widespread instability. The US and its allies have imposed sanctions, but China and Russia have backed the regime, limiting the impact. The World Bank has warned that Myanmar's potential for inclusive growth has been severely weakened.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is the chair of the 10-member Association of South-east Asian Nations for 2023 and will host the bloc’s annual leaders’ meetings later this year.

A protester holds up a poster of Aung San Suu Kyi during a demonstration against the military coup in Yangon, Myanmar, Feb 15, 2021. Observers say planned polls by the junta cannot be free and fair under the present circumstances, with one analyst characterising it as a mere “performance” aimed at justifying the military’s hold on power.

site_title: Thai monetary tightening to be gradual but faces challenges: central bank minutes
summary: The Bank of Thailand's monetary policy committee has reaffirmed its pledge to gradually tighten monetary policy, but noted it may adjust its approach if the growth and inflation outlook shifts. The committee voted to raise the one-day repurchase rate by a quarter point to 1.50% to combat inflation. However, the minutes suggest that monetary policy will face greater challenges due to rising demand-side inflationary pressures and the need to support the recovery of fragile businesses and households. The committee must balance these competing priorities.

site_title: Japan financial regulator plans ‘action programme’ to boost shareholder engagement
summary: Japan's Financial Services Agency (FSA) plans to release an "action programme" in the first half of 2023 to boost shareholder engagement and enhance corporate governance. The programme aims to improve capital efficiency and promote effective dialogue between companies and investors. The move follows the Tokyo Stock Exchange's announcement to urge underperforming companies to improve capital efficiency. The FSA seeks to address the issue of companies trading below book value, with about half of listed companies still in this situation, and aims to translate corporate governance reforms into tangible improvements in corporate value.

images.alt_text: As inflation surges to its highest levels in four decades, Fumio Kishida has repeatedly urged business leaders to raise pay faster than prices.

site_title: Iron ore seesaws as traders weigh demand prospects in China
summary: Iron ore futures fluctuated on February 8 as traders reassessed demand prospects in top steel producer China. Prices briefly fell below $120 a tonne before rebounding to $121.10 a tonne. China's policy support for its ailing property sector and easing of Covid-19 restrictions boosted prices in January, but analysts expect iron ore prices to consolidate before seasonal demand kicks in. The real recovery in Chinese iron ore demand may occur in the second quarter, driven by the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A stacker unloads iron ore onto a pile at a mine located in the Pilbara region of Western Australia December 2, 2013. REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo/File Photo
The most-traded May iron ore contract on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange has ended daytime trading 2 per cent higher, at 873.50 yuan (S$169.90) per tonne.

site_title: Republicans will lose in a fight over the debt ceiling
summary: US President Joe Biden and Republican Speaker of the House Kevin McCarthy met at the White House to discuss the debt ceiling, with McCarthy insisting on major spending cuts in exchange for raising the limit. The negotiations are expected to continue, with the Treasury Department facing a June deadline of $31.4 trillion in debt. The Republicans' slim majority in the House leaves McCarthy with limited room to maneuver, and a recent poll shows Americans overwhelmingly reject the Republican plan to tie debt payment to spending cuts. If negotiations fail, a default could lead to a devastating economic recession and a political blowback for the Republicans.

images.alt_text: Georgieva warned that 60 per cent of low-income countries are at or near a debt crisis, and reiterated her call for China, the biggest creditor to emerging countries, to cooperate with multiparty debt restructuring talks.
A bus stop display showing the US national debt. A standoff between the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, President Joe Biden and Democratic legislators could lead to a fiscal crisis.

site_title: Union intervenes to stop security agency from demoting 300 officers to ‘reset’ their wages
summary: A security agency attempted to demote 300 officers to "reset" their wages, prompting the Union of Security Employees to intervene. The agency reversed its decision without naming it, but the union intervened and the agency agreed to work with the affected officers to establish remedial actions. The move comes as the Progressive Wage Model for the outsourced private security sector is set to shift from basic wages to gross monthly wages, exceeding the S$2,600 cap. The union will ensure that workers reap the benefits of the model and will not hesitate to take the agency to task for non-compliance.

images.alt_text: A MooVita autonomous vehicle seen on 30 November 2019. Local autonomous vehicle start-up MooVita is developing a software solution that transforms various vehicle types into autonomous vehicles for different driving conditions and applications.
Singapore’s aerospace industry is coping well with the increase in demand for MRO services, following the reopening of borders.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up but rate worries keep optimism in check
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday but optimism was tempered by Federal Reserve boss Jerome Powell's comments that inflation may require higher interest rates than expected to control. Despite recent data suggesting tighter monetary policy is paying off, a strong jobs report and Powell's warnings of further rate increases kept traders cautious. Markets are now awaiting the latest inflation report due next Tuesday, which could determine peak rate expectations and impact appetite for risky assets.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 64 to 53 after 47.7 million securities worth S$51.9 million changed hands on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: ‘King James’ claims throne as NBA’s all-time leading scorer
summary: LeBron James of the Los Angeles Lakers surpassed Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's record of 38,387 points to become the NBA's all-time leading scorer. James achieved this milestone with a fadeaway jumpshot in a home game against the Oklahoma City Thunder on February 7. The record-breaking shot sent the sold-out crowd into a frenzy, with Abdul-Jabbar, who previously held the record, applauding James from the stands. James became the new NBA all-time leading scorer, solidifying his legacy as "King James."

images.alt_text: LeBron James at Netflix's Los Angeles premiere of "Hustle" in Los Angeles last week. The sought-after trading card featuring him is the “Triple Logoman” card, a single-issue card that includes patches taken from jerseys he wore while with the Cleveland Cavaliers, Miami Heat and Los Angeles Lakers.

site_title: Swedish housing market activity slows as prices tick down
summary: Sweden's housing market activity has slowed, with house and apartment prices down 15% from their peak, following a 1% decline in January. This marks the 10th consecutive month of price declines, as falling activity is attributed to the end of ultra-low interest rates. The decline in home values has almost erased pandemic-era gains, making it one of the biggest residential real estate routs globally.

images.alt_text: Singapore will be one of the cities to get highest prime capital value growth in 2023.

site_title: Sri Lanka president seeks to reunite, revive bankrupt nation
summary: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe has outlined his plans for recovery from the country's worst economic crisis, aiming to secure a $2.9 billion IMF loan. The president has taken steps to curb sweeping powers and promote unity among political parties, but criticism remains over his alignment with the Rajapaksas and clampdown on protests. Wickremesinghe has called for a 13th amendment to the constitution, devolving powers to provinces, and has made efforts to unify approaches with China and other countries.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka's Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe gestures as he speaks during an interview with Reuters at his office in Colombo, Sri Lanka, May 24, 2022. REUTERS/Adnan Abidi

site_title: Philippines’ Marcos visits Japan seeking closer security ties
summary: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. visited Japan for the first time since taking office in July, seeking to deepen security ties with Tokyo. The visit comes after Marcos signed an agreement granting the US greater access to its military bases. Marcos and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida are expected to cooperate on disaster relief and potentially establish a broader legal framework for Japanese forces to deploy to the Philippines. The move is seen as a response to China's growing military presence in the region, and Japan's defense ministry has expressed interest in joining the US in the Philippines.

images.alt_text: The Philippine CPI rose 8.7 per cent in January, well above the 7.7 per cent forecast in a Reuters poll and topping the 8.1 per cent rate in December, when the central bank had expected prices to peak.

site_title: Coinbase manager pleads guilty to insider trading on tokens
summary: A former Coinbase manager, Ishan Wahi, pleaded guilty to insider trading on tokens, becoming the first person to be charged in the cryptocurrency space. Wahi admitted to conspiring with his brother and a friend to trade on confidential information about upcoming token listings, resulting in approximately $1.5 million in profits. He faces 36-47 months in prison and has a parallel case with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The case marks a significant development in regulating insider trading in the cryptocurrency industry.

images.alt_text: The suit alleges that Coinbase promoted the sale of the tokens by providing users with descriptions and their purported value.

site_title: Job redesign might just be the solution to Singapore’s talent crunch
summary: Singapore's talent crunch is partly addressed by exploring non-traditional talent segments, including digital nomads, and re-engaging the existing workforce through job redesign. Employers must provide flexible work arrangements and work-from-anywhere programmes to accommodate time differences, virtual workplaces, and more. A tripartite collaborative approach involving government, business, and population cooperation is crucial for successful change management. Job redesign is imperative to retain caregivers, attract non-traditional talent, and re-balance the workforce.

images.alt_text: people, girls, women

site_title: UK job recruiters see first increase in vacancies in 9 months
summary: The UK saw an increase in job vacancies for the first time in 9 months, according to a survey by the Recruitment and Employment Confederation and KPMG. Permanent staff hires fell for the fourth month, while temporary workers' billings increased slightly. This uptick in demand puts pressure on the Bank of England to control inflation, which has been a concern. The data suggests a potential for a shallower economic downturn than expected, and the government is urged to address labor market issues and economic inactivity to support growth.

images.alt_text: Since entering Downing Street in October, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has been under pressure to stamp his authority not only on his government but also over his party.

site_title: Maersk expects 2023 profits to plummet as volumes, freight rates fall
summary: Maersk, the world's second-largest container fleet, reported fourth-quarter earnings slightly below expectations, with forecasted 2023 core profit significantly lower than last year's due to falling volumes and freight rates. The company expects earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) of $8-11 billion, down from $36.8 billion in 2022. Maersk aims to become an integrated logistics provider connecting land, sea, and air, with inventory correction expected to be complete by the end of the first half of 2023.

images.alt_text: The lessons from all the disruptions since 2020 have underscored how the term “supply chain” itself is something of a misnomer, because it suggests that global trade is seamless and unbreakable.
Maersk has cut its outlook for global container demand, now seeing it down by 2 per cent to 4 per cent this year.
US consumers are not buying as much as they did during the pandemic, and confidence has been hurt by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.
The news from MSC comes as container shippers confront a downturn as weaker demand pushes prices to their lowest in more than 2 years.
China’s economic slowdown is also cutting into import demand, with companies in Asia and Europe seeing weaker growth or declines in orders from Chinese companies.
THE world’s biggest container lines are on course to post profits in 2022 that will top last year’s record by 73 per cent

Maersk, which controls about one-sixth of the world’s container trade, earlier this week raised its 2022 profit forecast to a record US$31 billion as bottlenecks in key trade lanes continue to boost rates.

site_title: Apple expands testing of ‘buy now, pay later’ service to retail employees
summary: Apple has expanded its internal test of the "buy now, pay later" service, Apple Pay Later, to thousands of retail employees. The service allows shoppers to split purchases into instalments without interest or fees. The test comes after the service was delayed from its initial 2022 release and technical challenges. Apple has used a similar rollout strategy for past financial products, and the service is expected to launch soon.

images.alt_text: The discounting emerged around the end of the Chinese New Year season when retailers gear up for a holiday shopping spree before schools reopen.
Apple said iPhone sales were US$65.8 billion, down 8 per cent from the year before and below analyst estimates of US$68.3 billion.

site_title: UK plans £20,000 ‘Britcoin’ limit for individuals holdings digital pounds
summary: The UK plans to impose a £10,000 to £20,000 limit on individuals holding digital pounds, dubbed "Britcoin," once the currency comes into existence. The measure aims to prevent money draining out of traditional bank accounts and is part of the Bank of England's efforts to introduce a central bank digital currency. The digital pound would be backed by the government, similar to physical cash, and would work like cash but without accruing interest or becoming a tool for speculators. The limit is subject to a consultation until June.

images.alt_text: The moves are part of an effort by central banks around the world to adapt to new forms of payment that work more quickly and smoothly in online transactions.

site_title: Volkswagen boosts earnings in 2022, high inventory drags down cash flow
summary: Volkswagen's earnings margin reached 8.1% in 2022, above its forecast, with sales and earnings surpassing 2021 levels despite supply chain disruptions. Deliveries were the lowest in over a decade due to Covid-19 lockdowns in China and the war in Ukraine. Despite this, the company reported 22.5 billion euros in earnings and 279 billion euros in sales. However, net cash flow fell short of target, totaling around 5 billion euros, due to high inventory levels and unstable supply chains. The company expects this to reverse in 2023.

images.alt_text: Hyundai and Kia, its affiliate, rank as the world's third-largest carmaker.
Toyota remains the world's top-selling automaker for a third straight year with 10.5 million vehicles sold in 2022.
Lotus plans to start production of its first electric SUV by the end of this year.

site_title: Hot stock: StarHub declines as much as 8.1% after profit falls
summary: StarHub's share price declined as much as 8.1% after the company reported a 98.4% year-on-year drop in net profit to S$1.3 million for the second half of 2022, despite higher revenue. The decline was attributed to lower profit from operations and higher operational expenses due to the company's Dare+ transformation initiative. Analysts Maybank and Citi downgraded StarHub to "hold" and "neutral" respectively, citing delayed earnings recovery and higher transformation costs, with Maybank lowering its target price to S$1.15.

images.alt_text: Excluding Dare+ provisions, non-operating items and its corresponding tax effects, StarHub's net profit after tax would have fallen by 34.6 per cent to S$53.2 million in the second half of the year.

site_title: Japan PM to ratchet up wage hike push with business, labour talks
summary: Japan Prime Minister Fumio Kishida plans to revive three-way talks between the government, business leaders, and labor unions to push for faster wage hikes amid surging inflation. The talks, last held in 2015, aim to encourage companies to increase pay, particularly for small and medium-sized firms. The move comes as Japan's wages rose at their fastest pace since 1997 in December, and the government seeks to address the impact of inflation on household finances. The talks may influence the Bank of Japan's policy after its governor steps down in April.

images.alt_text: Fumio Kishida has repeatedly urged business leaders to raise pay faster than prices so that people’s real spending power increases.

site_title: Malaysia weighs trade curbs to fight EU’s anti-palm oil policies
summary: Malaysia is considering trade curbs in response to the European Union's (EU) new law, which bans products causing forest destruction from being sold in European shops and supermarkets. The EU's policy is seen as discriminatory, affecting millions of small farmers across the region. Malaysia and Indonesia, the world's second- and largest edible oils suppliers, will coordinate their response, with Deputy Prime Minister Fadillah Yusof stating that counteraction may be necessary if the EU does not "fairly treat" them. The two countries will discuss strategies, including slowing commodities trade with Europe and reviewing imports from the bloc.

images.alt_text: Indonesia, the world’s top palm oil exporter, issues export quotas for palm oil companies which have sold a proportion of their products to the domestic market, under a policy known as “Domestic Market Obligation” (DMO).
Surging domestic prices forced the government to suspend palm oil exports temporarily last April, causing turmoil on global and local markets, something Jakarta would not want to repeat.

site_title: Meituan dives after hiring 10,000 to fight ByteDance incursion
summary: Meituan, a Chinese food delivery giant, has hired up to 10,000 people in an effort to fend off a challenge from ByteDance, owner of TikTok. The move comes as ByteDance expands its delivery services nationwide, including a grocery and food delivery service in several Chinese cities. Meituan's recruitment drive contrasts with layoffs in the tech industry, and is expected to benefit from China's reopening and economic activity. The competition between Meituan and Douyin, ByteDance's delivery service, could lead to a battle for control of the market.

images.alt_text: The job cuts represent a small percentage of ByteDance’s workforce, the report said.
Meituan, whose services also include restaurant reviews and bike-sharing, said total revenue rose to 62.62 billion yuan (S$12 billion) in the three months ended September.

site_title: Gold ticks up as dollar eases after Powell’s comments
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,876.14 per ounce, following a weaker US dollar after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell did not signal a more hawkish stance on interest rates. Powell acknowledged that inflation may require higher interest rates, but did not specify the level. The dollar index fell 0.2%, making gold less expensive for buyers holding other currencies. The US trade deficit widened in December, and China's gold holdings rose to 65.12 million ounces.

images.alt_text: Gold is sensitive to high interest rates, which lift the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: US-China goods trade hits record even as political split widens
summary: The US and China reached a record merchandise trade of $690.6 billion in 2022, despite a widening split between the two nations. The annual goods-trade deficit with China increased 8% to $382.9 billion, the largest on record. Washington is pushing to curb China's access to sensitive semiconductor technology and encouraging Western companies to invest in trusted trading partners, such as India. The Biden administration has maintained tariffs imposed under President Trump, but hundreds of US businesses have urged their removal due to inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: US sailors recover remnants of a high-altitude surveillance balloon off the coast of Myrtle Beach, South Carolina, Feb 7, 2023.
Imports increased 1.3 per cent to US$317.6 billion, with goods rising 1.8 per cent to US$258.8 billion.

site_title: Bankman-Fried opposes public disclosure of bail guarantors
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried is challenging a federal judge's order to make public the identities of two people who helped secure his $250 million bail package. The two unidentified people signed on as sureties for separate bonds of $500,000 and $200,000. Bankman-Fried's attorneys argue that revealing their identities would subject them to media scrutiny and potential harassment. The judge granted media applications to unseal their names last month, but Bankman-Fried has appealed the decision.

site_title: Australia faces housing crunch as population growth accelerates
summary: Australia is facing a housing supply crunch driven by a rapidly growing population, with over 80% of Australians surveyed citing a lack of affordable housing. Median home prices in Sydney have slipped below A$1 million, and rents are expected to surge further due to a lack of new supply. The government has proposed solutions, including a A$10 billion Housing Australia Future Fund, but experts say more needs to be done to address the issue, with Property Council of Australia chief executive Mike Zorbas calling for "meaningful change" to provide more housing options.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of Australia lifted borrowing costs by 25 basis points to 3.35 per cent.

site_title: Credit Suisse dials back Asia risk controls after bankers revolt
summary: Credit Suisse has relaxed some of its anti-money laundering controls in Asia after protests from clients and bankers, who felt the measures were too stringent and hindered their ability to attract new clients. The bank had implemented stricter controls in 2021, including a requirement for private bankers to verify most clients' sources of wealth, but these were eased in December 2022. The backtracking highlights the delicate balance facing Credit Suisse, which is trying to tighten operations while retaining clients in a fast-growing region. The move is seen as a response to staff departures and client outflows, which contributed to a quarterly loss for the embattled bank.

images.alt_text: The bank is seeking to cling on to talent contending with a restructuring of its Wall Street operations after a period of scandals and losses sparked a tide of departures
Staff inside Credit Suisse’s investment-banking arm have contended with uncertainty amid the Zurich-based lender’s plans to merge those operations with rainmaker Michael Klein’s advisory boutique.
The affected clients in the Credit Suisse data leak include drug barons and kleptocrats, holding more than US$100 billion with the bank in total.

site_title: No new variants in weeks after China ended zero-Covid: study
summary: A new study by Chinese researchers found no evidence of novel Covid-19 variants emerging in Beijing after China ended its zero-Covid policy in late 2022. The study analyzed 413 samples from November 14 to December 20 and found that Omicron subvariants BF.7 and BA5.2 were responsible for the majority of cases, with BF.7 accounting for 75% of the samples. The study's findings contradict concerns that China's lifting of pandemic measures would lead to the emergence of new, more transmissible or severe strains.

images.alt_text: The city — in cooperation with mainland exchanges — is changing rules to allow China’s retail investors to buy shares of overseas-based companies listed on the local bourse for the first time.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Lendlease Reit, StarHub, HPH Trust, F&N, UOI
summary: Lendlease Reit's DPU rose 2.1% to S$0.0245 in H1 FY2023, up from S$0.024. The company's distributable income and gross revenue also increased. StarHub posted a 98.4% decline in net profit to S$1.3 million in the second half of 2022.

images.alt_text: The local benchmark Straits Times Index fell 0.2 per cent or 5.09 points to end the trading session at 3,380.84.

site_title: Intel sells US$11 billion of bonds days after debt downgrades
summary: Intel sold $11 billion in bonds to refinance debt and fund capital expenditures after a series of rating downgrades. The 40-year notes yielded 215 basis points over Treasuries, attracting strong demand from investors. Despite recent downgrades, Intel's deal reflects investor confidence in favorable market conditions. The company aims to use the funds for working capital, debt refinancing, and general corporate purposes. Intel's debt load is expected to remain elevated due to capital spending and dividend payments.

images.alt_text: Intel last week said its profit margins were plunging as the PC market cools after several years of growth during the pandemic.

site_title: UK’s Royal Mail unveils first King Charles stamps
summary: Royal Mail has unveiled its first postage stamps featuring King Charles III's image, following his ascension to the throne last September. The "definitive stamp" will go on sale from April 4 and features Charles' head, value, and barcode. The image is adapted from the official effigy on new UK coins. The stamps are intended for everyday use and were approved by Charles himself.

images.alt_text: Royal Mail will be resuming its International Tracked and Signed, and International Signed services to all destinations for business account customers and customers buying postage online from Jan 26.

site_title: Ebay to lay off 500 employees
summary: eBay plans to lay off 500 employees globally, representing 4% of its workforce, to create space for investments in high-potential areas. The move follows a trend of US companies, including Goldman Sachs and Alphabet, cutting thousands of jobs due to high inflation and rising interest rates. eBay shares rose 1% in aftermarket trade after the announcement. CEO Jamie Iannone stated that the shift will allow for investments in new technologies, customer innovations, and key markets.

site_title: Tencent co-founder joins funding for Chinese air taxi startup
summary: Chinese electric aircraft startup TCab Tech raised 100 million yuan (S$19.5 million) in funding to develop and build its contender for the electric vertical takeoff and landing aircraft market. The funding round was led by Grand Flight Investment and included participation from Decent Capital, the family office of Tencent Holdings co-founder Jason Zeng. TCab plans a maiden flight for its prototype in 2023 and aims to commercialize manned eVTOLs to develop a comprehensive three-dimensional transportation system in China.

images.alt_text: The eVTOL aircraft have been touted as air taxis that could be the future of urban air mobility.

site_title: Optimistic Biden to try to lift Americans with State of the Union speech
summary: President Joe Biden is set to deliver an optimistic State of the Union address, highlighting the economy's recovery and his administration's achievements. Despite polls showing widespread doubts, Biden aims to demonstrate his ability to seek reelection. The speech will focus on unity, economic growth, and infrastructure development, with proposals including a "billionaire tax" and a new infrastructure building splurge. Biden will engage with the American people and call for unity, but faces opposition from Republicans who vow to block his policies, including a potential debt ceiling crisis.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden announces his plan to send M1 Abrams tanks to Ukraine, Jan 25, 2023.
In an AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research poll, a paltry 37 percent of respondents said they back Joe Biden running for a second term, which would end when he was 86 years old.
A bus stop display showing the US national debt. A standoff between the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, President Joe Biden and Democratic legislators could lead to a fiscal crisis.

site_title: 5 Questions with quantum scientist Dr Tan Si-Hui
summary: Dr. Tan Si-Hui, chief science officer of Singapore's Horizon Quantum Computing, discusses quantum computing and its potential to revolutionize computing. She explains that quantum computers can solve problems that would take current machines 10,000 years to crack. Dr. Tan Si-Hui shares her experience transitioning from academia to the startup world, highlighting the importance of collaboration and equal access to programs for all students to address systemic biases against women in STEM. She emphasizes that anyone, regardless of their background or education, can contribute to the quantum industry, and Horizon is actively seeking professionals from various disciplines to join their team.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Quantum computers and related technologies – such as quantum sensing and cryptography – could revolutionise everyday life.

site_title: Retail investors flock to small-cap AI firms as Big Tech battles for share
summary: Retail investors are flocking to small-cap AI firms, such as C3.ai and SoundHound AI, amid intense competition between tech giants Google and Microsoft for AI leadership. The viral success of ChatGPT has sparked interest, with shares of these firms surging 140% and 200% respectively this year. Analysts attribute the trend to small-cap firms' larger AI focus, while Microsoft's partnership with OpenAI and Azure capabilities are seen as key advantages in the AI race.

images.alt_text: Baidu has diversified in recent years into artificial intelligence, cloud computing and autonomous driving technologies as advertising revenue has remained sluggish in the face of tighter regulatory scrutiny.
Google said it will soon release an experimental chatbot called Bard as it races to respond to ChatGPT, which has wowed millions of people since it was unveiled at the end of November.
Microsoft has been preparing to add ChatGPT to Bing to offer better, more precise answers to queries, rather than a list of links.

The OpenAI website ChatGPT about page on laptop computer arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 12, 2023. Microsoft Corp. is in discussions to invest as much as $10 billion in OpenAI, the creator of viral artificial intelligence bot ChatGPT, according to people familiar with its plans. Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: Zoom Video to cut 1,300 jobs, or 15% of global workforce
summary: Zoom Video Communications is cutting 15% of its workforce, approximately 1,300 jobs, as part of a restructuring effort to reverse slowing growth. CEO Eric Yuan acknowledged the company's issues and vowed to reduce his salary and forgo his bonus. The move comes after the company's user base tripled in two years during the pandemic, but Yuan stated the company didn't thoroughly analyze its teams or assess sustainable growth.

images.alt_text: Zoom is fighting to reverse a slowdown in growth for its video communications service by expanding its tools for business.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 open lower ahead of Powell comments
summary: The US stock market opened lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones falling 121.24 points, or 0.36%, to 33,769.78. The S&P 500 also declined, opening 5.73 points, or 0.14%, at 4,105.35. Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks for guidance on interest rate hikes, with expectations that rates may be reduced in the near future.

site_title: China refused call with Pentagon chief on day of balloon downing: US
summary: China has declined a request for a secure call between US Pentagon chief Lloyd Austin and Chinese Minister of National Defence Wei Fenghe, amid tensions over a downed surveillance balloon. The US had requested the call on February 4, following the downing of the suspected Chinese spy balloon. China claims the balloon was a weather observation aircraft, while the US describes it as a sophisticated spying vehicle. The US commitment to open communication remains unchanged.

site_title: Hong Kong targets prized Aramco listing with Xi’s backing
summary: Hong Kong is changing rules to allow Chinese retail investors to buy shares of overseas-based companies listed on its local bourse for the first time. The move is seen as a bid to attract Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil company, to list in the city. Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Saudi Arabia two months ago sparked the effort, with Hong Kong's leader John Lee seeking to persuade Aramco to list in the financial hub. A successful listing would add diversity to the China-dominated bourse and deepen ties between China and the Gulf.

images.alt_text: Lee is kicking off a campaign to attract new investment to Hong Kong following almost three years of pandemic isolation.

site_title: Goldman Sachs raises US$5.2 billion for private equity growth fund
summary: Goldman Sachs has raised $5.2 billion for its private equity growth fund, West Street Global Growth Partners I, exceeding its initial target. The fund, which targets enterprise, financial technology, healthcare, and consumer sectors, received $3.7 billion from institutional and high net worth investors. The move marks the largest first-time growth equity fund in history, surpassing Blackstone's $4.5 billion two years ago. The fund will invest in early to mid-stage businesses with a $50 million average investment threshold, and Goldman's team will seek minority stakes in these companies.

images.alt_text: The investment in Verdalia follows Goldman’s formation of the Japan Renewable Energy business amid a shift in the country’s energy policy after the Fukushima nuclear disaster.

site_title: HDB BTO oversupply not the answer to home affordability: Desmond Lee
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee stated that an oversupply of Build-To-Order (BTO) flats is not the solution to keeping public housing affordable. He cited the 1997 Asian financial crisis, where 31,000 unsold flats took over five years to clear, resulting in homeowners paying heavily and facing negative equity. The Government has instead ramped up BTO supply, with almost 100 projects running simultaneously, and aims to have 150 projects by 2025. Lee emphasized that the current approach will continue to increase supply, rather than relying on oversupply to address affordability.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Generic photo of Toa Payoh HDB estate covered in mist on a rainy day on January 25, 2023. 
Can be used for property, low visibility, rain, weather, climate stories.
Sound reasons exist for some buyers to pay over a million dollars each for certain HDB resale flats.
Sliding home values threaten to undermine consumer confidence and weigh on household spending, which had been a rare bright spot for the global economy last year.

site_title: Credit Suisse tells some bankers bonuses will be in instalments
summary: Credit Suisse is offering some junior and mid-level bankers their bonuses in instalments, amid a restructuring of its Wall Street operations following scandals and losses that led to a tide of departures. The bank has delayed compensation for some investment bankers and will pay out bonuses in three instalments, approximately 40 days after April 1, July 1, and October 1. This move aims to retain talent as the bank prepares to merge its investment-banking arm with Michael Klein's advisory boutique.

site_title: China reopening: Singapore businesses in country hit by Covid surge but remain optimistic
summary: China's reopening from its zero-Covid approach has led to a surge in Covid-19 cases, shuttering retail outlets and factory lines, but businesses are cautiously optimistic as the wave subsides. Furniture retailer Commune and restaurant operator Jumbo Group experienced acute labour shortages, while metal stamping specialist Patec and manufacturing company Akribis Systems saw a swift recovery after workers recovered from the virus. Despite disruptions, cost pressures have eased, and businesses expect fewer snap lockdowns in 2023, with some competitors winding up.

images.alt_text: Travelers in the departure hall at the Hongqiao Railway Station in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, Jan. 19, 2023. With China's 296 million migrant workers on the move this year, factories and local governments are bracing for disruptions during a longer-than-usual holiday period. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

The scale of infection suggested by the official estimates underscores the challenge China faces after it abruptly pivoted from the Covid Zero regime that largely kept the virus at bay for the past three years.

site_title: Fakery and fraud: Scammers cast ‘wide net’ on Facebook
summary: Scammers on Facebook are casting a wide net, preying on social media users amid a cost of living crisis and high utility costs. Energy-related scams, such as fake solar panel incentives and hoax electric bike giveaways, are proliferating on the platform. Victims, like Brenilyn Ayachock in the Philippines, have reported receiving faulty products, including a power bank filled with sand, after making purchases from suspicious Facebook pages. Critics say social media platforms' lax vetting of ads and algorithms prioritizing content based on preferences have let scam ads prey on users, and Meta has taken action to disable ad accounts responsible for reported scams.

images.alt_text: This illustration photo taken on February 6, 2023 shows a phone screen displaying a video about a Filipino woman finding sand in her power bank. - AFP’s fact checkers have recently uncovered a slew of energy-related scams that have proliferated on Facebook – from fake incentives for solar panels in the United States to hoax electric bike giveaways in Indonesia and the sale of dud “power saving” devices in the Philippines. And the trend underscores how fraudsters worldwide profit off disinformation, casting a wide net across social media users, many of whom take the bait amid a cost of living crisis and high utility and energy costs. (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP)
A AFP journalist watches a video manipulated with artificial intelligence to potentially deceive viewers, or "deepfake" at his desk in Washington, DC, Jan 25, 2019.
SMSes is weak as an authentication factor, and users should be prepared to accept some inconveniences in exchange for stronger protections for their online accounts.

site_title: Ford works council in Germany to update staff on job cut talks on Feb 14
summary: The Ford Motor works council in Cologne, Germany, invited workers to a meeting on February 14 to discuss job cuts at the company's European plants. Up to 3,200 roles may be lost in the worst-case scenario, according to a union representative. The decision will be made by mid-February. Ford aims to improve its quality and cost structure in Europe and the US, according to CEO Jim Farley.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Wednesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,376.24 in early trade on Wednesday, following gains in US and European markets. Gainers outnumbered losers 64 to 53, with Shen Yao and Thai Beverage being the most actively traded stocks. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC gained 0.5%, 0.2%, and 0.1% respectively. The decline follows positive market movements in the US and Europe, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8% and the S&P 500 climbed 1.3%.

images.alt_text: Lendlease Reit's DPU rises 2.1 per cent to S$0.0245 from S$0.024 in H1 FY2023.

site_title: ‘Unfair’ EU carbon tariff could spur Asia to develop separate pricing schemes: ADB chief economist
summary: The Asian Development Bank's chief economist, Albert Park, warns that the European Union's upcoming carbon tariff on imports could spur Asia to develop separate pricing schemes. The tariff, part of the EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM), could be "unfair" for Asian exporters, potentially leading to "carbon leakage" if manufacturers move to countries with less strict environmental policies. Park suggests that countries adopting carbon pricing should channel tax revenue back to poorer countries to improve their carbon efficiency, rather than keeping the funds.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
ADB's analysis found that the effect of new environmental elements in bilateral investment treaties is “positive and significant” for total FDI and green FDI.
Degrowth pushes for the downscaling of harmful industries and the flourishing of helpful ones that address social needs, justice, care and sustainability, its proponents say.

site_title: BT Future of Finance: Sticking to your guns in uncertain times (Ep 6)
summary: Michele Ferrario, CEO of StashAway, emphasizes that running one's life and finances is similar to running a business, requiring strategic planning and management. The conversation touches on the impact of macroeconomic uncertainty on budgets and personal finance, with Ferrario advocating for a goals-based approach to planning and investment. She also stresses the importance of separating personal finance from commercial information and managing life like a business.

site_title: Decoupling, Taiwan-style
summary: Taiwan, a key player in the global semiconductor industry, is navigating the complexities of its relationship with China amidst rising tensions. The US has pushed for decoupling, mandating restrictions on chip sales to China, but Taiwanese businesses are diversifying and de-risking reliance on China. Despite the tensions, most Taiwanese are less alarmist about conflict, with opinion polls showing less than 25% concerned about war. The Tsai administration is seeking to balance ties with the US and Europe while maintaining economic ties with China, reflecting a nuanced approach to the issue.

images.alt_text: While Taiwan’s assisted local chipmakers in the past with infrastructure construction and other measures, the island is now stepping up its efforts.
On Oct 7, the US Department of Commerce's Bureau of Industry and Security announced major controls on exports to China of advanced semiconductors, chip-making equipment and supercomputer components.
The US-China contest will accelerate in the coming decades and become the biggest challenge for Singapore companies.

site_title: Sustainable financing must make commercial sense for investors, market players say
summary: Financial institutions prioritize commercial viability when investing in green or sustainability-related projects, despite potential environmental or social benefits. To justify investments, corporates must demonstrate how they can generate continued financial returns, according to Srikanya Yathip and Eric Lim, experts in sustainable finance. Compromising short-term financial returns for long-term social and green returns is acceptable, but regulatory stability, technology maturity, and corporate track records are key assessment criteria.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Doubts around the ability of indexes to address serious environmental and social issues coincide with a growing sense of urgency to come up with genuine ESG investing solutions.

investors are asking ESG-related questions relating to businesses – referring to sustainability ratings and metrics when assessing an organisation’s suitability for inclusion in their investment portfolios.

site_title: Microsoft unveils Bing search engine using OpenAI technology
summary: Microsoft has unveiled a new version of its Bing search engine, powered by OpenAI technology, aiming to compete with Google's dominant search market. The new Bing can be switched to chat mode, allowing users to compose emails and summarize web pages. The search engine can also provide contextual answers with citations to sources, addressing concerns about misinformation. Microsoft's investment in OpenAI has accelerated its efforts to integrate AI technology into its products, including Office and security software. The new Bing is available now as a preview, with full access expected to expand to millions in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: A “recent change” led to the issue and the company was working to restart portions of the affected infrastructure in order to restore service, Microsoft said in a tweet.
Microsoft has been preparing to add ChatGPT to Bing to offer better, more precise answers to queries, rather than a list of links.

site_title: Big move for US dollar not a given in the next three months
summary: The US dollar's recent recovery may not signal a long-term trend, with forex strategists divided on its path in the next few months. Markets expect the federal funds rate to peak above 5.1% by July, but volatility is expected to dominate currency markets. Analysts are split on the dollar's risk, with some predicting it could weaken over the next 12 months, while others see potential for a short-term gain. The euro is forecast to strengthen, while the Japanese yen is expected to rise against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the performance of the greenback against a basket of six other currencies, has edged up 0.1 per cent to 103.68.
The yuan rose 2.2 per cent against the US dollar in Jan, while the US dollar last month fell 1.4 per cent against a basket of other major currencies.

site_title: ION brings clients back online after ransomware attack
summary: ION, a financial trading services group, has started to bring clients back online after a ransomware attack last week, which disrupted major banks, brokerages, and hedge funds. The attack, claimed by hacking group Lockbit, halted trading and settlement processes for exchange-traded derivatives. The Futures Industry Association reported that the situation is improving, with exchanges offering extensions to meet clearing and reporting deadlines. Despite some delays, markets appear to be functioning normally, with the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission delaying publication of weekly trading statistics due to affected clients' inability to compile reports.

images.alt_text: Ransomware works by encrypting vital company data and extorting the victims for payoffs in exchange for the decryption keys.

site_title: The Tiktok “threat” to US national security
summary: The US House of Representatives has established a select committee to investigate allegations that TikTok, a popular Chinese-owned social media app, is used as a tool of foreign espionage and influence by the Chinese government, targeting its 100 million American users. The committee, chaired by Representative Mike Gallagher, aims to investigate data security issues and potential propaganda use. Despite concerns from lawmakers, TikTok has taken steps to address US security concerns, and a "mitigation agreement" could be reached, potentially allowing the app to operate with greater oversight. The issue highlights the growing tensions between the US and China.

images.alt_text: TikTok’s presentation “Protecting US National Security Interests” - which has been viewed by Reuters – offers a detailed look at the app’s efforts to demonstrate the data security for TikTok’s more than 100 million US users.
TikTok said “calls for total bans of TikTok take a piecemeal approach to national security and a piecemeal approach to broad industry issues like data security, privacy, and online harms”.

site_title: Morgan Stanley names Ong, Aronovitch to lead South-east Asia
summary: Morgan Stanley has appointed Ronald Ong as chairman of South-east Asia and David Aronovitch as chief executive officer, overseeing investment banking and other businesses in the region. Ong, who joined Morgan Stanley in 1995, has led the bank's South-east Asia franchise since 2004. Aronovitch, who started as an analyst in 1998, previously served as global co-head and head of Asia Pacific consumer retail investment banking. The appointments aim to boost Morgan Stanley's presence in the region.

site_title: HSBC says the 'headwinds are ahead' for UK mortgage holders
summary: HSBC UK CEO Ian Stuart warned that "headwinds are ahead" for UK mortgage holders, with approximately 222,000 customers expected to refinance loans this year, likely facing higher costs due to the cost of living crisis. This contradicts reassurances from other bank executives. Stuart's comments were made during a hearing of lawmakers, emphasizing the need for a health warning about customers' finances.

images.alt_text: Bank-to-business lending is also facing a reversal of fortunes.

site_title: Oil surges over 3% as Federal Reserve’s Powell eases rate hike concerns
summary: Oil prices surged over 3% on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures rising US$2.52 to US$83.51 a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate US crude futures rising US$2.77 to US$76.88 per barrel. The surge was driven by easing concerns over interest rate hikes by US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, as well as forecasted stronger demand in China. Saudi Arabia also raised oil prices for Asian buyers, citing expectations of demand recovery, particularly from China.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for April delivery rose US$1.05, or 1.3 per cent, to US$80.99 a barrel, after trading between US$79.10 and US$81.25.

site_title: Russian central bank sees record 5.25 trillion roubles deposit auction as budget deficit widens
summary: The Bank of Russia raised a record 5.25 trillion roubles at a one-week deposit auction on February 7, amid a widening budget deficit and excess liquidity in the banking sector. The auction saw nearly 250 banks participate, the highest number since August 2020. Analysts attribute the surge in spending to Russia's slumping energy revenues and soaring expenditure, which may limit the central bank's room to ease monetary policy. Experts predict the budget deficit could reach 6.5 trillion roubles, prompting potential tighter monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The move against aluminium also continues efforts by the US and European Union to blunt Russia’s role as global commodities powerhouse.

site_title: Europe: Shares gain on earnings boost, focus on Powell comments
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 closed 0.2% higher on Tuesday, driven by upbeat earnings reports from BP and BNP Paribas. However, investors remain cautious about interest rates staying higher for longer, awaiting comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. The energy index rose 3.0%, while industrial shares and consumer staples firms like Nestle and Unilever limited the upside. Policymakers, including Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic, have expressed a need for higher interest rates to combat inflation, leading to a cautious market outlook.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8 per cent to 34,156.69 on Tuesday.
The local benchmark Straits Times Index fell 0.2 per cent or 5.09 points to end the trading session at 3,380.84.

site_title: How to set your stocks up for success in 2023 and beyond
summary: Investors can set their stocks up for success in 2023 and beyond by adopting a disciplined approach, similar to Roald Amundsen's steady pace in reaching the South Pole. Former hedge fund manager Michael Steinhardt's tactic of liquidating stocks and starting anew can help investors reset their portfolios and identify areas for improvement. By reviewing past decisions, documenting thoughts, and focusing on processes rather than outcomes, investors can gain clarity and make informed decisions. This introspective approach allows investors to learn from past errors and apply lessons to future investments.

images.alt_text: More than half of job applicants on LinkedIn target remote work, in a reminder that innovation and digital tools gained prominence during the pandemic and are here to stay.
In 2022, the S&P 500 clocked in with its worst performance since 2008, an abnormality in the context of history.

site_title: GuocoLand’s aim at more modest tenants for Beach Rd project could optimise recurring income
summary: GuocoLand's office tower in Guoco Midtown has received its Temporary Occupation Permit and has secured 80% pre-commitment of its office space, despite not having a dominant anchor tenant. The diverse mix of tenants, including Pacific International Lines and BASF, reduces tenant concentration risk and mirrors GuocoLand's strategy for the Guoco Tower project. This approach is expected to optimize recurring income, as super anchors typically ask for rental discounts and try to negotiate for rights to give up space. The weighted average office rental rate is expected to be higher due to this strategy, which may benefit GuocoLand's investment property portfolio.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) along the Singapore River on Oct 29, 2022.

Guoco Midtown has injected 709,000 sq ft of new premium Grade A office space in the Downtown Core business district as its 30-storey office tower achieved its Temporary Occupation Permit.
The Singapore office market has swung from exuberance to caution in the course of 2022.
GuocoLand, whose projects include Midtown Modern (pictured in artist's impression), benefitted from a strong property market and tourism revival.

site_title: German media giant RTL Group to axe 500 jobs
summary: German media giant RTL Group is cutting 500 jobs and eliminating about 20 magazines in Germany due to the ongoing print media crisis and rising costs.
