The jobs will be lost in Hamburg, affecting 7,500 employees. The company plans to reorganize its portfolio, concentrating on flagship titles representing 70% of current sales. This move aims to reduce costs and adapt to the changing media landscape.

site_title: StarHub H2 net profit falls 98% on higher operating expenses, one-off impairment losses
summary: StarHub's net profit for the second half of 2022 fell 98.4% to S$1.3 million, despite a 18.7% increase in revenue to S$1.3 billion. The decline was attributed to lower profit from operations, including provisions for the company's Dare+ transformation initiatives, which include establishing a 5G network. Excluding these provisions, the net profit after tax would have fallen by 34.6%.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
StarHub leapt 38 spots and is ranked 34th on Corporate Knight's Global 100 rankings this year.
While Singtel and StarHub both have very substantial and profitable consumer operations, margins on consumer services have been hit as a result of stiff competition.
CGS-CIMB and DGS note that the telco will see an uptick in costs for the broadcast rights to the English Premier League (EPL), which it won in February this year.

site_title: Adani crisis unlikely to pose credit risk for Indian banks: rating agencies
summary: Indian banks' exposure to Adani Group is deemed insufficient to pose a credit risk, according to Fitch and Moody's rating agencies. The exposure accounts for 0.8-1.2% of total lending for Indian banks, equivalent to 7-13% of total equity. State Bank of India's exposure is "well-manageable" due to its strong provision reserves. However, if Adani Group becomes more reliant on bank loans, the risk to banks could increase. The Reserve Bank of India has stated that the Indian banking system remains resilient and stable.

images.alt_text: A man looks to an electronic signage displaying news on the Adani Group at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai on January 27, 2023. - Trading in the business empire of Asia's richest man Gautam Adani was halted on January 27, 2023 following a 15 percent plunge in its share price, days after a US investment firm claimed it had committed "brazen" corporate fraud. (Photo by SUJIT JAISWAL / AFP)
The central bank’s commentary on inflation will also be closely watched, given China’s economic reopening could fuel demand and exert upward pressure on global commodity prices.

An activist of India's Congress party shouts slogans as he burns an effigy of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Indian tycoon Gautam Adani during a rally to press for a probe into allegations by a US short-seller against Adani Group which triggered its market rout.
FILE PHOTO: The Deloitte Company logo is seen on a commercial tower at Gurgaon, on the outskirts of New Delhi August 9, 2012. REUTERS/Parivartan Sharma/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Traffic moves past the logo of the Adani Group installed at a roundabout on the ring road in Ahmedabad, India, February 2, 2023. REUTERS/Amit Dave/File Photo
The Adani group has repeatedly denied the short seller’s allegations.

site_title: Indonesian telcos could enjoy better margins as more take up home and mobile broadband bundles
summary: Indonesian telcos, such as Telkom and XL Axiata, are introducing fixed and mobile broadband bundles to capitalize on growing demand for video streaming. Analysts predict these bundles will lead to reduced customer churn and higher margins. Telkom is expected to benefit the most from bundling strategy, as it plans to merge IndiHome and Telkomsel by the end of this year. Analysts also expect telcos to raise prices this year, creating room for other operators to revive their price tweaks.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
A groundbreaking ceremony at Singtel's new hyperscale data centre in Kabil Industrial Estate in Batam, Indonesia. The ceremony was jointly held by Singtel and partners Telkom and Medco Power.
Fitch Ratings analyst Nitin Soni also noted that there is little evidence of 5G leading to sustained and significant average average revenue per user uplift across the world.
Moratelindo is planning to build shared ducting in cities to reduce the number of tower poles used for cable lines.

site_title: STMicro leans on AI, cloud as chip designs become more complex
summary: STMicroelectronics, a European chipmaker, has successfully used artificial intelligence (AI) software running on Microsoft's cloud to design a working chip. The achievement aims to solve the growing problem of getting increasingly complex chip designs ready for customers in an acceptable time. Synopsys, the maker of the AI software, has aided in designing over 100 chips since its release in 2020, and cloud computing helps ease the time crunch by providing a burst of computing power. This technology will help engineers optimize chip designs and meet business deadlines.

site_title: Central bank test lab to trial ‘stablecoin’ monitoring system
summary: A global central bank test lab is developing a 'stablecoin' monitoring system to provide authorities with clearer oversight of these cryptocurrencies. The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) aims to address the lack of tools to monitor stablecoins and avoid asset-liability mismatches. The project, named Pyxtrial, will run tests and simulations on multiple stablecoins by the end of the year, with the goal of building policy frameworks and increasing visibility on what assets stablecoins are backed by. This follows recommendations from the Financial Stability Board to boost cryptomarket oversight.

site_title: US supports India's G20 presidency on energy, food issues
summary: The US has expressed support for India's G20 presidency, focusing on addressing food and energy security challenges and building a resilient global economy. This comes as India seeks backing from its partners ahead of key meetings in February and March. The US also plans to deepen its bilateral partnership with India on various regional and global issues. India has increased its oil imports from Russia, making it the third-largest supplier, amid the ongoing war in Ukraine. The US and India will work together on issues such as women's economic empowerment and trade.

images.alt_text: Scattered clouds are seen over Mumbai's skyline. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s popularity remains robust, giving him a platform to enact change that many world leaders would envy.

site_title: US: Stocks higher after latest Federal Reserve comments
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve issued comments viewed as muted on inflation, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.8% to 34,156.69. Tech shares gained, driven by new artificial intelligence offerings from Microsoft and Alphabet, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index climbing 1.3% and 1.9% respectively. The comments from Fed Chair Jerome Powell were seen as a dovish sign, and the market is now looking ahead to President Joe Biden's State of the Union address, which is expected to highlight the robust jobs market and progress in mitigating inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A trader works on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., December 14, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Reclaims Global chairman retains position after conditional warning from CPIB
summary: Reclaims Global executive chairman Chan Chew Leh received a conditional warning from the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) following an investigation into corrupt transactions. Chan was found guilty under Section 6(b) of the Prevention of Corruption Act, which may result in fines or imprisonment. However, the company's board has accepted Chan's continued role as executive chairman and director, citing no impact on his duties. The incident has no financial consequences and Chan did not personally benefit from it. New measures have been introduced to ensure compliance with relevant laws and regulations.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Six former senior management staff of Keppel Corporation’s Offshore & Marine unit are being issued stern warnings for bribery-related offences.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Powell says job strength shows inflation fight may last ‘quite a bit of time’
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the strong US job market, with a 3.4% unemployment rate, may be beyond "maximum employment" and require higher interest rates to control inflation. The jobs report showed 517,000 new jobs in January, contradicting expectations. Powell emphasized that the inflation fight may take "quite a bit of time" and that interest rates may need to rise higher than anticipated if the strong job gains threaten the Fed's progress in lowering inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign for hire is posted on the window of a Chipolte Restaurant in New York City, U.S., April 29, 2022.  REUTERS/Shannon Stapleton/File Photo
Brent crude futures were up US$2.52, or 3.1 per cent, to US$83.51 a barrel by 1.07 pm EST (1807 GMT) on Tuesday.

site_title: Saudi Arabia eyes more fixed-rate debt as borrowing costs jump
summary: Saudi Arabia is considering borrowing more in international currencies, such as the euro, to reduce its floating-rate debt. The country aims to lock in fixed-rate debt, which will make up 90% of government borrowing by the end of the year. Despite expecting a budget surplus in 2023, Saudi Arabia raised $10 billion from a bond sale in January, with the government pre-funding $12.8 billion of its refinancing needs for the year. The move is aimed at diversifying the economy and executing the "Vision 2030" objectives.

images.alt_text: Saudi officials have pressed international companies to invest in the kingdom and move their regional headquarters to Riyadh, in order to benefit from government contracts.

site_title: Scoot CEO sanguine about 2023, amid ‘robust’ forward bookings and China reopening
summary: Scoot Airlines, Singapore Airlines' budget arm, is optimistic about demand in 2023 due to "robust" forward bookings and China's reopening. CEO Leslie Thng attributes Scoot's success to retaining its core team and updating crew members' skills during the pandemic, allowing it to ramp up capacity to 80% of pre-pandemic levels. In contrast, competitors have struggled to restore capacity due to staff cuts. Scoot's larger fleet of 55 aircraft has enabled it to scale up operations promptly, with Thng emphasizing the importance of maintaining flexibility in terms of adjustments with aircraft manufacturers.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
DBS has raised its target price for SIA to S$6.80 from S$6.60, maintaining its "buy" call on the stock.

AirAsia joins peers including Thai Airways International in scrambling to right-size their fleets to cater for a jump in tourists from China, which now allows people to come and go freely without quarantine.

site_title: US dollar inches up as focus turns to Powell speech
summary: The US dollar index edged up 0.1% to 103.68, nearing one-month highs, ahead of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech on the labour market. The speech's focus on interest rates is expected to provide signals on how high US rates may go this year, following a sharp jobs growth report last week. Markets now expect the federal funds rate to peak above 5.1% by June, higher than earlier expectations. The euro fell 0.2% and sterling dropped 0.3% against the dollar, while the Australian dollar rose 0.6% following the country's central bank raising its cash rate.

images.alt_text: Against a basket of currencies, the US dollar index touched a three-week high of 103.40.

site_title: UOI net profit down 36.9% in FY2022, gross premium and underwriting profit below pre-Covid levels
summary: United Overseas Insurance (UOI) reported a 36.9% drop in net profit to S$16.7 million for FY2022, below pre-Covid-19 levels. Gross premium rose 1.6% to S$99 million, while underwriting profit grew 2% to S$21.2 million. Non-underwriting income plummeted 94.9% to S$618,000. Despite a final dividend of 21 cents per share, the company's net asset value per share decreased to S$6.86. UOI expects recessionary pressures to build, with inflation increasing the risk of an economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
UOB's general Insurance arm, UOI reported a loss of S$18.7 million for 1H 2022 on losses from non-underwriting and other comprehensive income
Net underwriting profit, however, increased by 1.6 per cent to S$12.4 million, as management expenses lowered.

site_title: Apollo said to be in talks to acquire stake in Credit Suisse spin-off
summary: Asset manager Apollo Global Management is in talks to acquire a stake in Credit Suisse Group's new investment bank unit, Credit Suisse First Boston. The spin-off aims to create a boutique entity under the Credit Suisse First Boston branding, following years of scandals and management missteps. Apollo has previously agreed to buy Credit Suisse's securitised products group. Talks with Apollo are ongoing, and a deal could still fall apart. Credit Suisse has received a $500 million investment commitment from a "highly respected investor" to fund the spin-off.

images.alt_text: Staff inside Credit Suisse’s investment-banking arm have contended with uncertainty amid the Zurich-based lender’s plans to merge those operations with rainmaker Michael Klein’s advisory boutique.
The affected clients in the Credit Suisse data leak include drug barons and kleptocrats, holding more than US$100 billion with the bank in total.
Credit Suisse ranked 8th in arranging Chinese stock sales overseas last year, down from 6th in 2020.
The Zurich-based lender is in the midst of working out how to carve out its investment bank into the rebranded Credit Suisse First Boston and which businesses will be housed there.
The Swiss lender has been reducing headcount across its divisions after announcing plans last year to eliminate 9,000 roles globally by 2025.
Credit Suisse is not alone in signalling lower variable pay, though reductions at the lender are likely to be steeper than at its Wall Street peers.

site_title: Shipping containers ablaze at Turkey’s Iskenderun Port, operations halted
summary: Hundreds of shipping containers were ablaze at Turkey's Iskenderun Port, forcing operations to halt and diverting freight liners to other ports. The fire broke out after an earthquake struck the area, causing significant damage to logistics and transport infrastructure. Global container shipping group AP Moller Maersk is diverting ships and assessing potential cargo loss. Operations at the port are expected to remain closed until further notice, with nearby ports such as Mersin and Port Said being used as alternatives.

images.alt_text: Turkish authorities say some 13.5 million people were affected in an area spanning roughly 450 km from Adana in the west to Diyarbakir in the east, and 300 km from Malatya in the north to Hatay in the south.
Aleppo's ancient citadel is damaged following a deadly earthquake that shook Syria.

site_title: Unesco sounds alarm over quake damage to Turkey, Syria heritage
summary: The United Nations' cultural agency Unesco has sounded the alarm over damage to two World Heritage sites in Syria and Turkey following a devastating earthquake. The old city of Aleppo, Syria's pre-war commercial hub, and the Diyarbakir Fortress in Turkey have sustained significant damage, with at least three other sites potentially affected. Unesco is providing assistance and mobilizing experts to assess the damage and rapidly secure the sites.

images.alt_text: Turkish authorities say some 13.5 million people were affected in an area spanning roughly 450 km from Adana in the west to Diyarbakir in the east, and 300 km from Malatya in the north to Hatay in the south.

site_title: Singapore, Vietnam need to step up cooperation in digital economy, sustainable development: Vivian
summary: Singapore and Vietnam are strengthening their ties, with Vietnam Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh visiting Singapore for the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations and the 10th anniversary of the Singapore-Vietnam Strategic Partnership. Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan emphasized the need for cooperation in the digital economy, renewable energy, and sustainable development, with a focus on achieving net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. The two countries have a strong track record of bilateral trade and investment, with bilateral trade reaching $31.3 billion in 2022, and Vietnam's GDP growth expected to be around 6.3% in 2023.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Vietnam Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh have met regularly since the latter took office in April 2021, including at this meeting in Washington, DC in May 2022.

site_title: Shania Twain dreams up joyful new music for post-pandemic celebrations
summary: Shania Twain has released her new album, "Queen of Me", after recovering from a life-threatening bout of Covid-19. The 57-year-old singer-songwriter, who has sold over 85 million albums, drew inspiration from her experience and is celebrating the post-pandemic world with upbeat tracks like "Giddy Up!" and "Waking Up Dreaming". Twain will embark on a world tour starting in April, with the goal of spreading joy and positivity through her music.

site_title: Fed’s Kashkari says strong jobs data show need for more hikes
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari stated that the strong labor-market report in January indicates a need for more interest rate hikes to bridle inflation. Kashkari reaffirmed his forecast of a 5.4% interest rate, citing the need for policymakers to keep raising rates despite the recent smaller rate hike. The recent strong jobs data, with 517,000 new jobs added, suggests that the impact of previous rate hikes on the labor market has been muted, and Kashkari believes the rate path remains unchanged.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on December 15, 2022 US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen meets with President of Senegal Macky Sall during the US - Africa Leaders Summit at the Walter E. Washington Convention Center in Washington, DC. - US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is heading for an 11-day trip to Africa starting this week, aimed at deepening economic ties on the continent where China has become a key player. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)

site_title: India opposition says Modi government afraid of Adani debate
summary: India's opposition parties are protesting outside parliament, demanding a probe into billionaire Gautam Adani's fight with a US short seller, alleging fraud and market manipulation. The Adani Group's market value has nearly halved, and the opposition claims the government is "afraid" to discuss the issue, fearing damage to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's vote base ahead of national elections next year. Despite brief protests, the opposition has failed to gain much traction, and parliament proceedings have been adjourned for the day.

images.alt_text: A man looks to an electronic signage displaying news on the Adani Group at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai on January 27, 2023. - Trading in the business empire of Asia's richest man Gautam Adani was halted on January 27, 2023 following a 15 percent plunge in its share price, days after a US investment firm claimed it had committed "brazen" corporate fraud. (Photo by SUJIT JAISWAL / AFP)

An activist of India's Congress party shouts slogans as he burns an effigy of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Indian tycoon Gautam Adani during a rally to press for a probe into allegations by a US short-seller against Adani Group which triggered its market rout.
Gautam Adani is considered a close ally of India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and his business interests often align with the government’s growth goals.
A nationwide protest planned for Monday will also draw attention to Gautam Adani's links with Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

The pandemonium in the Indian parliament could be a sign that Adani’s woes may become a political headache for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, as he looks at a third term in office in elections due next year.

site_title: Malaysia’s December industrial production up 3%, below expectations
summary: Malaysia's industrial production index rose 3% in December, below expectations, driven by easing manufacturing activities. The growth was slower than November's 4.8% and lower than the average 4.4% forecast by economists. For the year, the index expanded 6.9%, down from 7.2% in 2021. Analysts attribute the decline to manufacturing slowdown, but note that consumer spending and trade performance turned out better than expected. Economists forecast slower growth in 2023, with Bank Negara expecting 4-5% economic growth this year.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's domestic-oriented industries continue to expand, supported by vehicles production activities and processed food products.

site_title: China says it will set up yuan clearing arrangements in Brazil
summary: China's central bank has signed a memorandum of understanding to set up yuan clearing arrangements in Brazil, aiming to boost the currency's global clout and facilitate cross-border transactions. This move is part of China's efforts since 2009 to reduce reliance on the US dollar and challenge the greenback's role as the world's major reserve currency. China has already signed similar deals with Pakistan, Kazakhstan, and Laos. The establishment of yuan clearing arrangements in Brazil is expected to promote bilateral trade and investment.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: JCube leisure and edutainment mall in Jurong East will cease operations in early August as developer CapitaLand Development converts the site into a 40-storey residential and commercial development. The Singapore Government will consider a report on "phantom credits" in carbon tax offsetting, while the aerospace sector seeks to fill 3,000 new roles. Asia can attract more FDI with greener treaties, and Singapore and Dubai are projected to lead prime residential markets globally.

site_title: It’s high time companies strengthened their tax governance
summary: Tax authorities worldwide face resource and compliance constraints due to digitalised transactions. To address this, tax governance is crucial for large organisations, with measures like OECD's Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) initiatives being adopted. Singapore has introduced two voluntary tax governance programmes, emphasizing the importance of tax governance as a "best practice" for taxpayers, not just a "good to have". This move aims to reduce tax leakage and ensure multinational groups pay their fair share of taxes.

images.alt_text: Deloitte said it would not be in Singapore’s best interest to be the first mover in enacting Pillar Two rules, and waiting for international consensus on implementation options is “more prudent”.
The new global tax rules will affect all business groups with annual global revenue of 750 million euros or more, regardless of industry.

The OECD’s final guidance aims to clarify lingering details so that governments adopt tax codes in a consistent and coordinated manner to limit compliance costs for companies and potential for conflicts.

site_title: Roadmap to prepare Singapore’s public transport workers for autonomous vehicles
summary: Singapore is developing a roadmap to prepare public transport workers for the deployment of autonomous vehicles (AVs). The Ministry of Transport is working with the National Transport Workers' Union and operators to identify emerging skills and new job roles. It will take time, with factors such as safety standards and operational requirements influencing large-scale deployment. As of January 27, 43 AVs have passed Milestone 1 tests, and one has passed Milestone 2, with trials showing the need for further development of AV capabilities for local operating conditions.

images.alt_text: (From left) Derrick Loh, CEO, Dilip Limbu, COO, and Anthony Wong, CTO of MooVita, with some of their autonomous vehicle solutions.
ComfortDelGro to invest S$30 million in autonomous vehicles
"Robotaxi" autonomous vehicles at a charging station in Shenzhen. Shenzhen will allow autonomous commercial driving services to be offered in the city from next month.

site_title: European airport traffic almost doubles year-on-year but still lags behind 2019
summary: European airport traffic almost doubled year-on-year in 2022 to 1.94 billion passengers, but still fell 21% short of 2019 levels. The Airports Council International Europe (ACI Europe) attributed this to ongoing uncertainty and supply chain issues. Despite this, the outlook is improving, with demand headwinds easing due to China's reopening and softening inflation. Only 27% of Europe's airports have fully recovered to pre-pandemic levels, with smaller regional airports leading the recovery.

site_title: Singapore, Dubai to lead price growth in prime residential markets amid slowdown worldwide
summary: Singapore and Dubai are expected to lead prime residential markets globally in 2023, with Singapore's prime price growth forecast to be 6.8% and Dubai's at 6-7.9%. However, both cities face challenges from higher interest rates and economic headwinds. The global average prime price growth is forecast at 0.5% for 30 cities monitored by Savills, with 17 cities expected to record slower growth, while 13 are expected to see equal or slightly enhanced growth.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Chinese have been the largest foreign buyer group in Singapore since 2016 and made up 6.9 per cent of foreign purchases of private apartments last year.
This photo taken on November 16, 2022 shows residental buildings in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
The IMF called on China to shift government spending away from investment and towards targeted support for households and to lower interest rates.
In Singapore, an acute supply crunch and an influx of wealth has pushed up rents.

site_title: Nomura’s Japan staff to get bigger raises as inflation quickens
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage, plans to give its employees in Japan a 6.2% average pay raise starting in April, citing intensifying competition for talent and faster inflation. This is slightly higher than the average 3% over recent years. The move is seen as a response to Japan's high inflation, with nominal wages increasing at the sharpest pace since the late 1990s. The Bank of Japan may shift its monetary policy in response to sustained pay rises.

images.alt_text: Nomura’s wholesale division logged a pretax loss of 1.9 billion yen, its first loss since the April-June quarter of 2021.

site_title: Fund bosses start turning backs on ESG indexes after downgrades
summary: Investment managers are shifting away from environmental, social, and governance (ESG) indexes due to concerns over their effectiveness in addressing serious environmental and social issues. The European Union's climate-transition and Paris-aligned benchmarks, intended to track clean assets, have been downgraded, leading some investors to seek alternative solutions. Fund managers like ABP, Nordea, and BlackRock are creating their own benchmarks to track companies that can realistically drive a transition away from high-carbon activities. The move reflects a growing sense of urgency to develop genuine ESG investing solutions, as scientists warn that limiting global warming to 1.5°C is increasingly out of reach.

site_title: Alibaba-backed Asian group Daraz cuts workforce 11%
summary: Daraz Group, an Alibaba-backed e-commerce platform, has cut its workforce in the Indian subcontinent by 11% due to market challenges. The cuts, affecting around 300 people, are part of a broader restructuring effort in response to factors like the Ukraine crisis, supply chain disruptions, and soaring inflation. Daraz CEO Bjarke Mikkelsen stated that the company will make 100 cuts in Bangladesh and 100 in Pakistan, both of which have similar market sizes to Daraz. The move is part of a broader effort to adapt to the "current market reality."

site_title: Thai central bank to help vulnerable debtors as rates rise
summary: The Bank of Thailand will provide assistance to vulnerable debtors affected by rising interest rates, with guidelines to be issued later this month. The central bank aims to tackle Thailand's high household debt, which reached 86.8% of GDP in the third quarter of 2022. Deputy Governor Ronadol Numnonda stated that support will be provided in line with debtors' ability to service their debts. The bank has raised its policy rate four times since August, and governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput warned that high household debt could disrupt economic recovery.

site_title: Adani stocks climb after eight-day rout
summary: Adani Group's flagship stock surged 25% after Gautam Adani and his family prepaid $1.11 billion of debt, trimming the group's market capitalization to $112 billion. The move came after a report by Hindenburg Research alleged market manipulation and accounting fraud, which Adani has repeatedly denied. The conglomerate's other stocks also rose, with Adani Enterprises gaining 25% and Adani Transmission jumping by its limit. However, concerns remain about the group's debt-fueled expansion and its access to funding.

images.alt_text: An activist of India's Congress party shouts slogans as he burns an effigy of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Indian tycoon Gautam Adani during a rally to press for a probe into allegations by a US short-seller against Adani Group which triggered its market rout.

site_title: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit H1 DPU up 2.1% to S$0.0245
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit reported a 2.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0245 for the first half of FY2023, driven by a 95.9% rise in distributable income and a 103% increase in gross revenue to S$101.7 million. The increase was largely due to the acquisition of Jem in April 2022 and easing of Covid-19 measures. The Reit's net property income surged to S$76.4 million, and its retail portfolio maintained a committed occupancy rate of 99.5% as of December 2022.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust reported 21.3 per cent y-o-y growth in tenant sales and 21.9 per cent y-o-y growth in shopper traffic for 9M 2022.
Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 0.2% on Tuesday, ending at 3,380.84, due to investor sentiment hit by possible interest-rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve, inflation, and worsening US-China ties. The benchmark index was also influenced by Fed chairman Jerome Powell's upcoming speech. Notable gainers included Haw Par Corp, First Resources, UOB, and DBS, while Jardine Matheson Holdings and Wilmar International were among the top losers.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

A man looks to an electronic signage displaying news on the Adani Group at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai on January 27, 2023. - Trading in the business empire of Asia's richest man Gautam Adani was halted on January 27, 2023 following a 15 percent plunge in its share price, days after a US investment firm claimed it had committed "brazen" corporate fraud. (Photo by SUJIT JAISWAL / AFP)
In investing, keeping a level head is harder than it looks, especially if your conviction in the stocks you own starts to waver.
The government is divesting stakes in state companies to fund expansion and reduce reliance on the state budget.

The Philippine CPI rose 8.7 per cent in January, well above the 7.7 per cent forecast in a Reuters poll and topping the 8.1 per cent rate in December, when the central bank had expected prices to peak.
The brokerage continues to value First Resources at a nine times price to earnings ratio based on earnings estimates for FY2023
The central bank’s commentary on inflation will also be closely watched, given China’s economic reopening could fuel demand and exert upward pressure on global commodity prices.
Hong Kong stocks were up one per cent, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Jakarta markets also rose.

site_title: India’s Bharti Airtel beats Q3 revenue view on rise in 4G users
summary: Bharti Airtel, India's No 2 telecom carrier, reported a 20.8% increase in Q3 revenue to 193.53 billion rupees, beating analysts' expectations. The company's 4G data customers rose 6.4 million to 216.72 million, and average revenue per user (ARPU) increased 1.6% sequentially and 18.4% year-on-year. Net profit for the December quarter rose to 15.88 billion rupees. The results were driven by 4G subscriber additions and higher revenue per user, outperforming market leader Reliance Jio's ARPU growth.

site_title: F&N Q1 net profit falls 29% to S$28.6 million
summary: F&N, a Singapore-based drinks maker, reported a 28.8% year-on-year decline in net profit for its first quarter, falling to S$28.6 million. Despite a 5.6% revenue growth to S$532.6 million, the company's profit before interest and taxes dropped 22.1% due to higher input costs and advertising expenses. Beverages and dairies segments contributed to the decline, with beer sales doubling and soft drinks growth supported by festive campaigns. The company has "generous debt headroom for acquisitions" with S$345.1 million in cash and S$1.09 billion in borrowings.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
F&N said the outlook for the food and beverage (F&B) industry for the next 12 months looks cautiously optimistic.

site_title: HPH Trust H2 DPU flat at HK$0.08
summary: HPH Trust reported a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of HK$0.08 for its second half, unchanged from the same period last year, resulting in a full-year DPU of HK$0.145. The company's net profit for the full year dropped 37.1% to HK$1.1 billion, while revenue and operating expenses fell 8.1% and 0.3%, respectively. HPH Trust attributed the decline to challenging business conditions, including a decline in containers shipped from China to Europe and North America. However, the company expects some encouraging developments in 2023, including relaxed Covid-19 controls and the reopening of the Chinese border with Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

In a bourse filing on Tuesday (Jul 26), HPH Trust reported a 6.8 per cent dip in profit attributable to unitholders of the trust to HK$716.3 million (S$126.5 million) in H1 2022 ended Jun 30, from HK$768.3 million a year ago.
SHARES of HPH Trust were trading in hefty volumes on Wednesday (Jul 27), as price slipped roughly 2.1 per cent or US$0.005 to US$0.235 as at 9.19am. Some 2.1 million shares changed hands at the time.
Brokers' take: DBS raises HPH Trust target price to US$0.37

site_title: A snapshot of which flag states take their responsibilities seriously
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has released its annual Shipping Industry Flag State Performance Table, which assesses the effectiveness of international rules by examining the collective Port State Control (PSC) record of ships flying a particular flag. Singapore stands out as one of the best performers, while several flag states, including the Bahamas and the Marshall Islands, have achieved all green indicators. The table also highlights the importance of labor standards, with 67.6% of flag states reporting on their ILO audit commitments. Despite some concerns, the ICS notes that the industry is moving towards greater transparency and accountability.

images.alt_text: New guidelines aim to protect seafarers better, in response to a significant rise in cases of crew abandonment.

Migrants prepare to get on board the Ocean Viking ship sailing in the international waters off Libya in the Mediterranean Sea, after being rescued by European maritime-humanitarian organization "SOS Mediterranee" on October 25, 2022. - Migrant rescue group SOS Mediterranee said on November 3, 2022 it had called on the governments of France, Greece and Spain to help find a port for 234 people rescued while trying to reach Europe, after Italy and Malta failed to answer. (Photo by Vincenzo CIRCOSTA / AFP)

site_title: Investors pulled £868m from UK equity funds in January
summary: UK equity funds experienced their 20th consecutive month of outflows, with January's losses being the third-largest on record, totaling £868m. This follows a near-record high for the UK market, indicating opportunistic selling amidst chronic pessimism. Global funds, however, attracted investments as markets rebounded. Fixed-income funds saw a net inflow of £1.23 billion, while UK property funds suffered a sixth consecutive month of outflows, with £48.3m sold.

images.alt_text: BlackRock had positive flows in its sustainable long-term products every quarter last year.
With the exception of Apple, eight tech giants are no longer "pure growth" stocks, while Exxon and Chevron are, a new study says. Buyer, beware.

site_title: Holland Tower on the market with S$76 million guide price
summary: Holland Tower, a 14-storey apartment in District 10, Singapore, has been put up for collective sale with a guide price of S$76 million, translating to a land price of S$1,739 per square foot per plot ratio. The 21,878 sq ft site is zoned for residential use and falls within the Good Class Bungalow Area in Holland Park. The public tender closes on March 14. This sale follows a strong demand trend in the Holland area, where existing units have sold for up to S$1,805 per square foot per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: The retail component of the 99-year leasehold mixed-use development has also attained 82 per cent expected occupancy, ahead of its launch by the end of this year.

site_title: Sias queries Sembmarine on financials, board accountability relating to KOM deal
summary: Sias, a shareholder body in Singapore, has issued 11 questions to Sembcorp Marine (Sembmarine) ahead of its extraordinary general meeting (EGM) next Thursday, where shareholders will vote on the proposed merger with Keppel Offshore & Marine Ltd (KOM). The queries cover financial terms, board accountability, and the conduct of the EGM. Sias expressed concerns over the dilution of net tangible assets, goodwill, and intangibles, as well as the lack of continuity and accountability on the new board. The EGM will decide the fate of the proposed deal, which would see Sembmarine acquire KOM at a revised equity-value exchange ratio of 46:54.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
This revised deal is S$378 million lower than if the one-for-one share exchange option was pursued, as Keppel O&M was being valued at S$4.87 billion under the previous terms.
Sembmarine says all of its directors are beneficial shareholders of Sembmarine, and will vote in favour of the proposed merger with Keppel O&M.

site_title: Nintendo promises 10% pay hike even as it trims profit outlook
summary: Nintendo has announced a 10% pay hike for its workers despite trimming its full-year profit forecast due to a firmer yen. The company, which sold 8.2 million Switch units in the latest quarter, revised its annual software sales forecast down to 205 million units and cut its Switch console sales target to 18 million units. Nintendo aims to secure its workforce for long-term growth, following calls by Prime Minister Fumio Kishida for Japanese companies to pay workers more amid inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Nintendo logo is seen in a GameStop in Manhattan, New York, U.S., December 7, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: AirAsia to lease 15 new planes to meet demand driven by China’s reopening
summary: AirAsia plans to lease 15 additional planes to meet growing demand from China following its reopening, with CEO Tony Fernandes saying the uncertainty of routes has disappeared. The move is part of the airline's efforts to meet its order book of 326 planes until 2030, with 150 planes already in service. Fernandes attributes the growth to strengthening Asian currencies, falling oil prices, and China's reopening, stating a clear path to normalcy has been established. The airline also plans to complete restructuring efforts and potentially split its businesses into separate listings.

site_title: OCBC Cycle returns in May with first full-scale event since 2019
summary: OCBC Cycle, Singapore's largest mass cycling event, is set to return in May after a three-year hiatus due to Covid-19 restrictions. The event will feature eight categories, including two new ones: the 500 km Virtual Ride and the Indoor Ride by Shimano. Organisers expect 7,000 cyclists to participate, up from 2,000 in 2022. The event marks OCBC Cycle's 15th anniversary and will include familiar categories such as the Sportive 40 km Ride and the Speedway Corporate Championships. Registration is now open, with early-bird discounts available.

images.alt_text:
Prudential Singapore employee Caleb Seow
(second from left) and other participants getting
hands-on training at the PRURide Seeker’s
Society cycling clinics.
Lien Choong Luen, Singapore Athletics Association president receiving the $50,000 cheque from Santoz Kumar, The Ironman Group Singapore general manager.

site_title: We’re not even close to running out of green minerals
summary: The world is not running out of green minerals, contrary to predictions of catastrophic shortfalls. New data from the US Geological Survey shows a boom in supplies of lithium, cobalt, tellurium, and copper, with reserves increasing by 18%, 9.2%, 8.3%, and 6.6% respectively. This growth is driven by rising prices, which have pushed lithium carbonate to nearly $80 a kilogram, and investments by miners and automotive companies. The market's response to fears of supply tightness has ensured the right investments are made to guarantee supply meets demand, repeating a pattern seen since the Biblical Pharaoh's dream of seven years of plenty turning to seven years of famine.

images.alt_text: button, cell, lithium
Jars containing rare earth minerals produced by Australia's Lynas Corp from its Mount Weld operations are seen near Laverton, northeast of Perth, Australia, August 23, 2019.
China produced 395,000 tonnes of lithium carbonate last year, up 32.5 per cent year on year, according to China’s Nonferrous Metals Industry Association.

site_title: Springtime in China: what will the reunion with investors bring?
summary: China's equities have rallied this year, driven by a mix of macro, regulatory, valuation, and positioning tailwinds. In January, China A-share indices rose 7-8% and HK-listed China shares rose over 10%. The revival is attributed to the post-Covid re-opening, strong economic data, and return of investment flows into Hong Kong/China markets. Key drivers include upside economic surprise and an attractive set-up of fundamentals, with sectors like consumer, technology, and renewables expected to benefit from policy tailwinds. However, investors should be cautious of near-term volatility and geopolitical risks, positioning for a sustainable bull market in 2023.

images.alt_text: Travelers in the departure hall at the Hongqiao Railway Station in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, Jan. 19, 2023. With China's 296 million migrant workers on the move this year, factories and local governments are bracing for disruptions during a longer-than-usual holiday period. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: UK PM Sunak reshuffles cabinet to better suit his priorities
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak reshuffled his cabinet, breaking up two departments to better suit his economic and party priorities. He created four new portfolios, including one for science and innovation, and appointed new ministers. The changes aim to steer the economy through double-digit inflation and stagnation, as well as develop new trade ties with international partners. The move is seen as an attempt to stamp Sunak's authority, but some experts believe it may not make a significant difference in the next election.

site_title: On the water with Myanmar’s ‘river cleaners’
summary: In Myanmar, dozens of people have taken to collecting plastic and glass in Yangon's Pazundaung Creek due to the post-coup economic crisis, with many losing their jobs and struggling to find alternative income sources. The "river cleaners" gather recyclable materials to sell to traders, with some earning as little as $4 per day. The hazardous work is often done on makeshift polystyrene boats, with workers facing risks such as tidal surges and encountering dead bodies in the water. The economic crisis has had a devastating impact on the country, with over a million people losing their jobs.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is the chair of the 10-member Association of South-east Asian Nations for 2023 and will host the bloc’s annual leaders’ meetings later this year.

site_title: Toshiba’s bidder set to win commitments for 1.4 trillion yen loan
summary: Japanese banks are set to issue commitment letters for a 1.4 trillion yen (US$10.6 billion) loan backing a consortium's takeover offer for Toshiba. The lenders, including Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, are demanding senior positions in Toshiba's management for their representatives in the event of a takeover. A Japan Industrial Partners-led consortium made the takeover offer for Toshiba, and the banks' commitment letters are expected to be issued this week.

site_title: BYD building own Europe factory more likely than taking one over
summary: BYD, a Chinese carmaking giant, is exploring setting up its own factory in Europe rather than taking over one from Ford Motor in Germany, according to a top executive. BYD wants to have solid sales and dealer networks in Europe to ensure consumer confidence in the brand. The company is conducting feasibility studies to determine the best solution for its future plans. BYD plans to sell its vehicles across Europe and has already announced plans to sell in Germany, Sweden, Norway, and other countries.

images.alt_text: BYD plans to open more than 100 dealerships in Japan by the end of 2025, but faces a tough task in a country where  nine in 10 cars sold annually are built by domestic firms such as Toyota.

site_title: Indonesia may raise nearly US$2 billion from three state company IPOs
summary: Indonesia is set to raise nearly US$2 billion from three state company IPOs by the end of the third quarter. State-owned companies PT Pertamina Hulu Energi, Pertamina Geothermal, and PalmCo are expected to offer shares, with Pertamina Geothermal's IPO potentially being the largest in a year. The government is divesting stakes to fund expansion and reduce reliance on the state budget, citing the recent rally in the Jakarta Composite Index.

images.alt_text: The IPO comes as Pertamina aims to double its geothermal capacity by 2027-2028, which may cost an estimated US$4 billion.
Indonesia is keen to tap into its geothermal resources amid efforts to cut energy imports and reduce carbon emissions.
The planned listing comes as Indonesia is targeting to raise 170 trillion rupiah in its capital markets this year, including listings and debt instruments.

site_title: Carlsberg warns of 'challenging year' after net loss of 1.06 billion kroner
summary: Carlsberg, a Danish brewer, reported a net loss of 1.06 billion kroner for 2022, despite revenue growth of 16.9% to 70.26 billion kroner. The loss was impacted by writedowns of 10.74 billion kroner, primarily due to the exit from Russia. The company warned that 2023 will be another "challenging year" due to uncertainties in the war in Ukraine and the Covid-19 recovery in China. Analysts had expected a higher revenue growth.

images.alt_text: Chief executive Cees ‘t Hart says if "inflation continues to increase and brewers raise prices again in the second half of this year and beginning of 2023, we see a bigger risk ahead of downtrading and lower volumes."

site_title: A US$5 trillion sovereign bond group rethinking climate risk
summary: A US$5 trillion investor coalition has proposed a framework to assess climate risk in sovereign bonds, aiming to unlock climate finance for emerging markets. The Assessing Sovereign Climate-related Opportunities and Risk (ASCOR) project, led by BT Pension Scheme Management and the Church of England Pensions Board, will assess countries on climate change and provide a free voluntary tool to demonstrate climate progress. The framework focuses on fairness between richer and poorer countries, exempting low- and middle-income nations from certain indicators and prioritizing factors such as annual climate finance commitments.

images.alt_text: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said the Singapore Government is aware of The Guardian’s report on rainforest credits issued by Verra, and the response and clarification issued by Verra.

site_title: Emerging market funds see big inflows in January on China reopening
summary: Emerging market funds saw significant inflows in January, with $13.2 billion in equity funds and $11.36 billion in bond funds, the highest in over a year. This surge is attributed to China's reopening and softening global inflation pressures. Analysts expect cheaper valuations, a weakening US dollar, and lower US Treasury yields to boost EM assets this year, following a dry patch in 2022 where EM bond funds faced a combined net outflow of $26.26 billion.

site_title: Boeing to slash about 2,000 white-collar jobs in finance and HR: newspaper
summary: Boeing plans to cut approximately 2,000 white-collar jobs in finance and human resources this year through attrition and layoffs. The move aims to streamline corporate functions and reallocate resources to support product development and manufacturing. This decision follows Boeing's previous announcement to hire 10,000 workers in 2023, with some support positions to be cut. The company cited growing bureaucracy and inefficient systems as the reason for the restructuring.

site_title: Celebrating the Roaring 2020s with a Bee’s Knees cocktail
summary: The Bee's Knees cocktail, a Prohibition-era favorite, is experiencing a resurgence in popularity, with creative variations appearing on menus across the US. The classic drink, made with gin, lemon juice, and honey, has been revived by bars and restaurants, with some incorporating unique ingredients and twists. The cocktail's simplicity and charm have made it an ideal starting point for creativity, with many bars offering period-correct and modern interpretations, including the Bee's Knees Cocktail Bar in Brooklyn, which features a beekeeping mural and serves a signature cocktail made with honey and bee pollen.

images.alt_text: The NSC Gin & Tonic is inspired by childhood memories of snacking on guava slices dusted with plum powder.
In Full Bloom, one of the signature cocktails at botanic-themed Ginger.Lily, is served in a clear infuser that displays a mix of fruit and herbs.
In a nod to the historical plantations in the neighbourhood, The Bar at 15 Stamford's signature cocktail Plantation 1840 features rum, pineapple juice, and sugarcane.
Named after a famous racehorse, the Secretariat cocktail at Farrer Horse draws inspiration from the equine diet with a hay bourbon base and apple puree.

site_title: UK house prices stabilise after four-month fall, Halifax says
summary: UK house prices remained unchanged in January after a four-month decline, according to Halifax. The annual rate of house price growth slowed to 1.9%, the weakest in three years, due to higher borrowing costs and high inflation. The trend of higher borrowing costs hitting demand is expected to continue in 2023, with lower house prices and interest rates potentially improving homebuying affordability over time.

images.alt_text: Bank-to-business lending is also facing a reversal of fortunes.

site_title: China forex reserves rise to US$3.184 trillion in Jan
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves rose to $3.184 trillion in January, surpassing expectations, driven by a 2.2% increase in the yuan against the US dollar. The US dollar fell 1.4% against a basket of other major currencies. China's gold reserves also rose to $125.28 billion, with a 7.4% increase. The increase in foreign exchange reserves and gold reserves suggests a strengthening Chinese economy, which may help alleviate deflationary price wars.

site_title: Ex-Surbana Jurong MD joins Meinhardt as Singapore COO and global board member
summary: Meinhardt Group has appointed Eugene Seah as its new chief operating officer (COO) of Singapore operations and senior director of the group's chief executive office, also joining the global board. Seah, formerly managing director of Surbana Jurong, brings extensive experience in the built environment industry and a reputation for success in senior leadership roles. He aims to bolster Meinhardt's business in Singapore and implement new initiatives while using the company as a platform to encourage young professionals to address urban development and climate change challenges.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
STACS' Benjamin Soh says the volume of green finance is on the rise, which raise demand for ESG data and monitoring services.
The Step IT Up programme by digital consultancy firm Temus is expected to benefit about 400 Singaporeans and permanent residents from non-tech backgrounds.
Quek who is currently the CEO of New Business in Surbana Jurong and will be the fifth person to helm the eight-year-old Sports Hub on a permanent basis.

site_title: Travelling artist provides a different view for Mauritania’s poor
summary: French artist Seb Toussaint, 35, has been travelling to poor neighbourhoods for the past decade to paint inspirational murals, as part of his "Share the Word" project. In Mauritania's slum Zaatar, Toussaint painted a mural with a word chosen by a resident, aiming to bring "colour to an environment where there is very little". Since 2013, he has painted over 222 words in 222 different locations, often using local themes and collaborating with residents. His work aims to give voice to those who don't have one.

images.alt_text: Poklong Anading of the Philippines is one of the over 60 artists featured in the book SEA: Contemporary Art In Southeast Asia. His photograph titled Counter Acts seeks to subvert photography's claim of capturing an image by having his subjects turn the lights towards the viewer instead, obscuring their own faces.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH upgrades First Resources to ‘buy’ on share price weakness
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has upgraded First Resources to "buy" from "hold" due to the stock's 10% decline since November 2022. The brokerage values First Resources at a nine times price-to-earnings ratio and expects a dividend yield of 9.7% for FY2022. UOBKH projects First Resources' Q4 financials to perform better than peers, with an estimated core net profit of up to US$100 million, and a higher FFB production growth of 7% year-on-year. The target price remains unchanged at S$1.85.

images.alt_text: UOB Kay Hian recommends holding on to the stock to reap “good” dividend yields of 6 per cent to 8 per cent between FY2022 and FY2024.
First Resources posts a surge in Q3 profit due to stronger palm oil prices and the resumption of palm oil exports in Indonesia.

site_title: Centurion unit to develop A$132.2 million student accommodation in Sydney
summary: Centurion Corporation, a Singapore-based parent company, plans to develop a $132.2 million student accommodation complex in Sydney, Australia. The 732-unit housing complex will feature cluster apartments and studios, located near Macquarie University and a metro station. The project is expected to provide convenient access to Sydney's central business district, making it an attractive option for students.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Centurion in April to sell its US asset portfolio within its Centurion US Student Housing Fund following a strategic review of its accommodation portfolio.

The lease and development of the land is in line with Centurion’s strategy to grow its workers accommodation business in Singapore, and represents an opportunity to enlarge its portfolio to 35,550 beds here.

site_title: Third wave of strikes over pension reform keeps pressure on Macron
summary: France's President Emmanuel Macron's pension reform plan is facing opposition as workers across multiple sectors launched a third wave of nationwide strikes, disrupting rail services, schools, and refinery deliveries. The government aims to make workers work two years longer to keep the pension system afloat, but unions argue the money can be found elsewhere. The strikes come as the legislation is set to pass through parliament, with over 20,000 amendments proposed.

site_title: Govt to consider ‘phantom credits’ report, Verra’s response in finalising criteria for carbon tax offset
summary: Singapore's government is considering the findings of a report by The Guardian, which claimed that over 90% of rainforest carbon offset credits issued by Verra are "phantom credits." Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said the government will take the report and Verra's response into account as it finalizes criteria for carbon tax offsetting. The government will publish a whitelist of eligible credits later this year, and companies must meet environmental integrity criteria set out by the government.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said the eligibility criteria for international carbon credits will “minimally reference” the Corsia standards for now, given that the carbon market is nascent and growing.

site_title: Philippine inflation beats expectations, lifts chance of bigger rate hike
summary: The Philippine inflation rate surged 8.7% in January, exceeding expectations and reaching a 14-year high due to surging food prices. This has raised the likelihood of the central bank increasing interest rates to combat inflation, with a possible 25-50 basis point hike. Core inflation also increased to a 2-decade high of 7.4%, indicating broad price pressures. The central bank is focusing on inflation rather than the Federal Reserve's recent rate hike, and the government is also taking measures to increase food production to cool inflation.

images.alt_text: A worker shows Philippine peso bills at a money changer in Manila. The central bank has expressed confidence that this could be brought down to below 4 per cent by as early as the third quarter of 2023.
Philippine inflation was likely to be within a range of 7.5 per cent to 8.3 per cent in January.

site_title: Australian central bank lifts rates to 10-year high
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 3.35%, a 10-year high, to combat surging inflation. This is the ninth consecutive rate hike, the highest since October 2012, as global central banks tighten monetary policy in response to rising food and energy prices. The move aims to prevent a recession while controlling inflation, which is partly caused by the Ukraine war.

images.alt_text: The Aussie struggled at US$0.6923, after slumping 2.2 per cent on Friday – the most since mid-December – to dip below 70 cents for the first time in two weeks.
The export windfall has aided Australia’s budget outlook, with both its debt and deficit position among the best in the developed world.

site_title: Asia: Markets rebound from Federal Reserve sell-off but traders still uneasy
summary: Asian markets rebounded on Tuesday, with Hong Kong and other markets rising after a recent sell-off fueled by concerns over US interest rates. Despite a jobs report showing over half a million new posts in January, investors are still wary of high borrowing costs. Central Bank boss Jerome Powell's speech later in the day is expected to provide further insight into the Fed's plans. Meanwhile, tensions between the US and China remain high after the US shot down a suspected Chinese spy balloon, with China accusing the US of overreacting.

images.alt_text: The losses continued in Asia, with Hong Kong sinking 1.9 per cent on Monday.

site_title: Microsoft investigates Outlook outage as users face issues
summary: Microsoft is investigating issues with its email service Outlook, affecting users in North America who faced problems accessing, sending, or searching emails. Over 2,000 incidents were reported on Tuesday, with the issue resolved as reports dropped to 351. The cause of the issue was attributed to a "recent change." Microsoft is working to restart affected infrastructure to restore service. Users may experience difficulties with sending, receiving, or searching emails, as well as issues with Calendar functionality.

images.alt_text: Microsoft logo is seen through broken glass in this illustration taken, January 25, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: ‘Commute, work, die’ should be retired
summary: France is experiencing nationwide strikes and protests over the government's proposed pension reform, which includes raising the minimum retirement age to 64 from 62. The French are not considered lazy, with a low unemployment rate and high employment rate among 25-54-year-olds. However, the proposed reform aims to encourage companies to hire more workers over 55 by setting targets for diversity by age. Critics argue that lifting the pension age will worsen unemployment as older workers get laid off before retirement. Experts suggest that expanding the labor pool and re-evaluating the concept of retirement age are more significant economic issues.

images.alt_text: Rail services were cancelled, schools disrupted and refinery deliveries halted as workers across multiple sectors walked out, and unions urged the public again to take to the streets in big numbers.
French Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne says: "We are going to move by extending the measure for long careers to those who started working at 20 and 21. They will be able to retire at 63.”
Widespread protests in Paris, around the Place de la Republique, against the French government's pension reform plan; Jan 19, 2023.

site_title: Rescuers in race against time as Turkey-Syria quake death toll passes 5,000
summary: A magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck Turkey and Syria, killing over 5,000 people and injuring 20,426. The quake, the deadliest in Turkey since 1999, destroyed thousands of buildings, including hospitals and schools. Harsh winter weather hindered search efforts and aid delivery, with fuel and electricity shortages reported. The death toll in Syria rose to 1,600, with thousands of children potentially among the dead. Rescuers face a "race against time" to save hundreds of families trapped under rubble, with urgent international help needed.

images.alt_text: Turkish pipeline operator Botas said there was no damage on main pipelines which carry crude oil from Iraq and Azerbaijan to Turkey.

site_title: UK property investors include Kremlin allies: study
summary: A Transparency International report found that over 18,000 offshore companies, including those linked to the Kremlin, own almost 52,000 properties in England and Wales worth £6.7 billion. The properties were purchased using "suspect funds" from Russia, including those subject to sanctions, through secretive offshore companies. Despite the UK's efforts to crack down on dirty Russian cash, the report claims the "Register of Overseas Entities" remains vulnerable to abuse, allowing corrupt wealth to hide.

images.alt_text: Britain’s construction sector lost its momentum during the second half of 2022 in the face of higher interest rates.

site_title: Marvel superheroes return to Chinese cinemas
summary: Marvel superheroes have returned to Chinese cinemas after a nearly four-year absence, with the Disney-owned studio's popular franchises resuming their presence in the world's largest movie market. The return coincides with China's loosening of strict zero-Covid policies and a recent easing of a tech crackdown. Fans are excited to watch Marvel films in cinemas, with Black Panther: Wakanda Forever and Ant-Man and the Wasp: Quantumania set for release. The move marks a significant boost for Disney's earnings, with the first Black Panther film earning $105 million at Chinese cinemas.

images.alt_text: Wakanda: Forever, the sequel to 2018’s blockbuster hit Black Panther, debuted in global theatres in November.

site_title: Aerospace sector seeks to fill 3,000 jobs to meet growing maintenance, repair, overhaul demand
summary: Singapore's aerospace industry is expanding, with 3,000 new job openings by end-2023 to meet growing demand for maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) services. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan said companies are investing in technology and innovation, and hiring in emerging areas such as digital services and autonomous technology. The industry is coping well with the increase in demand, with factory output exceeding pre-Covid levels since the second quarter of 2022.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Excluding the typically volatile biomedical manufacturing cluster, factory output expanded 0.3 per cent year on year, reversing November’s 5.8 per cent contraction.

Around 20 regional Asian airlines have been unable to restart or increase services to Hong Kong despite months of negotiations with ground handling services, five airline executives told AFP, asking not to be named.

site_title: Global bonds tumble as central bankers hammer home hawkish message
summary: Global bond markets tumbled for a second day as central bankers signaled further interest rate hikes, pushing back on speculation of a tightening cycle's end. US Treasuries saw significant selling pressure, with yields rising 19 basis points to 4.48% for the two-year yield and 17 basis points to 3.83% for the five-year yield. The Fed's policy ceiling is now expected to reach 5.25% by the end of the year, according to market pricing. This shift in expectations has reduced the likelihood of rate cuts this year, with traders pricing over 30 basis points of rate cuts by year-end.

images.alt_text: At current rates cash may be seen as a strategic asset.

site_title: Goodbye JCube: New 40-storey project to boost housing supply in Jurong Lake District
summary: CapitaLand Development plans to redevelop the JCube site in Jurong East into a 40-storey residential and commercial development. The mall will close its doors in August, with the new project slated for completion in 2027. Observers estimate a S$2,000 to S$2,100 per square foot price tag for residential units, which will have commercial space on the first and second storeys.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Income At Raffles at 16 Collyer Quay was sold for about S$1 billion in  late-June 2022 to Singapore-based Bright Ruby Resources group.

The white site in Jurong East (comprising three land plots) can be developed into about 150,000 sq m GFA of office space, 1,760 private homes and 75,000 sq m GFA of complementary uses such as for retail, hotel or community.
Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s (MPACT) Mapletree Business City (MBC) recorded yoy growth in both gross revenue and NPI in H1FY23.

site_title: SoftBank tumbles to loss as Vision Fund in red for fourth straight quarter
summary: SoftBank Group reported a quarterly loss of 783.42 billion yen due to a fourth consecutive loss by its Vision Fund, which incurred an investment loss of 730.36 billion yen in the fiscal third quarter. The Vision Fund's losses are prompting investors to focus on an initial public offering (IPO) of British chip designer Arm, which SoftBank aims to list by March 2024.

images.alt_text: SoftBank shouldered big writedowns on investments in some of the world’s most high-flying startups, resulting in deep losses last year.

site_title: Siemens Energy Q1 net loss more than doubles on wind unit woes
summary: Siemens Energy reported a net loss of 598 million euros in the first quarter, more than doubling from the same period last year, due to quality issues at Siemens Gamesa. The company plans to raise up to 1.5 billion euros to fund a full takeover of the wind division. Despite the loss, the company's order backlog reached a record 98.8 billion euros, driven by its grid technology division, and is expected to translate into 22 billion euros in revenue in 2023.

site_title: Binance plans to suspend US dollar transfers using bank accounts
summary: Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, has temporarily suspended US dollar transfers using bank accounts, starting Wednesday, due to banking partner issues. The suspension affects only 0.01% of its monthly active users and does not impact other fiat currency transfers or alternative payment methods. Binance US remains unaffected. The move comes amid growing concerns from federal regulators about the risks of doing business with crypto firms following the collapse of FTX.

images.alt_text: The two companies have been embroiled in a months-long dispute over whether exchange giant Binance owns WazirX.
Binance has issued more than US$539 million in total of the 41 B-Tokens that have Binance 8 as their collateral wallet.

site_title: China’s Baidu says developing AI chatbot
summary: Chinese search engine giant Baidu is developing an AI-powered chatbot called "Ernie Bot," expected to integrate into its main search service. The move follows the success of ChatGPT, sparking fears of cheating and job obsolescence. Baidu's shares soared 15% on the announcement, as the company diversifies into AI, cloud computing, and autonomous driving technologies. The chatbot's potential misuse has raised global alarm, with Beijing warning of the threat to national security and social stability. Internal testing is expected to be completed in March, with a public launch yet to be confirmed.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 6, 2022 shows an employee walks past the company logo at Baidu's headquarters in Beijing. - Chinese internet giant Baidu on November 22, 2022, reported third-quarter revenues of 32.5 billion yuan ($4.6 billion), representing a year-on-year increase of 2 percent, according to the company's earnings report. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP)
Baidu has spent billions of dollars researching AI in a years-long effort to transition from online marketing to deeper technology.

site_title: Affirming the power of couple-hood in personal finance
summary: Marriage can provide financial benefits for Singaporean couples, including advantages in homeownership, insurance, and investment. Couples can buy HDB flats at subsidized prices, potentially earning a significant mark-to-market gain, and may also be eligible for housing grants. Marriage also offers insurance benefits, such as mitigating job disruption risks and providing flexibility for one partner to pursue entrepreneurial or retraining opportunities. Additionally, couples can manage investments together, making better investment decisions through diverse perspectives and frank discussions. However, couples should be mindful of the financial consequences of divorce, including the loss of economies of scale and potential legal fees.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
While the 2015 personal income tax hike did not directly affect Singapore's wealthy, it had a positive redistribution effect for the lower-income groups, an NUS study has found.

site_title: Indian central bank seen delivering final rate increase of cycle
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is expected to deliver its final interest-rate increase in the current tightening cycle, with 34 economists predicting a 25 basis-point hike. The decision comes amid signs of cooling inflation and weakening growth, with the median projection suggesting the main repurchase rate will reach 6.50% this quarter. The RBI's cautious approach is influenced by a stronger-than-expected US jobs report and the ongoing Adani Group crisis, which may impact the Indian economy.

images.alt_text: The Adani Group denies all Hindenburg’s allegations, but the fall in the value of its stocks led it to call off last week a US$2.5 billion share sale by Adani Enterprises.

site_title: US debt ceiling: A nation divided and indebted cannot stand
summary: The US debt ceiling crisis poses a significant threat to the nation's economic stability, with a potential default on federal debt having catastrophic consequences. The current standoff between the Republican-controlled House of Representatives, President Joe Biden, and Democratic legislators could lead to a fiscal crisis. The US has a history of addressing debt crises, with Alexander Hamilton's financial principles playing a crucial role in restoring creditworthiness during the Revolutionary War and subsequent conflicts. However, the current path of unsustainable fiscal deficits and the massive expansion of entitlement programmes threaten to make the problem even worse, with the deficit projected to average 5% of GDP per year. A voluntary default would be equivalent to driving a car off a cliff, and the US must work together to address the issue and prevent severe consequences for future generations.

images.alt_text: Mark J Higgins
Ukrainian troops in a tank in the Bakhmut district of eastern Ukraine. The West has committed to sending advanced battle tanks to help Ukraine against Russia.

Georgieva warned that 60 per cent of low-income countries are at or near a debt crisis, and reiterated her call for China, the biggest creditor to emerging countries, to cooperate with multiparty debt restructuring talks.

site_title: Hot stock: Leader Environmental Tech gains 17% on heavy trading
summary: Leader Environmental Tech's share price surged 17.7% on heavy trading volumes, with over 3 million shares changing hands, following the announcement that its US$15 million zero-coupon convertible bonds had been cleared by the Singapore Exchange. The bond investment, with a three-year tenure, will be used to secure sludge treatment and AI water management projects. The company's share price reached its highest level in a year, surpassing its previous record in October 2022.

images.alt_text: Leader Environmental Technologies on Tuesday evening said it received a US$15 million, zero-coupon convertible bond investment commitment from funds managed by China’s InnoVision Capital.

site_title: Vietnam PM to make official visit to Singapore from Feb 8-10
summary: Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh will make an official visit to Singapore from February 8-10, marking the 50th anniversary of diplomatic relations and the 10th anniversary of upgraded relations. The visit comes after high-level visits by Singapore officials to Vietnam in 2022. This is Chinh's first official visit since taking office in April 2021, and the trip is seen as a significant step in strengthening bilateral ties between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Maybank analysts noted that property prices in Vietnam have skyrocketed in recent years and become increasingly unaffordable, particularly since the pandemic
VinFast is gearing up to expand in the United States, where it hopes to compete with existing automakers by offering two models, the VF8 and VF9.

site_title: SK Innovation to invest in battery business growth as profit target delayed
summary: SK Innovation, a South Korean energy group, plans to invest heavily in its electric vehicle battery business despite delays in reaching profit targets. The company has allocated 70% of its capital spending budget to batteries, aiming to ramp up production at foreign factories. Battery unit SK On accounted for 15% of revenue in the fourth quarter, with customers including Ford, Hyundai, and Volkswagen. The company expects to break even in the battery business by 2024, driven by growing demand and favorable bargaining power with automaker customers.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s exports of processed nickel then swelled to more than US$30 billion in 2022 from about US$1 billion in 2015.
SK On is the wholly owned battery unit of SK Innovation and counts Hyundai Motor, Volkswagen and Ford Motor among its customers.
SK On’s new factories have been built with guarantees from automakers that they will take the batteries, Jason Lee, head of SK On’s battery marketing division said.

site_title: Australia records its fifth straight year of trade surpluses
summary: Australia recorded its fifth consecutive year of trade surpluses in December, with a surplus of A$12.2 billion. The export windfall has improved the country's budget outlook, with its debt and deficit positions among the best in the developed world. The trade surplus is expected to remain healthy in 2023 due to China's rapid reopening and high commodity prices. This is also expected to benefit Australia's education and tourism sectors, with China being the nation's top trading partner.

images.alt_text: The RBA will weigh signs of weaker hiring and household spending against a sharp acceleration in core inflation when it discusses policy settings.

site_title: NYSE plans to pay in full majority of claims after glitch
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) plans to pay the majority of claims related to a recent glitch, which cancelled thousands of trades affecting hundreds of securities. The exchange operator will reimburse investors for trades that fit certain parameters, with the majority receiving full compensation. However, those with loss-making trades triggered on other venues may not receive any reimbursement, with estimates suggesting around 60% of claims will be covered. NYSE will seek permission from regulators if losses exceed its monthly disruption fund of $500,000.

site_title: Japan’s wages jump by biggest margin in almost 26 years
summary: Japan's workers saw a 4.8% increase in nominal wages in December, the largest jump in nearly 26 years, driven by hefty winter bonuses. The data may prompt speculation about a shift in the Bank of Japan's policy, with some economists suggesting the central bank could consider adjusting its stimulus program under a new governor. The yen firmed after the data, but investors remain cautious. Despite the wage growth, real wages only edged up 0.1%, and household spending fell 2.1% in December, indicating that price growth is still weighing on consumption.

images.alt_text: For Japan, maintaining an alliance with the US is by far the safest and most cost-effective option.

site_title: BP profit soars to record US$28b, dividend increased
summary: BP reported a record profit of US$28 billion in 2022, driven by a surge in energy prices since Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The company increased its dividend by 10% to 6.006 US cents per share. This follows a 10% increase in the third quarter and a 50% increase in the fourth quarter of 2021. The results were impacted by weaker gas trading activity and lower oil and gas prices. CEO Bernard Looney attributed the strong performance to improved plant reliability and reduced production costs.

images.alt_text: BP forecast worldwide energy consumption to drop 2.3 per cent by 2035 compared with its forecast a year ago.

site_title: BlackRock US ESG flows fall on tech rout, anti-green backlash
summary: US sustainable fund flows plummeted in 2023, with net outflows of $772 million in January, a significant decline from $953 million in January 2022. BlackRock, the world's largest money manager, saw zero net flows into its sustainable products in the US last year, despite positive flows in previous quarters. The decline was attributed to a backlash against ESG investing, particularly from Republican state officials and anti-ESG crusaders.
