The anti-ESG sentiment was not global, with ESG investments performing better outside the US last year.

images.alt_text: BlackRock's chief executive officer Larry Fink has been outspoken about investing with ESG goals, making it a focal point in his annual letters to the industry.
BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager, posted adjusted earnings of US$1.36 billion, or US$8.93 per share, in the three months to Dec 31.

site_title: Scottish nationalists make 2023 push for independence
summary: Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is preparing a roadmap for independence from the UK, despite a political and economic black hole this may lead to. The UK Supreme Court ruled that the Holyrood legislature lacks authority to declare a new independence referendum, and Sturgeon's leadership is facing internal challenges. She aims to capitalize on Brexit's unpopularity in Scotland and pressure the UK government into allowing another referendum. However, independence would likely weaken the UK, with uncertainties about Scotland's economic future and potential costs to the UK's international influence.

images.alt_text: The repercussions of Scottish independence, together with military cutbacks, will undermine the UK's hard and soft power.

site_title: A housing crash takes down the krona and sounds inflation alarm
summary: Sweden's housing market crash has led to a significant decline in its currency, the krona, which has fallen to an almost 14-year low. The country's high levels of household debt, plummeting home prices, and rising bankruptcies have caused the Riksbank to face a difficult tradeoff between saving an overleveraged economy and taming price growth. The krona's value has dropped by almost 8% in the past 12 months, and analysts predict it may continue to slide beyond its mid-year target price of 11.5 per euro.

images.alt_text: Sweden's house prices have plunged in the last nine months, and property companies there are facing a funding squeeze.
The rapid slide in prices, driven by higher borrowing costs and soaring inflation, has made Sweden emblematic of a wider trend as real-estate markets retreat globally.

site_title: OCBC appoints group CEO Helen Wong as executive director
summary: OCBC appoints group CEO Helen Wong as executive director, assuming dual roles. Wong, the first woman to head a Singapore bank, was previously chief executive of HSBC in Greater China. She was paid S$7.6 million in 2021. The nomination was made by OCBC's nominating committee and approved by the board.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The bank’s earnings per share stood at S$1.40, up from last year’s S$1.07.
OCBC says it is developing a systematic plan to achieve net zero by 2050. It also aims to unveil sectoral financed emission targets by the first half of 2023.
Helen Wong (left), Group CEO, OCBC Bank with Lim Khiang Tong, Group chief operating officer,  harvesting the lettuce at the OCBC Centre carpark.
The first guest on Mark to Market 'Live' will be OCBC Bank's Group Chief Executive Officer, Helen Wong.
OCBC talks sustainability in growth strategy; CEO Helen Wong paid S$7.6m in 2021
Prevention key to tackling scams, customers bear responsibility too: OCBC CEO

site_title: Gold edges up on softer dollar; investors eye Powell’s comments
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,870.63 per ounce, driven by a softer dollar and investors awaiting Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments on monetary policy. Spot silver rose 0.1%, while platinum fell 0.2%. The dollar index eased 0.1%, making gold more attractive for customers holding other currencies. Fed funds futures traders now expect interest rates to rise above 5% in May, supporting gold prices.

images.alt_text: Physical gold demand in India ticked up last week, as jewellers resumed purchases after staying away for a couple of weeks hoping for an import duty cut in the government budget amid the wedding season.

site_title: Singapore’s soaring rents narrow the gap with pricey Hong Kong
summary: Singapore's rental market is expected to continue its upward trend, with analysts predicting a 10-15% increase in 2023, narrowing the gap with Hong Kong's pricey market. Despite Hong Kong's higher home rents, Singapore's growth rate is expected to surpass its neighbor's, driven by an acute supply crunch and influx of wealth. This trend is expected to continue, with Singapore's rents potentially outpacing Hong Kong's 5% increase in 2023.

images.alt_text: Despite the decline in luxury property transactions over Q4, Huttons sees the market benefiting from the lifting of border measures by China this year.
The IRAS building along Newton Road on 17 September 2018.
Chinese have been the largest foreign buyer group in Singapore since 2016 and made up 6.9 per cent of foreign purchases of private apartments last year.
Two buyers purchased the 4,596-square-foot home for HK$390 million (S$65.1 million) in late January. The seller bought the property for HK$520 million in 2018.

site_title: Record-breaking 2022 for North Korea crypto theft: UN report
summary: North Korea set a record for cryptocurrency theft in 2022, with estimated losses of $630 million to $1 billion, according to a confidential UN report. The report, submitted to the UN Security Council committee, attributed the thefts to North Korean-linked hackers who targeted foreign aerospace and defense companies. The hackers used sophisticated cyber techniques to gain access to digital networks and steal valuable information, including for the country's nuclear and missile programs. The report also noted that North Korea has continued to evade sanctions by illicitly importing refined petroleum and exporting coal.

images.alt_text: The judicial managers of Hodlnaut are in the process of signing non-disclosure agreements with the potential investors.
To date, little about the collapse of crypto exchange FTX suggests a massive new regulatory infrastructure is needed to police the world of cryptocurrency and assets.
The FCA will be given supervision and enforcement powers over AML-complying cryptoasset businesses promoting cryptoassets, such as forcing a company to take down its website.

site_title: Hot stock: Boustead stocks surge as much as 10% after news of takeover offer
summary: Boustead Singapore made a takeover offer to take its real estate subsidiary Boustead Projects private at S$0.90 per share, a 7.8% premium over the last traded price. The offer is seen as undervaluing Boustead Projects, with analysts citing a 50% discount to its revalued net asset value. The move is expected to boost Boustead Singapore's earnings, with analysts projecting a "fundamental inflection point" in the second half of FY2023.

images.alt_text: Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore. The company’s S$0.90 per share offer translates to a premium of 7.8 per cent over Boustead Projects’ last traded price per share of S$0.835 on the Singapore Exchange on Feb 3.
CapitaLand India Trust reported its distribution per unit rose 9 per cent to S$0.0391 in the six months ended Dec 31, 2022.
The acquisition of J’Forte Building, an eight-storey high-spec industrial property at 26 Tai Seng Street, marks Boustead Industrial Fund's first in the open market.

site_title: Boustead Singapore makes offer for real estate unit; analysts say S$0.90 offer price undervalues Boustead Projects
summary: Boustead Singapore has made an offer to privatize its real estate subsidiary Boustead Projects at S$0.90 per share, a premium to the last traded price but below the company's net asset value. Analysts consider the offer undervaluing Boustead Projects and favoring the parent company. Despite this, investors have sent Boustead Projects shares above the offer price, trading at S$0.91, and analysts predict a possible "bump" in the offer price.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand India Trust reported its distribution per unit rose 9 per cent to S$0.0391 in the six months ended Dec 31, 2022.
The acquisition of J’Forte Building, an eight-storey high-spec industrial property at 26 Tai Seng Street, marks Boustead Industrial Fund's first in the open market.
Boustead Projects' net profit for the 6-months ended Sep 30, 2022, rose to S$7.7 million from S$5.9 million in the year ago period.

site_title: UK retailers struggle but consumers spend on films and holidays
summary: UK retailers experienced a slower growth in spending in January, with 4.2% annual increase, lagging behind inflation and December's 6.9% rise. However, consumers boosted spending on cinema trips and holidays, with Barclays reporting a 9.7% rise in payment card spending and a 63% confidence measure. The Bank of England's interest rate hike and rising utility prices pose a challenge for consumers, but some retailers appear to be finding ways to adapt to changing consumer behavior.

images.alt_text: Prices are steadily rising for consumers even as broader measures of inflation start to ease in the UK.
Bank-to-business lending is also facing a reversal of fortunes.

site_title: Bed Bath & Beyond plans share sale in bid to avoid bankruptcy
summary: Bed Bath & Beyond plans to raise over $1 billion through a share sale and convertible preferred securities to avoid bankruptcy. The company, facing solvency challenges, will use the funds to repay debt and make overdue interest payments. Despite a recent surge in its stock price, Bed Bath & Beyond's options for emerging from bankruptcy seem to be narrowing, and analysts question whether the company can win back customers and suppliers. The retailer's efforts to rebuild merchandise and improve stores may be insufficient to stem its decline.

images.alt_text: With a Bed Bath & Beyond bankruptcy filing growing increasingly imminent, competing retailers like Target and Walmart are poised to score a fresh crop of customers if the company is forced to shut its doors entirely.
The notice is the latest sign that one of the largest sellers of home goods in the US is likely to seek bankruptcy protection in short order after years of falling revenue.

site_title: The power of partnership
summary: TE Asia Healthcare Partners, co-founded by Eng Aik Meng, has established a portfolio of specialist hospitals in Malaysia, Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines, focusing on cancer, cardiovascular disease, and orthopaedics. With over $250 million in capital invested and $150 million in annual revenue, the group has attracted over 300 doctors and 2,600 staff. Eng emphasizes the importance of partnership and collaboration, aligning interests between doctors, patients, and payers. The group's model, where doctors are co-owners or equity partners, has proven successful, and partnerships with stakeholders, regulators, and other hospitals are key to its sustainable business.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

The shortage of healthcare staff, particularly nurses, in Singapore is a concern for healthcare players

ST PHOTO : MALCOLM MCLEOD

site_title: China an important driver for global recovery in H2: Standard Chartered
summary: Standard Chartered predicts China's GDP will grow 5.8% in the second half of 2023, higher than the market consensus of 4.9%, making it an "important driver" for global recovery. The bank also expects US and euro area growth to pick up in the second half, with global GDP growth forecast at 2.5%. Most central banks are expected to end rate-hiking cycles by mid-2023, allowing financial conditions to stabilize.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
The full impact of rate hikes can take a year or more to show up in economies.
In an earlier session, Dr He Dong, deputy director for monetary and capital markets at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), described 2023 to be a challenging year for monetary policy.
Some 18 per cent considered a world recession “extremely likely” in World Economic Forum (WEF) survey, more than twice as many as in the previous survey conducted in September 2022.

site_title: Many airlines will not meet US 5G upgrade deadline: IATA
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) warned that many airlines will not meet the US 5G upgrade deadline, citing supply chain issues, certification delays, and logistical challenges. Airlines working to retrofit airplane altimeters to ensure they are not susceptible to 5G wireless interference will likely miss the July 2023 and March 2023 deadlines. This could impact the summer international travel season.

images.alt_text: AirAsia joins peers including Thai Airways International in scrambling to right-size their fleets to cater for a jump in tourists from China, which now allows people to come and go freely without quarantine.
Airlines traditionally disclose few financial details of their loyalty programmes — including their primary source of revenue.

site_title: Goldman cuts US recession odds to 25% on jobs, business outlook
summary: Goldman Sachs has cut its estimate for the probability of a US recession in the next 12 months to 25% from 35%, citing a persistently strong jobs market and improving business sentiment. This reduces the risk compared to Bloomberg's survey, which indicated a 65% chance of a downturn. The strong labor market, with over 500,000 jobs added in January, supports the Federal Reserve's view of a "soft landing" for the economy.

images.alt_text: The exterior of the Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve Board Building is seen in Washington, D.C., U.S., June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Sarah Silbiger

site_title: UK steps up planning for digital pound currency backed by BOE
summary: The UK is planning to develop a digital pound currency, dubbed "Britcoin," which would be backed by the Bank of England and issued alongside physical banknotes. The move aims to keep the government involved in supplying money and provide a trusted, accessible, and easy-to-use alternative to online transactions. A consultation paper will be published, and a decision on the project is expected around the middle of the decade. The digital currency will be linked to sterling, and holders will not be able to earn interest on their coins. Critics have raised concerns about financial exclusion and the potential for the phasing out of physical notes and coins.

images.alt_text: The British Retail Consortium said spending in store chains rose by 4.2 per cent in annual terms in January, weaker than December’s 6.9 per cent rise and lagging behind inflation which signified a fall in sales volumes.
The FCA will be given supervision and enforcement powers over AML-complying cryptoasset businesses promoting cryptoassets, such as forcing a company to take down its website.

site_title: Singapore shares decline at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.01%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.01% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,385.58. The decline follows a negative overnight session in US and European markets, driven by concerns over Federal Reserve policy and US-China relations. Gainers and losers were evenly matched, with top gainers including Thai Beverage (1.5%) and Capitaland Ascott Trust (0.9%). Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC rose 0.5%, 0.1%, and 0.2% respectively.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand India Trust reported its distribution per unit rose 9 per cent to S$0.0391 in the six months ended Dec 31, 2022.

site_title: Avaya board accused of ‘massive fraud’ in suit by bondholders
summary: AVAYA Holdings' board is accused of "massive fraud" by bondholders in a New York state court lawsuit. The investors claim to have lost over $125 million due to the board's misrepresentation of the company's finances and management. The lawsuit targets unsecured convertible notes issued in 2018 with a face value of over $100 million. Avaya sought to raise funds by refinancing the notes after releasing "rosy financial results" in the second fiscal quarter of 2022. The board's alleged actions are seen as a breach of fiduciary duty.

images.alt_text: Avaya last month disclosed that it received multiple restructuring proposals from creditor groups.

site_title: Navigating 2023: Key themes
summary: Bonds and quality assets are seen as top investment opportunities in 2023, with China's economy expected to recover due to domestic consumption. Despite inflation concerns, interest rates are expected to stabilize, and the severity of economic recession in major economies may be clearer. Analysts predict the US Federal Reserve will continue to raise interest rates, but at a slower pace. Asia's growing economy is expected to drive dollar asset diversification, and retail investors are expected to drive growth in exchange-traded funds (ETFs).

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
An employee works on a vehicle assembly line at a JAC Automotive factory in Qingzhou, in China's eastern Shandong province on January 31, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

People in the main tourist and shopping area Nanjing street, in Shanghai, China, 27 January 2023. Standard Chartered said it expects China to be an "important driver" for global recovery in the second half of 2023.

Travelers in the departure hall at the Hongqiao Railway Station in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, Jan. 19, 2023. With China's 296 million migrant workers on the move this year, factories and local governments are bracing for disruptions during a longer-than-usual holiday period. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Credit Suisse is delaying compensation day for some of its bankers
summary: Credit Suisse is delaying compensation day for some of its bankers, further straining its relationship with employees as it restructures its Wall Street operations. The bankers, mainly at managing director or director level, were notified on Monday that meetings on bonuses, typically paid at the end of the month, have been cancelled. Discussions may be rescheduled in the coming weeks, following a commitment for a $500 million US injection into the business received in October. A spokesperson for Credit Suisse declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Management alpha key to growth
summary: Singapore's UOB private wealth business is poised for growth under the leadership of Managing Director Chew Mun Yew, who believes a strong leader is key to making the right decisions and driving performance. The bank has a strong Asian presence, a trusted regulatory framework, and a network of branches, making it an attractive option for entrepreneurial clients. UOB's assets under management for private wealth rose 4% to S$139 billion in 2021, with a record high in new net asset inflows. Chew aims to expand the business to a size where it can compete effectively with scale, with a target of S$100 billion to S$120 billion in assets under management.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
UOB has priced S$850 million in 5.25 per cent perpetual capital securities on Thursday (Jan 12), which will be first callable in 2028.
OCBC last month launched what it styled as an “integrated lifestyle and banking branch” at Wisma Atria, along the Orchard Road shopping belt.

site_title: Taking the long view
summary: Capital Group's Jeik Sohn advises investors to maintain exposure to risk assets and compounding returns to build their retirement pot, despite the challenging 2022 market. Sohn notes that inflation is easing, equity market leadership is shifting, and a moderate recession in the US is expected, creating buying opportunities. Bonds are also at an attractive level, with income at the highest levels in 15 years. For long-term investors, Sohn recommends a balanced portfolio and focusing on fundamentals rather than market timing, as "time in the market" beats "timing the market."

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
2022 has been challenging for stocks and bonds, but Capital Group's Mike Gitlin says it is now possible to obtain a yield of 7.5 per cent from a portfolio of investment-grade and high-yield bonds

site_title: Google to release ChatGPT-like bot named Bard
summary: Google plans to release an experimental chatbot named Bard, aiming to compete with Microsoft-backed ChatGPT, a language AI app that has gained popularity since its release in November. The move comes as Google faces pressure to respond to ChatGPT's success, with the company's earnings falling short of investor expectations. Bard, based on LaMDA, will be made available for testing and is expected to be widely available to the public in the coming weeks, combining the breadth of the world's knowledge with the power of large language models.

images.alt_text: The OpenAI website ChatGPT about page on laptop computer arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Thursday, Jan. 12, 2023. Microsoft Corp. is in discussions to invest as much as $10 billion in OpenAI, the creator of viral artificial intelligence bot ChatGPT, according to people familiar with its plans. Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
Microsoft has been preparing to add ChatGPT to Bing to offer better, more precise answers to queries, rather than a list of links.

site_title: Seeking luxe real estate
summary: The Singapore real estate market is expected to remain buoyant in 2023, driven by strong demand and limited supply, particularly in the luxury segment. Despite inflationary pressures and potential global downturns, the post-pandemic opening up of economies is expected to spur urban transformation. Luxury apartment prices have nearly doubled in the past five years, with the average freehold new launch price in core central region areas averaging S$3,000 psf. The government's marketing efforts and business-friendly environment have also attracted private wealth, driving up rental rates and transaction activity.

images.alt_text:

site_title: JPMorgan sees US ETF market doubling to US$15 trillion in five years
summary: JPMorgan predicts the US ETF market will more than double to $15 trillion by 2028, up from $7 trillion currently, driven by explosive growth. The industry saw record growth last year with 430 new funds launched, despite stocks and bonds experiencing their worst returns in decades. This growth is attributed to increasing investor demand for ETFs, with asset management arm JPMorgan Asset Management's global head, Bryon Lake, stating that the industry is "just on the very beginning cusp of what could be substantial growth."

site_title: US: Stocks hit by worries over Fed, US-China tensions
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, falling 0.1% to 33,891.02, due to worries over Federal Reserve policy and US-China tensions. A strong employment and services sector report raised concerns the Fed may extend aggressive measures to combat inflation. The 10-year US Treasury note yield increased, reflecting these concerns.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 51.57 points, or 0.15 per cent, at the open to 33,874.44.

site_title: Microsoft schedules mystery event for Tuesday as company accelerates AI investments
summary: Microsoft is set to hold a mysterious event on Tuesday, where it will share progress on several AI projects, including its plans to integrate ChatGPT into Bing search engine. The move is part of the company's accelerated investments in AI, following a reported $10 billion investment in OpenAI. This comes as Google also releases its ChatGPT rival, Bard, for testing, and both companies compete in the growing generative AI market.

site_title: Adani crisis spills into street protests as losses top US$110b
summary: Hundreds of Indian opposition party members protested in the streets, calling for a probe into allegations against Adani Group, a conglomerate accused of stock market manipulation and use of tax havens by a US short-seller. The group's cumulative market losses now top US$110 billion, sparking fears of wider financial contagion. The protests come amid questions about Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's close connections with Adani, with state-backed Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) and State Bank of India (SBI) also under scrutiny for investments in the Adani Group.

images.alt_text: The Adani Group denies all Hindenburg’s allegations, but the fall in the value of its stocks led it to call off last week a US$2.5 billion share sale by Adani Enterprises.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand India Trust,  Boustead Singapore, Boustead Projects, YKGI
summary: CapitaLand India Trust reported a 9% increase in distribution per unit to S$0.0391 for the six months ended Dec 31, 2022. This rise was attributed to higher portfolio occupancy and income from acquired buildings. Meanwhile, Boustead Singapore made a voluntary offer to take its real estate subsidiary, Boustead Projects, private at S$0.90 per share, with both counters ending Monday 0.6% higher.

site_title: ChatGPT will lead to layoffs, but traders not worried
summary: Investors remain largely unfazed by potential job displacement due to advanced artificial intelligence, with 2/3 of respondents in the financial sector not viewing their own jobs as being at risk. Despite this, AI-generated tools like ChatGPT have sparked excitement among investors, with 49% planning to buy stocks with exposure to such tools. Many companies, including Alphabet and Microsoft, are investing heavily in AI, but some are cutting jobs, with 11% of respondents believing the layoffs are too small or just right.

images.alt_text: Microsoft’s investment in OpenAI and aggressive efforts to make ChatGPT widely available to its cloud customers, among other plans, represent a new challenge to Alphabet.

site_title: China balloon, polls scramble script for Biden speech to Congress
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to deliver his State of the Union speech on Tuesday, overshadowed by a mysterious Chinese balloon's dramatic downing by a US Air Force fighter. Polls show Biden's approval ratings are low, with only 37% of respondents supporting his re-election bid. The polls also indicate that Democrats are divided, with 58% saying the party should find someone else for 2024. Despite the challenges, Biden's speechwriters are optimistic about the economy's strong performance, with low unemployment and steady job creation.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on December 15, 2022 US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen meets with President of Senegal Macky Sall during the US - Africa Leaders Summit at the Walter E. Washington Convention Center in Washington, DC. - US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is heading for an 11-day trip to Africa starting this week, aimed at deepening economic ties on the continent where China has become a key player. (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)
President Joe Biden announces his plan to send M1 Abrams tanks to Ukraine, Jan 25, 2023.

site_title: Asia ex-Japan equities beckon
summary: Asia ex-Japan equities are seen as promising in 2023 due to China's reopening, with the lifting of citywide lockdowns expected to increase domestic consumption and boost tourism-related sectors. Experts, such as Hou Wey Fook of DBS Bank, are overweight on the region, citing attractive valuations and supportive policies for growth prospects. China's pivot away from zero-Covid and renewed focus on quality growth are also seen as tailwinds, particularly for domestic-oriented sectors.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
The benchmark Hang Seng Index surged 522.13 points, or 2.37 per cent, to close at 22,566.78, the highest since Mar 2, 2022.

site_title: Asia can attract more FDI with greener treaties: ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) recommends that Asian economies adopt more environmentally ambitious approaches in negotiating new investment agreements to attract foreign direct investment (FDI) from green industries. The bank found that economies with climate change and environmental elements in their bilateral investment treaties benefited from greater FDI flows. ADB proposes the inclusion of substantive standards on environmental protection and climate change in existing agreements, as well as regulatory immunity for climate policy measures. The bank also warns of a "pollution haven effect" in Asia, where FDI can lead to environmental degradation, but notes that green FDI can promote efficient energy consumption and renewable energy generation.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

Indonesian officials are also working with representatives of the US and other wealthy countries on a “just energy transition package” set to include millions of dollars in funding to support a move away from coal.
A zero carbon economy could hardly be counted as a victory for the path towards net zero if it comes at the expense of the livelihoods of local communities.

Solar panels on the rooftop of an HDB block in Ang Mo Kio. Singapore is looking to quadruple its solar energy deployment by 2025 by covering the rooftops of its public housing blocks with solar panels.
While others in South-east Asia remained in negative territory last month, most saw manufacturing conditions improve.

site_title: Amid excitement over tourism rebound, don’t overlook industrial S-Reit resilience
summary: Singapore-listed industrial real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have seen resilience amidst the tourism rebound, with Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust being the top performer with 8.6% returns in January. While the hospitality and retail sectors have gained attention, investors should consider the industrial space for potential upside. Despite the economic recovery, companies have been laid off, and the global AI talent war continues to impact various sectors. The EU-China summit is set to take place later this month, with implications for global trade and investment.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
In 2022, Keppel DC Reit was among the 18 S-Reits that announced acquisitions, expanding its presence in London, and in Guangdong, one of China’s most established data centre markets.

The first batch of China Rse onshore C-Reits, with an aggregate value of 31.2 trillion yuan (about S$6 billion), hold infrastructure assets ranging from toll roads and waste treatment plants to logistics and industrial parks. 
Since 2021, the C-Reit market has grown exponentially, raising a total capital of more than 75 billion yuan, or more than S$15 billion, with the listing of 24 infrastructure and rental housing Reits as of December 2022.
The partial offer for Sabana Reit is not particularly compelling, but could have implications for its future direction.

site_title: China’s rapid Covid reopening tests PBOC’s easing path
summary: China's rapid Covid-19 reopening has altered the People's Bank of China's (PBOC) easing path, with the central bank relying on structural tools to support the economy. Despite a faster-than-expected recovery, sectors such as property and exports remain weak, potentially necessitating further stimulus. The PBOC may still cut interest rates or reserve requirements, but inflation is expected to rise to 2.2% in January, limiting options. The yuan has strengthened as investors forecast the Federal Reserve to slow its tightening, narrowing the yield gap between US and Chinese sovereign bonds.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China building in Beijing. Source: Bloomberg
The move also comes amid expectations that Chinese authorities will do more to stimulate the country’s Covid-ravaged economy.
FILE PHOTO: Headquarters of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), the central bank, is pictured in Beijing, China September 28, 2018. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Oil rises 1% in choppy trade on China demand hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 1.3% to $80.99 a barrel, driven by hopes of increased demand from China. Brent futures for April delivery increased $1.05, while West Texas Intermediate crude gained 72 cents. The price rise came despite supply concerns and fears of slower growth in major economies.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures crawled up 16 cents, or 0.2 per cent, to US$80.10 a barrel at 0022 GMT.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as strong US data stokes rate hike jitters
summary: European shares fell 0.8% on Monday, retreating from a nine-month high, amid concerns about the global interest rate-hiking cycle persisting longer than expected. The decline was driven by rate-sensitive technology and real estate shares, with retail stocks also falling 2.2%. Fears of elevated Sino-US tensions and strong US job growth data have rekindled worries about prolonged high interest rates, while the European Central Bank struck a relatively hawkish tone after raising rates by 50 basis points.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 0.1 per cent to 33,891.02 on Monday.

site_title: US plans 200% tariff on Russia aluminium as soon as this week
summary: The US is set to impose a 200% tariff on Russian-made aluminium as early as this week, targeting Moscow's role as a global commodities powerhouse amid the one-year anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The move aims to counter Russia's dumping of aluminium supplies on the US market and harm American companies. The tariff would effectively end US imports of the metal from Russia, which has traditionally accounted for around 3% of total US aluminium imports. The US and EU are working together to blunt Russia's influence in the commodities market, with the EU banning imports of Russian oil, gas, and fuels.

images.alt_text: The exclusions cover 81 medical-care products, and the exemptions stem from the US battle against the Covid-19 pandemic.
Goldman sees the aluminium, used to make everything from beer cans to plane parts, climbing to US$3,750 a ton in the next 12 months.

site_title: Turkey’s Ceyhan oil terminal, Iraq’s KRG pipeline halted after quake
summary: A magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck southern Turkey and northwest Syria on Monday, halting operations at Turkey's Ceyhan oil terminal and Iraq's KRG pipeline. The Turkish pipeline operator Botas reported no damage to main pipelines, while Iraq's KRG halted flows through the pipeline, which carried 400,000 barrels per day. Oil exports will resume after a pipeline inspection is finalized. The eastern Mediterranean terminal of Ceyhan is 155 km from the quake's epicentre, and state pipeline operator BOTAS also halted natural gas flows due to damage to a gas transmission line.

images.alt_text: People try to help victims at the site of a collapsed building after an earthquake in Diyarbakir, Turkey, 6 Feb, 2023.

site_title: The art of foreign policy ‘muddling through’ in the US
summary: President Joe Biden's foreign policy approach is characterized by a "playing-by-ear-as-you-go" modus operandi, often driven by reactive rather than deliberate decisions. This "muddling through" process has led to unexpected outcomes, such as the US entry into World War II and the evolution of its strategy in the Pacific and Europe. Biden's decisions, like increasing military aid to Ukraine, have expanded US goals beyond initial plans, but he has refrained from declaring a total military victory or seeking direct US intervention. Instead, he aims to maintain Congressional and public support while building a stronger NATO and containing China's rise.

images.alt_text: Ukrainian troops in a tank in the Bakhmut district of eastern Ukraine. The West has committed to sending advanced battle tanks to help Ukraine against Russia.
US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin meets with Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr in Manila on Feb 2. The US now has access to nine military bases in the Philippines.

site_title: One-time passwords marked ‘Likely-SCAM’ could breed complacency
summary: A recent SMS scam prevention initiative has encountered issues, with legitimate messages being marked as likely scams. This has raised concerns that the public may become complacent, undermining the initiative's effectiveness. The problem is expected to be temporarily resolved, but new loopholes will likely be found and exploited. Experts emphasize the need to find better ways to communicate and secure accounts against fraudulent use, rather than relying solely on SMSes as an authentication factor.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
People wearing masks with mobile phone at Pagoda Street along Chinatown on April 6, 2021.
From Jan 31, SMS from organisations that have not registered with the SSIR will be marked "Likely-SCAM".
Organisations will need to register SMS sender IDs with IMDA, with registrations opening on Oct 31, 2022.
MAS said on Jul 18 that the development of the framework for equitable sharing of losses from scams is taking longer than expected “in view of the complexity of the issues”

site_title: Rothschild family to take Paris-listed investment bank private
summary: The Rothschild family plans to take its Paris-listed investment bank, Rothschild & Co, private, citing a desire for long-term performance assessment and reduced market scrutiny. The family's largest shareholder, Concordia, will file a tender offer for the bank's shares at 48 euros each, representing a 19% premium. The private ownership plan aims to strengthen the family's grip on the bank, which has grown beyond deal-making into wealth management, private equity, and debt financing.

site_title: Close to S$1 billion committed for Career Conversion Programmes, helping more than 40,000 so far
summary: Singapore has committed close to S$1 billion for Career Conversion Programmes (CCPs), supporting over 40,000 local workers since 2016. The Capability Transfer Programme (CTP) has also committed S$5 million to projects supporting over 1,000 local workers. Take-up of the CTP has been low due to pandemic travel restrictions, but is expected to increase with the resumption of international travel. Additionally, around 200,000 locals were placed into jobs, traineeships, and attachment opportunities under the SGUnited Jobs and Skills Package, with 80% of them being placed into permanent jobs.

images.alt_text: Any unemployment support measures will likely be for vulnerable workers, such as those who are older, have lower-income, or are less educated, one economist told The Business Times.
Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.

site_title: Adani’s UK units dropped Deloitte as auditor for smaller firm
summary: Adani Group, an Indian conglomerate, dropped Deloitte as its UK auditor and replaced it with Crowe UK, a smaller firm, after buying its UK entities in 2021. This move comes as Adani seeks to restore confidence in its financial health following a short seller attack that wiped out $118 billion of its market value. The decision was made after Hindenburg Research accused Adani of accounting fraud and stock price manipulation. Adani's UK subsidiaries include renewable power plants across India, which were sold to Adani Green Energy Limited in 2021.

images.alt_text: Debt investors are contemplating heavy losses on their holdings if Gautam Adani is unable to restore confidence and stem the losses in his industrial empire.

site_title: Tech winter dulls the shine of employee stock ownership plans
summary: Employee Stock Ownership Plans (Esop) have lost luster for startup employees in South-east Asia due to falling tech valuations and uncertainty around initial public offerings (IPOs). Regional unicorns, including Grab, GoTo Group, and Bukalapak, have seen their valuations decline, reducing the potential upside from Esop. Some employees are opting for higher cash salaries instead, and Esop values may be impacted if employees struggle to exercise their options and realize value. To mitigate this, founders should consider setting a reasonable exercise price and accelerated vesting in the event of layoffs.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
A valuations soften, some startups are raising money to make acquisitions.
Esop fables: A cautionary tale for those joining startups
The days of unicorns running rampant may well be over.

site_title: BOE officials say Brexit fuelling inflation, driving up rates
summary: Bank of England officials, Huw Pill and Catherine Mann, warned that Brexit is fueling inflation and driving up interest rates in the UK. Pill stated that the UK's departure from the EU has not led to any positive economic impact, and the trade blow is contributing to the economy overheating. The BOE is monitoring the situation closely and may adjust interest rates to manage demand and supply imbalances. The comments are likely to anger some Conservative members of Parliament, who have previously criticized the central bank's pessimistic outlook on the UK's post-Brexit prospects.

site_title: Asean needs to keep the pressure on Myanmar
summary: Asean is urged to maintain pressure on Myanmar's junta, which has shown no intention of adhering to a five-point peace plan. Since the coup, over 2,940 civilians have been killed and 17,570 arrested, with many remaining in jail. The junta has considerable revenue from natural resources, making meaningful change unlikely soon. Asean's relevance and credibility are at stake in addressing the crisis, and the bloc should push for talks among the parties involved, including telling the junta leaders of their lack of legitimacy and the need to implement the peace plan.

site_title: Yellen says US can avoid recession with unemployment at 53-year low
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the US can avoid a recession with the unemployment rate at a 53-year low of 3.4% and inflation declining significantly. She cited the strength of the labor market and measures adopted by the Biden administration to reduce the cost of gasoline and prescription drugs. Yellen also emphasized the need for Congress to raise the US debt limit, warning of an economic catastrophe if it fails to do so. The economy remains strong, with job growth accelerating sharply in January and inflation expected to continue declining.

images.alt_text: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's department will be deploying two special accounting manoeuvres to avoid breaching the debt limit.

site_title: Vietnam seizes 600 kg of ivory smuggled from Africa
summary: Vietnamese authorities have seized over 600 kilograms of ivory smuggled from Africa, the largest seizure in the country in over four years. The ivory was found hidden in a container of cow horns at Haiphong Port and nearly 500 kilograms at Lach Huyen Port. The trade in ivory is illegal in Vietnam, but wildlife trafficking remains widespread, with other items such as pangolin scales, rhino horns, and tiger carcasses often found smuggled into the country.

site_title: Climate tech beckons
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) estimates that the global energy sector has a $126 trillion investible opportunity to reach net zero by 2050, spanning 30 years. This presents a significant opportunity for investors in climate tech and green infrastructure. A roundtable discussion featured experts discussing the potential for green growth and the need for improved carbon credit frameworks. The conversation highlights the growing importance of sustainable finance and the need for businesses to transition towards green technologies.

images.alt_text: Carbon capture facilities, such as this one in China, are gaining in popularity and interest; but what are some of the pitfalls investors in such projects should be aware of? PHOTO: REUTERS

site_title: China urges restraint as US military searches for balloon remnants
summary: China urged the US to show restraint as the military searched for remnants of a Chinese surveillance balloon it shot down over the Atlantic, claiming it was a civilian craft that accidentally drifted astray. China denies the balloon was for espionage, saying it was for scientific purposes. The incident has strained relations between the two countries, prompting the US to cancel a planned visit by Secretary of State Antony Blinken. China hopes the US will work with them to properly handle differences and avoid miscalculations.

images.alt_text: With China’s economy reeling and relations with neighbours and countries in Europe strained, restraint and prudence are in its own interests.

site_title: Wuhan eases key home-buying ban to arrest China housing slump
summary: Wuhan, China's eighth-most populous city, has eased a key restriction on housing purchases, allowing local families to buy an additional home in areas with purchasing caps. This move aims to boost demand in the country's struggling property market. The city, where Covid-19 cases first emerged, has modified the restriction based on home prices and inventory, following the central bank's relaxation of mortgage rate rules. The easing has strong implications, showing that even hard rules can be made more flexible, according to experts.

images.alt_text: Local government financing vehicles are propping up China's ailing land market by snapping up residential land sales.

site_title: Saudi Arabia says tech giants to invest more than US$9b in kingdom
summary: Saudi Arabia has attracted over $9 billion in investments in future technologies, including cloud regions from Microsoft ($2.1 billion) and Oracle ($1.5 billion), and $400 million from Huawei. The investments aim to enhance the kingdom's position as the largest digital market in the Middle East and North Africa. The investments follow Saudi officials' push for international companies to invest in the kingdom and move their regional headquarters to Riyadh to benefit from government contracts. The investments are part of Saudi Arabia's economic plan, Vision 2030, led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

images.alt_text: Though Oracle lags its bigger rivals in the race to corner the cloud computing market, it was among the first large tech companies to open a data centre in Saudi Arabia.
Saudi Tabreed provides district cooling services to major urban developments across Saudi Arabia and the Gulf region.

site_title: US dollar surges on robust US jobs data; lira, yen slump
summary: The US dollar surged to a three-week high against the euro, reaching 103.40 on the US dollar index, amid strong US jobs data and expectations of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates above 5% to combat inflation. The euro slipped to its lowest level since January 12 at US$1.0757. The Turkish lira hit a record low of 18.85 against the US dollar, while the yen weakened after reports of a potential Bank of Japan policy shift.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on Fed fears; Tyson Foods slides
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones falling 51.57 points, or 0.15%, to 33,874.44, amid concerns about the US Federal Reserve's interest rate cuts. Tyson Foods slid on disappointing quarterly results. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 16.91 points, or 0.41%, and the Nasdaq down 102.55 points, or 0.85%. Investors reassessed their predictions on when the Fed would start cutting rates.

site_title: Thai protesters weak after three weeks on hunger strike
summary: Two Thai protesters, Tantawan Tuatulanon and Orawan Phupong, have been on a nearly three-week hunger strike, refusing food and most liquids, to demand the abolition of Thailand's lese majeste laws and other justice reforms. They were charged with lese majeste over protests in 2022 and are growing weak, with their kidneys starting to work more slowly. The protesters have agreed to take liquids and some minerals, but their condition remains critical, with rights groups describing their situation as "heart-wrenching".

images.alt_text: Mass cremation for victimes of a mass shooting in northeastern Nong Bua Lam Phu province on October 11, 2022. A former policeman, who was discharged from duty for drug use, went on a knife and gun rampage killing 37 people, including 24 children.

site_title: Hedge funds in bigger squeeze than 2021 meme-stock frenzy: Goldman Sachs
summary: Hedge funds rapidly exited bearish positions last week, surpassing the speed of their 2021 exit from meme stocks, according to Goldman Sachs. The largest short positions were in industrials and IT companies, with exits in Asian markets and Chinese equities also reported. The rapid exit was driven by a sharp rally in equities following the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate hike slowdown, with the Nasdaq rising 3.3% on February 2. This led to a sell-off the next day, sparking concerns about the Fed's monetary tightening.

images.alt_text: With the exception of Apple, eight tech giants are no longer "pure growth" stocks, while Exxon and Chevron are, a new study says. Buyer, beware.
The MSCI World Stock Index has slipped 0.1 per cent, but was still near its highest since August following a sharp rebound in recent weeks.

site_title: More than 100,000 green jobs announced since US adopted climate law: study
summary: US President Joe Biden's landmark climate bill, the Inflation Reduction Act, has led to over 100,000 green jobs announced in the US since its passage, according to a study by Climate Power. The group found nearly $90 billion in new investments in clean-energy projects across 31 states, with the majority in seven states, including Georgia, which is expected to produce 17,000 jobs. The bill's tax credits and incentives are driving the economic boom in clean energy, with CEO Lori Lodes stating that the law's impact will benefit people's lives and make it durable.

images.alt_text: When companies set ambitious targets for themselves and at the same time demand greater commitment and transparency from their top suppliers, pressure for action will build up along entire value chains.
The lease sale was one of several previously cancelled offerings reinstated in the Democrats’ climate spending bill signed into law in August.

The House voted 220-207 along party lines to pass the measure titled the “Inflation Reduction Act” and send it on to Biden to sign into law. The Senate approved the legislation on Sunday after a marathon, 27-hour session.

site_title: Public sector to drive sustainable bond issuance in Asean in 2023: Moody’s
summary: Moody's predicts public sectors in Southeast Asian countries will drive sustainable bond issuance in 2023, as governments push for low-carbon economies through green policies and taxonomies. The Asean taxonomy's "traffic light" approach provides granularity to companies' economic activities, enabling issuers to finance transition activities aligned with local taxonomies. This trend is expected to gain momentum as reporting standards and taxonomies improve, encouraging companies to promote carbon transition.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

investors are asking ESG-related questions relating to businesses – referring to sustainability ratings and metrics when assessing an organisation’s suitability for inclusion in their investment portfolios.
Globally, ESG bond proceeds fell 52.9 per cent to US$133.3 billion in Q4 2022, compared to the US$203.8 billion in the same quarter in 2021.
ESG bond volumes swelled over the past few years but dropped by 22 per cent in 2022 amid a broader slowdown in corporate bond issues.

site_title: AGO’s FY2022/23 audits to cover S$32.3b in Covid-19 spending; includes JSS, Rental Relief Framework
summary: The Auditor-General's Office (AGO) will cover S$32.3 billion in Covid-19 spending in its FY2022/23 audits, including the Jobs Support Scheme, Rental Relief Framework, and other schemes. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said the audits are part of a "risk-based approach" and will focus on expenditure incurred by agencies. Over half of the S$72.3 billion in total Covid-19 spending has been audited, with the remaining audits expected to be completed by the end of FY2024.

Checks should be conducted to ensure transactions were bona fide and that there was no erroneous payment, said Public Accounts Committee chairman Foo Mee Har. ST PHOTO: KEVIN LIM
Singapore spent S$72.3 billion on Covid-19 in FY2020 and FY2021, less than budgeted

site_title: F-22 makes first air-to-air strike in Chinese balloon takedown
summary: The US F-22 fighter jet successfully shot down a Chinese spy balloon off the South Carolina coast, marking the first air-to-air strike for the aircraft since its combat debut in Syria and Iraq in 2014. The F-22 fired an Aim-9X Sidewinder missile at the balloon hovering at 60,000-65,000 feet. This incident is considered the highest altitude air-to-air kill ever, with defence analysts praising the US military's action. The downing of the balloon was seen as a significant event, with Rebecca Grant stating that Americans witnessed an unfriendly aircraft being shot down over their skies.

images.alt_text: With China’s economy reeling and relations with neighbours and countries in Europe strained, restraint and prudence are in its own interests.

site_title: Singapore bears ‘no financial impact’ from Sun Cable collapse: MTI
summary: Singapore bears no financial impact from the collapse of Sun Cable's plan to send electricity from Australia, according to Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) has clarified technical requirements with Sun Cable but made no financial commitments. Singapore remains on track to import up to 4 GW of low-carbon electricity by 2035, with discussions with other companies in progress. The country continues to work on decarbonizing its power generation, exploring alternative sources such as hydrogen and geothermal energy.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
While it would be a sweet victory for climate goals to see this radical project take fruition, Sun Cable’s fate has been eclipsed by shareholder spat

site_title: How to invest your first S$100,000
summary: Investing $100,000 requires a personalized approach, mapping core life needs to specific portfolios. A framework should define asset classes and investment strategies based on environment and goals. For a rainy-day fund, allocate $20,000 to diversified cash and money market funds, while for near-term goals, consider a balanced portfolio of globally diversified stocks and bonds. Long-term and retirement plans can be invested aggressively, with the power of compounding driving growth. With $1 million, a wider range of strategies can be explored, but it's essential to be discerning and aligned with goals.

images.alt_text: With the exception of Apple, eight tech giants are no longer "pure growth" stocks, while Exxon and Chevron are, a new study says. Buyer, beware.

site_title: Trustee of Laguna National mired in conflict of interest; shouldn’t be involved in club’s winding up, court told
summary: A trustee of Laguna National Golf & Country Club is being questioned by a court over a potential conflict of interest in the club's winding-up process. The trustee, British and Malayan Trustees, had "turned a blind eye" to issues and failed to disclose information, raising doubts about its objectivity. The club was insolvent as early as 2016 and owed millions to noteholders, who are seeking to wind up the club. The court heard that the trustee had neglected its duties and failed to declare an Event of Default, which could have protected the assets and recovered debts.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

site_title: Beijing says second balloon flying over Latin America is Chinese
summary: China has confirmed that a balloon spotted flying over Latin America was Chinese, stating it was a civilian weather surveillance instrument that deviated from its course due to "weather forces". The US shot down the balloon on Saturday, prompting China to lodge a formal complaint and express fury at Washington's decision. China also confirmed another Chinese balloon had been seen across Latin America, with investigations underway to establish the object's origins. The US says the downing of the balloon was necessary to block it from collecting sensitive information.

images.alt_text: With China’s economy reeling and relations with neighbours and countries in Europe strained, restraint and prudence are in its own interests.
China on Friday expressed regret that an “airship” used for civilian meteorological and other scientific purposes had strayed into US airspace.

site_title: UK watchdog warns crypto firms to prepare for advertising rule change
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) warned crypto firms to prepare for a rule change on advertising later in 2024, allowing compliant cryptoasset businesses to issue their own promotions without approval. The FCA will gain supervision and enforcement powers to enforce the new rules, with breaches potentially resulting in up to two years in prison. The government will reduce the implementation period to four months from six months, emphasizing the high risk of cryptoassets and the potential for consumers to lose all their money.

site_title: Man City referred to commission over alleged financial rule breaches
summary: Manchester City has been referred to an independent commission by the Premier League over alleged breaches of financial rules from 2009-10 to 2012-13, including failing to disclose managerial remuneration. The breaches relate to accurate financial information, including revenue, related parties, and operating costs. The allegations come after the club was acquired by its Abu Dhabi-based owners, City Football Group, in 2008. The Premier League will investigate the claims and determine the outcome.

site_title: Deutsche Bank is looking at strategic job cuts, UK CEO says
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering strategic job cuts to maintain cost targets amid inflationary pressures. UK & Ireland CEO Tiina Lee stated the bank needs to "maintain a laser focus on costs" and is looking to adjust headcount. The bank has previously failed to meet expense-reduction targets, and CEO Christian Sewing has vowed to rein in spending through staff reductions and other initiatives. While some areas, such as consumer banking, may be cut, others, like trading operations, are expected to be spared. The bank aims to keep expenses at last year's level despite inflation.

site_title: MOM ‘considering’ extending Heightened Safety Period beyond February
summary: The six-month heightened safety period (HSP) in Singapore, which began on September 1, 2022, may be extended beyond its planned end-date of February. The Ministry of Manpower is reviewing "the next steps" and considering further measures to strengthen workplace safety and health incentives and culture. Since the HSP's start, 760 composition fines and 48 stop work orders have been issued, with 15 companies barred from hiring new foreign employees for up to three months due to serious WSH lapses.

images.alt_text: For listed companies, ensuring a safe working environment also ties in with environmental, social and governance (ESG) responsibilities.
BCA expects 60 per cent of construction demand to come from the public sector.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singaporeans living overseas will be able to vote by post in future elections if proposed changes to two sets of electoral laws are passed. The government will also provide up to S$180 million annually to support SPH Media Trust's transformation for five years. Six former Keppel O&M staff received stern warnings for bribery offences, despite a lack of evidence. More businesses are seeking support to expand overseas and reduce foreign worker levies in Budget 2023.

site_title: Record UK health strike piles pressure on stretched service
summary: UK healthcare workers are on record-breaking strikes, crippling the National Health Service (NHS) amid a surge in Covid cases and other illnesses. The strikes, involving 100,000 nurses and 10,000 ambulance workers, are over pay disputes, with unions claiming years of real-term pay cuts. The government, led by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, has offered a 4% pay rise, but unions are demanding higher pay to address staff shortages and rising living costs. The strikes have already delayed 90,000 appointments and may lead to further disruptions, with junior doctors and senior medics also considering action.

images.alt_text: Nurses and ambulance workers are due to stand side-by-side on picket lines for the first time on Feb 6, in an escalation of their campaign against below-inflation raises.

Striking teachers march during joint strike action by train drivers, teachers, university staff and civil servants, in Leeds, UK, on Wednesday, Feb 1, 2023. The day of coordinated industrial action is expected to be Britain’s most severe day of strikes for over a decade.

site_title: Thai inflation drops to nine-month low
summary: Thailand's headline inflation cooled to its lowest rate in nine months, rising 5% in January from a year earlier, below analyst forecasts. The core CPI index was up 3% in January, and the Ministry of Commerce maintained its forecast for headline inflation between 2% and 3% in 2023. Despite this, the inflation rate remains above the Bank of Thailand's target range, suggesting a potential interest rate hike. The central bank will review its policy on March 29, with the Minister of Finance predicting inflation will return to target this year.

images.alt_text: Tourists visit the Grand Palace, one of the top tourist attraction spots as Thailand is expecting arrivals of Chinese tourists after China reopens its borders amid the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic, in Bangkok, Thailand, January 7, 2023. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha

AirAsia joins peers including Thai Airways International in scrambling to right-size their fleets to cater for a jump in tourists from China, which now allows people to come and go freely without quarantine.
The Bank of Thailand says that economic activity in the country is likely to improve steadily as tourism gains momentum.

site_title: AI startup Cohere in talks to raise funding at US$6 billion plus valuation
summary: Toronto-based AI startup Cohere, established by former Alphabet researchers in 2019, is in talks to raise hundreds of millions of US dollars in a funding round that could value the startup at over US$6 billion. Cohere competes with Microsoft-backed OpenAI in the generative AI market, which focuses on making human-like creations through computer code. The funding round is the latest sign of the investment frenzy around generative AI.

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust DPU up 9% to 3.91 S cents in H2, full-year DPU up 5% to 8.19 cents
summary: CapitaLand India Trust reported a 9% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.91 Singapore cents in the six months ended Dec 31, 2022, and a 5% increase in its full-year DPU to 8.19 cents. Total property income for H2 grew 15% to 6.2 billion rupees, resulting in a 12% rise for the full year to 11.9 billion rupees.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Amid a "general nervousness" in the market, Sanjeev Dasgupta, CEO of CapitaLand India Trust, is optimistic about India's growth trajectory.

site_title: Stern warnings to Keppel O&M ex-staff signal they are not completely off the hook: Parliament
summary: Singapore authorities have issued stern warnings to six former Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) staff for alleged bribery related to Brazilian Petrobras contracts. Despite insufficient evidence to prosecute, the warnings signal that the authorities are not completely off the hook, with Minister Indranee Rajah stating that further action may be taken if new facts come to light. The warnings were issued after the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) completed its investigation, citing evidentiary difficulties and a lack of sufficient evidence to meet the burden of proof.

Keppel O&M, a unit under Keppel Corporation, is currently working towards a merger with Sembcorp Marine (Sembmarine) after shareholders approved the proposed merger through an extraordinary general meeting last December.

site_title: Oracle to invest US$1.5 billion in Saudi Arabia, open data centre in Riyadh
summary: Oracle plans to invest US$1.5 billion in Saudi Arabia, opening its third public cloud region in Riyadh. The investment aims to expand its cloud footprint in the kingdom. Saudi officials have encouraged international companies to invest in the country, with the goal of benefiting from government contracts. Oracle's move follows increased demand for cloud computing and is part of its efforts to corner the cloud computing market.

site_title: Singapore shares begin week with meagre gains as traders tread cautiously
summary: Singapore stocks opened the week with minimal gains, as traders cautiously digested global macroeconomic data and central-bank announcements. The Straits Times Index ended flat, up 0.1% to 3,385.93, while the broader market saw decliners outpace advancers 328 to 248. Top gainers included iFast Corporation, DBS, and UOB, while Nio and Jardine Matheson Holdings were among the biggest losers. The mixed market sentiment was attributed to lower yields, with investors trying to calculate the impact of the Federal Reserve's higher interest rates.

site_title: Adani in talks to prepay loans on shares, denies report on capex cut
summary: Adani Group, facing a US$100 billion loss in market value, is in talks to prepay loans backed by pledged shares, according to a spokesperson. The group denies reports of a capital spending cut, instead planning to trim spending while providing more collateral in the form of stock pledges. Domestic lenders are not expected to cut off the conglomerate from utilizing unused credit lines, citing concerns of defaults. The company's flagship company abandoned a US$2.5 billion share sale following a US short-seller's report on debt levels and tax haven use.

site_title: Newmont bids US$17b for Australian gold miner Newcrest
summary: Newmont Mining has offered to buy Australian gold miner Newcrest Mining in a US$17 billion deal, strengthening its positions in copper and gold. The takeover would be the largest globally this year and one of the biggest in Australian history. Newcrest shares jumped 14% following the offer, driven by sustained gold price strength and increasing copper demand due to renewable energy and electric vehicle growth. The deal would also increase Newmont's copper footprint and increase its market value to nearly US$57 billion.

site_title: UK construction slips to near 3-year low but confidence rises
summary: The UK construction sector experienced its worst month in almost three years in January, with the S&P Global/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 48.4 from 48.8 in December. Rising interest rates, which reached 4% in January, negatively impacted house-building and civil engineering work, while commercial projects also declined. However, business expectations for the construction sector improved, with the gauge of new sales enquiries rising to its highest level since July last year.

site_title: German industrial orders beat expectations in December
summary: German industrial orders rose 3.2% in December, beating forecasts and posting the largest increase in over a year, driven by strong domestic and eurozone demand. This boost suggests a milder economic slowdown in winter than initially expected. The improvement in the business climate and order data indicates that the economy is stabilizing. Despite this, new orders continue to point downward, and industry experts expect the German economy to slow down this year.

site_title: More than one-third of US animals and plants at risk of extinction
summary: US animals and plants face a high risk of extinction, with 40% of animals and 34% of plants in danger of disappearing. A report by NatureServe found nearly half of US cactus species and 200 tree species are at risk, including the saguaro cactus. The report identifies areas with unprotected land as the most threatened, with California, Texas, and the southeastern US having the highest percentages of animals, plants, and ecosystems at risk. Conservationists are urging lawmakers to pass protections, such as the Recovering America's Wildlife Act, to address the biodiversity crisis.

images.alt_text: Buyers in the voluntary carbon markets must expect mixed quality in any category of carbon credits, and should identify credible project developers that can track and demonstrate impact.

Safari-goers watching elephants in South Africa. The African forest elephant is listed as “critically endangered”, and the African savanna elephant, “endangered” by the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

The landmark international biodiversity framework that came out of COP15 raises the need for businesses and investors to gain a greater understanding of the risks that biodiversity degradation presents to their bottom line and portfolios.

site_title: Institutional money staying invested in private markets, but say valuations need to adjust: survey
summary: Institutional investors in private markets believe valuations need to adjust to market conditions, with 50% citing this as a major concern. Despite rising interest rates reducing the attractiveness of highly leveraged asset classes, 70% of respondents plan to stick to their target allocations. However, there are opportunities for buying assets at a discount, with 75% of respondents believing tougher times bring opportunities. Real estate is the least favored asset class, while infrastructure is drawing more inflows from private capital. Private equity is expected to remain the top alternative asset class for new investments over the next two to three years.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Investor surveys by alternative assets data company Preqin show most investors are expecting the value of their portfolios to fall.
Blackstone cemented its stature as a powerhouse in the real estate industry with the growth in Breit in recent years.

KKR is among private equity firms that expanded their offerings to retail investors in a bid for growth as institutional investors run up against the limit of what they can allocate to alternative assets.

site_title: Goldman Sachs makes 1 billion euros biomethane bet in Europe
summary: Goldman Sachs has invested over 1 billion euros in Verdalia Bioenergy, a European company focused on biomethane production. The investment, made through the West Street Global Infrastructure Partners IV fund, aims to acquire and operate biomethane plants in Europe. Biomethane, a renewable gas, can be made from organic matter and supports European government incentives to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. Goldman's investment is expected to bring much-needed biomethane supply to Europe, contributing to the continent's decarbonisation and energy-security agenda.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars nurse heavy losses after hot US jobs data
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced heavy losses after US jobs data revealed interest rates will need to rise further. The Australian dollar slumped 2.2% to US$0.6923, its largest decline since mid-December, falling below 70 cents for the first time in two weeks. The New Zealand dollar also struggled, with traders shifting focus to the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy decision.

images.alt_text: The RBA will weigh signs of weaker hiring and household spending against a sharp acceleration in core inflation when it discusses policy settings.

Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed real retail sales dipped 0.2 per cent in the December quarter to A$96.9 billion (S$88.9 billion), a sign higher borrowing costs are finally working to curb spending.

site_title: Postal voting for overseas Singaporeans among electoral changes in new amendment Bills
summary: Singaporeans living overseas will be able to vote by post in future elections under proposed amendments to two electoral laws. Postal votes must be postmarked before Polling Day and reach the returning officer within 10 days. Overseas voters will also be able to retain their voting status unless they cancel or have their names removed. The amendments also allow for special polling stations in nursing homes and mobile polling teams to facilitate voting for residents. The changes aim to make voting more convenient and accessible for eligible voters.

site_title: ERP rates at five locations to go up by S$1 from Feb 13
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore announced that Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) rates at five locations will increase by S$1 starting February 13. The rate hikes are in response to increased traffic conditions observed in January. The affected locations include the Ayer-Rajah Expressway, Central Expressway, Kallang-Paya Lebar Expressway, and Pan-Island Expressway. The rate changes will vary by location and time period, with some experiencing a S$1 increase and others a S$2 increase.

images.alt_text: LTA said traffic has been building up on various stretches of expressways, and these changes are have been made in response to monitoring of traffic conditions throughout August this year.

site_title: China’s local government financing vehicles splurge on land shunned by developers
summary: China's local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) have purchased over half of residential land sales last year, spending 2.2 trillion yuan ($425.9 billion). This surge in land buying is driven by cash-strapped private developers avoiding land purchases amid a slump in the industry. LGFVs and national state-owned developers now dominate the land market, with national private players largely absent due to liquidity pressure. This development has raised concerns about the government's efforts to stabilize the ailing property market.

images.alt_text: In a sign of how the record downturn has hurt bottom lines, defaulted developer Shimao Group Holdings’ main unit onshore is expected to record its first full-year loss in 21 years.
Beijing has over the past years sought to reduce leverage in the economy, primarily through crackdown on shadow banking that has rocked the nation’s real estate market.
