Many Chinese companies have set up factories in Nuevo Leon, Mexico to be closer to their North American customers, while also limiting their vulnerability to shipping problems and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: 70% of BTOs launched in 2022 affordable with S$8,400 median household income: Desmond Lee
summary: National Development Minister Desmond Lee announced that nearly 70% of Build-To-Order (BTO) flats launched in 2022 can be affordably purchased with Singapore's median household income of S$8,400 at a mortgage servicing ratio of 25% or less. PSP's Leong Mun Wai proposed a "reset" in public housing policy, suggesting that new flats be priced without including land cost to maintain affordability. The government has kept BTO prices "almost flat" despite rising construction costs, with Lee emphasizing that artificially suppressing prices would distort the real market and lead to oversubscription in mature estates.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Generic photo of Toa Payoh HDB estate covered in mist on a rainy day on January 25, 2023. 
Can be used for property, low visibility, rain, weather, climate stories.

site_title: Senior Taiwan opposition leader to visit China amid continued tensions
summary: Taiwan's main opposition party, the Kuomintang (KMT), announced a high-level visit to China by its deputy chairperson, Andrew Hsia, amid continued tensions between the two sides. Hsia will meet China's Taiwan policymaker, Song Tao, and engage in exchanges and dialogue on security and regional stability. The visit is seen as a rare high-level interaction between top politicians from Taiwan and China, and comes as China has ramped up pressure on Taiwan to accept its sovereignty over the past three years.

images.alt_text: Taiwan Vice-President William Lai is widely expected to be the Democratic Progressive Party’s candidate for president in the early-2024 election.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s trip is expected to meet Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang and possibly President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Japan’s strategic imperative
summary: Japan is doubling down on its alliance with the US to ensure national security and regional stability. The country has announced a 2% increase in defense spending and a new National Security Strategy, which includes acquiring long-range missiles and strengthening its military presence in the "first island chain" off China. This move comes amid increased assertiveness from China and Russia, and Japan's neighbors are reassured that the country is not reverting to its militarist past. Maintaining the alliance with the US is considered the safest and most cost-effective option for Japan, providing a reliable security guarantee.

images.alt_text: Joseph S Nye

Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (right) and Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida (left) walks towards the exit at the end of their bilateral meeting at the Tower of London, London, on Jan 11, 2023. Japan is hosting this year’s G7 and Kishida is visiting all bloc members except Germany on a trip capped by talks in Washington on Friday with US President Joe Biden.
Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (R) and Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida (L) at the end of their meeting on Jan 11, 2023 at the Tower of London, where the two leaders signed a defence pact.

site_title: Luxury yachtmaker Ferretti seeks approval for Milan listing
summary: Italian luxury yachtmaker Ferretti is seeking Hong Kong regulatory approval for its planned Milan share sale, which could be the first dual listing between the two cities. The company, backed by China's Shandong Heavy Industry and Ferrari's founding family, plans to list in Milan as soon as the second quarter, pending regulatory approval. Ferretti's Hong Kong IPO last year raised US$257 million, and the company aims to raise around 300 million euros (S$428 million) in Milan to ensure liquidity for Italian investors. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and UniCredit are leading the Milan offering.

images.alt_text: Yacht maker Ferretti raises HK$1.9b in Hong Kong IPO

site_title: It’s time to switch from passive to active investing
summary: Active managers outperformed passive managers in the US last year for the first time in a long time, reversing a trend that has seen passive funds outperform active ones for nearly two decades. This shift is attributed to a reversal in market dynamics, including rising interest rates, a decrease in low-cost, off-shore production, and a shift away from the growth of tech stocks. As a result, active managers may be able to capitalize on the reversal and continue outperforming passive funds, particularly those that track the S&P 500 index, which is heavily weighted towards tech stocks.

images.alt_text: The MSCI World Stock Index has slipped 0.1 per cent, but was still near its highest since August following a sharp rebound in recent weeks.
With the exception of Apple, eight tech giants are no longer "pure growth" stocks, while Exxon and Chevron are, a new study says. Buyer, beware.

site_title: A million-dollar HDB resale flat makes sense for some buyers
summary: In Singapore's resale market, some HDB flats are selling for over $1 million. The attributes of a large floor area, central location, good views, and relatively new construction contribute to these high prices. Buyers, particularly those who cannot afford new HDB flats, may opt for pricey resale homes to save on capital outlay and monthly management fees. These buyers include families recycling profits from selling BTO units, homeowners downsizing to HDB units, and young couples skipping the wait for BTO units.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
In the past two years, HDB has completed 55 per cent of BTO projects delayed by pandemic-related factors.
Resale prices rose 2.3 per cent quarter on quarter, making for the slowest growth in 2022.

site_title: Way of Water finally yields to horror flick in North America theatres
summary: AVATAR: The Way of Water, a sci-fi film, has been overtaken by horror movie Knock at the Cabin in North American theatres. Knock at the Cabin earned an estimated US$14.2 million for the Friday-through-Saturday period, despite costing US$20 million to make. The film, directed by M Night Shyamalan, tells the story of a couple whose vacation is disrupted by a mysterious man who warns of an impending apocalypse unless they make a sacrifice.

site_title: Indonesia to suspend some palm oil export permits
summary: Indonesia, the world's top palm oil exporter, will suspend some export permits to secure domestic supply amid rising cooking oil prices ahead of Islamic festivals. The move aims to incentivize palm oil exporters to supply the domestic market, following a policy known as "Domestic Market Obligation" (DMO). This policy requires companies to sell a proportion of their products to the domestic market before exporting. The suspension of export permits is expected to help maintain domestic supply and reduce the impact of rising cooking oil prices.

site_title: IMF head warns American consumers would suffer if US defaulted
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva warns that a US debt default would lead to a significant spike in borrowing costs, harming American consumers and the global economy. The US debt ceiling is at $31.4 trillion, with the Treasury projecting it can be held through early June. Georgieva urges cooperation from China, the largest creditor to emerging countries, to address the debt crisis affecting 60% of low-income nations.

images.alt_text: The US Treasury is now using extraordinary measures to pay the country's bills and service its debt, as in previous years.

site_title: Japan’s Daikin picks Manchester, UK as test bed for green tech
summary: Japan's Daikin has signed an agreement with Manchester, UK to deploy heat pumps in public buildings and act as a test bed for the technology. Daikin will provide heat pumps and cooling systems to social housing, which will be monitored remotely. The partnership aims to demonstrate and promote carbon-neutral technology globally. Manchester plans to become carbon neutral in 2038, ahead of the rest of Britain. The deal includes establishing a training program for heating and cooling system skills in short supply in Britain.

site_title: Like Musk, nickel-rich Indonesia has high electric vehicle ambitions
summary: Indonesia has become a crucial player in the electric vehicle (EV) industry, leveraging its vast nickel reserves and ban on nickel ore exports. The country has signed over $15 billion deals with major manufacturers, including Hyundai, LG, and Foxconn, and is now targeting Tesla. With its exports of processed nickel reaching over $30 billion in 2022, Indonesia aims to become indispensable for the EV industry, positioning itself as a key hub for battery and electric vehicle production in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: The Philippines is the world’s second-biggest nickel-ore supplier. Its government is looking at taxing exports of the material to encourage local miners to invest in local processing, instead of just selling raw ore.

site_title: Hot stock: Ley Choon rises more than 10% to three-month high on new contract wins
summary: Ley Choon Group's shares surged 11.8% to a three-month high of S$0.019 after securing S$153 million in contracts for underground services installation and road infrastructure maintenance. The company, primarily involved in sewer pipe construction and maintenance, has not seen such highs since November 2022. Founded in 1990, Ley Choon is one of five asphalt plant operators in Singapore and has been trading near its highest levels since the announcement.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Indonesia 2022 GDP growth races to 9-year high on commodities boom
summary: Indonesia's economy experienced its strongest 9-year growth in 2022, with a 5.31% expansion driven by high global commodities prices and lifted pandemic restrictions. However, momentum slowed in the final quarter, and weaker global demand, inflation, and interest rate hikes may pose a drag on activity this year. Analysts predict growth to slow further, with some forecasting 5.04% growth in 2023, despite the central bank signaling an end to its rate hike cycle.

images.alt_text: A person walks past Bank Indonesia's headquarters in Jakarta. Indonesia exported a record US$292 billion in 2022, driven by high global commodity prices.
The 10 sites include working areas in Natuna D Alpha, which are giant gas fields in the South China Sea.

site_title: Nissan to buy up to 15% stake in Renault EV unit
summary: Nissan is set to buy up to a 15% stake in Renault's electric vehicle unit, Ampere, as part of a redesigned alliance between the two companies and Mitsubishi Motors. Renault will transfer its 28.4% stake in Nissan to a French trust, reducing its stake to 15%, allowing it to sell the shares without a specific deadline. Nissan will benefit from a right of first offer on any shares sold, making it a strategic investor in Ampere. The move aims to make the two companies more equal partners in the alliance.

site_title: Potential buyers inquiring about buying Singapore crypto lender Hodlnaut
summary: Potential buyers are inquiring about purchasing Singapore-based crypto lender Hodlnaut and its claims against bankrupt digital-asset exchange FTX. The judicial managers of Hodlnaut have signed non-disclosure agreements with interested investors. As of Dec 9, Hodlnaut owed $160.3 million to creditors, including Algorand Foundation, Samtrade Custodian, and Jean-Marc Tremeaux. The move comes after Hodlnaut sought protection from creditors, signaling a possible sale or restructuring of the company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of the Ripple, Bitcoin, Etherum and Litecoin virtual currencies are seen on a PC motherboard in this illustration picture, February 14, 2018. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Dell to cut about 6,650 jobs, battered by plunging PC sales
summary: Dell Technologies is cutting approximately 6,650 jobs, about 5% of its global workforce, due to plummeting demand for personal computers. The company, facing an uncertain future, cited market conditions that have "eroded" with a 37% decline in PC shipments compared to 2021. The layoffs are part of a restructuring effort to drive efficiency, with Dell's headcount expected to be its lowest in at least six years. The move follows similar job cuts by tech peers, including HP and Cisco Systems.

images.alt_text: The demand for smartphones and PCs initially rose during the pandemic, but started to weaken in the middle of the last year.

site_title: Thailand welcomes first Chinese tour groups after pandemic
summary: Thailand welcomed its first Chinese tour groups after the pandemic, with two groups of 20 tourists each arriving at Bangkok's airport on February 6. The groups have a six-day itinerary covering popular destinations, and the government aims to attract at least 5 million Chinese visitors this year. Despite a Covid insurance mandate, nearly 100,000 Chinese tourists have visited Thailand since February 2. Thailand expects foreign tourist arrivals to more than double this year, with tourism accounting for 12% of the country's economy. Flights from China to Thailand are expected to return to pre-pandemic levels in 2024.

images.alt_text: The government’s target of drawing 25 million overseas holidaymakers in 2023 stands to gain momentum now that China has abandoned its Covid-Zero policy and reopened its borders.

site_title: Global recession in 2023? | Investigating Inflation
summary: A global recession in 2023 is being investigated due to volatile macroeconomic conditions and inflation. The article does not provide conclusive evidence of a global recession. Meanwhile, Singapore has achieved its 12th consecutive year as the world's top port. The country is also embracing innovation, with FedEx partnering with a startup to deploy robots for deliveries. Additionally, Singapore is setting up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific and has seen better employment rates for graduates.

site_title: Tesla raises prices of its Model Y SUV in the US
summary: Tesla raised prices of its Model Y SUV in the US, with the Model Y Long Range increasing to $54,990 and the Model Y Performance to $57,990. The price hikes come after the Biden administration expanded the electric vehicle tax credit, allowing SUVs costing up to $80,000 to qualify. The move follows Tesla's earlier price cuts to drive demand and qualify for the credits. The company's average price is estimated to be down $8,100 from prior levels.

images.alt_text: Tesla plans to produce a weekly average of nearly 20,000 units at its Shanghai factory in February and March.

site_title: More firms want support to expand overseas, lower foreign worker levies in Budget 2023: UOB survey
summary: Businesses in Singapore are seeking support for expansion overseas and reducing foreign worker levies in Budget 2023, according to a UOB survey. The top priorities for businesses are extending the Job Support Scheme, wage credit scheme, and grants for digital adoption. The number of businesses hoping for support for overseas expansion increased by 8 percentage points to 32%, while those seeking a reduction in foreign worker levies rose by 10 percentage points to 30%. Sustainability is also a growing concern, with 76% of businesses viewing it as important.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Modest budget goodies expected at Budget 2023

site_title: China must repair damage from its burst balloon
summary: China must take the first step to repair damage from its burst balloon, which caused a diplomatic crisis with the US. The incident has strained relations and made a stable relationship between the two superpowers seem naive. China's leaders should conduct a credible investigation, punish those responsible, and issue a stronger apology to the US and Canada. They should also scale back grey-zone coercion against Taiwan and tone down bellicose rhetoric. China's economy is reeling, and restraint and prudence are in its own interests to avoid further damage and potential conflict.

images.alt_text: China on Friday expressed regret that an “airship” used for civilian meteorological and other scientific purposes had strayed into US airspace.

site_title: Australia’s retail sales volumes dip in Q4, price growth slows
summary: Australia's retail sales volumes decreased 0.2% in the December quarter to A$96.9 billion, marking the first decline in a year. The drop is attributed to higher borrowing costs curbing spending. Retail prices also slowed to the lowest growth rate of the year, potentially reassuring the Reserve Bank of Australia that its rate hikes are cooling demand. The RBA is expected to hike interest rates by a quarter point to 3.35% at its upcoming meeting.

site_title: Modest budget goodies expected at Budget 2023
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 is expected to feature modest budget goodies, with cash payouts unlikely due to substantial support packages last year. The government may focus on tax incentives and investments in key sectors. The country has been ranked as the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year and is partnering with FedEx to deploy robots for deliveries. The government is also setting up a centre for sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. Graduates can expect better employment rates, according to Tan See Leng.

site_title: Is the dollar’s dominance under threat?
summary: The US dollar's dominance as a global currency is not under threat, according to economist Paul Krugman. Despite speculation, the dollar's continued dominance is due to self-reinforcement, where its use is driven by ease of transactions and widespread invoicing. The dollar's fundamentals, including the US economy's size and sophistication, also support its position. The euro, once a potential rival, has been hindered by European capital market fragmentation. Instead, central banks have diversified their currency holdings into smaller currencies. The dollar's dominance is not a significant concern, and its impact on the global economy is minimal.

images.alt_text: The dollar is still king - an asset to hold for now
Even as the perennial fight over the US debt ceiling ensues in Washington, the greenback's status in global trade may be beginning to lose lustre.

site_title: Beyonce breaks all-time Grammy wins record, Harry Styles claims album prize
summary: Beyonce broke the record for most career Grammy wins with four additions, surpassing Georg Solti's record of 31. Despite this, she lost the album of the year category to Harry Styles for his album "Harry's House." Lizzo won record of the year for "About Damn Time," and Bonnie Raitt won song of the year for "Just Like That." Beyonce thanked God, her family, and the queer community for their support, while Styles praised the diversity of the music industry.

images.alt_text: US actress Viola Davis accepts the award for Best Audio Book, Narration, and Storytelling Recording for her memoir "Finding Me" during the pre-telecast show of the 65th Annual Grammy Awards  in Los Angeles on Feb 5, 2023.

site_title: China developers flag worst earnings in years on historic slump
summary: China's real estate developers reported their worst earnings in at least seven years due to the record downturn and construction halt. 60% of 60 mainland-listed property firms expected losses for 2022, while only 5% turned profitable. The industry is now counting on government measures to ease financing as home sales and prices continue to tumble. Defaults and debt defaults have severely impacted developers' earnings, with Shimao Group Holdings expected to record its first full-year loss in 21 years.

images.alt_text: The IMF called on China to shift government spending away from investment and towards targeted support for households and to lower interest rates.

site_title: Australia’s CBA simplifies financial reporting after sale of wealth management unit
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) will simplify its financial reporting by consolidating non-core income into its operating income, reflecting the sale of its wealth management business. This change has been applied retrospectively, resulting in a reduction of A$109 million in operating expenses for the half-year ended June 2022. CBA will announce its first-half results for fiscal 2023 on February 15, 2023.

site_title: Oil prices edge higher as IEA’s Birol talks up China demand outlook
summary: Oil prices rose 0.2% to $80.10 a barrel, as Brent crude futures climbed 16 cents, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures rose 15 cents. The increase follows a 8% drop last week, amid concerns over major economies and the impact of the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Despite China's demand outlook being seen as positive, global economic jitters outweighed the signs of a demand recovery in the world's top oil importer.

images.alt_text: European Union countries agreed to set price caps on Russian refined oil products to limit Moscow’s funds for its invasion of Ukraine, the Swedish presidency of the EU said on Friday.

site_title: Reasons to fund SMT’s transformation remain valid: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's government will continue to provide up to S$180 million annually to support SPH Media Trust's (SMT) transformation for five years, starting from FY2022, to address structural changes and technological disruptions in the media industry. Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo stated that local news media is at a "watershed" and preserving it serves larger public interests by giving voice to Singaporean perspectives. The funding will be used for technology development, talent development, and preservation of vernacular media, with accountability measures in place to track readership and reach.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
SPH Media Holdings Board has also directed its audit and risk committee to further investigate the overstatement of circulation data and consider its next steps.
SPH Media chief executive Teo Lay Lim said data on reach and readership is collected periodically via a survey panel that is statistically representative of the Singapore population.
The inconsistencies led to a 10 to 12 per cent discrepancy in circulation figures.

site_title: Luxury property deals take a dip in Q4, but 2023 outlook remains strong: Huttons
summary: Singapore's luxury property market saw a decline in Q4 2022, with 73 non-landed luxury homes sold, down 33.6% from the previous quarter. The total value of non-landed luxury homes sold was S$684 million, a 31.9% decrease from Q3 2022. Despite this, Huttons expects the market to benefit from China's lifting of border measures, potentially leading to increased luxury property transactions in 2023. The top three selling luxury condominium projects were Les Maisons Nassim, Tomlinson Heights, and Le Nouvel Ardmore, with prices ranging from S$6,057 to S$5,800 per square foot.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Real estate consultancy Knight Frank noted that the scant inventory of landed and non-landed homes on the market will continue to shrink in 2023.
This house on 17,905 sq ft of land in Tanglin Hill and completed in 1997 is currently on the market with an asking price of S$52 million or S$2,904 psf.
Ultra-luxury condominium Les Maisons Nassim

The landed property market looks set to continue at the current pace for the rest of 2022 as global geopolitical uncertainties persist. Total demand for landed homes could reach around 2,000 units and the URA price index for landed homes could gain some 10 per cent for the whole year, according to List Sotheby’s International Realty.
Good Class Bungalows (GCB) near Grange Road and Chatsworth Road on 27 Oct 2021.

site_title: Australia’s New South Wales unveils plan for cashless poker machines
summary: New South Wales, Australia's most populous state, plans to make all poker machines cashless by 2028 to combat money laundering and problem gambling. Premier Dominic Perrottet unveiled the proposal, which would allow players to bet only from a bank account, and offer interest-free loans for pubs and clubs to purchase new cashless machines. The move is expected to set up a political battle ahead of the state election next month, with the center-left Labor opposition stopping short of calling for mandatory cashless poker machines.

images.alt_text: In a report published last month, the New South Wales Independent Casino Commission said it had identified “systemic governance, risk and cultural failures” at the Sydney casino of Star, Australia’s second-biggest casino operator.
Last week, the Queensland government slapped penalties totalling A$100 million on Star Entertainment and deferred a proposed suspension on its operations in the state on condition they be monitored.

site_title: Moody’s sees limited impact on Japan’s debt finance from BOJ rate hike
summary: Moody's senior vice-president Christian de Guzman says a future interest rate hike by the Bank of Japan (BOJ) will likely be gradual and have a limited impact on Japan's debt financing. Despite Japan's huge public debt, its huge savings and domestic investors' strong home bias offset this weakness. The government has a "very comfortable funding situation" and will continue to fund itself at favorable interest rates, with Moody's not seeing a significant change in this regard.

images.alt_text: Friday’s final au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers’ index (PMI) rose in January to a seasonally adjusted 52.3 from December’s 51.1, marking the fastest pace since October.

site_title: Investor focus to shift from inflation to slowing global economy in 2023
summary: Investors are shifting their focus from inflation concerns to a slowing global economy in 2023, as the world recovers from 2022's volatility. The Singapore Budget 2023 highlighted key trends, including the country's continued relevance and growth. Meanwhile, Singapore remains the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year, and FedEx has partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas. The country is also advancing sustainable aviation and has set up a centre to achieve this goal.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembmarine, Frasers Hospitality Trust, Halcyon Agri, A-Smart, Colex
summary: Sembcorp Marine's net debt to equity ratio improved to 0.26 times in 2022, down from 0.53 times in September. Frasers Hospitality Trust saw revenue per available room increase across its portfolio in Q1 2022. Halcyon Agri is making a mandatory conditional cash offer for the company, with a 36% stake already acquired. A-Smart's board composition is in compliance with corporate governance rules, and Colex shareholders approved a privatisation offer. Charisma Energy received debt repayment demands from a secured lending bank, and Acesian Partners is expected to report significant profit improvement.

images.alt_text: Losers outnumbered gainers 306 to 281, after 2.2 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion changed hands.

site_title: Asia frequent flyer programmes lose value as US rivals’ ones climb
summary: Asia-Pacific frequent flyer programmes have lost value, falling behind US rivals' loyalty divisions. A report by On Point Loyalty found that US airlines' loyalty programmes, such as Delta Air Lines, are now worth more than the stock-market valuations of each airline. This is due to the pandemic's impact on travel restrictions and the role of loyalty programmes as revenue generators for airlines. Asian airlines, including Cathay Pacific and Singapore Airlines, have been particularly affected, with China's international border reopening only recently after a years-long closure.

site_title: Huge earthquake kills more than 2,200 in Turkey and Syria
summary: A magnitude 7.8 earthquake struck Turkey and northwest Syria, killing over 2,200 people and injuring thousands more. The quake, followed by a 7.7 magnitude earthquake, caused widespread destruction in cities already devastated by war. In Turkey, the death toll stands at 1,498, while in Syria, at least 716 people were killed. The disaster is the worst to hit Turkey this century, with temperatures expected to worsen conditions for trapped people. International aid has been offered, with the US ready to provide assistance, and rescue efforts continue amidst challenging weather conditions.

images.alt_text: The London P&I Club, which provides insurance against risks including spills and collisions, said that the letters Turkey is demanding cannot and should not be published for the time being.

site_title: Apple’s latest iPhones sell at rare US$100-plus discounts in China
summary: Apple's latest iPhones are selling at discounts of over US$100 in China, a rare move just months after launch. Retailers such as JD.com and China Mobile are cutting prices for the iPhone 14 Pro range by 800 yuan (S$156) and 700 yuan, respectively. This suggests weak demand in the world's largest smartphone market, which may impact Apple's recovery in China. The discounts, which mirror those on lower-end models, are seen as a sign of weak demand by analysts.

images.alt_text: Apple said iPhone sales were US$65.8 billion, down 8 per cent from the year before and below analyst estimates of US$68.3 billion.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB raises TDCX target price, sees China’s reopening as catalyst
summary: Singapore-based digital customer experience solutions provider TDCX has had its target price raised to US$15.50 by CGS-CIMB, driven by stronger growth assumptions and a 1.3-3.1% increase in FY2023-2024 forecasts. The brokerage attributes the growth to structural trends, business process outsourcing, and a highly cash-generative business model. With China's border reopening expected to boost outbound tourism, TDCX is poised to achieve 15.6% year-on-year revenue growth to S$767 million in FY2023.

images.alt_text: TDCX logo

site_title: Shenton House on the market at S$590 million reserve price
summary: Shenton House, a 99-year leasehold commercial building in Singapore's Central Business District, is being put up for collective sale at a reserve price of S$590 million. The 36,350 sq ft site is zoned for commercial use and eligible for a 25% bonus gross floor area under the CBD incentive scheme. This could allow for a higher gross plot ratio and more flexible development options, including mixed-use or hotel developments. The sale price translates to approximately S$2,035 per square foot per plot ratio, making the site highly attractive to developers.

Skyline of the Central Business District (CBD) along the Singapore River on Oct 29, 2022.

site_title: UK mortgages set for slowest year since 2011 as house prices dip
summary: The UK mortgage market is expected to experience its slowest growth in over a decade, with demand projected to increase just 0.4% this year, down from 4.1% in 2022. Rising interest rates, inflation-squeezed incomes, and falling but still high house prices are driving this decline. Bank-to-business lending is also expected to decline, with a 3.8% drop predicted this year, although business lending may return to growth in 2024. The Bank of England's prediction of a recession is exacerbating the economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Prices remain 1.1 per cent higher than a year ago, reflecting pandemic stimulus programmes including a tax break on home purchases.

site_title: Hong Kong dollar carry trade reignited on biggest yield gap since 2007
summary: The Hong Kong dollar is experiencing its largest yield gap since 2007, with a 0.74% drop against the US dollar, trading at HK$7.8464. The currency weakness is driven by a plunge in local borrowing costs, making it less attractive compared to the US dollar. This has reignited the carry trade, with traders selling the Hong Kong dollar to buy higher-yielding US assets. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) may intervene to tighten liquidity and raise borrowing costs if the currency reaches the weak end of its trading band.

images.alt_text: A protester stands behind a mock jail with photos of the 47 pro-democracy figures already in prison, Sept 19, 2021.
Sales increased to HK$33.7 billion in December compared with a revised 4.1 per cent decline in November.

site_title: Hong Kong-China border reopens as city looks to rebuild economy
summary: Hong Kong's border with China fully reopened on February 6, marking a significant step in the city's campaign to rebuild its battered economy and tourism industry after years of Covid-induced isolation. Daily quotas and testing requirements were dropped, and all boundary checkpoints opened, lifting some of the world's toughest virus-related travel measures. The reopening aims to revive Hong Kong's reputation as a business hub and attract new investment, with a bid to convince oil giant Saudi Aramco to consider a secondary listing in Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: A protester stands behind a mock jail with photos of the 47 pro-democracy figures already in prison, Sept 19, 2021.

site_title: Asia: Most markets drop as US jobs fan rate worries
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Monday, with Hong Kong sinking 1.9% amid US jobs data that exceeded expectations, fueling concerns of higher Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The US jobs report showed over 500,000 new jobs, nearly double December's figure, and a record-low unemployment rate, indicating the Fed still needs to combat inflation. The losses were further exacerbated by geopolitical tensions following the US shooting down of a suspected Chinese spy balloon.

site_title: China moves from contrite to confrontational over US balloon
summary: China has shifted from expressing regret to threatening retaliation over the US's decision to shoot down a Chinese spy balloon that drifted over American territory. The incident has strained US-China relations, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Beijing postponed indefinitely. China claims the balloon was a civilian climate research vehicle, while the US calls it a spy balloon. The US and China have a history of escalating tensions over Taiwan and other issues, with presidential elections in both countries potentially worsening the situation.

images.alt_text: China on Friday expressed regret that an “airship” used for civilian meteorological and other scientific purposes had strayed into US airspace.

site_title: Aspen Glove to fight gas supply deal termination and RM306.4m claim
summary: Aspen Glove, a subsidiary of Aspen Group, has received a notice of termination and demand from Gas Malaysia Energy and Services for RM306.4 million, claiming outstanding payments and unused gas supply. Aspen Glove denies the claim and intends to contest the notice. The company claims the demand is "invalid and/or without basis" and plans to assess a counterclaim against Gas Malaysia Energy and Services.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Aspen Group’s core business is on property development in Malaysia — creating both residential and mixed use properties which target middle-income mass market purchasers.
Aspen Glove's manufacturing facility in  Kedah.
SIAS queried Aspen on its board's approval process for diversification into the healthcare business, in which it manufactures and distributes rubber gloves.

Aspen subsidiaries face claims amounting to over RM100m

site_title: StanChart stops accepting Adani bonds as collateral, ET Now says
summary: Standard Chartered has stopped accepting Adani Group bonds as collateral on margin loans, according to a report by ET Now. The lender has asked private clients to top up their collateral for any shortfall. This move follows similar actions by Citigroup's wealth arm and Credit Suisse Group, amid allegations of fraud by US-based Hindenburg Research. The Adani group has denied the allegations, and bondholders are weighing their options, having shelved plans to sell Adani bonds. The company has also pulled a record domestic stock offering after its shares tanked.

site_title: Gold hits over 4-week low as dollar edges higher
summary: Gold prices hit a four-week low at US$1,865.88 per ounce due to the stronger-than-expected US jobs data, which fueled concerns about the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The US dollar also edged higher, making gold less attractive for buyers holding other currencies. Physical gold demand in India ticked up last week as jewellers resumed purchases ahead of the wedding season, while other precious metals such as silver, platinum, and palladium also experienced declines.

images.alt_text: Gold tends to benefit in lower interest rate environment, as it reduces the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Oxley invites noteholders to exchange outstanding S$75 million fixed rate notes due Feb 2023
summary: Oxley Holdings is offering existing noteholders the chance to exchange their outstanding S$75 million fixed rate notes for new notes with a higher annual interest rate of 7.5%. The exchange offer is in response to major noteholders' interest in extending their bond investment and remaining invested in the group. Existing notes are due to mature on Feb 28, and the new notes will have a maturity date of Aug 24, 2023. Existing noteholders have until Feb 17 to apply for the exchange.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Oxley Tower, a 32-storey freehold mixed commercial development, located at 138 Robinson Road.

site_title: Singtel appoints Allen & Gledhill’s Tan Tze Gay as independent director
summary: Singtel has appointed Tan Tze Gay, a partner at Allen & Gledhill and head of equity capital markets, as a non-executive independent director. Tan has extensive experience in equity and debt capital markets, corporate regulatory and compliance, and has acted for issuers and underwriters on "innovative, high value and complex transactions", including initial public offerings and global debt offerings.

site_title: China banks offer cheap consumer loans as Xi urges more spending
summary: Chinese banks are offering cheap consumer loans as part of a push to boost spending and drive economic growth. Lenders such as Bank of China and China Construction Bank are offering preferential interest rates and incentives, including gift cards, to lure customers. This comes as Beijing seeks to exit its stringent Covid Zero policy and create a more solid foundation for the world's second-largest economy. Policymakers have signaled a focus on boosting consumption and investment, potentially leading to more fiscal and monetary stimulus.

images.alt_text: In a sign of how the record downturn has hurt bottom lines, defaulted developer Shimao Group Holdings’ main unit onshore is expected to record its first full-year loss in 21 years.

site_title: Renault board said to vote in favour of Nissan alliance reset
summary: Renault's board voted in favor of a deal to rebalance its troubled two-decade alliance with Nissan Motor, according to two people familiar with the situation. The agreement aims to move the partnership forward amid industry challenges. A joint press conference with Nissan and Mitsubishi Motors is scheduled for London after the vote. The deal is part of a rebalancing of cross-capital ties and cooperation on future projects.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1% higher on cheap yen
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1% higher on Monday, driven by a cheap yen against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index rose 296.80 points to 27,806.26, while the Topix index added 17.95 points to 1,988.21. The dollar-yen exchange rate increased to 132.35 yen after the US jobs data last Friday, prompting investors to reassess expectations of the Federal Reserve's rate hikes. A report on the potential succession of Bank of Japan governor Masayoshi Amamiya also supported the market's gains.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led losses in Asian trade, losing close to two per cent, and Shanghai was down by more than one per cent.

site_title: Elon Musk says he saved Twitter from bankruptcy, on track to ‘breakeven’
summary: Elon Musk says Twitter is "trending to breakeven" after saving the company from bankruptcy. He completed a $44 billion deal for Twitter last year, giving him control for $54.20 a share. Despite facing "extremely tough" conditions, Musk cites strong daily user counts and user minutes. Twitter made its first interest payment on $12.5 billion in debt, bolstering confidence in Musk's ability to avoid bankruptcy. Musk, who also oversees Tesla and SpaceX, expressed that he wouldn't wish the experience on anyone, but remains optimistic about Twitter's financial future.

site_title: F&B player YKGI slips 10.5% on Catalist trading debut to S$0.179
summary: YKGI, the operator of Yew Kee Duck Rice and Chicha San Chen's Singapore franchise, slipped 10.5% to S$0.179 on its first trading day on the Catalist board, down from its IPO price of S$0.20. The company raised S$16.6 million through the sale of 82.8 million shares, with funds planned for expansion, supply chain upgrades, and strategic acquisitions. YKGI has a total of eight F&B brands under its portfolio, including Yew Kee Duck Rice, Chicha San Chen, and PastaGo.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
YKGI's chief executive Seah Qin Quan and chief marketing officer Seah Kun Miao are looking to use the proceeds from the listing for expansion across the brands.
The food group has a licence to operate Chicha San Chen in Singapore for ten years, starting from 2019.

site_title: Singapore stocks open flat on Monday; STI up 0.02%
summary: Singapore stocks opened flat on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.02% to 3,385.12. Losers outnumbered gainers 86 to 65, with 59.7 million securities worth S$67.5 million changing hands. Acesian Partners was the most actively traded, up 10.7%, while Singtel was among the top five actively traded counters, down 0.4%. The move follows mixed activity in US and European markets, which saw the Dow Jones decline 0.4% and the Stoxx 600 rise 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Losers outnumbered gainers 306 to 281, after 2.2 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion changed hands.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.44% at the open on Monday, following a drop on Wall Street due to a US jobs report that fueled concerns of more interest rate hikes. The Hang Seng Index fell to 21,349.17. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Index dropping 0.57% and the Shenzhen Index falling 0.60%. The losses were attributed to the US jobs report, which sparked worries about future interest rate hikes and their impact on global markets.

site_title: Price caps hit Russia’s export revenue by about US$8 billion in Jan: IEA
summary: Russia's oil export revenue took a hit of about US$8 billion in January due to global price caps, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA). The caps, which affect Moscow's oil and gas exports, likely reduced revenues by nearly 30% compared to the same period last year. IEA chief Fatih Birol attributed the growth in global oil demand this year to China's rebounding economy, particularly the "exploding" demand for jet fuel. This may prompt OPEC to reassess its output policies.

site_title: SingPost, Mo Batteries to begin trial of electric motorbikes with swappable batteries
summary: SingPost and Mo Batteries have begun a three-month trial of electric motorbikes with swappable batteries in Singapore's Districts 9 and 10. The trial assesses charging convenience, ease of use, maintainability, and energy efficiency. The motorbikes will be used by SingPost for 18 months, with the goal of fully transitioning to an electric delivery fleet by 2026. The trial is part of a regulatory sandbox granted to Mo by the Land Transport Authority, Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Speedpost standard delivery fee within Singapore will also be revised from S$6 to S$6.10 from Jan 1, 2023, and to S$6.20 from Jan 1, 2024.

site_title: Summers sees US soft landing more possible than few months ago
summary: US Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers expressed optimism that a "soft landing" for the US economy is more likely, citing slowing consumer price increases and a significant job gain of 517,000 in January. The unemployment rate fell to 3.4%, the lowest since 1969. However, Summers warned that inflation indicators remain too high and getting back to the Federal Reserve's target may still be challenging.

site_title: Adani Group plans to trim its capital spending plans: newspaper
summary: The Adani Group is planning to trim its capital spending plans, according to a report by Mint, citing people close to the situation. This move comes after the conglomerate's flagship firm cancelled a $2.5 billion share sale. To maintain liquidity, the group may moderate its capital expenditure plans in some businesses by providing more collateral in the form of stock pledges to lenders.

images.alt_text: Adani Group, one of India’s top conglomerates, has rejected the criticism and denied wrongdoing in detailed rebuttals, but that has failed to arrest the unabated fall in its shares.
The Adani Group denies all Hindenburg’s allegations, but the fall in the value of its stocks led it to call off last week a US$2.5 billion share sale by Adani Enterprises.
Debt investors are contemplating heavy losses on their holdings if Gautam Adani is unable to restore confidence and stem the losses in his industrial empire.

site_title: Ley Choon units secure contracts worth a total of S$153 million
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings announced the securing of contracts worth S$153 million for underground services installation and road infrastructure maintenance. The contracts, expected to be completed within 36 months, are likely to contribute to the group's performance. This news comes as Ley Choon shares remained unchanged at S$0.017 on the day of the announcement. The contracts are held by the group's subsidiaries, including Ley Choon Constructions and Engineering, Teacly, and Ley Choon Gim Tian Joint Venture.

site_title: Asean markets present global businesses with the diversification opportunities they seek
summary: Asian markets, particularly those in Southeast Asia, are presenting global businesses with diversification opportunities as the world enters 2023 with uncertainty. China's economic transformation, shifting towards a dual circulation model, is expected to impact global supply chains, with countries like Vietnam, Indonesia, and Malaysia poised for growth. German businesses, with over 2000 operations in Singapore, are increasingly looking to diversify and capitalize on opportunities in the region. Sustainability and innovation are key drivers, with the implementation of initiatives like the German Supply Chain Act and EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement.

images.alt_text: An employee works on a vehicle assembly line at a JAC Automotive factory in Qingzhou, in China's eastern Shandong province on January 31, 2023. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Viola Davis secures rare EGOT status with Grammy win
summary: US actress Viola Davis has secured EGOT status with her Grammy win for Best Audio Book, Narration, and Storytelling Recording for her memoir "Finding Me." This achievement marks the 18th person to join the rare group, following in the footsteps of Jennifer Hudson in 2021. Davis, 57, has previously won an Oscar, Tony, and Emmy for her work in film, theater, and television, solidifying her status as a showbiz luminary.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift said the Eras tour would be “a journey through all of my musical eras of my career.”

Beyonce’s Renaissance, a pulsating club track collection, will face off with Adele’s introspective, ugly-cry ode 30 in the most prestigious categories – six years after the British artist shut out Queen Bey’s culture-shaking Lemonade for 2017’s major awards.

site_title: Yen retreats after report Amamiya approached to become BOJ chief
summary: The Japanese government has approached Bank of Japan deputy governor Masayoshi Amamiya to succeed Haruhiko Kuroda as central bank head, according to a report. The yen initially retreated after the news, but Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki later said he hadn't heard anything about the BOJ nomination. Amamiya's response to the inquiry was unclear. The government is in the final stage of finalizing its nominations.

images.alt_text: A vocal advocate of aggressive monetary easing, Masazumi Wakatabe has consistently voted for maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy.

site_title: SoftBank CEO to skip earnings call for first time as tech slumps
summary: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son is skipping the company's earnings call for the first time, handing over the spotlight to CFO Yoshimitsu Goto. The decision comes as investors question SoftBank's ability to navigate its struggling investments, including a fourth straight quarter of losses. The Vision Fund's internal rates of return have deteriorated, with the first fund's return estimated near zero and the second fund underwater. SoftBank's reliance on opaque valuations of closely held companies also raises concerns. An IPO of chip designer Arm, once expected to boost SoftBank's investment machine, may be delayed until 2024.

images.alt_text: SoftBank shouldered big writedowns on investments in some of the world’s most high-flying startups, resulting in deep losses last year.

site_title: Australia set to push rates to 10-year high as inflation spirals
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), is expected to raise interest rates to a 10-year high of 3.35% at its first meeting of the year, due to a sharp acceleration in core inflation. The decision comes despite signs of a cooling economy, with weaker hiring and household spending. Economists predict a quarter-point hike, with some speculating a larger move to counter the inflation surge, which has reached 6.9% from 6.1% in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: Retail sales have been seasonally weak in December in recent times, suggesting further evidence of slowing demand is needed before the RBA pauses tightening.

site_title: SingPost on expansion track in fast-growing Australia market with latest acquisition
summary: SingPost, a Singaporean postal services provider, is expanding its operations in Australia through its acquisition of Freight Management Holdings (FMH). The company has already acquired 51% of FMH and plans to raise its stake to 88% for A$175.4 million, giving it full ownership. This deal is expected to be completed in early 2023, funded by cash reserves and bank lending. SingPost's growth in Australia is expected to drive its performance, benefiting from a network effect. The acquisition is part of the company's transformation into an international logistics player, helping to offset lack of growth opportunities in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
UOBKH expects SingPost’s increased stake in FMH to boost the group’s profitability from the first quarter of 2024 onwards, given the Australian subsidiary’s robust operating profit growth.
Singpost’s subsidiary QSI was also granted two put options by Cainiao to dispose of its equity interest in 4PX.

site_title: 8,000 layoffs don’t exactly scream family values
summary: Tech companies in Silicon Valley, led by CEOs like Salesforce's Marc Benioff, are reeling from massive layoffs, with 8,000 employees being let go. The company's attempts to frame the layoffs as a "family" issue, with Benioff describing the affected employees as "friends" and "family," have been met with skepticism. The trend of using family metaphors to describe company culture is being seen as a "suspension of disbelief" that is no longer effective in attracting and retaining top talent, as the industry has grown into large, complex organizations.

images.alt_text: Salesforce said earlier in January that it would eliminate about 10 per cent of its workforce.
Rapid interest rate hikes, weak consumer demand and an economic slowdown in China have forced firms such as Amazon, Walt Disney, Facebook-owner Meta and American banks to trim their workforce.
The latest round, scheduled to commence Wednesday, will mostly affect the retail division and human resources.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on December 1, 2020, The Salesforce logo at Salesforce Tower in San Francisco, California. - Cloud computing giant Salesforce on January 4, 2023, said it was shedding about 10 percent of its employees, or just under 8,000 jobs, and closing several offices. With the plan, Salesforce joins other US tech giants including Facebook-owner Meta, Twitter and Amazon that have also imposed job cuts as the world economy heads into a downturn. (Photo by Stephen Lam / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / AFP)

site_title: Bonds are back, but how attractive is the risk-reward proposition?
summary: Bonds have become more attractive with current yields ranging from 4.3 to 5% for investment-grade corporate bonds and over 13% for junk bonds. However, high fixed deposit rates for Sing and US dollar deposits over 12 months pose a high hurdle rate for bonds, making cash a strategic asset for now. The article suggests that investors consider investing in fixed income funds, such as bond funds, to lock in attractive yields for the longer term, but warns of the importance of being selective and favoring high-quality issuers.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Sembmarine reports improving debt profile from Q4 cash collections
summary: Sembmarine has reported an improvement in its debt profile, with its net debt to equity ratio decreasing to 0.26 times as of end-2022, from 0.53 times as of end-September 2022. The improvement was mainly due to cash collections in Q4 2022 from long-term receivables and progress and delivery payments from customers. Sembmarine's directors, who are also beneficial shareholders, will vote in favor of the proposed merger with Keppel O&M, set to be voted on by shareholders on February 16.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Sembmarine said its independent directors recommend that shareholders vote in favour of its merger with Keppel O&M.
Terms of the proposed deal to merge Sembmarine and Keppel O&M were revised in October.
Keppel sky sign taken at Ocean Financial Centre.
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger
This revised deal is S$378 million lower than if the one-for-one share exchange option was pursued, as Keppel O&M was being valued at S$4.87 billion under the previous terms.

Both Sembmarine and KOM provide shipbuilding, conversion and ship repair services at their Singapore shipyards, with a specific focus on vessels and structures in the offshore, marine and energy industries.

site_title: Canadian dollar loses weekly winning streak as US jobs surge
summary: The Canadian dollar weakened against the US dollar, ending a weekly winning streak, amid strong US job data and rising US interest rates. The US economy added more jobs than expected in January, raising doubts about a potential recession. This strengthens the US dollar, making it harder for the Federal Reserve to control inflation. The Canadian dollar fell 0.6% to 1.34 US dollars, and the Bank of Canada may pause its interest rate hikes, following its recent benchmark rate increase to 4.5%.

images.alt_text: A Canadian flag flies in front of the Peace Tower on Parliament Hill in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, March 22, 2017. REUTERS/Chris Wattie

site_title: Fed’s inflation fight making painless headway, but investors should not quickly jump into stocks
summary: The US Federal Reserve's disinflation process has started, with chairman Jerome Powell stating that inflation has subsided without significant economic fallout. The S&P 500 surged 1% after Powell's comments, while the Nasdaq 100 rose 2.2%. However, the strong US jobs report tempered the bullish sentiment, and the Fed still expects to increase interest rates to return inflation to 2% target. Despite Powell's optimism, the Fed is likely to err on the side of caution, and investors should not quickly jump into stocks, as further rate hikes and potential economic downturns remain risks.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
A recent Fed survey hinted at strategies banks may be using to recoup lost cash as funding pressures increase.
Stocks were further pressured by a trove of mostly disappointing earnings.
However, the first days of February showed central banks were not quite done yet with monetary tightening, with the US Federal Reserve adding 25 bps and the ECB and the BOE each hiking by 50 bps.

site_title: Hong Kong’s largest national security trial to begin with 47 in dock
summary: Hong Kong's largest national security trial begins with 47 pro-democracy figures, accused of "conspiracy to commit subversion" for organizing an unofficial primary election. The trial, expected to last over four months, carries up to life imprisonment if convicted. The defendants, including prominent opposition figures, claim they are being prosecuted for normal opposition politics, while authorities see it as an attempt to topple the government. The trial is seen as a test of Hong Kong's autonomy and freedoms, with critics labeling it a "complete farce."

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on September 19, 2021 a protester stands behind a mock jail with photos of the 47 pro-democracy figures already in prison as Hong Kong's political elite began selecting a powerful committee which will choose the city's next leader and nearly half the city's legislature under a new "patriots only" system imposed by Beijing. - The trial of 47 of Hong Kong's most prominent pro-democracy figures begins on February 6, 2023, in the largest prosecution yet under a national security law that has crushed dissent in the city. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP) / To go with AFP story "Hong Kong-China-politics-court-trial", ADVANCER by Su Xinqi and Jerome Taylor

site_title: Value stocks? Growth stocks? Markets last year turned everything topsy-turvy
summary: The US stock market has seen a significant shift in the classification of growth and value stocks, with traditional categories like tech and energy becoming topsy-turvy. According to a new study by S&P Dow Jones Indices, eight tech giants, including Apple, have been replaced by fossil fuel energy companies like ExxonMobil and Chevron in the S&P 500 Pure Growth Index. This change is attributed to soaring inflation, rising interest rates, and a sharp decline in the growth rates of tech companies in 2022. The shift has significant implications for investors and highlights the need for a more nuanced understanding of the stock market.

images.alt_text: Previously high-flying stocks like Tesla lost more than 60 per cent of their value in 2022. Shares of energy companies like Occidental Petroleum, Hess and Exxon Mobil gained more than 60 per cent.  Making all the right choices over short periods is nearly impossible.
Stocks like Meta, Microsoft, Amazon and Apple have suffered staggering losses this year, but is this a good time to buy?
Recessions come in many varieties. Any would bring pain, but if history is a guide, stocks and bonds are likely to rise eventually

site_title: Malaysia to refresh appeal of Iskandar southern growth corridor to Singapore
summary: Malaysia aims to revitalize its southern growth corridor, Iskandar Malaysia, by proposing an "economic corridor" with Singapore to attract high-value investments in sectors such as electrical engineering, chemicals, and transport equipment. The plan includes improving connectivity, including a ferry service from Puteri Harbour International Terminal to Singapore. The move is part of Malaysia's goal to position itself as an "alternative supply chain hub in Asia." The new administration is considering refreshing derailed connectivity plans to woo more investments from Singapore, with the goal of stimulating growth in the region.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Iskandar boleh
Malaysia’s International Trade and Industry Minister Tengku Zafrul Azizand the representatives from Yondr Group.

site_title: Kane becomes Spurs’ record scorer as Man City suffer title blow in 1-0 loss
summary: Harry Kane became Tottenham Hotspur's all-time record scorer with his 267th goal for the club, surpassing Jimmy Greaves' record. Kane scored in the 1-0 win against Manchester City, severely damaging City's bid to retain the Premier League title. The goal made Kane the third player to score 200 Premier League goals, joining Alan Shearer and Wayne Rooney. The win lifted Tottenham to within one point of fourth-placed Newcastle and moved them closer to Champions League qualification.
