The BMW X1 is really a family car first and Sport Utility Vehicle (SUV) second.

site_title: US: Wall St tumbles at open as jobs data fans higher rate worries
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Friday, February 3, as jobs data showed the economy added jobs at a rapid pace, fueling fears that the Federal Reserve may keep interest rates higher for longer. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 127.64 points, or 0.37%, to 33,926.30, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell. The jobs data has raised concerns about the Fed's ability to control inflation, leading to a sell-off on Wall Street.

site_title: US lifts import ban on Sime Darby Plantation products
summary: The US has lifted a two-year import ban on palm oil products made by Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation after determining the goods were no longer produced with forced labor. The decision follows the company's efforts to review and upgrade its labor practices, including appointing an ethical trade consultancy and setting aside $20 million to compensate workers who paid recruitment fees. Sime Darby Plantation has taken steps to correct 11 labor indicators of forced labor, and the lifting of the import ban applies to products imported into the US on or after the notice was published.

site_title: Big Tech earnings show digital ads market not out of the woods
summary: Big Tech companies Meta Platforms and Alphabet reported year-over-year revenue declines, with Meta posting its third consecutive decline and Alphabet missing Wall Street expectations. The advertising industry, closely tied to the economy, is showing signs of weakness due to record-high inflation rates and uncertainty about a recession. Advertisers are reducing marketing budgets, leading to lower spending on digital advertising. Snap also expects revenue to decline, citing competition for ad dollars and a challenging economy.

images.alt_text: Shares of Alphabet were down nearly 5 per cent in after-hours trading, after losing about 40 per cent of their value in 2022.
Meta plans to cut costs in 2023 by US$5 billion to between US$89 billion and US$95 billion compared with its earlier outlook of US$94 billion to US$100 billion.

site_title: Chinese cities lower or scrap floor on mortgage rates to boost demand
summary: China's cities have lowered or scrapped mortgage floor rates for first-time home buyers, with at least 26 cities implementing measures, including Tianjin and provincial capitals. The central bank allowed cities with falling home prices to cut or abolish the floor on mortgage rates in January. The move aims to boost demand for residential property, which has been recovering due to state support and eased COVID policies. Despite signs of recovery, fragile demand remains a constraint, and further support is expected to stimulate the sector.

images.alt_text: China's property sector was one of the biggest drags on the economy last year.

site_title: Tech giants call time on stocks party
summary: Global stocks slipped 0.1% on Friday, near their highest level since August, after US tech giants' weak earnings derailed a stock rally fueled by hopes of central banks ending aggressive rate hikes. The MSCI World Stock Index fell, with tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 contracts down 1.5%. Investors also watched the fallout from India's Adani group's plunge, with market losses amounting to $115 billion. Despite the setback, futures markets suggest the Federal Reserve may be nearing the end of its rate-hiking cycle, with a possible 25-bp hike in March.

images.alt_text: The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index finished 3.3 per cent higher at 12,200.82 on Thursday.
Meta Platforms posted its third consecutive quarter of year-over-year revenue decline, while Google-owner Alphabet reported a slight fall in quarterly ad revenue.

site_title: EU seeks agreement on Russian fuel price caps
summary: The European Union is seeking an agreement on price caps for Russian fuel products, which would cost Moscow around 160 million euros (S$229.3 million) daily. The move comes ahead of an embargo set to enter into force over the weekend, targeting Russian President Vladimir Putin's war chest due to his assault on Ukraine. The EU, along with its G7 partners, has set an international export cap of US$60 per barrel. The goal is to limit Russia's revenue from its key exports.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$82.17 a barrel, shedding 67 cents, or 0.8 per cent on Thursday.
OPEC+ have tried to balance markets through changes in supply this year, which since October involved cuts
The shifting market trend reverses months of buyers in Thailand, India and Bangladesh staying on the sidelines as prices soared following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

The more active second-month Brent contract settled at US$85.46 a barrel, up 96 cents or 1 per cent, while the US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at US$78.87 a barrel, up 97 cents or 1.3 per cent.

German Chancellor Olaf Scholz speaks next to a Leopard 2 battle tank of the German armed forces Bundeswehr as he visits troops on a training exercise at the military ground in Ostenholz, northern Germany, on Oct 17, 2022.
BP is aiming to rapidly grow the company’s renewables business and slash oil and gas output by 2030.
Refining outages in the US are feeding the price run-up.

site_title: New EU rules to tackle AI, ChatGPT concerns
summary: The European Union is introducing new rules to address concerns surrounding artificial intelligence (AI) and the risks posed by popular AI program ChatGPT. EU Commissioner for Internal Market Thierry Breton says the new regulations are necessary to ensure trust in AI technology among Europeans. The rules aim to set a global standard for AI, following Breton's proposal last year. ChatGPT, developed by OpenAI, has raised concerns due to its rapid growth and ability to generate articles, essays, and other content, highlighting the need for a solid regulatory framework to ensure trustworthy AI based on high-quality data.

site_title: India’s top lender SBI smashes estimates with record Q3 profit
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) reported a record high quarterly profit, exceeding analyst estimates by 8.5% with a 68.5% surge. Net interest income rose 24% to 380.69 billion rupees, while net interest margin increased to 3.69%. Credit growth stood at 17.6%, with retail and corporate loans growing 18% each. Deposits grew 9.51%, and net profit rose to 142.05 billion rupees. The bank's bad loan provisions nearly halved to 15.87 billion rupees, easing concerns about its exposure to the embattled Adani Group.

images.alt_text: The exposure by various financiers to companies controlled by Gautam Adani has come under increasing scrutiny, after their shares plunged following a scathing report from US-based Hindenburg Research.
HDFC, set to merge with India’s largest private lender HDFC Bank, said interest income climbed 30.8 per cent to 144.58 billion rupees.

site_title: China clashes with IMF over property downturn, growth rate
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged China to address its unresolved real estate crisis by shifting government spending to support households and lowering interest rates. The IMF forecasts China's economy to expand 5.2% this year, but notes the sector remains below potential. China has rejected the IMF's assessment, calling the property market "smooth" and the growth projection "overly pessimistic." The IMF recommends increasing funding for unfinished housing projects and promoting market-based restructuring to address the slump.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on November 16, 2022 shows residental buildings in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

China’s economic growth is rebounding thanks to a package of support policies and the move to adjust Covid-19 control measures, and the government should work to consolidate and expand the recovery trend, Premier Li Keqiang said.

site_title: Modi government officials opt for silence over Adani stock rout
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration has shown little concern over the Adani Group's $120 billion loss in market value following allegations of fraud, despite the conglomerate's significant impact on the country's economy. Officials have downplayed the issue, stating that the stock rout is primarily about valuation and not a systemic risk, while the government has avoided direct comments on the matter. The Adani Group's stock has plummeted, raising concerns about the potential impact on Modi's re-election prospects in 2024.

images.alt_text: A nationwide protest planned for Monday will also draw attention to Gautam Adani's links with Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
Having linked hands while Modi ran the state, when he became prime minister their close cooperation went national, enabling Adani to expand into virtually every area of the economy.

site_title: Hiap Hoe issues profit warning guiding for loss in H2 FY22
summary: Hiap Hoe's board of directors has issued a profit warning, expecting a loss for its second half of FY22 due to elevated volatility and significant declines in asset classes. The expected losses are mainly attributed to fair-value changes in financial instruments. The real estate group did not provide figures for the expected loss and will disclose further details in its unaudited results on or before Feb 28.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Platform workers raise concerns on costs, earnings pressure at dialogue session
summary: Singapore's government has formed a committee to plan and implement a work injury compensation framework for platform workers, amid concerns over rising costs and falling earnings. The committee, PWIN, aims to ensure platform workers receive adequate compensation and benefits, including CPF contributions, in line with the country's job protection laws. The measures, set to roll out in late 2024, aim to strengthen job protections for gig economy workers, including ride-hailing drivers and delivery riders.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Platforms like Grab could do more to support drivers amid strong cost pressures.

site_title: Nippon Paper, others look at making sustainable aviation fuel from wood
summary: Nippon Paper Industries, Sumitomo, and the Green Earth Institute have agreed to study the production of bioethanol from woody biomass to be used as a feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Japan. The project aims to produce bioethanol by 2027 to meet Japan's plan to increase SAF production for its aviation industry, which aims to be carbon-neutral by 2050. This aligns with the global airline industry's goal to use SAF to meet its net zero emissions target by 2050. The partnership could support Japan's aviation industry in reducing its carbon footprint.

site_title: Cyberattack sends derivatives trading back to the 1980s
summary: A cyberattack on London-based derivatives trading platform Ion Trading UK has caused financial markets to experience disruptions, forcing traders and brokers to revert to manual processing of trades, similar to the 1980s and 1990s. The attack, attributed to Russian ransomware gang LockBit, affected 42 clients, including major banks and brokers, and has delayed overnight processing and regulatory reporting. The incident has highlighted vulnerabilities in the plumbing underpinning trading processes and raised concerns about systemic risk. Regulators and financial firms are working to mitigate the fallout and restore operations.

images.alt_text: ION Group, the financial data firm’s parent company, said in a statement on its website that the attack began on Tuesday (Jan 31) .

site_title: Japan’s Sumitomo to produce green hydrogen and ammonia in Chile
summary: Japan's Sumitomo and Chile's Colbun agreed to collaborate on green hydrogen and ammonia production and export, with a memorandum of understanding signed on February 3. The partnership aims to establish a green hydrogen and ammonia supply chain from Chile to Japan. Hydrogen production has gained importance as countries transition to lower-emissions energy sources, with Japan, China, and South Korea setting targets for hydrogen fuel-cell vehicles. The agreement is seen as a step towards Chile's transformation into a green hydrogen and clean energy powerhouse.

site_title: Big stimulus unlikely as China considers steps to support consumers
summary: China's policymakers are planning to show more support for domestic demand this year, but are unlikely to announce large-scale household stimulus measures. Instead, they will focus on investment and infrastructure spending to boost jobs and incomes. The government aims to widen its budget deficit to 3% of GDP and is expected to offer local consumption vouchers and subsidies. However, economists warn that such measures may not be enough to revive consumer demand, and that a large chunk of the rise in household savings may be explained by consumer's safety-first reallocations into bank deposits.

images.alt_text: Beijing’s abrupt abolishment of pandemic curbs and faster-than-expected peaking of infections that boosted demand for services, especially during the week-long Lunar New Year holidays.

site_title: Colex requests lifting of trading halt; privatisation scheme approved
summary: CATALIST waste management company Colex requested the Singapore Exchange to lift its trading halt on February 3, following a scheme meeting where 79% of shareholders approved the privatisation scheme proposed by Bonvests. The privatisation offer, valued at S$0.23 per share, aims to buy out the remaining shares that Bonvests and its subsidiary Coop International do not own.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Activision to pay US$35 million for disclosure control failures
summary: Activision Blizzard has agreed to pay the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) $35 million for failing to establish proper controls to address employee complaints about workplace misconduct. The company lacked adequate procedures to assess material issues, leading to a failure to disclose and violating whistleblower protections. This settlement follows allegations that Activision Blizzard's management did not fully understand the magnitude of employee complaints. The incident occurred while Microsoft is considering a $69 billion acquisition of the video game company.

site_title: The 200-year-old mystery of Waterloo's skeletal remains
summary: Belgian researchers are analyzing the skeletal remains of soldiers killed at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815, 200 years after the battle. The remains, which include a Prussian soldier's foot and femurs, are being examined to determine their nationality and origin. DNA tests and analysis of the bones' geology may provide clues, and experts hope to learn more about the soldiers' identities and the battle's events. The discovery is a unique opportunity to study the past through forensic science, and researchers are working to piece together the history of the battle.

images.alt_text: The discovery suggests “detailed knowledge of limb anatomy and muscular and vascular systems,” the research team wrote in a paper published Wednesday in the journal Nature.
The statues depict deities venerated at a sanctuary in San Casciano dei Bagni, established first by the Etruscans and then expanded under the Romans.

site_title: Plummeting Adani shares send ripples through India’s parliament, finance sector
summary: India's Adani Group shares plummeted sharply, losing over half their market capitalization, following a critical research report by a US short-seller that raised questions about the conglomerate's debt levels and tax havens. The group shelved a $2.5-billion share sale, further jolting investor sentiment. Lawmakers have called for a wider investigation, and the central bank has asked lenders for details of exposure to the group. The collapse has sent ripples through India's parliament and finance sector, fueling fears of systemic risk.

images.alt_text: The group’s flagship firm – Adani Enterprises - plunged 10 per cent after opening higher on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia proposes new way to ease Singapore Causeway traffic
summary: Malaysia proposes a "single clearance system" to ease traffic congestion on the Johor-Singapore Causeway, which affects 150,000 commuters. Malaysian immigration officials would be stationed on the Singapore side, while Singaporean officials would be deployed to Johor. The proposal includes additional funds for motorcycle lanes and weekend access to truck lanes for passenger cars, aiming to reduce wait times from two hours to 20 minutes. The move is part of efforts to manage the world's busiest land crossings.

site_title: Switzerland probing Credit Suisse’s account data leak
summary: Switzerland's Attorney-General's Office is investigating a data leak involving 18,000 Credit Suisse accounts, which were leaked to media in 2022. The affected clients include drug barons and kleptocrats with over $100 billion in the bank. The probe is focused on suspected corporate spying and violations of banking-secrecy laws, and requires approval from the federal government. The leak could dent efforts to boost transparency in Switzerland, where banking secrecy is protected by law, and may intensify international criticism of the country's treatment of whistleblowers.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse ranked 8th in arranging Chinese stock sales overseas last year, down from 6th in 2020.
The Zurich-based lender is in the midst of working out how to carve out its investment bank into the rebranded Credit Suisse First Boston and which businesses will be housed there.
Credit Suisse is not alone in signalling lower variable pay, though reductions at the lender are likely to be steeper than at its Wall Street peers.

site_title: A-Smart responds to SGX queries on annual report
summary: A-Smart Holdings has responded to queries by the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) regarding its non-compliance with the Code of Corporate Governance 2018 in its annual report for 2022. The company acknowledged not having a majority of independent directors on its board and not disclosing the full remuneration of key management personnel. However, A-Smart claimed its board has substantial independent elements and that remuneration details were disclosed in a way that provides an indication of each director's package. The company also stated it has a whistleblowing policy in place.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Office workers walking past the SGX logo outside the SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on 6 December 2021.

site_title: ECB plans next big rate hike, making Lagarde the last hawk standing
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is planning a half-point interest rate hike in March, with President Christine Lagarde indicating that the bank will continue to be hawkish despite growing market confidence that inflation is fading. The ECB's stance is in contrast to its global peers, which have signaled a slowdown in rate hikes. Lagarde cited underlying consumer-price gains and wage-pressure risks as reasons for the decision, but the market reaction suggests that investors are skeptical. The ECB's next monetary policy meeting will be held in six weeks, with policymakers pledging to remain data-dependent and make decisions meeting by meeting.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)
Germany’s 10-year government bond yield, the benchmark of the eurozone, has fallen 3.5 bps to 2.3 per cent.
The first ECB policy meeting of 2023 is next week and will almost certainly deliver the half-point hike that president Christine Lagarde promised in December.

site_title: Thailand to toughen rules on methamphetamine pill possession
summary: Thailand plans to tighten rules on methamphetamine possession, labeling those found with one pill as "drug distributors" and potentially subjecting them to severe penalties, including imprisonment. The move, prompted by a mass shooting in October 2022, could reverse 2021's narcotics reform prioritizing prevention and treatment over punishment. Health Minister Anutin Charnvirakul said the changes aim to address social problems effectively and curb the spread of methamphetamine pills. The new regulation is pending cabinet approval and has sparked concerns from experts that it could overcrowd prisons and reverse progress in reducing prison sentences.

images.alt_text: Despite its rapid growth, Thailand’s cannabis industry is in fact walking a political tightrope.

site_title: Billionaire Draper pitches Sri Lanka on Bitcoin, gets rejected
summary: Billionaire investor Tim Draper proposed widespread adoption of Bitcoin to Sri Lanka, citing the country's reputation for corruption as a potential solution. However, Central Bank Governor Nandalal Weerasinghe rejected the idea, stating that adoption of 100% Bitcoin is not a reality for Sri Lanka. The country is facing severe financial struggles, including inflation and fuel shortages, and Weerasinghe argued that introducing Bitcoin could make the crisis worse.

images.alt_text: Digital assets are rebounding from steep losses last year, a period pockmarked by blowups like that of the FTX exchange.

site_title: Thai AirAsia adding back idled jets amid China tourism restart
summary: Thai AirAsia plans to resume operations of eight idled jets amid China's tourism restart, which now allows free travel without quarantine. The airline aims to cater for the growing number of visitors from China by shifting planes from other parts of the group. CEO Santisuk Klongchaiya expects improved earnings growth with increased flights to Chinese cities, citing strong advance bookings. Thai AirAsia currently has 53 jets in its fleet and may face seat shortages due to high demand from Chinese travelers.

site_title: Australia to legalise MDMA and magic mushrooms for medical use
summary: Australia's Therapeutic Goods Administration announced that psychiatrists can prescribe MDMA and psilocybin for medical use starting July. The substances were found to be "relatively safe" in a medical setting, providing an "altered state of consciousness" for treating depression and post-traumatic stress disorder. The move follows similar approvals in Canada and the US, and advocates hope to expand their use to other conditions such as alcohol dependence and obsessive compulsive disorder.

site_title: The Tanamera joins en bloc hopefuls
summary: The owners of The Tanamera condominium in Bedok are considering a collective sale exercise, which could potentially fetch a reserve price of over S$500 million if successful. The 99-year leasehold condo has 288 units and a gross plot ratio of 2.1. The process began in the fourth quarter of 2022, with an extraordinary general meeting scheduled for Saturday to agree on the sale terms. The collective sale market has seen a lower success rate in recent years, with only 30% of sales in 2021-2022 being successful, compared to 60% in 2017-2018.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

ST20221110-202260773278-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
Commercial buildings and condominiums as viewed from OCBC Centre on Nov 10, 2022.

Orchard Bel Air relaunched for en bloc sale at unchanged S$587.5m guide price
Built in 1959, the 5-storey building on Lim Teck Kim Road currently has 5 commercial units on the ground floor and 20 residential units above.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 7.4% year-over-year in December, extending the previous month's 6.5% growth. The Ministry of Manpower formed a new committee to develop a work injury compensation framework for platform workers. Major South-east Asian crops are under scrutiny due to EU supply-chain due diligence rules. Singapore shares gained 0.6% on Friday as Reits continued to trade higher amid expectations of interest rate hikes halting soon.

site_title: Temasek-backed fish farmer Apollo Aquaculture in judicial management
summary: Apollo Aquaculture, a fish farm backed by Temasek, has entered judicial management after failing to meet financial obligations. The company was reported to be building a S$65-million multi-storey fish farming facility in 2021, but it never started operations. Apollo's largest shareholder, Ng Yong Hock Capital, holds 43.3 million shares. The company's current directors are Phua Bo Wen, Yeo Yeow Hwee, and Ng Chuen Guan. The judicial management is the latest development in the company's financial struggles.

images.alt_text: Apollo Aquaculture Group was placed under interim judicial management on Mar 17 2022, and subsequently under judicial management on May 4, 2022, said the group's judicial manager Tan Wei Cheong  of professional services company Deloitte & Touche.
Shane Kimpton, chief executive officer of AusGroup. The company's application for judicial management comes after restructuring plans, talk of potential sales and several resignations.

site_title: Indonesia’s economy likely lost some steam in Q4: poll
summary: Indonesia's economy likely slowed in Q4 2022 due to declining commodity and energy prices, which hit exports. The country's economy, the largest in Southeast Asia, exported a record $292 billion in 2022, driven by high global commodity prices. A global recession is expected to accelerate the slowdown this year, according to a Reuters poll.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's president Joko Widodo has three children and one of them is the mayor of Surakarta in Java that has an outsize influence in determining future leaders.
Astra Daihatsu Motor is aiming for construction of the plant to be completed by December 2024.
Indonesia has a target of having at least 1.2 million electric motorcycles and 35,000 electric cars in use by 2024.

site_title: China Hainan Rubber launches mandatory conditional offer for Halcyon Agri at S$0.413 per share
summary: China Hainan Rubber Industry Group is making a mandatory conditional cash offer for Halcyon Agri Corporation at S$0.413 per share, following the acquisition of 36% of its shares last November. The offer is conditional on receiving valid acceptances, and Sinochem International (Overseas), which holds 29.2% of Halcyon Agri's shares, has provided an irrevocable undertaking to reject the offer. The offeror does not intend for Halcyon Agri to be delisted or privatised, and it is unlikely to become entitled to compulsory acquisition rights.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Halcyon rubber processing factory in Palembang, Indonesia.

Core earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) was at US$10.2 million, up year-on-year from US$9.4 million in Q3 2021, but down quarter-on-quarter from US$16.2 million in Q2 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong luxury home on the peak sold at US$17 million loss
summary: A luxury apartment in Hong Kong's Mount Nicholson development was sold for US$16.6 million less than its original price of HK$520 million in 2018. The 4,596-square-foot home was purchased by two buyers for HK$390 million (S$65.1 million) in late January, amid a struggling upscale home market due to weak demand, Covid-19 restrictions, and rising interest rates. This sale highlights the challenges faced by Hong Kong's luxury property market, with the number of luxury residential sales falling 60% in 2022.

site_title: China's banking sector bad loan ratio 1.71% at end of 2022
summary: China's banking sector bad loan ratio decreased to 1.71% at the end of 2022, down 0.09 percentage points from the previous year. Non-performing loans stood at 3.8 trillion yuan, while financial institutions disposed of 3.1 trillion yuan in bad assets. However, analysts believe the actual bad loan levels may be higher due to COVID-19 curbs and loan repayment extensions. China's regulators have stepped up efforts to manage risks, with a focus on supporting the real economy and providing financing guarantees for investment activities in 2023.

images.alt_text: Top policymakers want to work towards harvesting the consumer power of China’s 1.4 billion people, after economic growth in 2022 slumped to one of its weakest levels in nearly half a century.

site_title: Assassin’s Creed creators cling to family control at Ubisoft
summary: Ubisoft's parent company, controlled by the Guillemot brothers since its founding in 1980, is facing a series of crises that have led to a 55% decline in shares since August, making it a potential takeover target. The company has experienced sexism and harassment cases, a contentious pact with Tencent, game delays, cancelled titles, and its first labor strike. The Guillemot brothers' vision for Ubisoft is being tested, and the company's future remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: The firm has been dogged by game delays, on top of project cancellations and heavy sector competition.

site_title: China says balloon over US is a civilian vessel blown off course
summary: China claims a suspected spy balloon over the US is a civilian airship for meteorological and scientific research, deviating from its course due to westerly winds. The US had previously identified the object as a Chinese spy balloon, prompting concerns ahead of a planned visit by US Secretary of State Antony Blinken. China expresses regret for the incident and vows to maintain communication with the US to handle the situation properly.

site_title: World food prices decline for 10th month running in January
summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization's (FAO) world price index fell to 131.2 points in January, its 10th consecutive decline, and is now down 18% from a record high in March 2022. This drop was attributed to falls in vegetable oils, dairy, and sugar prices, while cereal and meat prices remained stable. The FAO revised its forecast for global cereal production in 2022 to 2.765 billion tonnes.

site_title: Acesian Partners guides for ‘significant improvement’ in profit for FY22
summary: Acesian Partners reported a "significant improvement in profit before tax" for FY22, driven by an increase in revenue due to improved business volume and pent-up demand. The exact figures were not provided, but the company expects a notable rise compared to the previous year. Acesian Partners is still finalizing its unaudited consolidated financial results for FY22, which will be released on or before March 1. The company's shares closed unchanged at S$0.056 on the day of the announcement.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Singapore stocks gain on Friday as Reits continue to trade higher; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing at 3,384.29 points, driven by gains in real estate investment trusts (Reits) amid expectations of a halt in interest rate hikes. Losers outnumbered gainers 306 to 281, with 2.2 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion changing hands.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 44 in early trade on the Singapore Exchange on Friday.

site_title: From millennial to millionaire: striking gold in property and insurance
summary: Millennials are ditching traditional professions to become property and insurance brokers, drawn by buoyant markets and flexible hours. Real estate agents and financial consultants under 35 have seen lucrative earnings, with some brokers raking in commissions of S$100,000 per month. Companies such as PropNex, ERA, and Prudential have reported an increase in young agents and financial consultants, with some earning significant incomes. However, industry experts warn that the good run may not last long, citing concerns over the lack of transferable skills and the rapidly changing job market.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Being prepared for market volatility, inflation and falling returns is as important as ensuring you are invested in the right asset class during a period of growth.
Sound reasons exist for some buyers to pay over a million dollars each for certain HDB resale flats.
China’s property sector, accounting for a quarter of the economy, has struggled with defaults and stalled projects, hitting market confidence and weighing on economic growth.
Sliding home values threaten to undermine consumer confidence and weigh on household spending, which had been a rare bright spot for the global economy last year.
Executive condominiums like The Vales in Sengkang, are favoured for their affordability and size.

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust posts 24.4% drop in H2 DPU to S$0.034
summary: CapitaLand China Trust (CLCT) reported a 24.4% year-on-year drop in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.034, down from S$0.045 in the same period last year. The decline was attributed to lower retail performance, higher interest expenses, and the absence of one-off proceeds. Despite this, the Reit's retail portfolio is expected to shift to a positive trajectory in 2023 following China's easing of Covid-19 restrictions, with business activity and consumer spending expected to return.

images.alt_text:
The first batch of China Rse onshore C-Reits, with an aggregate value of 31.2 trillion yuan (about S$6 billion), hold infrastructure assets ranging from toll roads and waste treatment plants to logistics and industrial parks. 
Since 2021, the C-Reit market has grown exponentially, raising a total capital of more than 75 billion yuan, or more than S$15 billion, with the listing of 24 infrastructure and rental housing Reits as of December 2022.
CapitaLand Ascott Trust attributes strong performance to higher portfolio revenue per available unit growth and accretive acquisitions.

site_title: New Zealand floods add to inflation challenge for new prime minister ahead of vote
summary: Heavy rainfall in New Zealand has caused widespread flooding, particularly in Auckland, exacerbating the country's inflationary pressures. The floods, which have damaged thousands of homes, roads, and crops, are expected to add to the already high cost of living, with annual inflation running at 7.2% and food prices reaching a three-decade high of 11.3% in December. New Zealand Prime Minister Chris Hipkins faces a challenge in managing the near-term inflation shock and handling the recovery process ahead of the October election.

images.alt_text: The town of Fitzroy Crossing, a community of around 1,300 people, has been among the worst hit, with supplies having to be airlifted in due to flooded roads.

site_title: Adani shares worth less than US$100 billion
summary: Adani Group's market capitalization has dropped to less than $100 billion after a US short-seller's critical report raised concerns over the company's debt levels and use of tax havens. The group's flagship company, Adani Enterprises, saw its share price decline 35% to its lowest level since March 2021, with total losses reaching nearly $33.6 billion since last week. The report has sparked a market rout, with lawmakers calling for a wider probe and the central bank seeking details of lenders' exposure to the group.

images.alt_text: The group’s flagship firm – Adani Enterprises - plunged 10 per cent after opening higher on Thursday.

site_title: UK faces bleakest outlook in generations as more Britons stop working
summary: The UK faces its bleakest economic outlook in generations, with the Bank of England warning of a shrinking workforce and lacklustre productivity as the main reasons for the economic downturn. The central bank forecasts the economy will shrink almost 1% over the next five quarters, with potential growth estimated at 0.7% a year by 2025, less than half the pre-Covid pace. The UK's workforce has shrunk significantly since the pandemic, with over 80% of inactive working-age individuals stating they do not want a job, and the Bank warns of chronic stagnation, higher interest rates, and more unemployment.

images.alt_text: The BOE’s new GDP forecast was similar to one published this week by the International Monetary Fund which said Britain’s economy would shrink by 0.6 per cent this year.
NCC said the job cuts would lead to a one-off implementation cost of £4 million in the second half of the fiscal year ending May 31.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Some bright spots in a cautious trading week (Ep 30)
summary: Singapore markets reacted cautiously this week due to macroeconomic news and global trends. The podcast highlights notable macroeconomic news, including insights from The Business Times' newsdesk and SGX's wrap for the week. Key events include market movements in response to global economic developments and the impact of US dollar fluctuations. The cautious trading week is attributed to uncertainty and market volatility.

images.alt_text: Despite a short trading week, why did investors seem enthusiastic?
Find out why tepid sentiment challenged markets this week.

site_title: TomTom raises 2023 revenue outlook as automotive drives Q4 beat
summary: TomTom, a navigation and digital mapping company, raised its 2023 revenue forecast to 540-580 million euros, beating expectations due to strong automotive performance. The company, which serves Volkswagen and Microsoft, reported 139 million euros in Q4 revenue, a 64% increase from the same quarter last year. TomTom now forecasts free cash flow of 0-5% of revenue, up from breakeven previously. The company attributes its Q4 success to the recovery in global car production following the global chip shortage.

site_title: Japan startup selling US$550,000 Star Wars-inspired hoverbike to list on Nasdaq
summary: A Japanese startup, Aerwins Technologies, has received approval to list on the Nasdaq in a merger with Pono Capital, valuing the company at $600 million. The company is selling its Star Wars-inspired hoverbike, the XTurismo, for $555,000, with estimated flight times of up to 40 minutes and speeds of up to 100 km/h. The deal comes as other mobility startups face funding difficulties, and shares in Pono Capital rose 24% on the news.

images.alt_text: Volvo has carved out and sold its petrol engine and hybrid powertrain operations to Geely.

site_title: Key South-east Asian crops exposed as EU tightens supply-chain due diligence rules
summary: The European Union is tightening supply-chain due diligence rules, affecting major South-east Asian exporters of coffee, palm oil, and rubber. Exporters like Indonesia, Vietnam, and Thailand are exposed due to the EU's directives on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues. Fitch reports that emerging markets face the largest compliance risks, with Brazil and Indonesia notably affected. The Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive aims to mitigate environmental impacts and human rights violations, but criticism focuses on compliance costs and requirements.

images.alt_text: Asia's financial regulators must pay heed to practical realities and take a systemic approach as they shape the region's markets for sustainable objectives

Sustainable Fitch’s Asia-Pacific head of ESG research Nneka Chike-Obi, said buyer-led regulations are going to heavily impact the region’s supply chain, especially with the upcoming supply chain directive in the EU.

site_title: Hong Kong retail sales rise 1.1% in December
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 1.1% in December to HK$33.7 billion, driven by improved economic sentiment and relaxation of social distancing measures. This compared to a 4.1% decline in November and a 0.7% year-on-year decrease in volume terms. The result marks a reversal of the decline seen in the previous month, indicating a modest improvement in the retail sector.

site_title: Singapore’s retail sales up 7.4% in December, extending November’s growth
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 7.4% year-over-year in December, following a 6.5% growth in November. On a month-on-month basis, retail sales increased 1.3%, reversing the 3.6% decline in November. December's total retail sales value was S$4.7 billion, with online sales accounting for 12.9%. This is lower than the 15% recorded in the previous month, attributed to a lack of major online shopping events.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Excluding motor vehicles. retail sales for November have expanded by 8.7 per cent.
Retail spaces in the Orchard Road area grew by 7.4 per cent to S$39.20 per square foot per month in Q4, noted Edmund Tie in a Thursday report.
Shoppers in Singapore's Orchard Road shopping belt.

site_title: India parliament adjourns for a second day over Adani issue
summary: India's parliament has been adjourned for a second day due to opposition protests over the stock rout in Gautam Adani's companies, with the Congress party planning nationwide protests on Monday to highlight the risks to small investors. The opposition is demanding an investigation into the crisis, which was sparked by allegations of widespread fraud and market manipulation. The protests will also draw attention to Adani's links with Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The government is under pressure to protect the interests of small investors and prevent any potential losses.

site_title: Asia: Markets drift as weak tech earnings dent recovery optimism
summary: Asian markets drifted lower on Friday as weak tech earnings from major companies like Apple, Amazon, and Alphabet dampened recovery optimism. Despite the Federal Reserve's progress in reducing inflation, traders worried about the global economy's resilience. The mixed signals overshadowed China's reopening and recovery hopes, while US jobs data later in the day will provide a clearer picture of the world's biggest economy.

images.alt_text: In early Asian trade, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta markets all rose.

site_title: Adani turmoil a key test for Modi’s India Inc
summary: India's Adani Group faces a major corporate scandal, with US short-seller Hindenburg Research accusing the companies of "brazen stock manipulation and accounting fraud" that amounts to "the largest con in corporate history". The claims, which accuse Adani of inflating stock prices using offshore tax havens, have led to a market rout wiping over $100 billion from the group's market value. The scandal raises questions about the effectiveness of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to root out corruption and the independence of India's regulatory bodies.

images.alt_text: A nationwide protest planned for Monday will also draw attention to Gautam Adani's links with Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

A man looks to an electronic signage displaying news on the Adani Group at the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building in Mumbai on January 27, 2023. - Trading in the business empire of Asia's richest man Gautam Adani was halted on January 27, 2023 following a 15 percent plunge in its share price, days after a US investment firm claimed it had committed "brazen" corporate fraud. Adani Enterprises fell 10 per cent at the open, while Adani Power, Adani Green Energy, Adani Total Gas – in which French giant TotalEnergies has a 37.4 per cent stake – and Adani Transmission were also suspended when they hit their trading stops.

The exposure by various financiers to companies controlled by Gautam Adani has come under increasing scrutiny, after their shares plunged following a scathing report from US-based Hindenburg Research.

The pandemonium in the Indian parliament could be a sign that Adani’s woes may become a political headache for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, as he looks at a third term in office in elections due next year.
The group’s flagship firm – Adani Enterprises - plunged 10 per cent after opening higher on Thursday.

site_title: Sanofi forecasts slower profit growth amid generic competition
summary: Sanofi forecasts slower profit growth due to generic competition for its multiple sclerosis drug Aubagio. Earnings per share are expected to grow at a low single-digit percentage this year, down from 26% last year. The company expects Dupixent sales to reach 10 billion euros, driven by its 44% revenue increase in 2022. Sanofi will also need to increase spending on marketing for new products, including Beyfortus and Altuviiio. The forecast follows Sanofi's unsuccessful bid for Horizon Therapeutics last year.

site_title: China’s latest IPO reform unlikely to flood markets with new issuance, bankers say
summary: China has introduced a new IPO reform, streamlining stock-market listing rules, but bankers say it's unlikely to flood markets with new listings. Under the new system, stock exchanges will vet IPOs themselves, but the government will still have significant control, dictating the direction of listings and applying national policies. The reform aims to speed up listings and corporate fundraising, but bankers warn of tighter regulatory scrutiny, citing the example of halted Ant Group's US$37 billion IPO dual-listing. The system remains largely at the mercy of authorities, with state intervention expected to delay or reject listings.

images.alt_text: Last year saw the longest-ever slump in China’s property market, following Beijing’s policies to rein in real estate credit.
The IPO reform is designed “to give the right of choice to the market,” and make IPOs more transparent and predictable, the CSRC said in a statement.

A giant screen displays stock indexes in Shanghai. At least 80 companies listed in mainland China are in danger of triggering delisting thresholds linked to finances, according to Caixin calculations.
While Jack Ma’s relinquishing of control could clear the way for Ant Group to revive its IPO, it won’t happen within this year due to listing regulations, market observers said.

Patients in Shanghai.. A senior doctor at Shanghai's Ruijin Hospital has said 70 percent of the megacity's population may have been infected with Covid-19 during China's huge surge in cases, state media reported on January 3.

site_title: US temporarily extends tariff relief on Chinese medical goods
summary: The US temporarily extends tariff exemptions on 81 Chinese medical products until mid-May, covering items such as hand sanitizer bottles, blood pressure monitors, and MRI machines. The exemptions were originally set to expire on February 28 but were extended to allow for public comments on whether the relief should continue. This move comes as inflation has surged and President Joe Biden faces pressure to end the Section 301 tariffs imposed by former President Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: China has been a major destination for capital spending by the largest semiconductor equipment companies.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) will propose on Wednesday a rule to ban “excessive” fees that credit card issuers charge for late payments, something the bureau estimated costs consumers US$12 billion a year.

site_title: World’s top pension fund posts longest losing streak in 20 years
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) reported its longest losing streak in 20 years, posting a 1.9 trillion yen (S$19.4 billion) loss, or 1% of its assets, during the three months ended Dec 31, 2022. The fund's assets fell to 189.9 trillion yen, marking a fourth consecutive quarterly loss. The losses were largely due to the US dollar's biggest quarterly drop against the yen since 2008 and the Bank of Japan's yield-curve-control policy revision in December.

images.alt_text: Yen company bond spreads have increased from 54.9 basis points at the end of October.
FILE PHOTO: Passersby are silhouetted as they walk past in front of an electric stock quotation board outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan October 18, 2022  REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Strong US job growth expected in January; wages seen cooling
summary: US job growth is expected to remain strong in January, with nonfarm payrolls likely increasing by 185,000, according to economists' forecasts. The unemployment rate is predicted to tick up to 3.6% from 3.5% in December, giving the Federal Reserve comfort in its fight against inflation. Wage growth is expected to moderate, with average hourly earnings forecast rising 0.3% and the year-on-year increase in wages to 4.3% from 4.6% in December.

images.alt_text: “Companies are preparing for an economic slowdown, cutting workforce and slowing hiring.”  said Andrew Challenger, labour expert.

Hourly output per worker, rose at a 3.0 per cent annualised rate in the fourth quarter while data for the third quarter was revised higher to show productivity growing at a 1.4 per cent rate, instead of the previously reported 0.8 per cent pace.
The rebound in factory orders in December was driven by a 16.9 per cent jump in bookings for transportation equipment, which followed a 5.2 per cent drop in November.

site_title: Japan credit spreads veer away from global tightening trend
summary: Japan's corporate bond spreads have reached a new high, diverging from the global credit trend, amid speculation over the Bank of Japan's policy changes. Yen company bond spreads increased to 63.3 basis points on Feb 1, the highest since June 2020. Investors are hesitant to take on credit duration risks, driving the divergence. The Bank of Japan's ultra-easy monetary policy normalization is expected, but the timing remains uncertain, contributing to market volatility and pressure on the central bank.

images.alt_text: Friday’s final au Jibun Bank Japan Services purchasing managers’ index (PMI) rose in January to a seasonally adjusted 52.3 from December’s 51.1, marking the fastest pace since October.
Rapidus will announce the location of its first factory in March, chairman Tetsuro Higashi said.

site_title: Adani Enterprises shares suspended as price slumps again
summary: Shares in Adani Enterprises, the flagship firm of Indian tycoon Gautam Adani, were suspended multiple times on Friday due to a price slump triggered by allegations of accounting fraud. The company fell 10% at the open, with other Adani Group companies including Adani Power, Adani Green Energy, and Adani Total Gas also suspended. Trading in Adani Enterprises resumed briefly before falling another 5%, leading to another halt. The suspensions come amid ongoing scrutiny of Adani Group's financial dealings.

images.alt_text: The group’s flagship firm – Adani Enterprises - plunged 10 per cent after opening higher on Thursday.

The pandemonium in the Indian parliament could be a sign that Adani’s woes may become a political headache for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, as he looks at a third term in office in elections due next year.

The exposure by various financiers to companies controlled by Gautam Adani has come under increasing scrutiny, after their shares plunged following a scathing report from US-based Hindenburg Research.

site_title: China to fully resume travel with Hong Kong, Macau on Feb 6
summary: China will fully resume cross-border travel with Hong Kong and Macau on February 6, dropping existing quotas and mandatory Covid-19 tests. Group tours and customs checkpoints will return to pre-pandemic levels. Hong Kong will also scrap its Covid-19 vaccination requirement for all arrivals. The move comes after China reopened its borders to the world on January 8 and follows Hong Kong's recent launch of a promotion campaign to lure back visitors.

images.alt_text: Chinese have been the largest foreign buyer group in Singapore since 2016 and made up 6.9 per cent of foreign purchases of private apartments last year.
Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee said the campaign would show that the city was open for tourism and was aimed at boosting business and investment in the Chinese special administrative region.

“The effects on Thailand may be particularly important, as several of its credit metrics, including fiscal ones, have deteriorated as a result of weak tourism activity and stepped-up fiscal efforts since 2019,” said Fitch Ratings.

site_title: China’s Jan services activity expands for first time in five months: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity expanded for the first time in five months in January, according to the Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers' index (PMI), which rose to 52.9. The expansion was driven by the lifting of pandemic curbs and the Lunar New Year holidays, boosting demand for services. The move marked a rebound in activity after four months of contraction, with business confidence reaching near 12-year highs. The decision to abandon China's strict "zero-Covid" policy is expected to accelerate economic recovery and promote normalised production and social order.

images.alt_text: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken’s trip is expected to meet Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang and possibly President Xi Jinping.
Passengers prepare to check in at Daxing International airport in Beijing on January 19, 2023. (Photo by WANG Zhao / AFP)

site_title: Beware the great battery industry fallacy
summary: The US and UK are investing heavily in battery production, despite concerns that the industry is not a promising business due to low margins, high capital costs, and technological limits. Industry leaders, such as Sony, Panasonic, and Samsung, are based in Asia, with China's CATL being the most profitable battery maker. The basic economics of battery production involve high costs, limited scalability, and a lack of brand loyalty, making it unlikely that many countries will be able to establish a thriving battery industry. Instead, innovation and growth will likely come from software, data, design, and safety features, which are areas where Silicon Valley is excelling.

images.alt_text: Volvo has carved out and sold its petrol engine and hybrid powertrain operations to Geely.
China produced 395,000 tonnes of lithium carbonate last year, up 32.5 per cent year on year, according to China’s Nonferrous Metals Industry Association.

site_title: Jokowi’s dynasty takes shape with another son entering politics
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo is building a political dynasty with his youngest son, Kaesang Pangarep, who plans to run for mayor in the 2024 elections. The move could give Widodo influence over the ruling party and potentially shape government policies after he leaves office next year. Widodo's popularity and family ties could also bolster his family members in the polls, allowing him to decide on future candidates and secure his legacy, including the $34 billion construction of Indonesia's new capital city in Borneo.

images.alt_text: The president, commonly known as Jokowi, cited 11 other incidents, spanning a period between 1965 and 2003 prior to his tenure as leader.
Joko Widodo, Indonesia's president, is expected to announce a cabinet reshuffle soon.
Indonesia has a target of having at least 1.2 million electric motorcycles and 35,000 electric cars in use by 2024.

site_title: Vietnam EV-maker VinFast delays US car deliveries to late February
summary: Vietnam's electric vehicle maker VinFast has delayed US car deliveries to late February due to software updates. The company initially targeted December deliveries but has not shipped its first 999 electric vehicles to customers yet. VinFast is expanding in the US to compete with existing automakers, aiming to capitalize on the growing demand for electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: For most of this year, Tesla joined rivals in aggressively raising prices on its most popular vehicles, such as the Model Y SUV.
VinFast is gearing up to expand in the United States, where it hopes to compete with existing automakers by offering two models, the VF8 and VF9.

site_title: ‘Something must be done!’ The crypto regulatory challenge for 2023
summary: Cryptocurrency exchange FTX's collapse in 2022 raised concerns about regulatory action, but little evidence suggests a massive new regulatory infrastructure is needed to police the crypto ecosystem. Despite billions of dollars in money laundering and scams, the collapse did not pose a significant threat to the global financial system. The "crypto winter" of 2022 showed crypto is closely correlated to conventional finance and did not cause significant transmission dangers. Existing gaps in laws and regulations, such as the definition of property rights, may be addressed by self-regulatory agencies or traditional regulatory bodies.

images.alt_text: Some of the FTX businesses have in aggregate attracted interest from more than 100 parties, earlier filings showed.
For the consultation a total of 58 submissions were received, and respondents “generally indicated their support” for regulating stablecoins, the HKMA said.
The UK government’s move to regulate crypto is part of a push by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak to attract more crypto businesses and investment to the country.

site_title: The Great Resignation to come for boards with long serving IDs
summary: A survey by KPMG found 48% of Singapore Exchange-listed company boards have an independent director serving for over 9 years. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has announced new rules limiting ID tenure to 9 years and removing the two-tier voting mechanism, prompting boards with long-serving IDs to plan for succession. Despite disagreement, STI companies with long-serving IDs stated they have succession plans in place, citing the new rules for greater clarity.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

Previously, long-serving IDs (LSIDs) could continue to be deemed independent if approval was obtained at two tiers of voting: first, from all shareholders; and second, from shareholders excluding directors, the CEO and their associates.
Market regulators should conduct a more comprehensive review and further amend existing listing rules to better equip independent directors in their governance roles of listed companies

site_title: Japan’s Jan services activity growth at three-month high: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector activity grew at its fastest pace in three months in January, with the au Jibun Bank Japan Services PMI rising to 52.3, a seasonally adjusted 52.4. The sector's expansion, driven by improved overseas demand and the National Travel Discount Programme, contrasts with rising inflation and employment trends, which signal challenges ahead. The contrasting price trends signal deteriorating profitability for service companies, potentially limiting post-pandemic growth.

images.alt_text: Japan's output and new orders contracted for a seventh consecutive month in January, although at a slower pace than in the previous two months, the S&P survey’s subindexes showed.
A vocal advocate of aggressive monetary easing, Masazumi Wakatabe has consistently voted for maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy.
Rapidus will announce the location of its first factory in March, chairman Tetsuro Higashi said.

site_title: Meta mojo is back as earnings surprise powers Big Tech rally
summary: Meta Platforms reported a 23% surge in its stock value, adding over $90 billion to its market value, after slashing its spending forecast and boosting its stock buyback plan by $40 billion. The company's earnings also lifted shares of Amazon, Apple, and Alphabet, and analysts boosted their price targets, citing a combination of lower costs, upbeat revenue growth, and share buybacks. Meta's CEO Mark Zuckerberg called the period a "year of efficiency," reflecting cost-cutting measures and a focus on core social-media business.

images.alt_text: Meta plans to cut costs in 2023 by US$5 billion to between US$89 billion and US$95 billion compared with its earlier outlook of US$94 billion to US$100 billion.
Shares of Alphabet were down nearly 5 per cent in after-hours trading, after losing about 40 per cent of their value in 2022.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, ST Engineering, CLCT, Nanofilm, Digital Core Reit
summary: Keppel's net profit for the second half ended December declined 40.6% to S$429.1 million, while CapitaLand Ascendas Reit's distribution per unit rose 4.3% to S$0.07925. ST Engineering acquired a Singapore shipyard for S$95 million, and Nanofilm Technologies warned of a 30% decline in net profit and 4% fall in revenue for FY2022. Digital Core Reit's DPU was below expectations, and trading halted for several companies pending announcements.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Friday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,369.88. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 44 in early trade, driven by gains in US and European markets. Sembcorp Marine and Mapletree Logistics Trust were among the top gainers, while UOB and DBS rose, while OCBC fell. The gains followed better-than-expected results from Meta platforms and anticipation of the end of the global rate hiking cycle.

images.alt_text: Photos by Yen Meng Jiin: Interior and exterior of SGX

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH upgrades CSE Global to ‘buy’ following acquisition of US radio group
summary: UOB Kay Hian upgraded CSE Global to "buy" from "hold" following its US$11 million acquisition of US radio communication group Radio One Group and securing two major contracts worth US$87.3 million. The target price was raised to S$0.45 from S$0.37, driven by the research team's view of the deal as "highly accretive". The acquisition is expected to lift CSE's earnings FY2023 by 20% or S$3.6 million, assuming Radio One Group's 2022 earnings can be sustained.

images.alt_text: CSE Global expects the acquisition will be earnings accretive and be a strategic fit to complement its current business.

site_title: With rare China trip, Blinken aims to steady rocky relationship
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken is set to meet Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang and possibly President Xi Jinping during his trip to China, aiming to steady the rocky relationship between the two superpowers. The trip follows a worsening trade war and tensions over Taiwan, with both sides seeking to avoid a new Cold War. Analysts see Blinken's main task as ensuring both countries can avoid a crisis, with a focus on reestablishing the undergirding of the relationship and managing tensions. However, expectations for the trip are low, with no breakthrough likely on major issues such as Taiwan, trade, or human rights.

images.alt_text: Beijing filed a dispute with the World Trade Organization in December aimed at overturning the US-imposed export controls.

CIA Director William Burns, speaking at a foreign policy event at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., said China's President Xi Jinping maintains serious ambitions over Taiwan and warned that conflict over the island nation would be “deeply unfortunate” for all involved.

site_title: Amazon still grasping for success with supermarkets: CEO
summary: Amazon has paused the expansion of its Fresh supermarkets and cashier-less convenience stores until it finds the right recipe for success, according to CEO Andy Jassy. The company believes it has fallen short in dominating the grocery sector, despite its acquisition of Whole Foods Market in 2017. Amazon's large business from packaged food and other goods has yet to translate to significant market share in perishables. The company is shifting focus to finding a distinctive store format that's financially successful before major expansion.

images.alt_text: Amazon’s decision to sell the property underscores the risks of a new real estate strategy the company has embraced in recent years.
Amazon says it invests hundreds of millions of dollars annually to ensure worker safety.

site_title: Hot stock: Nanofilm declines 6.7% after FY2022 profit warning
summary: Nanofilm Technologies' shares plummeted 6.7% after the company warned of a 30% drop in net profit for FY2022, citing a 4% year-on-year decline in revenue. The counter hit a one-month low of S$1.38, its lowest level since Jan 4. The company's stock closed at S$1.40, with 11.2 million shares changing hands.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Nanofilm said it remains focused on achieving its targeted S$500 million revenue and S$100 million in net profit by 2025.
UOB analyst John Cheong expects that “sporadic lockdowns” in China will negatively affect Nanofilm's revenue.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit near one-year high on hopes of rate hike pause
summary: Europe's stocks hit a near one-year high, closing up 1.8% on Thursday, as investors remained hopeful the global rate hiking cycle would soon end. The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates by 50 basis points and signaled another hike of the same magnitude next month. Despite the hawkish tone, analysts believe the market is not fully convinced, citing a desire for sustained inflation reduction. The ECB's comments were seen as less hawkish than the US Federal Reserve and Bank of England, contributing to the rally in equity markets.

images.alt_text: The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index finished 3.3 per cent higher at 12,200.82 on Thursday.

site_title: Beef that makes the cut at Meadesmoore
summary: Meadesmoore, a CBD steakhouse in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience by focusing on secondary cuts of beef, such as tri-tip and rump cap, which are served in "large format" plates. The restaurant, led by chef Victor Loy, aims to remind diners of the quality of beef beyond prime cuts. The menu features a range of dishes, including baby squid-like octopus, roasted bone marrow with clams, and spicy pig's ears. While prices are steep, the consistent, solid cooking and creative twists on classic dishes make for a memorable experience.

images.alt_text: Ummi Beirut's plush interiors.

site_title: Okta to cut 300 jobs citing overhiring, ‘execution challenges’
summary: OKTA, a software company, is cutting approximately 300 employees, about 5% of its workforce, due to overhiring and "execution challenges." CEO Todd McKinnon cited the need to reduce spending and improve profitability as the reason for the layoffs. The company will incur about $15 million in restructuring costs. The move comes as the company focuses on improving its financial performance.

site_title: Oil slumps on economic data, stronger US dollar
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, with Brent crude futures settling at US$82.17 a barrel, down 67 cents or 0.8%, and West Texas Intermediate crude at US$75.88 a barrel, down 53 cents or 0.7%. The decline was driven by weaker US industrial-linked factory orders and a stronger US dollar, which made crude more expensive for non-American buyers. A rebound in the dollar index also weighed on oil prices, following the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down US$2.62, or 3.1 per cent, at US$82.84 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Alphabet misses Street estimates as ad business slips after pandemic run-up
summary: Alphabet missed Street estimates for fourth-quarter profit and revenue, with shares falling nearly 5% in after-hours trading. The company's digital ad clients pulled back spending, driven by rising inflation and interest rates. Net income fell to $13.62 billion, and adjusted profit fell short of expectations. Revenue from Google advertising, including Search and YouTube, fell 3.6% to $59.04 billion. Despite a 32% growth in cloud revenue, Alphabet's overall performance was impacted by a tough macroeconomic environment and competition from rival platforms.

images.alt_text: Meta plans to cut costs in 2023 by US$5 billion to between US$89 billion and US$95 billion compared with its earlier outlook of US$94 billion to US$100 billion.
The departure of these veterans may be a sign that Google is drifting away from a business that has weathered significant privacy and antitrust scrutiny.

site_title: Ford shares fall as Q4 profits lag estimates
summary: Ford reported a quarterly profit of $1.3 billion, below the estimated $12.3 billion due to "execution problems" and supply chain issues. The company attributed its annual loss of $2 billion to missed profits within its control. Ford has invested heavily in electric vehicles and has designated legacy internal combustion autos into its "Ford Blue" division. Shares fell 5.9% to $13.47 in after-hours trading, following a year of profits of $17.9 billion.

site_title: Apple’s lower iPhone sales drive first profit miss since 2016
summary: Apple reported its first profit miss since 2016 due to weak iPhone sales, down 8% to $65.8 billion from the previous year. The sales fell below analyst estimates of $68.3 billion. The company's shares dropped 4% after the results were published. The decline in iPhone sales was attributed to disruptions in China's production due to Covid-19 lockdowns.

images.alt_text: The demand for smartphones and PCs initially rose during the pandemic, but started to weaken in the middle of the last year.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) will propose on Wednesday a rule to ban “excessive” fees that credit card issuers charge for late payments, something the bureau estimated costs consumers US$12 billion a year.
On Wednesday, Samsung took the wraps off the latest iteration of its closest iPhone competitor, the S23, with better cameras and battery life.

site_title: US factory orders rebound in December
summary: US factory orders rebounded 1.8% in December, driven by a 16.9% jump in transportation equipment bookings. However, higher interest rates and a strong US dollar are weighing on business spending, with non-defence capital goods orders dipping 0.1% and shipments of core capital goods dropping 0.6%. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes are undercutting demand for goods, and spending is shifting back to services, with the manufacturing PMI contracting for a third straight month in January.

images.alt_text: Hourly output per worker, rose at a 3.0 per cent annualised rate in the fourth quarter while data for the third quarter was revised higher to show productivity growing at a 1.4 per cent rate, instead of the previously reported 0.8 per cent pace.
Claims have been running low this year, consistent with a persistently tight labour market.

site_title: Starbucks misses quarterly sales estimates as China weakness weighs
summary: Starbucks missed quarterly sales estimates, with comparable sales declining due to ongoing Covid-19 outbreaks in China despite the country's reopening in early December. The company's North American market saw strong sales, but it wasn't enough to offset the weakness. Shares dropped 3% in extended trading, closing at $106.34. The decline was attributed to China's lingering customer traffic issues.

images.alt_text: Organisers say the planned strike will involve more than 1,000 workers, making it the biggest multiday work stoppage ever by Starbucks Workers United.

site_title: Netherlands’ largest bank posts bigger Q4 profit
summary: ING Group, the largest Dutch bank, reported a fourth-quarter net profit of 1.1 billion euros, exceeding forecasts, but its shares fell as 2023 guidance fell short of expectations. Loan-loss provisions decreased 22% from the previous year. The bank's chief executive, Steven van Rijswijk, stated that rising interest rates will benefit margins, but warned of low single-digit downgrades to 2023 consensus due to economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo
The ECB is seen raising its deposit rate by another half a percentage point to 2.5 per cent on Thursday, in line with what it said in December.

site_title: Metaverse dating has legitimate use cases, accompanying business opportunities
summary: A recent survey by Dating.com found that a third of singles plan to venture into "meta-dating" in 2023, where couples meet in digital realms, such as virtual concerts and themed gardens, using immersive headsets. This trend has legitimate use cases, including social isolation and accessibility issues. The survey also revealed that over three-quarters of respondents would be keen to attend a digital concert, highlighting the potential for metaverse dating to become a viable business opportunity.

images.alt_text: Digital artist Mason Rothschild’s creation of “MetaBirkin” nonfungible tokens sparked a trademark battle with Hermès International.
Consumers globally have taken to VR less rapidly than initially hoped, held back in part by a lack of titles that can showcase the technology
woman, technology, science

site_title: US: Nasdaq leaps 3.3% in tech rally after Meta results
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index surged 3.3% to 12,200.82 on Thursday, driven by strong tech earnings from Meta Platforms. The move lifted hopes for future earnings from Apple and other major tech companies. In contrast, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1% and the S&P 500 rose 1.5%. The tech-rich Nasdaq's rally helped counterbalance losses in the broader US stock market.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 36.34 points, or 0.11 per cent, at the open to 34,129.30.

site_title: Ransomware attack on data firm ION could take days to fix
summary: A ransomware attack on ION Trading UK, a financial data firm, has left scores of brokers unable to process derivatives trades, potentially taking days to fix. The attack began on January 31 and is contained to a specific environment, with ION Group stating remediation of services is ongoing. The affected servers are disconnected, and ransom demands could total millions of US dollars. Several major banks, including ABN Amro and Intesa Sanpaolo, were impacted, with operations severely hampered by IT problems at ION.

site_title: US productivity accelerates in Q4
summary: US worker productivity increased by 3.0% annually in Q4, higher than forecasted 2.4%, while unit labour costs rose 1.1% and hourly compensation increased 4.1%. Productivity fell 1.5% from last year, and unit labour costs rose 4.5% from 2022, outpacing the Federal Reserve's 2% inflation target. The increase in productivity is seen as a moderation in labour costs growth, which may ease pressure on the US central bank to raise interest rates further.

site_title: ST Engineering acquires shipyard from Keppel FELS for S$95 million
summary: ST Engineering acquired the site and assets of a shipyard in Singapore from Keppel FELS for S$95 million. The new Gul yard will replace ST Engineering's existing Tuas shipyard, which expires its lease in 2024. The Gul yard, with a 20-year remaining lease, will support the group's commercial ship repair business and be upgraded to a smart shipyard with end-to-end digitalisation. This acquisition minimizes capital expenditure and enables immediate operation with minimal disruption.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
ST Engineering says TransCore acquisition complies with US rules

site_title: China private sector sees big-business share drop a second year
summary: China's private sector saw a drop in its share of big businesses for the second consecutive year, according to the Peterson Institute for International Economics. The private sector's share declined 5 percentage points to 42.8% at the end of 2022, following Beijing's regulatory crackdowns and a property-market slump. The slump, which lasted a year, was triggered by Beijing's policies to rein in real estate credit, affecting large privately owned companies such as China Evergrande Group and Country Garden Holdings. This marks the longest-ever slump in China's property market.

images.alt_text: China’s property sector, accounting for a quarter of the economy, has struggled with defaults and stalled projects, hitting market confidence and weighing on economic growth.

site_title: UK urges British steel to continue talks to secure its future
summary: The UK government urged British Steel to continue talks to secure its future, following reports of 800 job losses at the Scunthorpe site. The company, owned by China's Jingye Group, is considering the redundancies despite a £300-million support package offered by the UK. Business Minister Nusrat Ghani said the government will ensure support is available for employees, while Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's administration is concerned about decommissioning liabilities and undermining domestic steel production.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak speaks during a Q&A at Teesside University in Darlington, Britain, January 30, 2023. Oli Scarff/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Umno’s internal conflict a test to stability of Malaysia’s unity government
summary: Malaysia's unity government, led by Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, is strengthened by Umno President Ahmad Zahid Hamidi's retention of his position, ensuring stability for at least three years. Zahid's influence within the party has been cemented, following a resolution on no-contest rules for the party's top positions. This development has boosted the unity government, despite potential internal conflicts within Umno, and upcoming state elections will provide a test of Zahid's influence and the government's stability. Analysts warn that growing divisions within Umno could pose a threat to the unity government if not addressed.

images.alt_text: Zahid’s potential toppling as party president could threaten Malaysia’s newfound political stability as he played a pivotal role in supporting Anwar’s coalition government.
Malaysians are hoping that the new government led by prime minister Anwar Ibrahim could focus on steering the economy and tackling issues on high cost of living.

site_title: ECB raises rates again and plans at least one more hike
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) raised interest rates by half a percentage point to 2.5%, in line with December's decision and market expectations. This marks the fifth consecutive rate hike to combat high inflation in the eurozone, which has been driven by factors such as the Covid-19 pandemic and energy crisis. The ECB has pledged at least one more hike of the same magnitude next month, with President Christine Lagarde believing the EU economy will recover over the coming quarters.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit H2 DPU rises 4.3% to S$0.07925 on higher revenue
summary: CapitaLand Ascendas Reit reported a 4.3% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.07925 for the second half of 2022, driven by strong operational performance and positive average rent reversion of 8%. The Reit's gross revenue rose 7.1% to S$686.1 million, while net property income (NPI) grew 3.5%.
