The Reit manager expects strong rental reversion in the logistics space in FY2023 and will continue to undertake redevelopment and asset enhancement initiatives to reposition its properties.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Jude Chan

The Business Times reported in May last year that Sea Ltd, parent company of e-commerce player Shopee, was expected to lease most of the office space at the CapitaLand Development-owned property in tandem with its business growth.

site_title: OECD offers final guidance for global minimum corporate tax
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has released final guidance for governments to adopt the global minimum corporate tax, aiming to limit compliance costs and conflicts. Nearly 140 countries agreed in 2021 to apply a 15% minimum tax rate on multinationals, with the reform expected to yield an extra $220 billion in tax income globally. The new tax code aims to update decades-old rules for the digital age, addressing issues where tech giants like Apple and Google can book profits in low-tax countries.

site_title: Indonesia’s Astra Daihatsu Motor starts building 2.9 trillion rupiah car assembly plant
summary: Astra Daihatsu Motor, a unit of Astra International and Daihatsu, began constructing a new car assembly plant in East Karawang, West Java, Indonesia, with a 2.9 trillion rupiah investment. The plant, expected to produce 140,000 cars annually, aims to be completed by December 2024. The facility is built on renewable energy concepts and is expected to reduce carbon emissions by up to a fifth. The construction is seen as a commitment to Indonesia's automotive industry, with the government welcoming the expansion as a successful implementation of incentives.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on Meta surge, Fed relief
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, February 2, driven by a surge in Meta Platforms and a dovish message from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.11%, the Nasdaq Composite rose 2.11%, and the S&P 500 opened higher by 0.96%. The Fed's softer landing expectations boosted market sentiment, while Meta's rigorous cost controls also contributed to the gains.

site_title: Thailand urges people to stay indoors as air pollution spikes
summary: Thailand's air pollution has spiked to 14 times the recommended safe level, prompting authorities to urge people to stay indoors. The pollution control department attributes the increase to stagnant weather conditions exacerbating vehicle emissions and seasonal fires on agricultural lands. The city of Bangkok is among the worst affected, with PM2.5 concentrations at a level considered hazardous by the World Health Organisation.

images.alt_text: More aggressive climate policies are par for the course if Singapore embarks on a more definitive plan to reach net-zero emissions by 2050, economists, academics and consultants told The Business Times.

site_title: UK financial watchdog proposes banning referral fees for debt-advisory firms
summary: The UK's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) has proposed banning debt-advisory companies from receiving referral fees from related businesses, citing a conflict of interest that could harm customers. The ban aims to address the issue of "unsuitable" debt arrangements, which could lead to customers paying more money over a longer period. The FCA estimates that 52,000 of 1.7 million people seeking debt advice annually begin with debt packagers, which would be affected by the proposed ban.

images.alt_text: Prices are steadily rising for consumers even as broader measures of inflation start to ease in the UK.
UK supermarkets say that consumers stocked up early for Christmas, then reduced their spending in December due to higher food and living costs.
An unprecedented series of interest-rate hikes from the Bank of England has bumped up the cost of mortgages. The effective rate on new loans rose 32 basis points to 3.67 per cent last month.
The budget deficit underscore risks to the UK economy as Prime Minister Rishi Sunak struggles to contain inflation near a four-decade high and strikes crippling the public services.
Confidence indicators have been sending conflicting messages over the state of the economy as forecasters warn that the UK is likely heading into recession in the first half of 2023.
Businesses have been battling severe worker shortages, with high demand for staff fuelling the strongest wage growth on record outside of the pandemic.
Average earnings in Britain excluding bonuses were 6.4 per cent higher than a year previously – the biggest increase since record began in 2001.

site_title: Bank of England raises borrowing costs to 4%, hints rates near peak
summary: The Bank of England raised interest rates to 4% for the 10th time, its highest since 2008, to combat 10% inflation and prevent a deep recession. The decision, voted 7-2, signals the end of a sharp rate hike cycle and inflation is likely to peak. The central bank forecasts a 0.5% contraction in GDP this year, a shallower recession than initially predicted, and inflation to fall to 4% by end of the year.

images.alt_text: People walk along Regent Street during the second day of Boxing Day sales, in London, Britain, December 27, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls
An unprecedented series of interest-rate hikes from the Bank of England has bumped up the cost of mortgages. The effective rate on new loans rose 32 basis points to 3.67 per cent last month.

site_title: US layoffs hit two-year high in Jan as tech slashed thousands of jobs: report
summary: US layoffs hit a two-year high in January, with 102,943 workers impacted, a more than two-fold jump from December and over five-times surge from a year earlier. Tech firms, including Microsoft and Amazon, cut 41,829 and 13,000 jobs, respectively, while financial firms shed 10,603 positions. Analysts expect more layoffs due to the Federal Reserve's rate-hiking path to control inflation, with companies preparing for an economic slowdown. Experts attribute the job cuts to companies correcting pandemic excesses and preparing for a possible recession.

site_title: Singapore PMI inches up in January but remains in contraction for 5th straight month
summary: Singapore's overall factory activity improved modestly in January, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising 0.1 point to 49.8, its fifth consecutive month in contraction territory. The electronics sector PMI also edged up 0.2 point to 49.1, but economists remain unconvinced that the manufacturing sector will see better days soon due to weaker external demand and the electronics down cycle. Experts predict further contraction in the first half of 2023, with a 5.4% manufacturing contraction expected this year.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Excluding the typically volatile biomedical manufacturing cluster, factory output expanded 0.3 per cent year on year, reversing November’s 5.8 per cent contraction.
Given the weaker-than-expected December NODX print, Singapore's key exports are expected to contract further in the coming months, according to private-sector economists.
The Purchasing Managers' Index dipped 0.1 point to 49.7 in December, the fourth consecutive month of contraction in overall activity.

site_title: Sterling slides after Bank of England meeting
summary: The pound fell to a session low of US$1.2276 after the Bank of England raised interest rates to 4.0% by 50 basis points, hinting its tightening cycle might be nearing an end. The move followed the US Federal Reserve's slower pace of rate rises, signaling a possible end to the US central bank's rate-rise campaign. The pound recovered slightly, but the euro also dipped against the dollar after the European Central Bank's interest rate hike, with the euro falling 0.64% to US$1.0920.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index, which measures the US currency against six major peers, fell 0.2 per cent to 101.91. It also slipped in the previous session.

site_title: Ferrari revs up for “even stronger 2023” after beating forecasts in Q4
summary: Ferrari reported a 16% increase in core earnings in 2022, driven by high demand for its luxury sports cars. The company expects "even stronger" results in 2023, with adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization (Ebitda) projected to range between 2.13-2.18 billion euros. Ferrari's new Purosangue four-seater is expected to start deliveries in the second quarter, with orders exceeding expectations. The company's shares rose 1.8% after publishing the results.

site_title: Google job cuts hit veterans of DoubleClick ad-tech business
summary: Google has laid off at least five executives from its ad-tech division, including veterans from DoubleClick, the company that Google acquired in 2007. The departures may signal Google's shift away from a business that has faced significant privacy and antitrust scrutiny. The US Department of Justice has sued Google over its dominance in digital advertising technology, and the company is expected to defend its practices in court. The job cuts, part of Alphabet's 12,000 job reductions, affect all product areas, but Google remains committed to its display business.

images.alt_text: The federal antitrust suit accused Google of unlawfully maintaining a monopoly that had “corrupted legitimate competition in the ad tech industry.”
Meta plans to cut costs in 2023 by US$5 billion to between US$89 billion and US$95 billion compared with its earlier outlook of US$94 billion to US$100 billion.

site_title: FWD appoints new Singapore head
summary: FWD Group has appointed Adrian Vincent as the new CEO of FWD Singapore, succeeding Khor Kee Eng. Vincent, who joined FWD in 2019, brings over two decades of insurance industry experience and previously served as deputy CEO at HSBC Life Insurance. He plans to continue FWD's customer-led approach to insurance, focusing on making protection, retirement savings, and legacy planning accessible and affordable in Singapore. The appointment is subject to regulatory approval.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; layoffs surge in January
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell to 183,000 in the week ending Jan 28, a seasonally adjusted decrease of 3,000, despite a persistently tight labor market. This drop is consistent with economists' expectations and suggests the labor market remains resilient despite higher borrowing costs and recession fears. The number of job openings at the end of December reached 11 million, with 1.9 openings for every unemployed person, indicating employers' reluctance to lay off workers.

images.alt_text: “Companies are preparing for an economic slowdown, cutting workforce and slowing hiring.”  said Andrew Challenger, labour expert.

site_title: Indian state bank has US$2.6b in loans to Adani
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) has provided loans of up to $2.6 billion to companies controlled by Gautam Adani, exceeding the allowed limit by half. The exposure includes $200 million from SBI's overseas units. SBI's chairperson, Dinesh Kumar Khara, stated that Adani Group companies are servicing the loans, and he does not foresee an immediate challenge. The Reserve Bank of India has requested lenders to provide details of their exposure to the conglomerate following a stock price rout.

images.alt_text: The group’s flagship firm – Adani Enterprises - plunged 10 per cent after opening higher on Thursday.

The pandemonium in the Indian parliament could be a sign that Adani’s woes may become a political headache for Prime Minister Narendra Modi, as he looks at a third term in office in elections due next year.

site_title: Digital Core posts H2 DPU of US$0.0192, lower than forecasted
summary: Digital Core Reit reported a second-half distributable per unit (DPU) of US$0.0192, lower than forecasted US$0.0209. Gross revenue for H2 FY22 was US$54.9 million, up 3.6% from forecast, but property expenses exceeded expectations. Distributable income to unitholders fell short of the forecasted US$23.8 million, resulting in a full-year DPU of US$0.0398, 4.8% lower than forecasted. Despite the disappointing results, the manager expressed confidence in creating sustainable value for unitholders.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The last time there were no S-Reit IPOs was in 2008 and 2009, in the aftermath of the Global Financial Crisis.
Digital Core Reit is no longer proceeding with plans to acquire a 90 per cent interest in a freehold data centre in Dallas, Texas (pictured).
DBS has cut the target price of Manulife US Reit, which is currently undergoing a strategic review, by 31 per cent.

site_title: Hong Kong giant Swire makes push into luxury residential in Bangkok with 2.4b baht land buy
summary: Swire Properties, a Hong Kong giant, has acquired a 40% stake in a prime 2.4 billion baht (S$95 million) land in Bangkok for its first investment in the Thai capital's property market. The company plans to develop the site into a luxury condominium project in a joint venture with City Realty. The 136,336 square feet site is located near upscale shopping malls, international schools, and embassies, with CEO Tim Blackburn citing Bangkok as an "exciting emerging market" for high-end residential properties.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei

site_title: Xiaomi demands payout from supplier after car designs leaked
summary: Xiaomi has imposed a 1 million yuan ($194,292) penalty on a Beijing-based supplier for leaking early design drafts of an upcoming car model, violating a confidentiality agreement. The leak occurred on January 22 and revealed images of the car's front and rear bumpers. As punishment, Xiaomi will also impose "economic compensation" on the supplier. The company did not disclose the name of the supplier, and Reuters was unable to identify it.

site_title: British cybersecurity firm NCC Group to cut workforce by 7%
summary: British cybersecurity firm NCC Group plans to cut over 125 jobs, accounting for 7% of its total employee count, as part of an ongoing strategic review. The job cuts will lead to a one-off implementation cost of £4 million and are expected to mainly affect the UK and North America. The company also lowered its annual revenue growth forecast to single-digit due to delays in revenue recognition, but expects an 8% growth in adjusted operating profit to £52 million.

site_title: Meta surges on cost cut, buyback plans; lifts mega-cap stocks
summary: Meta Platforms' shares surged 20% in premarket trading after the company announced plans to cut costs by $5 billion in 2023, aiming for $89-95 billion in revenue. CEO Mark Zuckerberg called 2023 the "Year of Efficiency." The company also announced a $40 billion share buyback. Meta forecasts first-quarter sales ahead of Wall Street estimates, boosting investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Meta cut 11,000 jobs, or 13 per cent of the workforce, in November in its first-ever major layoff.

site_title: India’s budget maintains fine balance between fiscal prudence and economic growth
summary: India's Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman unveiled a 45 trillion rupees (S$715.1 billion) budget for the next fiscal year, aiming to strike a balance between fiscal prudence and economic growth. Key highlights include a 33% increase in capital expenditure to 10 trillion rupees, a reduced fiscal deficit target of 5.9% of GDP, and a boost to infrastructure development. The government also extended tax neutrality for offshore funds at the Gujarat International Finance Tec-City and increased the tax collected at source for foreign payments.

images.alt_text: The exposure by various financiers to companies controlled by Gautam Adani has come under increasing scrutiny, after their shares plunged following a scathing report from US-based Hindenburg Research.
HDFC, set to merge with India’s largest private lender HDFC Bank, said interest income climbed 30.8 per cent to 144.58 billion rupees.
India's total expenditure for the next fiscal year, which starts on Apr 1, is expected to rise 7.4 per cent to 45 trillion rupees (S$722.3 billion).

site_title: Covid sales hit, Roche warns that 2023 profits will fall by 5b Swiss francs
summary: Swiss pharmaceuticals company Roche warned that its profits will decline by 5 billion Swiss francs (S$7.2 billion) in 2023 due to falling demand for Covid-19 treatments and diagnostic kits. The company's Covid-related sales, mainly from lab tests and antibody treatment Ronapreve, are forecast to fall by 5 billion Swiss francs. Despite this, Roche's underlying business is growing strongly, with core earnings per share expected to decrease at a "low single-digit" percentage. The company's shares fell as investors worried about the weaker-than-expected outlook.

images.alt_text: Schinecker will replace Severin Schwan, whom the company has nominated to be its next chairman.
Pfizer’s Covid-19 vaccine Comirnaty and virus pill Paxlovid have been transformative for the company, contributing more than half of the company’s US$100 billion in sales last year.
Lim See Wah , CEO of Hyphens Pharma
Pfizer and BioNTech agreed to supply the European Union with 900 million Covid-19 vaccine doses by the end of 2023, though that amount might change due to a supply glut.
Pfizer has also separately agreed over the past year to supply millions of doses of its Covid-19 oral treatment drug Paxlovid to low- and middle-income countries.

site_title: Nanofilm issues profit warning for FY22 amid lower revenue
summary: Nanofilm Technologies has issued a profit warning for its financial year ended December 31, 2022, predicting a 30% decrease in net profit and a 4% decline in revenue compared to the previous year. The decline in revenue is attributed to one-off costs related to Covid-19 restrictions and a net loss incurred by its subsidiary, Sydrogen Energy. The company remains focused on achieving its targeted revenue and net profit of S$500 million and S$100 million by 2025.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

The company expects its efforts to expand its production facilities as well as business in green energy and hydrogen fuel to drive its revenue to S$500 million and its profit to S$100 million by 2025.
Nanofilm Technologies has entered into a joint venture to provide coating solutions for electric vehicles' battery components.

site_title: Heathrow boss John Holland-Kaye to leave this year
summary: Heathrow Airport's CEO, John Holland-Kaye, has announced he will step down this year after nine years at the helm. Holland-Kaye led the airport's efforts to build a third runway, a contentious issue due to environmental concerns. Heathrow regained its position as Western Europe's busiest airport last year after the COVID-19 pandemic. His departure will be completed by the end of the year, with a search for his replacement underway. Chairman Paul Deighton praised Holland-Kaye's leadership, citing his efforts to promote the UK's aviation industry and reduce carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: The Public and Commercial Services Union said more than 1,000 Border Force staff, who are employed by the government, were expecting to strike.

site_title: Japanese chip venture Rapidus needs 7 trillion yen to begin production, says chairman
summary: Japan's state-backed chip venture Rapidus will need approximately 7 trillion yen (S$70.9 billion) of taxpayer money to begin mass producing advanced logic chips in 2027. The venture, which aims to revive Japan's aging semiconductor industry, will announce its first factory location in March. The project is seen as a joint effort to counter China's growing influence in the global chip market, with Japan and the US cooperating on semiconductor technology. Rapidus has secured initial funding of 70 billion yen from Japan's government, but will require sustained investment from the government to proceed.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's shares fell on Thursday, led by declines in local banks, amid market expectations that the US Federal Reserve is close to ending its rate hike cycle. The US Fed hiked its policy rate by 25 basis points, but the local banking trio traded in the red. Meanwhile, a new career conversion program aims to re-skill 280 PMETs for jobs in Singapore's furniture industry by September 2024. Singapore's six-month T-bill closed with a yield of 3.88%, and the country launched its largest energy storage system, operated by Sembcorp Industries.

site_title: Spain’s jobless inches up in Jan but stays at 15-year low
summary: Spain's unemployment rate remained at a 15-year low in January, increasing by 70,744 people to 2.91 million, a 2.5% rise from December. This modest increase is considered stable compared to historical averages, according to Labour Minister Yolanda Diaz. The low unemployment rate is an encouraging sign for Spain's economy, which is expected to slow down this year after a 5.5% growth last year.

site_title: Keppel H2 net profit falls 40.6% to S$429.1 million
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a 40.6% year-on-year decline in net profit for the second half of 2022 to S$429.1 million, mainly due to lower revenue from continuing operations. Excluding discontinued operations, net profit from continuing operations fell 55.2% to S$404.8 million. The company's energy & environment segment recorded a net profit of S$126.6 million, while urban development and asset management segments posted weaker profits. Keppel's full-year net profit slipped 9.4% to S$926.6 million, and a final cash dividend of S$0.18 per share for FY22 was proposed.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Sembmarine said its independent directors recommend that shareholders vote in favour of its merger with Keppel O&M.

Keppel O&M, a unit under Keppel Corporation, is currently working towards a merger with Sembcorp Marine (Sembmarine) after shareholders approved the proposed merger through an extraordinary general meeting last December.

site_title: Paris Club to give Sri Lanka financial assurances amid IMF debt talks
summary: The Paris Club, a group of creditor nations, is set to provide financing assurances to Sri Lanka, a key step needed to unlock a $2.9 billion IMF bailout. This move comes after Sri Lanka entered into a staff level agreement with the IMF last September. China and India, major bilateral lenders, have offered financial assistance, but the US has expressed concerns that Beijing's assurances are not sufficient, calling for "credible and specific" debt relief. The Paris Club's support is expected to unlock the IMF bailout, providing financial assurances to Sri Lanka.

images.alt_text: Cooling inflation provides the monetary authority more scope to support an economy that ground to a halt last year following the debt crisis.

site_title: Hong Kong offers 500,000 free flights to woo back visitors after Covid
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive John Lee launched a "Hello Hong Kong" campaign to attract visitors, businesses, and investors after more than three years of COVID-19 curbs. The campaign includes 500,000 free flights to boost tourism and investment in the Chinese special administrative region. Lee emphasized the city's reopening, with no isolation, quarantine, or restrictions, and aims to reconnect Hong Kong to the international world. The move comes after China relaxed its COVID-19 policies in December and Hong Kong dropped most of its remaining rules in December.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s top developers have enjoyed decades of lucrative returns in one of the world’s most expensive property markets.
Hong Kong’s monetary policy moves in lock-step with the United States as the city’s currency is pegged to the greenback in a tight range of 7.75-7.85 per dollar.

site_title: TikTok’s coming for Amazon’s search traffic
summary: Amazon's grip on online shopping search traffic is loosening as TikTok gains popularity, particularly among young shoppers. In Q3 last year, 63% of shoppers began their search on Amazon, down from 74% in 2021, while TikTok's share rose to 21% from 10%. Amazon is responding with its "Inspire" feature, aiming to connect customers with "shoppable content" created by other customers, influencers, and brands. However, its platform's lack of entertainment, engagement, and surprise factor may hinder its ability to compete with TikTok, which has become a more enjoyable and addictive shopping experience.

images.alt_text: TikTok has been seeking to assure Washington that the personal data of US citizens cannot be accessed.
Amazon’s decision to sell the property underscores the risks of a new real estate strategy the company has embraced in recent years.

site_title: New book shines light on region’s vast art scene
summary: A new book, "SEA: Contemporary Art In Southeast Asia," offers an authoritative and accessible introduction to the diverse art scenes of the region, featuring over 60 artists from 10 countries. Edited by Ute Meta Bauer, Karin G Oen, and Tan Boon Hui, the book includes brief profiles, images, and works by prominent artists, but has been criticized for its limited representation of certain countries and artists. Despite biases, the book aims to spark further exploration and knowledge of Southeast Asian contemporary art, with plans for a follow-up series.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Yukiharu Furuno (left) and Takanao Todo are showing their ceramics at the Japanese Creative Centre.
Visitors tour the exhibits during a VIP preview of the ART SG art fair in Singapore.
Dinh Q Le's installation features over 5,000 found photos from Vietnam, with the majority dating to the pre-Vietnam War era before 1975.

site_title: Japanese potters challenge wabi-sabi aesthetic at new exhibition
summary: Japanese ceramicists Yukiharu Furuno and Takanao Todo challenge the traditional wabi-sabi aesthetic in a new exhibition, "Post-Wabi," at the Japan Creative Centre. Furuno, 80, has shifted his focus from ashen glazes to vibrant blues, inspired by his late wife's love of the sky and ocean. In contrast, Todo, 39, incorporates natural phenomena and imperfections into his work, embracing the beauty of ordinary creatures and their symbiotic relationships with nature. The exhibition seeks to push beyond wabi-sabi's principles of simplicity and imperfection.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

Poklong Anading of the Philippines is one of the over 60 artists featured in the book SEA: Contemporary Art In Southeast Asia. His photograph titled Counter Acts seeks to subvert photography's claim of capturing an image by having his subjects turn the lights towards the viewer instead, obscuring their own faces.
Large Green-Glazed Pottery Horse from the Han Dynasty. Horses such as this are typically found in Han burial tombs and are meant to be rode upon in the afterlife.

site_title: Panasonic cuts full-year outlook as costly raw materials weigh
summary: Panasonic cut its full-year operating profit forecast to 280 billion yen (S$2.83 billion) due to a slowing global economy and high raw materials prices. The company's energy business, which includes making auto batteries for Tesla, faces challenges amid a tricky outlook for global growth. Panasonic aims to grow profits in automotive batteries by expanding sales of its 2170 model lithium-ion battery cells and commercializing the 4680 format battery. The company's operating profit for the third quarter fell short of estimates, and investors are seeking clarity on benefits from the US Inflation Reduction Act for EV battery cell production.

images.alt_text: Panasonic will transfer rice cookers production to the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou by June 2023, according to media reports.

site_title: TAR is worth watching – and hating
summary: Cate Blanchett's film "TAR" has sparked controversy with its portrayal of a sexual predator, with some viewers labeling it "regressive" and "racist towards Asians". The film, which has received six Oscar nominations, centers around Lydia Tar, a celebrated conductor who is accused of impropriety and eventually blacklisted. However, the film's ending has been criticized for depicting a South-east Asian city as a squalid cesspool willing to ignore sexual offenders, with some accusing it of xenophobia. The film's director, Todd Field, has been praised for tackling a hot-button issue, but the ending's miscalculation has left some viewers upset and disappointed.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Despite a rich stable of characters from Batman to Wonder Woman, the DC film and television studio has failed to match the success of Walt Disney’s Marvel hit factory.

Malaysian actress Michelle Yeoh poses with the award for Best Actress - Motion Picture - Musical/Comedy for "Everything Everywhere All at Once" in the press room during the 80th annual Golden Globe Awards at The Beverly Hilton hotel in Beverly Hills, California, on January 10, 2023.

site_title: Remaining two of Japan’s top three lenders also book strong Q3 performance
summary: Japan's top three lenders, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Mizuho Financial Group, and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, reported strong third-quarter profits despite recession fears in the US and uncertainties over the war in Ukraine. Mitsubishi UFJ's nine-month earnings reached 1.1 trillion yen, ahead of its full-year forecast, while Mizuho's third-quarter net profit more than doubled to 209.3 billion yen. The lenders maintained their annual profit outlooks, citing economic recovery in Japan and solid loan demand abroad.

images.alt_text: The fund, known as MUFG Innovation Partners Garuda No 1 Limited Investment Partnership, will focus on the Indonesian market.
Nomura’s wholesale division logged a pretax loss of 1.9 billion yen, its first loss since the April-June quarter of 2021.
A vocal advocate of aggressive monetary easing, Masazumi Wakatabe has consistently voted for maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy.

site_title: Latest 6-month T-bill offers 3.88% yield; March Singapore Savings Bond opens with 10-year average return of 2.9%
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill closed its auction with a cut-off yield of 3.88%, attracting 2.6 times subscriptions for the S$4.9 billion allotment. The March issuance of Singapore Savings Bonds opened with a 2.76% first-year interest rate and a 10-year average return of 2.9%. Despite declining interest in SSBs, DBS senior rates strategist Eugene Leow expects reasonable demand for T-bills due to attractive yields.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
While bond yields are up, investors should bear in mind that interest rates are rising because central banks worldwide are trying to tame inflation.
The February tranche of the SSBs, which are backed by the Singapore government, received S$477.1 million in applications for the S$700 million allotment.
The total value of applications in this 1-year T-bill auction was S$10.5 billion, up from the S$8.6 billion applied in the last 1-year T-bill auction.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng privatisation offer closing date extended to Feb 16
summary: The closing date for Chip Eng Seng's mandatory cash offer, initially set for Feb 2, has been extended to Feb 16, marking the third extension. As of Feb 1, the offeror has received 649.5 million shares, translating to about 82.7% of the company, with 694.3 million shares now owned by the offeror and its concert parties, representing about 88.41% of the company. The initial price of S$0.72 per share was raised to S$0.75.

images.alt_text: LTA said in a statement on Monday that the contract has been awarded to CES_SDC-Chip Eng Seng Contractors (1988) joint venture.
Celine Tang (pictured) and her husband Gordon Tang launched the offer under the vehicle Tang Dynasty Treasure.

The offer of S$0.75 per share represented a steep 43.9 per cent discount to CES’s revalued net asset value (RNAV) per share.
But the IFA, Xandar Capital, deemed the offer to be “fair and reasonable” – and recommended shareholders accept it.
Mapletree Logistics Trust is selling an asset it considers "outdated" for S$22 million.

site_title: Swiss engineering firm ABB says demand ‘normalising’ after 2022’s stock build-ups
summary: ABB, a Swiss engineering firm, expects demand for its products to "normalise" in 2023 after customers stockpiled items in 2022 to avoid supply-chain disruptions. The company posted fourth-quarter earnings of $1.13 billion, exceeding market forecasts. ABB's CEO, Bjorn Rosengren, noted that while inflation adds uncertainty, the company expects a strong start to the year and comparable revenue growth in the double-digit percentage range, with 5% growth for the full year.

images.alt_text: ABB subsidiaries also pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to violate the anti-bribery provisions of the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA).

site_title: DBS now accepts online applications for T-bills using CPF Ordinary Account funds
summary: DBS Bank is now allowing online applications for Singapore Treasury Bills (T-bills) using funds from Central Provident Fund (CPF) Ordinary Accounts (OA). To apply, investors must first open a CPF investment account with DBS, UOB, or OCBC and apply through their respective banks' digital platforms. The service is currently only available on DBS Internet banking, with applications closing two business days before each auction date. Other local banks, UOB and OCBC, are also planning to offer similar services soon, with OCBC aiming to launch its digital platforms by March 2023.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The last time yields were at the 4 per cent level was in 1989.
T-bills can be purchased by anyone above the age of 18, even non-Singapore residents. They can also be purchased by institutions.

The T-bills were around 2.6 times subscribed for the S$4.9 billion allotment in the latest auction. Meanwhile, the March issuance of the SSBs opened with a first year interest rate of 2.76 per cent, and a 10-year average return of 2.9 per cent.

site_title: Climate risks may impact financial market infrastructures: study
summary: A new study by the Depository Trust & Clearing Corporation (DTCC) warns that climate change poses risks to the stability of financial market infrastructures (FMIs), including physical risks from extreme weather events and transition risks from changes in policies and market preferences. FMIs may experience economic costs or financial losses due to business disruptions, loan default rates, and credit risk. The DTCC recommends applying existing regulatory frameworks and standards to mitigate these risks, and standardizing disclosure requirements to support FMIs in assessing their climate-related financial exposures.

images.alt_text: investors are asking ESG-related questions relating to businesses – referring to sustainability ratings and metrics when assessing an organisation’s suitability for inclusion in their investment portfolios.

site_title: Banks lead decline in Singapore shares on Thursday amid slowing rate hikes
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% on Thursday, led by declines in local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB, amid market expectations that the Federal Reserve will soon end interest-rate hikes. The US Fed concluded its latest meeting with a 25-basis-point rate hike, which boosted net-interest margins for local banks but kept them in the red. Real estate investment trusts (Reits) gained, while the Nikkei 225 Index rose 0.2% and the Hang Seng Index fell 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The banks have been beneficiaries of policy rate hikes by the Fed, with their bread and butter - net interest margin - rising in tandem with higher borrowing costs.
Gainers outnumber losers 86 to 33 in early trade on the Singapore Exchange on Thursday.

site_title: Infineon Q1 revenue comes in slightly below expectations
summary: Infineon, a leading microchip supplier, reported Q1 revenue of 3.95 billion euros, slightly below analyst expectations of 4 billion euros. The company's segment result margin rose to 28.0% from 25.5%, beating expectations. Despite a less favorable exchange rate, Infineon maintained its full-year revenue outlook of 15.5 billion euros. The company expects a segment result margin of 25% for the full year and Q2 revenue of 3.9 billion euros. Investments for the full year remain expected to be approximately 3 billion euros.

site_title: US targets global sanctions evasion network supporting Russia
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on 22 individuals and entities in multiple countries for allegedly supporting Russia's military-industrial complex and evading US sanctions. The sanctions, led by Igor Zimenkov and his son Jonatan, target a global network that limits Russia's access to revenue needed for the war in Ukraine. This action marks the latest round of US sanctions on Russia and aims to increase pressure on Moscow over its invasion. The US Treasury Department says the sanctions will restrict Russia's access to revenue, limiting its ability to fund the war.

images.alt_text: The sanctions are likely to see a great re-routing of global diesel flows – aided by Russia’s new crude buyers sending fuel back to Europe. In the short term, there is a risk of higher prices.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on May 23, 2014 Interros Investment Company President Vladimir Potanin takes part in the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum 2014 (SPIEF 2014) in St. Petersburg. - The US announced financial sanctions targeting one of Russia's wealthiest men, Vladimir Potanin, the Treasury Department and State Department said on December 15, 2022, adding to efforts that curb Moscow's ability to fund its war in Ukraine. (Photo by OLGA MALTSEVA / AFP)

site_title: Credit Suisse weighs splitting China team in First Boston revamp
summary: Credit Suisse is considering splitting its China investment banking team into two units: one retaining the domestic unit and the other shifting to Credit Suisse First Boston. The domestic unit would continue to operate under the Swiss lender, while Hong Kong staff focusing on offshore deals would be transferred to CS First Boston. This move aims to simplify the restart of a licence application for the revived First Boston brand and focus on wealth management. The restructuring follows a series of scandals and billions in losses.

images.alt_text: The Zurich-based lender is in the midst of working out how to carve out its investment bank into the rebranded Credit Suisse First Boston and which businesses will be housed there.

site_title: Deutsche Bank clinches third straight annual profit on Q4 2022 earnings surge
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a surge in fourth-quarter earnings, exceeding expectations and contributing to a third consecutive year of profit. The bank's net profit attributable to shareholders increased to 1.8 billion euros, beating analyst expectations, and marked a tenth consecutive quarter of profit. The full-year profit jumped to 5 billion euros, the largest annual profit since 2007, driven by a 1.4 billion euro tax benefit and higher interest rates. Despite a decline in investment banking revenue, the bank's corporate and retail banking divisions showed significant growth.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse has seen a slew of senior departures across Asia and Europe as it’s undertaking a sweeping overhaul of its business following years of scandals and management missteps.

site_title: Philippines grants US greater access to bases amid China concerns
summary: The Philippines has granted the US greater access to its military bases, expanding US presence to nine locations, amid growing concern over China's assertiveness in the South China Sea. The 2014 Enhanced Defence Cooperation Agreement (EDCA) now allows the US to access four more sites, bolstering its security options in the country and deterring moves by China against self-ruled Taiwan. US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin described the decision as a "big deal," reaffirming the alliance between the two countries.

images.alt_text: U.S. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin III meets Philippines President Ferdinand "Bongbong" Marcos Jr. at the Malacanang presidential palace in Manila, Philippines, February 2, 2023. Jam Sta Rosa/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: New World considers sale of majority of HK$11 billion Hong Kong office tower: sources
summary: New World Development is considering the sale of a majority stake in its HK$11 billion Hong Kong office tower, K11 Atelier King's Road, to investors. The sale is part of the developer's efforts to fund its rapid expansion and dispose of non-core assets. A guaranteed capitalisation rate of around 4% is being offered to attract investors, similar to the sale of a land plot last year. The sale would be a significant move for the fourth-largest developer in Hong Kong, allowing it to focus on its core businesses.

images.alt_text: A decline in prices combined with soaring interest rates are squeezing homeowners in what’s traditionally been one of the world’s most expensive housing markets.

site_title: Fresh takes on suiting for a return to the office
summary: The menswear industry is updating its approach to business wear, focusing on comfort and smart sensibility after nearly three years of working from home. Key trends include alternative jackets like Harringtons, bombers, and coach jackets, which were showcased at Paris Fashion Week and Milan Fashion Week. Designers are incorporating looser cuts, knit fabrics, and relaxed silhouettes to create a more comfortable yet professional look. Vests are also being considered as a stylish alternative to jackets, offering a cooler way to look professional. The focus is on fit, fabric choice, and styling to maintain a sharp, office-appropriate look.

images.alt_text: Louis Vuitton owner LVMH has experienced solid growth despite soaring inflation and slowing economies, making the French luxury group a darling among investors.
British startup Vollebak sells t-shirts woven from hemp and coloured with algae that can eventually be tossed on the household compost heap or buried in the garden, decomposing within weeks.

In recent quarters, Gucci has lagged behind rivals including Hermes and Louis Vuitton, with its performance in the key Chinese market becoming a source of concern for investors amid Covid-19 lockdowns.
The interior of SuitYourself's store at Far East Plaza. The space features a 3D scanner that can take instant, accurate measurements of clients' bodies.
New technologies present solutions for the fashion industry to meet its sustainability goals; others suggest changing consumption patterns instead.

site_title: Shell makes record US$40 billion annual profit
summary: Shell reported a record annual profit of US$40 billion in 2022, more than doubling from the previous year, due to a surge in energy prices following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The company's record fourth-quarter profit was US$9.8 billion, beating analyst forecasts. Shell's CEO, Wael Sawan, stated the company intends to remain disciplined while delivering shareholder returns. The company also announced a new US$4 billion share buyback program and a 15% dividend boost.

images.alt_text: Shell’s latest shipment used credits primarily from a project which prevents deforestation.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally with Wall Street on softer Fed tone
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday, following a softer tone from the Federal Reserve, which acknowledged progress in controlling inflation and may be nearing the end of its interest rate hikes. The decision to lift rates by a quarter-point came after data showed the US economy is slowing down. Tech firms led the surge on Wall Street, with the Nasdaq up 2% and the dollar weakening against major currencies. Analysts believe the Fed's dovish message suggests the terminal rate may not exceed 5%, providing relief for investors.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong dipped for a third straight day, having piled on more than 10 per cent in the past month.

site_title: India’s largest mortgage lender HDFC misses Q3 profit view on higher funding costs
summary: India's largest mortgage lender HDFC missed Q3 profit estimates, reporting a 13.2% rise in profit to 36.91 billion rupees, despite strong housing loan growth. The company attributed the miss to higher funding costs, which compressed net interest margins and net interest income. HDFC's interest income climbed 30.8% to 144.58 billion rupees. The lender is set to merge with HDFC Bank, India's largest private lender.

site_title: Sony raises outlook on strong PlayStation 5 momentum
summary: Sony raised its full-year profit outlook due to strong PlayStation 5 console sales, selling 7.1 million units in the holiday quarter and now forecasting 19 million units for the fiscal year. The company also hiked its operating profit forecast to 1.18 trillion yen, driven by favourable exchange rates and a growing PS5 ecosystem. Despite a global economic downturn, Sony expects to continue this momentum, with its chief financial officer citing the second half of the year as a potential turning point for the chip sector.

images.alt_text: Consumers globally have taken to VR less rapidly than initially hoped, held back in part by a lack of titles that can showcase the technology

site_title: Japan’s Takeda says 9-month profit skids 13%, but keeps annual guidance
summary: Takeda Pharmaceutical reported a 13% drop in nine-month operating earnings to 401.9 billion yen, but maintained its annual profit forecast at 530 billion yen. The company expects its dengue vaccine, QDENGA, to generate $700 million to $1.6 billion in sales over several years. Takeda also agreed to buy an experimental psoriasis drug for up to $6 billion, demonstrating its commitment to investing in its pipeline despite a decline in mainstay products. The company's net debt to core earnings ratio has improved to 2.5 times as of the end of the third quarter.

site_title: 👋 Making friends at work: how close is too close?
summary: A new work environment can be daunting, and forming close relationships with coworkers can be a challenge. Experts advise starting small and being cautious, as overly close relationships can blur professional boundaries. Red flags include constant gossip, sharing of personal information, and enabling bad behavior. Completely isolating or boxing oneself in can lead to self-sabotage, while maintaining personal boundaries and exemplifying supportive behavior can lead to healthy work relationships. Research shows that having a best friend at work correlates with optimal business outcomes, such as increased profitability and employee retention.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: Is Jeju overhyped? We went there, and no – it absolutely isn’t
summary: A travel writer visits Jeju Island in South Korea and finds it exceeds expectations. The island's natural beauty, including its UNESCO World Heritage Sites, is breathtaking. Visitors can explore volcanic landscapes, including Seongsan Ilchulbong, a crater formed 5,000 years ago, and Hallasan, South Korea's highest mountain. The island is also famous for its seafood, with fresh catches available at many restaurants. From abalone and sashimi to black pork and tangerine orchards, Jeju offers a unique culinary experience. The writer suggests driving around the island to take in its scenic views and exploring its many cafes and orchards. Overall, Jeju Island is a hidden gem that lives up to its reputation as a paradise.

images.alt_text: The beautiful surrounding nature reflected on the surface of Roku Kyoto's water basin.

site_title: FedEx to cut senior jobs as part of larger staff reduction
summary: FedEx plans to cut its senior officer and director ranks by over 10% as part of a broader cost-reduction effort, reducing staffing by 12,000 workers since June. The move, part of a plan to slash expenses by $3.7 billion this year, has raised hopes among investors, with shares rising 3.4%. The layoffs follow a profit forecast cut in September and a global business downturn, with FedEx's CEO citing the need for efficiency and agility.

site_title: Malaysia freezes opposition party’s accounts in graft probe
summary: Malaysian anti-graft authorities have frozen the bank accounts of the opposition party Bersatu, led by former Premier Muhyiddin Yassin, amid an investigation into RM300 million found in the party's accounts. The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) is investigating the party under the MACC Act and the Anti-money Laundering Act. Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim questioned the party leaders' credibility, stating that they must explain the source of the funds. The investigation is ongoing, with the MACC seeking to determine the legitimacy of the party's assets.

site_title: Citigroup’s wealth unit halts margin loans on Adani securities
summary: Citigroup's wealth unit has halted margin loans on Adani securities with immediate effect, following a similar move by Credit Suisse Group. The decision comes amid allegations of fraud by short seller Hindenburg Research and a dramatic price drop of Adani issued securities. The move is part of the banks' increased scrutiny of Adani's finances, with bonds of the Indian billionaire's flagship firm plunging to distressed levels in US trading. This decision may limit the impact on Citigroup's margin lending portfolio.

images.alt_text: Citigroup headquarters in New York, U.S., on Friday, Jan. 7, 2022. Citigroup Inc. was the first major Wall Street bank to impose a strict Covid-19 vaccine mandate: Get a shot or face termination. With its deadline fast approaching, the company is preparing for action. Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg
Wilmar International’s headquarters at Biopolis Road, one-north. DBS believes any share price weakness in Wilmar due to news related to Adani is likely to be more sentiment-driven.
The withdrawal of the Adani Enterprises share offering marks a stunning setback for Gautam Adani, the school dropout-turned-billionaire whose fortunes rose rapidly in recent years.

site_title: Share prices of Singapore banks dip following expectations of Fed rate hikes ending
summary: Singapore bank shares fell after the US Federal Reserve hinted at ending its rate hike cycle, with DBS down 2%, OCBC 0.8%, and UOB 0.3%. The move followed a 25-basis-point rate hike on Wednesday, which has benefited the banks' net interest margins. The local banking sector's decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and amid split Fed views, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Even after the Fed stops raising nominal interest rates, real rates are likely to go on increasing for some time.
In early Asian trade, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta markets all rose.
Digital assets are rebounding from steep losses last year, a period pockmarked by blowups like that of the FTX exchange.
Hong Kong’s monetary policy moves in lock-step with the United States as the city’s currency is pegged to the greenback in a tight range of 7.75-7.85 per dollar.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose less than 0.1 per cent to 34,092.96, while the broad-based S&P 500 advanced 1.1 per cent to 4,119.21 on Wednesday.
Gainers outnumber losers 86 to 33 in early trade on the Singapore Exchange on Thursday.

site_title: New career conversion programme to re-skill 280 PMETs for Singapore’s furniture industry
summary: Singapore has launched a career conversion programme to re-skill 280 mid-career professionals for jobs in the furniture industry by September 2024. The programme, managed by the Singapore Furniture Industries Council (SFIC) Institute, offers up to 70% salary support and six-month on-the-job training. The initiative aims to address manpower woes in the industry, which faced challenges during the pandemic due to foreign workers leaving. The programme is part of efforts to build up local manpower and is the latest in a series of career conversion programmes rolled out for the furniture industry since 2020.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The initiatives address one of SSIA’s top priorities of building a robust pipeline of talent in the electronic sector, says executive director of SSIA Ang Wee Seng.
Establishing a flagship store is a natural step forward for Castlery, given its increased recognition among Singapore consumers, said co-founder Declan Ee.

site_title: Rallying markets suffer from a doveish illusion
summary: The US Federal Reserve's recent interest rate hike may appear to signal a shift towards a more dovish stance, but real interest rates are likely to continue rising for some time. Despite nominal rates being cut, real rates have soared to 2%, the highest level since 2007, due to rising inflation expectations. This increase in real rates is expected to continue even after the Fed stops raising nominal rates, potentially leading to a recession in the future.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose less than 0.1 per cent to 34,092.96, while the broad-based S&P 500 advanced 1.1 per cent to 4,119.21 on Wednesday.
In early Asian trade, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta markets all rose.
Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell speaks at a news conference in Washington, Feb 1, 2023. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a point on Wednesday.

site_title: Assertions about six ex-Keppel O&M staff show ‘inadequate understanding’: Indranee
summary: Singapore Minister Indranee Rajah stated that assertions about six ex-Keppel O&M staff being issued stern warnings for corruption are based on an "inadequate understanding of facts". The warnings were issued instead of prosecution for bribes amounting to US$55 million, which were allegedly paid to Brazilian officials. Indranee emphasized the government's position against corruption and clarified that criminal charges would have been brought if there was sufficient evidence.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Sembmarine said its independent directors recommend that shareholders vote in favour of its merger with Keppel O&M.

site_title: South Korea’s inflation quickens, keeping rate-hike option alive
summary: South Korea's inflation accelerated to 5.2% in January, exceeding expectations and keeping the door open for further central bank policy tightening despite the weakening economy. The Bank of Korea (BOK) has maintained its inflation target of 5% and warned that upward pressure on international commodity prices could increase if China's economic reopening fuels demand. The central bank is set to meet again in three weeks, with speculation growing that it may pause rate hikes this time, but Governor Rhee Chang-yong has signaled that the tightening cycle will continue as long as inflation remains above 5%.

images.alt_text: South Korea's economy shrank by 0.4 per cent in the October-December quarter and is on the brink of falling into a recession.
New orders in South Korea shrank for the seventh straight month in January, although the rate of decline was a little slower than a month earlier, a business survey showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Adani debate gets rejected in Indian parliament, causing uproar
summary: The Indian parliament was adjourned due to pandemonium after opposition lawmakers demanded a debate on tycoon Gautam Adani's tussle with a US short-seller, citing public sector investments in "companies losing market value." The opposition, led by Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge, plans to ask for an inquiry by a parliamentary or judicial panel. The Adani Group's stock rout has intensified, with losses exceeding $100 billion, amid allegations of fraud. The opposition's move could become a political headache for Prime Minister Narendra Modi ahead of next year's elections.

images.alt_text: The group’s flagship firm – Adani Enterprises - plunged 10 per cent after opening higher on Thursday.

site_title: Quantum Healthcare scales back acquisition of New Silkroutes Group’s dental businesses
summary: Quantum Healthcare has scaled back its acquisition of New Silkroutes Group's dental businesses from six clinics to three, reducing the consideration to S$1.7 million. The decision, made after considering market conditions and the clinics' financial performances, will allow the group to expand its operations in north-western, southern, and eastern Singapore. The scaled-back acquisition is deemed in the best interests of the company, which plans to retain the working team and integrate the clinics with its existing Asia Dental Group subsidiary.

images.alt_text: Q & M's medical laboratory business weakened after the demand for Covid-19 testing in Singapore fell.

site_title: Volvo readies EV blitz in biggest product revamp under Geely
summary: Volvo, owned by Geely, aims to convert its entire lineup into fully electric vehicles by 2030. The company plans to launch at least six new battery electric vehicles through 2026, including a luxury electric van targeting Asian markets. Volvo's Australia unit will sell only EVs by 2026, marking a significant shift in the Swedish carmaker's product strategy.

images.alt_text: Lotus plans to start production of its first electric SUV by the end of this year.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH downgrades ComfortDelGro to ‘hold’ on compressed margins
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) downgraded ComfortDelGro to "hold" from "buy" with a lower target price of S$1.38 due to concerns over the transport operator's market leadership and potential earnings drops. The downgrade comes amid two bus contracts put up for tender and expected losses of 2-10% in earnings for 2023 and 2024, respectively. Analysts also predict a rise in taxi booking commission rates and extended taxi rental rebates to compress taxi margins.

images.alt_text: RHB lowers ComfortDelGro’s target price to S$1.65 from S$1.80 as a result of lowering earning estimates to 5-9 per cent for FY2022-FY2024.
As part of the tie-up, the companies have agreed to provide Gojek users access to ComfortDelGro taxis via the Gojek app to help with the driver shortage.
The investment in Shift4Good was made through ComfortDelGro’s US$100 million venture capital fund.
ComfortDelGro's venture arm has not made investments at a regular pace as its peers, and having a separate head and team running its US$100 million fund could help fulfil its potential.

site_title: Hedge funds that beat Asia turmoil are looking to China for 2023
summary: Asian hedge funds that beat the turmoil in 2022 are now looking to China for gains in 2023. Funds such as Dymon Asia Capital and Modular Asset Management, which scored significant gains last year, are optimistic about China's re-opening and its potential impact on currencies and equities. They anticipate benefits from travel, hospitality, and luxury stocks, as well as from relative value trades in currencies and equities. The funds also see opportunities in post-Covid reopening, particularly in Malaysia and Japan.

images.alt_text: In 2022, when fears of rising interest rates and geopolitical uncertainty weighed on markets, investment firms that focused on trading strategies and bet on macroeconomic trends reaped gains. Those with strategies linked to market moves stumbled.

site_title: Shell accused of greenwashing by climate group in US SEC claim
summary: A climate activist group, Global Witness, has accused Royal Dutch Shell of greenwashing by claiming its investments in renewable energy are misleading to investors. Shell denies the allegations, but the complaint filed with the US Securities and Exchange Commission's Climate and ESG Task Force seeks an investigation. This comes after a 2021 court ruling in the Netherlands ordered Shell to cut its carbon emissions more aggressively.

images.alt_text: Shell’s latest shipment used credits primarily from a project which prevents deforestation.
The review of Shell Energy, which supplies energy to around 1.4 million homes across Britain and broadband to around half a million customers, could affect its 2,000-strong UK workforce.
Shell also expects to pay about US$2 billion in additional 2022 taxes related to the European Union and British windfall taxes imposed on the energy sector.

site_title: Honda to start producing new hydrogen fuel cell system co-developed with GM
summary: Honda plans to start producing a new hydrogen fuel cell system co-developed with General Motors (GM) this year, aiming to expand its use in commercial vehicles, stationary power stations, and construction machinery. The company targets annual sales of 2,000 units in the mid-2020s and 60,000 units by 2030. The "next-generation" system promises to double durability and reduce costs by two-thirds, with plans to differentiate commercial trucks from battery-powered ones.

images.alt_text: The new division will consolidate the Japanese automaker’s electrification strategy and development of cars, motorcycles and power products such as generators.

site_title: Adani news unlikely to impact Wilmar materially, says DBS
summary: DBS Group Research believes Wilmar International is unlikely to see a material impact from negative headline news surrounding its Indian associate Adani Group, despite a recent short-seller report alleging Adani's stock manipulation and accounting fraud. DBS analysts note that Wilmar's earnings from its JV with Adani are non-material and that the company's shares have underperformed the Straits Times Index over the past two months, likely due to sentiment-driven factors. DBS continues to favor Wilmar for its steady earnings outlook and attractive valuation.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

The sprawling Adani Group has been rocked to its core in recent days after Hindenburg Research accused the conglomerate of widespread corporate malfeasance, including market manipulation and accounting fraud.
While Gautam Adaninet's net worth took a beating in the days after Hindenburg’s report emerged, he was still comfortably in the top 10 in the Bloomberg Billionaires Index as at late January.
Wilmar’s chief financial officer Charles Loo said sustainable financing remains part of its holistic approach to integrate sustainability principles into every aspect of the business operations.

site_title: Adani group’s market losses hit US$100 billion as stocks sink after botched share sale
summary: The Adani Group's flagship firm, Adani Enterprises, plunged 10% after shelving a $2.5 billion share sale amid a turbulent market, following a short-seller attack that has led to cumulative market capitalisation losses of $100 billion. The group's shares have fallen, and other companies, including Adani Ports, Adani Total Gas, and Adani Transmission, have also dropped in value. Adani's billionaire leader has lost his title as Asia's richest man, and Indian banks have been asked to disclose their exposure to the group's debt. The group has denied allegations of stock manipulation and improper use of offshore tax havens.

images.alt_text: With the rout in the group’s stocks triggered by short seller Hindenburg Research’s fraud allegations reaching US$92 billion on Wednesday (Feb 1), the risk is that more financial institutions will start to scrutinise their exposure to the indebted conglomerate.
The withdrawal of the Adani Enterprises share offering marks a stunning setback for Gautam Adani, the school dropout-turned-billionaire whose fortunes rose rapidly in recent years.

site_title: Gold scales late-April highs after dovish Fed
summary: Gold prices rose to their highest in over nine months after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 25 basis points and Chairman Jerome Powell's comments were seen as dovish. Spot gold reached $1,952.29 per ounce, with US gold futures also gaining 1.4%. The Fed's decision was seen as reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, benefiting gold.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates tend to be beneficial for bullion, decreasing the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: Australia to replace Queen Elizabeth’s image on A$5 banknote
summary: Australia's central bank announced plans to replace Queen Elizabeth II's image on its $5 banknote with a design honoring Indigenous culture. The decision follows consultation with the federal government, which supports the change. The Reserve Bank of Australia will consult with Indigenous groups in designing the new banknote, which will take several years to complete. The current note will continue to be issued until the new design is ready. This move comes as Australia considers altering its constitution to recognize Indigenous people and as the country continues to navigate its constitutional monarchy.

images.alt_text: The Aussie slipped 0.1 per cent to US$0.7050, having already lost 0.7 per cent overnight amid a broad-based bout of risk aversion.
Retail sales have been seasonally weak in December in recent times, suggesting further evidence of slowing demand is needed before the RBA pauses tightening.

site_title: Bitcoin jumps to highest since August in post-Fed crypto rally
summary: Bitcoin surged to its highest level since August, jumping 2.4% to $24,020, amid optimism over a potential easing of monetary policy following Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments on inflation. The move was part of a broader crypto rally, with Ether climbing 3% and a gauge of top 100 digital assets rising 37% this year. Investors interpreted Powell's comments as a sign that a less harsh monetary policy backdrop lies ahead, driving risk-on sentiment and fueling the cryptocurrency market.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin transaction fees as a percentage of the total block rewards from the blockchain rose above 2.5 per cent on Jan 31 and are climbing even higher on Wednesday.
The largest token is up over 40 per cent since the turn of the year, a first-month gain bettered only twice before when crypto was in its infancy.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang’s chief operating officer resigns
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates' chief operating officer, Charles Chow, has resigned to pursue other career opportunities, effective February 10. Chow, who joined the company in 2021, led the company's day-to-day operations and has over 20 years of experience in project management and property development. His departure comes after the company named a new CEO, Chng Kiong Huat, in September 2022. Chow plans to help his wife's construction business, but may reassess opportunities in the future. The company expressed appreciation for Chow's services and contributions during his tenure.

images.alt_text: Some 24 units of Pollen Collection have been released for sale so far, with four units sold, said developer Bukit Sembawang Estates.
The Bukit Timah Link land parcel is on a site area of 4,611.1 sq m and comes with a maximum GFA of 13,834 sq m.
Liv @ MB is a Bukit Sembawang Estates residential project at Mountbatten.

site_title: Singapore property market braces for surging Chinese demand, immigration interest
summary: Singapore's property market is bracing for a surge in demand from Chinese buyers as the country reopens to the world. Chinese buyers made up 6.9% of foreign purchases of private apartments in 2022, with a 10-15% increase in inquiries since Beijing's border reopening. While demand is expected to rise, it is unlikely to fuel price increases, as the number of Chinese buyers is still relatively small. Migration interest is also on the rise, with wealthy Chinese considering Singapore as a top destination, driven by its stable environment and pro-business policies.

images.alt_text: Knight Frank estimates that total listings, including repeated listings, will surge by 40 to 50 per cent, chalking up some 600 listings in 2023.
Major transactions in Q4 include the S$1,988.9 million sale of mega suburban mall Jurong Point by Hong Kong's Link Reit.

site_title: RGE closes US$550 million sustainability-linked derivative with MUFG
summary: Royal Golden Eagle (RGE) has closed a US$550 million sustainability-linked derivative (SLD) with MUFG Bank, a first for both the company and the financial institution. The SLD will allow RGE's member company Apical to partially hedge the interest rate risk of US$787 million of sustainability-linked loans secured in November last year. RGE must meet its pre-defined sustainability key performance indicators (KPIs) to avoid higher interest rates on both the SLD and its SLLs.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

SGX RegCo is also proposing a hard nine-year limit on the tenure of independent directors and the mandatory disclosure of the actual amount and breakdown of the remuneration of directors and chief executive officer on a named basis.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts mixed on CICT’s outlook despite higher DPU
summary: Analysts have mixed views on Capitaland Integrated Commercial Trust's (CICT) outlook, despite a 2.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.0536 in H2 FY2022. Brokers expect CICT's positive momentum to sustain in the first half of 2023 but slow down in the second half due to higher interest and inflationary pressures. Analysts have downgraded their calls, with RHB Research changing its rating to "neutral" and deeming valuations fair, while others consider the trust's 5% dividend yield attractive.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of the revamped CQ @ Clarke Quay.

site_title: Bankrupt FTX extends bid deadlines for Japan, Europe Units
summary: Bankrupt FTX has extended bid deadlines for its Japan and Europe units, with a new preliminary bid deadline of March 8 and an auction date of April 26. The move aims to raise funds to pay creditors. Several FTX units, including LedgerX and European digital assets, were put on the auction block in December, attracting interest from over 100 parties. Administrators are seeking to sell the businesses to recover debts.

images.alt_text: Bankman-Fried, 30, has been free on US$250 million bond and required to live with his parents since pleading not guilty to looting billions of dollars from the now-bankrupt FTX.

site_title: Barclays fixed-income traders may be getting a 15% bonus increase
summary: Barclays is considering a 15% bonus increase for its fixed-income traders, who are expected to report their best year ever with record revenue. This comes after the bank's fixed-income trading division is anticipated to surge 49% to $7.07 billion in 2022. Meanwhile, equity trading compensation may drop by 10%, and some lowest performers may receive no bonus at all. The proposal is still under discussion and could change.

images.alt_text: Barclays also says it will increase the amount of its own capital that it invests in climate start-ups through its Sustainable Impact Capital initiative to £500 million by 2027.

site_title: No change to ultra-easy policy commitment: BOJ deputy governor
summary: Bank of Japan deputy governor Masazumi Wakatabe stated that the central bank's ultra-loose monetary policy commitment remains unchanged. He emphasized the need to monitor key factors such as annual wage negotiations and inflation outlook to sustainably achieve the 2% inflation target. Wakatabe's comments come as companies are raising prices and becoming more willing to lift wages, but uncertainty remains about whether these changes will be sustained. His five-year term as deputy governor is set to end in March.

site_title: Only the US Congress can stop Ukraine from winning
summary: The US Congress's Republican opposition to raising the debt ceiling may undermine efforts to support Ukraine in its war against Russia. The West has committed to sending advanced battle tanks and limiting Russian fossil-fuel revenues, which are essential for European and global security. However, a Republican-controlled House of Representatives threatens to block these efforts, potentially allowing Russia to maintain its grip on power and expand its borders. The US and its allies must find a way to overcome this obstacle to support Ukraine and prevent a Russian victory.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz speaks next to a Leopard 2 battle tank of the German armed forces Bundeswehr as he visits troops on a training exercise at the military ground in Ostenholz, northern Germany, on Oct 17, 2022.
At a speech in Virginia on Jan 26, Biden criticised Republicans for opposing a move to raise the US debt ceiling.

site_title: Asia faces shortage of ships to install offshore mega wind farms
summary: Asia is facing a shortage of ships to install offshore mega wind farms, with only about 10 turbine installing ships and a few dozen commissioning service operation vessels (CSOVs) operating worldwide. The shortage is expected to worsen as demand for wind turbines grows, with a projected gap of 15 turbine installers and over 145 CSOVs by 2030. This shortage could set back countries' efforts to diversify away from fossil fuels and hinder Asia's goal to top Europe as the region with the most new offshore wind installations by 2026.

images.alt_text: The company already generates more renewable energy than it consumes across its global operations.
The issues at Gamesa “more than offset” improvements at Siemens Energy’s gas service, grid technology and industry transformation businesses, the German company said in a filing.

site_title: Irish commercial real estate deals plummet as buyers bide time
summary: Irish commercial real estate investment plummeted in the fourth quarter of 2022, with office deals declining 83% to 128 million euros, down from 756 million euros in the same period in 2021. Investment in warehouses and industrial properties also significantly decreased. This marks a sharp turnaround from 2022, which was a near-record year for investment in Irish commercial real estate, largely due to uncertainty over rising interest rates and subsequent asset pricing.

images.alt_text: Real estate markets across Europe are braced for significant declines in valuations as rising interest rates coupled with persistent inflationary pressures and broader economic uncertainty hit investment volumes and asset valuations.

site_title: Seeing is believing? Global scramble to tackle deepfakes
summary: The global community is scrambling to tackle deepfakes, a growing threat to online trust and truth. Artificial Intelligence (AI) has enabled the creation of realistic images, videos, and audio recordings that can deceive viewers, eroding social trust and spreading misinformation. China has adopted new rules to regulate deepfakes, while the US and EU are discussing legislation to address the issue. Experts warn that detection tools are outpaced by creators, and the technology is evolving rapidly, making it difficult to keep up. The misuse of deepfakes poses significant risks, including identity theft, financial fraud, and reputational damage, with some predicting an "information apocalypse" where fact and fiction become indistinguishable.

images.alt_text: A AFP journalist views a video on January 25, 2019, manipulated with artificial intelligence to potentially deceive viewers, or "deepfake" at his newsdesk in Washington, DC. - "Deepfake" videos that manipulate reality are becoming more sophisticated and realistic as a result of advances in artificial intelligence, creating a potential for new kinds of misinformation with devastating consequences. (Photo by Alexandra ROBINSON / AFP) / TO GO WITH AFP STORY by Rob LEVER "Misinformation woes may multiply with ‘deepfake’ videos"

site_title: Samsung aims to outrun smartphone slump, make headway in China
summary: Samsung aims to drive double-digit growth in 2023 smartphone sales despite a global market contraction, focusing on premium devices and expanding in China. The company unveiled the S23 with improved cameras and battery life, maintaining prices despite rising material costs. Samsung expects to outpace the industry, with a 21.6% market share in 2022, and is working on a new strategy centered around premium smartphones, including a foldable model for the Chinese market. The company's goal is to achieve double-digit growth and sustain its market share despite industry challenges.

images.alt_text: China is the world’s biggest smartphone market and is unlikely to repeat the double-digit falls in shipments and sales it saw in 2022.

site_title: Pinterest cuts about 150 jobs, joining flurry of tech layoffs
summary: Pinterest is laying off about 150 employees, less than 5% of its total workforce, as part of organizational changes to deliver against its long-term strategy. The job cuts, announced on Wednesday, affected teams across the San Francisco-based company. Pinterest confirmed the move, stating that impacted employees will receive separation packages, benefits, and other services. The move joins a flurry of tech layoffs by other companies, including Amazon, Microsoft, Meta Platforms, and Google parent Alphabet, amid a turbulent industry expansion.

images.alt_text: PayPal saw headcount swell when the virus forced governments around the world to issue lockdown orders, spurring consumers to do more shopping online.
Alphabet now has reported three straight quarters of disappointing earnings per share.
Pinterest, which helps users find and share image-based lifestyle ideas, is operating under its new chief executive officer, Bill Ready.
The Snapchat parent will report its fourth-quarter results on Tuesday (Jan 31), and the results will serve as the season’s first major indication of the state of online advertising
Meta cut 11,000 jobs, or 13 per cent of the workforce, in November in its first-ever major layoff.

site_title: Republican US lawmaker meets with TikTok, but unpersuaded
summary: US Representative Mike Gallagher, the Republican chair of a US House of Representatives select committee on China, met with TikTok officials, but remained unpersuaded by the app's data security plans. Despite the meeting, Gallagher plans to introduce legislation to ban TikTok in the US, alongside Rep. Raja Krishnamoorthi. TikTok has been working with the US government to address concerns over user data, including hiring a US Data Security division and partnering with Oracle Corp to store user data. The company's CEO, Shou Zi Chew, will testify before Congress in March.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: TikTok app logo is seen in this illustration taken, August 22, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
TikTok said “calls for total bans of TikTok take a piecemeal approach to national security and a piecemeal approach to broad industry issues like data security, privacy, and online harms”.
Snap’s loss for the entire year nearly tripled to US$1.43 billion when compared to 2021, an earnings release showed.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday, with STI up 0.1%; but banks take a hit
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,380.62, driven by gains in media company The Place Holdings and shipbuilding firm Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. However, local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB traded mixed, with DBS down 0.5% and OCBC up 0.4%. The move followed a positive overnight session in US stocks, where the Dow Jones rose less than 0.1% and the S&P 500 advanced 1.1%.

images.alt_text: Blythe Valley Park, FLCT's business park located in Birmingham in the UK. The trust has recorded over 239,500 square metres of leasing across its portfolio for the first quarter.

site_title: IMF sees Australia ‘soft landing,’ cuts economic growth forecast
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised its economic forecast for Australia, predicting a "soft landing" for the country despite a slowdown in economic growth. The IMF expects Australia's economy to expand 1.6% in 2023, down from a previous forecast of 1.9%, and inflation to remain above the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) 2-3% target until 2024.
