The IMF advises the government and RBA to continue tightening fiscal and monetary policies to mitigate inflation and address economic concerns.

images.alt_text: Retail sales have been seasonally weak in December in recent times, suggesting further evidence of slowing demand is needed before the RBA pauses tightening.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FLCT, Oxley, Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit, Quantum Healthcare
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) reported a strong first quarter, recording over 239,500 square meters of leasing across its portfolio, with overall occupancy at 95.9%. In contrast, Oxley, a property developer, saw a decline in net profit for its first half, falling to S$277,000 from S$23.5 million. Shares of Oxley closed flat.

site_title: US opens embassy in Solomon Islands
summary: The United States officially re-opened its embassy in the Solomon Islands, a move aimed at boosting relations in the Pacific region as a counter to China. The embassy was re-established after a 30-year hiatus, with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken stating that it is a "renewal of our commitment to the people of Solomon Islands and our partnerships in the Indo-Pacific region." The move is seen as a strategic effort to strengthen ties with the Pacific nation and counter China's growing influence in the region.

images.alt_text: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken speaks during a working lunch at the U.S.-Pacific Island Country Summit at the State Department in Washington, DC, US, Sept 28, 2022.
Joe  Biden vowed to make a priority of strengthening the US partnership with their countries and to help them address what he called the “existential threat” posed by the climate crisis.
Australia's Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the agreement is proof that the country remains the “security partner of choice” for Vanuatu.

site_title: US job openings unexpectedly increased in December
summary: US job openings unexpectedly rose to 11 million in December, exceeding forecasts of 10.25 million. This increase suggests labor demand remains strong despite rising interest rates and recession fears. The Labor Department also reported wages and salaries grew at their slowest pace in a year. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise its policy rate by 25 basis points, maintaining its tightening path.

site_title: Hong Kong central bank raises interest rate after Fed hike
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) raised its base rate by 25 basis points to 5.0% on February 2, 2023, in lock-step with the US Federal Reserve's 25 basis point rate hike. This move aims to combat inflation and maintain the city's currency peg to the US dollar within a tight range of 7.75-7.85 per dollar. The US Federal Reserve also signaled a couple more rate hikes, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Meta sales beat expectations as Facebook grows; shares soar
summary: Meta reported better-than-expected sales for the fourth quarter, driven by strong demand for advertising and a growth in Facebook's user base to over 2 billion daily users. Revenue reached $32.2 billion, beating estimates, and shares surged 18% in extended trading. CEO Mark Zuckerberg cited progress in artificial intelligence investments and a focus on becoming a "stronger and more nimble organisation" in the "Year of Efficiency." Meta also boosted its stock-buyback authorization and reduced projected expenses for the year.

images.alt_text: Meta announced it would, in the coming weeks, "end the suspension" of Donald Trump's Facebook and Instagram accounts, two years after the former US president was banned following the assault on Capitol Hill.

site_title: Singapore’s corporate tax takings in first 9 months of FY2022 exceed full-year estimate
summary: Singapore's corporate income tax receipts exceeded its full-year estimate, reaching S$18.9 billion in the first nine months of FY2022, surpassing the full-year estimate of S$18.2 billion. Personal income tax and goods and services tax receipts also surpassed 80% of FY2022 budget projections. Overall operating revenue is ahead of pace, with the government's overall operating revenue crossing the 80% mark. This indicates a strong start to the fiscal year for Singapore's economy.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
A general view shows the city skyline in Singapore on December 1, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
MPs asked whether the government would consider deferring the planned Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike, following an unexpected 22.4 per cent surge in Singapore's tax revenue in FY2021.
Corporate income tax accounted for the largest share of taxes collected, at 30 per cent or S$18.2 billion, followed by individual income tax at 23 per cent or S$14.2 billion.

site_title: Europe: Shares muted on caution ahead of Federal Reserve rate decision
summary: European shares were muted on Wednesday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 flat at close. Investors awaited clues on monetary tightening plans and Chair Jerome Powell's news conference. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points to 4.50-4.75%, followed by European Central Bank and Bank of England rate hikes. Despite a strong January gain, concerns about inflation and economic growth persist, with euro zone manufacturing activity easing and inflation easing for a third straight month.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose less than 0.1 per cent to 34,092.96, while the broad-based S&P 500 advanced 1.1 per cent to 4,119.21 on Wednesday.

site_title: Adani abandons US$2.5 billion share sale in big setback to Indian tycoon
summary: Gautam Adani's Adani Enterprises has withdrawn its $2.5 billion share sale, marking a significant setback for the Indian tycoon. The decision comes after a US short-seller's criticisms sparked a market rout, wiping billions off Adani's stock values. Adani cited "extraordinary circumstances" and a desire to avoid "morally incorrect" actions, leading to the cancellation of the share sale. This move is a blow to Adani's fortunes, which rose rapidly in recent years.

images.alt_text: Wednesday’s stock losses saw Adani slip to 15th on Forbes rich list with an estimated net worth of US$76.8 billion

With the rout in the group’s stocks triggered by short seller Hindenburg Research’s fraud allegations reaching US$92 billion on Wednesday (Feb 1), the risk is that more financial institutions will start to scrutinise their exposure to the indebted conglomerate.

site_title: Smallest US firms are shedding workers fast as economy cools
summary: The US's smallest businesses, with fewer than 20 employees, are shedding jobs for the sixth consecutive month, according to data from the ADP Research Institute. Despite a surge in business formation since the COVID-19 pandemic, these firms are struggling to meet financial commitments due to waning consumer demand. This trend contrasts with overall small business payrolls, which have returned to pre-pandemic levels, and highlights the vulnerability of these firms to economic downturns.

site_title: Oil dives US$3 after US EIA reports big builds in US crude, fuel stocks
summary: Oil prices fell on Wednesday after the US Energy Information Administration reported a surge in US crude and fuel inventories, with crude oil rising 4.1 million barrels to 452.7 million barrels. Brent crude futures dropped 3.1% to $82.84 a barrel and WTI crude fell 3.1% to $76.41 a barrel. The market reacted to the report indicating weak demand for crude oil and fuels. OPEC+ maintained its output policy unchanged, and the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The more active second-month Brent contract settled at US$85.46 a barrel, up 96 cents or 1 per cent, while the US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at US$78.87 a barrel, up 97 cents or 1.3 per cent.
OPEC+ have tried to balance markets through changes in supply this year, which since October involved cuts

site_title: Coinbase wins dismissal of lawsuit over unregistered securities
summary: Coinbase has won dismissal of a class-action lawsuit alleging the cryptocurrency exchange facilitated the sale of unregistered securities on its platform. A US district judge in New York granted the dismissal, assuming the digital tokens were securities for the purposes of the case. The lawsuit, filed in 2021, sought damages from 79 digital assets sold on the platform, which consumers claimed were illegal contracts due to Coinbase's unregistered status with the US Securities and Exchange Commission. The judge noted that determining the digital tokens' status would have been a central battleground if the suit had proceeded.

site_title: Ikea buys into planned Australian wind farm in renewables push
summary: Ingka Group, the investment arm of Ikea, has acquired a 15% stake in the TagEnergy Golden Plains Wind Farm in Victoria, Australia, as part of its push into renewable energy. The $1.89 billion, 756-megawatt wind project is the company's first significant move into utility-scale renewable energy in Australia. Ingka Group aims to generate 6.5 billion euros in green energy investments by 2030, and the wind farm is expected to produce over 2,000-gigawatt hours of electricity per year.

site_title: Airbus and Qatar Airways resolve A350 dispute
summary: Qatar Airways and Airbus have resolved their dispute over 29 A350 jets, ending a US$2.5 billion battle over peeling paint that forced the grounding of the aircraft. The two sides reached an amicable settlement, with a repair project underway and the jets expected to return to service soon. The agreement, which remains confidential, allows Qatar Airways to continue its expansion plans and prevents Airbus from alienating a key customer. Experts say the settlement was beneficial for both parties, with Qatar Airways avoiding a prolonged court case and Airbus avoiding a loss of a major client.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Boeing logo is seen on the side of a Boeing 737 MAX at the Farnborough International Airshow, in Farnborough, Britain, July 20, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Cziborra/File Photo
Surface damage seen on an Qatar Airways' Airbus A350 plane parked in Doha, Qatar, June 20, 2022.

site_title: US Fed delivers small 25 bps rate hike, sees ‘ongoing increases’ as inflation fight not over
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, marking the first rate hike since March 2020. The Fed acknowledged that inflation has eased somewhat but remains elevated, and pledged to continue increasing borrowing costs to return inflation to its 2% target. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell emphasized that recent progress on inflation is insufficient to signal an end to rate hikes, and that the central bank could be only a couple of more rate hikes away from a restrictive stance.

images.alt_text: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, speaks at a news conference in Washington on Wednesday, Feb. 1, 2023. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter of a point, a less aggressive move than before, bit said that ÒongoingÓ rate increases are warranted.  (Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times)

site_title: South-east Asia could lose some appeal as political risks resurface
summary: South-east Asia's appeal to investors may wane due to resurfacing political risks. Thailand's general election by May could lead to a Thaksin Shinawatra-backed government, while Indonesia's 2024 elections will introduce volatility. In contrast, India's political stability and policy continuity offer opportunities for global manufacturers, with a growing electronics sector and investments from companies like Foxconn. India's presidency of the G20 and bilateral trade agreement negotiations may further highlight investment opportunities in the country.

images.alt_text: India aims to achieve a fiscal deficit of 4.5 per cent of GDP by 2025/26. The current year’s fiscal deficit target is pegged at 6.4 per cent.

Indonesian President Joko Widodo calls on his supporters to pick a leader who understands the people’s plight. “This is a big country, don’t get a leader who just sits pretty in the presidential palace. Find, I remind you, find a leader who wants and loves to go down among the people.”
Joko Widodo, Indonesia's president, is expected to announce a cabinet reshuffle soon.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim will be visiting Singapore by end-January, this will be his first visit to the Republic since he took office in November last year.
Thailand’s economic recovery has lagged that of other South-east Asian nations, with the crucial tourism sector just starting to pick up last year with 11.15 million foreign arrivals.

site_title: Vaccine-makers kept US$1.4 billion in prepayments for cancelled Covid shots for  world’s poor
summary: Global vaccine maker Johnson & Johnson is refusing to refund US$1.4 billion in advance payments for Covid-19 shots that were cancelled, leaving the international immunization organization Gavi facing financial damage. Gavi had initially paid US$1.4 billion for the doses, but the shots were never delivered due to declining demand. The organization has since settled with other manufacturers, but its dispute with Johnson & Johnson is ongoing, with the company demanding additional payment for the vaccines. This is part of a broader issue, with pharmaceutical companies holding onto US$13 billion in revenue from cancelled vaccines.

images.alt_text: A medical worker prepares a dose of the Pfizer-Bivalent Covid-19 vaccine at a vaccination centre in France. The International Federation of the Red Cross warned that the world is "dangerously unprepared" for the next health crisis.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end solidly higher as Federal Reserve enacts smaller rate hike
summary: The US stock market closed higher on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising 1.1% and 2.0% respectively, after the Federal Reserve enacted a smaller interest rate hike. The rate hike was a quarter-point increase to 4.50-4.75%, and Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaled that more hikes may be needed to combat inflation. Despite expectations of a hawkish tone, Powell's press conference was seen as a positive for markets, with analysts noting that he avoided criticizing recent market movements.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 27, 2023. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: ECB to raise rates again and face questions about future path
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to raise its deposit rate by another half percentage point to 2.5% on Thursday, in line with its previous announcement in December. The move is aimed at combating high inflation in the euro zone, which has been driven by factors such as the aftermath of the Covid-19 pandemic and an energy crisis following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. However, ECB President Christine Lagarde is likely to face questions about the pace of future hikes, with some data suggesting a bleaker outlook for the euro zone.

images.alt_text: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay

site_title: TheSmartLocal’s regional push gets leg-up with acquisition of Malaysian tech firm
summary: TheSmartLocal, a Singapore-based media company, has acquired Malaysian software-as-a-service company StackIdeas as part of its broader tech ambitions. The acquisition aims to develop in-house data analytics solutions to help fine-tune advertising campaigns. The company's CEO, Bryan Choo, expects the move to meet increasing industry demand for data insights and drive growth. With revenue doubling in the last five years, TSL remains profitable and expects growth to match its previous trajectory, with plans to expand its physical footprint in Singapore and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
From left: Acclaim chief executive Tony Lim; Acclaim-Heartware Endowment Fund 2021 recipients Dewi Murni binte Musa and Crystal Khoo Jinying; and Acclaim chairman Anthony Lim.

ITCAN chief executive officer Amit Sujan (centre, in blue suit) and IT managing director Sippy Sujan (centre, in red dress) attending a company event with employees. The Sujans see company culture as key to attracting and retaining talent.

site_title: Bitcoin NFTs push transaction fees on the blockchain to highest in over a year
summary: Bitcoin transaction fees surged to their highest in over a year due to the recent rise of Ordinal NFTs, a protocol that allows creators to mint digital assets directly on the Bitcoin network. The fees, which rose above 2.5% on January 31, are now climbing even higher. This is attributed to the large amount of data required for the NFTs, leading to higher costs per transaction, which can range from tens of dollars. The Ordinal NFT protocol is contributing to the increase in transaction fees, according to experts.

images.alt_text: The fund, which tracked blockchain-related companies and an NFT index, will start liquidating its portfolio on or about Feb 16.
Bitcoin miners earn a fixed supply of token rewards released from the blockchain and fees for processing transactions.

site_title: Why EU is hampered in global green race
summary: The European Union (EU) faces challenges in the global green race, with the US's Inflation Protection Act (IRA) making it a more attractive investment environment for green industries. The EU accuses China of unfair subsidies, while the IRA provides massive subsidies for US green industries. The EU's industrial policy is fragmented, with key member states like France and Germany dominating state aid. The bloc's energy crisis and high energy costs may lead to a shift in production to countries with cheaper energy. The EU is planning to propose new legislation to secure critical raw materials and build a level playing field with the US and China.

images.alt_text: Last year, Washington passed the landmark Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) that contains around US$370 billion in subsidies for green energy, as well as tax cuts for US-made electric cars and batteries, to speed up the transition to a low-carbon economy.
Sources say that the US is likely to want to focus only on extraction and processing critical minerals used in the vehicles, while the EU wants any arrangement to also include recycled materials.

site_title: US construction spending unexpectedly fall in December
summary: US construction spending unexpectedly fell 0.4% in December, contrary to economists' expectations of no change. Residential construction investment declined 0.3%, with single-family housing projects experiencing a 2.3% drop due to higher mortgage rates. This decrease follows a 7.7% year-on-year increase in November and a 10.2% increase in 2022.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve’s fastest interest rate-hiking cycle since the 1980s has driven housing into recession.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on April 08, 2022 Cars are seen on the assembly line during a tour of the Tesla Giga Texas manufacturing facility ahead of the "Cyber Rodeo" grand opening party on April 7, 2022 in Austin, Texas. - American factory growth sped up in May after slowing in the prior two months, even as employment contracted and firms continue to face supply challenges, according to a business survey released June 1, 2022. (Photo by SUZANNE CORDEIRO / AFP)
Companies added 106,000 jobs last month, sharply down from 253,000 in December and below analyst expectations.

site_title: Judge denies US bid to block Meta virtual reality deal: reports
summary: A US judge denied the Federal Trade Commission's request to block Meta's acquisition of virtual reality firm Within Unlimited, citing "decades of legal precedent" that will encourage innovation and investment. The deal, valued at an undisclosed amount, aims to help Meta lead the metaverse market. The judge's decision puts the deal on hold for a week to allow regulators time to appeal. Meta expressed confidence in the acquisition's benefits for VR users and developers, calling the FTC's case based on ideology and speculation, not evidence.

images.alt_text: Meta Platforms, the parent company of the Facebook group, is facing a mass action brought on behalf of around 45 million Facebook users in Britain.
Digital artist Mason Rothschild’s creation of “MetaBirkin” nonfungible tokens sparked a trademark battle with Hermès International.
Meta cut 11,000 jobs, or 13 per cent of the workforce, in November in its first-ever major layoff.

site_title: Morgan Stanley PE unit acquires environmental services firm Apex Companies
summary: Morgan Stanley Capital Partners acquired environmental services firm Apex Companies, with Sentinel Capital Partners retaining a minority stake. Apex offers water infrastructure and ESG consulting services, amid investor pressure to cut financing for fossil-fuel sectors. This deal follows similar investments by Morgan Stanley, including Alliance Technical Group, and reflects growing focus on the ESG segment.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower ahead of Fed decision
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on February 1, 2023, ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Dow Jones fell 46.44 points, or 0.14%, to 34,039.60, while the S&P 500 dropped 6.53 points, or 0.16%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 11.41 points, or 0.10%. Investors cautiously awaited the Fed's decision, which may impact market sentiment and interest rates.

site_title: Crypto firm Luxor starts marketplace for Bitcoin mining machines
summary: Luxor Technologies has launched a trading platform for Bitcoin mining machines, dubbed "request-for-quote" marketplace. The platform aims to improve transparency and liquidity in the secondary market, where the value of mining machines has plummeted by up to 80% from their peak in 2021. This move comes amid a surge in equipment sales by troubled miners and crypto lenders facing loan defaults. The platform allows users to create requests and negotiate prices directly, providing a unified marketplace for buyers and sellers.

site_title: US private hiring slows more than expected in January
summary: US private hiring slowed more than expected in January, adding 106,000 jobs, down from 253,000 in December and below analyst expectations. The slowdown is a sign of cooling economic activity as efforts to rein in inflation continue. ADP chief economist Nela Richardson noted that hiring was stronger during other weeks of the month, but weather disruptions affected numbers. The data comes as the US economy faces challenges, with the UK economy shrinking for the second month in a row.

images.alt_text: Wages and salaries for civilian workers rose 1 per cent in the final three months of 2022

site_title: FLCT posts over 239,500 sq m of leasing in Q1; overall occupancy rate at 95.9%
summary: FRASERS Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) recorded over 239,500 sq m of leasing in Q1 FY 2023, with overall occupancy at 95.9%. The Reit maintained 100% occupancy for its logistics and industrial portfolio, while its commercial portfolio had an 89.8% occupancy rate. FLCT has sufficient internal funds to refinance its debt maturing in FY2023, and discussions with banks on refinancing options for FY2024 borrowings are underway. Despite headwinds, FLCT's manager sees growth in e-commerce as a potential bright spot.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Blythe Valley Park, a business park located in Birmingham in the UK
FRASERS Logistics and Commercial Trust (FLCT)’s distribution per unit (DPU) rose by 1.3 per cent to S$0.0385 for its first half ended March 31, 2022, from S$0.038 a year ago.

site_title: US manufacturing sector sinks further in January
summary: The US manufacturing sector contracted further in January, marking the third straight monthly decline, with the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) index dropping to 47.4, the lowest level since May 2020. Higher interest rates stifled demand for goods, while a softening in global demand and appreciation of the dollar against trade partners' currencies also contributed to the decline. Despite this, factories did not lay off workers in large numbers, with the ISM survey's measure of factory employment dipping to 50.6.

images.alt_text: The S&P Global survey is the latest indicator to show the US economy is cooling off but whether it falls into recession remains an unsettled issue.

site_title: Indonesia considers slashing VAT on electric car sales to 1%
summary: Indonesia is considering reducing the value-added tax (VAT) on electric car sales from 11% to 1% to drive up demand and attract investment. The goal is to reach 35,000 electric cars in use by 2024. A cash incentive of 7 million rupiah (S$613.6) will be given for every electric motorcycle sold, with a local content rule requiring vehicles to be at least 40% locally-made. The regulation on incentives for electric vehicles is expected to be issued next week.

site_title: Opec+ sticks to oil output policy after brief meeting
summary: Opec+ has reaffirmed its commitment to the current oil output policy, sticking to production cuts agreed last year until the end of 2023. The Joint Ministerial Monitoring Committee (JMMC) reviewed production figures and made no changes, despite hopes for higher Chinese demand and uncertain Russian supply. Oil prices were little changed, remaining around $85 a barrel, as investors await the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision later in the day.

images.alt_text: OPEC+ have tried to balance markets through changes in supply this year, which since October involved cuts

The more active second-month Brent contract settled at US$85.46 a barrel, up 96 cents or 1 per cent, while the US West Texas Intermediate crude futures settled at US$78.87 a barrel, up 97 cents or 1.3 per cent.

site_title: Japan trading house says workers can be YouTubers to top up US$100,000 salaries
summary: Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui trading house has lifted its ban on side jobs, allowing employees to earn money elsewhere, including as YouTubers or artists. This move aims to retain younger workers demanding flexible work rules amid a population decline. Employees can now pursue side careers and earn an additional US$100,000, in addition to their base salary of around US$114,000. This decision reflects a broader trend among Japanese companies to adopt more flexible working conditions to attract younger workers.

site_title: US airlines cancel over 1,800 flights as ice storm hits multiple states
summary: A severe ice storm hit multiple US states, causing over 1,800 US airline flights to be cancelled and 750 flights to be delayed as of February 1. The cancellations, primarily by American Airlines and Southwest Airlines, were attributed to the winter storm's impact on crew scheduling systems. This comes nearly a month after Southwest faced US government backlash for cancelling 16,700 flights over the holidays. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) warned of hazardous conditions in certain areas, including Texas and Memphis.

images.alt_text: Southwest, which also reported a loss in the fourth quarter, said it expects a revenue hit of between US$300 million and US$350 million in the first quarter.

site_title: Biden moves to slash US credit card fees, app charges
summary: The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) will propose a rule to ban "excessive" credit card late fees, estimated to cost consumers $12 billion annually. The rule aims to reduce typical late fees from $30 to $8, saving consumers $9 billion a year. Additionally, the White House will unveil efforts to slash app store fees and promote competition in consumer markets.

site_title: Oxley Holdings H1 net profit falls to S$277,000 on lower revenue
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a net profit of S$277,000 for the first half of 2022, down from S$23.5 million in the same period last year. The decline was attributed to lower revenue streams and higher finance costs, including rising interest rates and lower mark-to-market gains on derivatives. The company cited "lower revenue streams coupled with higher finance costs resulting from rising interest rates and lower mark-to-market fair-value gain on derivative financial instruments" as the main reasons for the decline.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Oxley currently holds 101.3 million Aspen shares, representing about 9.4 per cent of the total number of issued shares.
Oxley Holdings' hotel development Novotel Singapore and Mercure Singapore on Stevens Road. The group posted a S$20.3 million loss attributable to shareholders for H2 FY2022.

site_title: Keppel Reit’s curious S$100 million anniversary distribution
summary: Keppel Reit declared a distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0295 for the second half of financial year 2022, up from S$0.0288 in the year-ago period. After stripping out the anniversary distribution of S$0.0027, the DPU would have been S$0.0268, 5.3% lower than FY2021's DPU of S$0.0283. This marks Keppel Reit's first anniversary distribution of S$100 million.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Hospitality S-Reits such as CapitaLand Ascott Trust are expected to ride on the tailwinds of the return of Chinese tourists.

site_title: ChatGPT owner launches 'imperfect' tool to detect AI-generated text
summary: OpenAI has released a software tool to identify AI-generated text, a move aimed at addressing concerns about copyright and plagiarism. The tool, in its public beta mode, is unreliable on texts under 1,000 characters and can be edited to trick the classifier. The company acknowledges its limitations and is seeking feedback from educators and users. This move follows the popularity of ChatGPT, which has been banned by some US school districts due to concerns over cheating and plagiarism. OpenAI plans to continue working on detecting AI-generated text.

images.alt_text: Baidu has spent billions of dollars researching AI in a years-long effort to transition from online marketing to deeper technology.

site_title: Wolfspeed teams with ZF to build US$3 billion chip plant in Germany
summary: Wolfspeed, an American chipmaker, plans to build a US$3 billion plant in Germany to produce electric vehicle chips. The factory, located in Saarland, will start production in 2027 and is expected to be the world's largest silicon carbide chip production facility. Automotive supplier ZF is investing US$185 million for a minority stake in the plant, covering a significant portion of the project costs. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz is expected to attend the factory announcement, with Wolfspeed expecting government subsidies to cover a "big part" of the remaining costs.

site_title: China to expand registration-based IPO system
summary: China's securities regulator has published draft rules to expand the registration-based initial public offering (IPO) system to the main boards, marking a significant step towards reforming the country's second-largest stock market. The new system aims to increase transparency and predictability, allowing companies to choose their IPO venue and removing daily trading limits for IPO shares during their first five trading days. The CSRC will consolidate IPO rules for Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Beijing bourses, while maintaining quality requirements and vetting IPO issuances against China's national industrial policy.

images.alt_text: Lotus plans to start production of its first electric SUV by the end of this year.

site_title: US dollar slips ahead of Fed rate decision
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% to 101.91 ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate decision, with investors expecting a quarter-point rate hike to 4.75%. The euro remained unchanged despite easing inflation data for a third straight month. Market analysts believe the Fed will signal an end to interest-rate tightening, potentially leading to rate cuts. The US dollar index has fallen for four straight months, and investors will closely watch Fed chair Jerome Powell's words for signs of a pivot in policy.

site_title: Singapore, EU sign partnership to strengthen bilateral digital trade
summary: Singapore and the European Union (EU) have signed the EU-Singapore Digital Partnership, aiming to strengthen bilateral digital trade and connectivity. The agreement will facilitate seamless digital transactions, reduce costs, and promote cooperation in emerging areas like artificial intelligence and 5G/6G. The partnership will serve as a framework for digital cooperation, covering areas such as digital trade facilitation, trusted data flows, and electronic payments. The signing ceremony took place in Brussels, with Singapore's Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran and European Commissioner for Internal Market Thierry Breton attending.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Premier League January spending spree sends records tumbling
summary: The Premier League spent a record £815 million in January, nearly doubling the previous highest figure, with Chelsea setting a new British record by signing Enzo Fernandez for £106.8 million. The league's huge spending is backed by record broadcasting rights revenues, with clubs from the top six accounting for over half of the total gross spend. This surpasses European rivals, with 79% of total spending in the major football leagues.

site_title: Murakami to publish first new novel in six years
summary: Japanese author Haruki Murakami will release his first new novel in six years, titled "Untitled" and expected to be published on April 13, 2023. The book will be 1,200 Japanese manuscript pages long and will be published in Japanese initially, with translations following later. This will be Murakami's first novel since "Killing Commendatore" in 2017, and details of the plot will be kept under wraps to respect the author's desire for "readers to discover it without knowing anything beforehand".

images.alt_text: Facing up to the shortness of our time on earth can help us focus more intently on the things that truly matter.

site_title: Tin Pei Ling joins Grab Singapore as director of public affairs and policy
summary: Member of Parliament Tin Pei Ling has joined ride-hailing company Grab as its Singapore director of public affairs and policy, effective January. Tin, who is the MP for MacPherson, will build partnerships and programs to harness technology's positive impact in Singapore. Prior to joining Grab, she was the CEO of Business China, a non-profit organization, and has also held roles at Ernst and Young and Jing King Technology Group.

images.alt_text: Grab's attempts to scale up its supply comes as commuters face longer waiting times and fare surges due to the driver shortage.

site_title: Tesla to raise Shanghai output after price cuts stoke demand
summary: Tesla plans to produce a weekly average of nearly 20,000 units at its Shanghai factory in February and March, following price cuts that sparked demand for its best-selling models. The production rate would match the plant's September output, and comes after the company extended a Lunar New Year holiday period and cut output by about a third in December. The move aims to meet growing demand and supports Tesla's goal of delivering 2 million vehicles in 2023, according to CEO Elon Musk.

images.alt_text: Tesla reported fourth-quarter profits of US$3.7 billion, up 59 per cent from the year-ago period as revenues jumped 37 per cent to US$24.3 billion.

site_title: Budget 2023 a delicate balancing act between prudence and support as costs rise: economists
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 is expected to strike a delicate balance between fiscal prudence and support for businesses and households amid rising costs and a weaker economic outlook. Economists predict a focus on raising productivity, investing in medium to long-term needs, and addressing rising inflation. Handouts will likely be carefully calibrated, with a continued eye on longer-term needs. The government may offer support to SMEs, attract foreign talent, and enhance training initiatives to help workers remain relevant. A GST Assurance Package may be increased, but immediate handouts are expected to be ad hoc to tide through the current inflation storm.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Elysia Tan
IMF's chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas said Singapore’s economy will grow by 1.5 per cent this year, slower than the 3.7 per cent growth achieved in 2022.
Singapore manufacturers’ sentiment worsens; services sector mood moderates: surveys
While the manufacturing sector appears more downcast, there are still pockets of growth segments which will be hiring, said OCBC chief economist Selena Ling.
Most SMEs are preparing for a rise in expenditure in the next 12 months, the survey by QBE Insurance found.

site_title: China bull run has investors on edge
summary: Global investors are pouring into China's yuan-denominated stocks via the Stock Connect scheme, with nearly $20 billion in purchases this year, surpassing last year's $13 billion. The MSCI China index has risen 50% since its October 2022 trough, but investors are concerned about whether the rebound is sustainable. Despite a pullback, both the Hang Seng Index and Nasdaq Golden Dragon China index are up over 10% and 13% respectively in the year to date. Experts weigh in on the market, with some warning of a potential correction, while others see the growth as already priced in and look for earnings growth to drive further upside.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
China A-shares received US$7 billion of foreign fund inflows in the week ended Jan 13, buoyed by optimism about the country's renewed focus on growth.
Hong Kong equities have risen 26 per cent since Nov 18, when Hong turned bullish ahead of China’s abrupt end to its years-long Covid-Zero policy.

site_title: Adani stock meltdown hits US$92 billion as collateral worries grow
summary: Gautam Adani's conglomerate saw its stock plummet by 28% after Credit Suisse stopped accepting Adani Group's bonds as collateral for margin loans, raising concerns over the group's exposure to debt. The stock rout has reached $92 billion, threatening Adani's financial stability and growth. Financial institutions, including Barclays, are scrutinizing their exposure to the indebted conglomerate, and investors may face deep losses. The crisis has also raised questions over India's corporate governance and has turned Adani into a drag on the nation's stock markets.

images.alt_text: Hindenburg Research's accusation of stock manipulation by Adani Group will not, on its own, be enough to convince investors who are deciding what to do with their Adani holdings.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: EnterpriseSG supported 18,100 Singapore companies in 2022, focusing on productivity, innovation, and internationalization. In 2022, more companies expanded overseas with EnterpriseSG's support, with about half doing so for the first time. The Energy Market Authority (EMA) launched a public consultation to enhance the electricity retailer framework. Singapore shares rose on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street gains, as investors anticipated a possible easing of the Federal Reserve's rate-hike path.

site_title: ABB’s electric-vehicle charging business gets new investors including Singapore’s GIC
summary: ABB's electric-vehicle charging business, ABB E-Mobility, has raised additional funds with a 12% stake sold to minority investors, including Porsche and General Atlantic, for $465.5 million. The division, valued at $2.5 billion, aims to grow its charging business using $525 million in funding from private placements. ABB plans to list the unit separately, subject to market conditions, as it continues to streamline its business to boost profitability.

site_title: Kore manager sees silver lining in ‘minor’ Big Tech layoffs even as H2 DPU falls 12.6%
summary: Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's manager views large-scale tech layoffs as "somewhat positive" for the US office-focused real estate investment trust, as they indicate a correction from years of rapid hiring. Despite a 12.6% decline in second-half 2022 distribution per unit, the manager sees the hiring freezes and minor layoffs as beneficial for getting employees back to offices, which could boost physical occupancy. The Reit's portfolio occupancy increased to 92.6% as of December 2022, with positive rental reversion in the technology hubs of Seattle-Bellevue/Redmond.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Jude Chan
Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit's aggregate leverage stood at 37.5 per cent as at end September 2022.

site_title: Grab Singapore grapples with driver shortages
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing operator in Singapore, is struggling with a driver shortage, leaving commuters with longer waiting times and fare surges. The company aims to increase supply by 70-80% of pre-pandemic levels, but rising fuel and vehicle costs are deterring drivers. Grab has introduced new features to improve driver productivity, such as a navigation system and carpooling option, but faces challenges in balancing fares for drivers and passengers. The company currently has about 57,000 active drivers in Singapore, lower than pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
DBS’ target price for Grab remains unchanged at US$2.93 as the brokerage continues to assume a 12 per cent adjusted Ebitda margin in FY2027, leading to US$1.1 billion adjusted group Ebitda.
An illustration on the Grab website shows that a S$1,500 cash advance, payable over one year, would be charged a S$120 admin fee

site_title: Asian football chief elected for third consecutive term
summary: Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim al-Khalifa, the chief of the Asian Football Confederation (AFC), has been re-elected for a third consecutive four-year term. The Bahraini royal, who has led the AFC since 2013, won the vote unopposed, stating that "Asian football is entering a new era." FIFA President Gianni Infantino congratulated al-Khalifa and praised the rise of Asian football, citing the 2022 World Cup in Qatar as a highlight.

site_title: Eurozone inflation eases as ECB debate over rates heats up
summary: The Eurozone's inflation rate slowed to 8.5% in January, beating economists' expectations of 8.9%. This data may embolden dovish officials at the European Central Bank to push for a decrease in interest rate hikes. The slowdown was driven by energy costs, while underlying inflation remained high at 5.2%. The third consecutive monthly retreat suggests a heated debate to come at the ECB over the pace of rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The IMF lifted its outlook for global inflation on Tuesday and now predicts it will slow from 8.8 per cent in 2022 to 6.6 per cent this year and 4.3 per cent in 2024.

site_title: Eurozone factories are likely over the worst
summary: Eurozone factories show signs of improvement, with S&P Global's manufacturing PMI rising to a five-month high of 48.8 in January, easing the downturn and moderating demand. Output and business optimism have also improved, with the future output index jumping to an 11-month high. The news is a relief for policymakers at the European Central Bank, who are struggling to control inflation, which is predicted to be 9.0% last month.

images.alt_text: Eurozone GDP is now expected to increase 0.6 per cent this year, compared with an earlier forecast for a contraction of 0.1 per cent.

site_title: EU lays out green industry plan to counter US, China subsidies
summary: The European Commission has proposed a plan to counter US and China subsidies for green industry investments, aiming to make Europe a manufacturing hub for electric vehicles and other green products. The plan includes loosening state aid rules, repurposing EU funds, faster approval of green projects, and boosting skills. The EU wants to reduce its dependence on China for critical raw materials and compete globally. The plan is a response to China's and the US's multi-billion-dollar support programs, including the Inflation Reduction Act, and is expected to be debated at a Feb 9-10 summit.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)
FILE PHOTO: A worker transports packaged pasta at De Cecco's factory in Fara San Martino, Italy, November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Remo Casilli/File Photo

site_title: White House takes aim at high credit card late fees, app stores
summary: The Biden administration is proposing measures to slash billions in credit card late fees and open mobile app stores to greater competition. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will cap late payment credit card fees at $8, saving consumers $9 billion annually. The Open App Markets Act, announced by the President, would require Apple and Google to make it easier for users to download other app stores and switch default apps on phones. This move aims to harm corporate consolidation and inflate prices, benefiting consumers.

site_title: UK's teachers and civil servants join 'Walkout Wednesday'
summary: In the UK, a coordinated strike by 500,000 workers, including teachers, civil servants, train drivers, and university lecturers, brought widespread disruption on February 1, 2023. The strike, which was the largest in Britain in a generation, forced millions of children to miss school and halted most rail services. The strike was over pay and conditions, with teachers citing a 12-year decline in pay as a major factor. The government, led by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, has taken a hard line with public sector workers, refusing to give in to demands for large wage increases, which it says would fuel inflation.

images.alt_text: Nurses and ambulance workers are due to stand side-by-side on picket lines for the first time on Feb 6, in an escalation of their campaign against below-inflation raises.

site_title: It’s not easy being a stock market villain
summary: Hindenburg Research's report on India's Adani Group has sparked criticism from the group, with Adani branding the firm "the Madoffs of Manhattan" and accusing it of a "calculated attack on India." Despite the challenges and stigma associated with short-selling, the role of Hindenburg and other short-sellers in maintaining efficient capital markets is crucial, as they augment liquidity and help detect fraud. Research suggests that 11% of large publicly traded firms commit securities fraud annually, with short-sellers playing a key role in uncovering such deception.

images.alt_text: Hindenburg Research's accusation of stock manipulation by Adani Group will not, on its own, be enough to convince investors who are deciding what to do with their Adani holdings.
Wednesday’s stock losses saw Adani slip to 15th on Forbes rich list with an estimated net worth of US$76.8 billion

site_title: Will Gen Z disrupt the Asean corporate landscape?
summary: Gen Z, born after 1997, is expected to influence the corporate world in South-east Asia as they join the workforce and consumers. A GlobalData survey found that 34% of 16-24-year-olds in the region strongly agree that brands should address social issues such as racism and sexism. This is higher than the global average, with enthusiasm varying across countries, with the Philippines being the most enthusiastic and Malaysia the least. As Gen Z takes on leadership roles, businesses in South-east Asia may need to adapt to their social concerns, but factors such as lower priorities on social issues in the region and higher trust in institutions may limit the extent of this influence.

images.alt_text: What did your favourite brand do in the war, Daddy?

An advocacy group calling itself Gen-Z for Change said it coordinated the pledge from more than 70 popular TikTok talents to stand in solidarity with Amazon workers through a “People Over Prime Pledge.”

site_title: Jeju’s natural wonders
summary: Jeju Island, a South Korean getaway, is showcased in a Netflix food show and invites travelers to experience its natural wonders, including three UNESCO heritage sites and a peaceful pace of life. The island offers a variety of seafood, pastries, and unique cuts of meat, as well as cultural attractions like Southeast Asian art and Japanese ceramics. Visitors can explore Jeju city and beyond, sample local cuisine, and enjoy the island's natural beauty, including sunsets over Suweolbong Peak.

site_title: The next retirement communities won’t be just for seniors
summary: Developers are reimagining retirement communities with an urban village model, offering communal spaces and shared amenities, rather than isolated suburban settings. This approach aims to provide affordable housing for seniors and reduce loneliness, while also serving younger renters. The concept, driven by an aging population and demographic shifts, focuses on local resources and inter-generational living, with projects in various stages of development worldwide. The urban village model has the potential to provide cheaper rent and support local businesses, as cities recognize the importance of keeping seniors in urban settings to maintain their activity and engagement.

images.alt_text: Widespread protests in Paris, around the Place de la Republique, against the French government's pension reform plan; Jan 19, 2023.
An elderly Ukrainian villager on a road on the outskirts of Dibrova on July 23, 2022. The relative balance of risks between demography and climate is changing.

site_title: DBS to subsidise 5 million hawker meals amid rising food prices
summary: DBS/POSB has announced a 12-month subsidisation programme to support 5 million hawker meals, amid rising food prices. The programme, available every Friday, will provide a S$3 subsidy to the first 100,000 users of DBS' mobile wallet app PayLah!. Approximately 11,600 hawker stalls across Singapore are participating, including those displaying the SGQR label. This initiative aims to alleviate the financial burden on Singaporeans and residents, particularly during times of inflation.

images.alt_text: About 250 senior citizens learnt how to make cashless payments and spot scams during the first set of Digital for Life workshops, which were run by volunteers from DBS and the IMDA's SG Digital Office.

site_title: No broad-based subsidies for SMEs in Budget 2023, but some scheme renewals possible: analysts
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 is expected to be "prudent and calibrated" as the country aims for fiscal consolidation after the pandemic. SMEs are unlikely to receive general subsidies, but existing schemes such as the Energy Efficiency Grant, Market Readiness Assistance grant, and Productivity Solutions Grant may be extended or enhanced. The government may also consider new initiatives to support SMEs in innovation, digitalization, and sustainability. Analysts emphasize the need for fiscal responsibility and caution against overly generous support measures, given the current economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Linus Goh, OCBC's head of global commercial banking, believes there is a chance that SMEs will still remain in expansionary territory for the first quarter of 2023.
Deloitte said it would not be in Singapore’s best interest to be the first mover in enacting Pillar Two rules, and waiting for international consensus on implementation options is “more prudent”.

site_title: Singapore Pools collaborates with ART:DIS to empower people with disabilities through the arts
summary: Singapore Pools has partnered with ART:DIS to fund the renovation of the non-profit organization's disability-friendly space in Bukit Merah, aiming to empower people with disabilities through the arts. The collaboration is part of Singapore Pools' corporate social responsibility efforts, which include supporting social service agencies and charities to uplift the community. ART:DIS empowers over 450 persons with disabilities through various arts programs, and the renovated space will enable them to pursue their artistic talents and realize their aspirations.

images.alt_text: UOB chief executive officer Wee Ee Cheong (centre) with winning bidders Kelvin Lim (second from left) and Neo Kah Kiat (second from right), as well as UOB head of group commercial banking Eric Lian (extreme left) and head of group wholesale banking and markets Frederick Chin at the Lunar New Year fundraising gala dinner.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street gains
summary: Singapore shares rose on Wednesday, tracking Wall Street gains, with gains outnumbering losses 331 to 182. The Straits Times Index rose 0.4% to close at 3,377.65, driven by anticipation of the Federal Reserve easing its rate-hike path. Top gainer Keppel DC Reit gained 3.4%, while CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust was the biggest loser, down 1.4%.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Shares on the Singapore bourse rose on Tuesday amid a mixed showing by regional peers
Analysts will be paying close attention to the earnings of banks, companies in the tourism sector as well as hospitality and retail Reits in the coming weeks.

site_title: Number of firms using EnterpriseSG to expand overseas higher in 2022 than previous year
summary: In 2022, more than 2,000 Singapore firms expanded overseas with the support of Enterprise Singapore, with about half venturing into new markets for the first time. The top destinations included South-east Asia, the Middle East, Africa, the US, Latin America, and Europe. EnterpriseSG assisted over 25,000 SMEs through business advisory and upgrading efforts, and helped 450 firms secure new opportunities, generating S$3.5 billion in overseas sales and S$1.4 billion in investments. The agency also expanded its Global Innovation Alliance programme and launched new strategies to grow promising companies and develop Singapore as a global trading hub.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
More productivity support but fewer Covid-related loans in 2021: ESG
Now that international borders have reopened, more Singapore companies are heading to Vietnam in search of business opportunities, industry watchers told The Business Times.

site_title: China’s CATL has picked banks for US$5b Swiss GDR sale: sources
summary: Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL), the world's largest electric car battery maker, has chosen banks for a US$5 billion sale of global depositary receipts (GDRs) in Switzerland. The GDR sale is part of the company's effort to tap the European market, as geopolitical risks and regulatory woes reduce the appeal of other offshore markets. CATL has partnered with China International Capital, China Securities International, Goldman Sachs, and UBS for the sale, which could happen as soon as this year. The listing would be the largest GDR issuance by a Chinese company, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

images.alt_text: CATL’s 1.8-billion-euro German factory, its first in Europe, sent its first sample battery cells to clients in December 2022.
The agreement with a consortium including CATL could help finally unlock Bolivia’s huge potential as a supplier of lithium for batteries needed to power the global shift to electric vehicle.

site_title: MUFG and Indonesia’s Danamon establish US$100m fund
summary: MUFG Innovation Partners and Bank Danamon Indonesia have established a $100 million fund to focus on emerging companies in Indonesia. The MUFG Innovation Partners Garuda No 1 Limited Investment Partnership will make investments with synergies to Danamon, aiming to enhance product competitiveness, promote digitalization, and attract new customers. This marks MUFG's third fund and follows a $200 million investment in Indonesian fintech company Akulaku last year. Danamon holds an 89.9% stake, while MUFG holds a 0.1% stake as a general partner.

images.alt_text: MUFG notes that Indonesia is important for its expansion in Asia, given the country’s economic size and a high growth potential among South-east Asian peers.
Even as Japan takes its most significant step yet towards reopening borders, the nation’s biggest banks say they are getting feedback from employees about greater productivity thanks to remote work.
A pedestrian walks in front of the Bank of Japan (BoJ) head office building in Tokyo on April 27, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Is it metaverse art or Birkin ripoff? A US jury will decide
summary: A US jury will decide whether digital artist Mason Rothschild's "MetaBirkin" nonfungible tokens (NFTs) infringed on luxury brand Hermès' intellectual property rights. The NFTs depict images resembling Hermès' hard-to-get Birkin bags and were sold for tens of thousands of dollars. Hermès claims the NFTs misled consumers into thinking they were affiliated with the brand, while Rothschild's lawyer argues that the First Amendment protects artistic expression. The trial marks the first case involving trademark infringement of NFTs in the metaverse.

site_title: BOJ’s record bond buying highlights challenge for yield control
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) purchased a record $182 billion worth of government bonds in January, exceeding its previous high, to defend its yield cap from rising interest rates. The massive buying highlights the central bank's increasing difficulty in sustaining its yield control policy, which aims to keep the 10-year yield around 0%. Analysts see this as a stop-gap effort to buy time until a new governor takes office in April, who may revamp the yield curve control policy.

images.alt_text: The announcement underscores the central bank’s resolve to prevent simmering market speculation of a near-term interest rate hike from pushing up bond yields too much.

site_title: South Korea closer to recession as Jan exports plunge
summary: South Korea's economy is on the brink of recession, with its trade deficit reaching a record high in January. The country's exports fell 16.6% in January, the largest drop since May 2020, while imports fell 2.6%. The decline in exports, particularly in the semiconductor sector, has led to concerns about the central bank's interest rate hikes and the potential for a recession. The government has forecast a 4.5% decline in exports this year and is taking steps to support exports and boost trade balance.

images.alt_text: New orders in South Korea shrank for the seventh straight month in January, although the rate of decline was a little slower than a month earlier, a business survey showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Indonesia’s Pertamina geothermal unit targets raising as much as 9.78 trillion rupiah in IPO
summary: Pertamina Geothermal Energy, a unit of Indonesia's state energy company Pertamina, plans to raise up to 9.78 trillion rupiah (S$860 million) through an initial public offering (IPO) offering up to 25% of its stake. The shares will be priced between 820-945 rupiah and are expected to be invested in capacity expansions of its geothermal areas. The IPO is scheduled for February 20-22, with underwriters CSLA Sekuritas Indonesia, Credit Suisse Sekuritas Indonesia, and Mandiri Sekuritas. The company aims to double its geothermal capacity by 2027-2028, which may cost an estimated US$4 billion.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of state-owned oil giant Pertamina's refinery unit IV  in Cilacap, Central Java, Indonesia January 13, 2016. REUTERS/Darren Whiteside/File Photo

site_title: Bank of England should raise rates one last time
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise its official interest rate by 50 basis points to 4% on Thursday, marking the final hike in a 15-month cycle. The decision comes as the UK's inflation rate has slowed to 10.5% in December, but still above the MPC's target. The BOE's pause for now is seen as a way to assess the economic impact of the rate hikes and to bring the differing views of the Monetary Policy Committee closer. The move is also influenced by the Federal Reserve's consideration of a 25 basis point hike this week and the European Central Bank's hawkish stance.

images.alt_text: The central bank has expected the UK to be in recession already, but the economy has proved resilient so far, growing slightly in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Nomura’s Q3 profit grows despite investment banking slump
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage and investment bank, reported a 11% rise in quarterly net profit to 66.9 billion yen, despite its wholesale division logging a pretax loss of 1.9 billion yen due to a slump in investment banking. The company attributed the loss to a decline in the global investment banking fee pool, which more than halved from the same quarter last year. Despite job cuts, Nomura plans to continue investing in its competitive areas, such as its Greentech unit. The company's CEO cited a potential market bottom due to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rebound from losses after Wall Street rally
summary: Asian markets rebounded from losses on Wednesday, driven by a Wall Street surge fueled by data indicating slowing US inflation and hopes of an end to the Federal Reserve's rate hike cycle. The US central bank's policy decision later in the day is expected to influence interest rates for the next few months. Most Asian markets, including Tokyo, Shanghai, and Sydney, rose, while Hong Kong dipped for a third straight day. Analysts expect the Fed to hike borrowing costs by 25 basis points, with some speculating it could be the final rate hike in the cycle.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Tokyo and Shanghai markets were flat, while Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta markets fell.

site_title: Inflation in UK shops hits record despite broader easing
summary: The UK saw a record 8% shop price inflation in January, with food prices rising 13.8%, according to the British Retail Consortium. Despite higher sales over Christmas, retailers remain cautious about the impact on shoppers, with profit outlooks unchanged. Higher food prices are reducing consumer spending on non-essential items, leading to increased visits to discount stores. The UK's antitrust regulator has started a review into grocery pricing, and economists predict weak consumer demand in the first quarter due to energy price increases and Christmas spending bills.

images.alt_text: Tesco says the 1,750 affected managers will have the option of moving to new shift leader vacancies, or be dismissed and receive redundancy pay.

site_title: Superman, Batman and Swamp Thing to anchor DC's revamped movie and TV slate
summary: DC Studios, under new owner Warner Bros Discovery, is revamping its movie and TV slate with a 10-year plan. Director James Gunn and co-chairperson Peter Safran aim to unify the studio's storytelling with a single, interconnected narrative across 10 projects. The first phase, "Gods and Monsters," introduces a new generation of characters, while "DC Elseworlds" will release standalone stories, including "Joker: Folie a Deux" and a new Superman film written by Gunn. The studio also plans to release several TV projects, including "Lanterns" and "Waller."

images.alt_text: Investors' obsession with technology has led to many countries and companies being overlooked.
Balancing art and commerce has always been the great game of Hollywood, and few have played it as well as director M Night Shyamalan.
Wakanda: Forever, the sequel to 2018’s blockbuster hit Black Panther, debuted in global theatres in November.

site_title: Geely’s Lotus going public via SPAC at US$5.4 billion valuation
summary: Lotus Technology, an electric-car maker owned by China's Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, has agreed to merge with a US$5.4 billion blank-check company, L Catterton Asia Acquisition, to go public. The combined entity will retain 89.7% ownership by Geely and its affiliates. The deal was facilitated by Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse Group, and is seen as a strategic move to support Geely's plans to expand its electric vehicle offerings.

images.alt_text: Lotus plans to start production of its first electric SUV by the end of this year.

site_title: Easing prices revive LNG interest from Asia's emerging gas markets
summary: Asian emerging markets are reviving interest in liquefied natural gas (LNG) after prices fell to their lowest in over a year, with spot LNG prices reaching US$19.50/mmBtu. The drop in prices has made LNG more competitive with coal for power generation, and companies in Thailand, India, and Bangladesh have issued tenders for LNG cargoes. If prices stay low, it could lead to additional LNG demand, reversing months of buyers staying on the sidelines following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Pakistan has struggled to procure spot cargoes of LNG amid elevated global gas prices, which spiked to record highs last year following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Singapore stocks close flat on Tuesday amid mixed regional performance
summary: Singapore stocks closed flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 0.02% to 3,262.63. Losers outnumbered gainers 279 to 273, following mixed regional performance. Markets in the US started the week higher ahead of key data releases. Despite rising inflation worries, investors debated the impact of the Federal Reserve's policy rate and yield increases.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
On the Singapore Exchange, gainers outnumber losers 64 to 39 after 34.1 million securities worth S$32.9  million changed hands.

site_title: Adani loses Asia’s richest crown as stock rout exceeds US$90 billion
summary: Gautam Adani's conglomerate saw stock losses of over $92 billion following a US short-seller report, causing him to drop to 15th on Forbes' rich list with an estimated net worth of $76.8 billion, down from third. This loss also took away his title as Asia's richest person, with Mukesh Ambani ranking ninth with a net worth of $83.6 billion.

images.alt_text: An Adani Enterprises Limited board of director arrives to attend a news conference to announce the company's forthcoming Follow-on Public Offering (FPO), in Mumbai on January 19, 2023. - Indian industrialist Gautam Adani on January 19 launched the country's biggest follow-on share sale, offering investors incentives and discounts in a bid to lower debt and fuel rapid expansion at his conglomerate. (Photo by Punit PARANJPE / AFP)
Ten of the conglomerate’s companies have seen about US$75 billion in market value erased as the rout entered a fourth session.
The Indian tycoon has fallen from fourth place to 11th on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: UK company directors most optimistic since Russian invasion
summary: The UK company directors are the most optimistic since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February last year, according to the Institute of Directors. Over 50% of executives believe inflation will be falling by summer, and a quarter are optimistic about the UK economy. The overall economic confidence index rose to minus 28 in January, contrasting with forecasts of a recession. This improvement in business outlook may help the UK withstand high-interest rates and inflation better than expected.

images.alt_text: Prices are steadily rising for consumers even as broader measures of inflation start to ease in the UK.

site_title: US, India partnership targets arms and AI to compete with China
summary: The US and India have launched a partnership to counter China's influence in the region, focusing on military equipment, semiconductors, and artificial intelligence. The initiative aims to deploy Western mobile phone networks in India, welcome Indian computer chip specialists to the US, and encourage collaboration on military equipment like artillery systems. Despite US restrictions on military technology transfer and India's dependence on Russia for military hardware, the partnership seeks to strengthen the US-India relationship and address China's growing economic and military presence in the Indo-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: In its publicity material, Eleven Labs produced a video of actor Leonardo DiCaprio being voiced by several other celebrities.

(FILES) This file photo taken on July 8, 2022 shows the Huawei headquarters in Shenzhen, China's southern Guangdong province. - Revenue at Chinese telecom giant Huawei fell by 2.2 percent in the first three quarters of 2022, company data showed October 27, 2022, as Covid-19 and US sanctions dragged down sales. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP)
RBI said the relaxation under LRS was based on SBM’s submission and also to provide relief to affected customers.
The Indian tycoon has fallen from fourth place to 11th on the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

site_title: India hikes spending, cuts deficit in last budget before 2024 vote
summary: India's finance minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, presented the country's budget for the next fiscal year, which starts on April 1. The budget includes a 7.4% increase in total expenditure to 45 trillion rupees (S$722.3 billion), with a focus on capital spending, which rose 33% to 10 trillion rupees (S$160.5 billion). The government aims to reduce the fiscal deficit to 5.9% of GDP, down from 6.4% for the current year. The budget also includes measures to support job creation and maintain financial discipline, with a target of 6% economic growth for the next fiscal year.

images.alt_text: epa10442119 A woman watches Union Budget news on TV inside a house boat in Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian Kashmir, 01 February 2023. The Union Budget for the financial year 2023-24 was presented in the parliament by the country's finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman in New Delhi.  EPA-EFE/FAROOQ KHAN

site_title: Kitchener Road shophouse for sale with S$12 million guide price
summary: A three-storey freehold shophouse on Kitchener Road has been put up for sale via an expression of interest (EOI) exercise with an indicative guide price of S$12 million. The property, leased to a restaurant and offices, sits on a 1,440.2 square foot plot of land and has a gross plot ratio of 3.0, zoned for commercial use. The sale is seen as an opportunity for investors and owner-occupiers to acquire a stable-yielding freehold F&B shophouse in a prime city fringe enclave.

images.alt_text: 466 Serangoon Road building which sits on a land plot spanning about 2,236 square feet (sq ft) has been put up for sale with an indicative guide price of S$20 million.

site_title: BMW raises prices for some models in China on higher costs
summary: BMW has raised prices for 17 models sold in China due to higher raw material and logistics costs globally. The price increases, effective immediately, include the 5 series sedans and X5 crossovers, with some models seeing price hikes of up to 7,000 yuan. This contrasts with recent price reductions by electric vehicle makers such as Tesla and Xpeng. BMW cited the need to flexibly respond to changes in raw materials and vehicle manufacturing costs, despite a 18.6% decline in BMW car sales in China during the first 29 days of January.

site_title: WhiteCoat sets sights on regional health passport; seeks fresh US$25 million in funding
summary: WhiteCoat Holdings, a digital health provider, is raising US$25 million in Series B funding to expand into Indonesia, Vietnam, and Malaysia. The company, which has seen 12 successive quarters of growth, aims to turn profitable this year and double revenues from 2022. WhiteCoat Holdings has set up a regional corporate headquarters in Singapore and plans to grow organically, rather than through mergers and acquisitions. The funding will support the company's regional expansion and contribute to its growth in the new markets.

images.alt_text: Dr. Shravan Verma., chief executive officer of Speedoc said: "The most rewarding thing about serving the country during Covid-19 was also being able to hire people from different industries,."

site_title: Hong Kong housing slump pushes negative equity to 18-year high
summary: Hong Kong's housing market faces its worst slump in over a decade, with 12,164 cases of negative equity reported in the fourth quarter, an 18-year high. Prices declined 16% last year, and soaring interest rates have squeezed homeowners. The combined value of underwater mortgages reached HK$66.3 billion (S$11.1 billion). However, recent border reopenings and removal of Covid restrictions have boosted optimism, potentially leading to a drop in negative equity homes in the second quarter.

site_title: Shell is selling ‘carbon neutral’ fossil fuels again
summary: Shell has resumed selling "carbon neutral" fossil fuels, following new industry guidelines that require companies to calculate and report greenhouse gas emissions, and have a stated commitment to decarbonization. The company's latest shipment of liquefied natural gas to Taiwan was certified as "greenhouse gas neutral" under the International Group of Liquefied Natural Gas Importers' (GIIGNL) framework. However, critics argue that these offsets do little to extract additional carbon from the air and that the lack of transparency in the industry makes it difficult to verify the authenticity of these claims.

images.alt_text: The review of Shell Energy, which supplies energy to around 1.4 million homes across Britain and broadband to around half a million customers, could affect its 2,000-strong UK workforce.
Shell also expects to pay about US$2 billion in additional 2022 taxes related to the European Union and British windfall taxes imposed on the energy sector.

site_title: UK house prices in longest slump since 2008, Nationwide says
summary: UK house prices fell 0.6% in January, marking the longest decline since the 2008 financial crisis, according to Nationwide Building Society. The decline follows a jump in mortgage rates and a tight cost-of-living crisis, squeezing the spending power of home buyers. Despite a 1.1% annual growth, prices remain lower than a year ago, and the housing market is unlikely to recover in the coming months. The Bank of England's interest rate hikes have added to the pain, with 4 million owner occupiers expected to face higher mortgage costs over the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: An unprecedented series of interest-rate hikes from the Bank of England has bumped up the cost of mortgages. The effective rate on new loans rose 32 basis points to 3.67 per cent last month.
Prices are steadily rising for consumers even as broader measures of inflation start to ease in the UK.

site_title: Singapore to buy electricity from Malaysia for first time from second half of 2023
summary: Singapore is set to import electricity from Malaysia for the first time, starting from the second half of 2023. YTL PowerSeraya, a local power producer, will import 100 megawatts of electricity from TNB Power Generation's gas-fired plant in Pasir Gudang, Johor. This will account for about 1.5% of Singapore's peak electricity demand, powering around 144,000 four-room flats for a year. The electricity will be exported via a recently upgraded interconnector between the two countries.

images.alt_text: The proposed enhancements will address certain gaps highlighted by recent upheavals in the retail electricity market, EMA said.
IMF's chief economist Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas said Singapore’s economy will grow by 1.5 per cent this year, slower than the 3.7 per cent growth achieved in 2022.
The proposal for Singapore to draw critical energy supply from a source some 4,200 KM away through an undersea cable was deemed a hard sell from the get-go by market watchers.
Rendering of the Sun Cable project. Source: Sun Cable Pty Ltd.

site_title: Compensation for early power termination? EMA seeks enhancements to electricity retailer framework
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) has launched a public consultation to enhance the regulatory framework for electricity retailers, addressing gaps highlighted by recent market upheavals. Proposed measures include a paid-up capital requirement, approval for key appointments, enhanced hedging requirements, and stronger consumer protection against premature contract termination. The EMA aims to strengthen retailers' ability to withstand market volatility and safeguard the retail market's stability. The consultation seeks feedback on these proposals to inform enhancements to the regulatory framework.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Singapore will start buying electricity from Malaysia for the first time in the second half of 2023.
Only one per cent of consumers – including both households and businesses –  buy electricity wholesale, according to the Energy Market Authority.

EMA is looking to strengthen consumer protection by enhancing regulatory requirements on electricity retailers and tightening the eligibility criteria for consumers on Wholesale Electricity Price (WEP) plans

site_title: Serangoon Road commercial building for sale at S$43 million reserve price
summary: A freehold commercial property in Singapore's Little India district will be sold by tender on Feb 2 at an indicative reserve price of S$43 million, or S$2,570 per square foot. The 4-storey building, developed in 2002, sits on a 5,624 sq ft site 400m from Farrer Park MRT station. It is zoned for commercial use and foreign buyers are eligible with no additional stamp duties. The property's built-up area is 16,733 sq ft.

images.alt_text: City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land has launched its 407-unit condominium Piccadilly Grand, with previews starting Saturday (Apr 23) and sales booking scheduled for 2 weeks later on May 7.
466 Serangoon Road building which sits on a land plot spanning about 2,236 square feet (sq ft) has been put up for sale with an indicative guide price of S$20 million.
The shophouses in District 8 can be potentially redeveloped into a six storey commercial building with a gross floor area of 27,125 square foot, PropNex said.

site_title: Macau casinos revenue jumps 82.5% y-o-y in January after visitor surge
summary: Macau's casinos saw a 82.5% year-on-year surge in revenue to 11.6 billion patacas ($1.83 billion) in January, driven by a surge of nearly 500,000 visitor arrivals over the Lunar New Year holiday. This marks the biggest crowds in over three years, but still less than half of the pre-Covid-19 2019 revenue. The resurgence in tourism comes after Macau dropped Covid-19 testing requirements for mainland travelers. The new 10-year contracts for casinos, including Sands China and Wynn Macau, have seen increased revenue for the first time.

images.alt_text: Marina Bay Sands' net revenue contribution nearly doubles for the fourth quarter, up to US$682 million from US$368 in the same period in the year before.

site_title: Aims Apac Reit manager appoints new independent director
summary: AIMS Apac Real Estate Investment Trust's manager has appointed Vivienne Yu as non-executive independent director, effective February 1, 2023. Yu has over 20 years of experience in leadership and management roles in the banking and financial services sector in Australia and Asia. She will join the audit, risk and compliance committee, as well as the nominating and remuneration committee. Her appointment is expected to bring valuable commercial and governance perspectives to the board and management.
