images.alt_text: Higher gross revenue and net property income result in an increase in distribution per unit for Aims Apac Reit.

site_title: Asean factories firing up as China reopens
summary: Southeast Asian factories are ramping up production and purchasing as business confidence lifts due to signs of softening prices and easing supply-chain disruptions. Thailand led the region with a January PMI reading of 54.5, while the Philippines and Indonesia also posted readings above 50. Despite this, Malaysia saw a 17-month low of 46.5. The region's growth outlook is supported by China's reopening, which could boost demand, according to economists. However, the International Monetary Fund warns that tight monetary policy and Russia's invasion of Ukraine will continue to weigh on economic activity.

images.alt_text: New orders in South Korea shrank for the seventh straight month in January, although the rate of decline was a little slower than a month earlier, a business survey showed on Wednesday.
Economists said the faster-than-forecast “exit wave” of Covid-19 infections suggests that the worst of the economic slump has passed.
Global investment banks are now pushing hard to keep a lid on costs after increasing their staffing over the past few years in a war for talent and higher inflation.

site_title: Hynix posts record loss on slump in memory-chip prices
summary: SK Hynix, the world's No 2 Dram maker, reported its biggest quarterly loss on record, with an operating loss of 1.7 trillion won (S$1.8 billion) due to a 50% drop in memory chip prices since their 2022 peak. The company has cut output and capital spending, awaiting a recovery in the second half of the year. Despite sector-wide inventory levels expected to peak in June, Hynix sticks to its plan to halve 2023 capital spending.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s largest company has been struggling with a historic slump in the price of memory, as consumers cut back on purchases of gadgets amid soaring interest rates and inflation.
The industry confidence gauge encompasses manufacturers of semiconductors, displays and smartphones, major drivers of Korea’s exports.

site_title: The US plan to block China on chips will backfire
summary: The US plan to restrict China's access to advanced chipmaking equipment will backfire, causing collateral damage to the global semiconductor industry. The move aims to curb China's ability to move up the value chain, but it will hurt a crucial market and weigh on the revenue of major industrial companies. China accounts for over a quarter of global billings for chip equipment, and restricting access will hinder innovation and development. The US policy focus on holding China back may ultimately push Beijing to develop its own advanced technology, and multinationals with significant investments in China know how to navigate the market successfully.

images.alt_text: An exhibit of ATE Service Corporation is pictured at the company's booth at the Semicon Japan exhibition in Tokyo on December 16, 2022. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)
The White House continued to press allies to pass restrictions limiting the sales of semiconductor manufacturing equipment by firms such as Dutch company ASML or Tokyo Electron in Japan.

(FILES) This file photo taken on July 8, 2022 shows the Huawei headquarters in Shenzhen, China's southern Guangdong province. - Revenue at Chinese telecom giant Huawei fell by 2.2 percent in the first three quarters of 2022, company data showed October 27, 2022, as Covid-19 and US sanctions dragged down sales. (Photo by Jade GAO / AFP)

site_title: With signs that inflation is being tamed, Republicans could be playing defence
summary: US President Joe Biden is facing criticism from Republicans over the economy, despite signs that inflation may be being tamed. The public perceives Biden as responsible for economic issues, despite economists arguing that the business cycle and external factors are more significant. The Fed's interest rate hikes may have slowed inflation without causing a recession, and the economy is experiencing a recovery. Biden is trying to shift the blame to Republicans, who are opposed to raising the debt ceiling unless major spending cuts are made. However, this may not prevent the political narrative from continuing.

images.alt_text: Republican Kevin McCarthy said he would meet on Wednesday with Joe Biden to discuss avoiding a US debt default.
Shoppers in the SoHo neighborhood of New York. Even with 75 per cent of the public saying the economy is poor, a majority of Americans rate their own financial situation positively.

site_title: Housing slump deepens from US to China in risk to global growth
summary: The global housing market is experiencing a slump, with home sales and prices declining in the US, China, Australia, and New Zealand. The US housing market has slid into a fifth month, with China's home sales falling 32.5% in January. Higher interest rates are eroding household finances and threatening to exacerbate falling prices. This could weigh on household spending and investment, particularly in the US and China. Policymakers are expected to raise interest rates to tackle inflation, further exacerbating the slowdown.

images.alt_text: China's housing market faces the prospect of slower recovery than consumption or broad domestic demand.
The Federal Reserve’s fastest interest rate-hiking cycle since the 1980s has driven housing into recession.
Public housing affordability and accessibility will be debated next Monday (Feb 6) when Parliament meets.
The pace of property price increases in the last quarter has moderated amid a drop in sales volume, says Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.

site_title: Tapping the potential of the new Asian consumer
summary: Asian consumers are expected to drive a $10 trillion consumption growth opportunity over the next decade, with the region's GDP per capita forecasted to reach $6,600 by 2030. As income levels rise, consumption in various product categories is expected to take off, creating opportunities for consumer companies. Companies that understand Asia's unique traits, such as a growing awareness of sustainability and a willingness to share data, will be well-positioned to tap the potential of Asia's growing consumer market.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ FILE Ñ Shoppers at a mall in Beijing on Sept. 24, 2022. China on Monday, Oct. 24, 2022, reported a modest rebound in economic activity for the quarter ending in September. (Gilles Sabri/The New York Times)

site_title: Japan’s factory activity shrinks for third month in January
summary: Japan's factory activity contracted for a third month in January, with the S&P survey's subindexes showing a slower pace of contraction compared to the previous two months. The au Jibun Bank Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers'Index was at 48.9, its weakest level since October 2020. Despite this, manufacturers remain upbeat on improved supply and price conditions. The contraction is attributed to worsening global economic conditions, leading to calls for higher wages at spring labor talks to counter inflation and support the consumption-led recovery in Japan's economy.

images.alt_text: About a quarter of Japanese firms have offered inflation allowances or plan to do so, said corporate credit research firm Teikoku Databank.
Japan's industrial output fell 0.1 per cent in December from the previous month, government data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: More Chinese cities post gains in new home prices: survey
summary: China's property sector, accounting for a quarter of the economy, has seen new home prices rise month-on-month in 12 major cities, with some cities reversing declines to post growth. A private survey by China Index Academy found prices rose 0.02% in January, narrowing declines for the fourth straight month. Analysts attribute the gains to property policy easing steps and lifting of Covid-19 containment measures, which have boosted market confidence and slightly improved economic growth. Market confidence is showing signs of recovery, with some cities expected to drive a gradual stabilisation of the national market.

images.alt_text: People ride scooters past residential buildings in Beijing, China, January 13, 2021. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Blackstone’s Breit ready to ‘play offence’ with US$14 billion
summary: Blackstone's real estate investment trust, Breit, has approximately $14 billion in liquidity, allowing it to "play offense" in the market. Following a surge in redemptions last year, Breit has a backlog of withdrawal requests, but received a $4.5 billion infusion from the University of California's regents. The trust is targeting discounted publicly traded real estate investment trusts and is also lending to borrowers in need of new property financing. Breit's portfolio, comprising 80% residential and industrial properties, is expected to deliver rising rents and higher cash flow due to a long-term supply shortage.

images.alt_text: The Blackstone Group headquarters in Manhattan, New York.

site_title: First NFT ETF is closing as once-hot crypto trend fizzles
summary: The Defiance Digital Revolution ETF, the first NFT ETF, is set to close and liquidate its portfolio by the end of February, with liquidation starting on or about February 16. The fund failed to attract assets, according to CEO Sylvia Jablonski, as the crypto trend continues to fizzle. This marks another victim in the crisis affecting the crypto industry.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin miners earn a fixed supply of token rewards released from the blockchain and fees for processing transactions.

site_title: Intel slashes employee, executive pay amid PC market downturn
summary: Intel has cut employee and executive pay amid a downturn in the PC market, following a lower-than-expected sales forecast. The cuts, which range from 5% to 25% for executives, aim to support investments and the workforce. The PC market, which experienced growth during the pandemic, has cooled, leading to a loss of market share for Intel. The company has also reported plunging profit margins. The reductions are designed to impact executive pay more significantly.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s largest company has been struggling with a historic slump in the price of memory, as consumers cut back on purchases of gadgets amid soaring interest rates and inflation.

site_title: UK looks to traditional finance to inform crypto regulations
summary: The UK government plans to regulate crypto asset activities, including trading, lending, and custody, under the same regime as traditional financial services. A consultation on new rules will be published, requiring exchanges to write detailed requirements on admission standards and disclosures for token issuers. The proposed guidelines also include strengthening rules around financial intermediaries and custodians, requiring firms to meet prudential regulation and standards on data reporting, consumer protection, and operational resilience.

images.alt_text: People walk along Regent Street during the second day of Boxing Day sales, in London, Britain, December 27, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: South Korea’s factory activity contracts in January at slightly milder pace: PMI
summary: South Korea's factory activity contracted for the seventh straight month in January, with the S&P Global's PMI at 48.5, slightly higher than December but below the neutral 50-mark. New orders shrank for the seventh consecutive month, with a slower decline than the previous month, amid weak global demand and rising Covid-19 cases in China. Despite the contraction, employment increased for the first time in five months, and manufacturers remained optimistic about future growth.

images.alt_text: The industry confidence gauge encompasses manufacturers of semiconductors, displays and smartphones, major drivers of Korea’s exports.
South Korea has suspended issuing short-term visas to Chinese visitors since early January, after China abruptly ended its stringent “zero-Covid” policy, leading to a wave of infections.

site_title: China’s Jan factory activity contracts at slower pace amid Covid-19 infections: Caixin PMI
summary: China's factory activity contracted at a slower pace in January, according to the Caixin/S&P Global manufacturing PMI, which rose to 49.2 from 49.0 in the previous month. Despite easing pressure on manufacturers after Beijing lifted Covid-19 curbs, infections among workers hindered production. This marks the sixth consecutive monthly contraction, as the PMI index is still below the 50-point mark separating growth from contraction. Economists suggest the "exit wave" of Covid-19 infections may signal the end of the economic slump.

images.alt_text: Patients in Shanghai.. A senior doctor at Shanghai's Ruijin Hospital has said 70 percent of the megacity's population may have been infected with Covid-19 during China's huge surge in cases, state media reported on January 3.

Medical workers attend to patients of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) at an intensive care unit (ICU) converted from a conference room, at a hospital in Cangzhou, Hebei province, China January 11, 2023. China Daily via REUTERS  ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. CHINA OUT.

site_title: Singapore to develop tech talent in key areas, help firms defend against cyberrisks
summary: Singapore's government is launching initiatives to grow a tech-savvy workforce and support businesses in key areas, particularly in cybersecurity. 93% of firms have adopted digital technologies, with strong demand for tech talent. A new scheme, co-funded by the Cyber Security Agency, will help businesses with cybersecurity services, covering up to 70% of costs for the first year. This move aims to meet future demand for a fast-growing digital economy.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Singapore is developing use cases for 5G technology as it expands coverage.

site_title: UK and EU strike deal on Northern Ireland protocol
summary: The UK and EU have reached a deal on the Northern Ireland protocol, a contentious Brexit legacy. The "Windsor Framework" aims to regulate trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The agreement includes new measures, such as "green" and "red" lanes for goods arriving in Northern Ireland, and gives the region's politicians an "emergency brake" to oppose new EU laws. The deal is seen as a significant step towards resolving the protocol's challenges, but some concerns remain. The agreement was reached after months of negotiations, with UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and EU President Ursula von der Leyen holding a press conference to announce the deal.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak (L) and European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen hold a joint press conference following their meeting at the Fairmont Hotel in Windsor, west of London, on Feb 27, 2023.

site_title: Caterpillar sinks as China warning, cost worries pile up
summary: Caterpillar shares plummet 3.4% to $252.66 after the company warned of weaker China demand and rising costs. The US heavy equipment maker reported its first quarterly loss since the pandemic, citing unfavourable raw material costs and global supply chain troubles. CEO Jim Umpleby expressed concerns about the Chinese excavator market, which is expected to be weaker this year than last. Despite optimistic outlook for the year, shares have dropped for the biggest decline in four months, wiping out January's gains.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Caterpillar construction machines sit parked at the Patten Cat dealership in Hammond, Indiana, in this October 20, 2006 file photo. Construction and mining equipment company Caterpillar Inc. said on January 26, 2009 that quarterly earnings fell more than 32 percent and warned of a tough year ahead as the downturn that began in the United States metastasized into a full-blown global recession that hit sales of its earth-moving equipment. Caterpillar announced that it would cut about 17,000 workers and buy out 2,500 others, to reduce costs in the face of what is predicted would be the weakest year for business since the end of World War Two.   REUTERS/Joshua Lott/Files   (UNITED STATES)/File Photo

site_title: Snap shares dive on bad quarterly results
summary: Snapchat's parent company reported a loss of nearly $1.43 billion in the entire year, nearly tripling from 2021. The company's quarterly loss was $288 million, with revenue remaining flat at $1.3 billion. Shares plummeted 14% due to stalled revenue and a disappointing earnings report, which may signal pain for other tech firms relying on digital ads. Analysts attribute the decline to advertisers pulling back on social ad spending amid economic challenges and Apple's privacy changes.

images.alt_text: The Snapchat parent will report its fourth-quarter results on Tuesday (Jan 31), and the results will serve as the season’s first major indication of the state of online advertising

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Wednesday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,377.76. Gainers outnumbered losers 90 to 20, with active trades in Place Holdings, Genting Singapore, and Sembcorp Marine. Local banks UOB, OCBC, and DBS also traded higher, with the trio up 0.3% each. The market followed mixed US and European activity, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rising, but the Nasdaq Composite Index fell.

images.alt_text: Losers outnumbered gainers 297 to 241, after 1.3 billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changed hands.

site_title: Visa, Mastercard pause crypto push in wake of industry meltdown
summary: US payment giants Visa and Mastercard have paused plans to launch products and services related to cryptocurrency due to market volatility and regulatory uncertainty following high-profile collapses of FTX and BlockFi. The decision comes as investors lose faith in the industry, prompting both companies to delay until market conditions improve.

images.alt_text: Depositors should not be taking any risks with their savings, especially when interest rates have risen substantially in recent months.

site_title: Applied Materials to challenge ASML’s grip with new machines
summary: Applied Materials has introduced a new chipmaking machine, the Centura Sculpta, designed to reduce reliance on ASML Holding and lower production costs for ultra-powerful semiconductors. The machine uses an electrically activated chemical technique to complete multiple patterning, streamlining chip production and reducing waste. This move threatens to disrupt the lithography market dominated by ASML, potentially changing the way the industry manufactures chips and reducing the company's grip on the market.

images.alt_text: The Dutch technology company has initiated an internal investigation and tightened security controls after discovering the most recent incident
An artist's impression of the Applied Materials greenfield facility, which is expected to be completed in 2024.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CICT, MPACT, Sembmarine, Keppel DC Reit, CSE Global
summary: Stocks to watch on Wednesday, Feb 1, 2023, include CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) and Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust (MPACT), with CICT's DPU rising 2.7% year-over-year to S$0.0536, and MPACT's DPU remaining the same due to higher finance costs. Sembcorp Marine announced an extraordinary general meeting to vote on its proposed merger with Keppel's offshore and marine unit, while Keppel DC Reit posted a 4.8% year-on-year increase in DPU to S$0.05165.

site_title: Gold little changed as traders await Fed decision
summary: Gold prices remained nearly flat at $1,927.42 per ounce ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, which is expected to scale back rate hikes to 25 basis points from 50 bps in December. Investors refrained from taking big bets, benefiting from lower interest rates, which tend to be beneficial for bullion. Meanwhile, US labour costs slowed in the fourth quarter, and India's gold consumption fell 3% in 2022 due to high local prices.

images.alt_text: Ingots of 99.99 percent pure gold are placed in a workroom at Krastsvetmet precious metals plant in the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, Russia, January 31, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk

site_title: Excelsior Hotel and shopping complex up for collective sale at S$458 million
summary: The Excelsior Hotel and shopping complex in Singapore is up for collective sale at a reserve price of S$458 million. The 99 strata-titled commercial units and hotel with 284 rooms are being sold based on a proposed land use of 60% hotel and 40% commercial. The sale is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the projected recovery of Singapore's hospitality sector following the reopening of borders.

site_title: Credit Suisse to move private funds group to First Boston unit
summary: Credit Suisse plans to move its Private Funds Group, a business that raises funds for buyout firms, to its rebranded First Boston unit later this year. The group, which operates globally, will be shifted to focus on capital markets, advisory, and leveraged finance businesses. The move is part of Credit Suisse's efforts to reshape its investment bank after losses. First Boston will be a partnership model, with key employees having ownership, and the Swiss bank has secured a $500 million investment commitment.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse has seen a slew of senior departures across Asia and Europe as it’s undertaking a sweeping overhaul of its business following years of scandals and management missteps.

site_title: Japan's biggest ad agency indicted in growing Olympics scandal
summary: Japan's largest advertising agency, Dentsu Group, and five other companies have been indicted for allegedly violating an anti-monopoly law in a corruption scandal over bid-rigging during the Tokyo Olympics. The indictment follows the arrest of a senior Tokyo 2020 organising committee official and others accused of rigging Olympic Games-related tenders. Seven company executives and officials are also named in the indictment, accused of colluding to restrict each other's business activities and limiting competition. The cases have cast a shadow over Japan's bid for the 2030 Winter Games.

images.alt_text: The IOC has said a boycott would violate the Olympic Charter and its inclusion of Russians and Belarusians is based on a UN resolution against discrimination within the Olympic movement.
Brisbane will become the third Australian city to host the Summer Olympics, after Melbourne in 1956 and Sydney in 2000.

site_title: Fixed income is attractive, but be wary of ‘fake’ yield
summary: Higher policy rates have made cash a competitive asset, reversing the yield scarcity of the 2010s. As central banks took action to contain high inflation, cash became a more attractive option, prompting an overdue de-rating of risk assets. However, higher sovereign bond yields and wider credit spreads created an abundance of yield, highlighting the distinction between attractive yields and lower risk. Investors must approach fixed income with caution, as higher rates make the operating environment more difficult.

images.alt_text: Fed chair Jerome Powell made clear that the impact of 450 basis points of tightening since March will have a lagging negative impact on the economy, adding that he sees signs of disinflation.
Credit-worthy companies have found in the past that they can raise funds more cheaply in investment-grade bond markets.

site_title: CICT’s H2 DPU up 2.7% to S$0.0536; market watchers mostly optimistic despite earnings miss
summary: CICT's half-year distribution per unit (DPU) rose 2.7% to S$0.0536, driven by contributions from recently acquired interests in Singapore and Australia, as well as higher rental income from most Singapore assets. The real estate investment trust's (Reit) H2 FY2022 DPU was slightly lower than consensus estimates due to higher financing expenses. Despite the earnings miss, analysts remain optimistic, citing a positive picture on Singapore's retail sector and potential redevelopment opportunities. CICT's net property income rose 13.1% year-on-year to S$541.7 million, and the trust's aggregate portfolio property value increased by 8.9% year-on-year to S$24.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong-listed Link Reit won the race to acquire Jurong Point and Swing By @ Thomson Plaza for S$2.16 billion.
The publicly accessible Sky Garden on Level 51 of the Capita Spring integrated development offers a 360-degree view of the surroundings, and is also home to Singapore’s tallest urban farm.

site_title: Sheng Siong H2 profit down 1.4% to S$65.9m, eyes new store openings
summary: Sheng Siong Group reported a net profit of S$65.9 million for the second half of 2022, down 1.4% from the same period in 2021. The company's full-year earnings rose 0.4% to S$133.3 million, driven by higher margins and increased store count in Singapore. Despite a decline in revenue, Sheng Siong eyes new store openings, particularly in China and Singapore, to tap into the growing demand for value-for-money products. The company also plans to enhance internal performance and increase productivity to mitigate the impact of inflation.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Generic photo of condos and private properties
Sheng Siong disclosed its China operations - all in Kunming - contributed 2.6 per cent of total revenue of S$333.5 million for Q3FY2022.

site_title: Europe: Shares post biggest weekly fall of 2023 as rate hike fears return
summary: European shares fell 1% on Friday, ending the week with their largest drop of 2023, amid fears of ongoing interest rate hikes. The Stoxx 600 index was influenced by hotter-than-expected US inflation data, which raised concerns about the Federal Reserve's future rate decisions. Despite a GfK survey indicating German consumer sentiment will improve for a fifth consecutive month due to falling energy prices, investors remain cautious about the impact of central bank actions.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1 per cent on Thursday.
IAG announced last August it had taken a 20 per cent stake in Air Europa after converting a loan.

site_title: Malaysia’s largest-ever budget is a prudent one with a ‘populist’ flavour
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim unveiled a record RM388.1 billion budget, the country's largest ever, with a focus on sustainable growth, fighting corruption, and reducing social inequality. The budget includes measures such as a tax on luxury goods, tax reduction for middle-wage earners, and higher taxes for the wealthy. Analysts describe the budget as "prudent" but lacking a "spark" to jumpstart the economy, with some criticizing the lack of comprehensive measures on climate change and net-zero emissions. The government aims to narrow its fiscal deficit to 5% of GDP this year.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister and Finance Minister Anwar Ibrahim holds the 2023 Malaysia's budget document at the Finance Ministry building as he departs to the Parliament on Feb 24, 2023.

site_title: Majority of global asset managers still not investing responsibly: ShareAction
summary: Majority of global asset managers, controlling $60 trillion in assets, have "serious gaps" in their responsible investment policies and practices, according to ShareAction. Two-thirds of 77 surveyed managers failed to assess and prevent negative impacts on nature or include Scope 3 emissions in climate targets. Despite efforts to promote sustainable finance, the industry still lags in investing responsibly, with only 13th-ranked JP Morgan Asset Management showing significant improvement. The proportion of poorly performing managers decreased from 51% in 2020 to 35% in 2023.

images.alt_text: The European Union and the United States are raising the stakes with massive green subsidies and a pro-green business push, but the UK has yet to follow suit.

site_title: Thailand sees 2.14 million foreign visitors in January as tourism rebounds
summary: Thailand welcomed 2.14 million foreign visitors in January, a slight increase from the previous month, driven by the return of travelers from China after Beijing lifted Covid-19 restrictions. The country saw a surge in arrivals from 133,828 in January 2022, with top source markets being Malaysia, Russia, and South Korea. Tourism is a key driver of Thailand's economy, accounting for 12% of its annual GDP. The government forecasts over 30 million foreign arrivals this year, with a further boost from China's reopening, expected to bring 7-8 million Chinese visitors.

images.alt_text: Thailand is the world’s third-largest rice exporter after India and Vietnam.
Domestic spending has increased and the government will accelerate large project investment to help growth, the minister told a Radio Thailand programme.

site_title: James Dyson taps top DBS banker Tan Su Shan to advise US$16 billion empire
summary: James Dyson has appointed Tan Su Shan, DBS' group head of institutional banking, as a director for his holding company Weybourne Holdings. The appointment is one of the most high-profile for Dyson's holding company, and Tan joins other directors including Singapore Airlines' former chairperson and a member of Singapore's richest families. Tan will oversee Dyson's investments spanning real estate, farming, and venture capital, with the company receiving over £2 billion in dividends and capital transfers since 2019.

images.alt_text: A timeline of Dyson Singapore's growth journey
Dyson goes on hiring drive in the UK and South-east Asia

site_title: Sri Lanka delays first vote since new president
summary: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe has indefinitely postponed local polls, citing the economic crisis as a reason for not funding the vote. The polls, scheduled for March 9, would have chosen local councillors and were seen as a referendum on Wickremesinghe's austerity measures. Wickremesinghe warned parliament that holding an election during the crisis could be disastrous, and the election commission agreed to postpone the vote after the president refused to provide necessary funding and logistical support.

images.alt_text: Opposition activists attacking police during a protest to get the government to hold local council elections on March 9. The election commission says it does not have funds to hold the polls.

site_title: EC World Reit Q4 DPU down 59.1% to S$0.00628
summary: EC World Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 59.1% to S$0.00628 for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2022, due to a decline in gross revenue to S$28.4 million, a 11% drop from the previous year. Despite this, executive director Goh Toh Sim attributed the resilience of "quality assets" to challenging operating conditions in FY2022.

After the release of funds, EC World Reit’s margin deposit as at Feb 11 stands at about 1.1 million yuan, which continues to be held in escrow.

The first batch of China Rse onshore C-Reits, with an aggregate value of 31.2 trillion yuan (about S$6 billion), hold infrastructure assets ranging from toll roads and waste treatment plants to logistics and industrial parks. 
Since 2021, the C-Reit market has grown exponentially, raising a total capital of more than 75 billion yuan, or more than S$15 billion, with the listing of 24 infrastructure and rental housing Reits as of December 2022.

site_title: SoftBank, Ant seek to sell Paytm stake via open market: ET
summary: SoftBank and Ant Group are seeking to sell their stakes in Indian digital payments firm Paytm in the open market, following the company's dismal listing in 2021. The companies had approached Bharti Airtel to sell their stakes, but talks were unsuccessful. Ant Group owns 25% of Paytm, while SoftBank owns 13%. A secondary sale to financial investors is still a possibility. Paytm's shares have tumbled 70% below their IPO price, and its parent company, One 97 Communications, has been under pressure to turn profitable.

site_title: mm2 Asia announces new concert unit, to transfer shares in UnUsUaL Limited
summary: mm2 Asia, a film producer and distributor, has announced the establishment of a new concert unit, mmLive, to promote and organize concerts and entertainment acts. As part of the move, mm2 Asia will transfer its entire shareholding in UnUsUaL Limited, a concert unit, to mmLive. The demand for live events in Asia has grown significantly in recent years, according to mm2 Asia executive chairman Melvin Ang, who cited the ongoing upward trend despite recessionary fears. The company has signed a non-binding letter of intent to invest in Hong Kong concert company Unipact Entertainment and Production.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The silver screen appears to have lost some of its appeal as a crowd puller. How does this change the way mall operators try to draw the crowds?

“The successful signing of this exchangeable bond deal indicates the confidence and belief in the strong recovery and fundamentals of our cinema business and the mm2 group in general,” said Melvin Ang, executive chairman of mm2 Asia.

site_title: China’s Sinopec says it shuts Zhenhai refinery partially for overhaul
summary: China's Sinopec Group has shut a portion of its Zhenhai refinery in Ningbo for a three-month overhaul, starting February 20. The refinery's No. 1 crude distillation unit, with a capacity of 160,000 barrels per day, and several derivative petrochemical units will be shut for maintenance. The overhaul involves the older section of the refinery.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Sinopec logo is seen at one of its gas stations in Hong Kong April 26, 2010.  REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo

site_title: NSL H2 net profit falls 43% to S$4.9 million on impairment loss
summary: NSL's net profit for the second half of 2022 fell 43% to S$4.9 million due to an impairment loss on an investment in German lifting-equipment maker Salzgitter Maschinenbau. Revenue rose 45% to S$194.8 million, driven by improvements in selling prices and project volumes. The board proposed a final dividend of five Singapore cents per share, unchanged from the previous year. Net profit for the full year ended December 31, 2022, more than doubled to S$10.7 million.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
The improvement comes on the back of a 39 per cent increase in group turnover to S$174.9 million, as revenue increased across all its business segments.

site_title: Prada brings blooming flowers to designs at Milan Fashion Week
summary: Italian designer label Prada showcased its autumn/winter 2023-24 collection at Milan Fashion Week, featuring blooming flowers on skirts, shoes, and from the ceiling. The collection included wedding dress-inspired everyday looks, utility suits turned into long shirt dresses, and colorful printed dresses. Models wore stick-out shoulders, colorful inside collars, and pastel-colored cigarette trousers. The collection also featured puffer jackets, asymmetrical mini skirts, and duffel coats in dark and pastel shades. The show marked a transition to the next generation of the founding family, with new CEO Andrea Guerra at the helm.

images.alt_text: “Growth like that of 2022 was exceptional,” reflecting a boost after the pandemic, said fashion chamber head Carlo Capasa.

site_title: Mistral: The topless car at the top of Bugatti’s world
summary: Bugatti's new Mistral open-top car is its first in a decade, featuring a 16-cylinder W16 engine producing 1600 horsepower. As a limited-edition model, the Mistral is expected to be a valuable investment, with only 99 units produced. According to Bugatti, its ultra-wealthy customers view these cars as a store of wealth, rather than a quick flip. The brand's gatekeeping process and clause in sales contracts discourage quick flipping, and Bugatti research suggests the average Mistral buyer is worth over $500 million.

images.alt_text: The Porsche Automobil Holding debut follows a record number of investment-grade firms issuing such debt last year, helping the market to a total 33 billion euros of sales.

site_title: Amazon taps T-Mobile, wireless carriers to sell private 5G to businesses
summary: Amazon's AWS is partnering with T-Mobile, Deutsche Telekom, KDDI, Orange, and Telefonica to offer private 5G wireless networks to businesses, replacing traditional Wi-Fi. This move aims to capitalize on the growing adoption of 5G technology, which provides precise location and low latency, enabling advanced uses such as autonomous robots. The partnership seeks to increase revenue and expand AWS' cloud services, with Amazon's business delivering most of its profit.

images.alt_text: Zoox, which Amazon acquired in 2020 for an undisclosed sum, is racing a collection of startups, including General Motors’s Cruise, to deploy robotaxis.
For the time being, the company has closed some grocery shops and impaired certain assets.
Amazon has paused expansion of its Fresh supermarkets and cashier-less convenience stores until it finds the right recipe for success, chief executive Andy Jassy said on Thursday.

site_title: China coal mine disaster may hit supply just as demand recovers
summary: A deadly coal mine collapse in Inner Mongolia, China, has left two dead and over 50 missing, raising concerns about the country's ability to supply fuel for its economic recovery. The incident, which could be the worst of its kind in years, has prompted President Xi Jinping to call for an all-out rescue effort and probe into its causes. As demand for coal is expected to rise due to a sustained recovery in power consumption, the disaster may disrupt supply just as the market is starting to recover, potentially affecting China's economic growth.

images.alt_text: The company logo adorns the side of the BHP gobal headquarters in Melbourne on February 21, 2023. - The Australian multinational, a leading producer of metallurgical coal, iron ore, nickel, copper and potash, said net profit slumped 32 percent year-on-year to 6.46 billion US dollars in the six months to December 31. (Photo by William WEST / AFP)

site_title: World Bank touts an ESG bond it says is ‘immune’ to greenwashing
summary: The World Bank has issued a unique five-year bond, dubbed an "outcome-based" or "impact bond," that is designed to be immune from greenwashing concerns. The $50 million bond will fund the manufacture of 300,000 water purifiers for 2 million children in Vietnam, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and generating verified carbon units. Investors will receive semi-annual coupon payments linked to these VCUs, rather than traditional coupon payments. The deal is seen as a promising development in the growing market for carbon as an asset class, with asset managers expressing interest in similar deals.

images.alt_text: David Malpass announced his resignation from the bank on Wednesday amid mounting pressure from the US Treasury to move faster on reforming the bank.

Climate activists had called for David Malpass to be ousted for what they said was an inadequate approach to the climate crisis and the chorus grew louder after his appearance at a New York Times-organised conference last September.

site_title: China’s Sinopec completes test runs at Hainan ethylene plant
summary: Sinopec Group has completed trial runs at a 1 million tonnes-per-year ethylene plant in Hainan, China, boosting exports. The facility is part of a $5.6 billion complex and aims to process different types of crude oil, developed with in-house ethylene technology. The plant will account for half of its production by 2025, with exports of downstream petrochemical products expected to increase. This is the second major petrochemical plant launched by Sinopec this year, following a similar facility announced by PetroChina last week.

site_title: Global miner BHP eyes brightening outlook in China as profit slumps
summary: BHP, the world's largest listed miner, reported a 32% year-on-year decline in first-half profit to $6.46 billion due to a drop in iron-ore prices. However, the company expects "markedly higher" price floors for some commodities and a brighter outlook in China, its largest customer, as the country reopens and revives its economy. Despite a 40% decline in its interim dividend, BHP's shares recovered slightly, beating analyst estimates, and the company announced plans to sell two coal mines in Queensland.

images.alt_text: China’s stepped-up policy support for its ailing property sector and dismantling of strict Covid-19 restrictions had pushed iron ore and steel prices to multi-month highs in January.

The headquarters of Glencore International AG stand in Baar, Switzerland, on Tuesday, Mar. 1, 2011. Glencore International AG, the largest commodities trader, may become only the third company to qualify for early entry to the FTSE 100 Index, potentially boosting demand for the stock from index-tracking funds. Photographer: Gianluca Colla/Bloomberg

Miners are increasingly reliant on computing heft to manage tasks such as automated truck fleets, and using artificial intelligence to delve into reams of data and discover the next big deposit, said BHP chief technology officer Laura Tyler.

site_title: Thai farmers tap into sustainable rubber industry
summary: Thai farmers are adopting sustainable methods to produce natural rubber, reducing the environmental impact of the industry. Wanida Hityim, a 41-year-old farmer, has received the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) certificate, which encourages sustainable forest use. By abandoning pesticides, farmers like Wanida are selling their rubber at a higher price, earning around $650 a month. However, the industry still faces challenges, with only 2% of Thailand's plantations worked under FSC guidelines. The European Union's ban on importing rubber contributing to deforestation is seen as a step towards sustainability, but China's lack of emphasis on sustainability may limit its impact.

images.alt_text: Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha says he will dissolve parliament in March.
Thailand uses the fund to support subsidies and manage oil prices in a bid to slow inflation that hit a 24-year high last year.

site_title: Private equity not insulated from macro risks, but asset class has shown resilience: Azalea
summary: Azalea Investment Management, behind the Astrea PE bonds, notes that private equity (PE) investments are not insulated from macroeconomic risks, but have shown resilience compared to public markets. Despite heightened risks in 2022, including supply chain disruptions, high inflation, and rising interest rates, PE returns have held up better than public markets. The asset class has a lower valuation multiple, providing a buffer when listed stock valuations decline. Azalea aims to make PE more accessible to retail investors through a "phased approach," but regulatory changes are needed to allow retail investors to invest in PE funds.

site_title: Watchfinder cuts prices 15% as Rolex and Patek Philippe values slide
summary: Watcheseller Watchfinder has cut prices by 15% due to declining valuations of used Rolex and Patek Philippe models. Supply has increased significantly, with dealers and investors flooding the market with previously sought-after watches. The drop is attributed to slowing economic growth, higher interest rates, and the collapse of cryptocurrencies. Despite the price correction, Watchfinder's average selling price remains around £7,000. The company is expanding its trading platform to compete with Chrono24 and eBay.

images.alt_text: Luxury watches on the secondary market declined 8 per cent in value last year, an index compiled by research platform WatchCharts found.

site_title: Smart money is on Singapore Airlines to build on its stellar results
summary: Singapore Airlines reported record interim financial results, beating analysts' forecasts "significantly" with a net profit of S$628 million and a quarterly top line of S$4.8 billion. The airline's passenger traffic rose 12.2% in the October-December quarter, driven by robust demand for air travel in the post-pandemic era. Despite operating below pre-pandemic capacity, SIA has the capacity to ramp up flights and reward shareholders with a bumper dividend, with analysts expecting the company to redeem its mandatory convertible bonds before they mature in 2030.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The International Civil Aviation Organization expects passenger demand to recover to pre-Covid levels on most routes this quarter and then to about 3 per cent higher than 2019 levels by year-end.
China’s move to reopen borders with Hong Kong, coupled with pent-up demand to travel for the Chinese New Year break, has fuelled the surge in passengers.
Global passenger demand is expected to recover to pre-pandemic levels on most routes in 2023, placing even more pressure on the stretched industry.

site_title: HSBC says greenwash risks have potential to impede market access
summary: HSBC has identified "greenwashing" as a potential risk that could impede market access due to the increasing scrutiny of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) claims. The bank has set itself a net-zero target of up to $1 trillion by 2030 and is monitoring "physical risk" and "transition risk" tied to climate change. Other banks, such as NatWest and Standard Chartered, are also taking steps to address greenwashing risks, including training staff and integrating greenwashing risks into their reputational and sustainability risk frameworks.

images.alt_text: The greenwashing allegation, which Shell denies, adds to efforts to heap pressure on some of the world’s biggest polluting companies as regulators take an increasing interest in climate change.
In an updated statement on ESG reporting, the UK watchdog said in 2023 it will focus on the use of ESG data and the link between investors and ESG reporting by companies.

site_title: Chinese banks hold rates as analysts bet easing to come
summary: Chinese banks maintained benchmark lending rates unchanged, with the one-year loan prime rate at 3.65% and the five-year rate at 4.3%, for a sixth consecutive month. Analysts expect possible reductions in the coming months to support the economic recovery, citing signs of a faster-than-expected recovery following the scrapping of Covid restrictions. However, challenges to growth, including a property downturn and weakening exports, may lead the People's Bank of China to cut interest rates and lower bank loan rates in the future.

images.alt_text: Global investors have been reducing their holdings of Chinese government bonds, a source of secure returns during the pandemic years, as they seek juicier returns from stock markets in the reopened economy.
The two regulators say implementation of the new rules will leave capital adequacy ratios in the banking sector generally unchanged, though the ratios for some banks would change slightly.

site_title: China central bank to encourage increased lending to private enterprises
summary: China's central bank plans to encourage increased lending to private enterprises to support the economy. The People's Bank of China will promote loans to micro and small businesses and rental housing, aiming to support steady growth and prevent financial risks. The move follows a slowdown in China's growth in 2022, attributed to harsh Covid measures and a property sector crisis. The central bank will also push for the overhaul of platform companies' financial businesses and deepen the opening of financial markets.

site_title: Oil dives US$3/barrel, heads for weekly loss on Federal Reserve worries, ample supply
summary: Oil prices plummeted by over US$3 per barrel, with Brent crude futures down 2.6% to US$82.93, and WTI crude down 2.9% to US$76.24, due to Federal Reserve worries about future interest rate hikes and signs of ample global supply. This is headed for a weekly decline of over 4%. Russian oil producers plan to maintain current export volumes, and US crude inventories rose to a 19-month high, further weighing on the market.

images.alt_text: The Paris-based watchdog echoed similar views from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, which this week raised its 2023 global oil demand growth forecast on Chinese demand growth.

site_title: Alibaba’s US$46 billion wipe-out tests investor support
summary: Alibaba's share price has plummeted by $46 billion over the past three weeks, raising concerns about the strength of the Chinese economy and the company's future growth. Despite months of gains driven by hedge funds and analyst upgrades, Alibaba's quarterly earnings are expected to show only slight revenue growth. Analysts attribute the decline to profit-taking and investors' desire to see Alibaba's management address the speed of China's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Paytm, which is also backed by China’s Ant Group and Japan’s SoftBank Group, has been under pressure to turn profitable ever since its dismal listing in November 2021.
The PBOC urged fund managers to comprehensively and prudently assess the impact of such major money market funds on investors, the broad capital markets and the financial system.

site_title: As Miami high-rises loom over financial district, local resident digs in
summary: A Miami resident, Ishmael Bermudez, is fighting to preserve historical relics uncovered during construction in the city's financial district. Bermudez, an artist and amateur archaeologist, discovered fossils, human remains, and sculptures under his home, which he handed over to local authorities. Community groups and archaeologists are joining him in advocating for preservation, citing the lack of historical significance in Miami's past. Bermudez calls for developers to work with the community, saying "we have to make sure that this don't get destroyed."

images.alt_text: Egyptian architect and heritage management expert May al-Ibrashy says:"We noticed that the older generations knew a lot more about the monuments and had a much deeper connection to them, because they had all these childhood memories that today’s children didn’t."
An anthropologist shows the skull of a soldier who fought in the Battle of Waterloo in 1815.

site_title: Resurgent China will drive 2023 oil demand but deficit could loom: IEA
summary: China's relaxed Covid-19 curbs are expected to drive 2023 oil demand growth, accounting for nearly half of the year's increase. However, a supply deficit could occur in the second half due to restrained OPEC+ production, particularly from Russia under international sanctions. Despite sanctions, Russia's oil exports were only down 160,000 barrels per day in January. Around 1 million barrels per day of production will be shut in by the end of the first quarter due to European and international sanctions.

site_title: Cheek by Jowl ex-head chef returns with semi fine-dining eatery on Leng Kee Road
summary: Chef Jay Teo returns with semi-fine dining eatery Full Circle by J. Man in Thye Hong Centre, Leng Kee Road, Singapore. The restaurant offers a menu inspired by Singaporean flavors, with dishes such as oyster cream-filled brioche rolls, obsiblue prawn in coconut cream sauce, and grilled pomfret with pearl oyster in a potato nest. Tasting menus are available, with dinner priced at S$168. The food is quietly confident, modern-leaning, but driven by an unapologetic Singaporean palate, with some dishes veering slightly off-key. The restaurant's no-fuss atmosphere and wine pairing options are also notable.

site_title: Airbus says it lacks orders to boost output of Eurofighter jets
summary: Airbus's defense unit chief, Michael Schoellhorn, stated that the company lacks orders to boost production of Eurofighter jets due to governments' reluctance to commit to contracts. Despite a push for accelerated production, Airbus has yet to see sufficient orders to ramp up output. Production of Eurofighters could take longer due to the industry's adaptation to low demand, while Airbus expects increased interest in its drones and space defense products, such as satellite imagery, in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Airbus confirmed it would, however, increase A330neo wide-body output to 4 a month in 2024 from around 3 now.
Founded under Tata in the 1930s, Air India is attempting to win back traffic from Emirates and Qatar Airways.
In a note to employees on Jan 27, the airline said it was “finalising a historic order for new aircraft”.

site_title: US actress Raquel Welch dies at 82: manager
summary: US actress Raquel Welch, known for her iconic deerskin bikini appearance in "One Million Years BC," died on Wednesday at 82 after a brief illness, according to her manager. A five-decade-long film and television career, including starring roles in "Fantastic Voyage" and "The Three Musketeers," earned her a Golden Globe award. Details of her illness were not provided.

images.alt_text: Burt Bacharach (right) with Irish pop star Ronan Keating. Keating's 2011 album titled "When Ronan Met Burt" was a collaboration with Bacharach.
That rather paltry total for the Warner Bros film, Magic Mike’s Last Dance starring Channing Tatum and Salma Hayek was doubtless hurt by National Football League’s Super Bowl.

site_title: Sias urges Boustead Singapore to raise offer price for Boustead Projects
summary: Sias urges Boustead Singapore to raise its offer price for Boustead Projects to S$1.265 per share, citing the offer as "unattractive" and undervaluing minority shareholders. The current offer price of S$0.90 is 71.1% of the company's NAV and has been deemed too low by analysts. Sias suggests a middle ground should be found, with an offer price on par with the NAV, as the current offer significantly undervalues the investment.

images.alt_text: Wong Fong Fui, chairman and group chief executive officer of Boustead Singapore. The company’s S$0.90 per share offer translates to a premium of 7.8 per cent over Boustead Projects’ last traded price per share of S$0.835 on the Singapore Exchange on Feb 3.

site_title: Genting Singapore H2 net profit more than doubles to S$255.7 million on travel recovery momentum
summary: Genting Singapore's net profit for the six months ended December 31, 2022, more than doubled to S$255.7 million, driven by increased gaming and non-gaming revenue from a travel recovery in Singapore. Revenue more than doubled to S$1.1 billion, with gaming revenue rising over 100% to S$753.7 million and non-gaming revenue more than doubling to S$307.8 million. The company remains cautiously optimistic for a full recovery in the medium term, despite flight capacity and economic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Analysts are expecting Genting Singapore to be a key beneficiary of an influx of tourists following China’s reopening.
Genting Singapore's gaming revenue rose 96 per cent on-year to S$382 million, while non-gaming revenue climbed to S$137.3 million from S$56.2 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: Sneaker wonderland
summary: The ArtScience Museum in Singapore is hosting Sneakertopia, an exhibition featuring over 100 limited-edition sneakers and 70 artworks inspired by sneaker culture. The show includes rare and priceless sneakers, such as the Supreme Nike SB Lunar Dunk Hi and Louis Vuitton Nike Air Force 1, valued at over $1 million. The exhibition also features personal collections from well-known figures, including JJ Lin and Mandeep Chopra, and artworks by notable artists. The show runs from February 25 to July 30, offering a unique celebration of sneakers, street culture, and contemporary art.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Parting is such sweet spectacle: A collector sells his Hirst, Koons and Calder
summary: Art collector and dealer Adam Lindemann is selling his collection of over 40 contemporary art pieces, including works by living artists like Andy Warhol and Damien Hirst, at Christie's auction house on March 9. Lindemann, 61, is making no secret of the sale, which he says is his first major public spectacle in a decade. He has owned many of the pieces for over 20 years and feels it's time to part with them. The sale will include works by artists like Alexander Calder, Takashi Murakami, and Jean Royere, with estimates ranging from $1 million to $7 million. Some market experts have questioned Lindemann's decision to sell, citing concerns that the prices of some artists may be on the downswing. However, Lindemann says he has helped artists' careers and is looking to fund a major gift to the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Michael C. Rockefeller wing.

images.alt_text: Large Interior W11, which Freud painted between 1981-1983, carried a US$75 million presale estimate at Christie’s on Wednesday  night.
The painting in question, Verger avec Cyprès (1888), depicts a pastel-hued spring day.
The two-day sale in New York comes as experts say the super wealthy are viewing art as a safe investment this year amid a tumultuous global economy and Russia’s war in Ukraine.
Allen, who died in 2018 at the age of 65, co-founded Microsoft with Bill Gates in 1975.
Aggregate sales of art and antiques by dealers and auction houses reached an estimated US$65.1 billion, surpassing the pre-pandemic levels of 2019.

site_title: Promising Thai-style at Chedi
summary: Restaurant Chedi, a modern Thai restaurant in Singapore's Jalan Besar neighbourhood, offers a refreshing take on traditional Thai dishes. The restaurant's dishes, such as salt-fish fried rice, Isaan-style grilled pork, and spicy pumpkin soup, showcase a strong sense of originality. However, some dishes, like the blue-hued jellied waterchestnut and coconut ice cream dessert, fall short. Overall, Chedi lends shine to its neighbourhood with tasteful interiors and authentic Thai flavors.

images.alt_text: The colourful interiors of Ms. Maria and Mr. Singh.

site_title: Next change: As anchor tenants evolve, so must mall operators
summary: Singapore's iconic Cathay Cineplex, a 1939 cinema, closed due to declining appeal as a crowd puller. Cinemas, once a staple in shopping malls, have lost their appeal as streaming services gain popularity. Analysts say malls must adapt by offering unique experiences, such as community clubs and services centers, to draw crowds. Market observers suggest losing cinemas and large department stores as anchor tenants could lead to lower rental rates and increased competition for retail landlords. CapitaLand is transforming Clarke Quay into a day-and-night destination with lifestyle and F&B offerings, while mm2 Asia sees a 71% rise in revenue from its cinema segment, but still faces a net loss.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

A Cineworld cinema in London. The world's No. 2 cinema operator had a net debt of US$8.9 billion as at the end of 2021. Excluding lease liabilities, Cineworld’s net debt was US$4.84 billion at end-2021, and it had cash of US$354 million.
Ari Emanuel, co-founder of 1 of the world’s largest talent agencies, strongly disagrees with folks who think cinemas will disappear.
An Imax spokesperson declined to give a projection on how Avatar: The Way Of Water could perform, but said the company was “very optimistic.”.

site_title: Will Singapore’s fine dining scene go the way of Noma? Top chefs weigh in
summary: Singapore's fine dining scene is not expected to follow the same path as Noma, with top chefs expressing concerns about the viability of the fine-dining business model. Despite Noma's closure, Singapore's high-end restaurants remain financially stable, with many citing strong business plans and adaptability as key to survival. Chefs emphasize the importance of paying staff well, managing expectations, and ensuring work-life balance to maintain a sustainable industry. The abundance of affluent diners in Singapore is seen as a positive factor, but also acknowledges that high labor costs and overheads are a challenge.

site_title: Budget 2023 aims to reposition Singapore’s resilience for a new era
summary: Singapore's Budget 2023 aims to reposition the country for a new era of resilience and prosperity in a changing world. The budget focuses on retooling the economy for resilience, doubling down on innovation, and providing continued focus on sustainability. Key measures include a S$3 billion Goods and Service Tax (GST) Assurance Package, a new Enterprise Innovation Scheme, and a S$1 billion boost to the Singapore Global Enterprises initiative. The government also plans to strengthen its social compact, boosting social spending and enhancing social mobility, while maintaining a fair and efficient tax system.

site_title: Fallout of crypto stablecoin regulation spills over to decentralised finance sector
summary: The fallout from the US regulator's pressure on Paxos to halt issuing new BUSD stablecoins is spilling over into the decentralized finance (DeFi) sector. The shutdown of BUSD, the third-largest stablecoin by market value, is raising concerns about the fate of other stablecoins like USDC, which is operated by Circle Internet Financial. DeFi advocates are warning that regulators could target USDC, potentially damaging the sector. As a result, some DeFi projects, such as Curve Finance, are considering adjusting their BUSD holdings or freezing lending markets.

images.alt_text: Crypto markets have since held mostly steady after an initial drop, as investors grappled with the implications of the development.

site_title: New Zealand inflation expectations drop before RBNZ rate review
summary: New Zealand's inflation expectations dropped to 3.3% for the first quarter, easing from a 31-year high of 3.62% in the fourth quarter. This shift prompted investors to reduce bets on a jumbo interest rate hike from the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) next week. Economists still predict a 50-point hike, but the likelihood has decreased from 50% to 30%. The RBNZ reviews its Official Cash Rate on February 22.

site_title: Budget 2023: S$2 billion deficit in FY22, S$0.4 billion deficit for FY23
summary: Singapore is expected to post a deficit of S$0.4 billion (0.1% of GDP) in FY2023, according to Finance Minister Lawrence Wong. This is in line with projected economic conditions for the year. The government does not plan to draw on past reserves, instead reducing the Contingencies Fund balance from S$6 billion to S$3 billion to maintain discipline in managing finances. The government will amend the Constitution to allow for reductions, with the bill to be tabled for its first reading later this month.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

site_title: Budget 2023: More support for low-income families and individuals
summary: The Singapore government has announced several measures to support lower-income individuals and seniors in its 2023 budget. Top-ups of S$500 million to the ElderCare Fund and S$1.5 billion to the MediFund will increase resources for seniors and lower-income individuals. Additionally, a S$300 million boost to the ComCare Endowment Fund will support social assistance schemes. The government will also expand childcare places and encourage charitable giving through tax deductions and a broader Corporate Volunteer Scheme.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Claudia Chong
A pregnant lady at the Raffles Place MRT station, 2 August 2022.
Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong arrives in Parliament to deliver this year's Budget statement.

site_title: The biggest penguin that ever existed was a ‘monster bird’
summary: Scientists have discovered two prehistoric penguins in New Zealand, including the massive Kumimanu, which weighed around 154.2 kg (340 lbs), making it the heaviest penguin known to science. The species lived around 60 million years ago and stood around 157 cm tall. Its primitive flippers suggest it retained features from its airborne ancestors. The discovery provides evidence that prehistoric penguins became larger before fine-tuning their flippers for diving. The two species, Kumimanu and Petradyptes, lived during a time when marine reptiles were wiped out, allowing penguins to thrive.

images.alt_text: The Antarctic sea ice, which is essential to the emperor penguins’ livelihood, is disappearing due to heat-trapping gases released by humans’ use of fossil fuels.

site_title: Heineken sees 2023 profit increase despite Europe weakness
summary: Heineken reported a higher-than-expected 2022 profit of 4.50 billion euros, driven by a recovery in beer drinking to pre-pandemic levels. Despite Europe's weakness, the brewer expects a profit increase in 2023, with operating profit expected to grow at a slower mid- to high-single-digit percentage rate. Heineken will pass on most of the extra costs due to energy and input price increases, but may use cost savings to mitigate potential losses in market share.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bottles of Heineken beer are seen at a super market during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Bangkok, Thailand, October 12, 2020. REUTERS/Soe Zeya Tun/File Photo

site_title: Oil edges higher as market weighs Russian supply cuts amid demand fears
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, rebounding from early losses, as investors weighed Russia's plans to cut crude production and short-term demand concerns ahead of US inflation data. Brent futures rose 22 US cents, or 0.3%, to $86.61 a barrel, while US crude rose 42 US cents, or 0.5%, to $80.14 a barrel. Russia's 500,000 barrel-per-day production cut is expected to alleviate supply concerns, with US shale crude oil production expected to rise to its highest on record in March.

images.alt_text: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies, including Russia, will meet in February to assess market conditions.

site_title: The future of fine dining
summary: Renowned chef-restaurateur Rene Redzepi announced the closure of his Copenhagen restaurant and the transformation into a food lab, sparking concerns about the future of fine dining due to high costs and thin profit margins. However, Singapore's top chefs argue that upscale dining is not yet doomed, citing the city-state's unique food scene and chefs' ability to innovate and adapt. Despite rising costs, Singapore's fine dining scene continues to thrive, with new restaurants and exhibitions emerging, suggesting that the "death of fine dining" may be premature.

site_title: Turkey’s earthquakes paralyse third of steel production capacity
summary: Turkey's steel production capacity is expected to remain idle for at least until the end of this month or possibly until mid-March due to the massive twin earthquakes that hit the region. The affected steel mills, accounting for a third of national output, are closed despite no physical damage, due to worker fatalities and survivors struggling in makeshift conditions. The industry's assessment of the toll is significant, with Bloomberg Economics estimating a 5.5% equivalent of gross domestic product in public spending required to address the aftermath.

images.alt_text: Leading global container shipping group AP Moller Maersk said there had been significant damage to logistics and transport infrastructure around the earthquake epicentre, including at the Port of Iskenderun.

site_title: Global bond investors’ biggest fear is coming true
summary: Global bond investors are concerned that Japan's cash flow out of international markets will increase due to the expected new governor of the Bank of Japan, Kazuo Ueda. Since his surprise appointment, local bond yields have risen, and Japanese investors have been selling overseas bonds worth $181 billion and buying domestic government bonds worth $304.5 billion. This shift is expected to continue, potentially destabilizing global debt markets if Ueda removes the BOJ's cap on yields, which could lead to higher Japanese yields and a return of cash from overseas assets.

images.alt_text: The heightened scrutiny over the investment plans of some of the world’s biggest fixed-income investors comes at a time when the global bond market is back under pressure.
FILE PHOTO: Passersby are silhouetted as they walk past in front of an electric stock quotation board outside a brokerage in Tokyo, Japan October 18, 2022  REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of Japanese yen and U.S. dollar are seen in this illustration picture taken September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: 'Enlightened tingle': Aussie cafe offers US$140 cup of coffee
summary: A Melbourne cafe, Proud Mary, is offering a cup of coffee, dubbed "Black Jaguar," for US$140, 50 times the price of a regular flat white. The coffee is grown in Panama's Chiriqui region and scored 96.5 out of 100 at the 2022 Best of Panama auction. Proud Mary owner Nolan Hirte described the experience as "out-of-body" and "enlightened," citing the coffee's complex flavor profile and high quality. Despite the high price, some coffee connoisseurs are willing to pay for the unique experience.

images.alt_text: This crop year's robusta beans are at “good levels” of quality and quantity, says one trader in Vietnam's so-called coffee belt.

site_title: Black chefs aim to restore New Orleans’ hidden history
summary: A new generation of Black chefs in New Orleans is working to restore the city's hidden history by shedding light on the role of enslaved West Africans in creating the city's famous cuisine. Dakar Nola, a restaurant co-founded by chef Serigne Mbaye and business partner Afua Richardson, serves dishes inspired by African and Caribbean traditions, challenging the "whitewashed" stories of the city's culinary past. The restaurant's emphasis on the influence of West Africans on New Orleans cuisine is part of a growing movement to redefine the city's culinary narrative and celebrate the contributions of Black residents.

images.alt_text: Diners toast at Brat in the Shoreditch neighborhood, in London, Dec. 28, 2022. ItÕs one of the worldÕs best cities for wine and you can find terrific lists in pubs, bars and all sorts of restaurants in almost any neighborhood. (Peter Flude/The New York Times)
View French inventions at the Iconic! exhibition.

site_title: UK's Camilla to wear Queen Mary's Crown at May coronation
summary: Queen Camilla will wear Queen Mary's Crown at her coronation alongside King Charles III on May 6, a first in recent history as an existing crown is being used instead of a new commission. The crown, over a century old, will be modified with several Cullinan diamonds to honor Queen Elizabeth II. The modification includes removing four of its eight detachable arches to create a new impression. The coronation will feature a star-studded concert, nationwide celebrations, and a volunteering initiative.

images.alt_text: A handout picture received from Britain's Royal Mail in London on February 7, 2023, shows the new King Charles III 1st class stamp. - Britain's Royal Mail on Wednesday unveiled the first postage stamps to feature the image of King Charles III, following his ascension to the throne last September. The new so-called "definitive stamp" -- intended for everyday use and consisting solely of the monarch's head and the stamp's value -- will go on general sale from April 4.
