site_title: Goldman’s CEO says business leaders are more optimistic on economy
summary: Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon stated that business leaders are more optimistic about the economy, shifting towards a "softer economic landing." This shift in sentiment comes after predictions of a possible US recession last year. Solomon attributed the change to improved forecasts and Goldman's efforts to address rising expenses and falling revenue. The bank has implemented a plan to cut 3,200 positions, marking its largest job reduction in history, in response to these challenges. Goldman plans to host an investor day on February 28.

images.alt_text: David Solomon, co-president and co-chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs Group Inc., smiles during a Bloomberg Television interview at the Goldman Sachs Technology and Internet Conference in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Wednesday, Feb. 14, 2018. Solomon will succeed Lloyd Blankfein as the firm's chief executive officer on Oct. 1, the bank said in a statement Tuesday. Blankfein will step down as chairman at the end of the year, when Solomon will also take on that role. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia, Malaysia to send palm oil envoys to EU over deforestation law
summary: Indonesia and Malaysia, the world's largest palm oil producers, plan to send envoys to the European Union to discuss the impact of the EU's new deforestation law on their palm oil sectors. The law, implemented in December, requires companies to provide due diligence statements on their commodities and risk hefty fines if they are produced on deforested land after 2020. The EU has denied discriminatory policies targeting palm oil, but environmentalists welcome the regulation as a step to protect forests responsible for 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Budget 2023: Top-ups to ElderCare, MediFund to support lower-income individuals, seniors
summary: The Singapore government has announced top-ups to its ElderCare Fund and MediFund to support lower-income individuals and seniors. The ElderCare Fund will receive S$500 million to support means-tested subsidies for seniors requiring home-based, centre-based, or institutional care. The MediFund will receive S$1.5 billion to strengthen the safety net for lower-income individuals and seniors facing medical bills. The move aims to address the growing need for elderly care in Singapore, which is expected to become one of the fastest-ageing nations in the world by 2030.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

ST20221215_202239441481/pixgeneric/Jason Quah
Generic photo of an elderly person in a wheelchair at Tiong Bahru Plaza on Dec 15, 2022.
healthcare, eldercare, mobility, caregiving

site_title: UK meal delivery group Deliveroo to cut 9% of jobs
summary: Deliveroo, a UK meal delivery company, plans to cut 350 jobs, or around 9% of its workforce, amid a slowdown in growth. The company aims to become profitable while facing tougher economic conditions. Founder and CEO Will Shu warned that the company needs to focus on profitability after breaking even in the second half of 2022. Deliveroo has been one of Britain's most high-profile success stories since the pandemic.

site_title: UK firms plan biggest pay rises since 2012 to fill staff gaps
summary: UK firms plan the largest pay rises since 2012, with median annual pay awards expected to reach 5%, the highest since CIPD records began in 2012. This is due to a tight labour market, with 55% of recruiters planning to lift base or variable pay to fill staff gaps. However, the expected pay deals still fall short of expected inflation, with the Bank of England expressing concerns about wage-setting. The public sector is expected to see a 2% pay rise, significantly lower than the 5% planned for the private sector.

images.alt_text: British living standards have been hammered by a surge in inflation, which hit a 41-year high of 11.1 per cent in October.

The Consumer Prices Index has leapt 11.1 per cent in October and then ticked down to 10.5 per cent in December. Official figures due on Wednesday (Feb 15) are likely to show it remained above 10 per cent in January.

site_title: Developers turn conservative in pricing approach to residential projects: poll
summary: Developers in Singapore are becoming more conservative in pricing residential projects amid rising inflation and interest rates, according to a survey by the National University of Singapore's Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies. In the fourth quarter, 71% of developers expected prices to maintain the same level, up from 33% in Q3, while 29% expected prices to be moderately higher. Concerns over job losses and the domestic economy are also impacting market sentiment, with 56.3% of developers citing these as potential risks, up from 32.4% in Q3.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
National Development Minister Desmond Lee highlighted that public housing affordability and accessibility cannot be solved with an oversupply of built-to-order flats.
PM Lee Hsien Loong said the government is working to ramp up the supply of flats, cool the resale market and keep flats affordable and accessible.

site_title: Disney explores the sale of more films and TV series to rivals
summary: Disney is exploring the sale of more films and TV series to rival media outlets as the company seeks to curb losses in its streaming TV business. The move follows pressure to improve financial performance, which led to the firing of CEO Bob Chapek and the return of Bob Iger, who will share his plans when the company reports financial results on Feb 8. Iger aims to redesign the company's organisational structure, prioritising creative executives and reducing personnel cuts, in an effort to reverse losses and improve performance.

images.alt_text: Nelson Peltz, who says Disney’s problems are primarily self-inflicted, has not given a detailed plan for achieving his goals.

site_title: Credit Suisse eyes US$380 million of awards for top staff
summary: Credit Suisse plans to grant its top executives up to US$380 million in long-term awards tied to specific financial targets, if its restructuring succeeds. The award is for around 500 senior managers, part of a broader effort to incentivize top staff amid annual bonus cuts. The restructuring aims to refocus the bank on wealth management and Swiss banking, with targets including a 6% return on tangible equity and cost savings. The proposal must be approved by shareholders at the annual meeting in April.

images.alt_text: The bank is seeking to cling on to talent contending with a restructuring of its Wall Street operations after a period of scandals and losses sparked a tide of departures

site_title: US trade deficit widens; goods exports at 10-month low
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $67.4 billion in December, reversing a 21.1% decline in November, as imports rebounded and exports of goods dropped to a 10-month low. Imports rose 1.3% to $317.6 billion, driven by consumer goods, while goods exports fell 0.9% to $250.2 billion, mainly due to declining crude oil prices. The trade deficit narrowed to a record $948.1 billion in 2022, with the economy's growth pace in the fourth quarter attributed to a smaller trade deficit.

site_title: Europe’s bond recovery falls at first hurdle after ECB high
summary: Europe's bond market has fallen at its first hurdle after European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde warned of underlying inflationary pressures. Despite the warning, traders initially reacted positively to her statement that the risks are now "more balanced". However, a strong US jobs report exposed the fragility of the rally, causing German bond yields to erase almost half of their day-before gains. ECB policymakers have signaled that another 50 basis-point rate hike is coming in March, and expectations for future hikes have increased slightly. Despite this, many investors remain optimistic about the bond market's prospects, with some predicting a lasting recovery in 2024.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 21, 2020 people wearing face masks walk in front of the euro sign at the former ECB headquarters in the city center of Frankfurt am Main, western Germany. - The European Central Bank is expected Thursday to unleash more stimulus to help shore up a eurozone economy devastated by the coronavirus pandemic, analysts said, in a move eagerly awaited by financial markets.

The Frankfurt institution already has a 1.35-trillion-euro ($1.6-trillion) emergency bond-buying programme in place, but ECB chief Christine Lagarde all but promised in October that extra support was on the way. (Photo by Yann Schreiber / AFP)

site_title: Exploring ‘black’ champagne
summary: "Black" champagne, also known as Blanc de Noirs, is a type of bubbly made from Pinot Noir and/or Pinot Meunier grapes, resulting in a clear juice that ferments separately and produces a white sparkling wine. The lack of skin contact during pressing prevents the dark colors from leaching into the liquid, giving it a characteristic white hue. Several prestigious Blanc de Noirs champagnes, such as Krug's Clos d'Ambonnay and Bollinger's Vieilles Vignes Francaises, showcase the unique characteristics of this style, with notes of red fruit, spices, and brioche.

site_title: Adani crisis ignites Indian contagion fears, credit warnings
summary: Adani Group, one of India's top conglomerates, faces a severe crisis after a Hindenburg Research report accused the group of stock manipulation and unsustainable debt. Despite Adani Group's rebuttals, shares have plummeted by over half their market value, totaling over $100 billion. Ratings agency Moody's warned the group may struggle to raise capital, while S&P cut its outlook on two Adani businesses to negative. The crisis has sparked concerns of financial contagion, with the Reserve Bank of India stating its banking system remains resilient.

images.alt_text: The seven listed Adani firms together have a market capitalisation of US$113 billion, versus US$218 billion before the Hindenburg report.
Gautam Adani is considered a close ally of India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and his business interests often align with the government’s growth goals.
A nationwide protest planned for Monday will also draw attention to Gautam Adani's links with Prime Minister Narendra Modi.

site_title: Michelin-starred restaurant Narisawa comes to Singapore for five-week pop-up
summary: Narisawa, a two-Michelin-starred Japanese restaurant, will host a five-week pop-up in Singapore in collaboration with Mandala Club and Porsche. Chef Yoshihiro Narisawa and his team will relocate to Singapore for the entire residency, offering a unique experience with modern Japanese cuisine that incorporates local ingredients. The menu will feature 50% of Narisawa's signature dishes from Tokyo, with some Singapore-specific dishes. Pricing starts at S$518 for lunch and S$748 for dinner, with optional sake and wine pairings available.

images.alt_text: The colourful interiors of Ms. Maria and Mr. Singh.

site_title: Singapore launches region’s largest energy storage system operated by Sembcorp
summary: Singapore has launched its largest energy storage system, operated by Sembcorp Industries, on Jurong Island. The system, spanning 2 hectares, has a maximum storage capacity of 285 megawatt hours and can meet the electricity needs of 24,000 four-room households for one day. Commissioned in six months, it is the fastest in the world of its size to be deployed, supporting Singapore's goal to decarbonize its power sector and tackle the challenge of weather-led intermittent solar energy.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
The facility has enough capacity to meet the daily electrical needs of nearly 17,000 four-room Housing and Development Board flats in a single discharge.

This will bring Jurong Island’s total solar energy capacity to 103.2 megawatt peak (MWp), an eightfold increase from the current 12.3 MWp generated from Jurong Island companies’ rooftop installations.
Greening the entire economy is said to be key to Singapore's transition to a sustainable economic model - and blended finance will play a crucial role. PHOTO: ST
If successful in scaling up the use of green hydrogen, Singapore's maritime, aviation and manufacturing sectors can tap low-carbon hydrogen and decarbonise.

site_title: Hot stock: Keppel Corp declines 5.1% after earnings fall
summary: Keppel Corporation's share price declined 5.1% after the group reported a 40.6% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$429.1 million for the second half ended December. Despite this, analysts maintained a positive outlook, citing strengths in Keppel's infrastructure, asset management, data centre, and M1 businesses. Analysts raised their target prices, with UOBKH predicting a 38.5% potential upside, and CGS-CIMB maintaining an "add" on the stock.

images.alt_text: Keppel's net profit for the second half ended December has declined by 40.6 per cent.
For the full year ended Dec 31, 2022, Keppel Corp’s net profit slipped 9 per cent to S$926.6 million,

site_title: Five global trends in business and society in 2023
summary: Five global trends in business and society in 2023 include climate change, income and wealth inequality, social instability, inflation and recession risks, and geopolitical crises. Climate change is cited as the top societal issue for businesses to address, with 18% of Insead faculty members ranking it as the biggest threat. Income and wealth inequality is the second-most important issue, with 18% of faculty members citing it as a critical societal issue. Social instability was cited as the biggest threat by 18% of faculty members, while inflation and recession risks were cited by 17%. Geopolitical crises were also identified as a major threat, with 25% of faculty members flagging it as the top threat.

images.alt_text: Global economic growth is set to slump in 2023, from an estimated 3.0 per cent in 2022 to 1.9 per cent this year, said the United Nations in its World Economic Situation and Prospects report.
The full impact of rate hikes can take a year or more to show up in economies.

site_title: Tokyo’s luxury sushi spots go casual with budget-friendly spinoffs
summary: Tokyo's luxury sushi spots are adapting to changing consumer preferences by introducing budget-friendly spinoffs, offering affordable omakase menus and standing sushi experiences. These new restaurants, such as Sushi Yuu Tsubasa and Touryumon Sushi Ginza Onodera, cater to younger diners and provide a more accessible alternative to traditional high-end sushi. The trend is also seen in the US, where high-end sushi restaurants like Sugarfish offer affordable lunch sets. This shift is partly driven by pandemic-related restrictions and a desire for high customer turnover.

images.alt_text: Butter-poached Maine lobster, American Osetra caviar, delicata squash raviolo, and tarragon sauce is presented during a media preview ahead of the state dinner in honour of French President Emmanuel Macron, in the State Dining Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on Nov 30, 2022.
In August, Virginia Beer released its malt liquor, 39 Words, a malt liquor made with flaked corn.
Teochew yu sheng drizzled with 98-year-old plum sauce.

site_title: CIA chief says China’s Xi a little sobered by Ukraine war
summary: CIA Director William Burns stated that China's President Xi Jinping maintains serious ambitions over Taiwan and warned that conflict over the island nation would be "deeply unfortunate" for all involved. Burns also noted that Xi has been a little sobered by the war in Ukraine, but it would be a mistake to underestimate Beijing's commitment to partnership with Russia.

images.alt_text: Blinken will visit Beijing on Feb 5-6, according to a US official, in the first trip by a secretary of state to the rising Asian power since October 2018.
Former US secretary of state Mike Pompeo said that US diplomats convinced both India and Pakistan that neither was preparing to use nuclear weapons against each other in 2019.
The action marks the latest round of US sanctions on Russia over the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Frasers Property posts pre-sold revenue of S$2.7 billion as at Dec 2022
summary: Frasers Property reported pre-sold revenue of S$2.7 billion as of Dec 31, 2022, across Singapore, Australia, China, and Thailand. The company sold 77% of Sky Eden@Bedok units and 90% of Riviere units, with 50 units sold in Singapore in Q1. Frasers Property's residential business in Australia remains resilient, and its hospitality portfolio is poised for recovery. The company's net gearing ratio stood at 70.2% and net debt rose 5.4% to S$13.2 billion as of Dec 31.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok, the first residential launch in Bedok Town Centre in 10 years.

site_title: Siemens raises sales and profit outlook after strong start to 2023
summary: Siemens has raised its full-year sales and profit guidance after a strong start to 2023, driven by its factory automation business and a record order backlog of 102 billion euros. The company reported a quarterly profit of 2.7 billion euros, beating forecasts, and expects 7-10% revenue growth and 8.90-9.40 euros basic earnings per share. Siemens' digital industries, including factory automation and smart infrastructure, are expected to drive the growth.

images.alt_text: A sign with the logo of Siemens company is on display outside its office in Moscow, Russia, May 12, 2022. REUTERS/Evgenia Novozhenina

site_title: Singaporeans flock to foreign currency to lock in top interest rates
summary: Singaporeans are flocking to foreign currency investments, particularly US dollar fixed deposits, to take advantage of high interest rates and protect against inflation. Foreign currency deposits rose 13% year-over-year in December, accounting for 55% of total deposits in the country. Banks are offering bumper interest rates of up to 5%, making the US dollar the preferred currency to invest in. Experts expect demand for foreign currency deposits to persist due to the stable Singapore dollar and favorable exchange rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. one hundred dollar notes are seen in this picture illustration taken in Seoul February 7, 2011.   REUTERS/Lee Jae-Won/File Photo

site_title: IMF chief says markets have good reasons to be more upbeat on economy
summary: IMF chief Kristalina Georgieva expressed optimism about financial markets, citing the US economy's likely avoidance of a recession and China's post-pandemic reopening. She noted resilient labor markets, central banks' efforts to curb inflation, and the UAE's fiscal reforms. Georgieva described the IMF's 2023 outlook as "less bad, not good," acknowledging a slowdown in economic growth and ongoing inflation concerns.

images.alt_text: epa10464797 International Monetary Fund (IMF) Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva during the World Government Summit in Gulf emirate of Dubai, United Arab Emirates, 13 February 2023.  EPA-EFE/ALI HAIDER

site_title: Washington weighing deploying medium-range missiles to US forces in Japan: Sankei
summary: The US is considering deploying medium-range missiles, including long-range hypersonic weapons and Tomahawks, to US forces in Japan as part of a plan to bolster defenses against China in the East and South China Seas. Japan is considering the southern island of Kyushu as a possible location. The move aims to reinforce islands near Taiwan, a democratically governed island claimed by China, and form part of the "First Island Chain" that hems in China's forces. The deployment is seen as a response to China's growing military presence in the region.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on September 8, 2017 shows a surface-to-ship missile (SSM-1) - a truck-mounted anti-ship missile system - at the Japan Ground Self-Defense Force (JGSDF) 1st Artillery Brigade at Camp Kita-Eniwa in Eniwa, Hokkaido prefecture. - Japan announced on December 16, 2022 its biggest defence overhaul in decades, hiking spending, reshaping its military command and acquiring new missiles to tackle the threat from China. (Photo by KAZUHIRO NOGI / AFP)

site_title: BNP Paribas plans 5b euros of buybacks after US unit sale
summary: BNP Paribas plans to buy back 5 billion euros of shares after selling its US unit, Bank of the West, to Canada's Bank of Montreal. The bank also raised its profitability targets, with net income growth expected to exceed 9% by 2025 and return on tangible equity reaching around 12%. Revenue from fixed income trading surged 45% in the fourth quarter, beating Wall Street peers. BNP Paribas aims to reduce recurring costs by 2.3 billion euros by 2025 and sees demand for fixed-income products remaining solid in 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BNP Paribas logo is seen at a branch in Paris, France, February 4, 2020. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: Love mismatch at Gaggan Anand’s Singapore outpost Ms. Maria & Mr. Singh
summary: Gaggan Anand's latest restaurant, Ms. Maria & Mr. Singh, in Singapore, offers a unique fusion of Indian and Mexican cuisine. The colorful and lively interior reflects the fictional love story of the restaurant's namesake couple. While the food is a mixed bag, with some dishes like keema quesadillas and churros standing out, others, such as the cold curry ceviche and papdi chaat, fall flat. The restaurant's fixed-price menu is a good option, with highlights like biryani and crab curry. Overall, the restaurant receives a 5.5-star rating.

site_title: Japan says past aerial objects likely Chinese spy balloons
summary: Japan's defense ministry says past aerial objects spotted over the country are likely Chinese spy balloons, following the US shooting down a Chinese surveillance balloon. The objects, including those in 2019, 2020, and 2021, are "strongly presumed" to be unmanned reconnaissance balloons flown by China. Japan is coordinating with Washington and has demanded China confirm the facts. The incident raises concerns about Japan's defense capabilities and has led to discussions about relaxing rules on shooting down aerial objects violating airspace.

site_title: A divide in millennial speak
summary: A writer reflects on the challenges of understanding millennial slang, particularly after being corrected by a younger colleague on the meaning of phrases like "LOL" and "LMAO." Despite efforts to catch up, she realizes the ever-evolving nature of language and the difficulty of keeping pace. Ultimately, she decides to accept her own limitations and "lean into being a millennial-boomer," suggesting that both generations should empathize and not feel pressured to constantly update their language.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: BT, UOB kick off award for those who walk the sustainability talk, Sustainability Impact Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Statista and the Association for Financial Technology (TIA) have announced plans to award Singapore's top fintech companies for 2026. The awards recognize innovation and excellence in the country's growing fintech sector. The awards will be based on a survey of over 1,000 financial decision-makers and industry experts. The winning companies will be selected based on their achievements in areas such as digital payments, lending, and investment platforms. The awards ceremony is expected to take place in 2026, with the exact date and location to be announced later. The winners will be announced in a press release.
